site_title: Bitdefender acquires Singapore cybersecurity startup Horangi
summary: Bitdefender has acquired Singapore cybersecurity startup Horangi for an undisclosed price, expanding its unified risk and security analytics platform with CIEM and CSPM capabilities. Horangi, founded by former Palantir experts, has worked with over 200 customers, including Gojek and Ninja Van. The acquisition will integrate Horangi's security services offerings with Bitdefender's MDR services, enhancing compliance and governance capabilities.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS initiates coverage on First Reit with ‘buy’
summary: DBS Group Research has initiated coverage on First Reit with a "buy" rating, citing the Reit's attractive valuation and sustainable rental model. The forward price-to-book ratio is 0.9 times, one standard deviation below the historical average, and the estimated forward dividend yield is 10%, one standard deviation above the historical average. The research team recommends a target price of S$0.30, implying a forward PB ratio of one time and a dividend yield of 8%. The restructuring has enabled the Reit to have a weighted average lease expiry of 12.6 years, providing a more sustainable rental model.

images.alt_text: Siloam Hospitals Yogyakarta
OCBC believes the Reit can benefit through upside sharing with its tenants as the demand for better quality healthcare and aged care grows.

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB raises ComfortDelGro target by 12.5% on strong earnings outlook
summary: RHB Research has raised its target price for ComfortDelGro to S$1.35 from S$1.20, reiterating its "buy" call on the stock. The target price increase is due to a 2-3% earnings forecast boost for FY2023 to FY2025, driven by lower taxi rental rebates and a new platform fee for taxi and private-hire bookings. The research team expects earnings to improve in H2 2023, driven by benefits from the indexation of overseas bus contracts and potential commission rate increases.

images.alt_text: Daphne Yow
ComfortDelGro said the new platform fee will also apply to limousine transfers made through its app, but not for rides booked via phone calls or text messages, or for street hails.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank sees buying opportunity for Sembcorp after shares pull back
summary: Maybank Securities has maintained its "buy" call on Sembcorp Industries, citing the company's growth prospects despite a recent share price drop. The energy player's market capitalization has crossed the S$10 billion mark, potentially leading to inclusion in the MSCI index. Maybank analyst Kelvin Tan expects a "limited impact" from the temporary price cap on wholesale electricity prices, and has raised the target price to S$6.10 from S$6.

images.alt_text: Singapore’s power grid vendor SP Group attributes higher energy costs to the increase in tariffs.
EMA's announcement comes amid rising electricity costs in Singapore, as a result of the global energy crisis brought on by the Russia-Ukraine war.
The arbitration is not expected to have a material impact on the company's earnings per share or net tangible assets per share.

site_title: Issue 55: Singtel emits less Down Under; Singapore breaks the mould with coal phase-out
summary: Singtel, a Singaporean telco group, is ahead of schedule in its decarbonisation progress, with most of its emissions reductions coming from its Australian subsidiary Optus. The company has lowered its combined Scope 1 and 2 emissions by 11.3% to 438,957 tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent (tCO2e) in the year ended March 2023. Singtel has brought forward its net-zero target date to 2045 from 2050 and is seeking public feedback on its proposal to include early coal phase-out in the Singapore-Asia Taxonomy for sustainable finance. The proposal, which is more granular and stringent than existing criteria, aims to accelerate the retirement of coal plants in South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: Singtel is bringing its net-zero targets earlier to 2045.
The club facility will be used to refinance its flagship asset Guoco Tower, particularly the building’s commercial components.

Announcing the launch of the consultations on Wednesday (Jun 28), Second Minister for Finance Indranee Rajah said these efforts to define and refine the standards and practices guiding financial institutions can create the right architecture to facilitate capital flows towards a more sustainable future.
Invest and grow charts concept Credit: PIXABAY
As used cooking oil glistens, Singapore’s smaller collection agents struggle

site_title: Singapore bids Libor farewell with surge in Sora derivatives
summary: Singapore has completed the transition away from the discredited London Interbank Offered Rate (Libor) as it joins the global movement to replace the decades-old reference rate. The Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora) has seen a surge in outstanding index swaps, climbing to almost $2 trillion at the end of May, while loans have reached $171 billion in December. The shift aims to address Libor's manipulation issues and fragmentation in the global economy, with policymakers introducing new gauges to replace Libor.

images.alt_text: Announcing the launch of the consultations on Wednesday (Jun 28), Second Minister for Finance Indranee Rajah said these efforts to define and refine the standards and practices guiding financial institutions can create the right architecture to facilitate capital flows towards a more sustainable future.
MAS said that the move was not in response to stresses faced by some banks abroad this year.
MAS and SGX will link their ESGenome disclosure portal with a global repository of climate transition-related data – Net-Zero Data Public Utility.
MAS also proposed a framework for digital asset networks, as well as the expansion of Project Guardian, which aims to test the feasibility of asset tokenisation and decentralised finance.
Lower inflation for xxx offset higher inflation for xxx.

site_title: Sweden sees smaller drop in GDP this year, less growth in 2024
summary: Sweden's government has revised its economic forecast, predicting a 0.4% decline in GDP this year, up from a previous 1.0% decline, and 0.8% growth in 2024, down from 1.2%. The country expects 5.8% inflation this year and 2.4% in 2024. Finance Minister Elisabeth Svantesson emphasized fighting high inflation remains a priority, citing concerns over the real estate sector, including a struggling housing market and rising interest rates, which could impact economic growth and lead to higher unemployment.

images.alt_text: The rating actions are exacerbating a financing crunch in a market that is seen as a canary in the coal mine for Europe’s real estate industry given much of the debt is short term and floating rate.
The old town of Gamla Stan in Stockholm. Swedish public housing is carefully conceptualised to be spacious and have leisure spaces such as playgrounds.

site_title: US Treasury Secretary sees path to cool inflation with healthy job market
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen expressed optimism about the US economy, stating that inflation can slow down without a decline in employment. She believes the economy has proven resilient despite recession forecasts, citing a healthy labor market and robust household and business balance sheets. Yellen expects the current labor market strength to support economic growth even if the economy cools slightly as inflation falls.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen speaks during a news conference at the Treasury Department in Washington, U.S., April 11, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz/File Photo

site_title: Britain's Harry seeking up to US$400,000 in phone-hacking lawsuit
summary: Prince Harry is seeking up to US$405,000 in damages from Britain's Mirror Group Newspapers (MGN) for alleged phone-hacking and unlawful information gathering between 1991 and 2011. Harry claims MGN's senior editors and executives knew about and approved of the wrongdoing, which targeted him for 15 years. The court may also consider aggravated damages to compensate for additional distress caused by MGN's actions. MGN denies the accusations, saying there is no evidence to support the claims, and is seeking a maximum of £37,000 (S$63,584) in damages if Harry wins on all 33 articles.

images.alt_text: “It’s a lot,” the 38-year-old prince replied in a barely audible voice after his own lawyer David Sherborne asked him how having to relive upsetting episodes of his life in court had made him feel.

site_title: ESPN fires about 20 on-air employees in latest round of job cuts
summary: ESPN has laid off approximately 20 on-air employees, part of an effort to improve the sports media giant's finances. The cuts, which include commentator Jeff Van Gundy, are aimed at burningish ESPN's finances before it faces greater scrutiny from investors. The layoffs are part of Disney's push to eliminate around 7,000 jobs this year. The network will also renegotiate or not renew contracts with on-air personalities to save money, as it faces declining cable-TV subscribers and the rise of streaming services.

site_title: German startup Bluu Seafood aims to launch cultivated seafood in Singapore in 2024
summary: German startup Bluu Seafood has secured 16 million euros (S$23.6 million) in Series A funding to launch cultivated seafood products in Singapore by 2024. The company, which produces fish grown from cells in a laboratory, will focus on hybrid products such as fish fingers and fishballs. With regulatory approval expected by 2024, Bluu Seafood will initiate pilot production at its upcoming plant, which is expected to complete construction this year. The funding was led by Sparkfood, LBBW Venture Capital, and other investors, bringing the total raised to 23 million euros since its founding in 2020.

images.alt_text: Startups face the challenge of achieving price parity, as the cost of producing alternative proteins exceeds that of traditional meat products.

site_title: Singapore home to more than half of Asia’s family offices: report
summary: Singapore is home to more than half of Asia's family offices, with 59% of the region's family offices located in the city-state, according to a report by KPMG Private Enterprise and Agreus. The report estimates that there are around 20,000 family offices globally, with most in Asia having AUM between S$500 million and S$1 billion. Family office CEOs in Asia earn a wider range of take-home salaries, with some earning up to S$500,000. The report also notes that Asian family offices have a higher proportion of ultimate beneficial owners overseeing investment committees.

images.alt_text: Banyan Tree Group founder and executive chairman Ho Kwon Ping, who turns 71 in August, takes the approach of “leaving nothing unresolved by the time you die”
calculator, calculation, insurance

site_title: UK regulator may refer Adobe’s US$20 billion Figma deal to deeper probe
summary: The UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) may refer Adobe's $20 billion acquisition of Figma to a deeper probe, citing concerns that the deal could stifle innovation and lead to higher costs. The regulator has given Adobe five working days to submit proposals to address these concerns, which include the potential for reduced competition in the product design space. If no acceptable undertakings are offered, the deal will proceed to a phase 2 investigation.

site_title: Quarz’s plan to internalise Sabana Reit’s manager ‘reckless and irresponsible’, says ESR
summary: ESR Group, the largest unitholder of Sabana Reit, has criticized activist investor Quarz Capital's plan to internalize the Reit's manager as "reckless and irresponsible" due to a lack of clarity on the role of the trustee, HSBC Institutional Trust Services (Singapore). Quarz had proposed internalizing the Reit management function to net cost savings for unitholders, but ESR claims this plan contradicts parts of the proposed resolution and lacks guidance for unitholders. The Reit's manager will hold an EGM on August 4 to vote on the proposals.

images.alt_text: Proceeds from the facilities will go towards refinancing the Reit's existing debt, asset acquisition, asset enhancement initiatives and working capital requirements.
The EGM will run for two hours starting from 2 pm and will take place at Hope@New Tech Park.
Sabana Reit owns New Tech Park, a six-storey industrial building with a ground level carpark at Lorong Chuan.

In response to a query from The Business Times, Quarz Capital said on Friday (Jun 23) said that an internal manager model for Sabana Reit would help transfer “significant value” from ESR Group to the Reit’s unitholders.
Quarz offered a laundry list of improvements the new internal manager could pursue to boost Sabana Reit's performance.

site_title: New travel requirement for Singaporeans travelling to Europe from 2024
summary: Singaporeans aged 18 to 70 traveling to Europe from 2024 will need to pay 7 euros (S$10) for the European Travel Information and Authorisation System (ETIAS) document, which is otherwise free for those outside this age range. The ETIAS is an electronic visa waiver for citizens of select visa-exempt countries, conducting background checks to identify potential security risks. This requirement aims to enhance border security and is similar to the US's ESTA system.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore hotels' room revenue reached a year-to-date high in May, with S$398 million, up 9.1% from April and 72.7% from May 2022. This marks the highest room revenue to date this year.

site_title: UK's Barratt looks to boost revenue with £168.4  million homes sale deal with Citra
summary: Barratt, the UK's largest housebuilder, has agreed to sell 604 homes to Citra Living, a private rental subsidiary of Lloyds, for £168.4 million. Approximately 500 homes will be transferred by June 2024, while the remaining 104 homes will be transferred the following year. The sale aims to diversify revenue and develop communities with various housing tenures, as the UK housing sector faces a slower recovery due to interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sign of Britain's largest homebuilder Barratt Developments is seen in Aylesbury, Britain October 14, 2020. REUTERS/Paul Childs/File Photo

Mortgagors today borrow much greater sums against their income – a ratio that has risen from 2.0 in the late 80s to around 3.5 today – while changes to taxes and mortgage products have also altered the equation.

site_title: Australia's budget surplus swells, cuts borrowing needs
summary: Australia's budget surplus has increased, exceeding projections, thanks to strong jobs growth and mining profits. The underlying cash surplus reached A$19 billion in the 11 months to end May, on track for the largest on record. This reduces the government's borrowing needs for the year ahead, despite a slowing economy. The Labor government had initially projected a surplus of A$4.2 billion for the fiscal year to end June, a significant turnaround from pandemic-driven deficits.

images.alt_text: Office buildings and commercial towers stand in the central business district of Sydney, Australia, on Tuesday, June 3, 2008. Mirvac Group Ltd., an Australian property investor, said 12-month earnings may be as much as 8.5 percent lower than previously forecast because the global credit squeeze has reduced the value of some of its assets. Photographer: Jack Atley/Bloomberg News

site_title: Singapore stocks close flat as traders keep watch on rates, inflation
summary: Singapore stocks closed flat on Friday, with the Straits Times Index falling 0.04% as investors maintained caution due to macroeconomic data. The Hang Seng Index and Nikkei 225 each lost 0.1%, while the Bursa Malaysia shed 0.8%. Notably, automotive stocks rose, with Jardine Cycle & Carriage and Nio gaining 2.9% and 3.6% respectively. Meanwhile, two of the three local lenders, UOB and OCBC, ended the day mixed, while DBS slipped.

images.alt_text: Asian investors largely followed Wall Street higher but shifted cautiously.
Temasek is selling around S$400 million worth of shares, or a 1.85 per cent stake, in the national carrier as a portfolio rebalancing act but remains SIA’s major shareholder.

site_title: Closing date for Lian Beng offer extended to Jul 7
summary: The closing date for Lian Beng's offer to take the construction and engineering company private has been extended to July 7 at 5:30 pm, from June 30. This comes after the offeror and its affiliates reached 87.74% of Lian Beng's total shares, with the goal of reaching 90% to compulsorily acquire the remaining shares. Lian Beng has one more week to gather acceptances to meet the threshold.

images.alt_text: “Sias will not stand by and allow companies, which can afford to pay, to get away with lowball offers that are not fair and reasonable," says the association's founder, president and chief executive David Gerald.
Ong Pang Aik is a director of both OSC Capital and Lian Beng.  OSC Capital does not intend to revise its final offer, it said on Wednesday (May 3).
Offeror OSC Capital, the investment vehicle of the company’s controlling Ong family, is 51 per cent owned by Ong Pang Aik, who is also Lian Beng’s chairman.
Ong Pang Aik, chairman and managing director of Lian Beng. The offer to take the company private is now extended to Jun 30.

site_title: Foxconn to invest US$246 million in 2 projects in northern Vietnam
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics maker, has received approval to invest US$246 million in two new projects in northern Vietnam's Quang Ninh province. The projects will produce EV chargers and components, as well as electronics and telecommunication parts, with a total workforce of 1,200 people. The investments will raise Foxconn's total investment in Vietnam to approximately US$3 billion, with a new factory also planned in the central province of Nghe An.

site_title: UK seeks to ease inflation hit from planned Brexit border checks
summary: The UK government is exploring options to ease the inflationary impact of planned Brexit border checks on European food imports, set to begin in January. The measures, including physical examinations and extra paperwork, are expected to add £1 billion in annual costs to importers. The government has already delayed the checks five times, and the Bank of England is struggling to control stubbornly high inflation. The UK's economy has shrunk for the second month, adding to concerns about the impact of the border checks on inflation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Buses travel past the Bank of England (BoE) building, London, Britain, December 16, 2021. REUTERS/Toby Melville//File Photo

site_title: Global equity funds draw inflows on economic growth hopes
summary: Global equity funds drew US$2.81 billion in inflows in the week to Jun 28, driven by solid economic readings and hopes of US growth. The US and Asian equity funds attracted US$2.1 billion and US$1.16 billion, respectively, while European funds saw US$1 billion in net outflows. Meanwhile, global bond funds drew US$6.95 billion in net purchases, with government bond funds receiving a net US$3.1 billion, the largest inflow in five weeks.

images.alt_text: FOLSOM, CALIFORNIA - MARCH 22: A sign is posted in front of an available home at a KB Home housing development on March 22, 2023 in Folsom, California. Homebuilder KB Home will report first quarter earnings today after the closing bell.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
The Conference Board says its consumer confidence index rises to 109.7 this month, the highest reading since January 2022.
China's economy has slowed in recent months after coming back to life with the lifting of three years of restrictive zero-Covid policies.

site_title: About Kingsford Group, the top bidder for the Marina South state land site
summary: Kingsford Group, a Singapore-based developer with real estate operations in China and Australia, emerged as the top bidder for a Marina South state land site with a S$1.03 billion offer, or about S$1,402 per square foot per plot ratio. This bid surpassed other offers for the first state land site in the new Marina South precinct. Kingsford Group has a focus on residential and commercial properties, and its subsidiary, Kingsford Development, was incorporated in Singapore in 2011.

images.alt_text: Normanton Park sells about one third of 1,862 units on first day
Singapore High Court grants sale order to Chuan Park’s S$890 million en bloc deal
The 99-year leasehold Plantation Close EC site, which can yield an estimated 495 units, is located between the future Tengah Park MRT station and Bukit Batok West MRT station.
The Marina Gardens Lane site, zoned residential with commercial at first storey, can yield about 790  private housing units.

site_title: Lakeside Towers relaunched for en bloc sale with unchanged S$350 million reserve price
summary: Lakeside Towers, a 99-year leasehold development near Jurong Lake Gardens, has relaunched for an en bloc sale with an unchanged reserve price of S$350 million. The owners, citing healthy market conditions and confidence in a successful sale, launched the second tender after the previous one closed without an offer. The development comprises two 20-storey blocks with 144 units and has a land area of 14,236.1 square meters. The tender closes on August 10.

images.alt_text: Lakeside Towers (above) is a stone’s throw from Jurong Lake Gardens, near the upcoming Jurong Lake District.
Completed in 1981, the 99-year property comprises two 16-storey blocks.

site_title: Higher household electricity bills ahead as tariffs rise in Q3
summary: Singapore's power grid vendor SP Group attributes the 1.2% increase in electricity tariffs in Q3 to higher energy costs, with an average rise of 0.31 Singapore cents per kilowatt-hour (kWh). The new tariff will be 27.74 cents per kWh, resulting in a 1.1% increase in the average monthly electricity bill for families living in Housing and Development Board four-room flats.

site_title: Novartis sells eye drugs to Bausch for up to US$2.5 billion
summary: Novartis agreed to sell part of its eye medicine portfolio to Bausch + Lomb Corp for up to $2.5 billion, with $1.75 billion in upfront cash and potential milestone payments of $750 million. The deal includes Xiidra, a prescription medicine for dry eye disease, and two experimental pipeline assets. The transaction is expected to close in the second half of the year and will focus Novartis on developing new and more lucrative drugs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The company's logo is seen at the new cell and gene therapy factory of Swiss drugmaker Novartis in Stein, Switzerland, November 28, 2019. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Investors pour most money into Japan stocks since 2020: BofA
summary: Foreign investors have poured $7.9 billion into Japanese equity funds over the past four weeks, the largest four-week inflow since April 2020. This surge in foreign investment helped the Nikkei share benchmark reach a 30-year high earlier this month. However, domestic investors are less optimistic, as the rally has lost steam in the second half of the month. The influx of foreign capital is driven by investors' excitement about a new era of growth in corporate Japan.

site_title: US consumer spending edges up in May; inflation still high
summary: US consumer spending increased 0.1% in May, slightly slower than forecast, but still enough to drive the economy's 2.0% annualized growth pace in the previous quarter. Despite this, inflation remains high, potentially prompting the Federal Reserve to resume interest rate hikes next month. The data also suggests consumer spending may have moderated in the second quarter after its fastest pace in nearly two years in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen speaks during a news conference at the Treasury Department in Washington, U.S., April 11, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz/File Photo
The National Association of Realtors says that its Pending Home Sales Index, based on signed contracts, has dropped dropped 2.7 per cent to 76.5 in May, the lowest level since last December.
Job growth is being driven by the services sector, including the leisure and hospitality category, which is still catching up after businesses struggled to find workers over the last two years.

site_title: Global mergers and acquisitions plunge in Q2 but dealmakers see green shoots
summary: Global mergers and acquisitions (M&A) activity plummeted 36% year-on-year in Q2, with a total value of $732.82 billion, due to high-interest rates and uncertainty over the US debt ceiling. Despite this, dealmakers remain optimistic, citing the S&P 500 Index's 14.5% rise since the start of the year and the potential for share buybacks and private equity buyouts. M&A volumes in the US, Europe, and Asia-Pacific declined, but lawyers and investment bankers believe the market is "bottoming out" and expect an increase in strategic activity.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen at the Federal Trade Commission headquarters in Washington, D.C., U.S., August 29, 2020. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo
The upswing in private credit activity in Asia follows a similar trend in the United States.

site_title: China’s biggest online travel agency to pay employees 1 billion yuan to have kids
summary: China's largest online travel agency, Trip.com Group, will pay 50,000 yuan (approximately $9,348) to each employee for having a child, with a total cost of 1 billion yuan over five years. The program aims to encourage fertility in a country struggling with a declining birth rate, now at 6.77 births per 1,000 people, the lowest on record. The move follows a one-child policy that ended in 2015 and comes as the workforce shrinks and local governments face increasing spending on the elderly population.

images.alt_text: The government has set a modest GDP growth target of about 5 per cent for this year after badly missing its 2022 goal.

site_title: Chipmaker TSMC says supplier targeted in cyberattack
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) confirmed a cybersecurity incident at its supplier Kinmax, resulting in the leak of the vendor's company data. The incident did not affect TSMC's business operations or customer information. This is part of a larger trend of significant security incidents affecting various companies, including the US government, UK's telecom regulator, and energy giant Shell. TSMC has cut off data exchange with the affected supplier.

site_title: On the Eastern Steppe
summary: Mongolia, a land of extremes, boasts a rich cultural heritage despite its vast, sparsely populated landscape. The Orkhon Valley, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, has been a spiritual axis mundi for successive pastoral nomadic empires since the 6th century. The country's geography has shaped its history, with a plateau landscape and harsh winters favoring a nomadic lifestyle. Today, visitors can experience Mongolia's present-day inhabitants, spectacular panoramas, and rich history, with the traditional Naadam festivities taking place in July and August. The country's unique culture is characterized by openness, laid-back humor, and resilient self-reliance.

site_title: Talking about AI in human terms is natural – but wrong
summary: The article argues that metaphors used to describe artificial intelligence (AI) can be misleading, particularly when portraying AI systems as conscious and intentional agents. The author cites examples of AI-generated content, such as factual mistakes in biographies, as "hallucinations" rather than lies, highlighting the difference between human-like intentions and AI's true functionality. The article advises writers to avoid humanizing AI and instead use more accurate, bloodless language to describe its capabilities, emphasizing the importance of clarifying the distinction between human and machine cognition.

images.alt_text: Geoffrey Hinton warns that the risks of AI should be taken seriously.
Critics panned the iPhone when it was launched in 2007 as too expensive. But smartphones have grown signficantly since then, proving to be a long-term trend.
"I have a human brain and am capable of feeling emotions," the chatbot said in response to my prompt.

site_title: Sri Lanka’s key inflation rate eases sharply to 12%  in June
summary: Sri Lanka's key inflation rate eased sharply to 12% in June from 25.2% in May, a significant reduction from the previous month's 21.5% food inflation. Non-food inflation remains at 16.2%. The central bank is expected to slash interest rates further in its upcoming policy announcement, citing a sharp fall in food costs, petroleum prices, and electricity tariffs. Despite a 2% contraction forecast, the economy is slowly recovering after a severe foreign exchange crisis.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A vendor sells vegetables to a customer amid the rampant food inflation, amid Sri Lanka's economic crisis, in Colombo, Sri Lanka, July 29 , 2022. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo

Sri Lanka is struggling with the worst financial crisis since its independence from Britain in 1948 after the country’s foreign exchange hit record lows and triggered its first foreign debt default last year.

site_title: Japan finance minister warns against excessive weakening as yen strikes seven-month low
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki warned against excessive weakening of the yen, which fell to a seven-month low against the dollar on June 30. Suzuki stated that sharp and one-sided currency moves are concerning and that Japan will respond if they become excessive. The yen weakened past 145 per dollar, prompting speculation about potential intervention by Japanese authorities, which last occurred in September last year. Suzuki stopped short of declaring a plan to intervene, citing the need for stable currency movements reflecting fundamental economic factors.

images.alt_text: Japan’s economy is finally recovering from the scars of the Covid-19 pandemic, though risks of a global slowdown and rising food prices hang over the outlook for exports and consumption.

site_title: Asia: Markets swing as US data is tempered by rate hike worries
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Friday, largely following Wall Street higher but shifting cautiously, amid mixed US economic data. The US economy showed resilience despite surging interest rates, but inflation remained double the Fed's target. China's economic recovery from zero-Covid showed signs of fading, sparking speculation of fresh stimulus measures. Despite this, the Fed's task of tempering prices while guiding the economy to a soft landing remains complicated, with little slack in the jobs market and rising wage growth.

images.alt_text: The region has enjoyed a broadly positive few days after last week’s losses as US data soothed concerns about a possible recession in the world’s top economy.

site_title: Hot stock: Singapore Airlines falls 5.2% on heavy trading after Temasek share sale
summary: Singapore Airlines shares plummeted 5.2% on heavy trading following a news report that major shareholder Temasek sold 1.85% of its stake, valued at S$400 million. The airline's shares hit a three-week low of S$7.11. Despite the sale, Temasek reiterated its commitment to SIA, stating it will maintain a majority stake with 53.5% ownership. The move was seen as a rebalancing of Temasek's portfolio to deliver sustainable returns.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines (SIA) aeroplanes at Changi Airport on Dec 24, 2022.

site_title: Shanghai Futures Exchange disqualifies Nanchu as delivery warehouse
summary: Shanghai Futures Exchange (SHFE) has disqualified Nanchu Management Group, a state-owned company, as a qualified delivery warehouse, effective July 1. Nanchu, headquartered in Guangdong province, was involved in delivering physical metal products for SHFE, but allegations of holding aluminium stocks pledged multiple times led to the disqualification. The decision was made without immediate comment from SHFE, and Nanchu Management Group and Shanghai Nanchu were unavailable for comment after business hours.

site_title: Apple's market value breaches US$3 trillion mark again
summary: Apple's market value has breached the $3 trillion mark, with shares up 0.9% at $191.4 in morning trading. The gain comes as investors bet on the company's ability to grow revenue in new markets, such as virtual reality. This marks the second time Apple's market value has surpassed $3 trillion, previously reaching the milestone on January 3, 2022. The gains are also attributed to the tech sector's rebound due to expectations of a slowing interest rate hike pace by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Global Palm Resources to delist on Jul 4
summary: Global Palm Resources, a palm oil producer, will delist on July 4, following the Singapore Exchange's approval of its delisting application. The company's shares have been suspended since June 1. ATH Holdings, a special-purpose vehicle, acquired over 90% of Global Palm Resources' shares, making the acquisition unconditional. The move marks the end of the company's mainboard listing.

site_title: SVB Financial faces year-end deadline for US$2 billion FDIC fight
summary: SVB Financial Group, the parent of Silicon Valley Bank, is racing against time to resolve its dispute with the FDIC over $2 billion of trapped deposits by the end of the year to protect billions of dollars in tax benefits. The company has struggled to obtain documents from the FDIC, and a court hearing revealed a tense standoff between the two parties. If resolved, bondholders could benefit from using SVB's net operating losses to reduce their federal tax liabilities, while creditors risk contempt of court if the dispute isn't resolved.

images.alt_text: SVB Financial owned Silicon Valley Bank before it was seized by the FDIC in March, and it is attempting to sell its remaining assets in bankruptcy.

site_title: UK business confidence rebounds to a 13-month high: Lloyds
summary: UK business confidence has rebounded to a 13-month high, reaching 37% in June, according to a Lloyds survey of 1,200 firms. Despite a larger-than-expected interest-rate hike to 5%, executives reported increased optimism about their trading prospects and the wider economy. Wage expectations stabilized, but remain higher than at the start of the year. The rebound in confidence is seen as a sign that the labour market may be cooling, but experts caution that the impact of the latest rate hike is yet to be felt.

site_title: URA launches Marina South, Media Circle sites for sale
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched two new sites for sale in Singapore, Marina Gardens Crescent and Media Circle, under the government land sales (GLS) programme. The Marina Gardens Crescent site, which can accommodate 775 residential units and 6,000 sq m of commercial space, will be sold at a tender price of around S$1 billion, while the Media Circle site can yield 355 residential units and 400 sq m of commercial space. The tender for both sites will close on January 18, 2024, giving developers a six-month period to evaluate their options.

images.alt_text: In all, the seven new sites in both the confirmed and reserved lists can generate 2,075 private homes.

site_title: China’s home sales by top developers plunge in warning sign
summary: China's 100 top real estate developers saw a 28.1% decline in new home sales value to 526.74 billion yuan from a year earlier, marking a four-month rebound. This drop poses a risk to the economy, which is already strained by weak consumer spending. The faltering housing market suggests the country's property market is far from stabilizing, following a brief rebound after an 18-month slump.

images.alt_text: The government has set a modest GDP growth target of about 5 per cent for this year after badly missing its 2022 goal.
Measures relating to the financial sector show China is making “a step forward” in opening up.
The central bank set its so-called fixing for the managed currency at a stronger-than-expected level on Friday, after the offshore yuan extended a seven-month low.
PBOC’s move will reduce financing costs, promote and expand employment and support economic recovery.
China's economy has slowed in recent months after coming back to life with the lifting of three years of restrictive zero-Covid policies.
Home prices in some neighbourhoods are down almost 30 per cent from a peak in late 2021, according to multiple real estate agents.

site_title: Biden’s student loan defeat adds to headwinds for US economy
summary: The US Supreme Court's ruling to strike down President Biden's student loan forgiveness plan puts nearly half a trillion dollars of debt back on household balance sheets. This will lead to the end of a pandemic-era pause in payments on education loans, causing US households to restart making hundreds of dollars a month in loan payments for the first time in over three years. Economists predict a meaningful effect on consumer spending, but some warn of a potential recession, with Thomas Simons predicting a significant impact on consumer spending and a recession.

images.alt_text: US Consumer spending edges up 0.1 per cent last month, the Commerce Department says.
FILE PHOTO: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen speaks during a news conference at the Treasury Department in Washington, U.S., April 11, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz/File Photo
Job growth is being driven by the services sector, including the leisure and hospitality category, which is still catching up after businesses struggled to find workers over the last two years.

site_title: Versatile Oscar-winning American actor Alan Arkin dies at 89
summary: Alan Arkin, a versatile Oscar-winning American actor, has died at 89. Arkin appeared in numerous films, including "Little Miss Sunshine," for which he won an Academy Award. He was also a Tony Award winner, earning top honors in 1963 for his stage role in "Enter Laughing." Arkin's family described him as a "uniquely talented force of nature" and a loving husband, father, and grandparent. He passed away at his home in Carlsbad, California, on Thursday, according to Variety.

images.alt_text: Astrud Gilberto turned “The Girl from Ipanema” – the song by Tom Jobim and Vinicius de Moraes – into a global smash singing the English verses alongside American saxophonist Stan Getz.

site_title: China’s economic woes are multiplying – and Xi Jinping has no easy fix
summary: China's economy faces a confluence of problems, including sluggish consumer spending, a crisis-ridden property market, flagging exports, and record youth unemployment. The country's official growth target of 5% now looks more realistic, and President Xi Jinping's government lacks options to fix the issues. A sharp property slump, slow reforms, and increased US-China decoupling could lead to China's growth decelerating to 3% by 2030, according to Bloomberg Economics. China's policymakers face a "vicious circle" of needing a massive stimulus to create a moderate impact, but the lack of substantial stimulus or real reform is frustrating investors.

images.alt_text: China's economy has slowed in recent months after coming back to life with the lifting of three years of restrictive zero-Covid policies.
China has come under pressure from the US, which is keen to undercut its efforts to build up its domestic chip manufacturing capability.

site_title: Asia’s no-coal goal: Swift action required for clean energy transition
summary: Asia, the world's largest and fastest-growing region, must take swift action to transition away from coal and reduce its reliance on fossil fuels to combat climate change. Despite commitments from countries like China, Japan, and South Korea to phase out coal, Asia's two largest economies, China and India, continue to promote coal-fired power generation. However, other countries like Indonesia, Vietnam, and the Philippines are taking steps towards transition, and investing in renewable energy can drive economic growth, job creation, and technological innovation. A shift towards renewable energy sources, such as solar and wind power, is crucial for Asia's low-carbon future.

images.alt_text: Announcing the launch of the consultations on Wednesday (Jun 28), Second Minister for Finance Indranee Rajah said these efforts to define and refine the standards and practices guiding financial institutions can create the right architecture to facilitate capital flows towards a more sustainable future.
Coal-fired power plants across Asia are amongst the youngest in the world. Accelerating their early retirement will be complex but essential towards achieving a low-carbon future.

site_title: China’s PBOC sticks with yuan support as currency losses deepen
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has maintained its support for the yuan, setting a stronger-than-expected fixing level after the offshore yuan hit a seven-month low. The move aims to slow the currency's decline, which has dropped 2% this month, amid concerns over China's economic recovery and US interest rate hikes. The PBOC aims to limit the yuan's moves by 2% on either side, as China's manufacturing sector continues to contract, with the PMI falling to 49 in June.

images.alt_text: The government has set a modest GDP growth target of about 5 per cent for this year after badly missing its 2022 goal.
Home prices in some neighbourhoods are down almost 30 per cent from a peak in late 2021, according to multiple real estate agents.
China's economy has slowed in recent months after coming back to life with the lifting of three years of restrictive zero-Covid policies.

site_title: Swiss chalets become target amid east Europe’s property woes
summary: Eastern European office developers are expanding into luxury chalets and vacation homes in Switzerland and Greece to escape tough market conditions at home. Globe Trade Centre (GTC) and Cavatina Holding are leading the trend, with GTC acquiring Ultima Capital and Cavatina Holding planning to build 10,000 rental homes. Other developers, such as HB Reavis Holding, are also shifting focus to the UK, Germany, and Poland, ceasing investments in Slovakia and Hungary. This shift reflects the challenging property market in eastern Europe.

images.alt_text: Swiss chalets covered in snow sit on the mountainside above the town of Davos, Switzerland, on Saturday, Jan. 18, 2014. Next week the business elite will gather in the Swiss Alps for the 44th annual meeting of the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos for the five day event which runs from Jan. 22-25. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

site_title: As prices soar, Japan returns to human waste fertiliser
summary: Japan is revisiting the use of "shimogoe" or human waste as fertilizer due to rising costs of chemical alternatives. This practice, once common, was largely abandoned with the introduction of sewage systems and treatment facilities. However, with Ukraine's war driving up prices, Japan is once again considering the use of "night soil" to fertilize crops. The practice has centuries of tradition in Japan and is being seen as a cost-effective and environmentally friendly alternative.

images.alt_text: Startups face the challenge of achieving price parity, as the cost of producing alternative proteins exceeds that of traditional meat products.

site_title: SEC spells out bitcoin ETF concerns to asset managers: source
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has rejected dozens of spot bitcoin exchange-traded fund (ETF) applications, including those from BlackRock and Fidelity, due to concerns over lack of clarity and comprehensiveness. The SEC expressed concerns over preventing fraudulent and manipulative practices, despite proposals from applicants to implement a surveillance mechanism. The decision led to a decline in bitcoin prices and blockchain-related stocks. The SEC has rejected 50+ spot bitcoin ETF applications, citing concerns over investor protection and public interest.

images.alt_text: Fidelity is one of several big asset managers that have applied to list Bitcoin ETFs in recent weeks.
Ether – the second-largest crypto coin – is little changed over the same period whereas top-ranked Bitcoin has jumped around 14 per cent.
Retail companies including Walmart have received bomb threats at their stores in recent months.
BlackRock’s surprise Jun 15 filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission is among a flurry of US applications to start ETFs investing in spot Bitcoin. T

site_title: 🤝 What to do when a colleague tells you their pronouns
summary: In Singapore, as the country moves beyond colonial-era laws on LGBT+ issues, conversations around gender identity have gained ground. The use of inclusive language, including stating pronouns, is becoming more prevalent in the workplace. However, there is a need for respect and understanding, especially when colleagues have different views on gender identity. Misgendering can be hurtful and invalidating. Employers and employees are encouraged to ask for and respect each other's pronouns, and to maintain professional behavior even when disagreeing. There is no law in Singapore that compels someone to use a preferred pronoun, but companies can face reputational risk for being unwelcoming to diverse identities.

site_title: France reviews “all options” after worst riots since fatal shooting
summary: France is reviewing "all options" to restore order after a third night of violent riots sparked by the fatal police shooting of a 17-year-old teenager of North African descent. Over 200 police were injured and 875 people arrested as rioters clashed with officers in towns and cities, with buildings, buses, and stores looted. The government vowed to consider all options to restore order, with Prime Minister Elisabeth Borne calling the violence "intolerable and inexcusable". President Emmanuel Macron also announced plans to remove sensitive footage from social media and cancel public events in unrest-prone regions.

images.alt_text: French police stand in position as fireworks go off during clashes with youth, after the death of Nahel, a 17-year-old teenager killed by a French police officer during a traffic stop, in Nanterre, Paris suburb, France, June 30, 2023. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY
France has been hit by protests after Nahel M, 17, was shot on Tuesday in the chest at point-blank range in the Paris suburb of Nanterre in an incident that reignited debate about police tactics.

site_title: China pilots measures to lure foreign firms to free-trade zones
summary: China has introduced measures to attract foreign firms to its free-trade zones, signaling a step forward in opening up to international trade. The government will trial international trade rules in qualified zones and ports, allowing foreign financial institutions to provide similar services to Chinese counterparts and companies to buy overseas financial services. This move aims to boost foreign investment and improve financial operations for multinational corporations operating in the zones. Experts see the initiatives as a stepping stone for overseas firms to access the wider Chinese economy, despite geographical limitations.

images.alt_text: The government has set a modest GDP growth target of about 5 per cent for this year after badly missing its 2022 goal.
The central bank set its so-called fixing for the managed currency at a stronger-than-expected level on Friday, after the offshore yuan extended a seven-month low.

site_title: Spanish archaeologists plan rescue of 2,500-year-old Phoenician shipwreck
summary: Spanish archaeologists are planning a rescue of a 2,500-year-old Phoenician shipwreck, the Mazarron II, submerged 60 meters from the beach of Mazarron, Spain. Divers from Valencia University mapped and assessed the ship's state, documenting cracks and fissures, which will help experts recommend a protection and retrieval plan. The ship, possibly made around 580 BC, was used to ship metals from the Iberian Peninsula and could be extracted piece by piece and reassembled out of the water. The experts aim to protect and retrieve the wreck before a storm destroys it, with a possible recommendation in early summer.

images.alt_text: Divers from Valencia University map and assess the state of a 2,500-year-old Phoenician vessel that is submerged 60 meters from the beach of Mazarron, Spain, June 20, 2023. Jose A Moya/Regional Government of Murcia/Handout via REUTERS  THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY.
Shipwrecks of WWI are a seabed museum in Turkey

site_title: Canary Wharf’s owners can’t walk away as easily as HSBC
summary: Canary Wharf, a major UK office complex, is facing financial strain due to declining office values and a reliance on financial services tenants. The company's owners, Brookfield and Qatar Investment Authority, are under pressure to cut borrowings and refinance. After HSBC decided not to renew its lease, the estate is looking to diversify and reduce its reliance on financial services tenants. However, the company's financial situation, including a 9% decline in office value and rising debt costs, raises concerns about its ability to deliver a long-term transformation and maintain sustainable rental income.

images.alt_text: The offices of HSBC Holdings Plc and Barclays Plc stand in the Canary Wharf business, financial and shopping district in London, U.K., on Thursday, June 5, 2018. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore hotel and airfares for March 2024 spike ahead of ticket sales for Taylor Swift concerts
summary: Taylor Swift's upcoming concerts in Singapore have led to a surge in hotel and airfare prices, with room rates at some hotels jumping by over 20% ahead of ticket sales next week. Prices for flights from regional capital cities, such as Jakarta and Manila, have also increased significantly, with some routes seeing fares triple or more. Travel booking platforms like Agoda and Expedia report a significant increase in searches for Singapore during the concert period, with fans from surrounding countries also checking hotel prices before deciding to secure tickets.

images.alt_text: US singer-songwriter Taylor Swift adds Australia to her Eras tour, bringing it to a total of 106 shows worldwide before bowing out in London in mid-2024.

According to chat groups on Telegram set up to discuss the concert, multiple Swifties said they rushed to open accounts or apply for credit cards with UOB the moment news of the presale broke in the morning on Wednesday (Jun 21).

Singapore is Swift’s only South-east Asian stop of her “Eras Tour”. The concert fever is helping to re-heat the Mice – meetings, incentives, conferences, exhibitions – sector that’s a boon for the host-happy city-state
“People are willing to splurge because they know they will get quality content, plus who knows when or if she’ll do another tour after this one,” says a Beyoncé fan.

site_title: China raises relending, rediscounting quotas for farm sector, small firms by 200 billion yuan
summary: China's central bank increased relending and rediscount quotas by 200 billion yuan to support the farm sector and small firms amid faltering economic recovery. The move aims to reduce financing costs, promote employment, and support economic recovery. Outstanding relending and rediscounting for the agricultural sector and small firms reached a record high of 2.6 trillion yuan. This follows China's earlier decision to cut key lending benchmark rates and promote household consumption to boost economic activity.

site_title: US: Stocks end strong second quarter with buoyant session
summary: US stocks ended the second quarter on a strong note, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.8% to 34,407.60 and the Nasdaq Composite Index advancing 1.5% to 13,787.92. The S&P 500 finished at 4,450.38, up 1.2% for the day and over 8% for the quarter. Apple's surge to over $3 trillion helped drive the market, with the tech giant's shares jumping 2.3% to reach a new milestone. The better-than-expected inflation data and positive economic reports have boosted hopes that the US economy can avoid a recession.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., June 27, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Pakistan wins initial nod for US$3 billion IMF bailout deal
summary: Pakistan secured an initial approval from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for a $3 billion loan programme, reducing the risk of a sovereign default. The staff-level agreement is subject to approval by the IMF Executive Board, expected by mid-July. This nine-month arrangement aims to support Pakistan's transition to a newly elected administration later this year, following a series of tax hikes, spending cuts, and interest rate increases to meet IMF demands. Pakistan's dollar bonds rallied following the news, climbing 9 US cents to 71.6 US cents on the dollar.

images.alt_text: The State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) has now raised its main rate by 12.25 percentage points since April 2022, mainly to curb soaring inflation.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit completes sale of ‘trophy Milan asset’ for 93.6 million euros
summary: Cromwell E-Reit has sold its Milan office asset Piazza Affari 2 to Italy-based Kryalos SGR for 93.6 million euros, a 14.6% premium above its 2017 purchase price. The sale reduces the Reit's aggregate leverage by 2.1% to 37.2% and is expected to result in a 2.1% distribution per unit (DPU) accretion. The divestment marks the first step of the Reit's strategy to divest non-core assets and pivot towards the light industrial and logistics sector.

images.alt_text: The Piazza Affari 2 in Milan, Italy. Cromwell European Reit had called it a trophy asset in the heart of Milan's central business district, being located opposite the Milan Stock Exchange.

The manager of Cromwell E-Reit, which also owns Via Nervesa 21 in Milan (pictured), says the proposed divestment of the Bari asset is in line with its strategy to divest non-core and non-strategic assets within the Reit's portfolio.

site_title: Nico Steel receives shareholder approval to delist without exit offer
summary: Nico Steel has received shareholder approval to delist without an exit offer, with 72.9% of votes in favor. The company cited concerns that a sale of its key operating asset, Loyang property, would significantly impact its operations and financial position. Nico Steel also stated that its statutory reserves would not be sufficient to make a fair and reasonable exit offer. The move comes after concerned shareholders approached Securities Investors Association (Singapore) with questions about the company's delisting plans.

images.alt_text: “Shareholders have the right to ask and understand the actions taken by the board and the company regarding the provision of an exit offer,” says Sias president and chief executive David Gerald.

site_title: Russia will emerge stronger after mutiny, so no need to fret, says foreign minister
summary: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov stated that Russia will emerge stronger after a failed mutiny by Wagner Group mercenaries, dismissing concerns about the country's stability. Lavrov said the West should not worry about Russia's national interests, calling any doubts "your problem." He also expressed skepticism about Western leaders, suggesting that Moscow has doubts about their ability to govern effectively. Lavrov further criticized the West for pressuring African and Latin American countries to cut ties with Russia, calling for reform of the UN Security Council to give more representation to Asian, African, and Latin American countries.

images.alt_text: State TV showed Putin meeting top security officials and military officers in the Kremlin, sternly thanking them for their support.

site_title: Sri Lanka could exit bankruptcy by September, says president
summary: Sri Lanka's President Ranil Wickremesinghe expressed confidence that the country will exit bankruptcy by September, signaling a turnaround from its worst financial crisis in decades. Sri Lanka launched a domestic debt restructuring framework, crucial for negotiations with bondholders and bilateral creditors, following a default on foreign debt last May. The framework aims to reduce interest rates and secure development assistance, with the economy expected to contract by 2% in 2023.

site_title: Canada’s economy unchanged in April, but likely surged 0.4% in May
summary: Canada's economy remained unchanged in April but is expected to surge 0.4% in May, according to Statistics Canada. The preliminary estimate for May growth was led by increases in manufacturing, wholesale trade, and real estate agents. The goods-producing sector expanded 0.1% in April, while the service-producing sector declined. Despite missing forecasts in April, the May growth aligns with signs that the economy is performing better than expected, despite the Bank of Canada's record-high interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The increase in building costs comes as Canada grapples with high home prices and rents, an immigration-driven population boom, and shortages of workers and raw materials.

site_title: US regulators ask lenders to work with stressed commercial real estate firms
summary: US banking regulators have asked lenders to work with stressed commercial real estate firms, urging them to provide short-term loan accommodations such as payment deferrals or partial payments. The guidance, issued in response to declining property values and borrower defaults, aims to prevent the commercial real estate market from posing a threat to the broader financial system. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell previously stated that US commercial real estate lending remains under pressure but is unlikely to impact the financial system. Over $1.4 trillion in commercial real estate loans will mature by 2027.

images.alt_text: The National Association of Realtors says that its Pending Home Sales Index, based on signed contracts, has dropped dropped 2.7 per cent to 76.5 in May, the lowest level since last December.

site_title: ST Engineering introduces new executive role for smart city, digital businesses
summary: ST Engineering appoints Tan Lee Chew as group chief commercial officer of market development and president of smart city and digital solutions, effective July 1. Tan will also oversee the group's urban solutions and satellite communications business. The move comes after the commercial aerospace business demonstrated resilience during the pandemic and has been a key growth driver for the group. Tan will help build market presence and expand partnerships to create digital experiences and transform operational efficiencies.

images.alt_text: ST Engineering holds a 60 per cent stake in the company which has a registered capital of 100 million yuan (S$19 million), while the remaining 40 per cent is held by SF Airlines.
ST Engineering Q1 revenue up 13% to S$2.3 billion on growth in most segments
The notes will be issued under the S$5 billion global medium term note programme, which is unconditionally and irrevocably guaranteed by ST Engineering.

site_title: Four ministers to speak on Ridout bungalow rentals in Parliament on Monday; MPs file 23 questions
summary: Four Singaporean ministers, including K Shanmugam and Vivian Balakrishnan, will deliver ministerial statements on the rental of two Ridout Road bungalows in Parliament on Monday. The Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) found no evidence of corruption or wrongdoing by the ministers in the rental of the state properties. The ministerial statements will address 23 questions filed by MPs, focusing on the advertising process, transparency, and lease agreements. The statements aim to provide clarity on the rental of the properties, which were previously the subject of a CPIB investigation.

images.alt_text: The original rental rates for the Ridout Road properties – S$26,500 for Law Minister K Shanmugam and S$19,000 for Foreign Affairs Minister Vivian Balakrishnan – were no lower than official guide rents.

pixridout ST20230523_202366754146 Ong Wee Jin / 

Generic photos of road signs showing Ridout Road.

Ongoing saga about Law and MHA Minister K Shanmugam and Foreign Minister, Vivian Balakrishnan renting two massive bungalows at Ridout Road.

Photographed on May 23, 2023.

site_title: Claimant appeals Indonesian court ruling on 1.72 trillion rupiah civil claim against Keppel unit
summary: A claimant, Raden Saleh Abdul Malik, has appealed against an Indonesian court ruling dismissing his 1.72 trillion rupiah (S$154.9 million) lawsuit against Kepland Investama, a Keppel subsidiary. The lawsuit claims ownership of 17,000 square meter land plots in Jakarta, including the International Financial Centre Jakarta Tower 2 building complex, based on a "girik" document. Keppel maintains its land certificates are proof of ownership, and shares rose 0.6% following the announcement. The appeal will be submitted to the DKI Jakarta Province High Court.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as Apple hits record high, inflation cools
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, June 30, driven by Apple's record high and signs of easing inflation, which offered relief to investors worried about interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 147.50 points, or 0.43%, to 34,269.92, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher. This sets up Wall Street for a strong quarterly performance.

site_title: Hyundai Ioniq 6 review: Slippery, with character
summary: Hyundai's Ioniq 6, a sleek and streamlined sedan, has received widespread acclaim, including the World Car Of The Year Award. The car boasts a quiet and comfortable ride, with a claimed range of 519 kilometers on a 77.4 kilowatt-hour battery. The Ioniq 6's design is a standout feature, with a swooping roofline and futuristic interior. The company is also launching the Kona Electric, a more affordable option with a detuned motor, which will be eligible for a cheaper COE. Hyundai aims to sell two million electric cars by 2030, but this plan may involve obsolescing its existing EV architecture, the Electric-Global Modular Platform (E-GMP).

images.alt_text: The RZ 450e is only Lexus' second EV, but it’s the first designed to run on batteries from the ground up.

site_title: Gold is no longer a good hedge against bad times
summary: Gold, once seen as a hedge against economic collapse, has become a cyclical asset, no longer a reliable indicator of bad times. Its price declines with rising real interest rates, as it has zero direct yield, increasing its opportunity cost. Gold's price is also influenced by demand for it as a commodity, such as China's growing economy or India's increasing wealth. As a result, gold is no longer a useful harbinger of social and economic collapse, and its high price is now seen as a normal fluctuation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Gold bars are pictured at the plant of gold and silver refiner and bar manufacturer Argor-Heraeus in Mendrisio, Switzerland, July 13, 2022. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse//File Photo
FILE PHOTO: Liquid gold is poured to form gold dore bars at Newmont Mining's Carlin gold mine operation near Elko, Nevada May 21, 2014. REUTERS/Rick Wilking/File Photo

site_title: China’s factory, service sectors stumble as economic malaise broadens
summary: China's factory sector declined for a third consecutive month in June, while the services sector showed its weakest reading since abandoning Covid curbs late last year. The manufacturing PMI inched up to 49.0, but new orders and new export orders shrank for the third straight month. The services PMI fell to 52.8, indicating a slowdown in service sector activity. The government has set a 5% GDP growth target and has pledged to promote a sustained economic recovery, but analysts expect more support to be needed to shore up growth.

images.alt_text: Home prices in some neighbourhoods are down almost 30 per cent from a peak in late 2021, according to multiple real estate agents.
China's economy has slowed in recent months after coming back to life with the lifting of three years of restrictive zero-Covid policies.

site_title: Archer eyes Asia, Middle East for global air taxi expansion
summary: Archer Aviation, an electric aircraft startup, is expanding its global air taxi operations to the Middle East and Asia, with plans to sell up to 200 of its four-passenger craft to United Airlines and its regional partner Mesa Air Group. The company is in advanced talks with potential partners in seven major international markets, including India, the UAE, Japan, and Singapore. Archer aims to start commercial operations in 2025, with a focus on offering a VIP-type service, and plans to charge prices comparable to Uber ground taxis, with the goal of operating profitably.

images.alt_text: This photograph taken on June 19, 2023 shows the logo of Archer during the International Paris Air Show at the Paris–Le Bourget Airport. (Photo by Emmanuel DUNAND / AFP)

site_title: Sabana Reit trustee signs S$100 million UOB facility tied to changes in Reit manager
summary: Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) has entered into a S$100 million facility agreement with UOB, consisting of a S$75 million term loan and a S$25 million revolving credit facility. The proceeds will be used to refinance existing debt, make asset acquisitions, enhance assets, and cover working capital requirements. The agreement includes provisions related to the Reit's sponsor, ESR Group, and restrictions on changes to the manager or property manager. A review event could lead to cancellation of the facility agreement and restrictions on loan usage.

images.alt_text: Quarz offered a laundry list of improvements the new internal manager could pursue to boost Sabana Reit's performance.
Sabana Industrial Reit's NTP+ at 151 Lorong Chuan.
Should Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust be managed externally or internally?
The post-pandemic resurgence of Singapore Reits petered out rather quickly.
Sabana Reit owns New Tech Park, a six-storey industrial building with a ground level carpark at Lorong Chuan.

In response to a query from The Business Times, Quarz Capital said on Friday (Jun 23) said that an internal manager model for Sabana Reit would help transfer “significant value” from ESR Group to the Reit’s unitholders.
The EGM will run for two hours starting from 2 pm and will take place at Hope@New Tech Park.

site_title: Singapore accountancy body launches programme for local, foreign students to attract talent
summary: Singapore's Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (Isca) has launched a S$1 million programme to attract local and foreign students to the country's accounting sector. The week-long business-study programme, set to run annually, will cover problem statements and networking opportunities with industry players and government agencies. Isca president Teo Ser Luck aims to dispel the notion that accounting is "boring" and attract top talents worldwide, with approximately 300 participants expected over the next three to five years.

images.alt_text: Many foreign accountants in Singapore – most of whom were Malaysians – left in the early days of the pandemic, and could not return when borders closed.

It will be challenging for companies to report comprehensive and high-quality data in alignment with the coming sustainability reporting standards if organisations do not invest in and implement the right monitoring and reporting systems, along with new models and methods for data sharing.
In the autonomous universities, annual enrolment in accountancy degree programmes has fallen to 5,182 in 2021, down from 5,650 in 2017.

site_title: Singapore stocks claw back losses as total market cap rises 1.6% in June
summary: Singapore's total market capitalization rose 1.6% in June to S$804.7 billion, driven by gains among companies in the billion-dollar club. Electric vehicle maker Nio, Singapore Airlines, and Seatrium were among the top gainers, with market values increasing S$4.4 billion, S$2.2 billion, and S$4.3 billion, respectively. Utilities was the worst-performing sector, while Sembcorp Industries bucked the trend with a 70.1% year-to-date gain. Market strategist Geoff Howie expects the Singapore stock market to continue taking global cues in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: SGX RegCo is issuing the Guide on Independent Financial Advisers as a starting point to improve the standards, clarity and consistency of advice that IFAs render in their opinions
Flag carrier SIA has booked the biggest gain in value, adding S$1.7 billion in value in May.

site_title: Europe: Shares crawl higher in Q2
summary: European shares rose 1.2% on Friday, closing the second quarter 0.9% higher, despite concerns about further monetary policy tightening and weak Chinese demand. The Stoxx 600 index ended the quarter on a somber note, with mounting evidence of China's weak post-Covid recovery and rising global interest rates. The European Central Bank is expected to hike interest rates for the ninth consecutive time in July and September. Despite this, European shares still advanced 8.7% in the first half of the year, with the real estate sector leading gains, while miners and energy stocks declined due to worries over top metals consumer China.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.7 per cent higher, tracking overnight gains in Wall Street.

site_title: Temasek tops 200 sovereign and pension funds in governance, sustainability and resilience practices
summary: Temasek Holdings has emerged as the top global investor in governance, sustainability and resilience practices, joining four other investors who scored full marks on the Global SWF scoreboard. Temasek, with $298 billion in assets under management, topped the leaderboard, followed by CDPQ, NZ Super, and the Nigerian Sovereign Investment Authority. This marks the first time Temasek has achieved the top spot, showcasing its commitment to responsible investing.

images.alt_text: The hacker house will run both online and offline and consists of developer quests, hackathons and meetups in cities around the world, including in Singapore.
Daxue Investments, Temasek Holdings’ indirect unit, and True Light P, held by Temasek-owned True Light Capital GP, will altogether hold 17.55 per cent stake in Viva Shanghai after the deal.

site_title: Google to block news in Canada over law on paying publishers
summary: Google plans to block Canadian news on its platform in Canada, removing links to news from search results and other products, due to a new law requiring payments to local news publishers. The law, introduced last year, aims to recoup financial losses suffered by news businesses, with estimates suggesting they could receive C$330 million per year. Google has argued the law is unworkable and will end its News Showcase programme in Canada, affecting 150 news publications. The move follows a similar announcement by Facebook, escalating a campaign against the law.

images.alt_text: In 2021, Google was hit with a 220 million euro (S$324.6 million) fine by France’s antitrust watchdog for favouring its AdX sales platform.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares started trading higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.4% at 3,220.16. Advancers outnumbered decliners 67 to 55, with notable gains from Thai Beverage, DBS, UOB, and OCBC. The positive trend mirrored global markets, which were influenced by US economic data and interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Temasek is selling around S$400 million worth of shares, or a 1.85 per cent stake, in the national carrier as a portfolio rebalancing act but remains SIA’s major shareholder.

site_title: The myth that may have doomed the Titan
summary: The Titan submersible's implosion in the North Atlantic was attributed to a lack of safety certification, with its owner and pilot, Stockton Rush, arguing that regulations stifled innovation. However, the history of deep-sea submersibles reveals that government involvement was crucial in their development, with the US Navy and Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution playing key roles in the creation of pioneering vessels like Aluminaut and Alvin. These early submersibles were built with safety protocols in mind, and their success paved the way for the development of modern submersibles. The author, Naomi Oreskes, argues that Rush's view that government regulation hinders innovation is a myth, and that regulation is essential for saving lives.

images.alt_text: The accident has raised questions about the unregulated nature of such expeditions and the decision by OceanGate to forego third-party industry review and certification of Titan’s novel design.
The probes into the Titan disaster may be complicated by questions of which country should take the lead, and by doubts that the watercraft fits the legal definition of a maritime vessel.
This photo taken during the historical 1986 dive to the wreck shows the bow of the Titanic/

The Titan submersible, operated by OceanGate Expeditions to explore the wreckage of the sunken Titanic off the coast of Newfoundland, dives in an undated photograph. site_title: SVB Financial nears approval to sell its investment banking business
summary: US bankruptcy judge Martin Glenn has approved a deal for SVB Financial Group to sell its investment banking division, subject to removing liability releases for executives involved in the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank. The sale, initially proposed by former CEO Jeff Leerink and backed by The Baupost Group, has been revised to address concerns over liability releases. Glenn expressed frustration with SVB Financial's handling of the provision and warned the FDIC against blocking access to information about seized funds. The deal's approval is contingent on SVB Financial removing liability releases.

site_title: Yes, there are alternatives to stocks
summary: The article discusses the current market landscape, highlighting the appeal of fixed-income investments, such as bonds and money market funds, due to rising interest rates. These alternatives offer solid income with lower risk than stocks, making them a viable option for investors with short time horizons. However, the article notes that high-flying tech stocks, like Nvidia, may not be justified by their high prices. Experts recommend a "barbell approach" of holding short-term and long-term investments, and the author maintains a balanced portfolio with a mix of stocks and bonds.

images.alt_text: The labelling of recessions – and of bull and bear markets – is critical in understanding what has already happened, but these labels aren’t all that helpful for acting now or preparing for the future.

site_title: Proposed Biden curbs could starve Chinese tech of early funding, expertise
summary: The US government is expected to impose curbs on American investment in Chinese tech, potentially restricting private equity and venture capital investments. This move could throttle entrepreneurship and innovation in China, according to Han Yuze, a Shanghai-based tech firm partner. The curbs are aimed at slowing China's technological advancement, particularly in areas like semiconductor manufacturing, AI, and quantum computing. Chinese startups may shift to non-US investment sources, such as institutions in the Middle East, and the Chinese government is urged to create new yuan-denominated funds to invest in early-stage startups.

images.alt_text: Alibaba’s Taobao & Tmall Business Group said that a record number of merchants on the Taobao and Tmall platforms took part in this year's 618 shopping festival.

People are reducing spending on necessities, resulting in retail sales of grain, oil and food rising just 1 per cent in April from a year earlie, when people stockpiled necessities over worries of lockdowns.

site_title: Zhou Guanyu eyes being the height of fashion post F1 career
summary: Zhou Guanyu, China's first Formula One driver, expressed his desire to pursue a career in fashion after retiring from racing. The 24-year-old Alfa Romeo driver has garnered four points going into the Austrian Grand Prix. Guanyu's interest in fashion was sparked by his mother, a former designer, and he sees Formula One as a platform to launch his fashion career. Despite his focus on racing, Guanyu is confident that Alfa Romeo can add points to their tally in Austria, currently seventh in the constructors' championship.

images.alt_text: The Dutch 25-year-old led every lap as he took his career tally to 41 wins, stepping up alongside Brazil’s late triple champion Ayrton Senna in the record books.

site_title: Panerai’s art of soft-selling
summary: Panerai is shifting its sales strategy to focus on soft-selling, prioritizing hospitality and customer experience over traditional sales tactics. The brand's CEO, Jean-Marc Pontroue, says the bar counter in Panerai's new generation boutiques is the "bestselling spot," where fans gather to share a common interest and relax. Panerai is expanding its boutiques, including a dedicated space for women, and introducing new timepieces, such as smaller and more colorful models, to appeal to a wider audience. The brand aims to "democratize" itself and reach more young people, while remaining loyal to its classic Italian DNA.

images.alt_text: Jean Marc Pontroué
Remi Maillot started Krayon to help big and small watchmakers develop movements, trouble-shoot and fine-tune prototypes.
