site_title: Inflation in Tokyo stays above BOJ’s target for 13th straight month
summary: Japan's inflation in Tokyo has exceeded the Bank of Japan's 2% target for the 13th straight month, with core consumer prices rising 3.2% in June. This follows factory output's unexpected decline in May, underscoring risks to the export-reliant economy. The BOJ may phase out its massive stimulus this year, with new governor Kazuo Ueda suggesting inflation could accelerate in 2024 if cost-push factors dissipate. The inflation figures will likely keep expectations alive for the BOJ to adjust its monetary policy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A woman looks at items at a shop in Tokyo, Japan, March 24, 2023. REUTERS/Androniki Christodoulou/File Photo
The currency swap deal was first agreed in 2001, and designed as a tool to help the two countries cope in the face of a financial crisis.

site_title: Kore’s focus on US suburbs could pay off amid Fortune 500 exodus from traditional gateway cities
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit's focus on US suburbs is paying off amid a trend of Fortune 500 companies shifting offices from traditional gateway cities to lower-cost locations. Companies like Caterpillar, Boeing, and Oracle are moving to cities like Dallas, Texas, and Florida, seeking favorable business regulations, cheaper housing, and lower tax rates. Keppel's properties, located in vibrant suburban submarkets, are attracting a diverse range of tenants, including technology, healthcare, and medical companies. The strategy has led to higher occupancy rates and increased portfolio value, with Keppel's portfolio committed occupancy standing at 91.9% as of March 31.

images.alt_text: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit's 105 Edgeview property (above) in Denver. The Reit posted a lower H2 2022 DPU of US$0.0278, down 12.6 per cent from its DPU of US$0.0318 a year ago.
The Children's Place will vacate its 197,949 square feet of space on May 31, 2024.
The Reit’s manager says it aims to enter into a definitive agreement for Phipps Tower’s disposal by Jun 30, 2023. It will also waive the disposal fee.

site_title: Gold struggles for momentum as traders await key US inflation data
summary: Gold prices struggled to gain momentum on Friday as traders awaited US inflation data, following strong data prints and hawkish comments from Federal Reserve officials. Spot gold remained flat at $1,908.33 per ounce, while US gold futures fell 0.1% to $1,916.40. A resilient labor market and upward GDP revision raised bets of further interest rate hikes, making gold less attractive. Investors now see an 89% chance of a 25-basis point hike in July, with benchmark Treasury yields surging on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Gold prices decline when real interest rates rise.
High interest rates discourage investing in non-yielding gold.

site_title: Airbnb disputes ‘collapse’ in host revenue, sees strong demand
summary: Airbnb disputes data showing a 48% decline in revenue for US property owners, citing strong demand for short-term rentals. The company says nights and experiences booked grew 19% in the first quarter of 2023 compared to the same period last year. Data from other providers, such as AirDNA, suggest a more muted decline, with Jamie Lane, chief economist, predicting a 1-2% decline in RevPAR for the first half of 2023. Despite this, Lane expects overall demand for short-term rentals to remain strong, with Airbnb expected to gain share over hotels.

images.alt_text: City councils around the United States are increasingly introducing ordinances to regulate short-term rentals.

site_title: Eurozone core inflation accelerates again in setback for ECB
summary: Eurozone core inflation accelerated to 5.4% in June, surpassing the European Central Bank's 2% target, as the cost of services rose markedly. This setback may reinforce the ECB's determination to raise interest rates next month. Despite a slight moderation in headline inflation, policymakers are concerned about strong demand for services and accelerating wage gains, which may lead to a wage-price spiral if inflation remains above target. The ECB aims to bring inflation back to 2% and has already increased borrowing costs by 400 basis points, with another rate hike expected in July.

images.alt_text: “We must ensure that inflation expectations remain anchored as the wage catch-up process plays out,” ECB president Christine Lagarde says

site_title: Virgin Galactic takes off on first commercial space flight
summary: Virgin Galactic successfully completed its first commercial space flight, dubbed Galactic 01, on June 29, 2023. The 90-minute mission reached an altitude of over 80 km, offering passengers a few minutes of weightlessness and a glimpse of the planet's curvature. The crew conducted 13 supervised and autonomous experiments, collecting data on their suits and sensors. This milestone marks a major achievement for the company founded by British billionaire Richard Branson, which has sold around 800 tickets for future commercial flights.

images.alt_text: The passenger rocket plane operated by Virgin Galactic takes off during the company's first commercial flight to the edge of space, at the Spaceport America facility, in Truth or Consequences, New Mexico, U.S., June 29, 2023. REUTERS/Jose Luis Gonzalez

Virgin Galactic hasn’t been into space since July 2021, when the company famously flew its billionaire founder and five other company employees to the edge of space using its passenger rocket plane, the VSS Unity (above).

site_title: China’s Shein files for US IPO: sources
summary: Shein, a Chinese online fashion retailer worth over $60 billion, has registered with the US Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering (IPO) in New York, despite opposition from a bipartisan group of US representatives who are concerned about the company's labor practices. Shein has denied allegations of using force labor and has adhered to ethical sourcing standards. The IPO could make Shein the most valuable Chinese company to list in the US since Didi Global in 2021, but is also seen as a test of the US-China trade tensions and the company's ability to navigate regulatory challenges.

images.alt_text: Shein’s pivot to selling products other than its own, including Skechers shoes and Lansinoh mother-care items, brings it closer to what rival Temu offers.
The Singapore-based retailer that was founded in China is also expanding its manufacturing network in Brazil, and Reuters reported last month it plans to open a factory in Mexico.

site_title: Under-fire UK minister quits and slams Sunak
summary: UK Minister Zac Goldsmith has resigned as international environment minister, criticizing Prime Minister Rishi Sunak for abandoning climate change commitments and environmental protections. Goldsmith accused Sunak of "apathy" and said the UK had become a leader on these issues under former Prime Minister Boris Johnson. The timing of Goldsmith's resignation, hours before Sunak's planned news conference, raised eyebrows, and the move is seen as a blow to Sunak's focus on healthcare reform.

images.alt_text: Following hours of debate, held on Boris Johnson’s 59th birthday, MPs voted by 354 to seven in favour of the Privileges Committee’s findings that Johnson lied to parliament about Covid lockdown-breaking parties.

site_title: Accounting firms question the partnership model
summary: BDO USA, the sixth-largest accounting firm in the US, is converting from a partnership to a corporation, marking a shift away from the traditional partnership model. The move is seen as a response to the drawbacks of the partnership model, including unwieldy decision-making and limitations on funding acquisitions. The change allows partners to become shareholders and employees, and offers tax benefits. Other large accounting firms, such as EY and PwC, have considered similar changes, with some embracing the partnership model despite its flaws.

images.alt_text: The case against turning the big four into a biggish eight is far from open and shut, not least as the commercial logic of the split is in many ways getting more compelling.

site_title: South Korea May factory output unexpectedly jumps, led by cars and chips
summary: South Korea's factory production unexpectedly rose 3.2% in May, driven by a 8.7% increase in automobile output and a 4.4% rise in semiconductor production. This rebounded from April's 1.3% loss and topped the highest estimate of a 2.8% rise. Retail sales also rose 0.4% in May, after a 2.6% drop in April. The all-industry production index, including manufacturing and services sectors, rose 1.3% in May.

images.alt_text: The ministers will also discuss global economic developments, infrastructure investment in developing countries, and the role both countries could play in multilateral financial cooperation.

site_title: Pokemon Go maker Niantic closes studio, cancels games
summary: Niantic, the maker of Pokémon Go, is closing its Los Angeles studio and cancelling NBA and Marvel titles due to financial struggles. The company will cut 230 jobs, about 25% of its staff, and halt work on the Marvel World of Heroes and NBA All-World games. CEO John Hanke cited growing expenses outpacing revenue as the reason for the restructuring, which aims to stabilize the company's finances and preserve its core assets, including Pokémon Go and other successful games.

Kawaii. Trailers for the new game suggest it combines a smartphone sleep tracker with gaming.

site_title: Fidelity spot Bitcoin ETF application refiled with US SEC
summary: Fidelity has refiled its application with the US SEC to list and trade shares of its Wise Origin Bitcoin Trust spot Bitcoin exchange-traded fund (ETF). This comes as several big asset managers, including BlackRock and Invesco, have also submitted paperwork for spot Bitcoin ETFs. The move is seen as a positive development for the ailing crypto industry, with Bitcoin hitting a one-year high of over $31,000. The SEC has previously rejected dozens of spot Bitcoin ETF applications due to concerns over fraudulent and manipulative practices.

images.alt_text: Rajeev Mittal, Fidelity International MD, at the official opening of the China fund management company. Fidlity raised RMB1 1 billion in its first China equity fund launch earlier this year.

site_title: Nike shows sales strength; profit falls just short of estimates
summary: Nike's global revenue rose 5% to $12.8 billion in the fiscal fourth quarter, beating Wall Street's expectation of $12.6 billion. However, profit fell short of estimates, and the company's full-year revenue growth outlook was met with skepticism. Analysts project 6% growth, while Nike expects mid-single-digit growth. The company's shares slipped 3.5% in late trading, and its stock has fallen 3.1% this year. Despite strong sales, Nike's high stockpiles of merchandise continue to erode profitability, leading to a year of "resetting, retrenching, and reformulating" its business strategy.

images.alt_text: On the Nike site, the original Ja 1 link goes to a page that reads “THE PRODUCT YOU ARE LOOKING FOR IS NO LONGER AVAILABLE.”

site_title: Britain’s annual house prices fall most since 2009, Nationwide says
summary: Britain's annual house prices have fallen by 3.5% in June, the largest decline since 2009, according to Nationwide Building Society. This is due to soaring mortgage rates and inflation readings, prompting investors to expect the Bank of England to raise interest rates above 6%. The average home price now stands at £262,239. Economists warn that this could push the UK into recession this year, and borrowers are facing a steep rise in mortgage costs, with mortgage approvals remaining below pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: About 500 of the homes will be transferred to Citra’s ownership by June 2024, Barratt said.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, iFast, Cromwell E-Reit, Cortina, Sabana Reit
summary: Temasek is selling around S$400 million worth of shares, or a 1.85% stake, in Singapore Airlines (SIA) as a portfolio rebalancing act. SIA shares closed 0.5% lower at S$7.50 on Wednesday. iFast Corporation's Hong Kong subsidiary launched a digital pension solution for Hong Kong ORSO Pension schemes, while Cromwell E-Reit sold its non-core office asset in Italy for S$138.5 million. Cortina's Hong Kong subsidiaries are disputing distribution rights for Franck Muller watches with Sincere Brand Management. Sabana Industrial Reit inked a sustainability-linked facility agreement with UOB for up to S$100 million.

site_title: Coca-Cola to see less pain from looming WHO decision on aspartame: analysts
summary: Coca-Cola is expected to experience a limited impact from the World Health Organization's possible classification of aspartame as a possible carcinogen. The company's large-scale production and distribution system, as well as its history of adapting to policy changes, will help mitigate the effects. While a shift to a natural sweetener could impact short-term profitability, analysts predict a minimal decline in long-term growth. PepsiCo, which has already moved away from aspartame, may gain an edge over Coca-Cola in the long run.

images.alt_text: Average selling prices rose 11 per cent in the first quarter, Coca-Cola said, while unit case volumes rose 3 per cent.
PepsiCo’s average prices jumped 16 per cent for the first quarter, while organic volume slipped 2 per cent.

site_title: Verstappen sees off Leclerc for fourth pole in a row
summary: Max Verstappen secured his fourth consecutive pole position at the Austrian Grand Prix, ahead of Charles Leclerc, with Ferrari's Carlos Sainz and McLaren's Lando Norris starting alongside them. Verstappen's teammate Sergio Perez struggled, failing to make the top 10 for the fourth race in a row and being 69 points behind Verstappen in the championship standings. Verstappen attributed his success to the challenging track layout of the Red Bull Ring, which has the shortest lap on the calendar.

images.alt_text: The Dutch 25-year-old led every lap as he took his career tally to 41 wins, stepping up alongside Brazil’s late triple champion Ayrton Senna in the record books.

site_title: Apac workers risk losing their jobs to climate change: report
summary: A report by Deloitte warns that over 40% of Asia-Pacific workers, or 43% of those in climate-reliant industries, risk losing their jobs due to climate change. These industries include agriculture, energy, manufacturing, transportation, and construction. To mitigate job disruption, business leaders must invest in climate adaptation and upskill workers, while governments must ensure green talent and provide social protections for disrupted workers. If coordinated, the region can create 180 million jobs by 2050 and an additional US$47 trillion by 2070.

images.alt_text: China has pledged to become carbon-neutral by 2060 and to reach peak coal consumption by 2025, but it continues to promote coal-fired power generation.

Involving local communities in the co-designing and consulting stages of the process will build trust, but Sharan Burrow emphasises that business leaders must be open to the idea that “some other people might have good ideas”.
Coal barges to be pulled along Mahakam river in Samarinda, East Kalimantan province, Indonesia, in August 31, 2019.

site_title: US: Stocks diverge as economy shows resilience
summary: US stocks advanced as the Commerce Department raised the US first-quarter growth rate to 2.0%, indicating economic resilience despite interest rate hikes. Treasury yields and the dollar rose in response. Consumer spending drove growth, but the strong data has raised concerns about the need for further monetary tightening. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell reiterated that two more rate hikes are likely by year's end to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average has risen 1.91 points, or 0.01 per cent, at the open to 33,854.57.

site_title: Swiss National Bank boosts forex sales in first quarter
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) sold 32.3 billion Swiss francs (S$48.6 billion) worth of foreign currencies in the first quarter of 2023 to bolster the franc and fight inflation. This marks the fourth quarter in a row of forex sales, as the central bank seeks to strengthen its safe-haven currency to combat high inflation caused by expensive imports. Despite a recent drop in inflation to 2.2%, the SNB remains committed to its campaign to limit inflation, with forecasts suggesting a possible reading of 2.2% for June.

images.alt_text: “This is not just an experiment, it will be real money equivalent to bank reserves and the objective is to test real transactions with market participants,” Swiss National Bank chairman Thomas Jordan says.
Chairman of the Swiss National Bank (SNB) Thomas Jordan pointed to rising inflationary pressures and the danger of price increases becoming entrenched.

Speaking less than two weeks before the SNB sets rates at its quarterly meeting, the central banker highlights that “we still have an environment where inflation is too high, and there are relatively widespread price increases”.

site_title: Amazon pulls the plug on Kindle store in China
summary: Amazon has closed its Kindle online store in China, ending the sale of new books and allowing users to download purchased e-books for another year. The move comes after Amazon admitted defeat to local rivals, citing the ease of access to free e-books and low cost of print. Experts attribute the closure to the widespread use of smartphones and 4G/5G networks, making e-book readers redundant for Chinese consumers. Users are rushing to stock up on e-books before the deadline, with some spending hundreds of dollars on purchases.

images.alt_text: In the coming weeks, the FTC, led by commissioner Lina Khan, plans to file a far-reaching antitrust suit focused on Amazon’s core online marketplace.
The sale of the two Vancouver properties would be the first significant office transaction in the country since last April, when a tower in downtown Toronto traded hands for about C$380 million
This announcement follows Amazon’s cloud computing unit Amazon Web Services saying last month it will invest 1.06 trillion rupees in the country by the end of 2030.

site_title: France braces for new protests as anger grows over police killing
summary: France has been hit by widespread protests after a 17-year-old boy, Nahel M, was shot and killed by a policeman in the Paris suburb of Nanterre. The incident reignited debate about police tactics, with the government ordering 40,000 police to deploy across the country. Clashes and unrest have occurred across the country, with 150 people arrested and several cars and buildings set ablaze. A prosecutor has announced that the policeman will be charged with homicide, and President Emmanuel Macron has called for calm, urging protesters to mark the coming hours with "contemplation and respect".

images.alt_text: French riot police try to extinguish a fire amid clashes during a demonstration against the French government's pension reform, in Paris, France, March 25, 2023.

site_title: Threat of ‘down rounds’ spur private credit funds in Asia
summary: Private credit funds in Asia are booming, with at least $2.5 billion in new funds launched or planned in the first half of the year, targeting startups that are moving away from "down rounds" - sharply discounted equity valuations. The trend follows a similar surge in the US, driven by global economic and market challenges. Private credit funds offer an alternative to startups seeking to avoid valuation scaling back, but come with less stringent conditions and higher interest rates. The Asian private credit industry is expected to boom further, with major firms like Apollo, Blackstone, and KKR investing in multi-billion dollar credit funds.

images.alt_text: Demand for credit is growing as Asia’s economies mature; South-east Asia alone is estimated to need at least US$2.8 trillion of infrastructure investments to ensure sustainable economic growth.

site_title: Coinbase, facing US SEC lawsuit, says regulator lacks police power over crypto
summary: Coinbase, the largest US cryptocurrency platform, has filed a motion to dismiss the US Securities and Exchange Commission's (SEC) lawsuit claiming it failed to register its business. The SEC alleges Coinbase broke the law by trading unregistered crypto assets and operating a staking program. Coinbase argues the SEC lacks authority to pursue civil claims, as the assets trading on its platform are not "investment contracts" and thus not securities. The company claims the SEC's actions are unlawful and an overreach of regulatory authority.

images.alt_text: Gemini on Monday said Singapore will be its hub for the Asia-Pacific region and announced plans to boost headcount in the city-state to more than 100 in the next 12 months.
A ruling favouring another crypto defendant at the trial court level would not be binding on Coinbase’s own case, but the company could potentially point to it in its defence, legal experts say.

site_title: Inflection AI raises US$1.3 billion in funding from Microsoft, others
summary: Inflection AI, co-founded by LinkedIn's Reid Hoffman and Google DeepMind's Mustafa Suleyman, has raised $1.3 billion in funding from investors including Microsoft and Bill Gates. This funding comes less than two months after the release of its chatbot, Pi, which utilizes generative AI technology for user interactions. The funding round also involved former Google CEO Eric Schmidt and Nvidia.

site_title: Oil settles higher, trade choppy as tight supply vie with rate hike fear
summary: Oil prices rose 0.4% on Thursday, settling higher after a bigger-than-expected draw in US crude inventories, but were pressured by concerns about rising interest rates and global economic growth. Brent crude futures rose to $74.34 a barrel and US WTI crude futures rose to $69.86 a barrel. Investors are weighing the impact of interest rate hikes on the global economy, with Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell reiterating a moderate pace of interest rate decisions, and European Central Bank president Christine Lagarde expecting a ninth consecutive rate hike in July.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures  have risen 45 US cents, or 0.6 per cent, to US$74.52 a barrel by 11.06 am ET (1503 GMT). US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures have risen 55 US cents, or 0.8 per cent, to US$70.11 a barrel.

site_title: Better supervision needed after bank failures: US Fed chair
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell emphasized the need for stronger regulation and supervision in the banking sector following a string of high-profile failures earlier this year. Powell cited California lender Silicon Valley Bank's collapse as a key example, highlighting the need for more agile and forceful supervisory practices. The Fed is working with institutions to improve interest rate risk management and funding models, particularly in regards to uninsured deposits. Powell stressed the importance of not growing complacent about the financial system's resilience.

images.alt_text: Small local banks and mid-sized regional banks were exempted from these tests.

site_title: Europe: H&M leads Stoxx 600 higher, rate hike jitters weigh
summary: European stocks rose 0.1% on Thursday, driven by H&M's 18.2% gain on stronger-than-expected quarterly profit. Spain's consumer prices rose 1.9% year-on-year, the slowest increase since March 2021, while Germany's inflation rose more than expected. US economic data showed initial jobless claims dropped and first-quarter GDP was revised upward, cementing the likelihood of further interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.7 per cent higher, tracking overnight gains in Wall Street.

site_title: Les Amis Group to end ties with long-term partner Aoki restaurant after 20 years
summary: Aoki restaurant, a 20-year-old Japanese eatery at Shaw Centre, will close its doors permanently on December 31 after the Les Amis Group ends its partnership with chef-owner Kunio Aoki. The closure marks a significant end to the restaurant's 20-year run, during which it has performed reasonably well financially despite a saturated market. Aoki plans to take a short break and open a new restaurant in February 2024, returning to his passion for nigiri sushi.

images.alt_text: Matera's executive chef Bjoern Alexander.

site_title: US, Dutch set to hit China’s chipmakers with one-two punch
summary: The US and Netherlands are set to restrict sales of chipmaking equipment to China, targeting companies like ASML, which dominates lithography technology. The US plans to withhold even more Dutch equipment from specific Chinese fabs, while the Netherlands will announce new regulations requiring licenses for top-tier ASML equipment. This move aims to prevent China's military from strengthening its capabilities. China has already imposed retaliatory measures, with a spokesperson describing the US as "deliberately blockading and hobbling Chinese companies."

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: ASML logo is seen in this illustration taken February 28, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

Enacted with the stated intention of safeguarding China’s national security and development interests, the Law on Foreign Relations stops short of creating new mechanisms for responding to rising geopolitical challenges, such as US-led export controls on advanced technology.

The Biden administration last October issued a sweeping set of rules designed to freeze China’s semiconductor industry in place while the US pours billions of dollars in subsidies into its own chip industry.

site_title: Volkswagen to remove Audi CEO after slide in brand’s performance
summary: Volkswagen's supervisory board is expected to approve the removal of Audi CEO Markus Duesmann due to the luxury brand's slow progress on innovation, falling behind competitors BMW and Mercedes-Benz. Duesmann will be replaced by Volkswagen strategy chief Gernot Doellner. The decision comes after a series of mishaps that have impacted Audi's performance. The move is seen as an attempt to revitalize the brand and improve its competitiveness in the luxury car market.

site_title: Thailand's economy picks up in May as tourism, spending rise
summary: Thailand's economy showed a steady rise in May, driven by increasing tourist arrivals and private consumption, despite weak exports. The Bank of Thailand reported a current account deficit of $2.8 billion and a 5.9% year-on-year drop in exports. The central bank expects economic growth of 3.6% this year and 3.8% next year, with the tourism sector a key driver. Global market volatility will be monitored, and the new government's policies will be closely watched.

images.alt_text: epa10614947 Chinese tourists visit the Emerald Buddha Temple at the Grand Palace in Bangkok, Thailand, 08 May 2023.  The Civil Aviation Authority of Thailand has announced that Chinese airlines will increase their flight frequency to Thailand to 430 flights per week starting on 01 June. This will significantly boost the country's tourism industry.  EPA-EFE/NARONG SANGNAK

site_title: Frozen food manufacturers grapple with soaring electricity costs amid global energy crisis
summary: Singapore's frozen food manufacturers face significant strain from soaring electricity costs, with bills doubling or tripling in the past year. The high and fluctuating costs make it challenging for businesses to anticipate monthly expenses, affecting earnings. To alleviate costs, some companies have replaced equipment with energy-saving alternatives and sought long-term contracts with electricity retailers, but success varies. The Energy Market Authority (EMA) has seen over 3,000 businesses sign retail contracts in the past three months, but new contracts may still be limited.

images.alt_text: The temporary price cap will kick in from Jul 1, 2023, said the Energy Market Authority in a paper published on its website.

site_title: Intangible asset valuation guidelines will bring clarity, boost Singapore’s IP standing: analysts
summary: Singapore is developing guidelines for valuing intangible assets (IAs), expected to bring clarity to the industry and boost the country's IP standing. The guidelines aim to create professional standards for valuation practices, addressing the current lack of authoritative guidance. Industry players and analysts believe the move will encourage investment in Singapore's IP ecosystem, facilitate the commercialization of IAs, and provide a boost to the country's technology-driven venture capital space. The guidelines are expected to be interoperable with valuation practices across various jurisdictions, setting Singapore apart as a leader in the industry.

images.alt_text: The government has previously hinted that IA valuation guidelines might be in the pipeline.
Singapore launches 10-year blueprint to cement IP hub status

site_title: A real-world investment in the age of AI
summary: Data centres are poised to thrive in the AI-driven world as generative AI models require substantial computational power, robust data processing capabilities, and extensive storage capacities. Unlike previous tech bubbles, AI's foundation is data and infrastructure, suggesting it's a developing long-term growth opportunity. As AI adoption increases, data centres will be integral to its implementation and growth, driven by the need for efficient data processing and storage. With many companies still in the research phase, AI's transformative impact is expected to be monumental, but its full potential is yet to be understood.

images.alt_text: Cloud computing, network, website, IT, technology Credit: PIXABAY

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall; first-quarter GDP revised higher
summary: US jobless claims fell 26,000 to 239,000 for the week ended June 25, indicating continued labor market strength. The services sector, particularly leisure and hospitality, is driving job growth, which averaged 314,000 jobs per month this year. The first-quarter GDP was revised higher to a 2% annualized rate, driven by consumer spending and exports, despite a slowdown in inventory investment.

images.alt_text: 264,000 new claims were filed for jobless benefits on a seasonally adjusted basis in the week ended June 17, unchanged from the prior week’s upwardly revised level.

site_title: Volkswagen in talks with Tesla to adopt its charging standard
summary: Volkswagen is in talks with Tesla to adopt its North American Charging Standard (Nacs) technology, following a trend of major automakers and charging equipment makers choosing Tesla's design. Electrify America, Volkswagen's electric vehicle charging network unit, has already agreed to use the system. The decision comes amid concerns that sticking to the Combined Charging System (CCS) design may harm customers. Several companies, including Ford, General Motors, and ChargePoint, have signed up for Tesla's charging design in recent weeks.

images.alt_text: Tesla chief executive officer Elon Musk has been willing to take lower profits as he reduces prices to keep market share.

site_title: US: Wall St rises as banks gain, economic data eases recession fears
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday as bank stocks gained after major lenders cleared the Federal Reserve's annual stress test, easing recession fears. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.91 points, or 0.01%, to 33,854.57, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained. The resilient US economy, despite aggressive interest rate hikes, supported the market's upward momentum.

site_title: Oil edges higher on US inventory fall
summary: Oil prices edged higher on Thursday, driven by a bigger-than-expected fall in US crude inventories, but were capped by concerns about rising interest rates and global economic growth. Brent crude futures rose 45 US cents to $74.52 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures rose 55 US cents to $70.11 a barrel. The smaller-than-expected decline in inventories suggests that the second half of 2023 may bring a decline in inventories, but rising interest rates remain a concern.

images.alt_text: Investors remained cautious that interest rate hikes could slow economic growth and reduce oil demand.

site_title: Basque Kitchen by Aitor to reopen with new name and Michelin-starred chef
summary: Basque Kitchen by Aitor in Singapore is set to reopen as Matera on July 19, with German chef Bjoern Alexander at the helm. Alexander, a two-Michelin-starred chef from Hong Kong's Octavium, will serve modern Italian food with Japanese and Chinese influences. The restaurant, named after an ancient Italian city, will offer a unique set lunch option and a variety of signature dishes, including whole red prawn with sesame bread and XO sauce. Alexander's culinary style is characterized by his open-minded approach to different cultures and flavors.

images.alt_text: Quietly opulent interiors of Restaurant Fiz.

site_title: Finance sector tells UK regulators to use new post-Brexit remit
summary: The UK's finance sector has urged regulators to apply their new post-Brexit remit to maintain London's position as a globally competitive financial centre. The Financial Services and Markets law, which received royal assent, gives regulators powers to amend rules and ensure global competitiveness and economic growth. Industry officials, including Bruce Carnegie-Brown and Chris Hayward, have called for regulators to make bold moves and ensure proportionate actions to aid growth, citing examples such as unlocking cash in pension funds.

images.alt_text: “This agreement with our European partners as sovereign equals builds on our arrangements with the US, Japan and Singapore, helping to support the sector’s role as a global financial services hub,” says UK Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt.

site_title: US pending home sales fall to five-month low in May
summary: US pending home sales dropped 2.7% in May to 76.5, the lowest level since December, due to a chronic shortage of houses on the market. Economists forecast a 0.5% decline, but actual sales fell 22.2% year-over-year. Despite this, the housing market remains resilient, with approximately three offers per listing, and construction and new home sales are up. The inventory of existing homes remains low, supporting a monthly increase in house prices.

site_title: Geneva airport strike to ground flights Friday
summary: Geneva's international airport will be grounded for four hours on Friday morning due to a workers' strike, affecting approximately 8,000 passengers. The strike, which began after the airport's board approved a new wage policy, was called in response to staff concerns. Flights will be cancelled or delayed between 6 am and 10 am local time, with airlines deciding on the best course of action. This disruption comes as the aviation industry seeks to avoid a repeat of last year's chaos, which was exacerbated by understaffing following the Covid pandemic.

images.alt_text: Workers had already staged 18 days of strikes in recent months, and while airport bosses said it would be able to keep operations running smoothly despite walkouts over the summer, passengers are worried there could be a repeat of last year’s chaos.

site_title: German inflation beats forecasts with June rise
summary: German inflation rose 6.8% in June, beating forecasts and ending a decline since the start of the year. Harmonized consumer prices, compared to EU countries, increased by 6.8% year-over-year, while non-harmonized prices rose 6.4%. This marks a bumpy road ahead for the economy, following a sharp decline in May. Analysts had expected a 0.3% increase in harmonized data and 6.7% annual growth.

site_title: Living near green spaces makes you 2.5 years younger: study
summary: A new study published in Science Advances found that living near green spaces can make people 2.5 years biologically younger, on average. The study, which followed over 900 participants from four American cities, found that those with access to more green cover were slower biologically aging. The benefits were not evenly shared, with white participants experiencing greater age reduction. The study's lead author believes the findings have significant implications for urban planning to expand green infrastructure and promote public health.

images.alt_text: Company well-being initiatives aren’t always making it out of the boardroom.

site_title: Micron delivers strong forecast in sign that glut is easing
summary: Micron Technology has delivered a strong forecast for its fiscal fourth quarter, projecting sales of $4.1 billion, surpassing the average analyst estimate of $3.87 billion. The company attributes the positive outlook to a decrease in the industry glut, with customers working through inventory and returning to purchasing. However, Micron faces challenges, including a Chinese government probe into its products being a security risk, which is expected to impact sales. The company predicts a loss of $1.12 to $1.26 per share and expects PC shipments to decline by a low double-digit percentage from a year ago.

images.alt_text: China has come under pressure from the US, which is keen to undercut its efforts to build up its domestic chip manufacturing capability.

site_title: UK mortgage rates rise again, turning screw on homeowners and buyers
summary: UK mortgage rates have risen again, with lenders increasing rates on many mortgage offerings to above 6% in a scramble to keep up with soaring funding costs. This is the second consecutive month of declining mortgage lending, with BOE data showing a contraction in mortgage lending value for the first time since records began in 1986. The increase in mortgage rates, coupled with rising borrowing costs, is putting pressure on homeowners and potential buyers, with the ratio of mortgage borrowing to income rising to 3.5 from 2.0 in the late 1980s.

images.alt_text: A sign at the entrance of an estate agents advertising mortgage advice services in Brentwood, UK, on Tuesday, June 27, 2023. Rising mortgage payments are squeezing the finances of millions of borrowers in Britain, threatening to undermine household spending and the broader economy. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

British banks are pushing up the cost of housing loans, pulling deals off the market and tightening borrowing criteria, making it harder for first-time buyers to get on the housing ladder and adding hundreds of pounds to the monthly mortgage bills of existing mortgagors.

site_title: Biological threats, misinformation among AI’s risks, says ex-Google CEO
summary: Former Google CEO Eric Schmidt warns that AI poses near-term risks, including the creation of dangerous pathogens and the spread of misinformation. He states that AI systems could be used by bad actors to "accelerate at scale," causing thousands of people to be harmed and killed. Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella also emphasizes the need for conversations on responsible AI and its societal impact, calling for regulation of the technology to address significant dangers.

images.alt_text: Databricks chief executive Ali Ghodsi believes that MosaicML can get to US$50 to US$100 million in annual recurring revenue in 12 months.
It can be tough to write about machines without metaphors. But AI is too important for loose language.
The funding comes less than two months after the company, founded by LinkedIn co-founder Reid Hoffman and Google DeepMind co-founder Mustafa Suleyman (above), released its chatbot, Pi.

site_title: Meta oversight board urges Cambodia prime minister's suspension from Facebook
summary: The Meta Oversight Board recommended suspending Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen from Facebook for six months due to a video posted on his page that threatened violence against political rivals. Meta agreed to remove the video but said it would review the recommendation to suspend Hun Sen. The decision highlights concerns over Meta's handling of election integrity and its treatment of authoritarian leaders, particularly in the run-up to elections. A suspension would silence Hun Sen's Facebook page just weeks before Cambodia's election, which critics say will be a sham.

images.alt_text: In the coming weeks, the FTC, led by commissioner Lina Khan, plans to file a far-reaching antitrust suit focused on Amazon’s core online marketplace.

site_title: Celebrity butcher Dario Cecchini has a beef with Singapore
summary: Celebrity butcher Dario Cecchini has opened his new restaurant, Bottega di Carna, in Singapore's Mondrian hotel. The Italian restaurateur, known for his expertise in traditional butchery, aims to raise awareness about responsible and sustainable meat consumption. Cecchini's restaurant concept emphasizes using every part of the animal, from the "fifth quarter" or offal, to promote a more mindful approach to eating. He hopes to inspire a new generation of butchers and chefs to adopt more ethical and creative approaches to food.

site_title: China to take measures to promote household consumption
summary: China's cabinet meeting, chaired by Premier Li Qiang, has agreed to take measures to promote household consumption amid concerns about the stuttering post-Covid economic recovery. The measures, expected to be unveiled in July, will focus on boosting consumer spending and economic growth. The plan involves coordinated policies for renovating neighborhoods, homes, and recycling networks, as well as supporting elderly housing. This comes as China's economy has slowed in recent months, with property investment, industrial output, and retail sales growth missing forecasts, prompting calls for further stimulus.

images.alt_text: China’s property sector is a key growth driver, accounting for about 30 per cent of its economic output. The sector is facing strong headwinds.

site_title: Meituan buys co-founder’s months-old AI startup for US$234 million
summary: Meituan has acquired Light Year, a generative AI startup co-founded by Wang Huiwen, for approximately US$234 million. The deal brings Meituan into a Chinese AI development contest with rivals Baidu, Tencent Holdings, and Alibaba Group Holding. Light Year's technology and talent will strengthen Meituan's competitiveness in AI, with the company citing the acquisition as a key step in its AI development strategy.

site_title: Invest in human capital for successful business transformation
summary: Investing in human capital is crucial for successful business transformation, especially in today's digital age. According to Workforce Singapore, companies must bring employees along on the transformation journey to equip them with necessary skills to keep pace with digitalisation and automation. The Jobs Transformation Maps (JTMs) provide in-depth studies on emerging trends and workforce shifts, enabling businesses to identify emerging positions, redesign jobs, and provide training for employees. By investing in human capital, companies can maximize employees' potential and remain competitive and adaptable in an ever-changing environment.

images.alt_text: In line with the new Jobs Transformation Map (JTM) for food services, trade associations and chambers in the sector have committed to work with over 800 member companies, employing around 80,000 workers, to transform their jobs.
Minister for Transport Dr Tan See Leng encourages retailers to adapt to shifting consumer demands.

site_title: Inflation up in German states, pointing to national rise
summary: German inflation rates rose in five economically important states in June, with rates of 6.2-6.9%, surpassing May's rates of 5.7-6.6%. This suggests a potential national rise in inflation, contradicting the European Central Bank's hopes that inflation has turned a corner. The ECB continues to monitor inflation, having lifted interest rates by 400 basis points over the past year, with further rate hikes expected in July and September.

images.alt_text: Spain's consumer prices have risen 1.6 per cent in June from a year earlier, but down from 2.9 per cent the previous month.

site_title: UK homeowners pay down mortgage debt for second month running
summary: UK homeowners made a net repayment of mortgage debt for the second month in May, repaying £100 million more than they borrowed, according to the Bank of England. This follows a £1.5 billion repayment in April, the first back-to-back reduction in secured lending since 1993. Mortgage approvals rose slightly to 50,524, but remain below pre-pandemic levels, as lenders tighten borrowing criteria and push up loan costs. The effective interest rate on new mortgages rose to 4.56% in May, amid speculation of future interest rate hikes to combat inflation.

site_title: Brisk interest in SL Green's Park Avenue tower shows strength in pockets of NY market
summary: SL Green Realty's 245 Park Avenue tower sold for $2 billion, a small premium to its previous sale price, after Japanese developer Mori Trust acquired a 50% stake. The property was nearly 84% occupied at the end of Q1, attracting foreign investors. However, experts warn that lower-quality offices face challenges, with vacancies rising in Q1 and potential defaults expected in the fall. This sale is seen as a positive sign for prime locations convenient for commuters, but does not accurately reflect the overall market.

images.alt_text: Global Holdings also has been involved in building luxury condo projects in Manhattan.

site_title: Credit Suisse money-laundering case faces axe in boost to UBS
summary: Prosecutor Yves Bertossa is dropping a money-laundering probe against Credit Suisse, citing the lack of convictions in a case related to rogue banker Patrice Lescaudron, who was convicted of fraud and forgery. The decision comes after a series of court losses and a damages bill in the hundreds of millions of Swiss francs. UBS, which acquired Credit Suisse, must now grapple with more than a half-dozen legal issues, including a trial in London over a Mozambican bond scandal.

images.alt_text: UBS may be richer following its acquisition of Credit Suisse, but large mega-banks are more prone to operational risks.
The cull of staff at the Swiss lender will dramatically worsen what is already a dismal year for financial sector jobs worldwide.
Credit Suisse agreed to the fine on Jun 12, and Finra accepted the fine on Jun 23.

site_title: Sterling licks its wounds after previous day’s mauling
summary: The British pound remains steady against the US dollar and euro after a sharp 0.88% drop on Wednesday, its largest daily fall in seven weeks. The decline was attributed to Bank of England governor Andrew Bailey's comments on interest rate hikes and difficulties at Thames Water. Investors now expect further rate hikes in Britain, increasing bets on a 50-basis-point rate rise at the BOE's next meeting on August 3.

images.alt_text: Sterling is one of the best-performing Group-of-10 currencies this year, extending a recovery from a record low near parity against the US dollar in September to around US$1.23.

site_title: Chip industry globalisation under threat, says chief of China’s YMTC
summary: China's YMTC chairman, Chen Nanxiang, says globalisation of the chip industry is under threat due to geopolitics and national security concerns. He doubts the US$1 trillion forecast for the industry by 2030, citing government intervention and political content. Chen also agrees with TSMC's Morris Chang that globalisation in the chip sector is "dead". YMTC is affected by US export control curbs on Chinese tech firms, which have barred its suppliers from shipping US goods without a licence.

images.alt_text: Powerful chipsets from the likes of Nvidia and Advanced Micro Devices are crucial in training large AI models – but Washington bars those from the country.

The Biden administration last October issued a sweeping set of rules designed to freeze China’s semiconductor industry in place while the US pours billions of dollars in subsidies into its own chip industry.
In September, Nvidia had said US officials asked the company to stop exporting two top computing chips for AI work to China.

site_title: UBS joins Goldman, Morgan Stanley in trimming China stocks view
summary: UBS has lowered its year-end target for the MSCI China Index to 72 from 83, citing a reduced earnings growth forecast of 15% due to slowing growth momentum in China. This revision joins other banking peers, including Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, who have also slashed their targets on Chinese stocks. The move comes amid mounting investor pessimism, with the MSCI China Index losing 20% since a January high. The central bank has intervened to support the currency, and authorities have taken steps to combat negative market sentiment.

site_title: Renault raises 2023 outlook following success of new launches, shares jump
summary: Renault raised its 2023 financial outlook, aiming for an operating margin of 7-8% and automotive operational free cash flow of 2.5 billion euros, up from previous targets. The company's shares jumped 7% after the announcement, following the success of new models such as the Austral SUV and Dacia Jogger hybrid. Renault's CEO Luca de Meo attributed the upgrade to cost reduction efforts and the group's "unprecedented product offensive."

site_title: Indiana Jones gets less than a fitting farewell
summary: The fifth and final Indiana Jones film, "Indiana Jones And The Dial Of Destiny," fails to deliver a fitting farewell to the iconic franchise. Director James Mangold's competent effort is hindered by studio interference, resulting in a convoluted plot, excessive cameos, and an overemphasis on action over character development. The film's attempt to reinvent itself feels forced, with a disjointed narrative and a reliance on CGI work. At 81, Harrison Ford's Indiana Jones still has charisma, but his performance is occasionally tired and disinterested, unable to save the movie from feeling like an overwrought videogame.

images.alt_text: The dress is among more than US$12 million worth of TV and film memorabilia that will be sold at the auction, with bids ending on Friday.

Sony’s Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse took in US$19.3 million over the weekend, according to Sunday estimates from Exhibitor Relations, bringing its domestic total to more than US$317 million, with showings in international theatres pushing the cumulative global earnings to US$560 million.

site_title: Regulatory logjam in China offshore listings hits firms’ funding plans
summary: China's regulatory logjam is hindering offshore listings for Chinese companies, with no successful listings in Hong Kong or the US since the new listing regime launched in March. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) has accepted offshore listing filings from 14 companies and is awaiting additional documents from 38 others, with a waiting time for approval now at least six months. Only companies from selective industries have won approval to list offshore, and the process has become increasingly complex, with some companies facing delays of up to 30 days.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Chinese national flag flutters outside the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) building on the Financial Street in Beijing, China July 9, 2021. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo
The market has since attracted a variety of issuers, from the World Bank to Veolia Environnement and United Co RUSAL International, as well as offshore units of cash-hungry Chinese developers.
China's 18.8 per cent year-on-year slump in May industrial profits adds to evidence of an economy that lost steam on many fronts in the month.

site_title: US probe finds Chinese balloon used American tech: WSJ
summary: A US probe found that a Chinese spy balloon that floated over the US in February was equipped with American-made surveillance gear, including commercially available equipment for sale online. The balloon, shot down off the South Carolina coast, was found to have been filled with American equipment interspersed with Chinese sensors. Preliminary conclusions from the investigation suggest the balloon did not transmit data back to China, contradicting a previous report. US investigators traced purchase orders for the equipment to Chinese government officials, leading to renewed tensions in US-China relations.

images.alt_text: The suspected Chinese spy balloon drifts to the ocean after being shot down off the coast in Surfside Beach, South Carolina, U.S. February 4, 2023.  REUTERS/Randall Hill      TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY
Chinese foreign ministry spokesperson Mao Ning said during a press conference on Feb 6 that China had found out its balloon had drifted over the United States after being notified by it.
US Navy sailors recover the downed Chinese surveillance balloon off the coast of South Carolina on Feb 5, 2023. China has accused the US of more than 10 illegal flights into Chinese airspace.

site_title: Amazon to face its biggest challenge yet from the FTC
summary: The Federal Trade Commission (FTC), led by Commissioner Lina Khan, plans to file a far-reaching antitrust suit against Amazon, focusing on its core online marketplace. The FTC alleges that Amazon rewards online merchants that use its logistics services and punishes those that do not. This case could be a career-defining moment for Khan, who has previously argued that Amazon's market power poses a threat to competition. Amazon has a history of disputes with the FTC, with previous cases resulting in fines and settlements. The case is expected to be a dramatic outcome, with Khan potentially seeking to restructure Amazon.

images.alt_text: An Amazon.com Inc. logo at the Viva Tech fair in Paris, France, on Thursday, June 15, 2023. Viva Tech gathers startups, investors and executives from several countries and has become France’s leading event in technology and innovation. Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg

Visitors cast their shadows past a Google logo at the Viva Technology conference dedicated to innovation and startups at Porte de Versailles exhibition center in Paris, France, June 15, 2023. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes
This announcement follows Amazon’s cloud computing unit Amazon Web Services saying last month it will invest 1.06 trillion rupees in the country by the end of 2030.
The sale of the two Vancouver properties would be the first significant office transaction in the country since last April, when a tower in downtown Toronto traded hands for about C$380 million

site_title: China’s new law extends Xi’s combative foreign policy stance
summary: China has passed a sweeping foreign policy law, bolstering President Xi Jinping's combative stance on asserting Beijing's influence worldwide. The Law on Foreign Relations aims to safeguard China's national security and development interests, but stops short of creating new mechanisms to respond to rising geopolitical challenges, such as US-led export controls. The law incorporates Xi's signature initiatives, the Global Security Initiative and Global Civilization Initiative, and gives existing tools more weight. The move is seen as a significant step in extending Xi's foreign policy stance.

images.alt_text: “These remarks are absurd and extremely irresponsible,” said Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Mao Ning, referring to President Joe Biden who referred to China's leader Xi Jinping as a dictator.

site_title: Two or more hikes needed to cool inflation: Powell
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated that at least two interest rate increases are likely necessary this year to bring the inflation rate down to the US central bank's 2% target. Powell also said that the outlook is "particularly uncertain" and that the Fed is committed to a stance of policy that is sufficiently restrictive to bring inflation back to 2%. The timing and extent of any further rate increases will depend on the course of the economy.

images.alt_text: epa10691114 Federal Reserve Board Chairman Jerome Powell holds a news conference after the Fed refrained from raising interest rates following its two-day conference at the Federal Reserve in Washington, DC, USA, 14 June 2023. The Fed is pausing its interest rate hikes after raising them 10 times in a row to curb inflation.  EPA-EFE/JIM LO SCALZO

site_title: Binance’s European banking partner to withdraw support: CoinDesk
summary: Binance's European banking partner, Paysafe Payment Solutions, will stop supporting the cryptocurrency exchange starting September 25. This change affects euro deposits and withdrawals through the Single Euro Payments Area (Sepa). The move comes as Binance faces scrutiny from regulators to clamp down on money laundering. Binance had partnered with Paysafe last year to enable sterling deposits via Faster Payments in Britain. The decision may impact Binance's ability to process euro transactions, raising concerns about the exchange's operations amidst regulatory pressure.

images.alt_text: On Tuesday, Binance.US and the SEC agreed to work on a deal that avoids a total asset freeze at the cryptocurrency trading platform.
The SEC sought the asset freeze last week for Binance.US, a trading platform owned by Binance Holdings founder Changpeng Zhao.

site_title: Japan, South Korea agree to revive currency swap deal
summary: Japan and South Korea agreed to revive a $10 billion currency swap deal, designed to strengthen the regional financial safety net amid increased geopolitical risks. The deal, first agreed in 2001, was allowed to expire in 2015 due to diplomatic tensions. The revived agreement marks the first dialogue between finance ministers of the two countries in seven years and will be discussed further in a 2024 meeting in Seoul. The move aims to promote cooperation in various areas, including the global economy and infrastructure investment.

images.alt_text: The Japanese currency, often perceived as a safe-haven asset, is now coming under renewed selling pressure, threatening an import cost spike in a blow to consumers.

site_title: Shanmugam, Vivian’s Ridout properties among several where SLA spent over S$500,000 for repairs
summary: The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) spent over S$500,000 on repair works for several black-and-white bungalows, including properties rented by two ministers. The works are aimed at making these state properties habitable for tenants. SLA provided four additional examples of preparatory works done on Malcolm Road and Orange Grove Road, in response to media queries. This highlights the need for government agencies to address maintenance and upkeep of state properties, which may be in disrepair.

images.alt_text: The original rental rates for the Ridout Road properties – S$26,500 for Law Minister K Shanmugam and S$19,000 for Foreign Affairs Minister Vivian Balakrishnan – were no lower than official guide rents.

site_title: Nico Steel yet to address questions over plans to delist without an exit offer: Sias
summary: Sias, the Securities Investors Association of Singapore, has yet to receive a response from Nico Steel regarding questions raised by concerned shareholders about the company's plan to delist without an exit offer. The extraordinary general meeting (EGM) is set to take place on June 30, where shareholders will vote on the proposal. Sias president and chief executive David Gerald stated that shareholders have the right to ask and understand the actions taken by the board and the company regarding the provision of an exit offer.

images.alt_text: Sias lamented in a March commentary the "ridiculous lowball" offers that foment investor resentment and mistrust in the local market

site_title: Twitter’s new chief working on plans to bring advertisers back to platform: FT
summary: Twitter's new CEO, Linda Yaccarino, is working on measures to bring back advertisers, including introducing video ads, pursuing celebrities, and raising staff. The company plans to launch full-screen video ads on its short-video feed and renegotiate contracts with tech companies like Amazon and IBM. Yaccarino is also in talks about a broader partnership with Google, which would include advertising and data access. These efforts aim to revitalize Twitter's business beyond digital advertising, following a chaotic period under Elon Musk's ownership.

images.alt_text: A promoted tweet on Twitter app is displayed on a mobile phone near a Twitter logo, in this illustration picture taken September 8, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration
Major music publishers in the United States launched a legal suit targeting Twitter this month, arguing that the platform had failed to stop “rampant” copyright infringement.
Twitter in those cases is accused of failing to pay promised severance and targeting female employees and workers with disabilities for layoffs, among other claims.

site_title: Eurozone inflation expectations gauge hits seven-year low
summary: EUROZONE consumers' inflation expectations dropped to a 7-year low of 6.1 in June, according to the European Commission. This decrease suggests that price increases are not becoming entrenched in the economy. ECB President Christine Lagarde stated that it's crucial to keep inflation expectations anchored as the wage catch-up process unfolds, providing reassurance to the European Central Bank as it aims to bring consumer prices under control.

images.alt_text: The data from Germany, the eurozone’s biggest economy, comes as the European Central Bank is still looking for evidence that inflation has turned a corner.

site_title: Tourism in Napa and Sonoma bounces back with posh, outdoorsy resorts
summary: Tourism in Napa and Sonoma has rebounded, with the regions experiencing a surge in luxury resorts, tasting rooms, and wineries. New establishments like SingleThread, the Montage Healdsburg, and Stanly Ranch offer high-end accommodations, working vineyards, and wellness activities. The influx of tourists has led to increased demand for upscale experiences, with prices rising to $5,000 for a weekend getaway. Despite concerns over affordability, occupancy rates remain strong, with Visit Napa Valley reporting a 10% decrease in occupancy compared to 2019.

site_title: Appeal of plant-based foods wanes, but Asian startups and investors still in for the long haul
summary: Asian startups and investors are maintaining interest in the plant-based food industry despite the industry's waning appeal globally. Despite slow mass adoption in the region, Asian consumers are becoming increasingly aware of the global food crisis driving the plant-based movement. Startups are adapting by using local ingredients and recipes rooted in regional crops and culinary traditions to achieve price parity and consumer appeal. While investors' appetite for alternative protein is fading, some firms remain optimistic about the industry's long-term potential, citing growing demand for sustainable food options in the region.

images.alt_text: Singapore is among the top five countries globally for the availability of “meat substitutes” in restaurant menus, according to GlobalData.
Randall Ang, deputy managing director of fishball manufacturer Ha Li Fa. Ha Li Fa launched its first plant-based brand, Eat Plant Love, in October 2022.

Enthusiasm for alternatives to beef and pork surged in the aftermath of Beyond Meat’s 2019 initial public offering, and venture capitalists were willing to invest in companies that offered little more than a recipe book.

site_title: Toyota’s May global sales jump as parts supply shortage eases
summary: Toyota's global sales jumped 10% in May from the previous year to 838,478 vehicles, driven by a recovery in parts supply and growth in Japan and other key markets. Hybrid sales grew 25.8% to 261,147 units, accounting for nearly a third of total sales. This marks a significant improvement from the 2022 May sales, which were impacted by parts supply shortages due to the pandemic.

site_title: Europe’s financial stability risk remains ‘severe’ EU watchdog
summary: Europe's financial stability risk remains "severe" due to high inflation, low household disposable income, rapid interest rate hikes by the European Central Bank, and notable bank failures overseas. The European Systemic Risk Board warned that the downturn in the housing market could become more broad-based, with a decline in commercial real estate investment and credit demand. Despite banks' relatively good performance, the ECB has cautioned on increasing arrears and funding costs. The ESRB urged vigilance on asset quality and funding costs, highlighting the need for a strong financial sector.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the European Central Bank (ECB) is pictured outside its headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany, April 26, 2018. REUTERS/Kai Pfaffenbach/File Photo

site_title: China’s renewable ‘mega’ bases face hurdles even as sector charges ahead
summary: China, already a global leader in renewable energy generation, is racing ahead in building new wind and solar farms, with a total of 1,200 GW of wind and solar energy by 2025, five years ahead of its government target. However, progress on Beijing's most ambitious "mega" bases, which are technically more challenging and face stricter requirements, is slower. Only 1 GW of solar components are under construction among four main desert energy bases with a combined planned capacity of 119 GW by 2025, with the remainder still in the planning or permitting stages.

images.alt_text: China has devoted significant resources to the construction of renewable energy capacity in recent years.

site_title: China steel exports seen surging to seven-year high as home demand wilts
summary: China is expected to export the most steel this year since 2016, with exports in the first five months up 41% compared to last year. Weakening yuan and competitive prices are helping China offload surplus metal due to weak domestic demand. Strong demand from Asia and Africa is keeping a lid on stocks, and analysts predict exports could surpass 77 million metric tons. A weaker yuan and appealing export prices are the main reasons for the surge in exports.

images.alt_text: The government has set a modest GDP growth target of about 5 per cent for this year after badly missing its 2022 goal.
China's 18.8 per cent year-on-year slump in May industrial profits adds to evidence of an economy that lost steam on many fronts in the month.

site_title: All major US banks pass Fed’s annual stress test
summary: US banks pass the Federal Reserve's annual stress test, with all 23 major banks found to be well-positioned to weather a severe recession. The test simulated a global recession, significant declines in real estate and house prices, and a sharp unemployment rate. Despite projected losses of over half a trillion dollars, all banks remained above minimum capital requirements, with aggregate equity-to-capital ratio declining to 10.1%. The test results confirm the banking system's strength and resilience, but Fed officials remain vigilant about potential risks.

site_title: Asia: Most markets rise as traders weigh central bank rate plans
summary: Asia's stock markets rose on Thursday, building on the previous day's advances, despite central bank chiefs warning of further interest rate hikes to combat inflation. The US data soothed concerns about a recession, while China's economic outlook remains uncertain. Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell said policymakers are leaving the door open to two more rate hikes, while European Central Bank chief Christine Lagarde warned of rising borrowing costs. Japan's central bank boss indicated it could move away from its ultra-loose monetary policy, citing a forecast of increasing inflation.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan is in focus as it stands by its ultra-loose monetary policy, even with the yen weakening on the back of expected Fed rate hikes.

site_title: Sri Lanka unveils debt restructuring plan to tackle economic crisis
summary: Sri Lanka has unveiled a domestic debt restructuring plan to tackle its economic crisis, a key condition for securing a $2.9 billion IMF bailout. The plan offers a 30% haircut on dollar-denominated bonds, with international sovereign bond holders able to accept a reduction in capital in exchange for receiving the rest of their money back in six years at a 4.0% interest rate. The plan is part of efforts to restore stability after the country's economic and political crisis last year, which led to the ouster of President Gotabaya Rajapaksa.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka is struggling with the worst financial crisis since its independence from Britain in 1948 after the country’s foreign exchange hit record lows and triggered its first foreign debt default last year.
Sri Lanka’s economy was engulfed in its worst financial crisis in more than seven decades last year after its foreign exchange reserves dropped to record lows.

site_title: Hong Kong Stock Exchange to shorten IPO settlement period to two days
summary: The Hong Kong Stock Exchange will launch a new IPO settlement platform, FINI, to shorten the settlement period from five days to two days, starting in October. The platform aims to improve efficiency and collaboration among IPO sponsors, underwriters, and regulators. Additionally, FINI features a new public offer pre-funding model to alleviate large sums of funds locked up in over-subscribed IPOs. The move is expected to enhance the IPO process and provide better investor experiences.

site_title: China’s factory activity seen contracting for third month in June: poll
summary: China's factory activity is expected to contract for a third straight month in June, with the official purchasing managers' index (PMI) likely edging up to 49.0, according to a Reuters poll. This marks a marginally slower pace than the previous contraction. The government has set a modest GDP growth target of 5% for this year, after missing its 2022 goal. Economists are downgrading forecasts, and policymakers are expected to implement further policy stimulus to counter weak demand at home and abroad.

images.alt_text: China’s long-awaited rules for offshore stock exchange listings form part of a regulatory tightening on cross-border listings after years of a laissez-faire approach.
The market has since attracted a variety of issuers, from the World Bank to Veolia Environnement and United Co RUSAL International, as well as offshore units of cash-hungry Chinese developers.

site_title: Foreigners raise record yuan debt in China as global issuers tap low rates
summary: Foreigners are raising a record amount of yuan debt in China, with sales of panda bonds reaching $10.4 billion this year, the most ever. Lower interest rates and looser rules in China are attracting global issuers, driven by the divergence in monetary policy between China and the US. The yield gap between US and Chinese 10-year government bonds has reached 119 basis points, making yuan borrowing cheaper. The panda bond market's growth is seen as a rare bright spot in China's economy, aiding authorities' goal to globalize the yuan.

images.alt_text: China's 18.8 per cent year-on-year slump in May industrial profits adds to evidence of an economy that lost steam on many fronts in the month.

site_title: Australia job vacancies fall 2% in May quarter, still historically high
summary: Australia's job vacancies fell 2% in the May quarter to 431,600, the fourth consecutive decline. Despite this, vacancies remain 89% higher than pre-pandemic levels due to strong labor demand. The Reserve Bank of Australia has raised interest rates 13 times to 4.1% due to the labor market's strength, potentially leading to another rate hike next week. The percentage of businesses reporting vacancies increased to 25%, highlighting the impact of a tight labor market on various industries.

images.alt_text: The RBA unexpectedly hiked earlier this month to take the cash rate to 4.1 per cent from a record-low 0.1 per cent when it began tightening a little over a year ago.

site_title: Homebuilding costs in Canada soar as population surges
summary: Canada's residential construction prices have surged 51% since 2020, outpacing the consumer price index, due to high home prices, immigration-driven population boom, and shortages of workers and raw materials. Labour costs have increased 9.4% in the construction industry, while extreme weather has constrained lumber supply and driven up cement prices. The elevated costs have contributed to a decline in new home construction, exacerbating the affordability crunch. Experts suggest that increasing skilled workers through federal immigration programs could ease construction industry labour shortages, but warn that homebuilding costs are likely to remain elevated in the medium to longer term.

images.alt_text: A housing development is seen on the edge of the Ontario Green Belt in the Greater Toronto Area of Bradford West Gwillimbury, Ontario, Canada, on May 25, 2023. A billboard at the foot of a field on the far outskirts of Toronto heralds the coming construction of new homes, while highlighting a broken promise never to permit encroachment on this vast green space, which has provoked a public outcry. (Photo by Cole BURSTON / AFP)
The sale of the two Vancouver properties would be the first significant office transaction in the country since last April, when a tower in downtown Toronto traded hands for about C$380 million

site_title: Brands focus on stories in refining China livestreaming to boost profits
summary: Brands in China are shifting their focus from massive discounts to storytelling in livestreaming to boost profits. Major brands, including Apple, are partnering with hosts to create engaging content, rather than relying on discounts to drive sales. This approach is seen as more effective in building brand resonance and encouraging repeat business. The industry is expected to continue growing, with livestreaming sales projected to reach $480 billion in China this year.

images.alt_text: Argentina's Messi reacting during last week's friendly  match against Australia at the Workers' Stadium in Beijing.

site_title: Vietnam’s GDP growth improves but stays weak in Q2, as manufacturing remains soft
summary: Vietnam's GDP growth improved to 4.14% in Q2 2023, but remained slower than last year due to weakening external demand. The country's exports contracted 14.2% and imports declined 22.3% year-over-year. The services sector drove growth, with a 6.11% increase, while the industry and construction sector grew 2.5% year-over-year. The government's official full-year growth target is 6.5%, which may be difficult to meet. The central bank has cut interest rates to support businesses, but credit growth remains weak.

images.alt_text: The move is a bid to shore up Vietnam’s manufacturing-led economy at a time of weak global demand and slower credit growth.
FILE PHOTO: Cars and motorbikes ride in an avenue decorated to welcome the 13th National Congress of the Communist Party of Vietnam in Hanoi, Vietnam, January 25, 2021. REUTERS/Thanh Hue/File Photo

site_title: ‘Godfather of AI’ urges governments to face dangers
summary: Artificial Intelligence expert Geoffrey Hinton, known as the "godfather of AI," warned governments to take the risks of AI seriously, stating that the technology could take control of society. He emphasized the need for developers to understand potential risks and for a balanced approach to AI development. Hinton also expressed concerns about AI deepening inequality and the spread of "fake news" generated by AI-powered bots.

images.alt_text: The institute, an arm of the world’s biggest asset manager, has an overweight allocation for AI-related shares in developed markets.

site_title: H&M shares jump 11% as summer collection boosts profit
summary: H&M's shares surged 11% on June 29, reaching a 16-month high, as its summer collection boosted profit, beating estimates. The company's second-quarter sales increased 10% and inventory levels dropped 16.7%, a positive sign for the third quarter. Despite a squeeze on consumers' spending, H&M's operating profit margin rose to 8.2%, and the company reiterated its goal of a 10% margin next year. Analysts attributed the results to cost-cutting measures, which are starting to bear fruit.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The H&M clothing store is seen in Times Square in Manhattan, New York, U.S., November 15, 2019. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo
H&M said net sales were up 12 per cent from a year earlier to 54.9 billion krona (S$7.1 billion).

site_title: World Bank approves US$700 million for crisis-hit Sri Lanka
summary: The World Bank approved a $700 million budgetary and welfare support package for crisis-hit Sri Lanka, the largest funding tranche since an IMF deal in March. The package includes $500 million for budgetary support and $200 million for welfare support. The funds aim to stabilize the economy, implement structural reforms, and protect the poor and vulnerable. This is part of a broader bailout package that includes a $3 billion IMF deal and potential funding from the Asian Development Bank and other multilateral agencies. The move aims to help Sri Lanka recover from its worst financial crisis since independence in 1948.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka’s economy was engulfed in its worst financial crisis in more than seven decades last year after its foreign exchange reserves dropped to record lows.
Globally popular Ceylon Tea is Sri Lanka’s highest foreign exchange-earning crop, brewing US$1.25 billion for the cash-strapped country last year, according to government data.

site_title: Banks need to speak the same digital language
summary: Global banks face significant operational risks due to complex, opaque, and outdated systems. The acquisition of Credit Suisse by UBS has increased complexity, with multiple standalone systems and legacy systems from the 1970s posing high risks of failure. This lack of a common language for financial information makes it difficult to identify and manage risks, threatening the stability of the global banking system. Estimated annual losses to operational risks are $190 billion, and devastating knock-on effects can occur when banks fail. Implementing artificial intelligence (AI) and a common language, such as the Financial Industry Business Ontology, may help integrate and virtualize data from multiple systems, enabling strategic risk-based decisions.

images.alt_text: The cull of staff at the Swiss lender will dramatically worsen what is already a dismal year for financial sector jobs worldwide.
All European banks are required to keep that ratio above 100 per cent and bigger lenders tend to publish the figure on a quarterly basis.

site_title: Spanish inflation now under 2% ECB goal, at 2-year low
summary: Spain's consumer prices rose 1.6% in June from a year earlier, the lowest in over two years, bringing inflation below the 2% target set by the European Central Bank. This marks a significant improvement from the 2.9% increase in the previous month. Despite this, ECB officials remain concerned about the underlying pace of price growth in the euro area, which is expected to have re-accelerated. The data provides a small victory for Frankfurt officials in their efforts to tame cost increases across the wider euro region.

images.alt_text: A tourist looks at abarcas (typical Menorcan footwear), at a workshop in the town of Mahon, on the Balearic Island of Menorca on June 25, 2023. (Photo by JAIME REINA / AFP)

site_title: Fewer Chinese visitors to derail Thailand’s tourism target
