The US must strike a balance between promoting its economic interests and avoiding protectionism.

images.alt_text: Anthony Blinken’s upcoming visit to Beijing could possibly provide an opportunity to announce an agreement on cooperation over issues of common interest.
The International Monetary Fund has warned of the repercussions of capital flows being fragmented along geopolitical fault lines.
Congress has passed the biggest foreign aid package since the end of the Cold War.
The Chips Act was a response to technological advances by China, regarded by a strong consensus in Washington as America’s leading global geo-strategic and geo-economic rival.

site_title: Public garden versus affordable housing: Court rules for housing
summary: A New York appellate court has ruled in favor of a 123-apartment development for lower-income people older than 62 and their families on a publicly-owned site in Manhattan, known as the Elizabeth Street Garden. The garden, a popular community space, had been at the center of a 10-year fight between housing advocates and garden supporters. The court's decision overturns a lower-court ruling that had stopped the project, with city officials hailing it as a "huge win" in addressing the city's housing shortage.

site_title: Biden says he thinks US economy will avoid potential recession
summary: US President Joe Biden believes the US economy will avoid a potential recession, citing a strong labor market and efforts to control inflation. Recent data shows new home purchases, durable goods orders, and consumer confidence beating expectations, indicating a resilient economy. Economists predict the economy will narrowly avoid a recession this year, but underlying inflation may be faster than expected. Biden's comments come ahead of his "Bidenomics" address on his economic policy, aimed at improving perceptions of his job performance before the 2024 election.

images.alt_text: US broadband companies have been reluctant to provide access to low-population, rural communities because the investments are expensive and the regions do not offer a lot of subscribers.

site_title: Fewer Chinese visitors to upset Thailand’s tourism recovery goal
summary: Thailand is likely to miss its goal of hosting 30 million foreign tourists in 2023, with inbound arrivals from China expected to drop below five million, significantly lower than the government's seven million target. This is due to China's economic slowdown, which may crimp demand for outbound tourism. As a result, Thailand's annual foreign tourist arrivals are forecast to be between 26 million and 28 million, still a significant recovery from last year's 11.2 million.

images.alt_text: epa10645508 Foreign tourists and Chinese tourists dressed in Thai traditional costumes rented from a clothing rental shop visit Wat Arun or Temple of Dawn in Bangkok, Thailand, 22 May 2023. According to Deputy Government Spokesperson Traisulee Traisaranakul, 9.47 million foreign tourists visited Thailand since January 2023 generating about 391 billion Thai baht (11.36 billion US dollars or 10.50 billion euro) in revenue. Further growth is projected in Thailand's tourism industry with an expected increase of seven million Chinese tourists arrivals this year.  EPA-EFE/RUNGROJ YONGRIT

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore shares rose on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.5% at 3,220.76. The market followed US and European gains, with 82 gainers outnumbering 32 losers. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC opened higher, while Singtel and Thomson Medical traded briskly. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also rose, driven by solid US data.

images.alt_text: Agricultural group Don Agro plans to dispose of the bulk of its stakes in four subsidiaries.

site_title: South Koreans get younger as traditional age system dropped
summary: South Korea has dropped its traditional age counting system, which counted months in the womb as a person's first year of life, and will now use the international system that calculates age according to a person's actual date of birth. The change, effective immediately, means that people will officially become a year or two younger. While the change has limited practical impact, the government hopes it will ease confusion and reduce disputes over pension and travel benefits. The shift is expected to gradually neutralize South Korea's hierarchical age-based culture, allowing people to communicate more easily without using honorifics based on age.

images.alt_text: In this photo taken on March 29, 2023, Korean-American entertainer Jay Park reacts during an interview in Seoul. The 36-year-old is now one of South Korea's most recognisable entertainers: he's founded two of the country's largest hip-hop labels, released a string of hits, has his own soju liquor brand and was the first Asian-American to sign with Jay-Z's Roc Nation. (Photo by Anthony WALLACE / AFP) / To go with AFP story SKorea-Kpop-music-entertainment, INTERVIEW

Tanaka, whose real name is Kim Kyung Wook, speaks during an interview with Reuters in Seoul, South Korea, May 16, 2023.  Young Koreans are fueling a sharp rebound in demand for Japanese culture and consumer products.

site_title: Asean capital market regulators: Let global sustainability disclosure standards be tailored to Asean context
summary: Asean capital market regulators have welcomed global sustainability disclosure standards but plan to tailor them to their respective jurisdictions. The International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB) has launched two sustainability disclosure standards, S1 and S2, which require companies to conduct climate-scenario analysis and report on "Scope 3" emissions. Regulators will have flexibility to customize these standards for companies in their jurisdictions, with some considering a phased approach to accommodate varying levels of readiness. This will help build capacity and reduce the burden on smaller companies, such as SMEs, which are still recovering from the COVID-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: South-east Asian governments must help their small and medium-sized enterprises to meet the accounting profession's new sustainability reporting standards.
Hua Jingdong, vice-chair of the International Sustainability Standards Board.
Invest and grow charts concept Credit: PIXABAY

site_title: FTX halts sale of its US$500 million stake in AI startup Anthropic
summary: FTX has halted the sale of its US$500 million stake in AI startup Anthropic, reportedly due to a pause in bidding after several months of interest from potential buyers. Anthropic, founded in 2021 by former OpenAI employees, has become one of the hottest companies in the current AI boom, valued at US$4.6 billion. The halt follows a period during which multiple bidders assessed private information about the stake, with expectations of fetching "nine figures."

images.alt_text: Powerful chipsets from the likes of Nvidia and Advanced Micro Devices are crucial in training large AI models – but Washington bars those from the country.
The Commerce Department will stop the shipments of chips made by Nvidia and other chip companies to customers in China as early as July, says the report.

site_title: E-commerce may not work for all heartland enterprises – and that’s okay
summary: Singapore's Heartlands Go Digital scheme, launched in 2020 to encourage small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to go online, has seen a significant drop-off in e-commerce efforts post-pandemic. About half of merchants who expired their subsidized Carousell for Business subscriptions did not renew them, with lower needs for digital solutions after pandemic restrictions eased. The government has adapted its support, removing digital commerce solutions from the current edition of Heartlands Go Digital and introducing visual merchandising solutions to help enterprises improve their physical stores.

images.alt_text: Brothers Ang Eng Guan (left) and Ang Eng Hwa set up Soon Lee Heng (SLH) Fresh Fruits Trading in 2014.

Under the Heartland Innovation and Transformation (HIT) Programme, more modular temporary spaces in mature heartland precincts will be constructed and made available for enterprises to use these spots to test out new business ideas.

site_title: China’s industrial profits tumble, deepening economic gloom
summary: China's industrial profits declined 18.8% year-over-year in May, deepening economic gloom. The decline follows a 20.6% contraction in the first four months of 2023, with retail sales, exports, and property investment also showing weakness. The Chinese government is expected to deliver more policy support to stabilize the economy, with Premier Li Qiang promising more effective measures to expand domestic demand. Industrial profits remain a concern, with 24 of 41 major sectors posting declines, and foreign firms and private-sector companies also experiencing significant losses.

images.alt_text: The crop in Xinjiang, which accounts for about 90 per cent of China’s cotton, is currently at risk from high temperatures and hailstorms, just a few months after cold weather disrupted sowing.

site_title: Don Agro shares hit 16-month high after proposed sale of crop, milk businesses
summary: Don Agro International shares rose 89.5% to a 16-month high on June 28 after the group proposed the sale of its crop and milk production businesses. The sale, through subsidiary JSC Tetra, is valued at around S$113 million and will leave flour milling as the remaining revenue-generating business. The deal aims to re-strategize the group's financial and capital resources, with expected net tangible assets and earnings per share to increase.

images.alt_text: Singapore-based firms not affected by Russia-Ukraine conflict
Russia-based Don Agro says operations face minimal impact from current events
Don Agro to seek legal views on implications of Russian sanctions
180 vehicles, including 58 grain harvesters, were deployed by Don Agro for this year’s harvest.

site_title: Samsung beefs up chip foundry business as it looks to challenge TSMC
summary: Samsung is expanding its chip foundry business, aiming to challenge market leader TSMC. The company plans to introduce 2-nanometer production for mobile phone parts by 2025 and increase output in South Korea and Texas. This move is a response to Intel's entry into the foundry market and sluggish demand for mobile and personal computer parts. Samsung's foundry division, which produces chips for customers on a contract basis, will benefit from the expansion.

images.alt_text: Powerful chipsets from the likes of Nvidia and Advanced Micro Devices are crucial in training large AI models – but Washington bars those from the country.
The Commerce Department will stop the shipments of chips made by Nvidia and other chip companies to customers in China as early as July, says the report.

site_title: Shanmugam, Vivian’s Ridout rents at S$26,500 and S$19,000; reviews by CPIB, SM Teo find no wrongdoing
summary: Singapore's Corruption Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) found no evidence of corruption or criminal wrongdoing in the rental of state-owned bungalows to two ministers, K Shanmugam and Vivian Balakrishnan. The original rental rates were no lower than official guide rents, and the ministers conducted themselves properly in the transactions. A separate review by Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean also found no conflicts of interest or wrongdoing. The CPIB report concluded that the ministers' actions were in compliance with procedures, and no further action will be taken.

site_title: SIA’s Goh Choon Phong sees total annual pay jump 86% to S$6.7 million
summary: Singapore Airlines' CEO Goh Choon Phong's annual pay increased by 86% to S$6.7 million, from S$3.6 million the previous year. The company rewarded eligible employees with a profit-sharing bonus of 6.65 months and a maximum total of 1.5 months of ex-gratia bonus due to record earnings and a continued recovery in the global aviation industry, resulting in a net profit of S$2.2 billion. The board also proposed a final dividend of S$0.28 per share, totaling S$0.38 per share for the fiscal year.

images.alt_text: DBS expects SIA's earnings to peak in FY2024.
SIA’s board has recommended a final dividend of S$0.28 per share. Including the interim dividend of S$0.10 per share, the total dividend payout for the fiscal year stands at S$0.38 per share.

site_title: NUS enters top 10 in global university ranking for the first time
summary: The National University of Singapore (NUS) has entered the top 10 in the latest Quacquarelli Symonds (QS) World University Rankings, ranking 8th globally. This marks the university's first time entering the top 10 and its highest ranking in the Asia region. The QS rankings, which feature updated methodology using three new metrics, also show NUS performing well in employment outcomes and international research network. NUS president Tan Eng Chye attributed the achievement to the university's faculty, staff, and students, while QS chief executive Jessica Turner praised NUS' dedication to research excellence and sustainability.

images.alt_text: Overall, median salaries increased to S$4,200 in 2022.
In the autonomous universities, annual enrolment in accountancy degree programmes has fallen to 5,182 in 2021, down from 5,650 in 2017.

site_title: GSK’s gonorrhea shot gets US FDA fast track as resistant cases multiply
summary: GSK's experimental gonorrhea vaccine has received fast-track designation from the US FDA, making it eligible for a sped-up approval process if it proves effective in an ongoing mid-stage trial. The vaccine aims to combat the growing resistance to treatment, with over 82 million people worldwide contracting gonorrhea in 2020. If successful, it could become the first preventive treatment for the infection, which can lead to long-term complications like infertility.

images.alt_text: Lion TCR's China headquarters at the International Biomedical Innovation Center.

site_title: Australia's Qantas appoints Rob Macrolina as new finance chief
summary: Qantas appoints Rob Macrolina as its new chief financial officer, succeeding Vanessa Hudson, who was named the airline's first female CEO in May.

site_title: Task force set up to persuade more to take up accountancy and change ‘boring’ tag
summary: A task force has been established in Singapore to address the decline in accounting degree students and dispel the perception that the profession is boring. The number of accounting degree students has fallen by over 10% in the past five years, and the number of graduates who become accountants or auditors has also decreased. Deputy PM Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for a workforce review committee to ensure Singapore has enough accountants. The committee, jointly headed by the Ministry of Finance and the regulatory body, aims to address the shortage and make the profession more appealing.

images.alt_text: Many foreign accountants in Singapore – most of whom were Malaysians – left in the early days of the pandemic, and could not return when borders closed.
In the autonomous universities, annual enrolment in accountancy degree programmes has fallen to 5,182 in 2021, down from 5,650 in 2017.

EY is on track to hire around 220,000 people in the 12 months to July 2023, having achieved its highest growth in nearly two decades in the previous period – and this is before a potential break-up of its auditing and consulting divisions takes effect. The break-up will create more jobs as well.

Up till 2016, at least 90 per cent of students that picked and got into National University of Singapore’s (NUS) accountancy course scored straight As for their A-Levels. With the drop in interest since, ABB/B was enough to secure a spot last year.

Mid-sized accounting firm Foo Kon Tan’s managing director Kon Yin Tong told BT that attrition rate has more than doubled from the previous year, even as talent pools shrank, with Nanyang Technological University (NTU) taking in fewer accountancy students.

site_title: Ramsay Health Care, Sime Darby explore sale of Asia joint venture
summary: Ramsay Health Care and Malaysian conglomerate Sime Darby are exploring the sale of their Asia-focused healthcare joint venture, Ramsay Sime Darby Health Care (RSD), valued at RM6 billion (S$1.7 billion). The joint venture, established in 2013, operates 1,530 licensed beds across seven hospitals in Malaysia and Indonesia. The companies are considering the sale after a previous attempt in 2022 failed, with a KKR & Co Inc-led consortium withdrawing a US$15 billion offer. Significant inbound interest has led the companies to explore the sale in the best interest of shareholders.

images.alt_text: Founders of digital health startups must understand the needs and perspectives of payers, patients, and providers, and demonstrate the value and scalability of their products.

site_title: China lures billionaires into race to catch US in AI
summary: China is investing heavily in artificial intelligence (AI) to catch up with the US, with billionaire entrepreneurs and tech firms pouring in billions of dollars. Despite US tech sanctions and regulatory hurdles, China is making significant strides in AI, with many Chinese startups and firms launching their own AI models and applications. The country aims to close the AI gap with the US, which currently leads in AI investments, with a goal of matching and surpassing US spending on AI technology. China's AI ambitions have significant implications for the global power stakes, with some analysts predicting that AI will shape the technology leaders of the future.

images.alt_text: The Commerce Department will stop the shipments of chips made by Nvidia and other chip companies to customers in China as early as July, says the report.

site_title: Five new one-starred restaurants raise Singapore’s  Michelin-starred restaurants to 55
summary: Singapore now has 55 Michelin-starred restaurants after five new one-starred restaurants were added, bringing the total number of one-starred restaurants to 46. The new additions include Born, Seroja, Willow, Poise, and Sushi Sakuta, with chef-owners Zor Tan, Kevin Wong, and Nicolas Tam among the winners. No new two or three stars were added, and former two-Michelin-starred Shisen Hanten was demoted to one star. The Michelin Guide 2023 awards also recognized Kevin Wong as Young Chef of the year and Seroja as the first restaurant in Singapore to receive a Michelin Green Star.

site_title: UBS preparing to cut over half of Credit Suisse workforce
summary: UBS is set to cut over half of Credit Suisse's 45,000-strong workforce, starting next month, as part of the bank's emergency takeover. The cuts will primarily affect bankers, traders, and support staff in Credit Suisse's investment bank globally. UBS aims to save $6 billion in staff costs and ultimately reduce its combined workforce by 30% or 35,000 people. The job cuts are expected to worsen a dismal year for financial sector jobs worldwide, following recent cuts at Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse says: “The decision is not final, and CS Life intends to vigorously pursue an appeal to the Privy Council."
Credit Suisse agreed to the fine on Jun 12, and Finra accepted the fine on Jun 23.

site_title: US considering new restrictions on AI chip exports to China: WSJ
summary: The US Commerce Department is considering new restrictions on exports of artificial intelligence (AI) chips to China, with shipments from Nvidia and other US chipmakers to China expected to stop as early as July. The ban would apply to top computing chips for AI work, including the A800 chip, and would require a licence to sell. Shares of Nvidia and Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) fell 1.4% on the news, following a September request by US officials to stop exporting these chips to China. The move is part of a broader effort to curb China's growing AI capabilities.

images.alt_text: Unesco’s work will be rooted in its 2021 Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence, which is based on “the promotion and protection of human rights, human dignity, and environmental sustainability”, the organisation says.

site_title: Pertamina plans to start making bioethanol from sugarcane, cassava this year
summary: Indonesian state energy company Pertamina plans to start producing bioethanol from sugarcane and cassava this year, addressing the need for feedstock to meet bioethanol mandates for petrol. The company has also begun production of green hydrogen using geothermal energy, aiming to double or triple its geothermal capacity in five to seven years. This move is part of Indonesia's efforts to reduce fuel imports and carbon emissions.

images.alt_text: A man unloads sugarcane from a truck at a market in Navi Mumbai on May 6, 2023. (Photo by INDRANIL MUKHERJEE / AFP)

site_title: Beyonce-flation? How stars are driving prices up as fans flock to concerts
summary: Concert ticket prices have surged, with fans willing to pay high amounts to see top music acts like Beyoncé, Taylor Swift, and Bruce Springsteen. The UK's recreation and culture prices rose 6.8% in the year to May 2023, driven by increased demand for live music events. Economists note that ticket prices have increased by 75% to 100% above face value, with some citing Beyoncé's shows as a factor in the inflationary trend. The demand for live music events is expected to continue, with 80% of consumers planning to attend more events this year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: 50th NAACP Image Awards - Show - Los Angeles, California, U.S., March 30, 2019 - Beyonce reacts after winning the entertainer of the year award. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni/File Photo

site_title: Stocks to watch: Don Agro International, Sabana Reit
summary: Agricultural group Don Agro plans to dispose of 99-99.99% of its stakes in four subsidiaries, valued at 6.2 billion roubles (S$113 million), following a trading halt request. Meanwhile, Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) will convene an extraordinary general meeting on August 4 to address a requisition by activist investor Quarz Capital, seeking to remove the Reit manager and internalize management.

site_title: Oil prices drop over 2% on interest rate hike worries
summary: Oil prices dropped over 2% on Tuesday due to concerns about interest rate hikes by central banks, despite lower US crude and petrol inventories during the peak summer driving season. Brent crude futures fell $1.92 to $72.26 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate futures dropped $1.67 to $67.70. Analysts attribute the price drop to the expectation that central banks will continue raising interest rates to slow demand in the overall economy, despite concerns about a slowing economy in Europe.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures rose 33 US cents, or 0.5 per cent, to settle at US$74.18 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate futures rose 21 US cents, or 0.3 per cent, to settle at US$69.37 a barrel.

site_title: Wagner chief heads into Belarus exile; Nato vows to protect allies
summary: Russia's Wagner mercenary group leader Yevgeny Prigozhin has fled to Belarus after an aborted rebellion, with NATO vowing to defend its allies. The move comes amid escalating tensions between Wagner and the Russian military, with Prigozhin blaming generals for thousands of Russian losses in Ukraine. President Vladimir Putin has sought to shore up his authority, but Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny has launched a stinging attack on the president. NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg has vowed to defend Nato members, while Belarus strongman Alexander Lukashenko has sought credit for mediating Prigozhin's retreat.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin gives a televised address in Moscow, Russia, June 26, 2023, in this still image taken from video. Kremlin.ru/Handout via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES. MANDATORY CREDIT.

site_title: US: Stocks bounce after solid economic data
summary: US stocks bounced back from weakness after solid economic data, with the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 1.7% to 13,555.67. Consumer confidence surged to an 18-month high in June, while new home sales and big-ticket manufactured items exceeded estimates. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 0.6% and the S&P 500 gained 1.2%. Investors expressed confidence in the economy, citing a strong indication that bulls remain in control.

images.alt_text: The S&P 500 opened higher by 8.54 points, or 0.20 per cent, at 4,337.36.

site_title: Sabana Reit to hold EGM on Aug 4 to vote on manager removal
summary: Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) will hold an Extraordinary General Meeting (EGM) on August 4 to vote on the removal of its current manager. Activist investor Quarz Capital has requisitioned the meeting, proposing the internalization of the Reit's management function by incorporating a subsidiary wholly owned by the trustee. The move aims to bring cost savings, resolve corporate governance flaws, and potentially increase distribution per unit. However, ESR Group, the Reit's manager, has warned that the change could destroy the value of their investment, and some lenders have also expressed concerns about loan covenants.

images.alt_text: The post-pandemic resurgence of Singapore Reits petered out rather quickly.
Sabana Reit owns New Tech Park, a six-storey industrial building with a ground level carpark at Lorong Chuan.

In response to a query from The Business Times, Quarz Capital said on Friday (Jun 23) said that an internal manager model for Sabana Reit would help transfer “significant value” from ESR Group to the Reit’s unitholders.
Should Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust be managed externally or internally?
Quarz offered a laundry list of improvements the new internal manager could pursue to boost Sabana Reit's performance.
Sabana Industrial Reit's NTP+ at 151 Lorong Chuan.

site_title: Global tech giants drawn to Vietnam’s big push to become advanced manufacturing hub
summary: Vietnam is gaining international attention as a hub for advanced manufacturing, with global tech giants such as Samsung, Apple, and LG Electronics investing heavily in the country. Samsung's $220 million R&D centre in Hanoi is its largest in Southeast Asia, and nearly all of its 2,000 staff are local tech talent. Other major investments include Apple supplier BOE Technology Group's $400 million factory and US semiconductor company Marvell Technology's integrated circuit design centre. These investments are expected to boost Vietnam's deep-tech startups and supporting industries, with the government aiming to become a high-income nation by 2045.

images.alt_text: Many global tech giants, such as Apple, Luxshare, Pegatron and Wistron, have decided to expand their production capacities in Vietnam in recent years.

site_title: How fintech drives international financial centres and regional cooperation
summary: Fintech has accelerated the development of international financial centers, promoting regional cooperation and growth. Digital assets, fueled by blockchain and tokenization, enable cross-border trading and investment. Sustainable financing, driven by green finance and carbon services, supports environmentally sustainable economic growth. Fintech also transforms regional cross-border payment systems, such as the multiple-central bank digital currency (M-CBDC) Bridge project, and promotes regional inclusive finance through initiatives like the Asean Financial Innovation Network (AFIN). These developments aim to enhance financial efficiency, connectivity, and sustainability, solidifying international financial centers as global hubs in the digital age.

images.alt_text: The development of various digital currencies over the past few years implies a need for digital representations of money, and it is the job of the central banks to meet this need, said Agustin Carstens, general manager of BIS.
MAS exploring links for cheaper, faster cross-border payments

epa10570963 IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva participates in a news conference at the IMF headquarters during the 2023 Spring Meetings of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank Group (WBG) in Washington, DC, USA, 13 April 2023. The Spring Meetings run from 10 to 15 April 2023.  EPA-EFE/MICHAEL REYNOLDS
To bridge the digital divide, governments must invest in both digital and physical infrastructure, as well as improve Internet penetration.

site_title: Singapore startup attracts high-profile backers for AI monocle
summary: Singapore startup Brilliant Labs has secured a $3 million seed round from high-profile investors, including Oculus co-founder Brendan Iribe and Siri co-founder Adam Cheyer, for its AI-powered wearable device, the Monocle. The Monocle, a pocket-sized lens that clips onto reading glasses, has a ChatGPT extension and can help users with daily tasks. The company plans to use the funding to bring its second wearable to market and develop additional functionality for the product, which aims to provide a more productive and augmented reality experience.

site_title: Tall task of implementing new sustainability accounting standards must start quickly
summary: South-east Asian governments must help small and medium-sized enterprises meet new sustainability accounting standards, known as S1 and S2, set by the International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB). Most listed companies in the region, such as Indonesia, Malaysia, and Singapore, did not report Scope 3 emissions, which are indirectly responsible for discharges in their value chains. To address the challenge, governments can focus on capacity building, fund research, and develop interoperability tools. With widespread support for the new standards, implementing them quickly is crucial to elevate corporate disclosures on environmental issues and combat climate change.

images.alt_text: Hua Jingdong, vice-chair of the International Sustainability Standards Board.
Invest and grow charts concept Credit: PIXABAY

It will be challenging for companies to report comprehensive and high-quality data in alignment with the coming sustainability reporting standards if organisations do not invest in and implement the right monitoring and reporting systems, along with new models and methods for data sharing.

Leading Singapore organisations have raised concerns about aspects of draft sustainability- and climate-related disclosure standards by the global accounting body International Sustainability Standards Board.

site_title: US truck startup Lordstown files for bankruptcy after Foxconn deal falls through
summary: Lordstown Motors, an electric vehicle startup, filed for bankruptcy after a dispute with Foxconn over a deal to produce pickup trucks in Ohio. The company had sought Chapter 11 protection from creditors amid a protracted dispute, with Lordstown accusing Foxconn of breaching its contract. The bankruptcy filing caps several years of struggles for EV startups that reached high valuations following reverse mergers. Lordstown listed $500 million in assets and liabilities in its filing.

site_title: Enterprise tech transitions for a more sustainable world
summary: Businesses are increasingly prioritizing environmental sustainability, with 42% of companies identifying extreme weather as disrupting their supply chains. The adoption of cloud computing, a key technology for reducing energy consumption, is on the rise. Cloud providers can service thousands of organizations, reducing the carbon footprint associated with individual hardware and data centers. By centralizing computing capacity and optimizing data centers, companies can reduce their environmental impact and achieve a more sustainable tech ecosystem. Technology leaders are playing a crucial role in measuring and tracking progress towards sustainability goals, creating transparency and accountability.

images.alt_text: Tropical data centres will soon be able to raise operating temperatures safely with new standards set by the government.
XPeng G9 electric vehicle (EV) flagship store in Beijing. Asia leads the world in solar, wind and electric-vehicle batteries.

site_title: MAS proposes to raise deposit insurance cap to S$100,000
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is proposing to raise the deposit insurance (DI) coverage per depositor to S$100,000 from the current S$75,000. The move aims to ensure that the vast majority of smaller depositors continue to be fully covered, maintaining a balance between coverage and cost. The proposed change would result in 91% of depositors being fully covered, and MAS is also proposing to give the regulator powers to state a specific time when deposit balances are taken as final and a time limit for DI compensation claims.

images.alt_text: Generic picture of Singapore financial buildings landscape

“Deposit insurance is not the primary way in which we safeguard the interests of depositors, be they small or large… a safe and resilient banking system is underpinned most fundamentally by a combination of pre-emptive safeguards,” said Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan.

site_title: Optima Carz Leasing revs up greening efforts
summary: Optima Carz Leasing, a Singapore-based car leasing company, aims to build a 100% sustainable fleet by 2030. Currently, half of its fleet is green, comprising 49% hybrid vehicles and 1% electric vehicles. The company plans to phase out all diesel vehicles by 2025 and go 100% hybrid and electric by the end of this decade. Despite low EV adoption rates among clients, the company expects take-up to pick up once more infrastructure and charging points are built by 2030. The government aims to install chargers at all HDB carparks by 2025 and deploy 60,000 EV charging points nationwide by 2030.

images.alt_text: Singapore is “on track” to quadruple solar panel deployment from 2021, the government said in its statement.

(Left to right) Patrick Adhiatmadja - Managing Director of Electrum, Catherine Hindra Sutjahyo - director and president of On-Demand Services at GoTo; Juli Oktarina - director of TBS; and Pandu Sjahrir - president director of Electrum, at the ground-breaking ceremony for the construction of the Electrum EV factory in Zone E of the Greenland International Industrial Center, Cikarang, Indonesia.
VinFast electric vehicles are parked before delivery to their first customers at a store in Los Angeles, California, U.S.,  March 1, 2023.

site_title: Europe: Shares inch up on China boost; rate hike fears limit gains
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.1% on Tuesday, snapping a six-day losing streak, driven by financials and luxury stocks amid expectations of further policy stimulus from China. China's Premier Li Qiang stated the country's economic growth in the second quarter would exceed the first and reach the annual target of around 5%. However, ECB president Christine Lagarde's hawkish comments on inflation and rate hikes limited gains. The financial sector led the gains, with luxury giants such as LVMH and Richemont also benefiting from China exposure.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: European Central Bank (ECB) President Christine Lagarde gestures while speaking to reporters following the Governing Council's monetary policy meeting, in Frankfurt, Germany June 15, 2023. REUTERS/Kai Pfaffenbach/File Photo

site_title: US home prices recover further as buyers battle for tight supply of listings
summary: US home prices rose 0.5% in April, marking a third consecutive month of growth, despite a tight supply of listings. The inventory shortage has led to buyers paying above asking prices in many areas. On a year-over-year basis, prices slipped 0.2%, with Miami, Chicago, and Atlanta reporting the highest annual gains. The housing market is still adjusting to mortgage rates that have doubled from early 2022, affecting affordability and discouraging homeowners from moving. Further improvement will depend on navigating mortgage rate challenges and economic weaknesses.

images.alt_text: With new construction activity at the highest level in more than a year, the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta’s GDPNow tracker is projecting that residential investment added 0.1 per cent to growth in gross domestic product in the second quarter.

site_title: CDL, Hong Leong, Frasers Property, CapitaLand units among 9 bidders for Plantation Close EC site
summary: Nine developers, including City Developments Ltd, Hong Leong, and Frasers Property, submitted bids for the 99-year leasehold Plantation Close EC site in Tengah, Singapore. The site, spanning 16,441.2 sq m, can yield an estimated 495 units. Bids were evaluated under a modified concept and price revenue tender system, with analysts expecting the winning bid to range from S$600 to S$680 per square foot per plot ratio. The site's strong connectivity and proximity to Jurong Lake District are expected to drive demand from Singaporeans.

images.alt_text: The Tampines Avenue 11 and Plantation Close land parcels can potentially yield about 1,685 residential units, said the Housing & Development Board (HDB) in a press statement.

site_title: US dollar hits 7-month high against yen; ECB comments boost euro
summary: The US dollar reached a seven-month high against the yen at 143.94 yen, driven by rising US interest rates and Japanese officials' vow to intervene if the currency moves become excessive. Meanwhile, the euro strengthened against the US dollar following hawkish comments from the European Central Bank. The eurozone's key interest rate is expected to rise to 4% or higher, and investors await US data on durable goods orders and building permits.

site_title: EU, Unesco to help developing countries shape AI rules
summary: The European Union and Unesco are partnering to help developing countries establish laws regulating artificial intelligence. The EU will provide 4 million euros to support events and advise governments. Unesco's work will be based on its 2021 Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence, focusing on human rights, dignity, and environmental sustainability. Thirty countries are already working on AI laws, and the EU aims to establish rules starting in 2026, although some developers have criticized the proposed text as too harsh.

site_title: Asean to drive the next decade of global trade
summary: Asean is poised to drive global trade growth over the next decade, with trade between bloc member states set to accelerate at nearly 9% annually. As businesses diversify into new markets, Asean's rise will extend to South Asia, East Asia, and the Middle East, with countries like Vietnam, Malaysia, and Indonesia benefiting from shifts. To succeed, companies must balance growth goals with resilient and sustainable supply chains, accelerating digitalization and achieving environmental, social, and governance compliance.

site_title: Malaysia’s Sarawak Energy plans 400MW floating solar capacity by 2030
summary: Sarawak Energy aims to install 400MW of floating solar power capacity at its dams by 2030, expanding its renewable energy capacity to meet rising demand from neighboring countries. The company is also building a 1,375MW hydropower plant in North Kalimantan and plans to reduce its reliance on coal to 10% by 2030. Sarawak Energy has signed agreements to export electricity to Sabah state and Indonesia's West Kalimantan, and is in discussions with Brunei and Singapore to export hydropower via undersea cables.

site_title: US core capital goods orders unexpectedly rise in May
summary: US core capital goods orders unexpectedly rose 0.7% in May, a closely watched proxy for business spending plans, after being revised down from 1.3% in April. The data suggests businesses remain cautious about new capital investment due to higher borrowing costs and an uncertain economic outlook, despite the Federal Reserve's rate hikes to cool inflation. Economists had forecast no change, with most expecting a recession by the end of the year.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after upbeat data, megacaps recover
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 rising 8.54 points, or 0.20%, to 4,337.36. The Dow Jones and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the Dow up 24.32 points, or 0.07%, and the Nasdaq up 53.47 points, or 0.40%. The recovery was driven by upbeat capital goods orders data, which alleviated concerns about a slowing US economy amidst Federal Reserve interest rate hikes.

site_title: Flexible exchange rates and emerging markets
summary: Emerging markets (EMs) that have floated their currencies since the 1990s have not achieved full insulation from external shocks, contrary to expectations. Despite flexible exchange rates, domestic financial conditions remain correlated with US interest rates and the value of the greenback. EMs face challenges in managing capital inflows and maintaining domestic financial stability, particularly during episodes of US dollar appreciation. To address these issues, EM authorities need to stimulate local savings, develop domestic capital markets, and implement macro-prudential policies, such as capital buffers and regulations on local banks' leverage. Additionally, EMs require access to US dollars during risk-off episodes, when exchange rates become grossly misaligned, and when bank failures force them to act as lenders of last resort in foreign currency.

images.alt_text: The half-century since the official demise of the Bretton Woods system of fixed exchange rates has shown the benefits of what replaced it.

site_title: Russian mercenary Prigozhin is in Belarus
summary: Russian mercenary chief Yevgeny Prigozhin flew to Belarus on Tuesday after a mutiny that has dealt a significant blow to President Vladimir Putin's authority. Prigozhin's "march for justice" aimed at settling scores with Putin's military top brass has raised the prospect of turmoil in Russia. A deal mediated by Belarus President Alexander Lukashenko allowed Prigozhin to move to Belarus in exchange for the return of his fighters. The future of Wagner, a deniable proxy war-fighting group, remains uncertain, with options including returning to Africa or attacking Ukraine from the north.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin gives a televised address in Moscow, Russia, June 26, 2023, in this still image taken from video. Kremlin.ru/Handout via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES. MANDATORY CREDIT.

site_title: Natural disasters caused US$80 billion in economic losses in Asia-Pacific, says Aon
summary: Natural disasters in the Asia-Pacific region caused US$80 billion in economic losses in 2022, with floods accounting for 61% of total losses. Aon estimates 1,739 lives were lost in Pakistan's monsoon floods, and over 33 million people were affected. The region experienced lower-than-average natural disaster losses, with insured losses of US$11 billion. The report highlights a "substantial" protection gap of 86% in the region, with floods remaining the costliest threat for the third consecutive year.

images.alt_text: The emergency comes after frequent flooding in Australia’s east over the last two years due to a multi-year La Nina weather event.
The high rainfall caused short-term disruption to harvesting operations and the evacuation of fruits, as well as poorer fruit quality.
Parts of Sittwe, the capital of Myanmar’s Rakhine state, are flooded and the ground floors of several buildings are under water.
Remains of destroyed houses almost a month after Hurricane Ian made landfall in Fort Myers Beach in Florida.

site_title: ECB staff preparing for new era of tighter money
summary: European Central Bank staff are meeting to work on a new framework for steering short-term borrowing costs, aiming to prepare for a scenario with less abundant liquidity, as banks start borrowing from the ECB to finance lending. The meeting follows efforts to curb inflation and consider options to adjust the "corridor" between interest rates, potentially raising the deposit rate to create a narrower gap. Policymakers are expected to make a decision on the corridor by the end of the year, with a July rate hike already promised and potential further moves in September or October.

images.alt_text: The ECB is expected to decide in October on whether to proceed with a digital euro for retail uses like payments from around 2026 at the earliest.

site_title: US consumer confidence rises to highest level since early 2022
summary: US consumer confidence rose to 109.7 in June, the highest level since January 2022, according to the Conference Board. This increase was driven by improved views on current and future conditions, with a gauge of current conditions jumping to 155.3 and expectations rising to 79.3. The labor market also showed signs of strength, with fewer consumers expecting a recession and more reporting jobs as "plentiful." However, buying plans for major purchases slowed, and inflation expectations eased, reflecting potential higher borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: FOLSOM, CALIFORNIA - MARCH 22: A sign is posted in front of an available home at a KB Home housing development on March 22, 2023 in Folsom, California. Homebuilder KB Home will report first quarter earnings today after the closing bell.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
FILE PHOTO: An employee works on an assembly line at startup Rivian Automotive's electric vehicle factory in Normal, Illinois, U.S. April 11, 2022. REUTERS/Kamil Krzaczynski/File Photo

site_title: Latest land tender results show caution among developers for big sites amid heightened risks
summary: Singapore's latest land tender results show caution among developers for big sites amid heightened risks. The top bid for the Marina Gardens Lane site, valued at S$1.03 billion, was made by Kingsford Group, while a UOL-Singapore Land consortium and CapitaLand Development secured the top bid for the Tampines site, valued at S$1.21 billion. The cautious sentiment among developers is attributed to cooling measures, reduced saleable area, high interest rates, and construction costs. The outcomes also reflect concerns over foreign demand, limited amenities, and schools in the vicinity, as well as the supply of homes in the area.

images.alt_text: Private residential properties in Singapore's prime areas are expected to be affected the most by the latest cooling measures due to the traditionally higher component of foreign buyers in these areas compared with the city-fringe and suburban locations.
The new launch is next to the upcoming Marina South MRT station.
The Tampines Avenue 11 and Plantation Close land parcels can potentially yield about 1,685 residential units, said the Housing & Development Board (HDB) in a press statement.
Mega Jurong Lake District site for 1,700 housing units, 1.6 million sq ft office space up for tender

site_title: Bank of America to expand in four US states, closing gap with JPMorgan
summary: Bank of America is expanding its US presence by opening new consumer branches in Nebraska, Wisconsin, Alabama, and Louisiana, bringing its retail footprint closer to rival JPMorgan. The expansion aims to serve clients under one roof and drive local community growth. With this move, Bank of America will have a retail presence in 39 states, compared to JPMorgan's 49 states. The bank's consumer banking accounted for 38% of its net income in the first quarter, and its network has shrunk to 3,800 branches from 6,100 in the last decade.

images.alt_text: epa10548296 A picture taken from the 61st floor of the US Bank Tower shows the building of the bank 'Bank of America' in Downtown Los Angeles, California, USA, 28 March 2023. According to reports from security company Kastle Systems, the occupancy in office building in ten major cities across the US is still at 50 percent of what it was pre-pandemic.  EPA-EFE/ETIENNE LAURENT

site_title: China ratifies WTO deal on fisheries subsidies
summary: China has formally accepted an agreement to cut state subsidies for the fisheries sector, as part of a global deal to eliminate billions of dollars in "harmful" subsidies emptying the world's oceans. The deal, struck by WTO members last year, aims to reduce subsidies estimated at $35.4 billion. China, the world's top fishing nation, is critical to the agreement's success, and its Commerce Minister has vowed to work with other members to push the deal into force. The deal still requires ratification by two-thirds of WTO members and finalization of some clauses.

site_title: Putin says Russia paid US$1 billion to Wagner group last year
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin revealed that the state paid over US$1 billion to the Wagner mercenary group, led by Yevgeny Prigozhin, between May 2022 and May 2023 for fighter salaries and incentives. Putin condemned the group's failed mutiny, ordering the loss of heavy weaponry and exile for its fighters. By confirming state funding for Wagner, Putin effectively portrayed the group as an arm of the state, reversing its previous heroic status in the Ukraine offensive.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin gives a televised address in Moscow, Russia, June 26, 2023, in this still image taken from video. Kremlin.ru/Handout via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES. MANDATORY CREDIT.

site_title: Malaysia central bank to intervene in FX markets as ringgit losses ‘excessive’
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, announced it will intervene in the foreign exchange market to stabilize the ringgit currency, citing "excessive" recent losses of nearly 6% against the US dollar. The ringgit is trading near a seven-month low. The bank believes the depreciation is not reflective of economic fundamentals and that ongoing government efforts to boost the export-driven economy will help stabilize the currency. The value of the ringgit will remain market-determined, with clarity on interest rates and additional stimulus measures in key trading partners potentially providing support.

images.alt_text: Analysts said the changing sentiment in local markets and recent developments surrounding domestic issues led to outflows of foreign funds, causing the ringgit to weaken further.

site_title: Manchester United raises annual forecast amid Champions League return
summary: Manchester United has raised its annual revenue forecast to £630-£640 million, citing strong commercial and matchday income due to its return to the Champions League. The club, currently in talks to sell itself, had previously forecast £590-£610 million. Adjusted profit is also expected to be between £140-£150 million, up from £125-£140 million. The US-based Glazer family, owners of the club, are negotiating a potential sale worth over $6 billion.

images.alt_text: Manchester United is widely seen as one of the most prized assets in all of sport.

site_title: New York court narrows Donald Trump fraud case; Ivanka dismissed as defendant
summary: A New York appeals court has narrowed a civil lawsuit against Donald Trump and his family business, dismissing claims against Trump's daughter Ivanka due to statutes of limitations. The court ruled that state attorney general Letitia James' lawsuit, accusing Trump of lying about asset values and net worth from 2011 to 2021, is barred by time limits. The court's 5-0 decision allows James to pursue claims against Trump and his adult sons, but not Ivanka. The lawsuit seeks at least $250 million in damages and aims to stop the Trumps from running businesses in New York.

site_title: Arsenal, Belgian FA among winners selected by Uefa for social change work
summary: UEFA announced the inaugural recipients of the "FootbALL Awards" on June 27, 2023, recognizing four organizations for their commitment to social change through football. The winners include the Belgian Football Association, the German Football League, Arsenal, and former France player Lilian Thuram. All four have demonstrated a commitment to sustainability and anti-discrimination issues, highlighting the power of football to drive positive social change across European communities.

site_title: Apple fails to end lawsuit over China sales comment by CEO Cook
summary: US district judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers has rejected Apple's bid to dismiss a class-action lawsuit alleging CEO Tim Cook defrauded shareholders by concealing falling iPhone demand in China. The lawsuit stems from Cook's November 2018 comment downplaying China's sales pressure. The decision clears the way for shareholders, led by a British pension fund, to sue over a one-day market plunge that wiped out $74 billion of Apple's value. The case now moves forward, allowing shareholders to pursue their claims against the tech giant.

images.alt_text: Apple says it disagreed with the ruling and will address it “through the NLRB process”.
The judge writes that Apple should be required to “cease and desist” from coercively interrogating workers about their legally protected labour activism.

site_title: China prepares to sell cotton from reserves on supply concerns
summary: China is planning to release cotton from state stockpiles to boost supplies amid concerns over a potential crop shortage in Xinjiang, the country's top cotton-producing region. High temperatures and hailstorms have damaged the crop, which could lead to a 10% drop in cotton acreage. China, the world's largest textile producer, has already seen a decline in cotton imports, and the sale of state reserves could either curb demand for overseas supplies or increase the need to replenish stockpiles. The move aims to mitigate supply concerns and maintain stability in the global cotton market.

site_title: MAS, SGX tie up with CDSC to boost global emissions reporting for companies
summary: MAS and SGX have signed a memorandum of understanding with the CDSC to link their ESGenome disclosure portal with the global Net-Zero Data Public Utility, a repository of climate transition-related data. This collaboration aims to strengthen global access to climate transition data of SGX-listed companies, starting work in Q1 2024. The move is expected to boost global emissions reporting for companies, enhancing transparency and sustainability efforts.

images.alt_text: Invest and grow charts concept Credit: PIXABAY
Fossil fuels remain dominant at 82 per cent of consumption, despite a strong showing from renewables.

site_title: Volkswagen China chief asks China’s premier Li for clarity on data transfers
summary: Volkswagen's China chief, Ralf Brandstaetter, met with China's Premier Li Qiang to seek clarity on cross-border data transfers amid rising tensions between Europe and China. The carmaker has established separate supply relationships with chipmakers in each region, including US-based Qualcomm and China's Horizon Robotics. Brandstaetter expressed concerns about the crowded electric vehicle market and lack of funds for its development, citing Volkswagen's 1 billion euro investment in a new development center in China. The meeting highlights Volkswagen's efforts to navigate complex global supply chains and technological partnerships.

images.alt_text: Rupert Stadler, former CEO of German car manufacturer Audi, attends his trial, at the regional court, in Munich, Germany, May 3, 2023. REUTERS/Lukas Barth/Pool
A federal judge rules that the counties could not prove that Volkswagen violated their regulations against tampering with vehicles’ emission control systems.

site_title: Hong Kong exports fall as global demand slump weighs on economy
summary: Hong Kong's exports declined for the 13th consecutive month in May, falling 15.6% from a year earlier, according to the Census and Statistics Department. Exports to India dropped 30.7%, while those to the US, Japan, and Korea also recorded double-digit declines. The decline is attributed to weak demand for goods from China and the world, posing challenges to the financial hub's economic outlook.

images.alt_text: The HKMA moves in lockstep with the Fed, given the local currency’s peg to the US dollar.

site_title: Stellantis aims to relieve ‘charging anxiety’ with new service for EV users
summary: Stellantis launches 'Charging & Energy' business unit to alleviate 'charging anxiety' for electric vehicle users, offering a platform called Free2move Charge providing access to over 500,000 charging points in Europe by the end of the year. The unit will also offer services such as home charging facility installation and advertising opportunities, with plans to expand to North America and other regions. The company aims to have 100% of European passenger car sales and 50% of US passenger car and light-duty truck sales as battery electric vehicles by 2030.

The world’s third largest carmaker by sales, last year launched Stellantis Ventures with an initial 300 million euros to invest in start-ups developing technologies.

site_title: Tackling the seafarer shortage with a slick promo video
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) has launched a recruitment video titled "An Adventurous Spirit" to address the global seafarer shortage. The 10-minute video features current seafarers sharing their experiences and benefits of working at sea, with a focus on showcasing the diverse and interesting career opportunities available. The video aims to attract more people to the maritime industry, particularly in the face of a projected shortage of 90,000 STCW-certified officers by 2026. The launch coincides with the Shaping the Future of Shipping – Seafarer 2050 summit in Manila.

images.alt_text: The OCIMF's ship inspection programme contributes to high safety standards in the global tanker industry.
A recent two-day conference in the Philippines explored the challenges and opportunities of shipping’s decarbonisation, including skills development for seafarers, and a “Maritime Just Transition”.
By the end of the Singapore Maritime Week 2023, top international industry leaders should have come away with a clear idea of Asian shipowners’ views.

Mukesh Sahdev, senior vice president and head of downstream at Rystad Energy, said that over the past 35 years, geopolitical events in big oil producers have increased oil prices by an average of 8 per cent over the five days after the start of the triggering event.

site_title: Academics can have a vital role in supporting Singapore’s startups
summary: Singapore's academia and industry must collaborate to foster innovation and bridge the gap between scientific discoveries and real-world applications. The complexity of internal startup processes and concerns about reputational risk hinder potential scientists from advising startups. Despite this, serving as advisers lends credibility to unproven therapies or clinical testing, making it a valuable contribution. Recognizing the reciprocal benefits of collaboration is essential for driving innovation and progress.

images.alt_text: Wanted: experts to sit on startups’ scientific advisory boards

site_title: Philippine police rescue more than 1,000 alleged trafficking victims
summary: Philippine police rescued over 1,000 people allegedly trafficked into the country to work for an online casino in Manila. The victims, including Chinese, Vietnamese, Singaporean, and Malaysian nationals, were lured with job postings on Facebook. Authorities are investigating whether the workers were involved in online scams, with this incident following a similar rescue in May. The Philippine National Police's anti-cybercrime group will examine the case to determine the extent of human trafficking and potential involvement in online rackets.

images.alt_text: A casino building shut down by police  in Sihanoukville in Preah Sihanouk province. Experts say the trafficked captives are held in large compounds in converted casinos in Cambodia, and in special economic zones in Myanmar and Laos.

site_title: Is the AI-led rally in US stocks a bubble?
summary: The US stock market has experienced a strong AI-led rally, with Nvidia being a poster child, trading at 37 times price-to-sales multiple. However, the rally's sustainability is questioned due to concerns over inflation, a potential recession, and the sector's reliance on cost rationalizations rather than revenue growth. Despite these concerns, generative AI has the potential to augment human knowledge, produce creative work, and add value in specialized areas, but its path ahead is likely to be bumpy with periodic setbacks.

images.alt_text: The benchmark S&P 500 Index as at mid-June had risen more than 22 per cent from a 3,577.03 closing low last October, crossing the widely-cited 20 per cent threshold for a new bull market.
bull, bear, stock

site_title: Pinetree Hill at Mount Sinai to start preview at prices from S$2,236 psf
summary: UOL Group's 99-year leasehold condominium Pinetree Hill in Mount Sinai will launch for preview on June 29 with prices starting at S$2,236 per square foot (psf). The 520-unit project, developed by UOL and Singapore Land Group, will feature three 24-storey towers with 78% of units having one to three bedrooms. Prices range from S$1.2 million for one-bedroom units to S$4.3 million for five-bedroom units, with a penthouse available. The project marks the first condo launch in the area in nearly 15 years.

images.alt_text: Overall resale prices rise 0.9 per cent from April.
Geneo comprises three properties at 1,5 and 7 Science Park Drive and will offer about 180,600 square metres (sq m) of gross floor area (GFA) upon its completion in 2025.

“The government will continue to monitor economic and property market conditions and calibrate the supply of future GLS programmes, as necessary, to help meet demand and promote market stability,” MND says.

site_title: Dutch court rules sultan's heirs cannot seize Malaysian assets
summary: A Dutch court of appeal has dismissed a bid by eight descendants of a former sultan to enforce a $15-billion arbitration award against the Malaysian government. The award was made in a dispute over a colonial-era land deal, with Malaysia claiming the process is illegal. The ruling is seen as a "landmark victory" for Malaysia, with Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim stating the government is "closer than ever to completely nullifying" the award. The decision upholds a previous Paris court ruling that the final arbitration award would be annulled.

images.alt_text: View from Pulau Mamutik to Mount Kinabalu World Heritage Site (WDPA ID 220292), National Park and ASEAN Heritage Park (WDPA ID 785) at the edge of Tenompok (WDPA ID 9851) and Crocker Range UNESCO-MAB Biosphere Reserve (WDPA ID 8796)

site_title: The next big thing or the next big bust?
summary: Investors must exercise patience to determine if generative AI is a long-term trend. Like smartphones, AI has shown significant growth since its emergence, but critics warn of valuations scrutinizing its potential. The article notes that trends can quickly fade, citing examples of consumer fads such as Roti Boy and Tamagotchi. Investors should remain cautious and monitor valuations to avoid getting caught up in a potential bubble.

images.alt_text: Nvidia is trading at 37 times price-to-sales multiple. Its price-to-earnings ratio based on 2024 earnings expectations is 55 times, way below the 300 times PE ratio on the Nasdaq 100 in 2000.

site_title: Nobel-winning lithium battery inventor John Goodenough dies at 100
summary: John Goodenough, Nobel Prize-winning inventor of the lithium-ion battery, has died at the age of 100. He shared the 2019 Nobel Prize in Chemistry with Stanley Whittingham and Akira Yoshino for their invention of the lithium-ion battery, which revolutionized modern life by enabling smartphones and reducing reliance on fossil fuels. Goodenough's contributions to the development of lithium-ion batteries paved the way for a fossil fuel-free society and improved the lives of billions of people worldwide.

site_title: Boustead Projects unit, subcontractor head into arbitration over contracts for work at waste treatment facility
summary: Boustead Projects' subsidiary, Boustead Projects E&C, has been served with a notice of arbitration by the liquidator of subcontractor Technics Steel over a breach of contract for a waste treatment facility project. Technics claims it was prevented from completing its work according to the original schedule and seeks around S$830,000 in payment and S$680,000 in damages. Boustead Projects aims to "vigorously defend" the claim, but its parent company's shares remain suspended due to a privatization attempt. The financial impact of the claim is yet to be determined.

images.alt_text: Boustead Projects granted another 3 months to comply with public float rule
Boustead Projects  shares have been suspended since Mar 28.

site_title: WHO warns Covid 'has not gone away'
summary: The World Health Organization's European office has warned that Covid-19 has not gone away, despite the global pandemic being deemed no longer a "global health emergency." According to the WHO's Regional Director for Europe, Hans Kluge, nearly 1,000 deaths occur weekly in the region, and an estimated 36 million people have experienced "long Covid" in the last three years. Kluge urged authorities to ensure vaccination coverage of at least 70% for vulnerable groups and emphasized the need for more research on long Covid to recover from the pandemic.

images.alt_text: People pass by the Europa-Center shopping mall, amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic in Berlin, Germany, December 14, 2020. REUTERS/Michele Tantussi/Files
None of the released intelligence definitively point to lab-related work as the cause of the pandemic.

site_title: ECB won’t be able to declare rate peak anytime soon, Lagarde says
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde stated that officials will likely not be able to declare the end of interest-rate increases anytime soon, citing stubborn underlying price pressures. The ECB will continue to hike rates in July, with a focus on the final stages of the rate push to bring down inflation. Economists expect officials to pause after July with a deposit rate of 3.75%, but money markets price a peak of around 4% later this year.

images.alt_text: The European flag flutters in front of the building of the European Central Bank (ECB) on October 5, 2011 in Frankfurt/M., western Germany. The European Central Bank could cut its key interest rates later this week, analysts predicted, as Frenchman Jean-Claude Trichet prepares to step down after eight years as the bank's president. site_title: Baidu claims its Ernie Bot now beats ChatGPT on key measures
summary: Baidu's Ernie Bot has surpassed OpenAI's ChatGPT on several measures, including general abilities and Chinese-language capabilities. According to a test by China Science Daily, Ernie 3.5 outperformed ChatGPT and the more advanced GPT-4. The new model also boosted training and inference efficiency, making it faster and cheaper to iterate and upgrade. Baidu aims to integrate Ernie Bot across multiple business lines and has set aside a US$140 million venture fund to invest in OpenAI-like startups.

images.alt_text: Baidu's fleet of robotaxis, under the brand Apollo Go, will be allowed to operate across an area of 188 square kilometres in China’s southern tech hub Shenzhen.
Baidu will use the pool to incubate projects built atop its Ernie AI model, in deployments as high as 10 million yuan apiece.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Condo resale prices rose 0.9% in June, a slower pace than April. Rental prices and volumes continued to rise in May, but at a slower pace. Singaporean Henry Yeo was sentenced to 12 months in prison for his involvement in the Wirecard case. Singapore companies will soon be able to showcase their climate transition commitments globally, while Databricks bought a generative AI startup for $1.3 billion. Natural disasters in the Asia-Pacific region caused $80 billion in economic losses in 2022, with only $11 billion covered by insurance.

site_title: WhatsApp Business users jump four-fold in three years
summary: WhatsApp Business has seen a four-fold increase in users over the past three years, now serving over 200 million users. This growth comes as Meta shifts focus to business messaging, aiming to monetize its messaging apps, WhatsApp and Messenger. Meta plans to introduce features allowing small businesses to run ads that click to the messaging platform without requiring a Facebook account, with personalized messages and fee-based services to be offered. This shift is seen as a response to an uncertain economy slowing down Meta's core advertising business.

site_title: Man cheated 62 victims from at least 12 countries of S$383k in one of Singapore’s largest rental scams
summary: A Singaporean man, Gibson Zeng Xianfu, 29, pleaded guilty to 23 charges of cheating and has admitted to scamming 62 victims from at least 12 countries of nearly S$383,000. The scam involved Zeng renting out non-existent units on Airbnb, with some victims paying deposits of up to S$7,000. The victims included students, professionals, and individuals from countries such as France, Germany, and the US. Zeng was arrested twice and has since made restitution of about S$29,800. He faces up to 10 years in jail and fine for each charge of cheating and dishonestly inducing another person to deliver property.

site_title: Surging India Internet stocks trounce China peers
summary: India's consumer technology stocks have surged over 20% in 2023, outperforming China's tech behemoths, driven by companies' focus on profitability and a booming economy. India's flagship Internet stocks, including Paytm's parent One 97 Communications and Zomato, are attracting investors due to the nation's growth potential and favorable ties with the West. In contrast, China's tech stocks have lagged a global tech boom amid geopolitical and regulatory risks, with some investors seeing undervalued opportunities in the sector.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Paytm QR code is seen at a grocery shop in Mumbai, India, November 10, 2021. REUTERS/Niharika Kulkarni/File Photo
This announcement follows Amazon’s cloud computing unit Amazon Web Services saying last month it will invest 1.06 trillion rupees in the country by the end of 2030.

site_title: Considering regret in optimal asset allocation for portfolios
summary: Investors traditionally consider risk as volatility, but this definition only captures one aspect of risk. Regret, an emotional response to underperforming assets, can also significantly impact portfolio decisions. A new research approach, developed by David Blanchett, incorporates regret into portfolio optimization, treating it as a distinct parameter from risk aversion. This method can lead to increased risk levels, especially for more risk-averse investors, as assets that inspire regret are often speculative in nature. The findings suggest that allocations to these assets may increase, and could influence how multi-asset funds are structured.

images.alt_text: blur, chart, computer

site_title: China’s May gold imports via Hong Kong dip as retail demand eases
summary: China's gold imports via Hong Kong decreased by 1.7% in May to 49.056 tonnes, down from 49.906 tonnes in April, according to Hong Kong Census and Statistics Department data. Total gold imports were also down 3.5% at 51.722 tonnes. The decline is attributed to easing retail demand, which has been weighed down by concerns over China's economy.

site_title: Blackstone looks to wind down fund holding riskiest CLO parts
summary: Blackstone's Blackstone Loan Financing Limited is seeking shareholder approval to wind down the fund due to a sustained slump in its stock price, trading 23% below net asset value. The fund, which holds parts of CLOs, aims to comply with risk retention rules by being the first to take losses. Despite a series of buybacks, the share price remains low, and the company plans to shut down in an orderly fashion, returning money to shareholders as underlying CLOs mature or are redeemed.

images.alt_text: Bellagio, one of the top-performing resorts on the city’s famous Strip, is operated under a long-term lease by MGM Resorts International, its original owner.
The world’s largest money manager began rolling out the BlackRock Private Credit Fund this month, targeting mom-and-pop investors while vowing to keep “an eye on risk”.

site_title: Byju’s seeks to raise US$1 billion to sidestep shareholder revolt
summary: Byju's, India's most valuable startup at $22 billion, is in talks with new investors for a $1 billion fundraising round to sidestep shareholder revolt. The company is offering preferential treatment in case of liquidation to win over new backers. Powerful shareholders and creditors are seeking to dilute founder Byju Raveendran's control after the post-Covid online education market slowed and the startup missed deadlines for filing results and an interest payment. If successful, the fundraising will help the company pay down a disputed $1.2 billion term loan and retain Raveendran's control.

images.alt_text: Byju Raveendran, founder and CEO of Byju’s, Bengaluru-based educational technology and online tutorial firm.

site_title: Singapore stocks end Tuesday higher, STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index rose 0.5% to close at 3,205.35, driven by bargain hunting and optimism over global economic issues. Top gainers included Jardine Matheson Holdings, Sembcorp Industries, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, while DBS and UOB were among the biggest decliners. Despite concerns over interest rates and global macroeconomic issues, traders focused on bargain hunting, with 1.4 billion securities worth S$973.1 million changing hands.

images.alt_text: A Paytm QR code at a grocery shop in Mumbai. India's consumer technology stocks are on a tear this year, including Paytm's parent One 97 Communications Ltd.
The Nikkei has lost a combined 3.1 per cent during the current, four-day losing streak, its longest since mid-December.

site_title: Bank of Thailand to further relax foreign exchange rules this year
summary: The Bank of Thailand plans to further relax foreign exchange regulations in the second half of 2023, aiming to encourage capital outflows amid a volatile baht. The measures include promoting local currency use and increasing foreign investment limits to up to US$10 million for Thai retail investors in foreign securities, up from US$5 million. This move aims to mitigate the impact of external factors on the Thai economy.

images.alt_text: The baht has been dragged lower in recent weeks as the coalition of pro-democracy parties have struggled to secure enough support from the pro-establishment senate to form a government.

site_title: Mizuho rolls out generative AI to all 45,000 bank staff in Japan
summary: Mizuho Financial Group has rolled out generative AI to all 45,000 bank staff in Japan, becoming one of the country's first financial firms to adopt the technology. The move aims to harness the power of generative AI, allowing employees to test out the service and submit pitches for innovative uses. Mizuho's general manager, Toshitake Ushiwatari, is embracing the technology, stating that it will "completely reset the world" and trigger disruptive innovation, despite acknowledging the risks.

images.alt_text: A man is silhouetted behind the glass entrance of a Mizuho bank in Tokyo July 29, 2011. Mizuho Financial Group posted a 35.6 percent fall in first-quarter net profit on Friday, hurt by the lack of anything comparable to its strong bond trading gains a year earlier, but kept its full-year forecast. site_title: Immunotherapy company Lion TCR raises US$40 million in Series B2 funding
summary: Lion TCR, a T-cell immunotherapy company, has raised US$40 million in Series B2 funding led by Guangzhou Industrial Investment and Capital Operation Holding Group. The funds will support clinical trials for its HBV-specific T-cell therapy targeting liver cancer cells and construct a good manufacturing practice facility in China. The company aims to develop treatments for various solid cancers and chronic viral diseases, including hepatitis B linked to liver cancer. Lion TCR plans to build a biotechnology ecosystem in Singapore and the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macau Greater Bay Area.

images.alt_text: There has been good progress along the Singapore-Sichuan Trade and Investment Committee's three themes – the Belt & Road initiative, innovation, and internationalistaion of small and medium enterprises – since the committee's last meeting, said Dr Tan.

site_title: Odey suspends two hedge funds after redemption requests surged
summary: Crispin Odey's hedge fund, Odey Asset Management, suspended two funds, including its flagship European hedge fund, due to high redemption requests from investors fleeing the firm following multiple sexual assault allegations. The firm received 19% of the flagship fund and 35% of the OEI Mac fund for redemption on July 3. Odey was removed from the partnership in June, and the firm is considering restructuring operations, which may allow clients to switch investments to a new fund.

images.alt_text: The name plaque of the businesses in the offices of Odey Asset Management in London, UK, on Wednesday, June 14, 2023.
