Hedge fund founder Crispin Odey leaving Westminster Magistrates' Court, after being found not guilty of indecent assault, during a three-day-long trial in London on March 11, 2021.

site_title: Britain says to sign cooperation pact with EU in financial services
summary: Britain is set to sign a cooperation pact with the European Union in financial services, marking a thaw in relations since Brexit. The memorandum of understanding, which was part of the Brexit deal, will help support the sector's role as a global financial hub. UK Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt said the agreement builds on existing arrangements with the US, Japan, and Singapore, and is a mutually beneficial relationship for both sides.

images.alt_text: Inflation has proven particularly sticky in the UK with the consumer prices index rising the same amount in May as the previous month.
The CBI says retail sales volumes are average for the time of year at +1 per cent in June compared with -18 per cent in May.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei posts longest losing streak of 2023 as tech slides
summary: Japan's Nikkei index slipped 0.49% to 32,538.33 on Tuesday, extending its four-day losing streak to 3.1% - its longest since mid-December. Despite tech sector losses, Chinese equities rose amid anticipation of Beijing's imminent stimulus. The Nikkei had reached a 33-year peak last week, prompting investors to book profits. Analysts project the Nikkei could finish the year between 34,000 and 35,000, with some long-term investors considering increasing allocations.

images.alt_text: As widely expected, the Bank of Japan kept intact its short-term interest rate target at -0.1 per cent and that for the 10-year bond yield around 0 per cent at the two-day meeting that ended on Friday.

site_title: Supply-chain startup Baskit raises US$3.3 million seed round
summary: Supply-chain startup Baskit has raised US$3.3 million in a seed round led by Betatron Venture Group, Forge Ventures, and Indonesian tobacco tycoon Michael Sampoerna. This follows the company's US$1.5 million pre-seed funding in March. Baskit, launched in November 2022, provides technology and commercial support to distributors and wholesalers in Indonesia, with month-on-month revenue growth exceeding 70%. The funds will be used to expand to more cities and develop its technology infrastructure, highlighting the increasing need for tech solutions in Indonesia's supply-chain sector.

site_title: PwC Australia asset sale unlikely to solve firm’s tarnished reputation
summary: PwC Australia's sale of its government consulting business to private equity firm Allegro Funds may provide temporary relief but is unlikely to repair the firm's tarnished reputation. The sale comes after a former partner shared confidential government plans to prevent tax avoidance with colleagues, damaging the firm's brand. Experts say the sale will not resolve past behavior and may lead to further staff exodus, with Allan Fels warning that the firm's reputation will affect its business. The sale also fails to address the underlying issues, with the firm remaining saddled with its tax practice at the heart of the scandal.

images.alt_text: The firm has already placed nine partners on leave and named four former partners directly involved in the breach who have since left the firm.
PwC on Sunday announced the sale of its government business for A$1.
PwC is reportedly planning to sell off its government consulting arm to private equity investor Allegro Funds for just A$1 (S$0.90).
Several major pension funds have frozen work with PwC and Australia’s most populous state bans the firm from new tax work for three months.

site_title: China calls West’s economic de-risking a ‘false proposition’
summary: China's Premier Li Qiang criticized the West's efforts to "de-risk" their economies by reducing reliance on China, calling it a "false proposition." The US and EU have been moving to reduce their economic ties with China, but Li said this approach is misguided, implying it will not lead to economic stability.

images.alt_text: The currency had suffered its biggest decline in nearly five months on Monday as sentiment soured towards the country’s growth prospects.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS downgrades SIA to ‘hold’ on expected earnings slowdown
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded its call on Singapore Airlines (SIA) from "buy" to "hold" due to expected earnings slowdown. The research team believes SIA's earnings will peak in FY2024 and notes that its promising outlook has been "aptly baked" into its valuation. The team recommends investors "rotate into other parts of the aviation value chain," such as ST Engineering or Sats.

site_title: Football pitch of tropical forest lost every 5 seconds
summary: Earth lost an area of carbon-absorbing rainforest larger than Switzerland or the Netherlands in 2022, with 41,000 square km of primary forests destroyed, equivalent to nearly a football pitch of mature tropical trees felled or burned every five seconds. The accelerating loss, primarily due to cattle and commodity crops, released 2.7 billion tonnes of CO2 into the atmosphere, equivalent to India's fossil fuel emissions. Brazil accounted for 43% of the loss, with the Democratic Republic of Congo and Bolivia responsible for 13 and 9%, respectively, threatening the world's most effective tool for combating climate change.

images.alt_text: Indonesia is the top global producer of palm oil, which has been linked to land clearance.
The Singapore Institute of International Affairs assigns a rating of “red” in its Haze Outlook 2023 released on Wednesday (Jun 21).

site_title: Taylor Swift mania set to give Australia’s economy a boost
summary: Taylor Swift's Eras tour is set to bring a potential boost to Australia's economy, with the pop icon adding 6 shows in Australia before her London leg in mid-2024. The tour, featuring 106 shows worldwide, could generate over US$1 billion. Economists believe that the limited schedule may encourage fans to travel from other states and potentially New Zealand, overcoming subdued confidence and spending. However, some experts caution that spending on concert tickets and associated services may be a substitution for additional outlays, rather than an increase in overall consumption.

images.alt_text: According to chat groups on Telegram set up to discuss the concert, multiple Swifties said they rushed to open accounts or apply for credit cards with UOB the moment news of the presale broke in the morning on Wednesday (Jun 21).

Singapore is Swift’s only South-east Asian stop of her “Eras Tour”. The concert fever is helping to re-heat the Mice – meetings, incentives, conferences, exhibitions – sector that’s a boon for the host-happy city-state
Why isn't Swift making even more money? Perhaps because live concerts play a more limited role now than they did 170 years ago.

site_title: World Bank approves US$1.14 billion clean-energy project in east Indonesia
summary: The World Bank has approved a US$1.14 billion clean-energy project in eastern Indonesia, which will connect about two million people to the electrical grid, increase solar power investment, and help the state utility improve its capacity to manage energy transition. The project is co-funded by the World Bank, private sector, and PLN, and aims to mobilize private sector finance for Indonesia's energy transition and help communities adapt to climate change.

images.alt_text: State Electricity Company officials walk near solar cell panels at the largest solar power plant in Indonesia, at Oelpuah village in Kupang, July 20, 2017 in this photo taken by Antara Foto. Picture taken July 20, 2017. Antara Foto/Widodo S Jusuf via REUTERS

site_title: Hot stock: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding nears 7-month high after contract win
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's shares hit a near seven-month high after securing a contract to build six 9,000 twenty-foot equivalent unit methanol dual-fuel container ships, valued at around US$5.6 billion. The company's order book value stands at US$14.6 billion for 180 vessels, providing four years of revenue visibility. Analysts from DBS Group Research, Citi, and CLSA have given the company a "buy" call, citing the potential for increased efficiency and productivity, and a potential upside of 8-18.1% in the share price.

images.alt_text: A ship under repair at a Yangzijiang shipyard in China.

site_title: ‘Golden age’ of EU-Japan ties shapes international relations
summary: The EU and Japan are experiencing a "golden age" in their bilateral relations, marked by significant economic and geopolitical cooperation. The two powers have strengthened ties through agreements such as the Economic Partnership Agreement and the EU-Japan Strategic Partnership Agreement. They have also deepened their security relationship, particularly in response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The upcoming EU-Japan summit on July 13 will showcase the growing partnership, which is seen as a model for international cooperation on issues like trade, energy security, and green growth.

images.alt_text: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida visits a  mass grave in the town of Bucha. He is the last of the G7 leaders to visit the country since Russia launched its invasion over a year ago.

(L-R) US President Joe Biden, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida, Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, France's President Emmanuel Macron, European Council President Charles Michel and Italy's Premier Giorgia Meloni arrive for the group photo during a visit to the Itsukushima Shrine on Miyajima Island, at the start of the G7 summit, May 19, 2023.
The yen falls broadly following the BOJ decision and hit a fresh 15-year low of 154.70 per euro.

site_title: Thai exports drop less than expected in May, seen improving in H2
summary: Thailand's exports contracted less than expected in May, with industrial goods shipments rising 1.5% year-over-year, beating forecasts. A weakening baht and higher shipments of automobiles and semiconductors contributed to the increase. Agricultural goods shipments fell 27% year-over-year, while rice exports jumped 85%. The trade deficit was $1.8 billion, higher than forecast. Despite sluggish global demand, the Ministry of Commerce expects the global economic outlook to improve, supporting exports growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of the port of Bangkok, Thailand May 26, 2016.  REUTERS/Jorge Silva/File Photo                   GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD PACKAGE - SEARCH BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD SEPTEMBER 26 FOR ALL IMAGES/File Photo
Thailand posts a trade deficit of US$1.47 billion in April versus an expected deficit of US$450 million, with imports showing a 7.3 per cent year-on-year contraction.

site_title: Audi ex-boss is first VW board member sentenced over diesel scandal
summary: Former Audi CEO Rupert Stadler was sentenced to a suspended one-year and nine-month sentence and fined 1.1 million euros for his role in the 2015 diesel scandal. He was the first former Volkswagen board member to receive such a sentence. Stadler's lawyer claimed he did not knowingly harm buyers but accepted the need for more care. The sentence is within the 1.5-2 year timeframe the judge had set.

images.alt_text: Rupert Stadler, former CEO of German car manufacturer Audi, attends his trial, at the regional court, in Munich, Germany, May 3, 2023. REUTERS/Lukas Barth/Pool

site_title: Low-income Britons can afford only 5% of private rental homes
summary: Low-income Britons can only afford 5% of private rental homes, a significant drop from 23% pre-pandemic, according to the Institute for Fiscal Studies. The freeze on Local Housing Allowance rates is exacerbating the issue, with rents rising by 20% and many affordable homes being of poor quality. Experts warn that if the freeze is maintained, private rents will become increasingly unaffordable for those on low incomes, forcing families to choose between unsafe or unaffordable homes.

images.alt_text: Several economists disagree with the Bank of England's 'sanguine' view that the UK will avoid a recession, noting high levels of indebtedness and inflation in the economy.
In Kensington and Chelsea, 5.7 per cent of the population has a place away.

site_title: With slashed funding, British museums turn to philanthropy
summary: British museums are shifting from government funding to philanthropy due to reduced government support. The National Portrait Gallery, for example, received a $53 million renovation with $5 million from a retail magnate and $13 million from a Ukrainian-born business owner. Other museums, like the British Museum and the National Gallery, are also seeking donations for multi-year renovations. This change in funding model is attributed to a lack of cultural philanthropy in Britain, with donors preferring to support social justice causes over arts institutions.

images.alt_text: In the first half of the 20th century, Grock’s success rivalled that of Charlie Chaplin. But while Chaplin satirised Hitler, Grock seems to have welcomed him into his dressing room.

site_title: Petronas, TotalEnergies and Mitsui ink carbon capture and storage project deal
summary: Petronas has signed a development agreement with TotalEnergies Carbon Neutrality Ventures and Mitsui & Co to collaborate on a carbon capture and storage (CCS) project in Malaysia. The agreement covers all aspects of CCS development, from evaluating storage sites to identifying potential customers. This follows a memoranda of understanding signed by the companies in 2022. The project aims to capture CO2 generated from industrial activity, transport it, and store it underground.

site_title: Pre-owned motorcycle startup iMotorbike raises RM12 million in Series A funding
summary: Malaysia-based pre-owned motorcycle platform iMotorbike has secured RM12 million (S$3.5 million) in Series A funding led by Gobi Partners and Ondine Capital. The startup plans to use the funding to expand its operations in Malaysia and Vietnam, including opening more motorcycle inspection centers, and invest in technology and talent. Founded in 2016 by Gil Carmo and Sharmeen Looi, iMotorbike has now received a total of RM19.3 million in funding.

images.alt_text: Singaporean electric motorcycle and mobility startup Charged has three models (left to right): the Anoa cargo bike, Rimau urban commuter, and Maleo ride-hailing model.
GrabExpress partners with Hanoi-based EV maker Selex Motors

site_title: Malaysia’s Petronas sees domestic oil, gas output peaking at 2 million boepd by 2024
summary: Malaysia's state energy firm Petronas expects domestic oil and gas production to peak at 2 million barrels of oil equivalent per day (boepd) by 2024, according to its exploration head. The company aims to maintain 60-70% natural gas production and expand its overseas portfolio to 700,000 boepd through its Canada liquefied natural gas joint venture. Petronas reported an average production of 2.4 million boepd in 2022, including domestic and overseas output.

site_title: Crypto firm Circle eyeing Hong Kong policies with Asia in focus
summary: US-based crypto firm Circle Internet Financial is closely monitoring Hong Kong's new crypto regulatory regime, which went into effect on June 1, as the company sees the territory as a potential hub for digital assets markets and stablecoins. Circle's co-founder and CEO Jeremy Allaire stated that Hong Kong is a "huge area of focus" for the company, particularly with the issuance of its USD Coin stablecoin. The company's Singapore licence will help distribute USD Coin in the region, amid a crackdown in the US and hopes that China could eventually lift its crypto ban.

images.alt_text: Japan has moved towards easing some crypto rules, such as on token listing and taxation, but overall is viewed as having strict regulations.
Gemini on Monday said Singapore will be its hub for the Asia-Pacific region and announced plans to boost headcount in the city-state to more than 100 in the next 12 months.

site_title: Thai PM front runner claims enough Senate support for top job
summary: Thai Prime Minister front-runner Pita Limjaroenra claims to have secured enough Senate support to become the country's next leader. His progressive Move Forward Party won the most seats in last month's election, and a coalition with 312 seats in the lower house needs 64 more from either house for a majority. Pita stated that he has enough Senate support, saying "Enough to make me become PM," despite several senators already saying they won't vote for him.

images.alt_text: Move Forward Party leader and prime ministerial candidate Pita Limjaroenrat (C) waves as he arrives to address a press conference with potential coalition partners in Bangkok on May 18, 2023, after his party secured the most seats in Thailand's general election. (Photo by Manan VATSYAYANA / AFP)

site_title: Japan reinstates South Korea as a preferred trading partner
summary: Japan has reinstated South Korea as a preferred trading partner, effective July 21. This move comes after a three-month period of improved relations, marked by steps to resolve issues tied to Japan's colonial rule over the Korean Peninsula. The restored status will ease export procedures and comes as leaders from Japan, South Korea, and the US prepare for a trilateral summit. The decision aims to bolster cooperation on North Korea and China issues, and follow Japan's easing of export restrictions on semiconductor materials in March.

images.alt_text: South Koreans spent a record US$19.97 billion on private education last year, despite a declining student population, a joint report by the education ministry and the government statistics bureau showed.
In 2009, MSCI added South Korea to the developed-markets watchlist, a stepping stone towards an actual entry into the club of mature markets.

site_title: China extends fight against weak yuan as drops unsettle PBOC
summary: China has taken steps to support the yuan, setting its daily reference rate at a stronger-than-expected level for a second day, in response to the currency's largest decline in nearly five months. The onshore yuan climbed 0.5% after the move, while the offshore yuan rose 0.2%. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) aims to slow the slide in the yuan, but investors will monitor if the rebound can be sustained. The central bank may still intervene if depreciation resumes, and the yuan's moves are expected to gradually ease as the economy improves.

images.alt_text: A view of the city skyline and Huangpu river in Shanghai. The boost from China's reopening to exports has been limited, says Maybank senior economist Chua Hak Bin.
The PBOC had sought to curb onshore currency weakness by setting its so-called fixing at the largest premium to estimates this year on Monday.

site_title: 12-month jail term for Singaporean in Wirecard case
summary: A Singaporean, Henry Yeo, was sentenced to 12 months in prison for his role in the Wirecard case, a major accounting scandal. Yeo, 67, pleaded guilty to three charges, including conspiring to commit criminal breach of trust, falsifying invoices, and laundering the benefits of criminal conduct. Wirecard Asia suffered a loss of $123,070 due to Yeo's offenses, and he had cooperated with authorities by handing over documents and testifying. This is the first conviction in the Wirecard case in Singapore and globally.

images.alt_text: This is the first Wirecard-related conviction in Singapore and globally.

site_title: New Zealand boosts tertiary funding as universities struggle
summary: New Zealand is investing an additional NZ$128 million in its tertiary sector over the next two years to support universities struggling with growing deficits and falling student numbers. The funding, on top of a 5% increase provided in the 2023 budget, will increase tuition subsidies at degree-level and above by 4% in 2024 and 2025. The move aims to help universities rebuild their pipeline and improve their financial stability, with efforts made to ensure recent cuts and changes do not impact programme capability.

images.alt_text: The RBNZ has signalled it’s done raising rates, and the housing market is showing signs of finding a floor.
Pessimism towards New Zealand’s property market has softened after the Reserve Bank last month projected the Official Cash Rate is unlikely to rise further in this cycle.

site_title: Billionaire Adani reiterates confidence in governance standards
summary: Indian billionaire Gautam Adani has reiterated his confidence in the governance and disclosure standards of his conglomerate, Adani Enterprises, five months after Hindenburg Research accused his company of widespread corporate malfeasance. The Adani Group chairman cited a report by a Supreme Court-appointed panel of experts that found no regulatory failure or signs of stock price manipulation. Despite ongoing investigations by US authorities and the Indian capital markets regulator, Adani remains confident in his company's standards, saying they have helped rebuild investor trust.

site_title: Indonesia’s Pertamina, Electrum sign battery packs development deal
summary: Indonesia's state energy company Pertamina signed a deal with Electrum to develop battery packs for electric motorcycles, aiming to utilize Indonesia's largest nickel reserves to create a full supply chain for the industry. The partnership could cover a capacity of 300 megawatts, supporting the production of 250,000 electric scooters per year. This move aligns with Indonesia's goal to create a full supply chain for electric vehicles and follows the country's significant nickel reserves.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.3% on Tuesday, driven by advancers outnumbering decliners 70 to 40. The Straits Times Index (STI) increased 9.95 points to 3,199.63, with Seatrium rising 1.6% and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding gaining 3.7%. In contrast, global markets closed lower amid uncertainty over Russia events, with the Nasdaq Composite Index down 1.2% and the S&P 500 falling 0.5%.

images.alt_text: Singtel chairman requests lower pay.

site_title: Condo resale prices, volumes rise at a slower pace in May: SRX, 99.co
summary: Singapore's condominium resale prices rose 0.9% in May, but at a slower pace than in previous months. Overall resale prices are up 9.2% year-on-year, with the Outside Central Region experiencing the largest gain. Resale volumes rose 8.9% in May but were 18.8% lower than the five-year average. The most expensive condo unit resold was S$14.1 million, while the median capital gain was S$308,000. Experts attribute the slower pace to new condo launches and high interest rates, which may be driving buyers to opt for new launches over resale units.

images.alt_text: Condominiums along Alexandra Road at night on Feb 26, 2022.
Two land parcels in the prime central areas of Orchard and River Valley will be up for sale in H2 2023 Government Land Sales Programme.

“The government will continue to monitor economic and property market conditions and calibrate the supply of future GLS programmes, as necessary, to help meet demand and promote market stability,” MND says.
With high interest rates, developers may benefit from buyers choosing new homes sold off-plan because of the progressive payment scheme.
New private home sales rose 17 per cent month-on-month, according to data released by the Urban Redevelopment Authority on Thursday (Jun 15).
Generic private properties around Orchard area.

site_title: Banks raised questions in 2020 about FTX-affiliated hedge fund’s wire activity, FTX says
summary: FTX-affiliated hedge fund Alameda Research raised concerns with banks in 2020 about its wire activity, with some banks rejecting wires to or from the firm. FTX has estimated that approximately $8.7 billion in customer assets were misappropriated from the exchange. This comes after founder Sam Bankman-Fried pleaded not guilty to 13 counts of fraud and conspiracy. The misappropriation occurred as Alameda received over $250 billion in deposits from FTX customers in 2020 alone, contradicting an employee's claim that all wires were for settling trades with Alameda.

images.alt_text: The logo FTX Cryptocurrency Exchange on a digital device arranged in Riga, Latvia, Nov. 24, 2022.

site_title: A road map for oil and gas in S-E Asia
summary: South-east Asia's energy security is threatened by a perfect storm of the pandemic, supply chain disruptions, and geopolitical tensions, driving demand for oil and gas. To succeed, oil and gas companies must undergo holistic reinvention through the 5 C's: competitiveness, carbon reduction, connectivity, customer-centricity, and culture. Companies must balance energy security and sustainability, invest in low-carbon solutions, and adopt digital technologies. A balanced approach to reinvention is key, with a focus on delivering value to customers, investors, and employees while meeting the challenges of a rapidly evolving energy landscape.

images.alt_text: The elections could decide if Anwar will stay on in power as head of the coalition that set aside decades of rivalry to form the government last November.

site_title: EU to set out legal underpinnings for a digital euro
summary: The European Union is set to publish draft rules giving legal underpinnings for a digital euro, a digital version of the eurozone's single currency, which would be "legal tender" and have to be accepted as a form of payment. The European Central Bank is expected to decide on proceeding with a digital euro for retail uses, such as payments, by 2026 at the earliest. The digital euro would support a stronger retail payments market, have high privacy, but not be "programmable", and initially only be available to euro area residents and visitors.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The European Central Bank logo in Frankfurt, Germany, January 23, 2020. REUTERS/Ralph Orlowski/File Photo

site_title: Chow Tai Fook to take NWS private in HK$35.5 billion deal
summary: Chow Tai Fook Enterprises is offering to buy New World Development's shares it doesn't own and take the company private in a HK$35.5 billion deal. The offer is a 14.5% premium over the last closing price, with New World Development set to receive about HK$21.8 billion from the disposal. This comes as Hong Kong's developers face a rare downturn in the property market due to higher interest rates. The deal, advised by HSBC, BOCI Asia, and ING Bank, aims to take NWS Holdings private, allowing the Cheng family to consolidate control.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong is one of only a handful of places in the world that have in-town check-in – others include Taipei and Kuala Lumpur.

The government is working with the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and will carefully deliberate between balancing financial stability and interests of first-time homeowners, says Financial Secretary Paul Chan.

site_title: Hong Kong high-rise aims to become ‘village’ of the dead
summary: A modern high-rise in Hong Kong, designed by German architect Ulrich Kirchhoff, has opened as a columbarium offering 23,000 niches for funeral urns. The building aims to provide a "neighbourhood village feel" and addresses the city's shortage of urn spaces, which has been exacerbated by its densely populated nature and ageing population. The columbarium, known as Shan Sum, offers private urn spaces at a high cost, with prices ranging from $58,000 to $3 million. The government's decade-long effort to bring in private companies has helped ease pressure on the deathcare sector, but the shortage is expected to worsen in the coming years.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong is one of only a handful of places in the world that have in-town check-in – others include Taipei and Kuala Lumpur.

site_title: New Zealand seen stumbling from one recession into another
summary: New Zealand's economy may emerge from recession in the current quarter but is expected to quickly enter another one, according to three major banks. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has signaled the end of interest rate hikes, and the housing market is showing signs of stabilization. Economists predict a second recession starting later this year, with ANZ Bank forecasting a contraction in the third quarter and Bank of New Zealand predicting a 0.5% contraction in the fourth quarter and 0.3% slide in 2024.

images.alt_text: Pessimism towards New Zealand’s property market has softened after the Reserve Bank last month projected the Official Cash Rate is unlikely to rise further in this cycle.
New Zealand has committed to achieving net zero emissions by 2050, and has set up structures including the ETS to push towards that target.

site_title: Relook how to integrate new migrants to preserve multiracialism, cohesion in Singapore: President Halimah
summary: Singapore President Halimah Yacob urges the government to reassess its integration strategies for new migrants to preserve multiracialism and cohesion. She notes that some newcomers may not integrate into local communities, instead forming exclusive social circles. Halimah emphasizes the importance of socially integrating new migrants into local communities, highlighting the need for them to recognize they are part of Singaporean society. She also discusses the challenges of meritocracy, inequality, and stewardship, emphasizing the need for a more inclusive approach to social mobility and recognizing diverse abilities.

images.alt_text: Speaking to media outside the Elections Department, potential presidential candidate George Goh said he wanted to give the people a choice.

Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam will resign from the People's Action Party and step down from his Cabinet positions on Jul 7 to fulfil his official commitments in Singapore and internationally.

site_title: Gold flat as Russia jitters, hawkish US Fed outlook weigh
summary: Gold prices remained flat on Tuesday, hovering above three-month lows, amid concerns over Russia's political turmoil and the Federal Reserve's hawkish outlook. Investors turned to safe-haven assets like the dollar and gold, with the US dollar strengthening 0.1% and spot gold holding at $1,923.94 per ounce. Economic data and a speech from Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell are expected this week, potentially influencing interest rates and gold prices.

images.alt_text: The dollar index was down 0.2 per cent, making gold more attractive for buyers holding other currencies.

site_title: Accor plans to add more than 1,200 hotels
summary: Accor plans to expand its hotel portfolio by over 1,200 properties in the next five years, a significant increase of more than one-fifth, driven by strong international demand and growing booking occupancy. The company raised its 2023 revenue per room forecast to 15-20% growth and aims to increase core earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) by 9-12% annually from 2023 to 2027. This growth is attributed to the hotel industry's recovery post-pandemic and Accor's reorganisation plans.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of French hotel operator AccorHotels is seen on top of the company's headquarters in Issy-les-Moulineaux near Paris, France, February 17, 2021. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo

site_title: Asia: Most markets rise but wary eyes on US Fed, Russia
summary: Asian markets rose, with Hong Kong climbing over 1% after five days of losses, and Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Manila, and Jakarta also increasing. Tokyo, Seoul, Wellington, and Taipei retreated. The positive trend came as concerns over Russia's aborted uprising subsided, but traders remain cautious about interest rate hikes to combat inflation. The focus now shifts to the battle against surging inflation, which has affected global markets this year.

images.alt_text: Traders on Monday appeared to take the events in stride, with Hong Kong, Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Taipei, Manila, Jakarta and Wellington moving in and out of positive territory in the morning.

site_title: Inflation in shops declines as UK battles living-cost crisis
summary: Inflation in UK shops declined to 8.4% in June, down from a peak of 9% in May, marking the sharpest decline since prices started rising in 2021. Food price inflation eased to 14.6%, with grocers cutting prices of basics. Supermarkets are under scrutiny, but bosses deny profiteering. Retailers, including Tesco and Sainsbury, are expected to face questions from MPs about pricing. The decline in shop price inflation offers hope to ministers and central bankers as the UK battles its cost-of-living crisis.

images.alt_text: The CBI says retail sales volumes are average for the time of year at +1 per cent in June compared with -18 per cent in May.

site_title: Meta launches Quest+ subscription for VR headsets
summary: Meta has launched Meta Quest+, a subscription-based service for its virtual reality (VR) headsets, priced at $7.99/month or $59.99/year. The service aims to shape the high-investment market, following Meta's price cuts in March due to the metaverse's lukewarm reception. The move enters Meta into a market dominated by Apple's $3,499 Vision Pro headset, which is three times the cost of Meta's priciest headset. Meta Quest+ will be available for Quest 2, Pro, and soon for Quest 3.

site_title: Asia lobby group pushes for easing of China’s offshore listing rules
summary: China's new offshore listing rules for domestic companies have created uncertainty among bankers and lawyers, who struggle to take on liabilities and avoid breaching confidentiality rules. The rules, set to come into effect on March 31, require firms to formally pledge "truthfulness, accuracy, completeness" of their work within three days of an overseas listing. Asia's largest financial lobby group, Asifma, has expressed concerns to the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC), which has promised efforts to offer a solution to the challenges arising from the new listing regime.

images.alt_text: A view of the city skyline and Huangpu river in Shanghai. The boost from China's reopening to exports has been limited, says Maybank senior economist Chua Hak Bin.
BYD, backed by Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway, has witnessed its domination surge over the past two years.

site_title: Illumina starts job cuts, plans office exit to rein in costs
summary: Illumina, a genetic sequencing equipment maker, has started job cuts and plans to exit an office in California to reduce costs amid inflation and a strong dollar. The company laid off 10% of its research and development team, with charges of $25-$35 million expected. Illumina aims to cut annual expenses by over $100 million in 2023. The company's core workforce consists of around 10,200 full-time employees, following the departure of CEO Francis deSouza earlier this month.

images.alt_text: EU antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager gives a press conference in Brussels, on September 6, 2022, to announce Eu's veto against US life sciences company Illumina’s acquisition of biotechnology company Grail.

site_title: An activist investor in Singapore pitches East against West
summary: A Singaporean Reit, Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust, is facing a shareholder vote on removing its external manager, owned by its sponsor ESR Group, in favor of an internal team. This move, backed by activist investor Quarz Capital Management, could lead to cost savings and increased dividends for unitholders. However, the Reit manager disputes the cost savings, citing potential operational challenges and disruptions to day-to-day management. The debate highlights the East-West split in Reit management, with Asian Reits often opting for external management and European and North American Reits managing internally.

images.alt_text: Economists flag risk of technical recession for Singapore as manufacturing contracts further in May
Likely, many graduate couples in their late 30s should be able to upgrade from an HDB home to a condominium.

site_title: Nvidia brings its AI computing platform to cloud data firm Snowflake
summary: Nvidia and cloud data analytics firm Snowflake have partnered to allow customers to build artificial intelligence (AI) models using their own data. The partnership aims to enable companies like financial institutions, healthcare providers, and retailers to leverage Snowflake's data analytics capabilities and Nvidia's AI computing hardware. The collaboration comes as chatbot ChatGPT has prompted companies to develop their AI strategies, contributing to Nvidia's rapid growth as a trillion-dollar company.

images.alt_text: Nvidia’s value has jumped as its graphics processors have become the most popular for data centres needed to power generative artificial intelligence.
The top ESG funds so far in 2023 are all tech-heavy and invested in AI, and all have returned more than 40 per cent.

site_title: Groundhog Day: Digilife Tech’s countless board, management shuffles
summary: Digilife Technologies, a Catalist-listed company, has experienced a series of board and management changes, including the recent departure of executive chairman and CEO Bhupendra Kumar Modi. The company has changed its name four times in over a decade, and its core businesses face margin pressures. Despite returning to profitability with a $540,000 net profit, the company's succession plan is unclear, raising concerns among investors. The Singapore Exchange Regulation has issued a "trade with caution" alert on the company, and the Securities Investors Association of Singapore has sought clarity on the board's selection criteria and nomination process.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Singapore Exchange Regulation issued a "trade with caution" alert on Digilife Technologies on Wednesday.
Will Sevak's latest change of name and leadership spice up investors' returns?
Before a 2021 name change, Digilife Tech was known as Sevak Limited, which was the subject of a trade with caution alert.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Sembcorp, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding
summary: Singtel set to bring forward its net-zero goal to 2045 from 2050, according to its sustainability report. The telco's chairman, Lee Theng Kiat, also requested a lower chairman's fee. Sembcorp Industries is involved in arbitration with Siemens Gamesa Renewable Power over a composite supply contract. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding secured a contract with Maersk to build methanol dual-fuel container ships worth around $5.6 billion. StarHub plans to spend $50 million on share repurchases and AIMS Apac Real Estate Investment Trust received oversubscribed offers for new units.

site_title: China’s top traders set oil spinning in Middle East play
summary: China's top oil refiners, PetroChina and Sinopec, have engaged in a high-stakes bidding war in the Middle East crude market, significantly affecting global cargo flows. The trading units of the two companies have been aggressively bidding and offering for Dubai crude, leading to a surge in derivatives contracts and prices. This unusual behavior has puzzled oil traders, as both companies are major refiners seeking to obtain crude cheaply. The activity has boosted markets for similar oil grades, such as Norway's Johan Sverdrup, and may impact Asian refiners' purchases of Middle Eastern oil.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A liquified natural gas (LNG) tanker leaves the dock after discharge at PetroChina's receiving terminal in Dalian, Liaoning province, China July 16, 2018.  REUTERS/Chen Aizhu/File Photo

site_title: Ford to cut hundreds of US salaried workers to lower costs
summary: Ford Motor plans to cut hundreds of salaried US workers, primarily engineers, to boost profit and lower costs amid a $50 billion shift to electric vehicles. The company will inform workers of the layoffs on Tuesday and Wednesday. CEO Jim Farley said the company needs 25% more engineers to compete with rivals, costing billions in profit. Ford will lose $3 billion on its EV business in 2023 but aims to generate an 8% return on battery-powered models by 2026.

images.alt_text: Ford Motor executive chairman Bill Ford Jr, great-grandson of founder Henry Ford, said he sees an opportunity for Ford engineers to understand the technology.

site_title: Blackstone is said to weigh offers for stake in Bellagio casino in Las Vegas
summary: Blackstone is considering selling half of its interest in the Bellagio casino in Las Vegas for approximately $4.25 billion, acquired almost four years ago. The New York-based investment firm is weighing offers as part of its efforts to cash out on real estate positions. This comes after Blackstone recently announced plans to sell warehouses and industrial properties for $3.1 billion. The sale of the Bellagio would be the company's second major exit in Las Vegas, following the sale of the Cosmopolitan hotel in 2021.

site_title: China’s slower-than-expected reopening will weigh on Asean growth: analysts
summary: China's economic reopening has been slower than expected, weighing on growth in Southeast Asia, particularly in countries heavily reliant on Chinese manufacturing and trade demand. Analysts predict a moderate boost to the region's growth, with Maybank shaving its Asean-6 GDP forecast to 4.2% in 2023 due to China's underwhelming showing. The lack of a significant surge in Chinese exports and tourist arrivals is attributed to ongoing domestic challenges, including the property market and weaker offshore manufacturing conditions. A more moderate recovery in China's economy is expected, with potential improvements in inbound tourists and imports in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Growth in GDP is expected to slow to 4.2 per cent in Asean-6 (Singapore, Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines) this year, down from 5.7 per cent in 2022

site_title: BlackRock debuts retail private credit fund at tricky time
summary: BlackRock has launched its retail private credit fund, dubbed BDEBT, targeting small investors, amid a challenging economic backdrop. The fund, which makes floating-rate loans to middle-market US companies, arrives as economists warn of a potential US recession and private credit faces liquidity tightening. Despite this, BlackRock CEO Rajneesh Vig predicts investors will seek extra returns, and the fund aims to charge a 1.25% management fee with an income distribution rate of 10.3%. The fund, which has $150 million in net assets, is designed for investors with a net worth of $250,000 or less and will start accepting investments in July.

images.alt_text: BlackRock headquarters in New York. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: No let-up in Singapore’s battle against dirty money
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) has imposed fines of S$3.8 million on four financial institutions, including DBS, OCBC, and Citibank, for breaching anti-money laundering and terrorism financing rules. The penalties follow an investigation into alleged involvement of Singapore-based individuals in the Wirecard scandal, a German payment company that collapsed in 2020. The move highlights the ongoing battle against dirty money in Singapore, which has intensified due to technological advancements. The MAS is set to roll out a new digital platform, Cosmic, to enhance information sharing and detection of financial crimes.

images.alt_text: MAS said the breaches were identified during its examinations following news of irregularities in Wirecard’s financial statements, and the alleged involvement of Singapore-based individuals and entities in the matter.

site_title: FTX creditor uses NFT to collect money from a bankruptcy claim
summary: A FTX creditor converted a bankruptcy claim worth $31,307 into a non-fungible token (NFT) on the Ethereum blockchain, sold it, and used the proceeds to borrow $7,500 worth of stablecoin USD. The tokenization process allowed the creditor to access cash while waiting for a greater recovery from the bankruptcy estate. This approach, facilitated by platforms like Found, enables creditors to temporarily reduce pressures and access loans. The lender decides the value of the NFT as collateral, with the loan set to be repaid in five days.

images.alt_text: The FTX.com exchange owed customers approximately US$8.7 billion when it filed for bankruptcy last year, based on ongoing analysis, according to the report.
FTX has also filed lawsuits over its pre-bankruptcy investment in the stock platform Embed and its payments to Genesis Global Capital, the bankrupt lending arm of crypto firm Genesis.

site_title: Germany set to raise minimum wage by more than 3%, unions want more
summary: Germany is set to raise its minimum wage by 3.4% to 12.41 euros (S$18.32) an hour from 2024, according to a government-appointed commission. However, unions and analysts say the increase is not enough to cover inflation, with some calling for a higher hike. The move aims to address high inflation and interest rate hikes, but critics argue it will not significantly impact purchasing power.

images.alt_text: Soaring inflation, painful interest rate rises, a sluggish recovery in its key export market China, and high energy costs are all weighing on business activity.

site_title: Princess Leia’s dress from the original ‘Star Wars’ is up for bids
summary: The iconic white dress worn by Carrie Fisher as Princess Leia in the original 1977 "Star Wars" film, "A New Hope," is up for auction. The dress, which was thought to have been destroyed after filming, was recently found in a London attic and has undergone extensive restoration. The dress, designed by John Mollo, is estimated to sell for up to $2 million and will be part of a live auction featuring over $12 million worth of TV and film memorabilia. Bids can be submitted online or in person at the Petersen Automotive Museum in Los Angeles.

images.alt_text: Brandon ALinger, Chief Operating Officer at Propstore, wears white gloves to handle the Princess Leia dress worn by actress Carrie Fisher in the 1977 film "Star Wars" for display on May 16, 2023 at Propstore in Valencia, California. The Propstore's live auction of film and TV memorabilia will be held on June 28 at the Petersen Automotive Museum in Los Angeles. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP)

site_title: FTX’s new management recovers US$7 billion in ‘substantial progress’
summary: FTX's new management has recovered approximately $7 billion in assets from the bankrupt exchange, a significant step in securing customer funds. The company previously commingled customer deposits and corporate funds, making false statements to banks about account usage. FTX's tangled relationship with its trading firm Alameda Research and misuse of funds were major factors in its downfall. The new management claims to have made "substantial progress" in addressing these issues, but the exchange still owes customers around $8.7 billion.

images.alt_text: FTX has also filed lawsuits over its pre-bankruptcy investment in the stock platform Embed and its payments to Genesis Global Capital, the bankrupt lending arm of crypto firm Genesis.
FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried and several company insiders have been indicted on fraud charges for their role in the company’s collapse.

site_title: Singtel chairman seeks fee cut; company brings forward net-zero target by 5 years
summary: Singtel chairman Lee Theng Kiat requested a fee cut to S$960,000 in FY2023, down from S$1.15 million. The telco brought forward its net-zero goal to 2045 from 2050, aiming to reduce energy use and increase renewable energy sources. Singtel's total greenhouse gas emissions decreased 53.6% in FY2023, with its sustainability-linked loans and bonds meeting their targets. The company's shares rose 2% on the news.

images.alt_text: Optus says it views the decision to block Telstra and TPG Telecom’s proposed network sharing agreement as a favourable one.
Artist's impression of the Lagoon tidal pool, which is supported by a S$1 million donation by Singtel.
Fibre optic cables will be used to transmit encryption keys encoded with light photons in quantum safe networks.

site_title: Putin says he let Wagner mutiny continue to avoid bloodshed
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin stated that he allowed the 24-hour Wagner militia mutiny to continue to avoid bloodshed, saying it reinforced national unity. Putin praised the majority of Wagner's members as patriots and thanked those who stood down from the mutiny. He also claimed that the mutiny was a result of "fratricidal bloodshed" caused by those who betrayed the country and its people. Putin made no mention of planned personnel changes at the Defence Ministry, despite demands from mutiny leader Yevgeny Prigozhin for the dismissal of top officials.

images.alt_text: This screengrab made from undated video footage released by the Russian Defence Ministry on June 26, 2023 show Russia's Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu (C) gesturing between officers as they look at a map in an undisclosed location.

(FILES) Russian President Vladimir Putin and Belarus' President Alexander Lukashenko at the Victory Day military parade in Moscow on May 9, 2023. The weekend mutiny in Russia ended after Lukashenko negotiated a truce with Yevgeny Prigozhin; the Wagner leader stood down his troops and left in exile to Belarus.

site_title: Kitchen Culture reaches agreement with dissenting shareholders to appoint new directors
summary: Kitchen Culture has reached an agreement with dissenting shareholders to appoint five new directors to the board, replacing the current directors with the exception of Hao Dongting. The new directors, James Rogers, Yip Kean Mun, Lam Kwong Fai, Tan Meng Shern, and Cheung Wai Man Raymond, will take their place after the board steps down. The company has also secured a S$4 million loan to pay debts and for general working capital.

images.alt_text: business, conference room, boardroom
Kitchen Culture receives letter of demand from CDL unit for S$250,970 in unpaid rent

Ooway claims the directors were elected at the Nov 25 EGM after shareholders representing about 40 per cent of Kitchen Culture's shares approved their appointments. Kitchen Culture maintains that its current board of directors remains unchanged as it denies the validity of the EGM.
The boardroom fight at Catalist-listed Kitchen Culture, an outfitter of kitchens, is now being played out at the court.

site_title: Robinhood cutting 7% of its full-time employees
summary: Robinhood, a trading platform that played a key role in the retail-trading frenzy during the pandemic, is cutting about 7% of its full-time employees as it struggles with a contracting customer base spooked by higher commodity costs. The company cited the need for "operational excellence" and made changes to teams based on volume and workload. This move comes as the platform faces reduced customer engagement.

site_title: US: Tech-centred Nasdaq leads stocks lower
summary: US stocks fell on Monday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index down 1.2% due to tech shares like Alphabet and Tesla dropping 3.2% and 6.1% respectively. The Dow Jones Industrial Average shed less than 0.1% and the S&P 500 fell 0.5%. The decline was partly due to market expectations of potential Federal Reserve interest rate hikes. Meanwhile, IBM and Prologis rose after announcing significant acquisitions, while Russia's President Putin addressed security officials following a failed mutiny by the Wagner mercenary group.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., May 4, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Europe: Heathcare stocks weigh on Stoxx 600, defence stocks slide
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index fell 0.1% as of 1600 GMT, extending losses for its sixth straight session. Healthcare stocks weighed on the index, while defence stocks dropped 4% following an aborted Russian mutiny. Energy stocks rose 0.8% despite geopolitical uncertainty. The healthcare index fell 1.1%, contributing to the Stoxx 600's decline, which is under pressure due to concerns about an economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: Germany’s DAX index sheds 1 per cent, leading losses among regional peers.

site_title: US: Wall St kicks off the week on a mixed note as rate worries persist
summary: Wall Street began the week on a mixed note, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 3.36 points, or 0.01%, to 33,730.79, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite opened lower due to investor concerns over the Federal Reserve's monetary tightening and Pfizer's decision to drop a weight loss drug.

site_title: Hong Kong to reopen downtown airport check-in service next month
summary: Hong Kong is set to reopen its downtown airport check-in service on July 5, allowing passengers to drop off luggage in the city and collect it at their final destination. This service, which was suspended in April 2020 due to COVID restrictions, will be revived after a shortage of workers prevented its restart. The move is expected to lift one of the last COVID-related remnants from the city, which has struggled to recover from the pandemic. The decision does not include Kowloon and Tsing Yi stations at this time.

site_title: Credit Suisse sent thousands of trades late to trace: Finra
summary: Credit Suisse agreed to a $900,000 fine with Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (Finra) for reporting 9,000 trades late and mislabeling key indicators on 514,000 and 264,000 transactions from 2015 to March. The trades involved securitized products, corporate debt, and agency debt securities. The bank, which didn't admit or deny the findings, declined to comment. The fine was accepted on June 23, following an agreement on June 12.

site_title: Navigating an era of cryptographic uncertainty
summary: Quantum computers now have a 50% probability of breaking highly secure RSA-2048 keys by 2031, posing a significant threat to national security, financial stability, and private data. To mitigate this, Singapore is investing in post-quantum cryptography and quantum random number generators, while companies must deploy and manage both conventional and post-quantum security measures. The increasing volume of connected devices and data creation will require secure networks and data protection, making quantum security a pressing concern for governments, businesses, and investors.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Quantum computer startup QuEra Computing's 256-qubit machine and Florian Huber, one of the team of scientist that built the machine are shown in this picture taken in Boston, Massachusetts, U.S., on February 18, 2021. The technology was born in the labs of Harvard University and MIT. It uses neutral atoms which are put in a vacuum chamber and controlled with lasers.    Alexei Bylinskii - QuEra/Handout via REUTERS    THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY. MANDATORY CREDIT./File Photo
Fibre optic cables will be used to transmit encryption keys encoded with light photons in quantum safe networks.
It is crucial to make sensitive data “quantum-safe”, or unhackable by quantum computers, well before these devices even enter the mainstream.

site_title: Biden kicks the Iran can down the diplomatic road
summary: US President Joe Biden's administration is exploring a temporary solution to the stalled nuclear deal with Iran, aiming to curb the Islamic republic's growing nuclear program. Despite concerns that reviving the JCPOA is a "mission impossible" due to opposition from Congress and other countries, officials are seeking a package deal that would include limited but reversible steps to curtail Iran's nuclear activities in exchange for economic relief. The goal is to avoid a regional war and maintain a temporary freeze on Iran's nuclear program, with a focus on marketing the deal as a humanitarian step to the American Congress and public.

images.alt_text: Brent crude settled down 99 cents, or 1.3 per cent, at US$75.96 a barrel while US West Texas Intermediate crude settled down US$1.24, or 1.7 per cent, to US$71.29 on Thursday.
In a way, irritating Biden (left) may just be the added benefit of what MBS regards as the pursuit of legitimate Saudi economic and strategic interests, and not as part of any anti-American policy.

site_title: Chinese corporates are making strides in their ESG journey
summary: Chinese corporates are rapidly adopting environmental, social, and governance (ESG) practices, with 93% expecting to publish annual ESG reports by 2026, according to a Fidelity International survey. The shift is driven by customer and investor expectations, as well as the country's economic development model focused on quality and sustainability. While progress is being made, challenges remain, including ESG data collection and the skills gap. Despite these obstacles, China's ESG regulation is maturing, and international bodies are providing guidelines to improve global reporting. As the nation continues to prioritize ESG adoption, investors can expect to see increased transparency and value creation.

images.alt_text: The political attacks on ESG seem to be working—mentions of ESG on earnings calls have fallen of late. Or perhaps companies that are committed to ESG are just being quieter about it.

site_title: Billionaire Ofer’s firm buys NYC apartment building in Gramercy
summary: Billionaire Eyal Ofer's Global Holdings Management Group purchased a 57-unit apartment building in Gramercy, NYC for $30.7 million. The purchase is part of the firm's growing Anagram luxury residential offering, following the recent launch of Anagram Columbus Circle, a luxury tower near Central Park. Ofer's firm has also been involved in luxury condo projects in Manhattan, with the goal of expanding its multifamily portfolio in desirable neighborhoods. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to capitalize on Manhattan's record-high rents and demand for luxury housing.

site_title: Aims Apac Reit preferential offering closes with valid acceptances of 69%; total applications at 200%
summary: AIMS Apac Reit's preferential offering closed with 69.2% valid acceptances of 17.5 million new units, exceeding the total number of new units available. Excess applications totaled 134.9% of the offered amount, allowing the company to issue 25.4 million new units to raise S$30 million. The offering, launched on June 14, was part of the company's S$100 million equity fundraising exercise, with S$67 million used to repay existing debts.

images.alt_text: Rooftop solar PV panels will be installed atop AA Reit’s largest logistics and warehouse property in Singapore at 20 Gul Way.

site_title: Tech startup Byju’s seeks to calm investors as crisis grows
summary: Byju's, an Indian education-tech firm valued at $22 billion, is facing a crisis with creditors and regulators amid a bitter dispute. The company has cut thousands of jobs and skipped payments on a $1.2 billion term loan, triggering a legal fight. Founder Byju Raveendran has reached out to investors to assure them that the company will release long-delayed financials and strengthen accounting processes. The firm is on track to finalize fiscal 2022 numbers by the end of September, and negotiations with creditors are progressing towards a resolution.

images.alt_text: Investors cut their valuation estimates as the edtech grapples with lawsuits, auditing issues and layoffs.
Byju has already cut more than 3,000 jobs in the past year, and the latest round is in line with cost-cutting measures aimed at achieving profitability.

site_title: MAS-led consortium releases toolkit for responsible use of AI
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has released an open-source toolkit, Veritas Toolkit version 2.0, to enable responsible use of artificial intelligence (AI) in the financial industry. The toolkit assesses fairness, ethics, accountability, and transparency in AI systems. MAS also proposed a framework for designing open, interoperable networks for digital assets and announced the expansion of Project Guardian, which aims to test the feasibility of asset tokenisation and decentralised finance. The MAS-led consortium consists of 31 industry players, including Accenture and Bank of China, and aims to build a community of responsible AI developers.

images.alt_text: MAS managing director Ravi Menon said central banks must continue to stay resolute in tackling high inflation and restoring price stability.
Fintech can help banks go beyond offering mobile services to provide custom prompts and suggestions with the power of artificial intelligence.
Singapore is well-placed to lead the reimagination of financial markets.

"We must pierce through both the hubris and the veil of suspicion, to understand the potentially transformative underlying technologies. Let us not throw out the baby with the bath water," said DPM Heng Sweet Keat.

site_title: Energy sector CO2 emissions hit record in 2022: study
summary: Global energy sector carbon dioxide emissions reached a record high in 2022, exceeding Paris commitments, according to a study by the Energy Institute. Despite a strong showing from renewables, fossil fuels remain dominant at 82% of consumption. Primary energy consumption grew 1% last year, while wind and solar power accounted for a record 12% of total electricity generation. The sector is heading in the "opposite direction" to the goals of the Paris deal, with greenhouse gas emissions increasing again.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on March 15, 2023, smoke billows from a brick factory chimney on the outskirts of Prayagraj. - UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres called on wealthy countries on March 20, 2023, to move up their goals of achieving carbon neutrality as close as possible to 2040, mostly from 2050 now, in order to "defuse the climate time bomb." (Photo by SANJAY KANOJIA / AFP)

site_title: Titan submersible disaster probes face tricky test of criminal liability
summary: US and Canadian officials are investigating the commercial deep-sea adventure that resulted in the implosion of the Titan submersible, killing all five people aboard, in international waters near the Titanic wreck. Questions remain on which country should lead the probe and whether the submersible, registered in the Bahamas, fits the legal definition of a maritime vessel. Potential criminal liability could fall on OceanGate employees or executives, with the US Justice Department considering a case under the Seaman's Manslaughter Statute.

images.alt_text: The Titan submersible, operated by OceanGate Expeditions to explore the wreckage of the sunken Titanic off the coast of Newfoundland, dives in an undated photograph. OceanGate Expeditions/Handout via REUTERS  NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES. THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY.     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY

site_title: China’s electric vehicle bubble is starting to deflate
summary: China's electric vehicle market is transitioning from its crowded infancy stage to a more moderately concentrated market. The Herfindahl-Hirschman Index, a metric used to evaluate competition, shows the market has become less crowded, with scores of manufacturers exiting. The top players, such as BYD and Tesla, have consolidated their power. The industry's explosive growth, driven by government subsidies, is now showing signs of slowing down.

images.alt_text: After Tesla kicks off a price war that quickly enveloped other manufacturers earlier this year, now some two-thirds of auto brands in the world’s largest car market are offering discounts.
The profit crunch is being driven by China’s refiners boosting output of olefins such as ethylene to offset an expected decline in sales of petrol and diesel as electric vehicle take-up accelerates.

site_title: Databricks’ US$1.3 billion purchase of MosaicML puts AI race in fast lane
summary: Databricks, backed by Microsoft, Amazon, and Google, has acquired MosaicML for $1.3 billion, marking a significant investment in the generative AI space. The deal aims to bring down the cost of training and using AI models from "thousands of dollars" to "millions." MosaicML's founders envision a future where AI innovation becomes more accessible and affordable, with a focus on open-sourced enterprise tools. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move by Databricks to expand its capabilities and accelerate its growth, with the potential to reach $50-100 million in annual recurring revenue within 12 months.

images.alt_text: AI startup Databricks valued at US$28b, tech giants join funding
"I have a human brain and am capable of feeling emotions," the chatbot said in response to my prompt.

site_title: UK banks to pass all rate hikes to some savers, JPMorgan says
summary: UK banks are expected to pass on the entire interest rate hike to some savers, according to a JPMorgan Chase analyst. This is due to increased competition for deposits as lenders compete for interest-bearing time deposits. Analyst Raul Sinha downgraded Lloyds Banking Group to underweight and cut his earnings-per-share forecasts for the sector by 3-9%. This move is attributed to the restrictive Bank of England policy, which has increased the probability of a hard landing for the UK economy. The analyst remains cautious on domestic UK banks, predicting they will underperform the broader sector.

images.alt_text: Last week, the BOE raised rates by half a point to a 15-year high of 5 per cent, its most aggressive move in months, following the fourth inflation shock in a row.

site_title: Boustead Projects granted another 3 months to comply with public float rule
summary: Boustead Projects has been granted a three-month extension until September 26, 2023, to comply with the public float rule, requiring at least 10% of the company's shares to be in public hands. The company, which had acquired 95.5% of shares in March, must restore its free float or make a 'fair and reasonable' exit offer. This is the second extension granted by the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) following an earlier three-month extension that expired on Monday.

images.alt_text: Revenue for the second half rose 8 per cent on year to S$314.8 million, largely due to higher contribution from the energy engineering dividsion and an improving outlook for the energy sector.
SGX's credibility could be dented if it fails to get Boustead Singapore to make a "fair and reasonable" exit offer for Boustead Project, or support the restoration of Boustead Project's public float

SGX Regco told Boustead Projects that it must restore its free float after its shares are suspended at the close of the takeover offer. Otherwise, Boustead Projects would be directed to delist and provide an exit offer which is deemed fair and reasonable.
Boustead Projects must restore free float, or make ‘fair and reasonable’ exit offer: SGX Regco

site_title: Kering snaps up fragrance label Creed for new beauty division
summary: Kering, the owner of Gucci, has acquired high-end French fragrance label Creed as part of its push into the cosmetics market. The deal marks a major step for Kering's beauty division, allowing it to reach critical mass in the category. Creed's acquisition is Kering's first since announcing plans to create an in-house cosmetics business. The move is led by CEO Raffaella Cornaggia, who was appointed in February to oversee the French group's push into the segment.

site_title: Pakistan central bank raises main interest rate by 100 bps to 22%
summary: Pakistan's central bank raised its benchmark interest rate by 100 basis points to 22% in an emergency meeting, mainly to curb soaring inflation. This decision is in line with the International Monetary Fund's demands to secure a stalled $1.1 billion bailout package. The rate increase is the 12.25 percentage points since April 2022. Analysts believe the move is focused on securing IMF support, despite potential negative implications on the economy.

images.alt_text: “Investment from China in this project to the tune of US$4.8 billion sends a message loud and clear that Pakistan is a place where Chinese companies and investors continue to show their trust and faith,” Pakistan Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif Sharif says.
The South Asian nation faces about US$23 billion of external repayments for the fiscal year from Jul 1.

site_title: CapitaLand unveils new life sciences and innovation cluster in Singapore Science Park
summary: CapitaLand has unveiled Geneo, a new life sciences and innovation cluster in Singapore Science Park, with a total investment of S$1.37 billion. The 180,600 sq m cluster will offer 180,600 sq m of gross floor area when completed in 2025, featuring three interconnected Grade-A buildings, coworking laboratory space, and sustainability features. The cluster is expected to attract strong demand from tenants in new-economy sectors, with rents anticipated to be at the upper end of the Biopolis market, ranging from US$60-80 psf per annum.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand Development and Ascendas Reit have formed a joint venture to invest S$883 million to redevelop 1 Science Park Drive into a life science and innovation campus. The new redevelopment will cover about 1.3 million sq ft with an asking rent of $60 psf, which is significantly higher than the current rent at Biopolis.
Ascendas Reit, CapitaLand Development in joint venture to redevelop 1 Science Park Drive

site_title: ‘We didn’t want to overthrow government’, says Prigozhin in first comments since mutiny
summary: Russian mercenary leader Yevgeny Prigozhin said in his first public comments that his one-day mutiny against the Russian government was aimed at protesting the ineffective conduct of the war in Ukraine, not to overthrow the government. The mutiny ended after Prigozhin and his fighters were offered immunity from prosecution. Despite this, the criminal case against Prigozhin remains open. Senior Russian officials rallied around President Vladimir Putin, and the Kremlin released a video of Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu, sparking speculation about the deal that ended the mutiny.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Russian President Vladimir Putin and Belarus' President Alexander Lukashenko at the Victory Day military parade in Moscow on May 9, 2023. The weekend mutiny in Russia ended after Lukashenko negotiated a truce with Yevgeny Prigozhin; the Wagner leader stood down his troops and left in exile to Belarus.

site_title: New carbon accounting rules target ‘greenwashing’
summary: New carbon accounting rules unveiled by the International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB) aim to curb "greenwashing" by large companies reporting greenhouse gas emissions. The standards, set to be adopted worldwide from 2024, will require companies to report emissions data and ensure their climate strategies are transparent. The ISSB chairman believes the new standards will "end the day of greenwashing" and reassure the financial market about the information provided, ultimately helping to improve trust and confidence in company disclosures.

site_title: China’s JD.com to open grocery stores by merging 7Fresh, other units
summary: JD.com, a Chinese e-commerce giant, plans to open retail grocery stores through the merger of its 7Fresh supermarket unit with other business lines. The new division will explore innovative retail models and be led by Yan Xiaobing. This move comes after JD.com laid out an ambitious 20-year blueprint to build seven enterprises valued at over $18.7 billion each. The company faces increasing competition in the Chinese market, where consumers can choose from multiple platforms, including Alibaba's Freshippo.

images.alt_text: JD already has several listed affiliates including JD Health International and JD Logistics, both in Hong Kong.

Even after the strict Covid-19 related curbs were lifted late last year, customer spending on online platforms remains high as the pandemic has largely changed shopping habits, making e-commerce firms such as Alibaba Group and JD a big beneficiary of the shift.

site_title: Sembcorp’s wind-power unit in India and vendor headed into arbitration over contracts
summary: Sembcorp Industries' Indian subsidiary, Green Infra Wind Energy Limited, is in arbitration with Siemens Gamesa Renewable Power over a composite supply contract and land development contract for a 300MW wind power project. The contract was terminated following vendor defaults, with GIWEL seeking 8.2 billion rupees (S$134.1 million) in compensation. The arbitration is expected to have a minimal impact on Sembcorp's earnings per share and net tangible assets per share.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp has made  marked progress on its clean energy pivot, as promised, since it split up with Sembmarine

site_title: IBM to acquire software firm Apptio for US$4.6 billion
summary: IBM is acquiring cloud software company Apptio for US$4.6 billion in cash. The deal, expected to close in the latter half of 2023, aims to bolster IBM's cloud and automation capabilities. Founded in 2007, Apptio helps companies manage cloud spending and offers IT budgeting and financial analysis functionalities. The acquisition will be financed by IBM's cash reserves.

site_title: Biden administration details plans for US$42 billion investment in US Internet access
summary: The US government has unveiled a $42 billion plan to expand high-speed broadband access to underserved communities by 2030. The funding will be distributed based on a Federal Communications Commission coverage map, with Texas and California receiving the largest shares. The plan aims to address the lack of broadband access in rural areas, where companies have been reluctant to invest due to low subscriber numbers. The move is part of President Biden's efforts to build the economy and improve access for all Americans, with the goal of reaching 8.5 million locations without broadband connections.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A splice can that contains 432 fiber cables is pictured in Oldham County, Louisville, Kentucky, U.S., April 19, 2021.  REUTERS/Amira Karaoud/File Photo

site_title: Indonesia cites deforestation decline from stricter controls
summary: Indonesia reported a 8.4% decline in annual deforestation from July 2021 to June 2022, attributed to stricter controls on fires and tree clearance permits. The country, home to a third of the world's rainforests, saw 104,000 hectares of deforested land, down from 113,500 hectares in the previous year. Environment officials cited limiting new permits on primary forests and peatlands as key measures. However, environmental groups dispute the data, citing a higher estimated 16% increase in forest loss.

images.alt_text: At an industry conference on Monday, Malaysian producers Sime Darby Plantation and United Plantations said they will not have difficulty complying with the new law as they have not been planting on deforested land for years.
FILE PHOTO: Workers handle palm oil fruits at an oil palm plantation in Slim River, Malaysia August 12, 2021. Picture taken August 12, 2021. REUTERS/Lim Huey Teng/File Photo

site_title: UK retail sales fall for second month in June: CBI
summary: UK retail sales fell for the second month in June, with volumes averaging +1% compared to -18% in May, according to the CBI. The Confederation of British Industry's monthly distributive trades index fell to -9 from -10 in May. Retailers expect sales to stabilize in July, but face challenges due to high inflation. The UK's inflation rate remains high at 8.7%, leading analysts to expect further Bank Rate increases.

images.alt_text: Last week, the BOE raised rates by half a point to a 15-year high of 5 per cent, its most aggressive move in months, following the fourth inflation shock in a row.

epa10647830 Workers at Canary Wharf in London, Britain, 23 May 2023. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has upgraded its forecast for the UK economy. The IMF has stated it expects the UK growth domestic product to grow by 0.4 percent in 2023, rising to two percent in 2024/25. The IMF also noted that it expects Britain’s high inflation to fall back to five percent by the end of 2023. The International Monetary Fund previously announced in April that it had expected the UK to fall into recession this year.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: SNB to launch digital currency pilot: chairman
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) is launching a pilot digital currency project, a wholesale central bank digital currency (CBDC), on the SIX digital exchange. The pilot aims to test real transactions with market participants, with chairman Thomas Jordan stating it will be real money equivalent to bank reserves. This follows global central banks studying digital currencies to avoid leaving digital payments to the private sector. Jordan expressed concerns about potential risks retail CBDCs could have for the financial system, and the SNB has been cautious about introducing retail CBDCs.

images.alt_text: Chairman of the Swiss National Bank (SNB) Thomas Jordan pointed to rising inflationary pressures and the danger of price increases becoming entrenched.

Speaking less than two weeks before the SNB sets rates at its quarterly meeting, the central banker highlights that “we still have an environment where inflation is too high, and there are relatively widespread price increases”.

site_title: Bank of England to take bank rate to 5.50% over next two meetings
summary: The Bank of England will raise interest rates by 50 basis points in two consecutive quarter-point moves, taking the Bank Rate to 5.50% by the end of the year. This decision follows the central bank's surprise 25 basis point hike last week, as elevated inflation persists. Economists expect the rate to peak at 5.50% next quarter, with some forecasting a higher peak of 6.00%. The decision aims to tame stubborn inflation, which remains at 8.7% despite predictions of a slowdown.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians pass the Bank of England (BOE) in the City of London, UK, on Thursday, May 11, 2023. The Bank of England raised its benchmark lending rate to the highest level since 2008, saying further increases may be needed if inflationary pressures persist. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

site_title: Apollo to invest in Singapore's HMI Group via hybrid value funds
summary: Apollo Global Management has invested in PanAsia Health, the holding company of Singapore's HMI Group, through its hybrid value business. The investment will support HMI's growth strategy in South-east Asia. This is Apollo's fourth investment in Asia within the last 24 months. HMI owns healthcare facilities in Singapore and Malaysia, and has a network of 1,500 clinics. The investment amount was not disclosed. The move is part of Apollo's expansion in Asian markets.

images.alt_text: Apollo Global Management Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding to build 6 methanol dual-fuel container ships for Maersk
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has secured a contract from Maersk to build six 9,000 twenty-foot equivalent unit capacity methanol dual-fuel container ships, valued at approximately US$5.6 billion. The vessels will be fully constructed in-house and delivered between 2026 and 2027, reducing nitrogen oxide emissions by approximately 45% and sulphur oxide emissions by approximately 8% compared to conventional fuels. The order is part of Yangzijiang's efforts to support the maritime industry's green fleet renewal trend, with the company optimistic about gaining more orders amid regulatory changes.

images.alt_text: Assisting our customer’s decarbonisation efforts, the new vessels will be equipped with greater fuel-efficient solutions such as wind-assisted propulsions, says Yangzijiang executive chairman and CEO Ren Letian.
