There's money to be made from flipping bags on the secondary market – if you can get your hands on the right pieces and are willing to wait.
The financial world's favourite TV drama Succession is now in its 4th and final season.
Ling Fu decided to start her own luxury handbag label when she got frustrated with the buying process of coveted handbags.
Xtra's UHNW Chinese clients favour brands like Tom Dixon, whose Melt modern lights are pictured here.
Han Chong's contemporary luxury label, Self-Portrait, is known for its ultra-feminine designs.

site_title: Future-proofing companies key to investment mission
summary: KKR's global head of public affairs, Ken Mehlman, emphasizes the importance of future-proofing companies to create and protect value through sustainable investing. The firm recognizes the need to manage material sustainability issues and climate risks, and has identified four key objectives to achieve this: managing ESG topics, engaging human capital, managing climate risks, and protecting data privacy and cybersecurity. By adopting these strategies, KKR aims to create stronger, better investment outcomes and mitigate risks, ultimately aligning with its fiduciary duty to clients and stakeholders.

images.alt_text: The Russia-Ukraine war has disrupted global wheat supplies, highlighting the need to address disruptions to food supply and distribution
Skyline of the Central Business District (CBD) and Marina Bay Financial Centre.
Sustainability living and Sustainabiltiy investing

site_title: PwC Global takes control of Australia arm, replaces CEO
summary: PwC Global has taken control of its Australia arm, replacing CEO Kirstin Stubbins with Kevin Burrowes, who will relocate from Singapore. The firm plans to sell its government consulting arm to private equity investor Allegro Funds for A$1, affecting around 130 partners and 2,000 staff. The move aims to rebuild trust and insulate the business from further damage following a tax scandal. The deal, representing 20% of revenue, will see Allegro set up a new firm, Bell, and split ownership between Allegro and former PwC partners.

images.alt_text: Several major pension funds have frozen work with PwC and Australia’s most populous state bans the firm from new tax work for three months.

site_title: More China EV makers eye Thailand as production base
summary: Chinese electric vehicle makers Hozon New Energy Automobile, Chongqing Changan Automobile, GAC Aion, Great Wall Motor, and BYD are investing in Thailand to establish production and distribution bases for the South-east Asian market. The investments are backed by recent incentives and are expected to increase with the Thai-Chinese Chamber of Commerce hosting the 16th World Chinese Entrepreneurs Conference in Bangkok. Thailand's foreign investment applications have more than doubled, with Chinese firms seeking to invest in industries such as battery production and electronics.

images.alt_text: Narit Therdsteerasukdi, Secretary General of Thailand Board of Investment (BOI), says: "We are talking to many companies, not only CATL but many companies in the battery industry.”

site_title: China’s latest holiday spending still below pre-Covid levels
summary: China's domestic tourism revenue reached 37.3 billion yuan during the Dragon Boat Festival holiday, 94.9% of the 2019 pre-pandemic level. This marks a slowdown in consumption, with travel spending falling short of pre-Covid levels. The country's economy is facing mounting evidence of a slowdown, with investment banks downgrading growth forecasts. Despite this, policymakers expect China to meet its 5% growth target for the year. The data suggests a fading post-Covid recovery momentum for in-person services, with further weakening expected in consumption growth in coming months.

site_title: Thai rates still low, tightening to be gradual, says central bank official
summary: Thailand's central bank official, Mathee Supapongse, stated that the country's interest rate remains low, around 2%, and will be gradually tightened to curb inflation risks as the economy recovers. This is consistent with the bank's long-term economic growth prospects. The rate is considered the lowest in South-east Asia, which is expected to promote future investment. Policymakers aim to ensure a continued recovery in the economy, driven by tourism and private consumption, with forecasted economic growth of 3.6% this year and 3.8% in 2024.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Thailand (BOT) sees average headline inflation returning to within its target range of 1 per cent to 3 per cent in 2023.

site_title: Singapore looking to launch guidelines for the valuation of intangible assets
summary: Singapore's Intellectual Property Office (IPOS) plans to launch guidelines for valuing intangible assets, such as trademarks and patents, to address gaps in existing practices. The new guidelines will build upon international valuation standards and be interoperable across jurisdictions. IPOS is seeking a contractor to propose an outline for the guidelines, which will facilitate drafting and drafting in the next phase of work. The goal is to improve consistency in intangible asset valuation practices globally.

images.alt_text: The new framework aims to help businesses communicate the value of their intangibles and maximise their economic potential.

site_title: How leaders can navigate the new workplace holistically
summary: Leaders must navigate the new workplace holistically, addressing the needs of both employees and organisations. A model, the integrated employee value proposition (iEVP), offers a balanced approach, comprising material offerings, growth and development, connection and community, and meaning and purpose. Implementing the iEVP requires commitment, data collection, and ongoing measurement to ensure a sustainable culture. Leaders should engage in dialogue, foster flexibility, and regularly reassess employee needs to create a thriving and sustainable future for the organisation and its employees.

images.alt_text: Company well-being initiatives aren’t always making it out of the boardroom.

site_title: Philippine finance secretary sees ‘long pause’ in rate hikes
summary: Philippine Finance Secretary Benjamin Diokno expects the central bank to maintain a "long pause" in interest rate hikes as inflation is expected to decline. The central bank held its key policy rate steady at 6.25% for the second consecutive meeting. Inflation has slowed to 6.1% in May but remains above the target of 2-4%. Diokno believes inflation could hit below 2% by the first quarter of next year, making it a potential time for rate cuts, but no cuts are expected until strong evidence of a decline in inflation is seen.

images.alt_text: Eli Remolona, who sits on the seven-man policy-making Monetary Board, will replace Felipe Medalla, as new Philippines central bank governor,  starting July.
The BSP has done enough after 425 basis points of hikes in the past year.

site_title: MFA advises Singaporeans to postpone trips to Russia, Ukraine due to unstable security situation
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Foreign Affairs advises Singaporeans to postpone non-essential travel to Russia due to the unstable security situation in its southern region, which could spread to other parts of the country. It also advises against travel to Ukraine and urges Singaporeans in Russia to avoid inter-state trips within the country. The move comes after recent incidents of shelling, drone attacks, and bombings in Russia. Singaporeans are advised to remain vigilant, take necessary precautions, and register with the MFA for personal safety.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - Members of Wagner group prepare to pull out from the headquarters of the Southern Military District to return to their base in Rostov-on-Don late on June 24, 2023. Rebel mercenary leader Yevgeny Prigozhin who sent his fighters to topple the military leaders in Moscow will leave for Belarus and a criminal case against him will be dropped as part of a deal to avoid "bloodshed," the Kremlin said on June 24. (Photo by Roman ROMOKHOV / AFP)

site_title: Hong Kong may relax some mortgage rules: finance chief
summary: Hong Kong's finance chief, Paul Chan, is considering relaxing mortgage loan-to-value ratios for some residential property purchases to balance financial stability and first-time homeowners' interests. The city last raised the cap for first-time buyers to a 10% down payment of HK$10 million. Chan also warned of a high-interest rate environment amid US Federal Reserve rate hikes. The move comes as Hong Kong's residential market shows signs of weakness, with home prices potentially dropping 7% by the end of the year.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding wins contract for three combination carriers from repeat customer
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has secured a contract from repeat customer Klaveness Combination Carriers to build three 83,300 dwt vessels for delivery in 2026. The new combination carriers, equipped with fuel-efficient solutions such as wind-assisted propulsion, are expected to reduce overall carbon dioxide emissions by about 35% and idle sailing. The order comes after Yangzijiang delivered eight combination carriers to the customer between 2019 and 2021, and is valued at an undisclosed amount.

images.alt_text: Over the past quarter year to date, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has delivered 16 vessels, translating to 28 per cent of its delivery target of 57 vessels this year.

site_title: Singapore Aquatics and South East CDC launch swimming programme for vulnerable children and youth
summary: Singapore Aquatics (SAQ) and the South East Community Development Council (CDC) have launched a free learn-to-swim programme, "Empowering Lives Through Aquatics", targeting vulnerable children and youth aged 6-14. The 52-week programme aims to equip participants with water survival and swimming competency skills, with plans to reach 100 participants by the end of the year. The initiative is part of SAQ's vision to make "Every Singaporean a Swimmer", with plans to expand to other districts and aquatic disciplines over the next three years.

site_title: US retailers targeted with bomb threats, seeking bitcoin and gift cards
summary: US retailers, including Walmart, Kroger, and Whole Foods Market, have received bomb threats at their stores in recent months. The threats, which began in New Mexico and spread to Wisconsin, demand payment in bitcoin or gift cards. In some cases, employees were asked to wire money or hand over cash. Authorities, including the FBI, are investigating the incidents, but it's unclear if they are part of an organized effort. The FBI is urging the public to report any suspicious activity.

images.alt_text: View of Walmart's newly remodeled Supercenter, in Teterboro, New Jersey, U.S., June 7, 2023. REUTERS/Siddharth Cavale

site_title:
Commodity-linked Canadian dollar weakens 
as global data spook investors
summary: The Canadian dollar weakened 0.3% against the US dollar, falling to 1.3193 to the greenback, amid global economic concerns. A slowdown in business data from the Eurozone and a decline in US business activity contributed to the decline. Oil prices also dropped 0.5% to $69.16 a barrel, sparking worries about demand. The loonie had reached a nine-month high on Thursday, but investors are now awaiting the release of Canada's May inflation report for guidance on Bank of Canada policy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar and euro banknotes are seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Honda recalling 1.3 million vehicles worldwide for rear camera issue
summary: Honda is recalling 1.3 million vehicles worldwide due to a potential issue with the rearview camera image. The affected vehicles include 2018-2023 Odyssey, 2019-2022 Pilot, and 2019-2023 Passport models. The recall covers 1.2 million US vehicles, 88,000 in Canada, and 16,000 in Mexico. Dealers will install an improved cable harness to resolve the issue, which has resulted in 273,870 warranty claims since May 2017, but no reported injuries or deaths.

site_title: Workers are losing power in the US job market. That’s good news for the Fed
summary: The US job market is shifting back towards employers as workers become more cautious about quitting, according to a labor leverage ratio that has retraced about two-thirds of its rise since 2021. This shift is seen as good news for the Federal Reserve, which has been concerned about a too-hot jobs market and its implications for labor costs and inflation. Worker compensation grew 4.8% in Q1, down from 5.1% in the previous quarter, while the quits rate fell to 2.4% in April, marking the end of the Great Resignation.

images.alt_text: Company well-being initiatives aren’t always making it out of the boardroom.

site_title: German economy bids goodbye to years of plenty
summary: Germany's economy is facing significant challenges, including soaring inflation, high interest rates, a sluggish recovery in its key export market China, and high energy costs. The country is expected to finish the year in recession, with GDP growth predicted to be around 0.2-0.4%. Experts warn that the malaise may be more than temporary, with a growing number of businesses considering relocating to other countries. Chancellor Olaf Scholz's vision of a green economy and post-2045 growth is being questioned, with many experts predicting relatively sluggish growth over the next few years due to structural weaknesses such as slow bureaucracy and an ageing population.

images.alt_text: Due to inflation, private consumption will fall by 1.7 per cent this year, Ifo says, adding that the figure will not rise again until 2024, when it is expected to post a 2.2 per cent increase.

site_title: Mexico's 'super peso' creates both winners and losers
summary: Mexico's peso has become one of the world's best-performing currencies this year, rising to around 17.1 per US dollar as of June 23. The currency's strong performance is attributed to high interest rates, financial stability, and inflows of remittances and foreign investment. This has led to double-digit percentage gains against the US dollar in 2023, benefiting some individuals like Rosario, whose remittances from the US increased in value. However, the strong peso has also created challenges for others, including those who rely on a lower exchange rate.

images.alt_text: The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) provides that a consulting party may ask for a dispute settlement panel to be set up if parties fail to resolve the matter within 75 days of the consultation request.

site_title: Men are returning to offices in US faster than women, new data shows
summary: Men in the US are returning to offices faster than women, according to government data. The share of men working at home dropped to 28% in 2022, while women's share fell only slightly to 41%. This disparity may be attributed to women continuing to shoulder the burden of housework and childcare. Despite this, many workers still favor remote work options, with searches for remote jobs increasing by almost five times pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: Setting an expectation that it’s OK (or even necessary) to work beyond your contracted hours disadvantages those that need more flexibility, such as carers, who are typically women.

The new directive will help workers better understand their position in the wider pay structure of a company, and includes collective measures to ensure employers share aggregated pay data broken down by gender.
Recent research shows men are 19 per cent more likely to assess their abilities higher than they really are, which can affect career outcomes for men and women.

site_title: Tackling burnout by tracking employee wellness data
summary: A new study by Deloitte and Workplace Intelligence found that 85% of C-suite executives believe organizations should require mandatory reporting of well-being metrics, but only half of executives think their own companies are doing enough to promote transparency. The study coincides with the US Securities & Exchange Commission's efforts to require public companies to disclose "human capital" data, including workforce health and benefits. While initial numbers show that most employees' health has not improved, the study highlights the need for concrete steps companies are taking to invest in employee health resources and for executives to model healthy behaviors.

images.alt_text: Traditional strategies that narrowly focus on financial output have become increasingly risky; long-term value is not just about immediate financial returns.
If you're looking for a job, it might be worth seeking out a workplace that prioritises employee wellbeing over job performance.
The concept of building naps into the working day remains anathema to most companies – even if it boosts mental wellbeing or helps attract top talent.

site_title: Homebuilding set to boost US economy after 2-year contraction
summary: The US homebuilding industry is expected to boost the economy after a 2-year contraction, with new construction activity reaching its highest level in over a year. The Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta's GDPNow tracker projects a 0.1% increase in residential investment in the second quarter, marking the first positive contribution since early 2021. Falling materials costs and limited resale market availability are driving demand for new homes, despite elevated mortgage rates. However, the outlook remains uncertain, with further interest rate hikes potentially weighing on new-home construction and limiting upside momentum.

images.alt_text: A worker nails a piece of lumber to a wall frame on the site of a home under construction at the M/I Homes Inc. Bougainvillea Place housing development in Ellenton, Florida, U.S., on Thursday, July 6, 2017. The U.S. Census Bureau is scheduled to release housing starts figures on July 19. Photographer: Ty Wright/Bloomberg

site_title: S Korea may cut 2023 GDP growth forecast on sluggish chip sales
summary: South Korea is considering lowering its 2023 economic growth forecast due to a downturn in the semiconductor industry. The Bank of Korea revised its forecast to 1.4% in May from 1.6% in February, citing the chip industry's decline. Finance ministry officials suggest a revised projection of 1.4% to 1.5%, with the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and the Korea Development Institute predicting 1.5% growth this year. The government has not released its economic policy direction for the second half of the year.

site_title: Nvidia CEO says chipmaker ‘extremely likely’ to invest in Europe
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang stated that the chipmaker is "extremely likely" to invest in Europe, following a meeting with European Commissioner Thierry Breton. Breton suggested Nvidia invest more in Europe to build its future, and the company's value has jumped due to its popularity in data centers for artificial intelligence. Nvidia's data center sales increased 41% to $15 billion in 2022. The company plans to expand globally and Breton invited Huang to discuss further in Brussels next month.

images.alt_text: The top ESG funds so far in 2023 are all tech-heavy and invested in AI, and all have returned more than 40 per cent.
“Their service will help enterprises around the world harness these capabilities to automate and accelerate,” Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang says of Cohere.

site_title: Gloom returns to China markets as stimulus trade fizzles out
summary: China's stock markets are experiencing a downturn, with the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index plummeting 6% in four sessions, its steepest weekly drop since March. The CSI 300 Index and yuan have also declined, with analysts attributing the slump to Beijing's modest stimulus measures, which are perceived as insufficient to revive the economy. Market sentiment remains bearish, with hedge funds increasing their short positions and active managers selling Chinese growth and tech stocks. The economy's momentum loss and record debt levels are also cited as concerns.

images.alt_text: Several months in a row of softer-than-expected consumption, production and property market data show how China’s recovery is falling short of high hopes.

site_title: Russia back in investors' focus after weekend mutiny
summary: Russia's aborted mutiny has sparked concerns among investors, with some predicting a shift towards safe-haven assets like US Treasuries and commodities. Despite a de-escalation, uncertainty about leadership in Russia may lead investors to flock to these assets. Market experts predict that the US dollar may gain support, and gold prices could rise, as investors become increasingly cautious. The situation has also reignited concerns about Russia's nuclear stockpile and the potential for subsequent instability.

images.alt_text: A destroyed car in the recently liberated village of Neskuchne in the Donetsk region, amid the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
FILE PHOTO: European Union flags flutter outside the European Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, June 5, 2020.  REUTERS/Yves Herman//File Photo
“Today, relations between Russia and China are at an unprecedented high level,” Russian Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin tells Chinese Premier Li Qiang in their meeting.

site_title: Huge jump in mortgage costs facing 1.4 million Britons, IFS says
summary: The UK's mortgage costs are expected to surge, with around 1.4 million Britons facing a 20% increase in disposable income loss. Average mortgage holders will pay an extra £280 per month, while one in 10 will face a £360 monthly increase, particularly under the age of 40. The rising costs are driven by investors' expectations of higher interest rates to combat inflation, which will hit hardest in London. The findings add pressure on Prime Minister Rishi Sunak ahead of the general election by January 2025.

images.alt_text: In Kensington and Chelsea, 5.7 per cent of the population has a place away.

site_title: Amazon commits to US$15 billion India investment, CEO says
summary: Amazon has committed to investing an additional US$15 billion in India, bringing its total investment to US$26 billion by 2030. This investment, announced by CEO Andy Jassy to Prime Minister Narendra Modi, will focus on supporting Indian startups, creating jobs, and empowering individuals and small businesses. This follows Amazon's cloud computing unit, Amazon Web Services, announcing a US$17.5 billion investment in the country by 2030.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on April 16, 2020 A picture shows the Amazon logo at the entrance area of the Amazon logistics centre in Lauwin-Planque, northern France, on April 16, 2020. - Amazon CEO Andy Jassy said March 20, 2023 he was cutting 9,000 more jobs from the online retail giant's workforce, following the 18,000 that were axed in January. (Photo by DENIS CHARLET / AFP)

site_title: Return to Office enters the desperation phase
summary: Companies are implementing stricter return-to-office policies, with incentives like $10 charitable donations for employees who come into the office and consequences for those who don't meet performance expectations. Many businesses, including Salesforce, Google, and DocuSign, are adopting hybrid models, with employees splitting time between in-person and remote work. The shift comes as business leaders accept that hybrid work is a permanent reality, with over a quarter of full workdays now done at home. Executives are seeking to make in-person time more valuable, citing the need for face-to-face interaction and collaboration.

images.alt_text: A "Wall Street" sign near the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US on Thursday, March 23, 2023. Stocks struggled for direction as banks remained lower even after Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said in prepared remarks to lawmakers that the US is ready to take further measures to protect deposits, if needed. Photographer: Angus Mordant/Bloomberg
Larry Gadea of Envoy created office “heat maps” so companies know which areas get used the most. Down the road, he plans to offer up those unused desks and meeting rooms to companies that need them.
There is still a long way to go to make the modern office fully inclusive.

site_title: Singapore, Sichuan companies sign 6 MOUs as bilateral trade hits record US$2.7 billion in 2022
summary: Singapore and Sichuan companies signed six memoranda of understanding, marking the country's continued interest in the region. Bilateral trade reached a record high of US$2.7 billion in 2022, with Singapore being Sichuan's largest foreign investor. The Singapore-Sichuan Trade and Investment Committee has made progress in three key areas: trade and connectivity, innovation, and sustainable development. The two countries aim to deepen and broaden their strategic cooperation, leveraging Sichuan's position as a major agricultural production base and trading hub.

images.alt_text: Singapore was Sichuan's largest foreign investor in H1 2021: ESG

site_title: ECB entering final stretch of interest rate hikes, says official
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is nearing the end of its interest rate hike cycle, with vice-president Luis de Guindos stating that the bank is "entering the final stretch." Since last July, the ECB has raised borrowing costs by 400 basis points, with another move expected next month. The timing of the final rate hike will depend on data on core inflation, which de Guindos considers crucial. Policymakers are also warning that more rate hikes may be needed after the summer break, and that fiscal policy will play a role in lowering inflation.

site_title: Microsoft executive vows to keep Call of Duty on Sony consoles
summary: Microsoft executive Phil Spencer has sworn under oath to continue releasing Call of Duty on Sony's PlayStation consoles, despite the US Federal Trade Commission's claim that the acquisition of Activision Blizzard would reduce competition in the console gaming market. Spencer's promise could hurt the FTC's attempt to halt the $69 billion deal, which would vault Microsoft to the No 3 position in the global games market. The deal's closure deadline is July 18, and a ruling in favor of the FTC could jeopardize its completion.

images.alt_text: Final Fantasy’s rich storytelling and colourful characters have made it one of the top-selling game franchises, with more than 173 million copies sold worldwide.
FILE PHOTO: A 3D-printed YouTube icon is seen in front of a displayed YouTube logo in this illustration taken October 25, 2017. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Ilustration/File Photo

site_title: Sunak fully supports Bank of England on rates
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak fully supports the Bank of England's decision to increase interest rates, stating that inflation is the enemy that must be conquered. Despite high inflation rates in the UK, Sunak believes the BOE is doing the right thing. The BOE's terminal rate could reach 6.25% by December, the highest in 25 years. The government is considering blocking pay rises for public workers to help control inflation, which remains stubbornly high.

images.alt_text: Shoppers pass an Armani Exchange store with a promotional offer in the window on Oxford Street in central London, UK, on Friday, June 23, 2023. UK retail sales rose unexpectedly in May, indicating strength in the economy that the Bank of England fears may be feeding inflation. Photographer: Carlos Jasso/Bloomberg

site_title: Volkswagen prevails against US counties' diesel emissions claims
summary: A federal judge has ruled in favor of Volkswagen, dismissing lawsuits brought by Utah's Salt Lake County and Florida's Hillsborough County over the company's diesel emissions cheating scandal. US District Judge Charles Breyer found that the counties could not prove Volkswagen violated regulations against tampering with vehicles' emission control systems. This decision is a significant victory for Volkswagen, which has already reached a $85 million settlement with Texas and paid over $30 billion in total penalties and settlements worldwide.

images.alt_text: VW’s mass-market and luxury vehicle groups will implement their own programmes to increase margins with a broader EV lineup and a range of cost cuts.
Volkswagen's battery chief Thomas Schmall says PowerCo will be ready next year and more information would be disclosed at Volkswagen’s capital markets day next Wednesday.

site_title: Shares of startups are turning dirt cheap, attracting venture funds
summary: Shares of startups are trading at a median discount of 61% compared to valuations at their latest funding rounds, attracting venture capital funds and other money managers. As cash-strapped founders, employees, and investors seek to sell their stakes, secondary markets are drawing increasing interest. Hedge funds like Coatue Management and Tiger Global Management are actively hunting for deals, while traditional private equity firms like Thoma Bravo and KKR & Co are entering the market. The opportunity is the hottest since the 2008 financial crisis, with many buyers willing to pay lower prices for stakes in companies with late-stage growth.

images.alt_text: During a funding winter, innovation is significantly impacted. Funded startups often reduce their R&D efforts, while unfunded ones struggle to bring their products to market.
Singapore has now seen four startup exits valued at over US$1 billion, the latest Global Startup Ecosystem Report shows.

Not only do founders have to convince new investors to invest, but raising at a down-round valuation means founders themselves have to be diluted substantially, and they have to convince their existing investors to mark down their investment below cost to reflect the revised valuation.

site_title: Indian edtech Byju's global investors confirm board exits
summary: Byju's, an Indian edtech startup, has confirmed that three global investors have resigned from its board, citing lawsuits, auditing issues, and layoffs as reasons for their departure. The resignations, which include representatives from Peak XV Partners, Sequoia Capital India, and the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative, leave the company's board comprised solely of its founder's family. Investors have cut their valuation estimates of the company by over 60%, citing these challenges, and Byju's is now in discussions with investors to reshuffle the board and add independent directors.

images.alt_text: The case is over claims that Prakash and Lui had devised a plan to mislead the group into believing that Educomp would agree to a buyout of its stake in a joint venture when it possessed no such intention.
Edtech startup Cialfo extends Series A funding to US$15m

site_title: Norway home prices to avoid decline this year, central bank says
summary: Norway's central bank expects housing prices to rise 0.3% this year, contrary to its March forecast of a 2.9% decline. Home prices will remain near record levels, with valuations 18% higher than pre-pandemic levels by the end of the year. Weaker new home sales and lower starts will drive housing investment into a larger decline than expected, potentially slowing interest rate hikes. This contrasts with neighboring countries Sweden and Denmark, where prices are trailing last year's peaks.

site_title: Meta is well-prepared to meet Europe content rules, Breton says
summary: European Commissioner Thierry Breton stated that Meta appears well-prepared to meet the EU's strict content moderation rules under the Digital Services Act. Meta presented detailed information about its compliance efforts and agreed to a stress test of its systems in mid-July. Breton also urged Meta to increase resources fighting disinformation, particularly Russian disinformation in Eastern European countries, and discussed the company's approach to artificial intelligence regulation, which is currently in final negotiations.

images.alt_text: To meet the new rules, Twitter, Meta, TikTok and other platforms will have to invest heavily in building compliance teams.

site_title: Klimt portrait Lady with a Fan headed to auction with US$80 million price tag
summary: The last portrait painted by Austrian artist Gustav Klimt, "Lady with a Fan," is set to auction off with a price estimate of US$80 million on June 27 in London. The 1918 piece, featuring imagery from Asia, is considered a rare and high-quality portrait by Klimt, drawing on elements like a phoenix and lotus flower. It is one of only a few Klimt portraits in private collections and is expected to be the most valuable artwork to be offered at auction in Europe.

images.alt_text: In the first half of the 20th century, Grock’s success rivalled that of Charlie Chaplin. But while Chaplin satirised Hitler, Grock seems to have welcomed him into his dressing room.
Several of Michael Jackson's fedoras have been auctioned, including this one, which was sold in December, 2009 in Los Angeles.

site_title: Petrol is here to stay for decades, say fossil fuel heavyweights
summary: The world's top fossil fuel producers, including Shell and BP, are shifting focus to natural gas, citing increased demand and investments in the fuel. Despite environmental concerns, companies like Shell plan to accelerate investments in LNG, with China and European importers signing long-term deals. The US is set to become the world's top LNG exporter, and Russia's invasion of Ukraine has boosted petrol production capacity. The industry argues that natural gas is a cleaner alternative to coal, with Shell aiming for "near-zero" methane emissions by 2030.

images.alt_text: The Groningen field, operated by a joint venture of Shell and Exxon Mobil, still holds massive reserves of natural gas, but production has been almost completely wound down in the past years.
Like it or not, the big energy companies – as the oil majors prefer to style themselves these days – will have to be significant players for many years.

site_title: IBM nears US$5 billion deal for software provider Apptio: WSJ
summary: IBM is nearing a $5 billion deal to acquire software company Apptio, following its 2021 purchase of Turbonomic for $1.5 billion and 2019 acquisition of Red Hat for $34 billion. Apptio provides cloud-based and hybrid business management software. The deal, if completed, would be the latest move by IBM to expand its software portfolio. The acquisition price may include debt, and both companies have declined to comment on the report.

site_title: Credit Suisse unit loses US$607 million rogue-banker damages fight
summary: Credit Suisse's life insurance unit, CS Life (Bermuda), lost its appeal of a $607 million damages bill for failing to stop a rogue banker from defrauding a Georgian billionaire client. The court upheld the award, but dismissed the claim of fraudulent misrepresentation against the unit. The bank plans to appeal the decision to the Privy Council, maintaining that the rogue banker acted alone and was not authorized by the client. Ivanishvili, the victim, has won the third court ruling against Credit Suisse in the case, which spans almost a decade and involves alleged crimes by bank personnel.

images.alt_text: The executives are accused of doing excessively risky trades to achieve high short-term returns and bonuses.
In the Asia Pacific region, there will be significant reduction in Credit Suisse investment bankers covering Australia and China, where the two banks overlap most, two of the sources say.

site_title: Hermes wins permanent ban on 'MetaBirkin' NFT sales in US lawsuit
summary: A US federal judge has granted a permanent ban on artist Mason Rothschild's sales of 'MetaBirkin' NFTs, which the luxury house Hermes claims infringe on its trademark rights for its Birkin handbags. The judge ruled that Rothschild's continued marketing of the NFTs would likely confuse consumers and irreparably harm Hermes. A jury previously awarded Hermes $133,000 in damages after finding Rothschild's NFTs violated Hermes' trademark rights.

images.alt_text: Bandwagon's first free metaverse event, Bandwagon Pixel Party, featured Singaporean DJ MYRNE and attracted over 250 attendees.
The NFT and meme-token craze spurred record transactions and an ensuing fee windfall for miners, who run the computers underpinning Bitcoin.

site_title: Apple to appeal judge’s ruling that it violated workers’ rights
summary: Apple plans to appeal a National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) judge's ruling that the company violated employee rights by coercively interrogating workers about pro-union sympathies and restricting the circulation of union flyers. The ruling, made at Apple's World Trade Center store in New York City, ordered Apple to cease such practices. Apple disagreed with the ruling and will address it through the NLRB process, stating that regular open communication is part of its collaborative culture. The decision marks the first time an NLRB judge has ruled against Apple.

site_title: Nio enters share subscription agreement with CYVN Holdings; OCBC ups Great Eastern stake
summary: Nio delivered 31,041 vehicles in Q1FY23, including 10,430 premium smart electric SUVs and 20,611 premium smart electric sedans. Meanwhile, OCBC increased its stake in Great Eastern Holdings. Institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks, with UOB, Keppel Corporation, and ST Engineering leading the outflow. In contrast, Great Eastern Holdings, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, Seatrium, and ComfortDelGro Corporation led the institutional inflow.

images.alt_text: Over the five trading sessions from Jun 9 to Jun 15, there were 76 filings for changes in director interests and substantial shareholdings in that period from 36 primary-listed stocks, as well as 63 filings for share buybacks by 18 companies.

site_title: Boeing’s 737 output at risk with key supplier in labour turmoil
summary: Boeing's 737 production is at risk due to a labor dispute between the company and Spirit AeroSystems, a key supplier. The dispute has resulted in a 6,000-member union rejecting a four-year contract offer, leading to a strike that may impact Boeing's output of 38 jets a month by mid-year. The strike could also affect Boeing's cash flow, with the single-aisle aircraft providing 70% of the company's first-quarter revenue. Boeing is considering a monthly build rate of 42 jets before the end of the year, but the outcome of the labor dispute remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: A Pratt & Whitney GTF turbofan aero engine on display at the Paris Air Show. Company president Shane Eddy, who has faced a backlash from airlines over durability problems and a shortage of spare engines, told the air show he was seeing “solid progress” in the supply chain.

With a total of almost 1,000 jet orders between them, IndiGo and Air India are betting an economic boom and growing middle class will spur demand for domestic air travel, and new jets will help them grab a bigger share of international traffic.

site_title: Sunrun, Lunar Energy to challenge Tesla’s dominance in residential battery market
summary: Startup Lunar Energy has launched a home power storage system with Sunrun as its first installer, challenging Tesla's dominance in the residential battery market. The Lunar System provides all-in-one solar generation and storage, offering 10-30 kilowatt hour of backup power. With Sunrun's 37% stake, Lunar aims to expand to other US regions, focusing on creating a more affordable and resilient grid for Americans. The growing demand for battery storage, driven by extreme weather, is expected to increase the market's size.

site_title: YouTube is testing an online-games offering: WSJ
summary: YouTube is internally testing a product called "Playables" that allows users to play online games directly on the platform. The test includes games such as Stack Bounce, available on YouTube's website and mobile devices. The move is part of CEO Neal Mohan's push for new growth areas, as the company faces a slowdown in advertising spending. A spokesperson for YouTube stated that the company is experimenting with new features, but has nothing to announce at this time.

site_title: Australia sanctions three involved in downing of MH17
summary: Australia has imposed financial sanctions and travel bans on three individuals involved in the downing of MH17. The sanctions target Sergey Dubinsky and Leonid Kharchenko, who were convicted in absentia by a Dutch court of murder and other charges, and Colonel Sergey Muchkaev, who commanded the anti-aircraft brigade that supplied the weapons system that downed the flight. The move is Australia's "ongoing commitment to hold to account those responsible" for the 2014 disaster that killed 298 people, including 30 Australians on board.

images.alt_text: Malaysia Airlines parent firm gets green light for restructuring
Trial in MH17 crash to start hearing evidence

site_title: Carlsberg agrees to sell Russian business to undisclosed buyer
summary: Carlsberg agrees to sell its Russian business to an undisclosed buyer, subject to a regulatory review by Moscow. The sale is expected to have no impact on the company's 2023 earnings. Carlsberg CEO Cees 't Hart stated that the deal is a "very important milestone" in the separation and selling process, with a goal of reaching the best possible solution for all stakeholders. The identity and price of the buyer remain unknown, pending approval from Russian authorities.

site_title: Covid-19 origins remain a mystery, declassified report shows
summary: The US Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI) has released a declassified report on the origins of COVID-19, revealing that intelligence agencies were unable to determine whether researchers at a Wuhan, China lab fell ill with the virus in 2019, before it spread globally. The report, which comes months after President Biden signed a bill requiring declassification of pandemic-related intelligence, found no definitive evidence of lab-related work as the cause of the pandemic. Intelligence officials continue to seek key information from China, and the report's findings are unlikely to settle the ongoing debate over the pandemic's origins.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A medical worker in a protective suit registers information for a patient at the entrance to the fever clinic of the Central Hospital of Wuhan, amid of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Wuhan, Hubei province, China December 31, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: Kensington, Chelsea residents lead UK in using holiday homes
summary: Residents in Kensington and Chelsea, a London borough, lead the UK in using holiday homes, with 5.7% of the population owning a second address. The trend is part of a growing crisis in the housing market, with soaring mortgage rates pricing out first-time buyers. The UK's richest people can maintain multiple properties, while the government's commitment to building more homes has been watered down. Data shows 93,650 Londoners use a second address for holidays, with 48.5% traveling within the UK.

images.alt_text: The mortgage squeeze comes on the back of two years of declining real incomes, and households are already cutting back to make ends meet.
In line with government efforts to optimise land use, the land where the Singapore Turf Club in Kranji sits will be redeveloped for housing and other developments.

site_title: Goldman Sachs begins cutting about 125 managing directors globally
summary: Goldman Sachs is cutting about 125 managing directors globally as part of a deep cost-savings drive amid a deals slump. The layoffs, affecting investment banking and other areas, are part of a larger effort to reduce headcount. The move follows other banks, including JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup, which have also cut jobs due to falling fees. This is the latest in a series of job cuts at Goldman Sachs, which has seen at least three rounds of layoffs in less than a year. The company has declined to comment on the matter.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo for Goldman Sachs is seen on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, New York, U.S., November 17, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly//File Photo

A man exits the JPMorgan Chase & Co. headquarters building in New York, U.S. in New York, U.S., on Friday, July 8, 2011. LivingSocial, the second-largest daily-coupon site, is close to hiring JPMorgan Chase & Co. as one of the banks to manage its initial public offering, a person with knowledge of the talks said. Photographer: Jin Lee/Bloomberg

site_title: Europe: Shares post worst week in three months, Siemens Energy slumps
summary: Europe's shares declined, posting their worst weekly performance in over three months, amid interest rate hikes and concerns of elevated inflation. The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.3% lower, with Germany's DAX index shedding 1%. Siemens Energy plummeted 37.3% after withdrawing its annual profit outlook. The eurozone business growth stalled this month, and a recession in the UK is now more likely. Investors worry about the impact of protracted tightening cycles on global economic recovery.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.5 per cent lower, after falling as much as 1.3 per cent earlier in the day, on fears of continued monetary policy tightening by major central banks.

site_title: Boustead Projects to jointly redevelop logistics and manufacturing facility with two investors
summary: Boustead Projects will jointly redevelop a 59,800 sqm logistics and manufacturing facility in Tuas with two accredited investors. The redevelopment aims to tap the logistics and manufacturing market with limited supply of high-quality facilities. Expected completion is in the first half of 2025, maximizing the plot ratio of the underutilized property.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Exchange may grant an issuer a period of three months to raise the percentage of securities in public hands to 10 per cent, after which the issuer may be directed to delist and provide an exit offer deemed fair and reasonable by an independent financial adviser.

site_title: Auto union blasts US$9.2 billion Ford loan for creating ‘low-road jobs’
summary: The US Department of Energy has approved a $9.2 billion loan to Ford Motor Co and South Korea's SK On to build three battery plants in Kentucky and Tennessee, creating over 7,500 jobs. The United Auto Workers (UAW) union criticized the loan as a "massive handout" that will lead to "low-road jobs" rather than "good-paying" jobs. The UAW's president, Shawn Fain, accused the Biden administration of facilitating corporate greed with taxpayer money, while Ford defended the loan as creating competitive wages and benefits for workers.

images.alt_text: Customers of Rivian, which has its own small network of fast chargers, will be able to access 12,000 Tesla Superchargers with adaptors in the US and Canada as early as spring 2024.
Ford Motor executive chairman Bill Ford Jr, great-grandson of founder Henry Ford, said he sees an opportunity for Ford engineers to understand the technology.

site_title: SpaceX tender offer values it at around US$150 billion: report
summary: SpaceX, the private company that sent astronauts into orbit, is offering to sell insider shares at a price of over $80 apiece, valuing the company at around $150 billion. This is a significant increase from its previous valuation of $137 billion in January. The company has around $5 billion in cash on its balance sheet and has recently successfully deployed satellites to boost internet connectivity. The valuation comes after a series of successful launches and tests, including the launch of its next-generation Starship spacecraft.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: SpaceX logo and Elon Musk silhouette are seen in this illustration taken, December 19, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration
Tech titans Mark Zuckerberg (left) and Elon Musk have baited each other for years with opposing views on everything from politics to artificial intelligence.

site_title: US warns of potential 5G delays for airplanes without updated altimeters
summary: The US Department of Transportation warns of potential flight delays starting July 1 due to the lack of updated radio altimeters on some aircraft. Over 80% of the domestic US fleet has been retrofitted, but international carriers and some US airlines, including Delta, are still awaiting the necessary equipment. Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg urges airlines to adjust schedules proactively to avoid disruptions, while carriers claim they are working to meet the deadline despite global supply chain issues.

images.alt_text: Cathay is resuming its Christchurch service from Dec 16 to Feb 29 with three return flights per week.
Germany’s Lufthansa says it plans to slash its net emissions by half by 2030 compared to 2019 levels and has a “constant dialogue” with customers.

site_title: Boustead Projects seeks another 3 months to comply with public float rule
summary: Boustead Projects' parent company, Boustead Singapore, has applied for a three-month extension to comply with the public float rule, requiring at least 10% of its shares to be in public hands. The request comes after a trading suspension of Boustead Projects' shares due to the parent company holding 95.5% of its shares. Boustead Singapore is exploring options, including a "fair and reasonable" exit offer, which could lead to the delisting of Boustead Projects if not met.

images.alt_text: In Feb this year, Boustead Project’s parent, Boustead Singapore launched a voluntary unconditional general offer for the company.
Shares of Boustead Projects were last trading at S$0.955 on Mar 27.

SGX Regco told Boustead Projects that it must restore its free float after its shares are suspended at the close of the takeover offer. Otherwise, Boustead Projects would be directed to delist and provide an exit offer which is deemed fair and reasonable.
Boustead Projects must restore free float, or make ‘fair and reasonable’ exit offer: SGX Regco
The entrance of Boustead Singapore’s office.
SGX's credibility could be dented if it fails to get Boustead Singapore to make a "fair and reasonable" exit offer for Boustead Project, or support the restoration of Boustead Project's public float

site_title: Rivals seek to profit from Chelsea's fire sale
summary: Chelsea is undergoing a fire sale, trimming their bloated squad to comply with financial regulations under new owner Mauricio Pochettino. The club spent over £500 million in transfer fees last year but finished 12th in the Premier League. Key players such as N'Golo Kante and Kai Havertz are expected to leave, with Saudi interest in players like Edouard Mendy and Kalidou Koulibaly potentially benefiting Chelsea's financial situation. The club's rivals are circling to take advantage of cut-price deals, which could strengthen their competitors if Havertz, Mount, and Kovacic succeed at their new clubs.

images.alt_text: Kante has been a mainstay at Chelsea, winning the Champions League, Premier League, Europa League and FA Cup during his time with the club.

site_title: Cathay Pacific flight incident injures 11 in Hong Kong
summary: Eleven people were injured on a Cathay Pacific flight from Hong Kong to Los Angeles after the plane aborted takeoff due to a technical issue. The incident occurred when one of the plane's tyres overheated and burst, prompting a precautionary evacuation. Nine of the injured passengers were discharged from hospital, while two remain hospitalized. Cathay Pacific apologized for the disruption to customers, stating it would provide support to the affected passengers and their families. The flight, carrying 17 crew and 293 passengers, was grounded at Hong Kong's international airport.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Cathay Pacific employees work at Hong Kong International Airport, in Hong Kong, China March 8, 2023. REUTERS/Lam Yik/File Photo

site_title: US luxury sales increasingly coming from high-end shoppers: Bain
summary: US luxury sales are shifting towards high-end shoppers, with brands catering to wealthier consumers outperforming those targeting aspirational shoppers. Bain expects 5-12% growth in the global personal luxury goods market this year, driven by China's post-pandemic spending. However, US sales are slowing due to economic uncertainty and rising prices, with categories like streetwear and sneakers underperforming. Luxury brands are adapting by shifting upmarket and targeting their wealthiest clients, with retailers like Hugo Boss reporting strong growth in the US and Asia-Pacific regions.

site_title: Chinese builder halts all offshore debt payment on property market weakness
summary: A Chinese real estate developer, Central China Real Estate, has halted all offshore debt payments due to weakness in China's property market and deteriorating sales. The company cited constrained liquidity and warned that non-payment may lead to creditors demanding acceleration of debt repayment. This move comes as China's home prices have slowed down, adding to evidence of renewed weakness in the residential property market. The developer's shares have tumbled 70% this year, and a gauge of Chinese property developers has slumped 26% during the same period.

images.alt_text: Xia Haijun stepped down from the embattled Chinese property developer in July.
Expectations for more monetary and fiscal stimulus have risen following the People’s Bank of China’s surprise rate cut last week, which economists said signalled a shift to more looser policy.

site_title: Messi says he struggled to adapt after PSG move, some fans treated him differently
summary: Lionel Messi revealed that he struggled to adapt after joining Paris St. Germain in 2021, citing a difficult transition and being treated differently by some fans. Despite recording 32 goals and 35 assists in two seasons, a rift with the fans emerged after the team's Champions League exit. Messi attributed the rift to the fans' way of showing respect, which he was not used to. He expressed appreciation for fans who respected him, but stated that the incident was an "anecdote." Messi will join MLS side Inter Miami after failing to renew his contract with PSG.

images.alt_text: Argentina's Messi reacting during last week's friendly  match against Australia at the Workers' Stadium in Beijing.
Fans in the football-mad country receive bad news that Messi would not play.
There’s no official date for Messi’s debut – the multi-million US dollar deal to make him the star of Inter Miami has yet to be finalised.

site_title: Australia commits to building US$34 million renewable hydrogen plant in Victoria
summary: Australia has committed to building a US$34 million renewable hydrogen plant in Victoria, valued at A$51 million, to supply around 40,000 homes. The 10 megawatt electrolyser, to be built in Wodonga, will be the largest in Australia and will blend green hydrogen into gas networks. Construction is set to start this year, with the site expected to go live in 2025, as the country aims to reduce carbon emissions and boost alternative power resources.

images.alt_text: Thon Thamrongnawasawat, deputy dean of the Faculty of Fisheries at Kasetsart University, attributes the fish deaths to the bloom – a natural occurrence that lowers oxygen levels in the water and causes fish to suffocate.
Earlier at the conference, Andrew Forrest said that 2023 is the deadline to reach a deal with the government, or Fortescue could walk away.

site_title: Oil dips on demand worries as more rate hikes likely
summary: Oil prices fell on Friday, posting a weekly decline, amid worries about interest rate hikes potentially slowing economic growth and reducing demand. Brent crude closed down 0.4% to $73.85 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 0.5% to $69.16. Higher interest rates are expected to increase borrowing costs, slow economic growth, and boost the value of the US dollar, putting downward pressure on oil prices.

images.alt_text: On the supply side,  US crude stocks posted a surprise draw in the last week, helped by strong export demand and low imports.

site_title: Netherlands to end Groningen gas production by Oct 1
summary: The Netherlands will cease gas production at the Groningen field by October 1, as promised to limit seismic risks in the region. The field, operated by Shell and Exxon Mobil, has massive reserves but minimal extraction has been ongoing since 2022. Production facilities will be closed permanently in 2024, with an option for limited extraction in extreme circumstances. The decision comes after an earthquake in 2018 and a parliamentary inquiry that found the government and energy companies underestimated the risks of production for local residents.

site_title: Eurozone bond yields tumble, bets pile up for recession
summary: Eurozone government bond yields fell, with 10-year yields dropping 14 bps to 2.342%, after data showed the economy is flagging and expectations that the European Central Bank won't raise rates further. The yield gap between 2-year and 10-year yields is its most inverted since 1992, a sign investors are worried about growth. Economists say the downturn in manufacturing and services sectors, particularly in France and Germany, is deepening, raising concerns of a recession.

images.alt_text: A German broker at the stock exchange in Frankfurt am Main, Western Germany. Germany’s 10-year government bond yield, the euro area’s benchmark, rose 2.5 basis points (bps) to 2.43 per cent.

site_title: UK's Heathrow Airport strikes cancelled after pay deal
summary: Heathrow Airport's planned 31 days of summer strikes have been cancelled after workers accepted an improved pay offer, resulting in a 15.5-17.5% pay rise. The Unite union reported over 2,000 staff accepted the deal, avoiding potential disruptions to air travel during the peak summer season. Airport bosses expressed relief, stating they could now focus on delivering a good summer for passengers, following last year's chaos caused by similar strikes.

images.alt_text: British author and activist Michael Rosen addresses the crowd outside 10 Downing Street in London on January 18, 2023, at the end of a protest march organised by Doctors Association UK, NHS Workers Say No! and NHS Staff Voices in support of the ongoing pay disputes. - Nurses across England began two days of strikes over pay on Wednesday, threatening fresh disruption for patients in the creaking state-run health service, as new figures showed inflation still surging. (Photo by CARLOS JASSO / AFP)

site_title: UK's Hunt says banks agree to ease mortgage payments strain
summary: British Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt announced agreements with banks and mortgage lenders to ease mortgage payment strain for homeowners struggling with fast-rising interest rates. The measures include allowing homeowners to revert to their original payment packages within six months if they reduce payments, and a minimum 12-month period before repossession without consent. These agreements come after the Bank of England raised interest rates to 5.0% to combat high inflation.

site_title: Dollar gets a safety bid as data spurs growth worries
summary: The US dollar rose against the euro and other currencies, driven by concerns over global economic growth and risk aversion. US business activity growth slowed in June, but services sector remained strong, while the eurozone's business growth stalled. The dollar index rose 0.48% to 102.88, and the euro fell 0.56% to US$1.0894, a three-day low. The US Federal Reserve's aggressive interest rate hikes have renewed market fears of a recession, weighing on risk appetite and supporting the dollar.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar and euro banknotes are seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Starbucks workers at over 150 stores to go on strike over Pride decor dispute
summary: Over 3,000 Starbucks workers at over 150 US stores will go on strike starting next week to protest Pride Month decorations being banned and to demand better pay and benefits. The strike also targets employees' treatment and pushes for a fair labor contract. Starbucks denied the claims, stating there was "no change to any policy" on Pride Month celebrations. The strike coincides with US Pride Month celebrations, with parades taking place in major cities.

images.alt_text: Starbucks said transactions grew 6 per cent in the US and also rose in China.

site_title: 3M to pay up to US$12.5 billion to settle forever-chemicals lawsuits
summary: 3M has agreed to pay up to $12.5 billion over 13 years to settle claims that its forever chemicals polluted US drinking water supplies. The deal resolves current and future claims by municipal water authorities and covers all present and future claims at any level. 3M will pay a minimum of $10.5 billion, with the final amount depending on future PFAS contamination in untested water systems. The settlement is a significant milestone for the company, resolving potential liabilities estimated to be tens of billions of dollars.

images.alt_text: “We announced actions that will reduce costs at the corporate centre, further simplify and strengthen our supply chain structure, and streamline our go-to-market business models, which will improve margins and cash flow,” said 3M CEO Mike Roman.
3M’s exit from the category comes 20 years after management phased out an early, popular form of PFAS, known as PFOS, in 2002 under pressure from scientific studies about its potential harms.

site_title: S$1.5 million Tiong Bahru HDB flat sale in May marks new resale record high
summary: A 1,894.5 sq ft HDB flat at 50 Moh Guan Terrace in Tiong Bahru was sold for S$1.5 million in May, setting a new resale price record. This transaction surpassed the previous high of S$1.42 million reached by a five-room loft in June 2022. Million-dollar HDB flat sales accounted for 1.5% of transactions in May, down from 1.7% in April. The sale marked a new record, with 34 million-dollar HDB deals transacted in May, down from 37 in April.

images.alt_text: Resale prices rise at a moderate pace of 0.3 per cent in May.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends down, snaps weekly winning streak on Fed worries
summary: US stocks ended lower on Friday, snapping their weekly winning streak, amid concerns about the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. Chairman Jerome Powell signaled more rate hikes but also expressed caution. The Nasdaq composite index, led by tech stocks like Microsoft and Tesla, fell 1.01% and broke its eight-week winning streak, while the S&P 500 lost 0.77% and its five-week rally. Financial markets expect another rate hike in July, but skepticism remains about a second hike by September.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange shortly after the opening bell as trading is halted in New York, U.S., March 16, 2020. REUTERS/Lucas Jackson//File Photo

site_title: Shipping emissions tax plan backed by some 20 countries at Paris summit
summary: More than 20 countries and regional organizations have backed proposals for a shipping emissions tax at the Paris summit, paving the way for the International Maritime Organization (IMO) to consider the levy. The tax could generate $100 billion annually, which could be used to help poorer countries cope with climate change. The IMO could then set a timetable for introducing the levy, which would encourage the shipping industry to reduce its 2.9% share of global greenhouse gas emissions.

images.alt_text: The OCIMF's ship inspection programme contributes to high safety standards in the global tanker industry.

site_title: Doctors in England to hold longest strike in NHS history
summary: Junior doctors in England will hold the longest single strike in NHS history, lasting five days from July 13-18, over pay demands. The British Medical Association (BMA) claims the government's "neglect" of the medical workforce has led to doctors being offered high-paying jobs abroad, including in Australia. The strike will put patient safety at risk, prompting Prime Minister Rishi Sunak to express disappointment, while the government offers to reopen talks if the strike is called off. Hundreds of thousands of appointments have been cancelled due to the dispute.

images.alt_text: Unions representing National Health Service workers say that the government has imposed years of real-term pay cuts.

site_title: Once Upon a Times House recalls tales of newsrooms past
summary: Singapore's leading newspapers, including The Straits Times, The Business Times, and Berita Harian, were once housed at Times House, a newsroom that operated from the 1960s to the 1990s. A new book, "Once Upon a Times House," tells the story of the newsroom through the memories and experiences of 16 veteran editors and journalists. The book, launched on June 23, 2023, showcases the transformative years of Singapore's journalism, including scandals and notable events, and will benefit the BT Budding Artists Fund, which supports financially disadvantaged youth in the arts.

images.alt_text: The team behind the book hopes the stories will inspire young journalists and showcase Singapore’s history of journalism.

site_title: The race to net zero will be won or lost in Asia
summary: Asia, home to over half of the world's population, is a critical region in the global race to net zero, accounting for 50% of global primary energy consumption. Progressive policy landscapes in Singapore and Malaysia, coupled with the Monetary Authority of Singapore's Finance for Net Zero Action Plan, demonstrate a collaborative approach between regulators and investors. This consultative approach is broadening the pool of investors engaged in sustainable finance, enabling a whole-of-economy response to net zero. However, systemic risks posed by climate change require systemic change, and the lack of such collaboration in other markets highlights the need for continued progress in Asia to win the race to net zero.

images.alt_text: The political attacks on ESG seem to be working—mentions of ESG on earnings calls have fallen of late. Or perhaps companies that are committed to ESG are just being quieter about it.
Predicting the unpredictable future of ESG

Though critiques of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) considerations in investing have increased, investors should still incorporate such factors, as they provide important information on risk and returns.

site_title: Biden orders US agencies to make contraception more accessible
summary: President Biden has ordered US agencies to make contraception more accessible, directing them to consider expanding and protecting availability under federal programs. The move comes ahead of the anniversary of the Dobbs decision, which revoked federal protections for abortion rights. The new rules instruct the Departments of Labor, Treasury, and Health and Human Services to ensure government-approved contraceptives are available without cost-sharing under the Affordable Care Act. This is part of the administration's efforts to advance protections of privacy and reproductive rights, following the Supreme Court's Dobbs vs Jackson Women's Health Organization ruling.

images.alt_text: The “March for Life” crowd's position is in the minority in modern America.

site_title: Goldman Sachs faces big writedown on GreenSky deal
summary: Goldman Sachs is likely to take a large writedown for its $2.2 billion acquisition of fintech lender GreenSky after seeking to divest the business. Bids for GreenSky are coming in below Goldman's expectations, with Apollo Global Management, Sixth Street, and Warburg Pincus among the initial bidders. Goldman president John Waldron mentioned a potential writedown on the $500 million of goodwill paid above assets' book value. The bank's shares are down 1% in early trading, and a spokesperson declined to reveal details about the potential writedown.

site_title: US business activity growth slows in June, but services keep humming along
summary: US business activity slowed in June to a three-month low, with the services sector showing signs of easing growth and the manufacturing sector contracting further. The S&P Global flash US Composite PMI Output Index fell to 53.0, indicating growth in the private sector, but down from 54.3 in April. Despite this, the overall US economy is expected to have expanded in the second quarter, with GDP growth estimated at 2% and inflation remaining stubbornly above the 2% target. The Federal Reserve's aggressive interest rate increases may trigger a recession, but officials project further rate hikes may be needed to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen’s latest assessment of the US economy follows a May employment report that showed job gains beating all economists’ forecasts.

site_title: UK economy stumbles, but price pressures remain high: flash PMI
summary: The UK economy showed signs of a slowdown in June, with its Composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) dropping to a three-month low of 52.8, down from 54.0 in May. The services sector grew at its slowest pace in three months, while the manufacturing sector contracted by the most in six months. Despite higher interest rates and inflation pressures, the services sector saw the strongest growth in hiring since September last year, contributing to ongoing inflation concerns. The Bank of England is expected to continue raising borrowing costs to tackle inflation.

images.alt_text: The BOE stepped up its fight against inflation by raising interest rates by a larger-than-expected 50 basis points to 5 per cent, the highest level in 13 years.

site_title: Offeror snags more than 90% of Challenger Technologies shares
summary: DigiTech Holding, the offeror for Challenger Technologies, has acquired over 90% of the consumer electronics retailer's shares, reducing the public float to under 10%. As a result, the company may be suspended from trading due to listing rules. DigiTech Holding now holds 71.1% of the total shares, with substantial shareholder Ng Leong Hai holding 20.68%. The revised offer price remains unchanged at S$0.60.

site_title: Over 600 public buses to be refurbished by LTA, first such exercise since contracting model
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has announced plans to refurbish over 630 public buses in Singapore, marking the first such exercise since the contracting model was introduced in 2016. The midlife refurbishment will take place between 2023 and 2025, replacing bus seats, floor covers, and other components. The work aims to rectify wear and tear issues and maintain bus condition, with all refurbished buses expected to continue operating until their statutory lifespan of 17 years.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as hawkish Fed saps market mood
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday, June 23, due to the hawkish interest-rate outlook by Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 111.05 points, or 0.33%, to 33,835.66, while the S&P 500 dropped 27.72 points, or 0.63%, to 4,354.17. The Nasdaq Composite fell 146.51 points, or 1.07%, to 13,484.10. Investor sentiment remains damp due to the Fed's interest-rate outlook, leading to a decline in market mood.

site_title: Eurozone activity almost stalls as rebound from recession fades
summary: Economic activity in the euro area almost stalled in June, with a purchasing managers index falling to a five-month low of 50.3, missing analyst estimates. The slump was led by France, hit by strikes, and Germany's struggling factories. Despite a slowdown in inflationary pressures, the data suggests a difficult second half of the year, with the European Central Bank considering further interest rate hikes to control inflation. The eurozone narrowly escaped a recession, but the outlook remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: A German broker at the stock exchange in Frankfurt am Main, Western Germany. Germany’s 10-year government bond yield, the euro area’s benchmark, rose 2.5 basis points (bps) to 2.43 per cent.

site_title: Singapore to unveil improved family office tax incentives
summary: Singapore's central bank will unveil improved tax incentives in July for family offices, which manage wealthy families' assets, to recognize their charitable contributions. Family offices will also benefit from making contributions to blended finance, a mix of public and private capital, and investments in climate change solutions locally and overseas. Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam announced the changes at an event by the Association of Banks in Singapore.

site_title: JPMorgan starts euro blockchain payments for corporate clients
summary: JPMorgan has launched euro-denominated payments for corporate clients using its JPM Coin blockchain technology. The system allows for constant, quick, and cost-effective payments, enabling corporate treasurers to manage liquidity and earn interest income on deposits. The move follows JPMorgan's successful dollar transactions on its platform, which has processed over $300 billion in transactions since its launch in 2019. This is a significant expansion of the bank's blockchain project, with Germany's Siemens conducting the first euro payment on the platform.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk past the JPMorgan Chase & Co. headquarters in New York, U.S., on Monday, March 17, 2008. JPMorgan Chase & Co., hours after saying the credit-market crisis is almost over, made plans to raise $6 billion in its biggest offering of perpetual preferred stock, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.  Photographer: Andrew Harrer/Bloomberg News

site_title: US office owners get dire warning that a  rebound is unlikely before 2040
summary: US office building values are expected to plummet 35% by the end of 2025 and take an additional 15 years or more to recover due to hybrid and remote work reshaping real estate. This trend is similar to the collapse of shopping malls as e-commerce grew. Major institutional investors have already defaulted on some office buildings, with nearly $43 billion at risk of default. US office owners are facing an arduous road ahead, with a possible recovery not expected until at least 2040.

images.alt_text: Higher borrowing costs have pummelled the commercial real estate industry, driving prices lower and causing some owners to choose to default.

site_title: Japan finance minister 'firmly' watching FX moves as yen weakens
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki has warned that sharp movements in the yen's exchange rate are undesirable, urging stability in currency markets reflecting fundamentals. Suzuki is watching the yen's recent weakening amid concerns about households' suffering from high import costs, while the yen's depreciation has boosted exporters' profits. The yen was steady at 143.05 per dollar, near a seven-month low. The Bank of Japan's ultra-dovish stance has also put pressure on the currency, with core consumer inflation topping forecasts in May.

images.alt_text: Japanese Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki attends a news conference after a meeting of G7 leaders on the sidelines of G20 finance ministers' summit on the outskirts of Bengaluru, India, February 23, 2023. REUTERS/Samuel Rajkumar

site_title: Sato cut to junk rating as Swedish real estate woes hit Finland
summary: Sweden's real estate owner Sato, which manages 25,000 Finnish apartments, has been cut to junk by Moody's Investors Service, entering the high yield bracket. The rating cut follows Sweden's real estate crisis and exacerbates a financing crunch in the Nordic region. Moody's cited deteriorating interest coverage ratio, financing challenges, and Balder's weakening position, reducing the likelihood of financial support. The downgrade was seen as harsh but not surprising, given Sato's weak first-quarter results.

site_title: Indonesia entrepreneurs cash in on TikTok live-selling spree
summary: Indonesian entrepreneurs are capitalizing on TikTok's live-selling feature, with users spending over a third of goods sold in South-east Asia on the platform. Since its launch in 2021, TikTok Shop has amassed over 2 million sellers, with many reporting significant revenue increases. Entrepreneurs like Christine Febriyanti and DIY home streamers Panji Made Agung and Astari Gita are leveraging the platform's e-commerce features to promote tech, fashion, and homemade products. Experts say the trend is driven by shifting shopping habits among younger customers seeking engaging experiences, with Indonesia's digital market predicted to grow into a $35 billion market next year.

images.alt_text: Shopee accounted more almost half of South-east Asia's GMV for 2022, taking top spot among e-commerce players.

site_title: A 99% stock crash and shock default raise alarm in Thailand
summary: Thailand's Stark, a US$2 billion electrical cable maker, has suffered a 99% stock crash and default on liabilities, raising alarm over hidden financial risks in the country. The company's accounting scandal, which included 202 "unusual sale transactions," has led to a cross default on bonds and loans. Investors have pulled back from Thai stocks, and the country's benchmark equity index has fallen around 10% this year. Regulators are trying to shore up confidence in the market, and the Finance Minister has urged law enforcement agencies to bring charges against individuals who broke laws.

site_title: Sri Lanka set to start tea-for-oil barter with Iran next month
summary: Sri Lanka is set to start a tea-for-oil barter with Iran next month, exchanging US$2 million worth of tea per month for 48 months in lieu of US$250 million owed for oil. The agreement aims to boost tea sales to Iran and protect Sri Lanka's foreign exchange reserves, following a significant decline in tea exports to the country due to US sanctions. This move comes as Sri Lanka's foreign exchange reserves grew to US$3.5 billion at the end of May, a 14-month high.

images.alt_text: Food price rises eased to 15.8 per cent in May from 27.1 per cent in April.

site_title: Issue 54: Singapore vs the Kempen blacklist; ESG progress through the back room
summary: Singapore has been blacklisted by Dutch fund manager Van Lanschot Kempen due to its perceived lack of progress on reducing greenhouse gas emissions and biodiversity. The country has committed to achieving net zero emissions by 2050, but Kempen claims Singapore's progress is on a "wrong trajectory" compared to other developed economies. Singapore has responded that its limitations in developing renewable energy capacity and reported progress on solar power and biodiversity should not be unfairly criticized. The disagreement reflects deep-seated divisions between the East and West on climate matters, with regional fund managers instead driving sustainability progress through behind-the-scenes engagements.

images.alt_text: Singapore is “on track” to quadruple solar panel deployment from 2021, the government said in its statement.
Singapore's goal as a regional hub for green finance has raised the prominence of sustainable loans, particularly sustainability-linked loans.
Skyline of the Central Business District (CBD) and Marina Bay Financial Centre.
Coal plant owners can get lower lending rates for their investment into renewable energy through blended finance, in exchange for the early closure of their coal assets, said the panellists.

Debt-for-nature swaps, which help countries cut their debt in return for conservation commitments, are attracting growing interest after Ecuador’s record US$1.6 billion deal last month to protect the Galapagos Islands.
