The Singapore Institute of International Affairs assigns a rating of “red” in its Haze Outlook 2023 released on Wednesday (Jun 21).

site_title: Game changer: Final Fantasy’s decades of reinvention
summary: Final Fantasy, a 35-year-old Japanese gaming franchise, has sold over 173 million copies worldwide, making it one of the top-selling game franchises. The series has evolved from 2D monster battles to real-time combat gameplay, incorporating fantasy and sci-fi elements. The latest title, Final Fantasy XVI, was released on June 22, featuring immersive graphics and a "grown-up" storyline influenced by Game of Thrones, with mature themes such as sex scenes, drug use, and graphic violence.

images.alt_text: Olympic Esports Week will mark several firsts – not just for Singapore, but also for the esports world. The event bears similarities with the Olympic Games, but players will compete virtually.

site_title: Brexit an ‘economic disaster’ for UK and German trade: DIHK
summary: Brexit has been deemed an "economic disaster" for UK-German trade and investment ties, according to German economists. Germany's direct investment in the UK declined 16.1% since 2016, while exports to the UK dropped 14.1% in 2022, and the UK's importance as a trading partner has also decreased. The UK has lost its third most important export market to Germany, and the country now ranks eighth. German companies have also reduced their presence in the UK, with 2,163 German companies active there in 2023, a 5.2% decrease from 2016.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Union Jack flag flies at Brandenburg Gate, in Berlin, Germany, March 29, 2023. REUTERS/Annegret Hilse/File Photo
Used car prices along with airline tickets and the cost of recreation and culture drove the increase, suggesting that price pressures have moved beyond food and energy into the rest of the economy.
FILE PHOTO: Shoppers walk past a branch of Marks and Spencer in Altrincham, Britain January 7 2020. REUTERS/Phil Noble/File Photo

site_title: Indonesia trials first high-speed rail in boost to Jokowi legacy
summary: Indonesia is launching trial runs for its first high-speed train, connecting Jakarta to Bandung, after years of delays and cost overruns. The US$1.18 billion project, part of China's Belt and Road Initiative, was initially scheduled for 2019 completion. President Joko Widodo's legacy is at stake as the railway aims to cement his push for major infrastructure projects. The 142-kilometre railway will take 36 minutes to travel at 350 km/h, with 601 passengers capacity and four stations. A soft launch is set for August.

site_title: Swiss apartment prices 15-40% above levels seen in fundamentals
summary: Swiss apartment prices have surged 15-40% above pre-pandemic levels, with the Swiss National Bank (SNB) warning of potential correction. The SNB attributed the price increase to fundamental factors, including a tight supply of built-up residential areas and slow high-density construction. Despite the SNB's tightening cycle last year having minimal impact on real estate markets, interest rate hikes on mortgages have raised concerns about a potential decline in residential prices. The SNB cautions that prices may decline in both owner-occupied and investment property segments.

site_title: PropertyBT: Is it worth paying a premium for a new private home? (Ep 20)
summary: High interest rates may make buying a new, uncompleted private home more attractive than a resale unit. This is due to the ample supply of new homes and potential value in the market. However, financing home purchases with CPF funds and timing the market can be complex considerations. Experts suggest weighing the pros and cons of new versus resale units, and considering factors such as financing options and market uncertainty before making a decision.

images.alt_text: Should one buy a new or resale home amid high interest rates?
Which segments of Singapore's housing market are foreigners active in?
With high interest rates, developers may benefit from buyers choosing new homes sold off-plan because of the progressive payment scheme.
In line with government efforts to optimise land use, the land where the Singapore Turf Club in Kranji sits will be redeveloped for housing and other developments.
Generic private properties around Orchard area.
New private home sales rose 17 per cent month-on-month, according to data released by the Urban Redevelopment Authority on Thursday (Jun 15).
ULI notes that the median price of Singapore’s private-sector homes now stands at US$1.20 million, compared with Hong Kong at US$1.16 million.

site_title: Intelsat, SES end talks on forming US$10 billion satellite giant
summary: Intelsat and SES, two major satellite operators, have ended talks on a potential $10 billion merger, which would have created a satellite giant to compete in a crowded market. The deal would have valued the combined business at over $10 billion, including debt. The two companies control about 40% of the fixed satellite services market, but were unable to reach an agreement on the future direction of the business. The talks have ceased, with Intelsat citing a lack of agreement with major stakeholders.

images.alt_text: satellite, spacecraft, space

site_title: As West battles China, a trade ally tries to keep both doors open
summary: Morocco is building a new massive port near Nador, aiming to replicate the success of its existing port in Tanger. The move seeks to maintain its position as a key emerging economy, balancing relations with both the West and China, amidst the new Cold War. Western corporations, such as Renault, are already present in the region, and Morocco aims to keep its doors open to both sides, despite the polarizing world. This strategy aims to foster economic growth and diversification.

images.alt_text: The signing came as a Chinese delegation led by Premier Li Qiang was in Berlin for intergovernmental talks with Germany, their first face-to-face summit since the Covid-19 pandemic.
Wednesday's announcement marks the fourth extension of China's NEV tax-break policy, which was introduced in 2014.

site_title: NYC backs price hikes for 1 million rent-stabilised apartments
summary: New York City's Rent Guidelines Board approved rent increases of 3% for 1 million rent-stabilized apartments, with 2.75% and 3.2% increases for two-year leases. The decision follows lobbying from landlords and a push from tenants and advocacy groups. Mayor Eric Adams acknowledged the need for balance but expressed support for the board's decision. Critics argue the increases will strain renters, while proponents say they are necessary to cover rising expenses and maintain affordable housing.

images.alt_text: Many homeowners are opting to stay put as moving means giving up a cheaper mortgage.
“My colleagues and I understand the hardship that high inflation is causing, and we remain strongly committed to bringing inflation back down to our 2 per cent goal,” Fed chair Jerome Powell says.

site_title: Japan upgrades employment situation in June, first time in 11 months
summary: Japan's employment situation improved in June for the first time in 11 months, according to the government's latest assessment. The jobless rate declined, and major companies pledged the biggest wage hikes in about three decades, expected to boost purchasing power and economic growth. The government maintained a "recovering moderately" assessment of the economy, citing solid consumer spending and capital expenditure. However, it remained cautious about global economic risks and price increases.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on December 29, 2022 Japanese flags adorn a popular street in the shopping district of Ginza in Tokyo, as people flock to shops for year-end sales ahead of the New Year's Day holiday. - Nearly 1.5 million working-age people in Japan are social recluses, according to a new government survey, with a fifth citing the Covid-19 pandemic as the main reason for their withdrawal. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)
About a quarter of Japanese firms have offered inflation allowances or plan to do so, said corporate credit research firm Teikoku Databank.

site_title: US rolls out red carpet for Modi even as criticism grows
summary: US President Joe Biden has rolled out the red carpet for Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, hosting him for a state visit despite growing criticism of Modi's human rights record. The visit, Modi's first to Washington, includes a private dinner with Biden, a joint session of Congress, and a state dinner. The two countries are expected to make significant announcements, including a deal on General Electric engines for India's first home-grown fighter jets and a climate agreement. Despite tensions over Ukraine and human rights, the US sees India as a strategic partner in a growing global competition with China.

images.alt_text: Each year, the US government makes 65,000 H-1B visas available to companies seeking skilled foreign workers, along with an additional 20,000 visas for workers with advanced degrees.

US President Joe Biden is under pressure by his fellow Democrats to raise human rights with Modi amid concerns about democratic backsliding in India under Modi’s Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party.

site_title: Netflix outlines US$2.5 billion South Korean bet as K-drama mania grows
summary: Netflix is investing US$2.5 billion in South Korea over the next four years to support the country's growing K-drama industry, with a focus on training and cultivating local showrunners and studios. The move aims to capitalize on the surge in global subscriptions driven by Korean dramas, with about three-fifths of Netflix users having watched a Korean show. The investment will include training programs for the next generation of auteurs and entertainers, both in front of and behind the camera, to generate economic ripple effects and differentiate Netflix from rivals.

images.alt_text: Ryan Murphy would likewise continue to make shows for Netflix after a move to Disney.
"Squid Game" creator Hwang Dong-hyuk said in various interviews in 2021 the series was rejected multiple times before being picked up by Netflix.
The restaurant is part of Netflix’s latest move into live experiences.

site_title: Beyond Meat wannabes are failing as hype and money fade
summary: The plant-based food industry is experiencing a significant shakeout as investors pull back funding due to surging interest rates, inflation, and increased consumer selectivity. Companies such as Unreal Food, Remastered Foods, and The Meatless Farm have halted product development or shut down operations. Industry observers predict more turmoil before the sector stabilizes, but some investors remain optimistic, citing growing demand for alternative proteins and the potential for companies to adapt and thrive. Despite the challenges, some companies are seeing opportunities, with sales expected to grow annually by high single-digits and reach $100 billion by 2030.

images.alt_text: While succeeding in the general lab-meat market has proven complicated and expensive, some companies have set their sights on pet food, whose consumers are less picky.

site_title: Tech companies including Google gripe about unfair cloud practices
summary: Tech companies, including Google, have complained to the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) about unfair business practices in the cloud industry, specifically by Microsoft and Oracle. The companies claim that licensing terms enforced by these providers distort competition and prevent customers from switching providers for lower costs or stronger services. Google and Amazon have made similar criticism, citing restrictions and surcharges for businesses that migrate licenses to cloud competitors. Microsoft has updated some terms in response but rivals have called its changes insufficient, and the FTC declined to comment.

images.alt_text: The social media company largely uses Google Cloud for data analysis and machine learning.
Google spokesperson Jose Castaneda says that the company is disappointed with the verdict and plans to appeal.

site_title: Asia stocks subdued after Powell testimony fails to surprise
summary: Asian stocks remained subdued on Thursday, June 22, after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's testimony failed to surprise investors. The MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index fell marginally, with Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index losing 1.17% and Japan's Nikkei easing 0.25%. Markets are pricing in a 25 basis point hike next month, with no further increases expected. The Fed's data-dependent approach suggests upcoming data releases could shift expectations, highlighting the growing debate over when and if the central bank should hike further.

images.alt_text: Stocks in Hong Kong dropped more than one per cent, with tech firms – which are susceptible to higher borrowing costs – taking the brunt of the selling, while Shanghai was also in negative territory.

site_title: SoftBank’s Vision Fund to start job cuts as soon as this week
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund is set to start another round of layoffs, affecting around 13% of its staff, with the majority of cuts expected to occur in the US. The job cuts follow five straight quarters of losses at the fund, which has seen global startup valuations decline due to economic malaise and rising interest rates. The fund's losses for the fiscal year ended in March reached a record 4.3 trillion yen (S$40.7 billion). Despite the losses, SoftBank's CEO Masayoshi Son plans to shift the company's focus to investing in artificial intelligence, which he believes will help the company recover.

images.alt_text: SoftBank reported a net loss of 970 billion yen for the year ended Mar 31, cushioning losses at the Vision Fund unit by selling down its stake in Alibaba.
SoftBank invested in seven startups through funding rounds totalling about US$550 million so far in the June quarter.

site_title: A thriving private credit market is in Asia’s best interests
summary: A thriving private credit market in Asia is seen as beneficial for the region's economic development. Despite initial concerns, private credit providers and banks can work together to support sustainable growth, filling gaps in the market and financing underserved sectors such as small and medium-sized enterprises. With Asia needing at least $2.8 trillion in infrastructure investments, private credit funds can help close the gap and complement bank lending. Industry cooperation and best practices are increasingly adopted, with the Asia Pacific Loan Market Association facilitating interactions between banks and funds to encourage collaboration and drive growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the Blackstone Group headquarters in New York City, U.S., January 18, 2023. REUTERS/Jeenah Moon/File Photo

Blackstone own figures show it’s attracted 240 million euros (S$347 million) to its new private credit fund, dubbed ECRED, a fraction of the US$12 billion raised for BCRED, an equivalent US fund, at the half-year point of its fundraising about two years ago.

site_title: Gold prices steady as markets assess Powell’s rate remarks
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,932.93 per ounce after hitting a three-month low due to remarks from US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell indicating further interest rate hikes. Swiss gold exports rose in May, rebounding from a 10-month low in April, amid higher shipments to India. Benchmark US 10-year Treasury yields declined to 3.723%, while the dollar index held near Wednesday's lows.

images.alt_text: Gold is considered a hedge against inflation, but interest-rate hikes raise the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Ripple gets in-principle go-ahead to offer crypto digital-payment services in Singapore
summary: Ripple has received in-principle approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore to offer crypto digital-payment services in the country. This move will allow Ripple to provide regulated digital-payment token products and services, enabling it to better support its customers. The approval is seen as a significant step for Ripple, which has doubled its Singapore headcount in the past year, positioning Singapore as its Asia-Pacific headquarters. The decision reflects Singapore's leadership in developing a clear regulatory framework for cryptocurrencies.

site_title: Hot stock: Nanofilm falls to near one-month low amid tech stocks rout
summary: Nanofilm Technologies, a specialist in advanced materials and coatings, closed at a near one-month low of S$1.46 on June 22 amid a tech stocks rout. The company's shares dropped 7.7% to reach this level, surpassing its previous day's trading volume. This follows a 40% fall in Q1 revenue to S$33 million, attributed to cyclical reasons and a slow China reopening. Other tech-related counters, such as Aztech Global and Micro-Mechanics, also fell, with Aztech Global closing near its one-month low at S$0.685.

images.alt_text: Ian Howe was the former chief executive officer of Dutch machining manufacturer Additive Industries, where he served between 2021 and 2022.
Tech manufacturing counters take a beating in Q1 on weak end-consumer demand
The first quarter is typically cyclical in line with production cycles, while revenue was also hit by China’s slow and soft recovery since its re-opening, Nanofilm said.

site_title: Dubai’s latest property spree has rich buyers taking more risk
summary: Dubai is experiencing its strongest construction cycle since 2017, with rich buyers taking on more risk as developers launch massive projects. The emirate has a history of sharp booms and busts, having faced a devastating debt-fueled real estate crash in 2008. Recent developments include a 71-story skyscraper and a 1,700-home housing complex, with prices starting at 21 million dirhams for a single penthouse. The market is expected to continue its upward trend, driven by capital from Arab nations seeking safety in Dubai.

images.alt_text: The approach pursued by the glitzy Dubai is a reboot of a flamboyant economic model that for decades focused on property investment, tourism and inflows of foreign capital.

site_title: BOJ policymaker calls for keeping low rates, focus on wages
summary: Bank of Japan policymaker Asahi Noguchi emphasized the need to maintain ultra-loose monetary policy until wages continue to rise, driving inflation towards its 2% target. Noguchi warned of potential risks to Japan's economy, particularly due to global economic uncertainty. His comments echo those of fellow board member Seiji Adachi, highlighting the BOJ's caution against prematurely dialing back its massive stimulus program. The BOJ will continue to monitor wage growth and inflation to determine the optimal policy, with the goal of sustaining inflation above the 2% target.

images.alt_text: Markets are simmering with speculation the BOJ will soon tweak its YCC policy, which has drawn criticism for distorting market pricing and crushing financial institutions’ profits.

site_title: Singapore proposes standards for ‘purpose-bound’ digital money
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), has proposed a common protocol for "purpose-bound" digital money, which would specify conditions for its use and transfer only upon fulfilling service or terms of use. This protocol aims to work with different ledger technologies and forms of digital money, enabling users to access digital money using their preferred wallet provider. The goal is to enable financial institutions to trial purpose-bound money in online commerce and programmable rewards, promoting secure and efficient digital transactions in the city-state.

site_title: US home listings plummet as high mortgage rates tie owners down
summary: US home listings plummeted to record low levels in May, with active listings falling 7.1% and 38.6% from pre-pandemic levels, according to Redfin. High mortgage rates, averaging 6.43%, are deterring people from moving, causing many homeowners to stay put. This scarcity has driven price increases, with nearly half of Redfin's offers met with bidding wars and over two-thirds of homes selling above list price. However, new building starts reached a 2016 high in May, potentially alleviating price pressures. Existing home sales are expected to decrease slightly in May.

site_title: US to ease visas for skilled Indian workers as Modi visits
summary: The US government plans to ease visa requirements for skilled Indian workers, allowing some to renew their H-1B visas in the US without traveling abroad. The move is part of a pilot program aimed at improving visa access for Indians, with the goal of scaling up the initiative over the next year. The pilot will initially focus on a small number of cases, with the aim of reducing the need for visa interviews in consulates abroad. The move is seen as an effort by the Biden administration to strengthen ties with India, particularly in the tech industry, and to address the country's concerns about visa access.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden is under pressure by his fellow Democrats to raise human rights with Modi amid concerns about democratic backsliding in India under Modi’s Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party.

site_title: New Zealand posts first lift in monthly house sales in two years
summary: New Zealand's house sales rose 7.5% in May, the first increase in two years, according to CoreLogic New Zealand. This follows a slowdown in house-price declines and a projection by the Reserve Bank that the Official Cash Rate is unlikely to rise further in this cycle. Chief property economist Kelvin Davidson believes sales volumes have finally bottomed out and may continue to increase modestly over the rest of 2023, with prices potentially finding a floor. Higher immigration and a scarcity of homes being sold provide confidence that the market is approaching its bottom.

site_title: Bankrupt SVB Financial still exploring options for venture capital arm
summary: Bankrupt SVB Financial Group is exploring options for its venture capital arm, SVB Capital, amid the US banking crisis. The company, which collapsed into bankruptcy after Silicon Valley Bank's failure in March, agreed to sell its investment banking division, SVB Securities, to a management team. SVB Financial is also evaluating strategic alternatives for SVB Capital and other assets. A hearing to approve the sale of SVB Securities is scheduled for June 29.

images.alt_text: SVB Securities management was in talks to buy back the investment bank from bankrupt SVB Financial Group, Bloomberg reported on Jun 1.

site_title: Google hit with US$15 million verdict in US trial over audio patents
summary: A US Delaware federal jury has ordered Google to pay US$15.1 million to patent holding company Personal Audio for infringing two audio software patents related to Google Play Music's playlist features. The jury also found Google infringed the patents wilfully, potentially leading to a triple damages award. Google spokesperson Jose Castaneda stated the company is disappointed and plans to appeal, as the verdict concerns a "discontinued product" and is unlikely to affect customers. Personal Audio had initially sought US$33.1 million in damages.

images.alt_text: The logo of Google is seen at the Viva Technology conference dedicated to innovation and startups at Porte de Versailles exhibition center in Paris, France, June 14, 2023. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes
Google says that there’s “enormous competition in the connected car space” and that thousands of applications are compatible with Android Automotive.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, OCBC, Best World, Penguin, Datapulse
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore imposed composition penalties totaling S$3.8 million on four financial institutions, including DBS and OCBC, for money-laundering rule breaches uncovered in a Wirecard probe. DBS received the largest penalty of S$2.6 million, while OCBC got S$600,000. Best World International reported a S$45.3 million net cash outflow for Q1 due to payment of management and staff incentives, sales-related expenses, and income tax. Penguin International's privatisation offer was extended to Jul 6. Datapulse Technology received a requisition notice to convene an extraordinary general meeting to pass eight resolutions, including removing five directors.

site_title: Billie Eilish, Lenny Kravitz, Jon Batiste headlining climate concert at Eiffel Tower
summary: Billie Eilish, Lenny Kravitz, and Jon Batiste are headlining a climate concert at the Eiffel Tower in Paris, organized by NGO Global Citizen. The event, part of an international summit, aims to raise awareness around climate change and features artists H.E.R. and Finneas. The concert is free and will take place at the Champ de Mars below the landmark. The event highlights the environmental advocacy efforts of Billie Eilish, who is known for her environmental activism.

images.alt_text: Harry Styles, Billie Eilish, Kanye West to headline Coachella

site_title: US approves lab-grown chicken for sale
summary: The US Department of Agriculture (USDA) has approved lab-grown chicken for sale, paving the way for the first-ever approvals of artificial meat in the country. Companies Upside Foods and Good Meat, cleared by the Food and Drug Administration in November, have been granted approval to sell their products at restaurants. The lab-grown chicken is grown directly from animal cells and is considered a sustainable alternative to traditional farming, with CEO Uma Valeti stating it's a "giant step forward towards a more sustainable future".

images.alt_text: Alternative proteins are those that do not involve the slaughter of animals; they may be plant-based, fermented using microbes, or cultivated from animal cells.
Neuralink is developing a brain implant it hopes will help paralysed people walk again and cure other neurological ailments.

site_title: Inflation would be same today even if Fed had hiked interest rates earlier, new model shows
summary: A new Bloomberg Economics model suggests that if the Federal Reserve had begun raising interest rates nine months earlier, US inflation wouldn't be lower today, peaking around 7.6% in the third quarter of 2022 instead of 8.6% in the second quarter. The model also indicates that an earlier liftoff would have made a difference in 2022, but not in later years. According to the analysis, the Fed would have had to put the economy through a sharp recession to head off the inflation problem altogether.

images.alt_text: “My colleagues and I understand the hardship that high inflation is causing, and we remain strongly committed to bringing inflation back down to our 2 per cent goal,” Fed chair Jerome Powell says.

site_title: Australia to decide fate of central bank chief in July
summary: Australia's central bank governor Philip Lowe will find out in July whether he will be reappointed for a second term or replaced, following a review that recommended sweeping changes in the bank's operation and policy-making process. Lowe has been under criticism for his handling of interest rates, which led to a 400 basis point hike, causing financial pain for mortgage holders. Deputy governor Michele Bullock, Treasury official Jenny Wilkinson, and former Bank of Canada official Carolyn Wilkins are possible replacements. Treasurer Jim Chalmers has been non-committal on Lowe's reappointment, stating that the governor needs to be well-placed to implement the review's recommendations.

images.alt_text: The RBA is seen by economists lifting rates two more times this year to 4.6 per cent.
Low productivity and rising wages was a particular worry, with the board noting that a recent national award for low-paid workers had been higher than expected.

site_title: Bitcoin eyes third straight day of gains after touching two-month high
summary: Bitcoin rose for a third consecutive day, reaching a two-month high of $30,755.00, driven by BlackRock's plan to create a bitcoin exchange-traded fund (ETF) and EDX Markets' operations. The global cryptocurrency industry faces US regulatory scrutiny, with the SEC suing major crypto exchanges. Despite this, Bitcoin is up 81% for the year-to-date, with analysts predicting a potential sustained rally, but cautioning that regulatory clarity is needed to reach a mid-$30,000 target.

images.alt_text: BlackRock filed for a spot Bitcoin ETF with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Jun 15.

site_title: Nvidia more popular than Tesla as another 100 ESG funds pile in
summary: Nvidia has become one of the most popular stocks among ESG funds, with over 1,400 funds directly holding the company and another 500 indirectly exposed. This surge in popularity has transformed Nvidia into an "ESG darling" with high levels of ESG disclosures and a business aligned with the 1.5C global warming threshold. The company's shares have hit a record high, with gains this year reaching about 200%. This trend is driven by tech-heavy ESG funds invested in AI, which have returned over 40% this year, outperforming traditional green powerhouses like Vestas Wind Systems and Tesla.

images.alt_text: Tesla chief executive officer Elon Musk has been willing to take lower profits as he reduces prices to keep market share.
Upbeat sales targets by Nvidia has bouyed its stock. About 1,300 ESG-registered funds hold more than US$20 billion in Nvidia, according to Bloomberg.

site_title: Asia-based funds gain traction as raised global capital increases: report
summary: Asia-based ESG private-capital funds raised US$11.7 billion, or 12.7% of the global total, in 2022, reaching a 10-year high. This represents a 22% increase from the previous year. Europe-based funds dominated the global market, raising US$62.1 billion, while Asia-Pacific funds saw a significant increase in infrastructure investments. Despite lower transparency among Asia-based funds, ESG assets under management are expected to grow to US$3.3 trillion in Asia in the next four years, surpassing growth in Europe and North America.

images.alt_text: Kempen said its updated ESG test only applied to mandates used by some clients.

site_title: Chipmaker Intel restructures manufacturing business
summary: Intel restructures its manufacturing business, with internal units now having a customer-supplier relationship. The manufacturing business will start generating a margin but no clear timeline for scaling up is given. Intel expects to be the second largest foundry by 2024 with over $20 billion in manufacturing revenue. However, this forecast is lower than Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing's expected $85 billion in sales for the same year. The restructuring aims to increase efficiency and competitiveness in the industry.

site_title: Tesla seen staying as top EV seller in US through 2026, buoyed by discounts
summary: Tesla is expected to remain the top electric vehicle (EV) seller in the US through 2026, with 18% market share, according to a BofA Securities report. The company's price cuts have sparked renewed sales momentum, allowing it to maintain its market-leading position. Tesla's CEO Elon Musk has taken lower profits to keep market share, and the company is predicted to launch a new, low-priced vehicle in 2026 and a revamped Model 3 in 2027. General Motors and Ford Motor will compete for second place with around 14% market share each.

site_title: Twitter resumes paying Google Cloud, patches up relationship
summary: Twitter has resumed paying Google Cloud for its data analysis and machine learning services after a strained relationship following Elon Musk's acquisition. New CEO Linda Yaccarino helped negotiate a broader partnership, including advertising and API use, with Google Cloud CEO Thomas Kurian. Twitter paid Google Cloud around $200-300 million annually, but Musk reduced spending on cloud computing. The companies are now working to revive their 2018 partnership, which Google hopes will aid its artificial intelligence efforts to close the gap with larger cloud rivals.

images.alt_text: Licencing music was a bigger priority for YouTube, which offers full-length songs, as well as Facebook and TikTok, which host a lot of videos set to music.

site_title: Keep calm and invest early in quantum-safe networks
summary: A growing threat from quantum computers, which can potentially break public-key cryptography, requires early investment in quantum-safe networks. Quantum computers, like those developed by IBM and Google, could pose significant threats to data security. To counter this, Singapore has launched the National Quantum-Safe Network Plus program to support network operators in deploying quantum-safe networks nationwide. This effort aims to integrate with international quantum-safe networks to ensure global connectivity and protect sensitive data from potential quantum computer threats.

images.alt_text: Fibre optic cables will be used to transmit encryption keys encoded with light photons in quantum safe networks.
Spacetech startup SpeQtral secures US$8.3m in funding round led by Temasek unit
Quantum computers and related technologies – such as quantum sensing and cryptography – could revolutionise everyday life.

site_title: JPMorgan commercial bank enters Singapore, Israel in global push
summary: JPMorgan Chase's commercial bank is expanding into Singapore and Israel, aiming to reach 28 countries by year-end. The move is part of the bank's global push to serve midsize and small companies, with a goal of quadrupling commercial clients. JPMorgan currently serves over 650 clients and has 2,500 prospects across 26 countries. The bank's international operations cater to American companies abroad and foreign companies in the US, with revenue from these operations reaching $847 million in 2022.

images.alt_text: The moves add to a February round of cuts that affected about 30 investment bankers in Asia.

The lawsuit filed by the victims charged that JPMorgan ignored repeated warnings that Epstein had been trafficking teenage girls and young women for sex, even after he registered as a sex offender and pleaded guilty in a 2008 Florida case to soliciting prostitution from a teenage girl.

site_title: Nobel-winning economist calls for climate tax as carbon costs lives
summary: Nobel Prize-winning economist Esther Duflo has called for a global climate tax to address the devastating impact of climate change on poor nations. She warns that climate change will cause a 73% increase in mortality among poor countries by the end of the century, equivalent to all deaths from infectious diseases today. Duflo advocates for a binding international tax mechanism, with part of the revenue going to support those affected by environmental hazards.

images.alt_text: Debt-for-nature swaps, which help countries cut their debt in return for conservation commitments, are attracting growing interest after Ecuador’s record US$1.6 billion deal last month to protect the Galapagos Islands.

US Special Presidential Envoy for Climate John Kerry speaks during an event on the sidelines of  the COP27 climate conference at the Sharm el-Sheikh International Convention Centre, in Egypt's Red Sea resort city of the same name, on November 8, 2022. (Photo by Joseph EID / AFP)
“Some are trying to draw climate policy into the culture wars, because then you create a tribal opposition,” EU climate chief Frans Timmermans says.

site_title: Oil rallies as grain markets tighten, dollar falls on US Fed chair comments
summary: Oil prices rose by a dollar a barrel on Wednesday as US corn and soybean prices reached multi-month highs, raising expectations of lower biofuels blending and increased oil demand. Brent futures gained 1.6% to $77.12, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 1.9% to $72.53. The US dollar fell against global currencies after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell suggested the central bank is nearing its policy destination, making dollar-denominated oil more attractive.

images.alt_text: The crude price decline was led by near 3 per cent losses in US petrol and diesel futures.

site_title: US: Stocks fall for third straight day
summary: US stocks fell for a third consecutive day as markets digested the Federal Reserve's hawkish commentary. US Fed chair Jerome Powell told a congressional panel that he expects additional interest rate hikes this year, citing high inflation. This stance has led to near-term profit taking, with investors weighing the market outlook and potential US-EU tariffs.

site_title: OCBC shows it’s still a buyer of Great Eastern
summary: OCBC Bank has acquired nearly 2.35 million Great Eastern shares on a "willing buyer, willing seller" basis, increasing its stake in the insurer to 88.4% and bringing its direct and deemed interest to over 418.4 million shares. This move comes nearly two decades after OCBC's previous attempts to take Great Eastern private were rebuffed by minority investors. Despite a recent surge in Great Eastern's share price, the stock currently trades at a 54% discount to its embedded value, making a full privatization deal unlikely in the near future.

images.alt_text: OCBC chairman Andrew Lee said the bank has no plans to reduce its "perceived excess capital" at the moment, given concurrent geopolitical tensions and macroeconomic stresses.
The decline in Great Eastern's total weighted new sales was due to lower single premium sales from the Singapore market, the group said.
OCBC affirmed Great Eastern’s as a capability within the banking group.

site_title: Uber to lay off 200 employees in recruitment division
summary: Uber is cutting 200 jobs in its recruitment division as part of efforts to streamline costs and maintain a flat workforce. The layoffs account for 35% of the recruitment team and affect less than 1% of Uber's 32,700-strong global workforce. This move follows earlier layoffs in Uber's freight services division and comes as the company aims to post operating income profitability this year. Uber's decision is seen as a cost-cutting measure compared to rival Lyft, which laid off 26% of its workforce in April.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The interior of the office of ride-hailing service Uber is seen in this picture in Gurugram, previously known as Gurgaon, on the outskirts of New Delhi, India, April 19, 2016.  REUTERS/Anindito Mukherjee/File Photo

site_title: Europe: Real estate, tech drag Stoxx 600 down on rate hike jitters
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index fell 0.5% on Wednesday, extending declines for the third consecutive session, as tech stocks dropped 1.6% following hawkish signals from the Federal Reserve. The prospect of more interest rate rises stoked concerns about mortgage costs, with real estate stocks also falling. Eurozone inflation remains stubborn, and the European Central Bank may need to continue raising interest rates to contain it.

images.alt_text: Germany’s DAX index closed 0.6 per cent lower, retreating further from a record high hit on Friday. The continent-wide Stoxx 600 index also fell 0.6 per cent.

site_title: India’s PM Modi to join Biden in rare press conference, questions limited
summary: US President Joe Biden will hold a rare press conference with visiting Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, marking the first time Modi has addressed a single press conference in India since becoming prime minister in 2014. The event is seen as a "big deal" by the White House, with a senior official stating it's a significant moment for Modi to take questions from the media. The press conference will feature one question from the US press and one from an Indian journalist, with human rights potentially being a topic of discussion amid concerns about democratic backsliding in India under Modi's Hindu nationalist government.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden addresses the nation on averting default and the Bipartisan Budget Agreement, in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, June 2, 2023.   JIM WATSON/Pool via REUTERS     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY
Easing inflation, a brightening growth outlook and a stable rupee are all helping to burnish the appeal of Indian bonds.

site_title: Best World explains net cash outflow of S$45.3 million for Q1
summary: Best World International reported a net cash outflow of S$45.3 million for the first quarter of 2023, despite a net profit of S$20.5 million. The outflow was primarily due to payment of management and staff incentives, sales-related expenses, and income tax for FY2022. The company's top line decreased by 30.8% year-over-year, mainly due to lower contributions from its franchise segment. Best World shares closed down 1.1% to S$1.79 on the day of the announcement.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as Powell doubles down on inflation fight
summary: US stock markets opened lower on Wednesday, June 21, as Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell reaffirmed the need to combat inflation, sparking concerns of further monetary tightening. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 63.31 points, or 0.19%, to 33,990.56. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped, with the Nasdaq falling 0.34%. The moves came despite no new economic data releases, fueling worries about the impact of Powell's stance on the market outlook.

site_title: Apple illegally interrogated staff about union, judge rules
summary: A US labour board judge ruled that Apple illegally interrogated retail employees about their pro-union sympathies and restricted the circulation of union flyers, violating employees' rights. The judge ordered Apple to "cease and desist" from coercive actions and to stop interfering with employees' rights. This decision marks the first time an NLRB judge has ruled against Apple, following a campaign by workers at several stores, including the World Trade Center store in New York City, to unionize.

site_title: Global Palm Resources allowed to delist
summary: Global Palm Resources, a palm oil producer, has been allowed to delist after the offeror, ATH Holdings, acquired over 90% of its shares. The company will be taken private at a takeover price of S$0.25 per share. The delisting date will be announced upon completion of the compulsory acquisition of remaining shares. The shares had dropped below 10% in public hands, prompting the regulatory filing.

site_title: Record plane orders raise the stakes in India's aviation boom
summary: India's top two carriers, IndiGo and Air India, have placed a record order of almost 1,000 jet orders, betting on the country's economic boom and growing middle class to drive demand for domestic and international air travel. IndiGo ordered 500 Airbus narrowbody jets, while Air India firmed up an order for 470 Airbus and Boeing aircraft. The significant plane orders suggest India's potential as an aviation superpower, but recent airline failures and regulatory rows may complicate progress.

images.alt_text: An Airbus A321 XLR in flight during the International Paris Air Show at the Paris–Le Bourget Airport, Paris, France, June 19, 2023.

site_title: China's state planner signs letter of intent to cooperate with European corporate giants
summary: China's state planner signed letters of intent with European corporate giants in areas like aviation, chemicals, and automobiles, aiming to strengthen ties with Europe. Premier Li Qiang led a Chinese delegation in Berlin for intergovernmental talks with Germany, marking their first face-to-face summit since the Covid-19 pandemic. The agreements focus on sustainable aviation fuel, low-carbon production, and new-energy vehicles. The move comes amid rising tensions between the West and China, as the European Union seeks to reduce its dependence on the Asian powerhouse.

images.alt_text: Li was given a full military honours welcome by Scholz on Tuesday.

site_title: Microsoft says new computing service for chemicals can slash R&D time
summary: Microsoft has introduced Azure Quantum Elements, a new computing service aimed at accelerating chemical research and development. The service uses a combination of quantum computers, artificial intelligence, and high-performance computing to simulate possible combinations of atoms, helping companies speed up the development process. Early customers have reported a six-month reduction in development time, with Microsoft aiming to compress 250 years of chemistry progress into 25 years. The company also announced a tailored version of its Copilot AI system for scientists and a milestone in developing its own quantum computer.

images.alt_text: The updates to Bing are part of Microsoft’s effort to capture more of the estimated US$286 billion market for search advertising globally.

site_title: Companies hand out cash, beef up perks to help staff cushion against inflation
summary: Singapore companies are providing cash allowances, one-off payouts, or improved staff benefits to help employees cope with inflation. Real estate group Far East Organization is giving a monthly special cash allowance to eligible staff, with larger allowances for those with lower base salaries. The scheme has been extended to cover essential spending due to rising costs. Other companies are also providing increments that take inflation into account, aiming to cushion staff against the economic impact.

images.alt_text: Categorising jobs as needing either academic qualifications or technical skills is wasteful, said President Halimah Yacob.
MAS policy change still not expected as Singapore headline inflation ticks up in April, core remains flat

site_title: Pharrell unveils his vision for Louis Vuitton on Paris’ oldest bridge
summary: Pharrell Williams unveiled his vision for Louis Vuitton with a star-studded show on Paris' Pont Neuf bridge, featuring monogram-adorned Speedy bags, Bermuda shorts, and pixelated camouflage. The debut show, attended by 1,800 guests, was a musical spectacle with a performance by Jay-Z and a gospel choir. Louis Vuitton CEO Bernard Arnault was thrilled with the event, which has a "greater halo effect" for the brand, according to HSBC. Williams, a fashion entrepreneur, was named menswear designer of LVMH's biggest label in February, following the departure of Virgil Abloh.

site_title: Grab’s mega layoffs send chill over company, but analysts upbeat on direction
summary: Grab's massive layoffs, affecting 1,000 staff, have sent a chill over the company, but analysts remain upbeat on its direction. The company's CEO, Anthony Tan, cited "fundamental step-changes" in operations to build a competitive moat for the long-term. Despite the layoffs, Grab's share price rose initially, and analysts see the cost cuts as a positive move. The tech community has rallied around laid-off employees, with some former Grab employees now working at startups and recruiters offering job openings. Grab aims to hit its target of adjusted Ebitda break-even this year, and analysts believe the company can recover from the layoffs.

images.alt_text: Grab is cutting more than 1,000 staff to streamline costs.
Food delivery company Grab's co-founder and chief operating officer Tan Hooi Ling speaking during an interview in Singapore.
CGS-CIMB believes Grab will be able to “accelerate its path to profitability” amid an easing competitive landscape.

site_title: Lentor Hills Residences to start preview at prices from S$945,000
summary: Lentor Hills Residences, a 99-year leasehold project, will start previews on June 24 with sales bookings set to begin on July 8. The development features 598 residential units across five towers on a 184,461 square feet site, with prices starting from S$945,000 for one-bedroom units and up to S$2.64 million for dual-key apartments. The project is part of the new Lentor Hills estate, which will eventually house five condominiums totaling 3,500 units, with prices ranging from S$1,834 to S$2,538 per square foot.

images.alt_text: Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) data released on Monday (Apr 17) show that in March, developers sold 492 units, excluding ECs, up 13.6 per cent from the 433 units sold in February.
The site at Lentor Central is launched under the confirmed list while Lentor Gardens site was launched under the reserve list for H1 GLS 2023.
DBS was optimistic about GuocoLand’s strategy and its appeal to buyers, citing the example of Lentor Modern.

site_title: SPH Media files police report following investigation into overstated circulation figures
summary: SPH Media Group filed a police report after an internal investigation found that circulation numbers for some publications were overstated by 85,000 to 95,000 daily average copies. The investigation, led by a committee chaired by Max Loh, found "inappropriate behaviour" and recommended the media group evaluate its risk culture and internal controls. The police report was not made against specific persons or entities, but rather to report the findings to the authorities. The investigation also found that bulk copies paid for from the Newspapers in Education fund were not distributed and inflated the circulation numbers.

images.alt_text: SPH Media will explore the use of artificial intelligence technology in the newsroom with Nikkei's support.
The bond-free scholarship, funded by the SPH Foundation, was set up in 2006 under the suggestion of the late Lim Kim San.
SPH Media Holdings Board has also directed its audit and risk committee to further investigate the overstatement of circulation data and consider its next steps.
SPH Media chief executive Teo Lay Lim said data on reach and readership is collected periodically via a survey panel that is statistically representative of the Singapore population.
The inconsistencies led to a 10 to 12 per cent discrepancy in circulation figures.

site_title: How alternative fuels can shape a net-zero future in Asia
summary: Asia is shifting towards alternative fuels to achieve a net-zero future, with growing demand for biofuels and renewable fuels varying across markets. Governments, energy players, and corporations are committing to decarbonization efforts, including the US' Inflation Reduction Act, EU's stricter regulation, and Singapore's National Hydrogen Strategy. Asia's high-performing economies are using electrification and biofuels, while countries like India and Vietnam need to accelerate their efforts. Partnerships, innovative technologies, and strong regulation are crucial to bridging the gap between aspiration and reality, with the aim of securing affordable finance and driving widespread decarbonization by 2050.

images.alt_text: The project, if it succeeds, would aim to produce bioethanol from Nippon Paper’s mills in the fiscal year of 2027 to be used as a feedstock for the sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) production Japan plans to gradually increase for its aviation industry.
The sustainable aviation fuel targets are the EU’s attempt to cut flight emissions pending breakthrough technologies such as zero-emission aircraft, which are not expected for at least a decade.
Shell invests in sustainable aviation-fuel maker LanzaJet
The refinery is now able to produce up to a million tonnes of sustainable aviation fuel each year.

site_title: Fed’s Powell says higher interest rates needed to curb inflation
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated that interest rates may need to increase further to curb inflation, despite holding rates steady last week. Powell said policymakers expect rates to rise to 5.6% by the end of the year, indicating two additional quarter-point hikes. He emphasized that reducing inflation may require below-trend growth and softer labor market conditions. Powell also expressed concerns about tighter credit conditions, which could weigh on economic activity and hiring.

images.alt_text: epa10691114 Federal Reserve Board Chairman Jerome Powell holds a news conference after the Fed refrained from raising interest rates following its two-day conference at the Federal Reserve in Washington, DC, USA, 14 June 2023. The Fed is pausing its interest rate hikes after raising them 10 times in a row to curb inflation.  EPA-EFE/JIM LO SCALZO
Fed officials like to look at an even narrower category of core inflation, services excluding housing, to assess the trajectory of the stickiest price pressures.

site_title: Rescuers race to find Titanic sub after hearing undersea sounds
summary: Rescuers are racing to find a missing submersible, Titan, with five people on board, after Canadian aircraft detected undersea sounds in the North Atlantic. The US Coast Guard deployed remotely operated vehicles and aircraft, while ships and a French research vessel are searching the area. The submersible, designed to remain underwater for 96 hours, lost contact with its parent vessel during a two-hour dive to the Titanic wreck site. Experts say rescuers face major obstacles, including finding the submersible in the dark depths and saving the occupants.

images.alt_text: The missing submersible, the Titan, carries a pilot and four crew members to a maximum depth of 4,000 metres.

site_title: Astrea V PE bondholders to receive semi-annual interest payments of up to 5.75% per annum
summary: Astrea V private equity bondholders will receive semi-annual interest payments ranging from 3.85% to 5.75% per annum, with Class B bonds receiving the highest rate. The bond portfolio, valued at around $1 billion, has been fully reserved for Class A bonds a year ahead of schedule. The issuer, Azalea Investment Management, has received $98 million in distributions from PE funds and invested $10 million through capital calls.

images.alt_text:
During recent market downturns in early 2020, and through 2022, PE returns have held up better than public markets. 
Azalea noted that total returns from the S&P 500 fell some 24 per cent between Q4 2021 to Q3 2022, but, Preqin’s private equity index showed that PE was down just 3 per cent.

site_title: Sri Lanka consumer inflation slows to 22.1% in May
summary: Sri Lanka's National Consumer Price Index (NCPI) inflation eased to 22.1% in May, down from 33.6% in April. Food price inflation decreased to 15.8% from 27.1% in April, while non-food inflation remained at 27.6%. This slowdown in inflation is a positive sign for the country's economic recovery.

site_title: Amazon duped millions into enrolling in Prime, says Federal Trade Commission
summary: The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) filed a lawsuit against Amazon, charging the retailer with enrolling millions of consumers into its Amazon Prime service without their consent and making it difficult to cancel. The FTC alleges Amazon used "dark patterns" to trick consumers into signing up for automatically-renewing Prime subscriptions. This has resulted in consumers paying significant money and experiencing frustration. FTC Chair Lina Khan stated that Amazon "tricked and trapped people into recurring subscriptions without their consent."

site_title: Intel to sell 20% stake in Austrian chip company
summary: Intel plans to sell 20% of its stake in Austrian chip company IMS Nanofabrication to private equity firm Bain Capital for US$860 million, valuing the company at US$4.3 billion. IMS has delivered significant returns for Intel, growing its workforce and production capacity fourfold since its 2015 acquisition. Bain Capital's investment will enable the company to capture market share for its tools, which are widely adopted by chipmakers. The deal is seen as a strategic move to strengthen Bain Capital's position in the chipmaking equipment market.

site_title: Yellen to push for concrete actions at Paris debt summit
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen will push world leaders to take concrete actions at the Paris debt summit, focusing on easing debt burdens of low-income nations and improving debt restructuring processes. Yellen aims to partner with developing economies to address climate change, pandemics, and fragility. She will also prioritize bilateral meetings with emerging markets and push for additional steps to enhance debt restructuring through the global sovereign debt roundtable.

images.alt_text: Janet Yellen, US Treasury secretary, second right, speaks with Shunichi Suzuki, Japan's finance minister, not pictured, during a bilateral meeting on the sidelines of the Group of Seven (G-7) finance ministers and central bank governors meeting in Niigata, Japan, on Saturday, May 13, 2023. Yellen said she expects to update Congress within the next two weeks on how close the federal government is to defaulting on its financial obligations. Photographer: Kazuhiro Nogi/AFP/Bloomberg
FILE PHOTO: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen speaks during a news conference at the Treasury Department in Washington, U.S., April 11, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz/File Photo

site_title: Germany’s recession will be sharper than expected: Ifo
summary: Germany's economy is expected to contract more than initially predicted this year due to inflation, with private consumption falling by 1.7% and GDP growth forecast at 0.4%. This is a sharper contraction than the 0.1% initially predicted by Ifo in March. The economic institute has also revised its 2024 forecast to 1.5% GDP growth, down from 1.7%. The contraction is attributed to sticky inflation, which is expected to persist until 2024 when it is expected to increase by 2.2%.

images.alt_text: “We are in a recession. For 2023, the BDI expects a sobering plus-minus zero percent for gross domestic product compared to the previous year,” BDI president Siegfried Russwurm says in a statement.

site_title: Eurozone yields edge up after Fed's Powell remarks
summary: Eurozone government bond yields rose slightly after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated the Fed's fight to lower inflation to 2% has a long way to go. German 10-year bond yields increased 2.5 basis points to 2.43%, while short-dated yields hit new highs. The comments came after data showed British consumer price inflation was higher than expected in May, leading investors to bet on the Bank of England's next moves on rates. Market bets on policy rates rose to 4% earlier in the session, with analysts expecting the European Central Bank to consider further rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The remarks come a day after the ECB increased its deposit rate by a quarter-point to 3.5 per cent.

site_title: US dollar higher after Powell says Fed inflation fight ‘has a long way to go’
summary: US dollar rises 0.15% to 102.66 after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell testifies that the fight to lower inflation "has a long way to go." Powell notes nearly all Fed participants expect further rate increases by year-end, despite the recent rate hold. Markets await July consumer price index and non-farm payroll data, which could prompt rate hikes. The euro and pound seeaws, while the yen is under pressure due to the Bank of Japan's dovish stance.

site_title: Privatisation offer for Penguin extended to Jul 6
summary: A consortium comprising Penguin's managing director and a special purpose vehicle under Dymon Asia has extended its offer to acquire Penguin International to July 6, up from the original June 22 closing date. The offer, priced at S$0.82 a share, has garnered 86.83% of total shares, with the deal sweetened by an additional S$0.01 per share. The consortium now has 86.83% of the shares, leaving only 13.17% to be acquired.

images.alt_text: 企鹅国际（Penguin International）目前约有700名员工，当中超过一半驻扎在新加坡。公司在大士设立船厂，专门打造高速铝制船舶。

site_title: Thailand’s WHA eyes record year as firms expand out of China
summary: Thailand's WHA Group, the country's largest industrial estate developer, is poised for a record year in land sales, driven by a surge in Chinese investment fleeing trade tensions with the US. The company aims to expand its industrial land portfolio by nearly 30% to 100,000 rai in the next few years. Chinese automakers and Taiwanese electronics companies are major drivers of this trend, with companies like BYD and Foxconn establishing facilities in WHA's industrial estates in eastern Thailand and Vietnam.

site_title: Airbus fills more than 7,000 of 13,000 positions targeted in 2023
summary: Airbus has filled over 7,000 of the 13,000 positions it aims to create in 2023, surpassing the halfway mark. The hires support increased plane production and other goals, according to Thierry Baril, Airbus's chief human resources officer. The company's commercial aircraft division has reached 60% of its recruitment target, with 29% of new hires under the age of 28. The trend is expected to continue through the year, enabling Airbus to meet soaring travel demand and boost production.

images.alt_text: An Airbus A321 XLR in flight during the International Paris Air Show at the Paris–Le Bourget Airport, Paris, France, June 19, 2023.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Airbus is pictured at the Airbus facility in Montoir-de-Bretagne near Saint-Nazaire, France, March 4, 2022. REUTERS/Stephane Mahe/File Photo

“This is just the beginning, there’s more going forward. With the growth of India (and) the growth of the Indian aviation market ... this is the right time for us to place this order,” said IndiGo's chief executive Pieter Elbers.
FILE PHOTO: A logo of Airbus is seen at Airbus headquarters in Blagnac, near Toulouse, France February 14, 2019. REUTERS/Regis Duvignau/File Photo
Airbus and US rival Boeing are contending with supply chain and production headaches that have slowed efforts by both plane makers to ramp up deliveries.

site_title: Paris Air Show: 'Progress' in supply chain as jet orders rack up
summary: Pratt & Whitney, a jet engine maker, reported "solid progress" in the aerospace supply chain at the Paris Air Show, addressing concerns over rising costs, parts shortages, and skilled labor shortages. The company's GTF engine faced durability problems and engine shortages, but the issue is expected to trend lower this year. Meanwhile, Airbus and Boeing signed new deals, including a 90-narrowbody jet order with Viva Aerobus, adding 1,000 planes to the industry backlog. Industry recovery from the pandemic remains challenging, but planemakers are optimistic about meeting delivery targets.

images.alt_text: With a total of almost 1,000 jet orders between them, IndiGo and Air India are betting an economic boom and growing middle class will spur demand for domestic air travel, and new jets will help them grab a bigger share of international traffic.

site_title: Orchard Road, Zion Road sites among 8 state land plots to be offered in H2 for private housing
summary: The Government Land Sales Programme will offer eight new sites for private residential housing in the second half of 2023, including two prime central areas in Orchard and River Valley. The Orchard Boulevard plot, the first GLS site in the Orchard area since 2018, will be up for sale. Prices at nearby Cuscaden Reserve, which recently sold for S$3,800 per square foot, set a benchmark for future developments. The sale of these sites is expected to attract developers and drive new housing projects in the area.

images.alt_text: “The government will continue to monitor economic and property market conditions and calibrate the supply of future GLS programmes, as necessary, to help meet demand and promote market stability,” MND says.
Due to the plot’s attractiveness and accessibility, OrangeTee & Tie deputy chief executive Justin Quek anticipates keen demand from developers.
New private home sales rose 17 per cent month-on-month, according to data released by the Urban Redevelopment Authority on Thursday (Jun 15).

site_title: ‘Wars bring back the past’: Booker Prize winner Georgi Gospodinov
summary: Bulgarian writer Georgi Gospodinov, winner of the International Booker Prize, says his dystopian novel "Time Shelter" has become a reality due to the current state of society's glorification of the past. The novel, which explores a clinic that recreates the atmosphere of past decades to treat Alzheimer's, has become a commentary on the current "referendums for the past" in Europe, where governments are re-enacting World War II. Gospodinov believes that nationalism and populism thrive on the past, and urges people to remember that peace cannot be taken for granted.

images.alt_text: Amis at home in Brooklyn in a 2012 file photo. The son of renowned comic novelist Kingsley Amis, he equalled and even surpassed his father in fame with novels filled with savage humour.

site_title: Junk food, sweet drinks are Philippines’ next tax targets
summary: The Philippines plans to tax junk food and sweetened beverages to boost revenue and reduce the incidence of diet-related diseases. A 10-peso-per-100-grams tax on pre-packaged junk food and a 12-peso-per-litre tax on sweetened beverages are expected to generate 76 billion pesos in additional revenue. The taxes are forecast to result in a 21% drop in junk food consumption, particularly among the country's 27 million overweight or obese population. The measures aim to reduce diabetes, obesity, and other diseases linked to poor diet.

site_title: EU’s powerful lending arm eyes first ‘debt-for-nature’ swap
summary: The European Investment Bank (EIB) is expected to back its first 'debt-for-nature' swap this year, bolstering efforts to stem biodiversity loss. The move comes after Ecuador's record $1.6 billion deal to protect the Galapagos Islands, and follows growing interest in debt-for-nature swaps. The EIB's vast firepower and credit guarantees will help cash-poor governments borrow cheaply, allowing them to protect ecosystems. The first deal is expected to be finalized by the end of 2023 or early 2024, with potentially five more deals in the next 12 months.

site_title: dtcpay raises US$16.5 million in pre-Series A round led by Pontiac Land chairman
summary: Digital payments startup dtcpay has raised US$16.5 million in pre-Series A funding led by Pontiac Land chairman Kwee Liong Tek. The funds will be used for product development, bolstering operations and infrastructure, and expanding global presence. Founded in 2019, dtcpay offers services including account issuance, money transfer, and digital payment token services. Other investors participating in the round include David Tung, Jean-Marc Poullet, and Tham Sai Choy. The funding aims to enhance dtcpay's capabilities and further its global expansion.

site_title: Google’s in-car tech sales face German antitrust crackdown
summary: Google's in-car technology sales are facing a German antitrust crackdown. The Federal Cartel Office plans to order Google to drop provisions bundling navigation and services to thwart competition. The agency claims bundling may obstruct competition and expand Google's power in markets dominated by one player. Google has thousands of compatible applications with Android Automotive and will engage constructively with regulators to resolve concerns. The probe may also target Google's default settings and rules for Google Maps, potentially striking down rules banning users from combining map services with others.

images.alt_text: Google has built about 9 million Pixel smartphones last year, according to Counterpoint Research, and the discussions in India underscore its plans to move production beyond China and Vietnam.
Google says in a statement that it has filed the lawsuit against Ethan QiQi Hu to “help put an end to these types of malicious schemes.”
While Google has previously introduced AI tools for advertisers, it is now using the technology to help brands achieve more specific goals for their ads.

site_title: Fashion retailer Love, Bonito faces more than 200 complaints over delayed orders, cites labour shortage
summary: Fashion retailer Love, Bonito has faced over 200 complaints about delayed orders from its recent mid-year sale, which saw a 400% surge in orders due to unforeseen demand. The brand has apologized and is hiring additional manpower to process and dispatch orders swiftly. Delays affected all markets except Indonesia, where a separate warehouse handles local orders. Love, Bonito expects to return to usual operations within two weeks and is offering refunds to customers whose orders have been partially fulfilled or delayed.

images.alt_text: How does Love, Bonito meet the demands of the fast-evolving retail landscape and stay relevant amid growing sustainability concerns over the impact of fast fashion?
Love, Bonito CEO sees a year of growth ahead

site_title: China says Biden calling Xi Jinping a dictator is ‘provocation’
summary: US President Joe Biden referred to Chinese leader Xi Jinping as a dictator, sparking a strong response from China. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Mao Ning called the remarks "absurd and extremely irresponsible," labeling them a "public political provocation." The comments came amid tensions between the two nations following a US-China meeting to stabilize relations and a disputed spy balloon incident. China has expressed strong dissatisfaction and opposition to Biden's remarks, highlighting the fragile state of bilateral ties between the world's two largest economies.

images.alt_text: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken meets with Chinese President Xi Jinping in the Great Hall of the People in Beijing.

site_title: Thai coalition nearing Senate nod for Pita premiership
summary: A coalition of pro-democracy parties in Thailand is close to securing enough support from the Senate to form a government led by Pita Limjaroenrat, a Harvard-educated politician. The eight-party alliance needs at least 64 more votes from the Senate to cross the 376-vote threshold for a joint sitting of parliament that selects the prime minister. The coalition currently has 312 votes in the House of Representatives and has made "satisfactory progress" in winning over Senate support, according to a deputy leader of the Move Forward Party.

images.alt_text: epa10675351 Move Forward Party leader Pita Limjaroenrat (C) speaks to the media after a meeting with the working group of seven party allies to form a coalition government, at Pheu Thai Party headquarters in Bangkok, Thailand, 06 June 2023. An eight-party coalition, spearheaded by the Move Forward party, agreed to form a government with Limjaroenrat as prime minister, after winning the most seats in the 14 May general election.  EPA-EFE/NARONG SANGNAK

site_title: Japan, Netherlands sign chip cooperation agreement
summary: Japan and the Netherlands signed a Memorandum of Cooperation on semiconductor policies, aiming to enhance private and public sector cooperation on related technologies. The agreement will facilitate sharing of information on policies and promote research projects, including those at Japan's Rapidus next-generation chipmaker. The move comes as both countries face US-led export curbs on China, which are critical to the global chip supply chain. The cooperation aims to strengthen their position in the industry.

site_title: UBS to start Credit Suisse Asia investment banking job cuts in July: sources
summary: UBS is set to start cutting Asia investment banking jobs at Credit Suisse in July, primarily in Australia and China, where the two banks overlap most. The move is part of the integration of the two banks, following UBS's emergency takeover of Credit Suisse last week. The reduction is expected to affect around 200 investment bankers, with the goal of streamlining operations and improving efficiency.

images.alt_text: he UBS 9 Penang Road offices, near the Orchard Road shopping belt and historic Fort Canning Park, were officially opened in 2021.
The UBS flagship office in New York.Photographer: Angus Mordant/Bloomberg

The logo of a Credit Suisse Group AG bank branch beyond a UBS Group AG office building walkway in Zurich, Switzerland, on Tuesday, April 25, 2023. UBS attracted $28 billion from wealthy clients in the months running up to its takeover of Credit Suisse Group AG, in an early indication of how many assets the combined firms will be able to retain. Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

site_title: Keppel and Sembcorp claw back gains on Wednesday; STI up 0.1% despite US stocks’ slide
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% on Wednesday, despite a decline in US stocks, as Keppel and Sembcorp Industries rebounded from losses. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 3.43 points to 3,223.66, driven by Keppel's 1.5% gain and Sembcorp's 4.5% increase. Investors are cautious ahead of Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell's testimony, citing concerns about a potential soft landing and the Fed's monetary policy.

images.alt_text: Keppel Corporation expects to generate about S$950 million over 30 years from a district cooling system plant in the Jurong Lake District.
Analysts from DBS Research and RHB Securities are positive on ComfortDelGro's decision to implement a S$0.70 platform fee charge for rides booked via its app.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The price for Category B COEs reached a record high of S$121,000, while other categories remained stable. The government increased the supply of private homes for full-year 2023 to 5,160 units. MAS fined four banks and an insurer S$3.8 million for breaching anti-money laundering and countering terrorism requirements. Fashion retailer Love, Bonito received over 200 complaints for delayed orders, and SPH Media filed a police report over overstated circulation figures. The STI ended 0.1% higher despite US stocks sliding.

site_title: Bundle clean-energy projects with early coal phase-out deals to bump up economic viability: panellists
summary: Coal plant owners can secure lower lending rates for renewable energy investments through blended finance, in exchange for early coal asset retirement. This bundled approach improves the commercial viability of such deals, allowing emerging markets to transition to cleaner energy sources. Regulators and industry players see blended finance as a key mechanism for funding renewable energy projects and reducing reliance on fossil fuels. By pairing renewable energy development with coal phase-out, owners and operators can access lower lending rates, facilitating a smoother transition to cleaner energy.

images.alt_text: Coal barges to be pulled along Mahakam river in Samarinda, East Kalimantan province, Indonesia, in August 31, 2019.

While Indonesia is not short on opportunities and ambition for decarbonisation, where it lacks is affordable financing, says its Coordinating Minister of Maritime and Investment Affairs Luhut Binsar Pandjaitanhe.
An initial investment plan detailing how Indonesia will green its power supply and cut greenhouse emissions is due mid-August.
A truck carries coal in Tabalong, Indonesia. Fitch expects the country's coal production levels to remain stable or grow moderately in the medium term.

The criteria for qualifying coal projects were laid out in the second version of Asean taxonomy for sustainable finance, released by the Asean Taxonomy Board after the market closed on Monday (Mar 27).

site_title: Michael Jackson’s Moonwalk fedora up for auction in Paris
summary: The black fedora worn by Michael Jackson during his iconic Moonwalk dance in 1983 is set to be auctioned off in Paris on September 26. Estimated to be worth 60,000 to 100,000 euros, the hat will be the star attraction at the auction of rock-and-roll items by Drouot. Other notable items include a guitar owned by T-Bone Walker and a suit worn by Depeche Mode's Martin Gore. The sale is being organized by Artpeges and Lemon Auction, which previously sold a guitar that broke up the British band Oasis for 385,500 euros.

site_title: Hong Kong borrowing rates’ catchup with US stymies carry trade
summary: Hong Kong's borrowing rates have caught up with US equivalents, reducing the attractiveness of a popular carry trade. The one-month Hong Kong interbank offered rate (Hibor) has largely matched the US dollar Secured Overnight Financing Rate (SOFR). Elevated Hibor levels have cooled pressure on the Hong Kong dollar, but analysts expect rates to retreat after a seasonal effect abates in July and potentially drop below SOFR before year-end due to further interest-rate hikes by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Sony unit says monitoring India regulator move on merger partner Zee
summary: Sony is monitoring the Indian regulator's move on its merger partner Zee, following the Securities and Exchange Board of India's (Sebi) one-year ban on Zee's founder and CEO Punit Goenka. The ban was announced due to allegations of diverting company funds to related entities. The merger, announced in 2021, aims to create a $10 billion TV enterprise, with Goenka set to become managing director and CEO. The development may trigger further delay in the deal, which has already faced multiple setbacks.

site_title: Coinbase waged unusual legal defence ahead of SEC’s crypto crackdown
summary: Coinbase has launched an unusual legal defense ahead of the US Securities and Exchange Commission's (SEC) crackdown on digital assets. The company filed briefs as an "amicus" in two other crypto-related lawsuits, urging judges to adopt views on open legal questions that are now at the heart of its own case. This could potentially be used as a defense in its own case, as a ruling favoring another crypto defendant at the trial court level would not be binding on Coinbase's case.

images.alt_text: The SEC last week widened its crackdown on the crypto industry through a one-two punch against the biggest firms, Binance Holdings and Coinbase.
In the longer term, Coinbase is facing a bigger hit should the SEC’s lawsuit prevail.
“The SEC allowed us to become a public company ... so, its not great to have a regulator come back and say, actually, we changed our mind,” Coinbase CEO Brian Armstrong says.
Mainstream US banks have become warier of processing wire transfers and holding deposits for the crypto industry, following last year’s turmoil and amid growing regulatory scrutiny.
The SEC says Coinbase has since at least 2019 operated as an unregistered broker by handling cryptocurrency transactions, evading the disclosure requirements meant to protect investors.

site_title: Clifford Capital names JPMorgan’s Murlidhar Maiya as new group CEO
summary: Clifford Capital, a debt financing solutions provider, has appointed Murlidhar Maiya as its new group CEO and executive director, succeeding Clive Kerner at the end of the third quarter. Maiya, who spent over 25 years at JPMorgan, previously led the bank's South and South-east Asia businesses. He will oversee the company's debt financing solutions and replace Kerner, who will remain in a senior advisory role until his retirement at the end of the year.

site_title: Taking music concerts into the metaverse
summary: Bandwagon, a Singaporean music media company, has successfully hosted free metaverse events, attracting over 250 attendees at its first event featuring Singaporean DJ MYRNE. The company, founded by Clarence Chan, aims to bring concerts into the metaverse, offering a digital stage for artistes' performances and allowing attendees to create avatars and watch the concert on their computers. Bandwagon has seen significant growth in revenue, with Bandwagon Labs accounting for 50% of the company's revenue, and plans to launch its own lightweight metaverse, BW Land, in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Changi Airport's Terminal 3 as seen in the ChangiVerse. XR experiences are already a reality, and will become more ubiquitous going forward.
Shares in Unusual have steadily risen since April, with a jump of over 10 per cent in May. The company cited the overwhelming response for Jacky Cheung’s concerts as a reason for the rise.

site_title: Cheesemaker spreads joy in tropical Thailand
