summary: Rachanikorn Srikong, a 47-year-old Thai cheesemaker, is part of a growing community of artisanal cheesemakers in Thailand. Despite the country's tropical climate, Rachanikorn produces 15 varieties of cheese, including ones with local twists, from her farm in Nakhon Pathom. She learned cheesemaking from scratch after growing up without dairy and found inspiration in Thai condiments like pla dak. Her cheeses are now sold to high-end restaurants in Bangkok, including Michelin-starred establishments, bringing joy to those who taste them.

images.alt_text: Anchovies at Table by Bruno Verjus, the No 10 ranked restaurant.

site_title: China state media, government advisers call for economic support
summary: China's state media and top government advisers are calling for economic stimulus, following the People's Bank of China's surprise rate cut last week. Prominent economists, including Wang Huning and Liu Yuanchun, are urging interest rate cuts and support measures to boost consumption and investment. Expectations for more monetary and fiscal stimulus have risen, with some analysts forecasting cuts in the second half of the year to shore up growth. The central bank may roll out structural monetary policy tools, such as relending programmes, to support sectors like hi-tech manufacturing.

images.alt_text: Beijing has been tightening rules on local government borrowing for years, curbing access to bank loans and bonds and driving their financing vehicles deeper into private markets to raise money.
China’s efforts contrast with those in the United States and other Western countries, which have been forced into a series of interest rate hikes while reducing money supply to tame inflation.

site_title: El Nino raising risk of South-east Asia haze crisis this year
summary: A strong El Nino is predicted to bring hotter and drier weather to South-east Asia, increasing the risk of a haze crisis this year, according to a report by the Singapore Institute of International Affairs. The region has not experienced severe haze since 2015, but the report assigns a "red" rating, the highest risk category, due to the likelihood of less rainfall and exacerbated forest fires. The US National Ocean and Atmospheric Administration predicts an 84% chance of a strong El Nino, with potential for a "super El Nino."

images.alt_text: After three years of the La Nina climate pattern, which often lowers global temperatures slightly, the hotter El Nino is back in action, according to an advisory issued on Thursday (Jun 8) by the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s Climate Prediction Center.

site_title: India economic growth prospects fuel foreign bond-buying streak
summary: Foreign investors are buying Indian debt for the best streak in almost four years, driven by easing inflation, a brightening growth outlook, and a stable rupee. In June, they purchased $184.5 million worth of Indian debt, with many analysts praising India's growth prospects, citing a relatively younger population and a "China+1" strategy. This trend is expected to sustain in the second half of the year, with improved real rates and reduced volatility making Indian debt more attractive.

images.alt_text: The rupee had declined on Tuesday, likely due to dollar outflows.

site_title: UK inflation overshoots again, heaping pressure on BOE
summary: UK inflation has risen 8.7% in May, exceeding expectations and putting pressure on the Bank of England (BOE) to hike interest rates more aggressively. Core inflation, excluding food and energy, accelerated to 7.1%, a 30-year high. The BOE has raised rates 12 times since 2022, with further hikes expected to 5.75% by early next year, potentially plunging the UK into recession. The pound rose after the release, and mortgage rates soared above 6%. The BOE is set to raise interest rates again on Thursday.

images.alt_text: British supermarkets are under pressure to curb prices as grocery inflation proves stickier than in other countries.

site_title: UK fines WH Smith, M&S and others for not paying minimum wage
summary: The UK government has fined over 200 companies, including WH Smith, Marks & Spencer, and Argos, a combined £11.9 million for failing to pay minimum wage to around 63,000 workers between 2017 and 2019. The companies also paid £4.9 million in arrears. The government stated that most businesses do the right thing, but a clear message is being sent to those who ignore the law. The minimum wage in Britain increased to £10.42 per hour in April, and the government noted that not all underpayments were intentional, but there was no excuse for underpaying workers.

images.alt_text: epa10410721 Commuters make their way to work in London, Britain, 17 January 2023. According to the Office for National Statistics (ONS), UK wages have grown at their fastest rate for twenty years. Real wages however have fallen by some 3.8 percent as pay failed to keep up with inflation.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: Government bumps up supply of private homes for full-year 2023 to highest in a decade
summary: The Singapore government has increased the supply of private homes for the full-year 2023 to 9,250 units, the highest in a decade. The confirmed list supply for the second half of 2023 is expected to rise by 26.2% to 5,160 units, including 560 executive condominium (EC) units. The move aims to meet demand and promote market stability amid a weaker economic outlook and consecutive cooling measures. The government will continue to monitor economic and property market conditions and adjust the supply accordingly.

images.alt_text: Private residential properties in Singapore's prime areas are expected to be affected the most by the latest cooling measures due to the traditionally higher component of foreign buyers in these areas compared with the city-fringe and suburban locations.
New private home sales rose 17 per cent month-on-month, according to data released by the Urban Redevelopment Authority on Thursday (Jun 15).
MND will supply land for development into 4,090 private homes (including 700 executive condo or EC units) on the confirmed list for the first half of 2023.
Due to the plot’s attractiveness and accessibility, OrangeTee & Tie deputy chief executive Justin Quek anticipates keen demand from developers.

site_title: Japan sees 1.9 million visitors in May, down from cherry blossom rush
summary: Japan saw 1.9 million foreign visitors in May, down 31.5% from May 2019, according to the Japan National Tourism Organisation. The decline was attributed to the post-pandemic cherry blossom rush in April. China's visitor numbers grew 24% to 134,400, but still lagged behind 2019 levels. The yen's weakening value made trips to Japan the cheapest in years, boosting consumer-focused businesses. Experts predict continued growth in tourism, driven by Japan's reopened borders and favorable exchange rates.

images.alt_text: As widely expected, the Bank of Japan kept intact its short-term interest rate target at -0.1 per cent and that for the 10-year bond yield around 0 per cent at the two-day meeting that ended on Friday.
The Tokyo Stock Exchange closed the June 14 session with the Nikkei index at 33,502.42 points, the highest close in over 33 years.

site_title: Swiber to delist on Jun 23
summary: Swiber, an offshore and marine group, will delist from the Singapore Exchange on June 23, following the exchange's approval of its application. The company, which was listed in 2006, was put under judicial management in 2016 and ordered compulsory liquidation in 2022 due to insolvency. As of June 23, shares held by the central depository will be withdrawn.

site_title: Asean must hold Myanmar junta accountable: UN expert
summary: A UN Special Rapporteur on Myanmar's human rights situation, Thomas Andrews, urged the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) to hold the country's military rulers accountable for their actions. A recent meeting in Thailand, attended by regional diplomats, was criticized for potentially legitimizing the junta and undermining Asean unity. Andrews called for alternative measures to break the deadlock, including imposing accountability for human rights violations and the failure to implement a peace plan. Asean is "deadlocked" over how to resolve the crisis, with some countries shunning the meeting due to the junta's barred presence.

images.alt_text: The outgoing Thai military-backed government has invited Asean foreign ministers, including the one appointed by Myanmar’s junta, to discuss a proposal for the regional bloc to “fully re-engage Myanmar at the leaders’ level”, according to an invitation seen by Reuters and verified by sources.

site_title: Swedish housing-start data paints brighter picture after slump
summary: Sweden's housing market is showing signs of improvement after a 15% decline in home values due to rising borrowing costs. The Byggfakta housing-construction activity indicator rose for the first time in almost two years, with a marginal increase in housing starts in May. This follows a stabilisation in recent months, with more Swedes believing home prices will rise than fall. The positive trend suggests a brighter picture for the Swedish housing market, which has been impacted by the global property rout.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Woman strolls through the Sodermalm area of Stockholm, Sweden October 22, 2020. Amir Nabizadeh/TT News Agency via REUTERS

site_title: Singapore poised to become offshore Islamic wealth hub in next five years: panel
summary: Singapore is poised to become a global hub for offshore Islamic wealth within the next five years, driven by increasing investment interest in Islamic finance products and services. Industry players attribute the growth to family ties, a mature ecosystem, and the region's rising middle-class wealth. With Asia-Pacific accounting for 30% of global high-net-worth individuals' wealth, Singapore is seen as a preferred offshore financial centre among HNWIs from Indonesia and Malaysia. The city-state's leading financial status, easy access to markets, and good infrastructure also make it an attractive destination for Islamic finance players.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s favourable regulatory and business environment have bolstered the development of the country's Islamic fintech sector, say analysts.
The future is bright for Islamic banking in Asean
A green sukuk is an Islamic bond, whose proceeds are used to fund investments in renewable energy and other environmental projects, like solar parks.

site_title: UK minister rules out significant financial help for mortgage holders
summary: UK Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt ruled out significant financial help for mortgage holders, citing concerns about prolonging inflation. He stated that schemes injecting large amounts of cash into the economy would be inflationary. Hunt will meet with major banks on Friday to discuss ways to support customers struggling with rising mortgage costs. The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates again to combat inflation, which reached 8.7% in April.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt gives Autumn Statement at the House of Commons in London, Britain, November 17, 2022. UK Parliament/Jessica Taylor/Handout via REUTERS THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY. MANDATORY CREDIT. IMAGE MUST NOT BE ALTERED./File Photo
The UK housing market is under pressure from a triple whammy of pricey borrowing, economic uncertainty and the worst cost-of-living crisis in a generation.

site_title: Australia’s home-loan market is resilient to RBA hikes: S&P
summary: Australia's home-loan market remains resilient to the Reserve Bank of Australia's (RBA) interest-rate hikes, with S&P Global Ratings predicting that most ratings can withstand a moderate level of economic stress. A stress test showed that top-rated Residential Mortgage-Backed Securities (RMBS) will only face pressure at interest rates above 5%, currently at 4.1%. Despite expected further rate hikes to 4.6% this year, loan arrears remain contained, and unemployment remains low at 3.6%. Debt serviceability pressures are expected to rise, particularly with fixed-rate loans coming up for renewal.

images.alt_text: Low productivity and rising wages was a particular worry, with the board noting that a recent national award for low-paid workers had been higher than expected.

Reserve Bank of Australia Deputy Governor Michelle Bullock said the jobless rate would need to rise relatively modestly to about 4.5 per cent to bring the economy back into balance, a rate still well below pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Charming Garden makes third and final bid at collective sale with same S$175 million guide price
summary: Charming Garden, a 32-unit condominium in District 10, Singapore, is relaunching for collective sale for the third and final time with an unchanged S$175 million guide price. The owners stand to gain between S$5 million and S$6.8 million each, depending on unit size. The site, which spans 84,357 sq ft, is near Raffles Girls' Primary School and the Singapore Botanic Gardens, and can be developed into landed housing or apartments. The public tender closes on July 10, following two previous attempts without securing a suitable buyer.

images.alt_text: Charming Garden collective sale

site_title: JPMorgan cuts about 20 Asia dealmaking jobs in new layoff round
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has cut about 20 investment-banking jobs in Asia, adding to a February round of cuts that affected 30 investment bankers in the region. The layoffs primarily impacted junior staff at associate and analyst levels, mainly in sectors including consumer, healthcare, and private capital markets. This move follows similar reductions by Goldman Sachs Group and Citigroup, resulting in at least 100 dealmaking jobs eliminated in Asia in the past month, with Hong Kong and China-based staff taking the biggest hits.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - MAY 26: The JPMorgan Chase logo is seen at their headquarters building on May 26, 2023 in New York City. JPMorgan Chase chief executive Jamie Dimon is set to be deposed under oath for two civil lawsuits that claim that the bank ignored warnings that Jeffrey Epstein was trafficking teenage girls for sex while profiting from his relationship with him. The lawsuits were filed in federal court late last year by lawyers representing Epstein's victims and the other by the government of the U.S. Virgin Islands. Epstein died by suicide three years ago while in federal custody on sex trafficking charges. The bank states that he was dropped as a client decades ago.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Iron ore subdued as traders ponder extent of China stimulus
summary: Iron ore prices remained subdued as traders assessed China's potential stimulus package to support its economic recovery. The most-traded September iron ore contract on China's Dalian Commodity Exchange rose 0.3% to 807.50 yuan (S$151) per metric tonne, while the benchmark July contract on the Singapore Exchange shed 0.2% to US$112.80 per metric tonne. China's loan prime rate cut was seen as modest, and no firm stimulus package was announced, leaving traders wondering about China's willingness to stimulate its economy, which could weigh on iron ore demand.

images.alt_text: Beijing has been tightening rules on local government borrowing for years, curbing access to bank loans and bonds and driving their financing vehicles deeper into private markets to raise money.
China’s efforts contrast with those in the United States and other Western countries, which have been forced into a series of interest rate hikes while reducing money supply to tame inflation.

site_title: Chinese e-commerce giants stay mum about sales figures for 618 shopping festival
summary: Chinese e-commerce giants JD.com and Alibaba Group have remained silent about their sales figures for the 618 shopping festival, a sign that China's consumer spending recovery may be slower than expected. JD.com reported a record number of online merchants and physical stores participating, while Alibaba's Taobao and Tmall Business Group saw a record number of merchants and a significant increase in combined gross merchandise value. The sales growth for JD.com beat expectations, but still fell short of last year's growth, and China's retail sales growth slowed to 12.7% year-over-year.

images.alt_text: Argentina's Messi reacting during last week's friendly  match against Australia at the Workers' Stadium in Beijing.
JD already has several listed affiliates including JD Health International and JD Logistics, both in Hong Kong.

People are reducing spending on necessities, resulting in retail sales of grain, oil and food rising just 1 per cent in April from a year earlie, when people stockpiled necessities over worries of lockdowns.

site_title: Hodlnaut’s managers file to wind up crypto platform
summary: Hodlnaut's interim judicial managers have applied to wind up the embattled crypto-lending platform, with a hearing scheduled for August 7. This comes after a year of judicial management, with a proposed sale of the business rejected by key creditors who instead prefer liquidation. The company had faced investigations into possible cheating and fraud offenses by the Commercial Affairs Department in 2022. The outcome of the winding-up application may mark the end of the road for the crypto platform.

site_title: Jack Ma-backed Ant developing large language model technology
summary: Jack Ma-backed Ant Group is developing large-language model technology, "Zhen Yi," to power ChatGPT-style services, joining Chinese companies like Alibaba Group, Baidu, and SenseTime Group in the AI race. This effort mirrors US companies like Google and Microsoft exploring generative AI, which can create original content with simple user prompts. Ant's project will utilize in-house research and aims to gain an edge in next-generation AI.

images.alt_text: A corporate logo sits on the side of the head quarters of Ant Group in Hangzhou, China, on Wednesday, November 10, 2021. Photographer: Qilai Shen/ Bloomberg

site_title: China unveils 520 billion yuan tax break for green cars to spur demand
summary: China has announced a 520 billion yuan (S$97 billion) tax break package for electric vehicles and green cars over the next four years to boost sales and stimulate the auto industry. The package exempts new-energy vehicles from purchase tax until 2027, with exemptions halved for purchases in 2026 and 2027. The move aims to rekindle growth in the world's second-largest economy, which has seen softening auto demand and economic momentum.

images.alt_text: Expectations for more monetary and fiscal stimulus have risen following the People’s Bank of China’s surprise rate cut last week, which economists said signalled a shift to more looser policy.
Alibaba’s Taobao & Tmall Business Group said that a record number of merchants on the Taobao and Tmall platforms took part in this year's 618 shopping festival.
Beijing has been tightening rules on local government borrowing for years, curbing access to bank loans and bonds and driving their financing vehicles deeper into private markets to raise money.
China’s efforts contrast with those in the United States and other Western countries, which have been forced into a series of interest rate hikes while reducing money supply to tame inflation.
Nio has been offering the services for free for at least four times each month to existing owners. I

site_title: Vietnam’s credit growth slow, credit in high-risk sectors under control: central bank
summary: Vietnam's credit growth is slower than expected, reaching 3.36% as of June 15, despite banks' abundant liquidity. The State Bank of Vietnam (SBV) has targeted credit growth at 14-15% for this year. High-risk sectors' borrowing remains under control, and inflation remains below 4%. The SBV has cut interest rates for the fourth time this year to boost growth amid a weakening manufacturing-led economy. The central bank aims to stabilize interest rates and inflation, with a focus on a 6.5% economic growth target for the year.

images.alt_text: The move is a bid to shore up Vietnam’s manufacturing-led economy at a time of weak global demand and slower credit growth.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop as traders await US Fed boss testimony
summary: Asian markets dropped on Wednesday as investors awaited US Fed boss Jerome Powell's testimony to the US Congress, following a subdued start to the week. Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Wellington, and Seoul all declined, while Tokyo initially fell but recovered. The retreat was attributed to investors' concerns over China's economic boost efforts, including a smaller-than-expected interest rate cut. The market decline mirrored the previous day's performance in the US and Europe, where all major indices closed in the red.

images.alt_text: Stocks in Hong Kong dropped more than one per cent, with tech firms – which are susceptible to higher borrowing costs – taking the brunt of the selling, while Shanghai was also in negative territory.

site_title: Philippine central bank creates temporary benchmark rate to replace Libor
summary: The Philippine central bank has created a temporary benchmark rate to replace the tarnished London interbank offered rate (Libor), which is set to be scrapped on June 30. The new rate will be used by financial institutions until a permanent benchmark rate is established by January 2024. This move comes as global markets seek alternative means to price transactions, according to Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas assistant governor Johnny Noe Ravalo. The creation of the temporary benchmark rate aims to mitigate the impact of Libor's phasing out on the country's financial institutions.

site_title: Hot stock: ComfortDelGro rises on heavy trading; analysts positive on platform fee charge
summary: ComfortDelGro's shares rose 2.6% to S$1.18 after the taxi operator announced a S$0.70 platform fee charge for rides booked via its app, starting July 1. Analysts from DBS and RHB are positive on the move, citing potential revenue uplift of S$15-18 million and a "good signal" for the company's financial benefits. The analysts reiterate their "buy" calls on the stock, with target prices at S$1.62 and S$1.25.

images.alt_text: ComfortDelGro said the new platform fee will also apply to limousine transfers made through its app, but not for rides booked via phone calls or text messages, or for street hails.

site_title: BOJ’s Adachi says it’s premature to tweak ultra-loose policy
summary: Bank of Japan (BOJ) board member Seiji Adachi stated it's premature to adjust the ultra-loose monetary policy due to uncertainty over the price outlook. Adachi cited growing signs of weakness in the global economy, particularly a downturn in the US, which would negatively impact Japan's economy and inflation. The BOJ's yield-curve control (YCC) policy has been criticized for distorting market pricing and crushing financial institutions' profits, but Adachi believes distortions have dissipated, making an early tweak unnecessary.

site_title: Mastercard launches global plan to recycle credit cards
summary: Mastercard has launched a global project to recycle credit and debit cards, aiming to reduce the 26 billion cards in circulation from landfill. The pilot project, initially partnering with HSBC in eight UK branches, will provide shredding machines to recycle 10,000 cards at a time. Mastercard estimates 600 million cards are produced annually, with a lifespan of five years. The initiative aims to reduce plastic waste and greenhouse gas emissions from the manufacturing process.

site_title: Raffles Education puts corporate building on the market again for S$200 million

The four-storey building, connected to conserved buildings and a basement carpark, sits on a 27,669 sq ft plot zoned for commercial use. The leasehold title has an outstanding tenure of 69 years. The building has been vacant since Raffles Education relocated its office and campus. site_title: SoftBank to shift to ‘offence mode’ as AI booms
summary: SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son plans to shift the company's stance to "offence mode" as artificial intelligence (AI) advances, amid excitement and investment in the technology. The conglomerate aims to list Arm on Nasdaq later this year and raise $8-10 billion. Following a defensive stance due to heavy investment losses, Son believes the time has come to aggressively invest in AI and other emerging technologies.

site_title: YouTube to launch its first official shopping channel in South Korea: Yonhap
summary: YouTube is set to launch its first official shopping channel in South Korea on June 30, marking the global heavyweight's entry into the live commerce market. The 90-day project will operate in the Korean language and feature live-commerce platforms for companies, with around 30 brands expected to participate. This move follows South Korea's booming live-streaming commerce business led by Naver, and comes as YouTube aims to become more "shoppable" amid declining ad revenue.

site_title: Top producer poised to leave Netflix for Disney
summary: Ryan Murphy, the producer of hit shows like "American Horror Story" and "Monster: The Jeffrey Dahmer Story," is poised to leave Netflix for Disney after his contract expires. Talks with Disney are advanced, with a deal expected to be completed after the screenwriters' strike in Hollywood is resolved. Murphy will continue to make shows for Netflix after a move to Disney, including new seasons of "9-1-1" and "American Crime Story."

site_title: European businesses in China fight post-Covid blues
summary: European businesses in China face significant challenges, with 2/3 of companies reporting it's become more difficult to do business due to a faltering recovery, regulatory headaches, and a politicized business climate. One in 10 companies are either planning to relocate their Asia headquarters or have already done so, with many choosing Singapore. The European Union Chamber of Commerce in China's annual survey of 570 companies highlights the difficulties faced by European companies in China despite the country's reopening.

site_title: Gold range-bound as markets position for Powell’s testimony
summary: Gold prices remained steady on Wednesday, trading almost unchanged at $1,936.99 per ounce, ahead of Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's congressional testimony. The narrow trading range reflects traders' cautious approach as they await insights into the central bank's interest-rate hike plan. Powell's testimony could influence gold prices, as interest-rate hikes increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion. The market is now pricing in a 78% chance of a Fed rate hike in July, according to the CME Fedwatch tool.

images.alt_text: Gold is considered a hedge against inflation, but interest rate hikes raise the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Biden to tighten policing of biofuel credits after wild swings
summary: The Biden administration plans to step up policing of biofuel compliance credits, known as renewable identification numbers (RINs), following complaints of market manipulation and wild price swings. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) will collaborate with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) and Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to monitor trading in RINs, with a goal of identifying possible changes to their generation and trading. The EPA will also set a new volatility threshold for RIN prices. This move comes as part of a new renewable-fuel quota plan being unveiled, addressing an 18-year-old mandate to blend renewable fuels into products.

site_title: Oil prices ease on weaker Chinese demand picture
summary: Oil prices eased in choppy trading on Tuesday as forecasts for slower oil demand growth in China and disappointment with China's key lending rate cuts weighed on the market. Crude supplies from Iran and Russia have increased, contributing to the bearish sentiment. Despite this, expectations for oil demand growth in China and India in the second half of the year limited the price drop. Brent futures fell 0.3% to $75.90 a barrel, while US WTI crude fell 1.8% to $70.50 a barrel.

site_title: Singtel’s Optus ‘delighted’ with decision to block Telstra-TPG deal

site_title: EU hopes for 160 billion euros of investment in key technologies

The funding is aimed at developing strategic industries and countering competition from the US and China. European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen stated that the extra funding would be multiplied by "crowding in of private capital" to drive investment in Europe. However, cutting-edge sound systems and microphones have made live concerts more viable, allowing artists to play to large audiences and command high ticket prices. In fact, lucrative tours by music superstars date back to the 1850s, with Jenny Lind's tours generating significant revenue. The real issue may be that live concerts play a smaller role now than they did in the past, with music being universally available through videos and streaming.

summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened lower on Wednesday, down 0.4% to 3,206.93, following losses in global markets. The broader market saw 59 losers compared to 43 gainers. site_title: South Korea central bank sees low possibility of banking crisis in country

The BOK attributes this to the institutions' preparedness to respond to potential risks, including improved external soundness and credibility. The central bank also notes that financial stability risks in the domestic real estate market are manageable, although there is a need to prepare for potential house price drops due to high interest rates and slowing growth.

Tsai, a blockchain proponent and Brooklyn Nets owner, will work alongside CEO Eddie Wu. Zhang will focus on cloud intelligence offerings. Currently, the government co-funds up to 75% of IVF procedures, but this may not be enough to encourage couples who face fertility issues. China's move to cover 16 types of assisted reproductive technology under its healthcare system is a significant step to reverse its population decline. Singapore's low TFR poses a challenge to its economic prospects, and the government may need to rethink its approach to pro-natalism.

site_title: Yuan drops to 7.2 on slow stimulus, PBOC’s greenlight

The People's Bank of China set its fixing slightly weaker than estimates, fueling bets that Beijing is on board with yuan depreciation. The yuan has fallen 4% in the last three months, becoming the second worst performer in Asia. Local banks delivered modest reductions to borrowing costs, disappointing traders seeking stronger support measures. Strategists flag 7.20 as a potential soft floor for the yuan, and capital outflows and Fed rate hikes also weigh on the currency.

site_title: South Korea Jun 1-20 exports rise on-year, first time in 10 months

Car exports jumped 110.1% and ship exports surged 148.7%, while semiconductors and petroleum products fell 23.5% and 36.0%, respectively. The country's trade balance for the period was a deficit of $1.61 billion, driven by a 11.2% decline in imports. Shipments to the US and EU gained 18.4% and 26.4%, respectively, while those to China fell 12.5%.

FedEx CEO Raj Subramaniam said the cost-cutting moves will support sustained profit improvement in the current fiscal year. He stated that his administration would seek expert advice to safeguard Americans' rights and safety while protecting privacy and addressing bias and misinformation. The meeting with civil society leaders and experts comes as several governments consider rules to govern the use of generative AI, following its boom in investment and consumer popularity. site_title: FedEx to fold Canada contractor-based Ground unit into Express
summary: FedEx plans to merge its contractor-based Ground delivery operations in Canada into its company-operated Express unit, converting contractors into employees. site_title: When Modi meets Biden

site_title: US: Stocks retreat as rally shows signs of fatigue
summary: US stocks retreated on Tuesday, shedding gains from recent weeks as markets showed signs of fatigue. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.7% to 34,054.07, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 0.5% and 0.2%, respectively. Investors remain hopeful that the US can avoid a recession despite the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes, which are seen as slowing growth without causing a "hard landing." site_title: Neptune Retail to buy Coupons.com-parent for US$430 million
summary: Neptune Retail Solutions to acquire Quotient Technology, parent company of Coupons.com, for $430 million in cash. Quotient's shares jumped 17% ahead of the offer price. site_title: ‘Culture wars’ are risking paralysis of Europe’s green deal

EU climate chief Frans Timmermans warned that drawing climate policy into the culture wars creates tribal opposition, hindering progress towards reaching net-zero emissions by mid-century. Environment ministers in Luxembourg backed the EU's plan to restore nature, but a centre-right group in parliament has rejected it, leaving its future uncertain. This divide threatens to undermine the EU's climate goals.

summary: Spotify is launching a new premium tier called "Supremium" in an effort to drive more revenue and placate investors. The tier will likely include high-fidelity audio and expand access to audiobooks for a fee. The new tier will launch in non-US markets this year, with a US launch planned for October. This move comes as the company competes with rivals Apple and Amazon, and seeks to maintain interest in its stock after doubling in value this year.

site_title: Europe: China-exposed miners, luxury shares drag Stoxx 600 down; Lanxess plunges
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index fell 0.6% on Tuesday, following Germany's DAX index, which retreated 0.6% from a record high. Shares of Lanxess plummeted 15.4% after cutting earnings forecasts, while China's interest rate cut failed to boost investor sentiment. The China-exposed basic resources index dropped 2.2%, and luxury giant LVMH shed 0.9%. Defensive sectors like utilities and healthcare helped limit losses, while Sanofi rose 3.7% after an arbitration ruling in its favor.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index shed 1.0 per cent on Monday.

site_title: Singapore startup Charged aims to sell 2 million electric motorcycles a year
summary: Singapore startup Charged aims to sell 2 million electric motorcycles a year by the end of 2033, with its Indonesia-based production facility already delivering over 1,000 units. Founded in 2022, Charged has secured $7.5 million in funding and has partnered with experienced suppliers to develop its three models. The company plans to expand into South-east Asia and beyond, capitalizing on the region's large motorcycle market and growing demand for eco-friendly electric vehicles. With a self-sustaining business model and solar-powered factory, Charged is poised to become a major player in the global electric motorcycle market.

images.alt_text: Singaporean electric motorcycle and mobility startup Charged has three models (left to right): the Anoa cargo bike, Rimau urban commuter, and Maleo ride-hailing model.
The Charged Anoa electric motorcycle underneath a company sign.
Oyika offers single-use, weekly and monthly packages for electric motorbike riders to swap their motorbike batteries at a “swap station”.
As we look deeper into the dynamics of Indonesia’s electric two-wheeler market, it’s impossible to overlook the vital role that regulators play in shaping its trajectory.

site_title: Paris Olympics organisers in turmoil after police raid headquarters
summary: Police raided the Paris 2024 Olympics headquarters and construction sites just over a year before the opening ceremony, in connection with two ongoing investigations. The raids were authorised by prosecutors and targeted the Paris Olympics committee (Cojo) and Solideo, the body in charge of construction sites. The exact nature of the investigations remains unclear, but the raids indicate growing turmoil within the Paris Olympics organising committee.

site_title: South Korea ordered to pay Elliott US$82.5 million over 2015 Samsung merger
summary: South Korea has been ordered to pay US$82.5 million to hedge fund Elliott, a minority stakeholder in Samsung C&T, over a 2015 merger deemed unduly favourable to the company. The arbitration tribunal at the Hague partly accepted Elliott's claim of US$770 million, stemming from the approval of the US$8 billion merger between Cheil Industries and Samsung C&T by the state-run National Pension Service.

site_title: GoTo’s new CEO inherits a tough balancing act
summary: GoTo, Indonesia's largest technology company, has grown its gross revenue 14% to six trillion rupiah, driven by its on-demand services and e-commerce segments. However, the company faces a challenge in balancing profits with healthy growth, as its gross transaction value has declined since cost cuts were implemented. GoTo aims to achieve adjusted Ebitda profitability by the fourth quarter of 2023 under its new CEO, Patrick Walujo, who must ensure the pursuit of profits doesn't compromise growth.

images.alt_text: Newly appointed CEO of GoTo Patrick Walujo is also the co-founder of private equity firm Northstar Group, one of the earliest investors of Gojek.
Indonesian tech giant GoTo remains an investor in Argor's funds.

site_title: Nio enters into US$738.5 million private placement with Abu Dhabi state investor
summary: Nio, a Chinese electric vehicle maker, has entered into a US$738.5 million private placement with CYVN Holdings, an investment vehicle majority owned by the Abu Dhabi government. CYVN will own 7% of Nio's shares after the completion of the transactions, including a share subscription and a share purchase agreement. The investor will also be entitled to a board seat and will jointly pursue international business opportunities with Nio. The transactions are expected to take place in early July 2023, subject to customary closing conditions.

images.alt_text: Nio has been offering the services for free for at least four times each month to existing owners. I
People visit a Nio booth during the 20th Shanghai International Automobile Industry Exhibition in Shanghai on April 18, 2023.

Firms such as Nio and Li Auto managed to enter China's electric vehicle industry by partnering original equipment manufacturers or through mergers, but regulators may tighten rules to remove such possibilities.
Li Auto has outpaced its peers by introducing a new model in each quarter since the middle of last year, a much faster pace than competitors such as XPeng and Nio.
Visitors look at a BYD Seal electric vehicle at the Auto Shanghai show, in Shanghai, China April 18, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song
Nio invests 995 million yuan for a 19.9 per cent stake of Neo Fusion, while Nio Capital invests 505 million yuan for a 10.1 per cent share.

site_title: Goldman says IPO bust looks ready to boom again
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts the initial public offering (IPO) market in the US will boom again in the second half of 2023, after a year of decline. The IPO Issuance Barometer, a gauge tracking factors like CEO confidence and stock market performance, has surged to 93 from 7 in September. While share sales are down this year, the improving macro backdrop is expected to translate into IPO activity, with Goldman forecasting a reading of 119 in the second half of 2023. This would be the highest since July 2022.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim also announced a reduction in stamp duty charges for shares traded on Bursa Malaysia to increase investor interest.

site_title: China’s Kuaishou, Taobao tap ‘Messi mania’ to give livestream e-commerce a leg up
summary: China's Kuaishou and Taobao have leveraged Lionel Messi's global fame to boost livestream e-commerce. Following a packed schedule of media appearances, Messi appeared on both platforms, drawing 190 million and 410 million views, respectively. The appearances helped boost sales and attract new followers, with Kuaishou's revenue from livestreaming increasing 14.2% in 2022. The move aims to draw traffic away from competitors like TikTok and Pinduoduo, and highlights the growing importance of influencer marketing in Chinese e-commerce.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat said the key to dealing with shared global challenges is leadership from the US and China.

People are reducing spending on necessities, resulting in retail sales of grain, oil and food rising just 1 per cent in April from a year earlie, when people stockpiled necessities over worries of lockdowns.
Pedestrians at a road crossing in Shanghai, China, on Friday, June 2, 2023. Consumers, for one, are not taking advantage of the central bank’s lower rates on new home purchases.
The combined assets under management of China's private securities fund managers is 5.9 trillion yuan, according to data by the Asset Management Association of China.

site_title: Amazon to overtake Walmart in beauty, says Morgan Stanley
summary: Amazon is projected to overtake Walmart as the largest US beauty retailer by 2025, according to Morgan Stanley analysts. Amazon is expected to account for 14.5% of the US beauty market, which could reach $180 billion in value by 2025. Amazon's e-commerce growth, expected to reach 46.5% of the market by 2025, is driving its gains in the beauty segment. Walmart, currently at 13% market share, is expected to remain a significant player, but Amazon's expansion is expected to surpass the retailer.

site_title: Against expectations, oil and gas remain cheap
summary: Oil and gas prices remain cheap despite Opec's efforts to increase crude prices, hovering around $75 a barrel. Disappointing demand, including a decline in oil and gas rigs in the US, and production cuts by Opec and its allies, may be contributing factors. In Europe, gas prices are 88% below their peak in August, with several key facilities, such as those in Norway and the Netherlands, in maintenance or closed. The recent suppression of oil prices defies expectations and highlights the shift in the global energy market.

images.alt_text: Oil refineries and tankers at the Houston Ship Channel in La Porte, Texas, Feb 14, 2023. US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude closed US$1.15, or 1.7 per cent, lower at US$68.27.
Brent crude settled down 48 cents, or 0.6 per cent, to US$76.13 a barrel while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude was down 49 cents, or 0.7 per cent, to US$71.29 at 1935 GMT on Monday.

site_title: Rio Tinto to invest almost US$1 billion in Utah copper mine
summary: Rio Tinto plans to invest nearly $1 billion in its Utah copper mine, Kennecott, with $920 million allocated to the operation and $498 million for infrastructure development. The new underground mine, North Rim Skarn, is expected to produce 250,000 tons of copper over 10 years, starting in 2024. The investment aims to meet growing demand for copper in the US due to the global energy transition, with production from the new operation ramping up over two years.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sign adorns the building where mining company Rio Tinto has their office in Perth, Western Australia, November 19, 2015. REUTERS/David Gray/File Photo

site_title: P&G to invest over S$100 million in manufacturing plant in Singapore
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) announced a $100 million investment in a state-of-the-art manufacturing facility in Singapore, marking 35 years of operations in the country. The investment represents P&G's strategic vision to leverage Singapore's position as a global hub for trade, technology, and talent. The company began operations in Singapore in 1987 with a sales team of fewer than 100 members and now employs 2,300 employees from over 40 nationalities.

site_title: Eli Lilly boosts immunology business with US$2.4 billion deal for Dice
summary: Eli Lilly has agreed to buy Dice Therapeutics for $2.4 billion, bolstering its immunology business with a mid-stage trial drug to treat psoriasis. The deal gains Lilly's lead drug, DC-806, an oral pill targeting interleukin-17, a key protein in psoriasis. Lilly's obesity drug tirzepatide is also expected to drive future growth, and the acquisition is seen as a strategic move to expand its immunology pipeline. The deal is expected to close in the third quarter, subject to regulatory clearances.

images.alt_text: Eli Lilly will rapidly submit its results to the US Food and Drug Administration, as well as other global regulators.

site_title: Demand, supply and the question of value
summary: Singapore's property market is facing challenges, with high entry costs, stagnant housing prices, and increasing transaction costs. Despite ample supply, investors are becoming price-sensitive, and foreign buyers have withdrawn from the market due to higher stamp duties. However, some key indicators suggest a potential turnaround, including upcoming government land sales and the redevelopment of ageing buildings. Office markets in the Asia-Pacific are expected to improve, with occupancy levels averaging 80% and office-focused REITs performing better than their global peers.

site_title: South-east Asia set for rocky H2 2023, but recession unlikely: analysts
summary: Southeast Asia's economy is expected to face a bumpy second half of 2023, with slower external demand still a challenge, but a domestic recovery and services sector growth may help avert a recession. Growth in the region is forecasted to slow to 4.2% this year, down from 5.7% in 2022. The trade boost from China's reopening may be limited due to Asean's close ties to China's industrial cycle, not consumer cycle. Analysts expect Malaysia and Thailand to be among the worst performers, while Indonesia may slow down more modestly on domestic demand.

images.alt_text: Prior to the recent developments, Singapore had earned a name for itself as one of the region’s top gambling spots, with two casinos – one at MBS and the other at  RWS.
The US Fed kept interest rates unchanged, but said borrowing costs will likely rise by another half of a percentage point by the end of this year.
Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim waving to his supporters in one of the Hari Raya celebration events in Terengganu.
Singapore continues to be the leading location in Asean for attracting FDI, given its status as both a business and financial hub.

site_title: ValueMax launches unsecured digital commercial paper at 5.15% to raise up to S$20 million
summary: ValueMax launched an unsecured digital commercial paper with a 5.15% interest rate, aiming to raise S$10 million to S$20 million. The issuance is part of a S$100 million multi-series unsecured commercial paper facility programme on the SDAX digital platform. The company expects to use the funds for general corporate purposes.

site_title: EV maker Rivian to adopt Tesla’s charging standard
summary: Rivian has agreed to adopt Tesla's charging standard, allowing customers to access 12,000 Tesla Superchargers in the US and Canada as early as spring 2024. This move gives Rivian access to the largest US charging network and adds momentum to Tesla's bid to set the industry standard. Rivian will also make a Tesla-style charging port standard on its vehicles starting in 2025.

images.alt_text: The company reaffirmed plans to build 50,000 vehicles this year.

site_title: US housing starts surge to 13-month high
summary: US housing starts surged to a 13-month high in May, rising 21.7% to 1.631 million single-family units, the highest since April 2022. Permits for future construction also climbed, suggesting the housing market may be turning a corner after Federal Reserve interest rate hikes. The National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo Housing Market index rebounded to above the midpoint mark, indicating improved sentiment among homebuilders. Despite this, tightening credit conditions could limit access to funding for new projects.

images.alt_text: A worker nails a piece of lumber to a wall frame on the site of a home under construction at the M/I Homes Inc. Bougainvillea Place housing development in Ellenton, Florida, U.S., on Thursday, July 6, 2017. The U.S. Census Bureau is scheduled to release housing starts figures on July 19. Photographer: Ty Wright/Bloomberg

Workers build a floor at a home under construction in Saratoga Springs, Utah, U.S., on Tuesday, March 12, 2019. The National Association of Home Builders (NAHB) released housing market index figures on March 18. Photographer: George Frey/Bloomberg

site_title: KKR agrees to buy up to 40 billion euros of PayPal’s Pay-Later loans
summary: KKR has agreed to purchase up to 40 billion euros of PayPal's Pay-Later loans, freeing up the payments giant to repurchase an additional US$1 billion of shares this year. The deal allows KKR to acquire substantially all of PayPal's existing European buy-now-pay-later loan portfolio and eligible future loans, while PayPal will remain responsible for customer-facing activities. The transaction is expected to generate US$1.8 billion in proceeds for PayPal.

images.alt_text: KKR has deployed US$5 billion in the market since he joined in 2020, making India one of the firm’s largest and most active markets in Asia.

site_title: Investors rely on engagement with Asean corporates to drive ESG change
summary: Investors in South-east Asia are relying on behind-the-scenes engagement with companies to drive environmental, social, and governance (ESG) change, rather than voting on climate-related shareholder resolutions. Unlike companies in Japan, North America, and Europe, few climate-related resolutions have been seen in the region. Asset managers such as Abrdn and Manulife Investment Management are using engagement to encourage companies to improve their sustainability strategies, including net-zero commitments and climate disclosures. This approach allows investors to have a more direct impact on companies' ESG practices.

images.alt_text: Skyline of the Central Business District (CBD) and Marina Bay Financial Centre.

site_title: What’s the difference between a submersible and a submarine?
summary: A submersible is a vessel that can operate independently underwater, while a submarine is an autonomous craft. The missing vessel, Titan, is classified as a submersible because it relies on a support platform to deploy and return, rather than functioning autonomously. The Titan is a crewed submersible capable of taking five people to depths of 4,000 meters for various purposes, including research and data collection. Its support platform allows for controlled descent and ascent, and it is equipped with a motion-dampening system for stable underwater operations.

images.alt_text: The missing submersible, the Titan, carries a pilot and four crew members to a maximum depth of 4,000 metres.

site_title: Estonia becomes first central European country to allow same-sex marriage
summary: Estonia's parliament approved a law to legalize same-sex marriage, making it the first central European country to do so. The bill received 55 votes in the 101-seat Parliament, following Prime Minister Kaja Kallas' strong win in the 2023 election. This move marks a significant shift in the country's stance on LGBTQ+ rights, aligning with Western European standards.

images.alt_text: Estonian Prime Minister Kaja Kallas speaks during news conference in Tallinn, Estonia May 26, 2023. REUTERS/Ints Kalnins

site_title: Yuan dips after China cuts rates; Swedish krona, Aussie slide
summary: China cut interest rates by 10 basis points, the first such easing in 10 months, to shore up a slowing economic recovery. The move led to a decline in the yuan, with the offshore yuan dropping 0.2% to 7.1827 per US dollar, near its lowest level since November. The Swedish krona and Australian dollar also weakened, with the Swedish currency at its lowest level since 2009 and the Aussie dollar tumbling 0.8% to a session low. The euro rose 0.1% to US$1.0931, supported by a hawkish European Central Bank.

site_title: Investors, governments should take a backseat in driving philanthropy programmes: panel
summary: A panel discussion at the Asian Venture Philanthropy Network (AVPN) Global Conference emphasized the need for sustainable philanthropy, where passionate individuals and companies drive programs with government support. Experts, including Temasek Foundation's CEO Ng Boon Heong and AVPN's CEO Naina Subberwal Batra, highlighted the importance of collaboration, impact investing, and standardised metrics to measure social changes. They noted that governments can play a supporting role in policymaking, offering tax incentives and matching grants, while companies can adopt measurable criteria to bridge the gap between small and large organizations.

images.alt_text: There is increasingly strong desire among wealthy clients to ensure that their philanthropy creates as meaningful an impact as possible.

site_title: Is it time to return to Asian high-yield? Here’s what we are watching
summary: The Asian high-yield (HY) bond market has retraced its gains from November 2022, reaching a year-low. China's property sector remains a significant drag, but India's renewable energy sector is expected to play a larger role. China Evergrande Group's overseas debt restructuring plan has yet to gain enough creditor support, highlighting idiosyncratic risks associated with the Chinese corporate HY bond market. Investors are shifting their focus to dollar asset diversification, with Asia expected to both drive and gain from this trend.

images.alt_text: The Chinese economy recovered more slowly than hoped in April and May; figures for retail sales, investment and property sales all fell short of expectations.
A view of the city skyline and Huangpu river in Shanghai. The boost from China's reopening to exports has been limited, says Maybank senior economist Chua Hak Bin.
China’s efforts contrast with those in the United States and other Western countries, which have been forced into a series of interest rate hikes while reducing money supply to tame inflation.

site_title: Malaysia nears South-east Asia’s first nationwide Airbnb control
summary: Malaysia is nearing the implementation of nationwide regulations on short-term rentals like Airbnb, following the partial ban on the platform in the island of Penang. The rules, set to take effect on March 1, 2024, will allow serviced apartments but restrict other types of short-stay rentals. Malaysia is the first country in South-east Asia to impose such regulations, following years of complaints about rowdy tourists. Airbnb has called for balanced regulations, citing the economic benefits of short-term rentals, with 82% of Malaysians surveyed supporting the practice.

site_title: Pakistan and China sign US$4.8 billion nuclear power plant deal
summary: Pakistan and China signed a $4.8 billion deal to build a 1,200-MW nuclear power plant, with work beginning immediately. The project, valued at $4.8 billion, is China's investment in Pakistan, showcasing trust and faith in the country. The plant, located in Punjab, will help Pakistan transition away from fossil fuels and increase its nuclear energy production capacity to 1,400 MW. Pakistan Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif thanked China for offering a $100 million discount and for disbursing initial funds despite a long delay.

site_title: Food inflation is still weighing on British shoppers at 16.5%
summary: British grocery inflation remains high at 16.5% in the UK, the lowest level this year, but still causing concern for shoppers. The rate has dipped slightly for another month, but nearly 70% of households are worried about food and drink inflation. Retailers, such as Aldi and Lidl, are experiencing growth, while supermarkets like Tesco have cut prices on some items. The Bank of England has warned that inflation may take longer to ease, and interest rate hikes are expected, further intensifying the cost-of-living squeeze.

images.alt_text: The UK housing market is under pressure from a triple whammy of pricey borrowing, economic uncertainty and the worst cost-of-living crisis in a generation.

Make UK said it expected factory output to fall 0.3 per cent this year compared with a 3.3 per cent contraction expected three months earlier, and kept unchanged its forecast for 0.8 per cent growth in 2024.
The BOE’s quarterly inflation attitudes survey showed expectations for inflation in the coming 12 months fell to 3.5 per cent from 3.9 per cent in February.

site_title: America’s mythical fiscal conservatives
summary: US policymakers must address the growing federal budget deficits and debt to ensure long-term sustainability. The rapid rise in interest rates has become a constraint on fiscal policy, as real interest payments on the national debt are set to rise despite inflation cooling. To achieve sustainable fiscal policy, policymakers should follow two guiding principles: countercyclical policy to stimulate the economy during recessions and long-term sustainability by slowing debt growth relative to the economy. Improving fiscal policy is crucial to maintain the US' government debt's long-term viability.

images.alt_text: Unfortunately, allowing the GOP to drive the US economy off a cliff may be President Joe Biden’s best option right now.
The Treasury Department had warned it would be unable to pay all its bills on Jun 5 if Congress failed to act by then.

site_title: Hyundai’s Singapore plant opening further delayed to Q4
summary: Hyundai's Singapore plant opening has been delayed to the fourth quarter of this year, one year after its original target date. The plant, which has assembled around 100 Ioniq 5 electric cars, will eventually export to nearby markets such as Australia and New Zealand. Hyundai is considering establishing body pressing and painting facilities in Singapore, which would transform the location into a full car-manufacturing site. The company is exploring new manufacturing methods, including using robots to move parts around the factory floor.

images.alt_text: A P.UP mobile charging van (left) and Hyundia Ioniq 5 EV (right)

Just for Singapore buyers, the Ioniq 5's standard range model, with its 58 kilowatt-hour (kwh) battery pack, has a 145 horsepower motor that lets the car sneak into the Category A COE segment, where prices are usually lower.
Cars made by Hyundai and Kia are currently not eligible for the tax credits.

site_title: Keppel bags district cooling system order, expects to generate S$950m in payments
summary: Keppel Corporation has secured a contract to design, build, own, and operate a 30-year district cooling system (DCS) plant in the Jurong Lake District, Singapore. The plant will have a capacity of 29,000 refrigeration tonnes and supply chilled water to an estimated 1.4 million-square-metre area. The deal is expected to generate approximately S$950 million in payments over 30 years, with the facility capable of reducing 145,000 tonnes of carbon emissions. Keppel's earnings per share and net tangible asset per share are not expected to be materially impacted.

images.alt_text: SGX: Asia’s international, multi-asset exchange
EMA's announcement comes amid rising electricity costs in Singapore, as a result of the global energy crisis brought on by the Russia-Ukraine war.

site_title: Go-Ventures raises US$240 million second fund, rebrands as Argor
summary: Indonesian tech giant Go-Ventures, now rebranded as Argor Capital Management, has raised US$240 million in its second venture fund. The fund focuses on sectors such as B2B marketplaces, tech-enabled consumer businesses, and SME digitisation platforms in South-east Asia. Argor's second fund was used to invest in 19 companies, with a total follow-on funding of US$1.4 billion. The company aims to deepen its impact on South-east Asia's technology ecosystem, with a plan to invest in both early and mid-stage companies.

images.alt_text: Sugito Walujo, often known as Patrick Walujo, founded private equity firm Northstar Group in 2003. His firm was one of the earliest backers of ride-hailing giant Gojek, which merged with Tokopedia to form GoTo.
Maybank Securities initiated coverage on GoTo Group with a "buy" call and 153 rupiah target price.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore has become the most expensive city for high net worth individuals (HNWIs) to live well, according to a report by Swiss private bank Julius Baer. This is the fourth consecutive year that Asia remains the costliest region for HNWIs. The top three cities in the Lifestyle Index are Singapore, Shanghai, and Hong Kong. Meanwhile, Hyundai Motor Company has introduced more charging options for its electric vehicles in Singapore, and two former executives were sentenced to jail in the first conviction for their role in the Wirecard scandal.

site_title: Carlos Ghosn sues Nissan for US$1 billion in damages over ouster
summary: Carlos Ghosn, the former head of Nissan Motor, has filed a $1 billion lawsuit against the Japanese automaker and connected individuals for ousting him in 2018 and arranging his arrest for alleged financial misconduct. Ghosn claims "deep damage" to his finances and reputation, seeking $588 million in lost compensation and $500 million in punitive measures. The lawsuit, filed in Lebanon, targets at least a dozen individuals, including Nissan employees and senior managers, who Ghosn alleges conspired against him.

images.alt_text: Ghosn hid part of Nissan salary, feared being forced out of Renault

site_title: Germany, China agree tentatively to deeper cooperation
summary: Germany and China agreed to deepen economic cooperation, including tackling climate change, during Chancellor Olaf Scholz's talks with Chinese Premier Li Qiang in Berlin. The two nations signed an initial agreement on electric and hydrogen mobility, and China expressed willingness to collaborate in areas such as manufacturing, electric vehicles, and green finance. However, the talks came amid growing Western mistrust of China, with Germany's domestic intelligence report labeling China as a "massive spying activity" country. Scholz's government views China as a rival rather than a partner, and an updated China policy is expected to be published in coming weeks.

images.alt_text: Chinese Premier Li Qiang will begin his two-nation tour with so-called “government consultations” involving talks with Chancellor Olaf Scholz and his cabinet, before heading on to France for a financing summit hosted by President Emmanuel Macron.

site_title: Exchange trading curbs spark US$9 billion rout in top Thai stock
summary: Delta Electronics (Thailand), the most valuable stock in Thailand, plummeted 23% due to unexplained gains in its shares, wiping out US$9 billion from its market value. The Stock Exchange of Thailand imposed trading curbs, requiring traders to pay cash upfront for buying orders and prohibiting the use of shares as collateral. Analysts questioned the surge in its valuation, citing it as unjustifiable and predicting a sell call. The stock's valuation is now 82 times its 12-month forward earnings, significantly higher than its average multiple over the past five years.

images.alt_text: The question that many traders and analysts wanted to know was how a Taiwanese subsidiary ended up becoming one of Thailand top three listed companies on the Stock Exchange of Thailand.

site_title: Perennial Holdings unit bags Parry Avenue assisted-living project for S$71.9 million
summary: Perennial Holdings' subsidiary, Pre 20, has secured a S$71.9 million tender for a private assisted-living development in Parry Avenue, Singapore. The 200-unit project will include assisted-living apartments, a nursing home, wellness clubhouse, and geriatric care centre, catering to seniors' diverse lifestyles. The winning bid was deemed comprehensive and innovative, with a focus on communal areas and dementia-friendly features. The development will be built on a 12,912.1 sq m site, with a maximum GFA of 18,077 sq m, and will provide a range of housing and care options for Singapore's ageing population.

site_title: Two former execs jailed in Singapore in first conviction over Wirecard fraud
summary: Two former executives in Singapore have been jailed for their roles in the Wirecard scandal. James Aga Wardhana, former Wirecard Asia's international finance process manager, was sentenced to 21 months in prison, while Chai Ai Lim, head of finance at Wirecard Asia, received a 10-month jail term. They pleaded guilty to charges related to the incident in 2018, making this the first global conviction over Wirecard fraud.

images.alt_text: The Interpol red notice comes weeks after a warrant of arrest was issued to Edo Kurniawan in Singapore.
German prosecutor looking into regulator's handling of Wirecard
Auditor EY replaces Germany boss after Wirecard scandal
Wirecard sells off Asia-Pacific entities in wake of accounting scandal

Wirecard's India unit sold to Temasek-backed Nium
Briton allegedly linked to Wirecard case in Singapore face 4 more charges of abetting to falsify document
