Bellenhaus, who was head of Wirecard's subsidiary in Dubai, said the company was a “swindle” from the start, with former chief executive Markus Braun at its core.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on November 19, 2020 Markus Braun, the former chief executive of disgraced payments giant Wirecard, waits to face a public grilling by German lawmakers over the massive accounting fraud that brought down his firm, in Berlin. - More than two years after the collapse of German digital payments firm Wirecard stunned the financial world, ex-CEO Markus Braun and two former managers will go on trial for fraud on December 8, 2022. (Photo by FABRIZIO BENSCH / POOL / AFP)

site_title: Keeping up standards in the world’s tanker and bulker fleets
summary: The Oil Companies International Marine Forum (OCIMF) promotes high safety standards in the global tanker industry through its Ship Inspection Report Programme (Sire). The OCIMF has introduced a new digitalised tanker inspection programme, Sire 2.0, which assesses a tanker's condition and operational standards. Meanwhile, Intercargo, a dry-bulk carrier organisation, has reported that its members' vessels consistently outperform industry averages in terms of safety and efficiency, with 11 leading Class Societies scoring an average of 1.69 deficiency and detention per inspection (DPI).

images.alt_text: Like it or not, the big energy companies – as the oil majors prefer to style themselves these days – will have to be significant players for many years.
Operations at Los Angeles and Long Beach have returned to normal after a series of labour actions from Jun 2 to Jun 7.

site_title: Sembcorp, Keppel lead STI decline on Tuesday; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.7% on Tuesday, led by Sembcorp Industries and Keppel Corporation, as the Energy Market Authority introduced a temporary price cap on wholesale electricity prices. The Straits Times Index fell 20.94 points to 3,220.23, with Sembcorp Industries losing 9.2% and Keppel Corporation 5.2%. The broader market saw ComfortDelGro rise 0.9%, while local banks traded mixed.

images.alt_text: EMA's announcement comes amid rising electricity costs in Singapore, as a result of the global energy crisis brought on by the Russia-Ukraine war.
Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 56 to 43 after 27.2 million securities worth S$29.2 million change hands.

site_title: Once again, UK Tories lose their way over Europe
summary: The UK Conservative Party's struggles with Europe are reminiscent of the 1919 "khaki" election, where the Liberal party, led by David Lloyd George, formed a coalition with the Conservatives. This coalition won the election, and Lloyd George's outsider status led to a shift in the party's direction. Similarly, current Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is facing pressure from within his own party, with some members potentially calling for his resignation to expose the party's weaknesses.

images.alt_text: Following hours of debate, held on Boris Johnson’s 59th birthday, MPs voted by 354 to seven in favour of the Privileges Committee’s findings that Johnson lied to parliament about Covid lockdown-breaking parties.
Boris Johnson, one of Britain’s most well-known and divisive politicians, says it is a lie to say that he deliberately misled Parliament.
Boris Johnson (left) and Donald Trump have championed a similar style of politics.
Former Italian prime minister Silvio Berlusconi was in many ways a forerunner of many of the populist politicians of today in Europe and beyond.

site_title: LReit celebrates Lendlease’s 50th year with community initiatives
summary: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit (LReit) celebrated its 50th anniversary by launching community initiatives, including a partnership with Dignity Kitchen to distribute baked goods and raise awareness of people with disabilities. Volunteers from LReit and Dignity Kitchen worked together to bake and distribute 500 muffins to social-welfare organizations. The initiative supports Lendlease's vision to create inclusive and accessible spaces, and is part of its commitment to four community-engagement initiatives each year.

images.alt_text: Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust’s VivoCity recorded positive rent reversion at 7.9 per cent.
Parkway Parade Partnership holds an indirect 100 per cent interest in Parkway Parade's 291 strata lots, which represent 77.09 per cent of the lots’ total share value.

site_title: Ex-China central bank deputy head arrested for suspected bribery
summary: Former China central bank deputy governor Fan Yifei, 59, has been arrested for suspected bribery under President Xi Jinping's anti-graft drive. Fan, who was expelled from the Communist Party and removed from his post, is accused of taking advantage of his position to make profits for others in loan financing and illegally accepting property. The case is under further investigation by China's top prosecutor.

site_title: UBS faces hit over Credit Suisse’s Archegos debacle
summary: UBS faces hundreds of millions of dollars in penalties from investigations into Credit Suisse's dealings with Archegos Capital, following its emergency takeover of Credit Suisse. Regulators may fine the bank up to $300 million, with Finma unable to impose fines. UBS has inherited unresolved cases from Credit Suisse, including a criminal conviction and a half-billion dollar settlement. The fines are a result of Credit Suisse's slow unwind of positions and billions of dollars in losses, unlike other banks. UBS declined to comment on the plans.

site_title: Taiwan’s export orders plunge amid persisting demand slump
summary: Taiwan's export orders plummeted 17.6% in May from a year earlier to $45.7 billion, the lowest in nine consecutive months. The decline was attributed to a global drop in demand for semiconductors, inflation, and rate hikes. May's overall exports fell 14.1% and chip shipments decreased by 8%. Orders from the US, Hong Kong, and China dropped significantly, while Asean saw a 10.2% increase. Only 15% of manufacturers expect orders to improve in June, with nearly a quarter expecting a further decline.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Trucks wait to be loaded on with containers at a port in Keelung, Taiwan, June 10, 2020. REUTERS/Ann Wang/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Google seeks suppliers to move some Pixel production to India
summary: Google is scouting Indian suppliers to assemble Pixel smartphones, aiming to diversify production beyond China and Vietnam. The company has initiated talks with local firms, including Lava International and Foxconn Technology Group's Indian unit, to take advantage of the country's production-linked financial incentives. This move follows Apple's example, which has tripled iPhone output in India since using the program. Google's local assembly could drive up Pixel sales, and potentially move production of other hardware to India, but no certainty exists that the talks will result in a deal.

images.alt_text: Google says in a statement that it has filed the lawsuit against Ethan QiQi Hu to “help put an end to these types of malicious schemes.”
While Google has previously introduced AI tools for advertisers, it is now using the technology to help brands achieve more specific goals for their ads.

site_title: Book review: Exploring technology and regulation in finance
summary: CFA Singapore Insights reports on Seth Oranburg's book, "A History of Financial Technology and Regulation: From American Incorporation to Cryptocurrency and Crowdfunding." The book explores the evolution of finance through three eras, from the 1790s to the present day, highlighting the role of technology and regulation in shaping financial markets. Oranburg argues that recent developments, such as cryptocurrency, are driven by smaller investors seeking higher returns, but also notes that excessive risk-taking in financial markets can lead to instability. The author urges policymakers to think creatively about regulations to protect investors and promote a safer economy with balanced financial opportunities for all.

images.alt_text: Mainstream US banks have become warier of processing wire transfers and holding deposits for the crypto industry, following last year’s turmoil and amid growing regulatory scrutiny.

site_title: Reasons for cheer, regardless of where markets and economies are
summary: A seasoned private investor remains optimistic despite market fluctuations, attributing his cheerfulness to a long-term perspective. He believes that businesses inevitably experience economic cycles, but a diversified portfolio can help spread risk. Investing in solid companies with dependable cash flow and reliable dividends is key, and he prefers buying shares when they're cheap. By focusing on companies with real prospects for profit and cash flow growth, investors can identify opportunities for rising dividends and capital growth, ultimately leading to a successful investment strategy.

images.alt_text: Investing in stocks can be scary at first, but this should pale in comparison to the fear of running out of money when we retire.
Apple accounts for 46% of Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc's stock portfolio. Individuals may not want to put so much wealth into a single company.

site_title: The next phase of the US dollar bear market
summary: The US dollar is likely in the early stages of its fourth long-cycle bear market since the mid-1960s, with its share of central bank reserves falling to below 60% by end-2022. The US dollar's weakening is driven by interest rate differentials with the euro and emerging economic headwinds in the US and Europe. As the Federal Reserve pauses hikes and the European Central Bank continues its rate hikes, the dollar's decline is expected to accelerate, prompting investors to seek returns outside the US.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: (L-R) The Hong Kong Exchanges flag, Chinese national flag and Hong Kong flag are hoisted outside the Hong Kong Stocks Exchange in Hong Kong June 7, 2016.  REUTERS/Bobby Yip/File Photo                         GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD - SEARCH GLOBAL BUSINESS 8 MAY FOR ALL IMAGES

site_title: China, HK stocks fall as rate cut, Blinken visit disappoint
summary: China and Hong Kong stocks fell on Tuesday as benchmark lending rates were cut less than expected, and US Secretary of State Antony Blinken's Beijing visit failed to improve Sino-US ties. The Shanghai Composite Index slipped 0.5% and the CSI300 Index dipped 0.2%, while the Hang Seng lost 1.5% in its worst day in nearly three weeks. China's key lending benchmarks were lowered, but the easing was below market expectations, and analysts expect limited impact on the economy. The visit between China and the US only agreed to stabilise their rivalry, with no major breakthroughs.

images.alt_text: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken meets with Chinese President Xi Jinping in the Great Hall of the People in Beijing.

site_title: Hyundai widens charging options for its EV buyers
summary: Hyundai Motor Company has introduced a new charging program for its electric vehicle (EV) buyers in Singapore, partnering multiple entities to create a "worry-free" charging network. The program includes on-location charging, destination charging, and home charging services, with options for up to 80% charge in 18 minutes at Hyundai's E-Pit ultra-fast charging stations. The program also provides a year of free mobile charging and charging credits at OCBC Bank, with up to six charges per month. Hyundai aims to make owning an EV as easy as possible, with multiple charging options available to owners regardless of their residence type.

images.alt_text: The Hyundai Motor Group Innovation Centre in Jurong incorporates a research and development centre and a test circuit.
Kim Hock Corporation has trialled wheel loaders for a month and received good responses from its operators.
BYD by 1826, a new restaurant in Boat Quay which is also a dealer for BYD electric cars.

site_title: Singapore is most expensive city for high-net-worth individuals to live well: report
summary: Singapore has become the most expensive city for high-net-worth individuals to live well, according to a report by Julius Baer. The city-state surpassed Shanghai and Hong Kong in the Lifestyle Index, which ranks 25 cities based on a basket of 12 consumer goods and eight services. Rising property prices and high car costs are attributed to Singapore's high ranking. The report also found that fine dining and hotels are the biggest expenses for HNWIs, with 63% of respondents in the Asia-Pacific region spending more on fine dining.

images.alt_text: Prior to the recent developments, Singapore had earned a name for itself as one of the region’s top gambling spots, with two casinos – one at MBS and the other at  RWS.
The star attraction at  11 New Bridge Road is the Song Fa Bak Kut Teh outlet which occupies the ground floor.
Xtra's UHNW Chinese clients favour brands like Tom Dixon, whose Melt modern lights are pictured here.

site_title: Facing housing crunch, Toronto cuts into once-protected lands
summary: The Ontario government, led by Premier Doug Ford, has cut into protected lands in the Ontario Green Belt to build 50,000 new homes in response to the housing crunch in Toronto. The move has sparked widespread protests and concerns from environmental groups, residents, and local municipalities, who argue that the development will harm flood protection, water quality, and the region's agricultural industry. The decision has also drawn attention from federal authorities, with Environment Minister Steven Guilbeault announcing a study on the potential environmental impacts of the development.

images.alt_text: Canadian home sales rise 5.1 per cent in May from April and are up 1.4 per cent year over year, the first increase on an annual basis since June 2021, the Canadian Real Estate Association says.

site_title: Foreigners biggest buyers of Asian bonds in two years
summary: Foreign investors purchased a net $10.1 billion worth of Asian bonds in May, the highest monthly inflows since June 2021. This was driven by hopes of less aggressive monetary tightening measures from the US Federal Reserve. South Korea's bonds attracted $8.2 billion, the highest since June 2021, while Malaysia and Indonesia drew $652 million and $500 million, respectively. Analysts believe the Fed's approach to ending its tightening cycle and regional economies' peak inflation levels will boost the appeal for Asian bonds.

images.alt_text: Bank of Singapore is bullish on Japan's domestic consumer discretionary segments.
Bondholders who subscribed to its 2018 tranche also received a bonus 0.5 per cent redemption premium on the principal amount because the performance threshold was met at the time of redemption.

Stock price information displayed in the trading floor of the Euronext NV stock exchange in Paris, France, on Thursday, Sept, 15, 2022. European stock investors are grappling with sticky inflation, hawkish central banks and a worsening energy crisis. Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg

site_title: Even Versace can’t lure homebuyers to Damac’s London Tower
summary: Dubai-based Damac Properties PJSC's luxury Damac Tower in London has seen low sales, with 55-70% of flats sold and 30% remaining empty as of June. The tower's flashy Versace interiors, typically appealing to affluent buyers, failed to attract interest in the Vauxhall Nine Elms area. Foreign developers, including Chinese firm Guangzhou R&F Properties, have also faced challenges in the area. The slow sales may be attributed to an exodus of investors from London's presale market, higher tax burdens, and new policies limiting overseas purchases.

images.alt_text: A view of residential properties with the skyline of London's financial district seen behind, seen from Alexandra Palace in London on January 15, 2023. (Photo by Justin TALLIS / AFP)

site_title: Coldplay breaks record for most tickets sold in Singapore
summary: British rock band Coldplay has broken the record for most tickets sold in a day in Singapore, with over 200,000 tickets sold for its six-night show in January. The initial four dates sold out quickly, prompting the addition of a fifth show, which also sold out within hours. Fans experienced technical issues during the ticket presale, and concert promoter Live Nation urged patience. Coldplay is touring Asia starting with Tokyo in November, with several shows selling out rapidly.

site_title: Stellantis, Foxconn form 50-50 JV on semiconductors for auto industry
summary: Stellantis and Foxconn have formed a 50-50 joint venture, SiliconAuto, to design and sell semiconductors for the automotive industry starting in 2026. The joint venture will supply Stellantis, including its 'STLA Brain' electronic architecture, and other customers. The deal aims to provide an auto industry-centric source of semiconductors for electric vehicles and other computer-controlled features. SiliconAuto will be based in the Netherlands and will include executives from both partners. The joint venture follows a preliminary agreement signed in December 2021.

images.alt_text: The world’s third largest carmaker by sales, last year launched Stellantis Ventures with an initial 300 million euros to invest in start-ups developing technologies.
Lordstown Motors says in a filing it believes Foxconn is unlikely to complete the promised purchase on the basis of a letter the contract manufacturer sent earlier this month

site_title: ComfortDelGro to charge 70-cent platform fee from July 1 for rides booked via its app
summary: ComfortDelGro will charge a 70-cent platform fee for rides booked via its CDG Zig app starting July 1, excluding limousine transfers booked via phone calls or text messages. The fee aims to improve the quality of its point-to-point transport services. This move follows other fare-related announcements from taxi and ride-hailing companies.

images.alt_text: Mark Christopher Greaves (left) and Choi Shing Kwok (right) are set to replace outgoing chairman Lim Jit Poh, who will retire on Apr 28.
4 new pillars to drive ComfortDelGro's growth
SBS Transit chairman Lim Jit Poh to step down; successor yet to be revealed

site_title: Swiss watch exports jump again in May as US demand rebounds
summary: Swiss watch exports surged 14% in May to 2.3 billion Swiss francs, driven by a rebound in US demand and strong sales in China. Exports to the US rose 9.8% after a decline in April, while shipments to China more than doubled as retailers restocked. European markets saw a 8.8% increase, with Italy's exports surging. The only decline was in watches priced between 200-500 francs. This marks the second consecutive month of growth for Swiss watches, with the first five months of the year seeing a 11% increase in exports to 10.9 billion francs.

images.alt_text: The A. Lange and Soehne booth at the Watches and Wonders fair in Geneva in March. The US overtook China as the top market for Swiss watches in 2021.
Roger Smith ‘Pocket Watch Number Two, with perpetual calendar, tourbillon and Moonphase complications was built by Smith over five years entirely from handcrafted parts.
The Omega Speedmaster with ‘Broad Arrow’ hands from 1957 featured on the Phillips website.

site_title: Hot stocks: Sembcorp, Keppel fall after news of power price cap
summary: Sembcorp Industries and Keppel Corporation shares fell after the Energy Market Authority (EMA) announced a temporary price cap on wholesale electricity prices in Singapore, effective July 1, amid rising electricity costs due to the global energy crisis. Sembcorp plummeted 11.6% and Keppel dipped 5.9% in heavy trading. The price cap aims to prevent huge swings in electricity prices.

images.alt_text: With increased usage, homeowners are requesting more frequent servicing as air-con units get clogged with dust more quickly.
Singapore is “on track” to quadruple solar panel deployment from 2021, the government said in its statement.
The temporary price cap will kick in from Jul 1, 2023, said the Energy Market Authority in a paper published on its website.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 2-month high as investors assess RBA minutes
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.9% to a 2-month high, its highest closing level since April 20, as investors bet the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) may become less hawkish. The RBA's minutes showed a finely balanced decision to hike interest rates in June, sparking expectations of a potential rate pause in July. Banking stocks jumped 1.2%, while miners and energy stocks also rose, driven by a positive announcement from Woodside Energy on a US$7.2 billion oil project.

images.alt_text: epa10182902 Indicator boards are seen as people are reflected in the window of the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) in Sydney, Australia, 14 September 2022. The Australian stock market is on pace for its worst day since 14 June after falling in early trading in the wake of a worse-than-expected US inflation report.  EPA-EFE/STEVEN SAPHORE AUSTRALIA AND NEW ZEALAND OUT

site_title: Vanishing ice on highest mountains threatens quarter of humanity
summary: A new study by the International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development (ICIMOD) warns that rapidly melting glaciers in Asia's Hindu Kush Himalayan region threaten the lives and livelihoods of up to 2 billion people downstream. The glaciers are thawing 65% faster than the preceding decade, with a potential loss of 80% of their current volume by the end of the century. This could drastically reduce freshwater supplies in 12 rivers, triggering more landslides and glacial lake outburst floods, and endangering agriculture, food security, and biodiversity.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Mount Everest, the world's highest peak, and other peaks of the Himalayan range are seen during the sunset on a clear day from Kathmandu, Nepal October 17, 2022. REUTERS/Navesh Chitrakar/File Photo

site_title: UK MPs approve report censuring ex-PM Johnson over ‘Partygate’
summary: UK MPs approved a report censuring ex-PM Boris Johnson over 'Partygate' lockdown-breaking parties, with 354 votes to 7. The Privileges Committee found Johnson lied to parliament, and he had his parliamentary pass withdrawn. Many Conservatives, including Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, abstained. The report's findings were seen as a "small but important step in restoring people's trust" in parliament, with opposition leader Keir Starmer urging Sunak to take a stance.

images.alt_text: A British Union flag on top of the Bank of England in the City of London, UK, on Monday, May 15, 2023. The upcoming batch of jobs data, due on Tuesday, May 16, is likely to show price pressures in the economy remain way too high for the Bank of England to tolerate. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg
Average asking prices over the previous decade for this time of the year had increased by 0.6 per cent on average, the survey showed.

Make UK said it expected factory output to fall 0.3 per cent this year compared with a 3.3 per cent contraction expected three months earlier, and kept unchanged its forecast for 0.8 per cent growth in 2024.

site_title: ECB calls on lenders to manage growing risk from shadow banks
summary: The European Central Bank has urged lenders to manage growing risks from shadow banks, entities such as investment funds and insurance companies with 31 trillion euros in assets, equivalent to 80% of the supervised bank sector. Shadow banks are more loosely regulated and take riskier bets, with growing leverage, asset-liability mismatches, and insufficient preparedness for liquidity demands. ECB supervisor Andrea Enria warned that risks could intensify as monetary policy aims to control inflation, and that stress could spread to traditional lenders, requiring banks to actively manage client risk.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The financial district in Frankfurt, Germany, March 18, 2019. REUTERS/Ralph Orlowski

site_title: Singapore Airlines trounces Hong Kong’s Cathay Pacific in battle for the skies
summary: Singapore Airlines has surpassed Cathay Pacific Airways in the battle for the skies, with a market value of US$17 billion compared to Cathay's US$5.7 billion. Singapore Airlines has rebounded faster from the pandemic, with record earnings and revenue exceeding pre-Covid levels. Cathay Pacific, on the other hand, is struggling to restore staff numbers and services, with revenue still less than half of its 2019 levels. Singapore Airlines' stock price has surged 40% this year, while Cathay's has fallen 9.3%.

images.alt_text: Last week, Cathay announced changes to pay for cabin crew among other shifts, including adjustments to its salary policy for pilots.
Singapore Airlines says there is no change in SIA's position from the November 2022 announcement.
SIAEC's revenue has risen 40.6 per cent to S$796 million, but this is only about 80 per cent of pre-Covid figures.
Singapore Airlines (SIA) aeroplanes at Changi Airport on Dec 24, 2022.

site_title: ‘Netflix Effect’ lifts South Korean content but market control worries grow
summary: South Korea's entertainment industry has achieved global fame through hits like "Squid Game" and "The Glory" on Netflix, prompting calls for government support to secure local content rights and ensure creators receive fair compensation. The "Netflix Effect" has lifted the local market, with 60% of global users watching at least one Korean title last year. The government has announced plans to provide 500 billion won to local streaming platforms to compete with global rivals, while Netflix has invested US$2.5 billion in local content, sparking concerns over market control.

images.alt_text: Netflix offered a lighter-than-expected forecast last week.

site_title: KKR shuffles Asia buyout team after US$15 billion fund raise
summary: KKR has reshuffled its Asia-Pacific private equity team, appointing Gaurav Trehan as sole head for the region, in addition to his role as head of India. This move comes as deal-making slows due to strained US-China relations. Ming Lu, current Asia-Pacific head, will become executive chairman, while Hiro Hirano will become deputy executive chairman and head for Japan. The changes are part of KKR's early stages of allocating capital from its US$15 billion regional fund.

images.alt_text: KKR plans to launch its private equity fund for US retail investors in the current quarter.
A group of private credit lenders is in discussions to provide a roughly US$6 billion debt package to help Vista Equity Partners’ financial-software company Finastra Group Holdings refinance debt.

site_title: Chinese tech giant Alibaba names new CEO, chairman
summary: Chinese tech giant Alibaba has appointed new CEO and chairman, Eddie Wu and Joseph Tsai, respectively, replacing Daniel Zhang, who held both roles. The move comes as the company seeks to recover from years of slow growth due to weak consumer spending and regulatory challenges. The restructuring, which includes a split into six business groups, aims to give individual units more independence and pursue public listing plans. Tsai, a company veteran, brings extensive experience in finance-related roles, and his appointment is seen as a smart move to facilitate communication with Wall Street investors and maintain confidence in the stock price.

images.alt_text: While buying or selling high-end US chips is not illegal in China, US export restrictions have created a de facto underground market with vendors keen not to draw scrutiny from either US or Chinese authorities.
JD already has several listed affiliates including JD Health International and JD Logistics, both in Hong Kong.

“What we will focus more for the future is to build local businesses, so you will see something called TMall which we have in China become TMall in Europe, which means we will serve local brands and local customers in local markets,” says J Michael Evans, president of Alibaba Group.

site_title: Australia’s central bank hikes rates for fear inflation becoming entrenched
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) hiked interest rates by a quarter point to 4.1% in June, marking its 12th rate increase in 13 months, to prevent high inflation from becoming embedded in wage and price expectations. The decision was deemed "finely balanced" but necessary given rising wages and inflation concerns. The RBA cited factors such as rising electricity prices, high rents, and services inflation as reasons for the hike, which was seen as a surprise by some in financial markets.

images.alt_text: Separately, the government wants to establish a A$10 billion housing fund to build at least 30,000 new affordable homes, but has faced opposition in parliament from minor party senators.
The data reinforces a picture of strong housing demand and limited property listings.
Employment strength has been a key factor in the RBA’s confidence that Australia can avoid a recession.

site_title: South Korea to gradually normalise regulations on banks from H2
summary: South Korea will gradually normalize bank regulations from the second half of this year, starting with a raised liquidity coverage ratio to 95% by the end of the year. The loan-to-deposit ratio requirement, currently at 105%, will also be normalized to 100% from July. The moves aim to tighten regulations after a credit crunch in domestic financial markets and global banking turmoil. The Financial Services Commission made the announcement on June 20, 2023.

site_title: Japan’s crypto exchanges are pushing for looser margin trading rules to help the sector grow
summary: Japan's crypto exchanges are pushing for a relaxation of margin trading rules to boost the sector's growth. Currently, retail investors can have at most double exposure via borrowing, while many want up to 4-10 times leverage. The Japan Virtual & Crypto Assets Exchange Association is in talks to reach a consensus on a recommended leverage limit, which may be presented to the Financial Services Agency (FSA) as soon as next month. This move aims to encourage more trading and make Japan more attractive for crypto and blockchain companies, despite strict regulations.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japan's national flag is seen behind the logo of  Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group Inc (MUFG) at its bank branch in Tokyo, Japan September 5, 2017. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo

“As the international competition for storage batteries is intensifying, competition for capital investment is also becoming more intense,” says Minister of Economy, Trade and Industry Yasutoshi Nishimura.

site_title: Renault sets out Ampere targets as IPO planning accelerates
summary: Renault's electric vehicle arm Ampere aims for a 30% compound annual growth rate until 2030, targeting breakeven on an operating basis by 2025. The company plans to introduce a lower-priced Megane E-Tech version to counter US rival Tesla's price cuts. Renault CEO Luca de Meo will oversee the division, which is set to go public. Despite challenges, the company views Ampere as a "growth story."

site_title: Australia’s unemployment rate needs to rise to curb inflation: top central banker
summary: Reserve Bank of Australia Deputy Governor Michelle Bullock warned that Australia's unemployment rate needs to rise to around 4.5% to curb inflation. The current rate is 3.6%, and Bullock believes a below-trend growth pace for a while is needed to achieve full employment. The central bank has already raised interest rates by 400 basis points to combat entrenched inflation, with projections suggesting inflation will return to the target range of 2-3% by mid-2025.

images.alt_text: Low productivity and rising wages was a particular worry, with the board noting that a recent national award for low-paid workers had been higher than expected.

site_title: Weaker ringgit, easier approvals boost appeal of Malaysian property for China investors
summary: Malaysia's commercial and residential property market is gaining appeal to Chinese investors due to the weakening ringgit and the country's strategic location in South-east Asia. The region's membership in the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) free trade agreement also boosts its attractiveness. Chinese investors are favoring Malaysia's Johor, Selangor, and Kuala Lumpur, with some also considering Penang and Kedah. The weakening ringgit and relatively easy approval process for investments are key factors drawing investors.

images.alt_text: Increasing demand has pushed home rentals in Johor Bahru higher, with some even rising more than 50 per cent from 2021 levels.

site_title: High seas treaty a collective game changer, says Vivian, as landmark agreement is adopted
summary: Singapore's Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan hailed the world's first international treaty to protect the high seas as a "collective game changer" for conservation efforts. Adopted on June 20, 2023, the treaty requires at least 60 nations to ratify it before it can go into effect. Balakrishnan emphasized the need for international cooperation to implement the agreement, noting that the work is not yet done. The treaty marks a significant milestone in the global effort to protect the high seas, which cover over 70% of the world's surface.

images.alt_text: Singapore's Minister for Foreign Affairs Vivian Balakrishnan (left), after a bilateral meeting hosted by US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, says the US-Singapore Climate Partnership signed in 2021 will see intensified efforts in regional energy transitions, low and zero-emission technologies and solutions, nature-based solutions and carbon markets, and urban decarbonisation and resilience.

site_title: Asia: Shanghai lead losses as China rate cut falls flat
summary: China's central bank reduced its benchmark interest rate by 10 basis points, less than expected, in a move that failed to boost investor confidence. Stocks in Hong Kong and Shanghai fell more than 1%, with tech firms taking the hardest hit due to rising borrowing costs. Analysts say the lack of detail on economic measures and limited policy options will continue to weigh on the economy, with a key meeting headed by President Xi Jinping next month potentially providing some clarity.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 56 to 43 after 27.2 million securities worth S$29.2 million change hands.

site_title: China’s central bank cuts two benchmark interest rates
summary: China's central bank cut two benchmark interest rates, reducing the one-year loan prime rate from 3.65% to 3.55% and the five-year LPR from 4.3% to 4.2%, to boost economic growth amid a slowdown. The moves follow similar measures last week and are the most significant policy easing yet by the government. China's efforts contrast with Western countries, which have raised interest rates to combat inflation. The cuts are aimed at invigorating growth after weak economic indicators, including rising youth unemployment and sinking exports.

images.alt_text: On global league tables, China now holds the top two spots for IPOs.
KKR has deployed US$5 billion in the market since he joined in 2020, making India one of the firm’s largest and most active markets in Asia.

US Special Presidential Envoy for Climate John Kerry speaks during an event on the sidelines of  the COP27 climate conference at the Sharm el-Sheikh International Convention Centre, in Egypt's Red Sea resort city of the same name, on November 8, 2022. (Photo by Joseph EID / AFP)
A total of HK$177 million (S$30.3 million) worth of yuan shares were traded on Monday, according to the HKEX, compared with HK$25 billion traded across their Hong Kong-dollar counters.

site_title: Inside China’s underground market for high-end Nvidia AI chips
summary: China's underground market for high-end Nvidia AI chips has emerged, with vendors selling the restricted chips at double the usual price. US export restrictions have created a de facto market, with buyers including Chinese local authorities and app developers. Vendors procure the chips through excess stock or imports from countries like India and Taiwan. The market is driven by demand for AI chips, particularly for machine-learning tasks, despite Nvidia stating it does not allow exports of the A100 and H100 to China.

images.alt_text: Recent economic data shows the retail and factory sectors struggling to sustain the momentum seen in the first quarter, raising concerns China’s post-Covid comeback could ground to a halt this year and trigger massive job losses.
Artificial intelligence, AI, organs, brains, bodies

site_title: Stocks to watch: IReit Global, Del Monte, OCBC, Great Eastern
summary: IReit Global launched a preferential offering to fund the acquisition of 17 retail properties in France, raising S$75.9 million. Del Monte Pacific reported a net loss of US$11.9 million for the fourth quarter due to unfavourable operating conditions and higher interest rates. OCBC increased its stake in Great Eastern Holdings to 88.4% and shares of both companies were affected by the news.

images.alt_text: Louis d'Estienne d'Orves, CEO of IReit Global's manager

site_title: Bank Indonesia to hold key rate at 5.75% for rest of year: poll
summary: Bank Indonesia is expected to hold its benchmark interest rate at 5.75% for the rest of 2023, according to a Reuters poll of 34 economists. The rate has been unchanged for five consecutive meetings, as inflation has eased to the upper end of the central bank's 2-4% target range. Economists expect a rate cut in 2024, with a median forecast of a 25-basis-point cut to 5.50% in the first quarter of 2024, driven by a prolonged pause in US monetary policy.

images.alt_text: The leader popularly known as Jokowi, 61, will step down next year after serving his second and final presidential term.
On global league tables, China now holds the top two spots for IPOs.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS upgrades Sheng Siong to ‘buy’ on attractive valuation, industry dynamics
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded its call on Sheng Siong to "buy" from "hold" due to the supermarket operator's recent share price weakness, expansion prospects, and potential savings from lower electricity costs. The research house believes the current share price presents an "attractive re-entry level" and expects steady revenue growth and easing utility cost pressure. DBS estimates that new stores will contribute S$14 million to the group's top line and S$1.3 million to its bottom line, with a mean incremental net profit of S$3.8 million to S$6.4 million.

images.alt_text: Sheng Siong’s argument misses the point that the independent directors on its board must have more than the ability to spark lively discussions.
RHB raised its target price on Sheng Siong to S$2.04 from S$2, and maintains its "buy" call.

site_title: Demand for air-con repair and servicing soars as Singapore swelters
summary: Demand for air-conditioning repair and servicing in Singapore has surged as temperatures rise, with companies receiving up to 50% more same-day requests. Increased usage leads to more breakdowns and servicing requests, with homeowners requesting more frequent servicing due to clogged units. Industry players recommend servicing every three to four months under normal usage, but the current heat wave is causing more frequent servicing needs.

site_title: Titanic-wreck tour charging US$250,000 a guest is missing
summary: A submersible vessel carrying five people, including chairman of Action Aviation, Hamish Harding, has gone missing in the North Atlantic while on a tour of the Titanic wreckage. The submersible, operated by OceanGate Expeditions, lost contact with its command ship, the Polar Prince, approximately 1,450 kilometers east of Cape Cod, Massachusetts. The US Coast Guard and multiple government agencies are assisting in the search, and the company is focused on the safe return of the crew members.

images.alt_text: The iconic 'I'm Flying' scene in "Titanic", where Jack (Leonardo DiCaprio) and Rose (Kate Winslet) are on the bow of the ship.

site_title: IReit Global launches fully underwritten preferential offering
summary: IReit Global has launched a fully underwritten preferential offering to raise S$75.9 million, primarily for the acquisition of a 17-retail property portfolio in France. The offering, at a ratio of 161 units for every 1,000 existing units, is expected to increase the real estate investment trust's market value by 14.4% to S$601.9 million. Existing unit holders will have the opportunity to purchase up to 186.1 million units at a discounted price of S$0.4515 per unit, with the transfer books closing on June 27.

images.alt_text: IREIT Global says that the European office market is likely to remain muted in 2023.
IReit Global's new tenant will be occupying about 25 per cent of Darmstadt Campus in the 15-year lease.
New Tech Park in Lorong Chuan is among the portfolio properties of Sabana Industrial Reit, which is among the 10 trusts with the lowest gearing ratios reported.

site_title: Gold steady as traders await Powell testimony for rate cues
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,950.89 per ounce on Tuesday as traders awaited US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's congressional testimonies for cues on future interest rate hikes. Markets now expect a 74% chance of a Fed rate hike in July, with gold considered a hedge against inflation but interest rate hikes increasing its opportunity cost. Meanwhile, China is expected to cut key lending benchmarks, and the European Central Bank is anticipated to raise interest rates again in July.

images.alt_text: Gold is considered a hedge against inflation, but interest rate hikes raise the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Hong Kong’s biggest mall amps up luxury appeal to compete for shoppers
summary: Hong Kong's largest mall, Harbour City, is revamping its luxury appeal to attract Chinese tourists and compete with other shopping destinations. After four months of reopened borders, the mall has seen sales and foot traffic return to over 70% of its 2019 peak, with potential for further growth. However, competition from mainland China, e-commerce, and limited flight capacity are challenges. To overcome these, Harbour City is strengthening relationships with luxury brands and offering exclusive items, with Moody's predicting a 15% growth in annual retail rental income for 2023 and 2024.

images.alt_text: The jobless rate was 3 per cent in the three months through May, the same as the February-April period, according to data from the Census and Statistics Department.
More expats are returning to the city after strict pandemic rules fully lifted early this year, and a new talent visa is attracting high-earners and foreign graduates.

site_title: Backroom deals position Jokowi to impact Indonesia for decades
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo, known as Jokowi, is positioning himself to remain influential in the country for decades after he steps down next year. He has been secretly dealing with his allies to secure his legacy, including backing 54-year-old Central Java Governor Ganjar Pranowo as his party's candidate for the 2024 presidential election. Jokowi is also strengthening ties with former rival Prabowo Subianto, who could become president if Ganjar's campaign falters. The move is aimed at securing his signature policies, including the new capital and onshore resource processing, and protecting his family's interests.

images.alt_text: Emperor Naruhito and Empress Masako’s Jun 17-23 visit to South-east Asia’s biggest economy came after President Joko Widodo invited the emperor during a trip to Tokyo last year.
The case, brought by several politicians including from the ruling Democratic Party of Struggle (PDI-P), seeks a return to the ‘closed’ ballot system.

site_title: Credit Suisse’s Singapore private bankers moving to UBS offices
summary: Credit Suisse private bankers in Singapore are relocating to UBS Group's offices, marking a key step in the merger between the two banks. Employees are set to start the move as early as next month, with some already informed of the switch. The relocation is taking place at UBS' flagship offices near Orchard Road shopping belt and historic Fort Canning Park, which were officially opened in 2021. The exact fate of Credit Suisse's vacated space remains unclear.

images.alt_text: The UBS 9 Penang Road offices.S ource: UBS Group AG

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Tuesday; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index down 0.2% to 3,233.65. Investors awaited cues on the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy outlook, following a 1% decline in the pan-European Stoxx 600 index. Losers outnumbered gainers 56 to 43, with SinoCloud Group and Marco Polo Marine rising, while Genting Singapore lost 0.5%. Local banks were mixed, with UOB flat and DBS and OCBC declining.

images.alt_text: IReit Global launched a preferential offering at a ratio of 161 preferential offering units for every 1,000 existing units at a price of S$0.408 per new unit.

site_title: Bankers stable interest rates reviving Asia’s capital markets in second half
summary: Asia's equity capital markets are expected to rebound in the second half of the year, driven by a stable interest rate environment, a Chinese economic rebound, and improved investor sentiment. After a 16% decline in the first half, Asia Pacific equity capital markets volumes fell to $117.2 billion, with a 34% drop in initial public offerings (IPOs). China's STAR and ChiNext markets dominated the IPO landscape, with companies raising $10.1 billion and $8.1 billion, respectively. Bankers anticipate larger transactions and a focus on consumer, clean energy, and sectors linked to China's reopening will drive deal activity in the next six months.

images.alt_text: Traders walk as tickers display stock prices inside the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Thursday, Aug. 13, 2015. Indonesian President Joko Widodo revamped his economic team in a cabinet reshuffle on Wednesday as China's currency devaluation spurred further declines in the rupiah. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg
Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim also announced a reduction in stamp duty charges for shares traded on Bursa Malaysia to increase investor interest.
Syngenta has been working on the listing since at least 2019, two years after it was acquired for US$43 billion in China’s biggest foreign takeover to date.

site_title: WTO backs Japan over Chinese stainless steel tariffs
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has largely backed Japan in its challenge to Chinese anti-dumping duties imposed in 2019 on imports of Japanese stainless steel. A three-person panel recommended that China bring its measures into conformity with WTO rules. China imposed 18.1% and 29% duties on Japanese stainless steel imports, citing a surge of imports harming its domestic industry. The panel accepted Japan's arguments that China made errors in its comparison of prices and failed to demonstrate harm to Chinese producers.

site_title: Malaysia secures RM71.4b in investments in Q1 2023
summary: Malaysia attracted RM71.4 billion in approved investments in Q1 2023, a 60% increase from the same quarter last year. The investments are expected to generate 24,000 job opportunities. Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim attributed the surge to restored confidence in Malaysia's growth outlook. The government plans to implement policy reforms to make it easier for companies to list on Bursa Malaysia, including reducing stamp duty charges and expediting initial public offerings.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim also announced a reduction in stamp duty charges for shares traded on Bursa Malaysia to increase investor interest.

site_title: Chinese battery giant CATL seals US$1.4 billion deal to develop Bolivia lithium
summary: CATL, the world's largest electric vehicle battery manufacturer, has invested $1.4 billion to develop Bolivia's lithium resources, with a total project cost of $9.9 billion. The partnership with Bolivia's state-run lithium company, Yacimientos del Litio Bolivianos (YLB), aims to build two lithium plants to extract minerals from the country's Uyuni and Oruro salt flats. The plants could produce up to 50,000 metric tons of battery-grade lithium carbonate per year, with construction expected to begin as soon as July.

site_title: Volatile Singapore power prices push it to finally embrace solar
summary: Singapore is accelerating its adoption of solar power due to volatile electricity prices, with residential rooftop panels seeing a surge in demand. The city-state has installed solar panels from 0.12% of its electricity generation in 2016 to 1.5% currently, with 90% of government housing developments planned for solar panels. Despite expectations that solar will only account for 3% of its power mix by 2030, small gains are seen as crucial for enhancing energy security. Utility-scale solar and commercial installations have driven capacity additions, with residential systems experiencing a recent surge in demand.

images.alt_text: The temporary price cap will kick in from Jul 1, 2023, said the Energy Market Authority in a paper published on its website.
Singapore is “on track” to quadruple solar panel deployment from 2021, the government said in its statement.

site_title: Masayoshi Son ends seven-month silence to make case for SoftBank’s future
summary: Masayoshi Son, SoftBank's billionaire CEO, is set to make his first public appearance in seven months at the company's annual shareholder meeting, where he will discuss SoftBank's future. Despite cash-strapped startups, SoftBank has invested $550 million in seven startups in the June quarter, with its chip design unit Arm's IPO prospects brightening due to hype around generative AI. However, the Vision Fund's outlook remains bleak, with losses for five straight quarters. Son plans to balance "defence" and "offence" investments, driving the information revolution while maintaining financial soundness.

images.alt_text: The Japanese conglomerate, which has been hit by the slumping value of its tech portfolio, has seen its shares gain 17 per cent since last week’s close.
S&P has lowered SoftBank’s rating to “BB” from “BB+”, citing its exposure to unlisted companies that are susceptible to changes in the external environment.
SoftBank’s founder Masayoshi Son says he hopes the ARM IPO can be the largest ever by a chip company.

site_title: Del Monte sinks into the red in Q4 on lower margins, higher interest expenses
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a net loss of US$11.9 million in its fourth quarter, down from a net profit of US$20 million in the same period last year. The company attributed the loss to a 5.7 percentage point fall in its gross margin to 20.2% due to commodity headwinds and higher costs. Despite implementing price hikes, which had a favorable impact of 5.7-6% on the group's price hikes, Del Monte expects a margin recovery from the second quarter of 2024. The company also faces concerns over its gearing levels, with a negative working capital of US$199.1 million and net debt of US$2.3 billion.

images.alt_text: Del Monte unit defers Philippine IPO amid Covid-19 surge
Del Monte to raise product prices by 6-7% to counter inflationary pressures
For the full FY2022, Del Monte’s earnings were up 58.1 per cent to US$100 million from US$63.3 million in FY2021.
Del Monte's US sales rose in its third quarter, but gross margin fell due to inflationary pressures.

site_title: Halcyon Agri allowed time to restore free float; Swiber’s proposed delisting granted
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has granted Halcyon Agri Corporation and Swiber Holdings a three-month extension to meet the free float requirement for delisting. Halcyon Agri was granted an extension to raise its shares in public hands to at least 10% after its mandatory conditional cash offer closed with a free float of less than 10%. Swiber Holdings' proposed delisting is also moving forward, with the date of its exit from the exchange to be announced.

site_title: South Korea’s US$169 billion wealth fund bets on private credit
summary: South Korea's $169 billion sovereign wealth fund, Korea Investment Corporation (KIC), has increased its bets on private credit and alternative assets to reduce volatility. The fund plans to allocate 25% of its assets to private credit, real estate, and hedge funds by 2025, up from 22.8% previously. CEO Seoungho Jin attributes the move to portfolio diversification and private credit's promising prospects. The fund aims to partially recover from double-digit losses in 2022.

images.alt_text: Yoo Ha-jin, 27, looks at a building where she lives in Seoul, South Korea, February 21, 2023.   REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji
South Korea’s seasonally adjusted unemployment rate has fallen to 2.5 per cent in May, the lowest since the data series began in June 1999, according to Statistics Korea.

site_title: To be future-proof, businesses must understand that sustainability is here to stay: HSBC’s Kelvin Tan
summary: HSBC's head of sustainable finance and investments for Asean, Kelvin Tan, emphasizes the importance of sustainability for businesses to future-proof themselves. ESG issues are unlikely to go away, and banks will play a crucial role in finding practical solutions for clients' transition journeys. Tan expects ESG to become a focal point for the industry in the next decade, with a focus on transitioning to a low-carbon economy, preserving biodiversity, and monetizing natural capital.

images.alt_text: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam said financial supervision is required if carbon taxes – the “most logical and rational” option – don’t rise to adequate levels globally without lots of free riders.

While Indonesia is not short on opportunities and ambition for decarbonisation, where it lacks is affordable financing, says its Coordinating Minister of Maritime and Investment Affairs Luhut Binsar Pandjaitanhe.
The responsible financing frameworks of all three local banks do not mention how they will accommodate early coal phase-out projects.

site_title: Montenegro court jails ‘cryptocurrency king’ Do Kwon for four months
summary: A Montenegrin court has sentenced cryptocurrency entrepreneur Do Kwon, charged in the US with a multibillion-dollar fraud, and his ally to four months in prison for using forged passports. Kwon, former CEO of Terraform Labs, was detained in March after trying to board a flight to Dubai with doctored passports. The sentence follows a court hearing where Do Kwon dropped his request to verify the passports' authenticity after Interpol confirmed they were fake. South Korean and US authorities seek his extradition.

images.alt_text: The US Securities & Exchange Commission in February accused Kwon and Terraform Labs of fraud.

FILE PHOTO: Do Kwon, the cryptocurrency entrepreneur, who created the failed Terra (UST) stablecoin, is taken to court in handcuffs, to face charges of forging official documents, in Podgorica, Montenegro, March 24, 2023. REUTERS/Stevo Vasiljevic MONTENEGRO OUT. NO COMMERCIAL OR EDITORIAL SALES IN MONTENEGRO/File Photo

site_title: ‘Great Resignation’ continues as quarter of workers look to change jobs: PwC
summary: Around 42% of employees surveyed by PwC plan to demand pay rises due to the higher cost of living, up from 35% last year. A quarter of workers expect to change jobs in the next 12 months, up from 19% last year. Financial struggles are prevalent, with 46% saying households can't pay bills most of the time. The 'Great Resignation' continues, with workers seeking more pay and meaning from their work. Purpose, company culture, and inclusion remain key to employee concerns, while AI is expected to impact productivity and create new job opportunities for some workers.

images.alt_text: A shopper enters a Marks & Spencer Group Plc (M&S) store in Guildford, UK, on Tuesday, Jan. 10, 2023. Marks & Spencer is due to give its Christmas trading update on Thursday. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

The problem with using an estimation of core inflation to guide policy is that the traditional measure of core inflation no longer does a good job of extracting the signal from the noise. If anything, it adds noise.
McDonald’s says the latest round of hikes would range from 10 to 90 yen per item or set.
The Chinese economy recovered more slowly than hoped in April and May; figures for retail sales, investment and property sales all fell short of expectations.

A British Union flag on top of the Bank of England in the City of London, UK, on Monday, May 15, 2023. The upcoming batch of jobs data, due on Tuesday, May 16, is likely to show price pressures in the economy remain way too high for the Bank of England to tolerate. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Europe: Shares slide, Germany’s DAX retreats from record high
summary: European shares fell 1.0% on Monday, with Germany's DAX index dropping 1.0% after closing at a record high. Investors await China's stimulus measures and Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's testimony for cues on US rate outlook. China is expected to cut key lending benchmarks on Tuesday, while shares of lab supplies maker Sartorius and medical gear maker Getinge plummeted 15.7% and 16.2%, respectively.
