site_title: New Zealand to review carbon pricing amid pollution concerns
summary: New Zealand is reviewing its carbon pricing system amid concerns it's not reducing pollution effectively. The Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) may not be incentivizing companies to cut emissions, with many relying on carbon credits generated from forestry to meet their obligations. The government is considering options to increase the carbon price, including reducing units offered through auction or allowing overseas buyers to purchase them, and creating separate incentives for gross emission reductions and removals. The goal is to find a stronger incentive for businesses to transition away from fossil fuels and meet the country's 2050 net-zero emissions target.

images.alt_text: New Zealand's new Prime Minister Chris Hipkins smiles as he is sworn in by Governor General Dame Cindy Kiro during a ceremony at The Government House in Wellington on January 25, 2023. - Former Prime Minister of New Zealand Jacinda Ardern announced on Thursday the 19th of January that she has resigned and her last day will be February 7, 2023. (Photo by Marty MELVILLE / AFP)
The weakness in the economy will not be seen as a negative by the central bank.

site_title: Oil falls on uncertainty about Chinese economic growth
summary: Oil prices fell 0.6-0.7% on Monday, closing at $76.13 and $71.29 per barrel, due to uncertainty over China's economic growth. Large banks have cut forecasts for China's 2023 GDP growth, and the country is expected to cut benchmark loan rates on Tuesday. The oil market is watching for signs of the global economy's recovery, particularly China's performance in the second half of the year. Despite OPEC+ output cuts and a decline in US oil rigs, rising Iranian oil exports and refinery throughput in China have weighed on prices.

images.alt_text: Brent crude lost 68 cents to trade at US$75.93 a barrel by 0042 GMT, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude was down 59 cents to US$71.19 on Monday.

site_title: India’s Byju’s to cut another 500-1,000 jobs: source
summary: Byju's, India's largest startup, plans to cut between 500-1,000 jobs in another round of layoffs, following a previous round of 3,000 job cuts. The company aims to achieve profitability through cost-cutting measures. This move comes as the company's valuation has been marked down to $8.2 billion by BlackRock, a 60% decrease from its peak valuation. Byju's is also facing a battle in US courts with creditors over a $1.2 billion loan and is under investigation by India's Enforcement Directorate over alleged foreign exchange law violations.

site_title: Biggest-ever airliner order marks first day of Paris Air Show
summary: Airbus announced the largest-ever civil aircraft order, a 500-plane deal with low-cost Indian carrier IndiGo, marking the start of the Paris Air Show. The deal covers A320 family planes at a list price of $55 billion. European leaders, including French President Emmanuel Macron, attended the event, which also focused on defence and sustainability efforts following Russia's invasion of Ukraine and the industry's efforts to reduce carbon emissions. The show features over 2,500 exhibitors and is expected to attract 320,000 visitors, with a focus on flying taxis and other vertical take-off aircraft.

images.alt_text: The narrowbody jet segment would drive fleet growth for the next decade due to strong demand for Boeing’s 737 MAX and Airbus’ A320neo aircraft..
Last week, Cathay announced changes to pay for cabin crew among other shifts, including adjustments to its salary policy for pilots.

Riyadh Air is owned by Saudi Arabia’s Public Investment Fund, which has more than US$620 billion in assets under management. Chief executive Tony Douglas said the owners would impose strict financial expectations, which he did not specify.
The planemaker has also begun to lay the groundwork for a new generation of aircraft that won’t reach the market until the mid-2030s.
Singapore Airlines carried 2.8 million passengers in May, hitting 88 per cent of its pre-Covid capacity and advancing towards the 3.4 million high set in January 2020.

site_title: US dollar nudges up, sterling near 14-month highs ahead of BOE decision
summary: The US dollar index rose 0.1% to 102.420, near a one-month low, as investors awaited the Bank of England's (BOE) decision on Thursday. The pound is near 14-month highs against the US dollar, with a 74% chance of a 25 basis point rate hike and 26% chance of a 50 basis point hike. The European Central Bank (ECB) raised rates by 25 basis points last week, and investors expect the BOE to follow suit in its battle against inflation.

site_title: Can Singapore banks deliver the green promise?
summary: Singapore banks are ramping up sustainable financing efforts, particularly through sustainability-linked loans (SLLs), as the country aims to be a regional hub for green finance. Large banks such as OCBC, DBS, and UOB have set targets to reduce financed emissions in six sectors, with a focus on SLLs that tie interest rates to sustainability performance targets. While this approach is promising, careful assessment of associated risks is crucial. Singapore's goal has led to a surge in SLLs, which allow borrowers from various industries to access sustainable financing.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong at the launch of NUS Sustainable and Green Finance Institute on Thursday (April 20) with Hsieh Fu Hua, chairman of NUS board of trustees, Professor Tan Eng Chye, NUS President and Professor Sumit Agarwal, managing director of the institute.

The uptake of loans that link borrowing costs to agreed sustainability targets shows that companies are growing more aware of the financial benefits of improving their sustainability practices over time, says Sustainable Fitch.  PHOTO:

site_title: Core inflation has gone rotten
summary: The US inflation rate has decreased significantly over the past year, but core inflation, excluding food and energy, remains elevated. However, this measure is no longer effective in extracting the signal from noise due to factors such as supply-chain disruptions and changes in shelter costs. A new measure, "super-core" inflation, which excludes used-car prices and shelter, shows disinflation on a six-month basis, indicating a clearer picture of the inflation situation. Experts suggest that news organizations should stop relying on annual core inflation estimates, which can be misleading, and instead focus on more accurate and timely measures.

images.alt_text: A shopping trolley is seen in a supermarket in Nice, France, August 18, 2022. REUTERS/Eric Gaillard
Fed officials like to look at an even narrower category of core inflation, services excluding housing, to assess the trajectory of the stickiest price pressures.

site_title: Armaments makers are the only winners in Ukraine and other conflicts
summary: Armaments manufacturers have seen a significant boost in sales due to the ongoing Ukraine war and other conflicts, with estimated sales reaching $592 billion in 2021. The top 10 arms producers, including Lockheed Martin and Boeing, are expected to see further growth, with world military expenditure reaching a record high of $2.24 trillion in 2022. However, the war has devastating humanitarian and economic consequences, including displacement, death, and destruction of infrastructure. Experts warn that the massive military spending can divert resources away from essential public services and exacerbate global hunger and energy shortages.

images.alt_text: Taiwanese Defence Minister Chiu Kuo-cheng speaks during a parliament session in Taipei, Taiwan April 6, 2023. REUTERS/Carlos Garcia Rawlins
Taiwan passes extra US$8.6b defence budget as China threat grows
US Secretary of Defence Lloyd Austin (right) and Japanese Defence Minister Yasukazu Hamada (left) review the guard of honour at the Defence Ministry in Tokyo, Japan, June 1, 2023.

site_title: Germany industry lobby expects economy to stagnate in 2023
summary: Germany's industry lobby, BDI, expects the economy to stagnate in 2023 due to a drop in investments, high inflation, and a skilled workers shortage. BDI president Siegfried Russwurm forecasts a plus-minus zero percent increase in gross domestic product compared to the previous year. A noticeable recovery is expected only for 2024. Russwurm calls for structural reforms, better tax framework conditions, and accelerated planning procedures to address the country's challenges and boost investment.

site_title: China-US climate partnership vital despite differences, Kerry says
summary: US climate envoy John Kerry expressed his desire to meet with Secretary of State Antony Blinken to discuss a potential partnership between the US and China to tackle climate change. Kerry confirmed he has been invited to visit China in the near term, despite previous differences, and emphasized that climate talks should be freestanding and not affected by bilateral issues. He hopes cooperation on climate can lead to further cooperation, and both countries agree that the threat of climate change should not be caught up in bilateral differences.

images.alt_text: Since November, the global population has officially crossed eight billion, more than three times the figure in 1950.

site_title: World Bank set to approve US$700 million for Sri Lanka next week: sources
summary: The World Bank is set to approve a US$700 million funding package for Sri Lanka at its June 28 board meeting, the largest funding tranche since an IMF deal in March. The economy is expected to shrink 2% this year before returning to growth next year, following a record 7.8% contraction last year. The IMF has approved a nearly US$3 billion bailout, with the World Bank funding expected to bring an additional US$4 billion. The funding will be disbursed in two tranches, with US$500 million for budgetary support and US$200 million for poverty programs.

images.alt_text: A container ships is seen docked at the Colombo International Container Terminal (CICT) port in Colombo on December 9, 2022. (Photo by Ishara S. KODIKARA / AFP)

site_title: Rome to open ancient square where Julius Caesar was killed
summary: Rome has opened a new walkway at the Largo Argentina archaeological site, allowing visitors to view the structures of four ancient temples where Julius Caesar was killed in 44 BC. The site, previously accessible only through barriers, is now open to the public at ground level. Italian fashion house Bulgari funded the renovation, which also includes a sanctuary for stray cats. Admission costs 5 euros for non-residents, who can now get a closer look at the site where legend says Caesar uttered "Et tu, Brute?" as he saw his friend Brutus among his murderers.

site_title: ECB hawks make a case for erring on the side of raising rates too high
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is urging policymakers to err on the side of raising interest rates too much to combat inflation, which could overshoot forecasts. ECB board member Isabel Schnabel stated that the bank should prioritize caution and raise rates aggressively to prevent price growth from slowing or reversing disinflation. This comes as inflation is falling quickly, but rapid wage growth and robust demand for services risk slowing disinflation. The ECB plans to hike interest rates again in July, aiming to keep inflation below its 2% target through 2025.

images.alt_text: The remarks come a day after the ECB increased its deposit rate by a quarter-point to 3.5 per cent.

site_title: Australian satellite company linked to tycoon Ching Chiat Kwong sues banks over withdrawn loans
summary: Australian satellite communications provider NewSat Group, linked to Singaporean businessman Ching Chiat Kwong, is suing five financial institutions in Australia for withdrawing critical funding. The lawsuit claims breach of contract, damages, and costs, totaling about US$415.1 million. NewSat went into liquidation in 2015 amid funding difficulties, and Ching has invested around S$70 million in the company. The case, set to be heard on July 7, alleges the lenders failed to honor loan commitments, leading to the company's inability to pay Lockheed Martin and Arianespace.

images.alt_text: Oxley Holdings CEO Ching Chiat Kwong raises his direct interest in the home-grown property developer from 42.65 per cent to 43.12 per cent.

site_title: Timken Singapore proposes to sell stake in Indian unit for US$231 million
summary: Timken Singapore has proposed selling an 8.4% stake in its Indian unit, Timken India, for up to $231 million, with a floor price of 3,000 rupees per share, a 14% discount to Monday's closing level. The sale is set to take place on June 20, with BofA Securities serving as the sole bookrunner. This move comes after the Indian unit's shares have risen over 12% this year.

site_title: AI’s difficulties in learning investing
summary: AI-powered investment funds have struggled to deliver outsized returns, despite significant advancements in machine learning and artificial intelligence. Research has shown that AI-driven investments often underperform, with many funds liquidating due to disappointing performance. Markets are complex, noisy, and adaptive, making it difficult for AI systems to pick up true signals. To succeed in investing, practitioners can focus on playing "easier games" with weaker players, such as investing in developing markets or exploiting investor weaknesses, and adopting a disciplined, long-term approach.

images.alt_text: Upbeat sales targets by Nvidia has bouyed its stock. About 1,300 ESG-registered funds hold more than US$20 billion in Nvidia, according to Bloomberg.
Gerard Lee, former CEO of Lion Global, has just retired and is now exploring projects harnessing fintech to boost Asian fund managers.

site_title: TikTok, just a matter of time?
summary: TikTok has quietly launched its e-commerce arm, which has grown its gross merchandise value from US$600 million in 2021 to US$4.4 billion in 2022. The company plans to double down on its emerging foothold in South-east Asia, investing US$12.2 million in small and medium-sized businesses. This move follows a trend of venture capital in Asia-Pacific accelerating past established markets, with investors expecting a bearish outlook for VC portfolios due to down rounds.

site_title: New Zealand PM Hipkins to visit China, meet President Xi Jinping
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Chris Hipkins will visit China from June 25 to 30, leading a trade delegation. He will meet with President Xi Jinping, Premier Li Qiang, and Chairman Zhao Leji to discuss topics such as climate change, economic stability, and regional security. China values its relations with New Zealand, looking forward to strengthening cooperation in various fields, including the economy and trade.

site_title: If Sheng Siong can’t add an independent director, maybe it should cut a family member instead
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singaporean grocery chain, was queried by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) about the independence of its board. In response, Sheng Siong suggested that if it cannot add more independent directors, it should remove a family member's directorship to ensure stakeholder protection. The company's argument misses the point that independent directors must have more than just lively discussions, highlighting the need for a more robust board composition to protect minority shareholders and stakeholders.

images.alt_text: Sheng Siong’s board is currently made up of 10 directors, five of whom are non-executive and independent.
While serving as an independent non-executive director on various listed boards can be financially rewarding, such roles come with huge responsibilities.
Sheng Siong's board will monitor the progress of the claim and evaluate Tan’s continued suitability.

site_title: Britain's M&S the latest supermarket to cut prices
summary: Marks & Spencer, the British supermarket group, has cut the price of 70 staple products by between 3% and 25% in its latest move to reduce food prices. This comes as the UK's food inflation, which peaked at 19% in April, is expected to abate. The price cuts follow similar actions by other major supermarkets, including Morrisons, Tesco, and Asda, in an effort to ease the cost of living crisis. The move aims to help Prime Minister Rishi Sunak meet his pledge to halve inflation in 2023.

images.alt_text: Food was almost the only area where consumers spent more last month, due to higher prices as well as celebrations to mark the coronation of King Charles.

site_title: IMF working on global central bank digital currency platform
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is working on a global central bank digital currency (CBDC) platform to enable transactions between countries, according to IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva. This platform aims to achieve interoperability, making CBDCs more efficient and fairer for international transactions. Georgieva emphasized the need for a connected system, stating that CBDCs should not be fragmented national propositions. The IMF is developing this concept to facilitate cross-border transactions and promote economic cooperation among countries.

images.alt_text: Gita Gopinath, Economic Counsellor and Director of the Research Department at the International Monetary Fund (IMF) speaks during a news conference in Santiago, Chile, July 23, 2019.

site_title: Airbus wins historic 500-plane IndiGo order
summary: Airbus has won a historic order of 500 planes from Indian budget carrier IndiGo, the largest ever by number of aircraft. The multibillion-dollar deal surpasses Air India's provisional purchase of 470 jets and comes as India's two largest carriers prepare for expansion in regional travel demand. IndiGo's CEO Pieter Elbers expressed optimism about the order, stating it is "just the beginning" with more deals to follow. The deal was announced on the opening day of the Paris Airshow on June 19, 2023.

site_title: EMA to cap wholesale power prices from Jul 1; but checks show fewer companies rely on wholesalers
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) of Singapore will introduce a temporary price cap on wholesale electricity prices, effective July 1, to prevent huge swings in electricity prices. The cap will be calculated using the long-run marginal cost of generation capacity. However, the impact of the cap may be limited as few electricity retailers still offer long-term contracts, leaving businesses at the mercy of the national grid operator SP Group. This move aims to mitigate the vicious circle of sustained volatility and risk aversion in the market, following months of public consultation and engagement with industry stakeholders.

images.alt_text: EMA noted that global energy prices have been “less volatile” in recent months, and that more longer-term retail contracts are now also available to large consumers.

site_title: US homebuilder sentiment up to an almost one-year high
summary: US homebuilder sentiment reached an 11-month high in June, rising five points to 55, according to the National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo gauge. The index has increased for six consecutive months, exceeding economists' estimates. Builder sentiment improved across all four US regions, with a quarter of respondents reducing home prices to boost sales. Sales expectations and prospective buyer traffic reached 11-month highs, and 56% of builders offered incentives to buyers, up slightly from the prior month. This suggests a gradual recovery in demand.

site_title: London home asking prices slide as rate rises stretch buyers
summary: Asking prices in London have slid 1.6% from May, according to Rightmove, as surging borrowing costs stretch affordability in the UK's most expensive property market. Nationally, prices are broadly unchanged, with a slight annual growth rate of 1.1%. Mortgage rates have jumped to 6.01% for a two-year fixed-rate loan, with experts warning of the risk of a deepening downturn. Sellers are split into two camps, with some holding optimistic price expectations and others having more realistic views, according to Rightmove's director of property science.

images.alt_text: The UK housing market is under pressure from a triple whammy of pricey borrowing, economic uncertainty and the worst cost-of-living crisis in a generation.

site_title: Renault sees Nissan executive’s exit accelerating alliance deal
summary: Renault executives expect the departure of Nissan's chief operating officer Ashwani Gupta to accelerate efforts to finalize a definitive agreement between the two companies. Gupta's exit is seen as a positive development after reports of clashes with Nissan CEO Makoto Uchida and disagreements over terms. Renault aims to finalize the deal by year-end, with potential talks leading to a final agreement by the end of summer. The departure of Gupta is expected to speed up work on rebalancing their decades-long alliance, with Renault willing to reduce its stake in Nissan to 15% in exchange for Nissan's investment in Renault's electric vehicle and software entity.

site_title: UK watchdog curbs activities at scandal-hit hedge fund
summary: The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has restricted activities of Odey Asset Management, a hedge fund embroiled in a scandal following allegations of sexual assault by its founder Crispin Odey. The restrictions, aimed at facilitating an orderly breakup of the company, follow a rapid collapse after Odey's resignation amid eight allegations of sexual assault and five of abuse or harassment. The FCA's move comes as a cross-party panel of British lawmakers calls for answers on the regulator's supervision of OAM and Crispin Odey.

images.alt_text: The firm has been in turmoil since last week’s Financial Times investigation into Odey’s treatment of women over a 25-year period that included multiple allegations of sexual harassment and assault.

site_title: Europe is world’s fastest warming continent: climate report
summary: Europe is the world's fastest-warming continent, with temperatures rising 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels over the last 30 years. The continent experienced its warmest summer on record in 2022, with record sea-surface temperatures and unprecedented glacier melt. Deadly heatwaves, severe droughts, and wildfires have become increasingly severe, resulting in thousands of heat-associated excess deaths and widespread damage. However, the report also notes a positive trend in renewable energy, with wind and solar power overtaking fossil gas as the primary source of electricity in the European Union.

site_title: Thai Parliament to convene soon, as poll body endorses election result
summary: Thailand's poll body has endorsed the results of the May 14 election, paving the way for the formation of a new government. The opposition, an eight-party coalition led by Harvard-educated Pita Limjaroenrat, is expected to form a coalition government. However, Pita faces uncertainty due to an ongoing investigation into his bid for prime minister, which could result in a 20-year political ban. The opposition alliance has control of 312 seats, and a speaker will be elected within the next few weeks, with a joint session of the legislature to vote on a prime minister expected shortly after.

images.alt_text: Pita Limjareonrat has downplayed the issue, arguing the shares in the firm, ITV, have since been transferred and the company was not an active media organisation.

site_title: Air taxi maker races to serve Paris Olympics as sector struggles for funds
summary: Volocopter, a flying taxi maker, is racing to demonstrate its readiness to serve passengers at the 2024 Paris Olympics, amid a challenging funding environment for the electric vertical takeoff and landing (eVTOL) sector. The company, which aims to be the first to receive certification, is working to overcome regulatory hurdles and convince investors of the safety and viability of air taxis. Success could boost the sector by persuading risk-averse investors to invest, but analysts warn that hundreds of other players could struggle or fold if the current investment climate continues.

site_title: HK stock exchange's yuan stock trading debut gets lukewarm trade volume
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange, HKEX, debuted yuan-denominated trading on Monday, but saw a lukewarm response with HK$177 million worth of yuan shares traded, compared to HK$25 billion in Hong Kong-dollar shares. The top three yuan counters, CNOOC, China Mobile, and Geely Auto, were the most actively traded, bucking the downward trend of the Hang Seng Index. The HKEX is working with Chinese regulators to allow mainland investors to participate in the yuan-counter service, which could increase trading volume.

images.alt_text: Signage for Hong Kong Stock Exchanges and Clearing Ltd. (HKEx) during the listing ceremony of ZJLD Group Inc. at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in Hong Kong, China, on Thursday, April 27, 2023. Shares of Chinese liquor company ZJLD tumbled on their debut in Hong Kong on Thursday following what was the Asian financial hub’s biggest initial public offering this year. Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

site_title: UK mortgage rate hits 6% for first time this year in fresh pain
summary: The UK mortgage rate has reached 6.01% for the first time this year, following a triple whammy of pricey borrowing, economic uncertainty, and the worst cost-of-living crisis in a generation. This marks a 14-year high, with the average two-year fixed-rate home loan and five-year fixed-rate deal also increasing. The move is expected to intensify the squeeze on finances for thousands of British homeowners, with some major lenders temporarily pulling products from the market due to rising bond yields.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Civil servants in Singapore will receive a 0.3-month mid-year bonus, with junior officers set to get an additional one-time payment of up to S$400. The Public Service Division consulted with public sector unions before making the announcement.

site_title: Gold miner Amman Mineral raises US$715 million in Jakarta’s top 2023 IPO, sources say
summary: Amman Mineral, Indonesia's second-largest gold and copper mine, raised approximately US$715 million in its initial public offering (IPO) in Jakarta, surpassing the largest IPO in Asia outside mainland China this year. The IPO, which sold 6.33 billion shares at 1,695 rupiah each, is the largest in Indonesia since GoTo Group in 2022. The company's proceeds will be used for working capital, debt repayment, and refinery projects.

images.alt_text: PalmCo has a total of 560.078 hectares of oil palm plantations in Indonesia, according to its website.

site_title: Polestar partners with Geely’s Meizu to build Chinese operating system
summary: Polestar, a Swedish electric vehicle maker, has partnered with Geely's Meizu to develop a Chinese operating system for its cars sold in China, offering the latest smart technologies. The joint venture, with Polestar owning 49% and Meizu 51%, will integrate the Flyme Auto system into its vehicles. Polestar CEO Thomas Ingenlath expects the new software to be quickly integrated, while the Google Auto system for international markets will remain unchanged, aiming to compete with Chinese EV makers offering lower prices and smart technologies.

site_title: McDonald’s Japan hikes prices in city centres as costs bite
summary: McDonald's Japan is raising prices at 184 city centre branches, equivalent to about 6% of its 3,000 stores, to absorb higher rents and labour costs. The price hikes will range from 10 to 90 yen per item or set, with the delivery price of a Big Mac increasing to 590 yen from 540 yen. This is the third price increase for McDonald's in Japan since March 2022. The move comes as businesses pass on higher costs of imported energy and raw materials to consumers.

site_title: Bank of England launches first sector-wide 'stress test'
summary: The Bank of England has launched its first system-wide "stress test" to evaluate how big banks, insurers, clearing houses, and investment funds collectively behave during extreme market stresses. The test, expected to be completed next year, aims to provide valuable insight into the system-wide dynamics following a severe but plausible stress to financial markets. This marks the first time the BOE has conducted a sector-wide test, building on previous separate stress tests of banks and insurers.

images.alt_text: Mortgage borrowers already are hurting from the 12 rate rises the BOE has delivered since 2021, putting the benchmark lending rate at its highest since 2008.

site_title: Commercial aircraft fleet to grow 3.3% annually over the next decade: report
summary: The global commercial aircraft fleet is expected to grow 3.3% annually over the next decade, reaching 42,000 aircraft, driven by strong demand for narrow-body jets, particularly Boeing's 737 Max and Airbus' A320neo aircraft. The narrow-body segment is projected to increase its market share to 69% by 2033, while wide-body jets will grow at a slower 1.8% annually. Aircraft production rates have been increasing slowly due to labor and parts shortages, leading airlines to place orders to secure production slots.

images.alt_text: Boeing estimates that 48,575 planes will be in service in 2042, compared with 24,500 last year. This will require producing, across all manufacturers combined, 42,595 planes – half to replace existing aircraft, and the other half to account for growth.
FILE PHOTO: A logo of Airbus is seen at Airbus headquarters in Blagnac, near Toulouse, France February 14, 2019. REUTERS/Regis Duvignau/File Photo

site_title: China’s maxed-out aluminium industry eyes future in Indonesia
summary: China's top aluminium producers are setting up smelters in Indonesia as the country's domestic capacity ceiling is reached. China aims to expand its aluminium output to 45 million tonnes annually, but its industry is expected to slow down. Indonesian authorities are encouraging foreign investment in the aluminium sector, with Chinese-backed plants already operational and more planned. However, analysts caution that Indonesia's reliance on coal-fired power and lack of demand drivers for aluminium may hinder its potential as a major aluminium hub.

images.alt_text: Bali reopens to international tourists, but flights have yet to catch up

site_title: Billionaires find big wins in big government
summary: Billionaires worldwide saw a slight decline in numbers and wealth from pandemic peaks, but still hold a significant amount, with over 2,500 billionaires worth over $12 trillion. Despite this, their wealth remains concentrated in a few countries, particularly those with deep socialist roots, including France, Sweden, and Russia. In France, billionaire wealth has nearly doubled to 21% of GDP, largely due to inherited fortunes. The analysis suggests that socialist tendencies may backfire by concentrating wealth, rather than spreading it, and increasing regulation may favor big tycoons.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk has gained more than US$55.3 billion this year, largely due to Tesla.
Coinbase CEO Brian Armstrong’s net worth has slumped by US$361 million to US$2.2 billion.
George Soros said he previously didn’t want his Open Society Foundations (OSF) to be taken over by one of his five children.

site_title: Hot stock: Ho Bee Land has no explanation for spikes in share price, volume
summary: Ho Bee Land's shares surged 19.4% to a six-month high, with over 343,700 shares traded, exceeding its average volume of 48,169. The developer has no explanation for the price increase, stating it is unaware of any information not previously announced. The shares ended at S$2.32, 12.6% higher than Friday's closing price, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Cautious trading for Singapore stocks on Monday; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks ended lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.6% or 18.86 points to 3,241.17. Investors traded cautiously amid an uncertain economic outlook, with a downgrade in China's GDP expectations and a wide disparity between the US Federal Reserve and markets' forward inflation expectations driving the decline. The Hang Seng Index, Nikkei 225, and Kospi Composite Index also fell, while Singapore Airlines and Top Glove were among the top-traded counters.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 57 to 46 at the opening.
FOMC meeting participants are now projecting US GDP growth of 1 per cent for 2023, up from 0.4 per cent back in March.

site_title: Sats appoints former Amazon Singapore country manager as COO
summary: SATS has appointed Henry Low Eng Kiat as its Chief Operating Officer (COO), effective July 1. Low, 48, will oversee technology, data and analytics, operational excellence, safety and risk management, and integration management. He previously held roles at Amazon, including country manager for Amazon Singapore, and joined SATS in 2022.

site_title: Goldman Sachs cuts China GDP forecast on limited stimulus space
summary: Goldman Sachs has cut its forecast for China's GDP growth to 5.4% from 6% due to limited options to boost stimulus. The bank's analysts cite a weakening recovery, elevated debt levels, and President Xi Jinping's call for curbing property speculation as reasons for the downgrade. Any upcoming policy easing is likely to be "targeted and moderate," with a focus on infrastructure and property stimulus, but not exceeding previous measures.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: (L-R) The Hong Kong Exchanges flag, Chinese national flag and Hong Kong flag are hoisted outside the Hong Kong Stocks Exchange in Hong Kong June 7, 2016.  REUTERS/Bobby Yip/File Photo                         GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD - SEARCH GLOBAL BUSINESS 8 MAY FOR ALL IMAGES

The policymakers agree to introduce measures to expedite the introduction of specific policies to promote the development of venture capital funds, provide more support to technology startups and to introduce measures against illegal financing.

site_title: Airbus agrees to US$6.7 billion helicopter pact with Saudi Arabia
summary: Airbus has agreed to a US$6.7 billion investment pact with Saudi Arabia to develop a helicopter manufacturing facility, with construction expected to begin early next year. The plant, in partnership with Scopa Industries, will produce up to 100 military and civilian helicopters by the end of the decade. The move is part of Crown Prince Mohammed Salman's plan to diversify Saudi Arabia's oil-dependent economy, aiming to spend half of the kingdom's military expenditure locally by 2030. This will be Airbus's first helicopter facility in the region, with potential for future exports to the Middle East.

site_title: Mitigating conflicts of interest in financial advisory
summary: Financial institutions and their representatives are compensated in various ways, which can skew financial advice. Globally, institutions are commission-based, fee-based, or fee-only, while representatives may also receive a salary. This compensation structure can lead to conflicts of interest, where advisers prioritize their own interests over those of their clients. A 20-year review of the author's practice and experience from different countries has led to a greater understanding of the implications of these compensation models, emphasizing the need for consumers to be aware of these factors when seeking financial advice.

images.alt_text: Planning your legacy involves not just financial provision for your heirs, but also the ensuring family harmony and cohesion last for generations.

site_title: Where housing prices have crashed and billions in wealth have vanished
summary: New Zealand's housing market has crashed, with prices plummeting 17.5% since November 2021, erasing over $6 billion in household wealth. The crisis, triggered by soaring mortgage rates and a post-pandemic surge in prices, has left many homeowners and investors struggling to sell their properties. The median home price is around $480,000, making it one of the least affordable in the world. The government faces increasing pressure to address the housing shortage, with calls for policy fixes growing urgent. The country is set to hold national elections this year, with the housing crisis expected to be a major issue.

images.alt_text: New Zealand has one of the highest house-price-to-income ratios in the world.

site_title: B Lab, Centre for Impact Investing and Practices to accelerate growth of B Corp movement in Asia
summary: B Lab Global and the Centre for Impact Investing and Practices (CIIP) have launched the B Lab & CIIP Centre for Excellence for Asia to accelerate the growth of the B Corporation movement in the region. The centre will provide training and accreditation programs for Asian businesses using B Lab's standards for B Corp certification. Led by B Lab Global's Eleanor Allen, the centre aims to harness the Asian economy's momentum to further promote business as a force for good, and will develop research, workshops, and collaborative programs with academic institutions to support enterprises on their impact journeys.

images.alt_text: B Lab Global's Eleanor Allen says the controversy surrounding Nespresso's B Corp certification has taught her and her team the importance of having both big and small companies on board, and getting them to accept each other into the community.

site_title: China approves first share sale by developer since ban lifted
summary: China's securities watchdog approved the first onshore share sale by a real estate developer since rules were eased in November. China Merchants Shekou Industrial Zone Holdings plans to raise up to 8.5 billion yuan (S$1.6 billion) in a private placement to fund existing projects and debt repayment. The approval marks a revival of a major fundraising channel for the struggling housing market, which is facing renewed downward pressure after a brief rebound earlier this year.

images.alt_text: The weakening sentiment in China’s real estate sector is prompting policymakers to weigh new support measures to keep the economy afloat.

The policymakers agree to introduce measures to expedite the introduction of specific policies to promote the development of venture capital funds, provide more support to technology startups and to introduce measures against illegal financing.

site_title: Carsome’s cash position at US$200 million after funding round
summary: Carsome, a car e-commerce platform, has secured US$200 million in funding after a recent round, bolstering its liquidity position to approximately US$200 million. The funding includes participation from existing investors and new investors like EvolutionX Debt Capital, which provided a long-term debt facility. The company's co-founder and CEO Eric Cheng stated that the funding places Carsome on solid footing to deliver the world's first integrated car ownership ecosystem. This funding follows a 250% revenue growth last year to US$1.5 billion, with operational profitability achieved in the first quarter of 2023.

images.alt_text: Carsome open to other strategic M&A deals beyond privatising iCar for US$200m
Carro and Carsome: Valuations run fast and furious, but true test lies in fintech
Carsome guns for US IPO after raising US$170m funding at US$1.3b valuation

site_title: Hong Kong unemployment unchanged as economy improves
summary: Hong Kong's unemployment rate remains unchanged at 3% in May, mirroring the February-April period, despite an improving economy. Economic growth rebounded in the first quarter as borders reopened and consumer spending increased. The city is facing labour shortages in some industries, prompting the relaxation of entry rules to bring in 27,000 foreign workers. Economists have upgraded their growth forecasts for Hong Kong, expecting a 4.6% growth rate this year, up from a previous estimate of 3.4%.

images.alt_text: People and mainland tourists walks along the promenade next to Victoria Harbour in Hong Kong on May 11, 2023. (Photo by ISAAC LAWRENCE / AFP)

site_title: Chinese premier in Germany as Western mistrust mounts
summary: Chinese Premier Li Qiang is visiting Germany and France, amid growing Western mistrust of China's policies on Russia, trade, and human rights. Li's two-nation tour includes "government consultations" with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz and a financing summit in France, where Beijing hopes to deepen relations with the EU. However, Germany's national security strategy has criticized China for acting against its interests, and Beijing has warned that viewing it as a rival will lead to division and confrontation. The visit comes as China faces an economic slowdown and intensifying diplomatic pressure from the West.

images.alt_text: Macron’s Summit for a New Global Financing Pact aims to change the way that multilateral institutions work to better support poor nations and address threats like climate change and future pandemics.
May data released last week showed the recovery was weakening.
China’s top graft-busting watchdog earlier this year vowed to eliminate ideas of a Western-style “financial elite” and rectify the hedonism of excessive pursuit of “high-end taste”.
The weakening sentiment in China’s real estate sector is prompting policymakers to weigh new support measures to keep the economy afloat.

site_title: Sweden’s property crunch worsens as another firm cut to junk
summary: Sweden's property sector faces another blow as Stockholm-based FastPartner was downgraded to junk status by Moody's Investors Service, with a possible further downgrade if the company fails to shore up its finances. The rating cut reflects rapid interest rate increases and challenging capital markets. FastPartner's shares fell 6.6% and its floating-rate notes were marked down at a bid price of 91.9. The downgrade exacerbates a financing crunch in Sweden's real estate market, seen as a canary in the coal mine for Europe's industry.

images.alt_text: The old town of Gamla Stan in Stockholm. Swedish public housing is carefully conceptualised to be spacious and have leisure spaces such as playgrounds.

site_title: Indonesia, SpaceX launch satellite to boost Internet connectivity
summary: Indonesia and SpaceX launched the 4.5-tonne Satellite of the Republic of Indonesia (Satria-1) into orbit from Florida, aiming to boost internet connectivity in remote areas. The $540 million project will provide internet access to 50,000 public service points and 150 gigabytes per second, covering the eastern Papua region. The satellite is Indonesia's first government-owned multi-function satellite with the biggest capacity in Asia, set to accelerate internet access to villages in the next 10 years.

site_title: Dubai chases long-term growth as property booms, seeks to blunt debt risk
summary: Dubai is shifting its economic focus from property investment and tourism to long-term growth, aiming to avoid past debt crises. The city-state is attracting foreign capital and people, with property booming due to Russian demand amid the Ukraine war and relaxed residency rules. Analysts note that this time, there are more guardrails in place to prevent a repeat of the 2008 global credit crunch, which subdued Dubai's global ambitions.

images.alt_text: The mansion's other amenities include a 15-car garage, indoor and outdoor pools, two domes, a 70,000-litre coral reef aquarium, a power substation and panic rooms.

site_title: China bankers told to shun flashy clothes, 5-star hotels in austerity drive
summary: China's top graft-busting watchdog has launched an austerity drive in the financial sector, urging state-owned and private financial firms to cut salaries, bonuses, and luxury expenses to eliminate the "financial elite" and rectify excessive lifestyles. Measures include staff being asked not to wear expensive clothes or carry luxury bags, refrain from posting pictures of high-end lifestyles on social media, and stay at 5-star hotels. The drive aims to bridge the wealth gap and promote "common prosperity" under President Xi Jinping's leadership, as the country's economy weakens and youth unemployment hits a record high.

images.alt_text: The weakening sentiment in China’s real estate sector is prompting policymakers to weigh new support measures to keep the economy afloat.

site_title: Macron gathers global leaders seeking elusive deal on lending
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron is hosting a summit in Paris to address global lending and financing issues, seeking to overhaul the global lending architecture to better support poor nations and address climate change and pandemics. The summit aims to reform international development banks, mobilize capital for countries vulnerable to extreme weather patterns, and provide debt relief to nations like Zambia and Sri Lanka. The event brings together major wealthy creditor nations, low-income countries, and heads of multilateral institutions like the IMF and World Bank, with the goal of producing a "to-do" list of targets and a timetable for achieving progress on key issues.

images.alt_text: Tesla CEO Elon Musk meets with France's President Emmanuel Macron (left) at the Elysee presidential palace in Paris, May 15, 2023. Musk will meet Macron on Friday for the second time in just over a month.
Bruno Le Maire, France's finance minister, meets employees on a production line at the inauguration of the Automotive Cells Company (ACC) gigafactory in Douvrin, France, on Tuesday (May 30).

site_title: Singtel, Ocean Network Express pledge S$1 million each to NParks initiative
summary: Singtel and Ocean Network Express have pledged S$1 million each to support the National Parks Board's Garden City Fund, a registered charity and institution of public character. The donations will fund enhancement works at the Sisters' Islands Marine Park, including a new tidal pool and Ocean Network Express Coastal Forest Trail. The projects aim to promote coastal conservation and marine biodiversity, with the tidal pool supporting seawater retention and habitat re-establishment, and the forest trail promoting critically endangered coastal species planting. The projects will open to the public in 2024.

images.alt_text: From left: Prof Leo Tan, chairman of Garden City Fund,  Kenneth Er, CEO of NParks, Helen Wong, group CEO of OCBC and Desmond Lee, Minister for National Development & Minister-in-charge of Social Services Integration.
Aramco cleans up Bendera Bay
Bill Winters (second from left) and Patrick Lee (third from left), with Standard Chartered Bank's staff volunteers at Mandai Wildlife Reserve

site_title: Berkshire Hathaway adds to Japan trading company holdings
summary: Billionaire investor Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has added to its stakes in Japan's five largest trading companies, increasing its holdings to over 8.5% across the companies. This move highlights the improving economic conditions and shareholder-friendly corporate governance reforms in Japan, contributing to the Nikkei share average's 28% rise this year. The aggregate value of the investments now stands as the largest of any Berkshire-held public stocks outside the US, with individual stocks up over 30% this year.

images.alt_text: Warren Buffett, chairman and chief executive officer of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., speaks at the Goldman Sachs 10,000 Small Businesses Summit in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Tuesday, Feb. 13, 2018. Goldman's 10,000 Small Businesses is an investment that brings economic opportunity and assists entrepreneurs to create jobs by providing better access to education, capital and business support services. Photographer: Andrew Harrer/Bloomberg

site_title: Malaysia to ease IPO rules this year to lure investors
summary: Malaysia plans to ease IPO rules this year to attract investors, with the goal of 39 new listings valued at RM10 billion. The government will expedite the IPO process and reduce stamp duty charges for shares traded on Bursa Malaysia, aiming to make the market more competitive and attractive. Additionally, the government is looking at policies to attract family offices and improve ease of conducting business, with the aim of boosting greater trading participation and access to financing.

images.alt_text: Analysts said the changing sentiment in local markets and recent developments surrounding domestic issues led to outflows of foreign funds, causing the ringgit to weaken further.

site_title: China’s economy is on course for a ‘double dip’
summary: China's economy is experiencing a slowdown, with retail sales, investment, and property sales falling short of expectations in April and May. The government's growth target for this year, around 5%, is at risk, with some economists predicting no growth in the second quarter. The property market is a key contributor to the slowdown, with prices declining and sales falling to 70% of their 2019 level. The central bank has taken steps to ease monetary policy, and some economists expect further interest rate cuts. However, others warn that monetary easing may not be enough, and the government may need to explore fiscal stimulus to support the economy.

images.alt_text: A Tiffany & Co. store in Shanghai, China on Wednesday, June 14, 2023. China's central bank ramped up its monetary stimulus to help spur the economy amid signs of a weakening property market, a slump in business investment and record joblessness among young people. Photographer: Raul Ariano/Bloomberg

site_title: Indonesia’s President Joko Widodo hosts Japanese Emperor Naruhito
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo welcomed Japanese Emperor Naruhito and Empress Masako on their June 17-23 visit to Indonesia, the country's largest economy. The visit followed a trip to Tokyo last year where Widodo invited the emperor. The royal couple was greeted with a presidential palace visit, well-wishers, and a marching band playing the Japanese national anthem. The meeting marked Naruhito's first state trip since ascending the Chrysanthemum Throne in 2019.

images.alt_text: Companies in power generation will become the first to trade in the exchange, while those in other sectors are under assessment to get onboard.
The resource-rich country last year saw exports jump to a historic high on rising global commodity prices.

site_title: China seen cutting key lending benchmarks as economy slows
summary: China is expected to cut key lending benchmarks, including the one-year loan prime rate (LPR) and five-year tenor, for the first time in 10 months, as the country's economy slows down. The cuts are aimed at shoring up a struggling recovery, with recent data showing the retail and factory sectors struggling to sustain momentum. Analysts predict cuts ranging from 5 to 15 basis points to the LPR and up to 15 basis points to the five-year tenor, with some expecting deeper cuts to stimulate the housing market and prop up the property sector.

images.alt_text: China’s residential property market is facing renewed downward pressure after a brief rebound earlier this year.
China’s top graft-busting watchdog earlier this year vowed to eliminate ideas of a Western-style “financial elite” and rectify the hedonism of excessive pursuit of “high-end taste”.
The weakening sentiment in China’s real estate sector is prompting policymakers to weigh new support measures to keep the economy afloat.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank positive on GoTo’s financial outlook; initiates with ‘buy’
summary: Maybank Securities has initiated coverage on GoTo Group with a "buy" call and a target price of 153 rupiah, optimistic about the Indonesian tech giant's growth outlook and market leadership. The research house expects GoTo's adjusted Ebitda to turn positive by FY2024, driven by higher net take rates, lower marketing expenses, and operational efficiencies. A potential upside of 30.8% from the current trading price is estimated, with an enterprise value-to-sales ratio of 5.6 times.

images.alt_text: Newly appointed CEO of GoTo Patrick Walujo is also the co-founder of private equity firm Northstar Group, one of the earliest investors of Gojek.

Sugito Walujo, often known as Patrick Walujo, founded private equity firm Northstar Group in 2003. His firm was one of the earliest backers of ride-hailing giant Gojek, which merged with Tokopedia to form GoTo.

site_title: Bank of Korea flags upward risks to core inflation
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, has raised concerns about upward risks to core inflation, citing strong consumption and employment trends. Core inflation, which remained higher than headline inflation, is easing at a slower pace due to sticky service prices. The bank expects core prices to rise 3.3% this year and overall consumer prices to rise 3.5%. The prospect of higher inflation lasting longer than expected has led the Bank of Korea to flag upward risks to core inflation as "a little high."

images.alt_text: The enlarged plenary meeting of the Central Committee of the ruling Workers’ Party of Korea opened on Friday and plans to also review the country’s economic projects during the first half of this year, says KCNA.
South Korea’s seasonally adjusted unemployment rate has fallen to 2.5 per cent in May, the lowest since the data series began in June 1999, according to Statistics Korea.

site_title: Xi, Blinken agree to stabilise US-China relations in rare Beijing talks
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping and US Secretary of State Antony Blinken agreed to stabilize their intense rivalry during a rare visit to Beijing, but no major breakthroughs were announced. The two sides reached an agreement on specific issues and discussed contentious topics such as Taiwan, with Xi urging the US not to "hurt China's legitimate rights and interests." Blinken emphasized the importance of open communication channels to manage competition and hinted at future senior US officials visiting China. The talks aimed to stabilize US-China relations ahead of a potential summit between Xi and US President Joe Biden later this year.

images.alt_text: “Intense competition requires sustained diplomacy to ensure that competition does not veer into confrontation or conflict,” says US Secretary of State Anthony Blinken (right) at a briefing alongside Singapore Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan.

site_title: Cathay Pacific to hire more cabin crew from mainland China
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways plans to hire more cabin crew from mainland China, starting the recruitment process in July, to cater to the growing number of Mandarin-speaking customers. The move comes after the airline fired three cabin crew members for disparaging passengers who didn't speak English. CEO Ronald Lam stated that the airline's cabin crew community will remain predominantly Hong Kong employees, with additional training starting next month to refresh their skills and provide consistent service to all customers.

images.alt_text: Cathay does not expect to return to pre-Covid passenger capacity until the end of next year.
Cathay Pacific Airways says it won’t need to utilise a government HK$7.8 billion bridge loan that’s due to expire later this week.

site_title: Asia: Markets fail to build on rally with eye on China policy
summary: Asia's stock markets fell on Monday, despite a rally last week, as traders turned cautious ahead of China's potential economic stimulus measures. The Federal Reserve's decision to pause rate hikes and Beijing's borrowing cost cut boosted sentiment, but officials have yet to make any announcements. Analysts expect policy stimulus to help the struggling property sector and consumer activity, but warn that the global economy's challenges remain. The Tokyo market eked out a small gain, while Hong Kong, Shanghai, and other markets fell, with hopes for a thaw in China-US relations also providing some support.

images.alt_text: Tokyo markets struggled on a stronger yen, even as the Bank of Japan on Friday stood pat on its ultra-loose monetary policy.

site_title: Japan regulator sounded out top domestic banks about China risks, sources say
summary: Japan's financial regulator has sounded out top domestic banks about China risks and whether they have plans in place if Sino-Western tensions escalate. The Financial Services Agency (FSA) requested insights and information from Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, and Mizuho Financial Group, which have a combined US$6.5 trillion in assets. The move comes amid increased tensions between China and Western allies, including the US, over issues such as Taiwan's political status and technology access. The regulator aims to ensure the banks are prepared to respond if the geopolitical situation worsens.

images.alt_text: Profit is expected to rise to 841.6 billion yen at number two lender Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, which will also be an all-time high.

site_title: JD sees seven units worth US$14 billion each after mega sales haul
summary: JD.com achieved a record-breaking sales haul during its "6.18" June online event, reaching an all-time high. The company aims to create seven listed firms with market values of at least $14 billion each, outlining aggressive targets spanning two decades. JD's core e-commerce business is expected to accelerate this quarter, and the company plans to pay out over $3 trillion in salaries and benefits for frontline staff over the next two decades.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People pass a JD Sports store in London, Britain April 11, 2017.  Shares in Britain's JD Sports Fashion Plc climbed to a record high after strong demand for leisure clothing helped to drive a 55 percent rise in headline annual pretax profit, its biggest increase in eight years REUTERS/Neil Hall/File Photo

site_title: Thais host Myanmar junta official for talks; key Asean members stay away
summary: Thailand hosts talks with Myanmar's junta-appointed foreign minister Than Swe, as part of a proposal to "fully re-engage Myanmar at the leaders' level" within the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean). However, key Asean members including Indonesia, Malaysia, and Cambodia have declined to attend or sent junior officials, citing a lack of consensus and criticism of the gathering as undermining regional unity. The talks come as Myanmar's military leaders face international condemnation and sanctions for their actions.

images.alt_text: Thailand’s foreign ministry is tight-lipped about exactly who is attending the hastily called two-day gathering, for which outgoing Foreign Minister Don Pramudwinai sent invitation letters just four days before its planned start.

st(FILES) In this file photo taken on February 15, 2021 a banner featuring Aung San Suu Kyi is displayed as protesters take part in a demonstration against the military coup in front of the National League for Democracy (NLD) office in Yangon. - Myanmar's junta-stacked election commission announced on March 28, 2023 that Aung San Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy Party would be dissolved for failing to re-register under a tough new military-drafted electoral law, state media said. (Photo by AFP)

site_title: Philippines’ easing inflation a ‘good reason’ to pause on rate hikes
summary: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) governor, Felipe Medalla, stated that the Philippines' easing inflation to below 4% by year-end provides a "good reason" to pause rate hikes. The BSP kept its benchmark interest rate steady at 6.25% following a series of rate hikes, and annual headline inflation slowed for a fourth consecutive month in May to 6.1%. This easing inflation is seen as a positive development, as it brings the January-May average to 7.5%, still within the central bank's 2-4% target range.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH downgrades SIA to ‘sell’ despite raising target price on higher valuation
summary: UOB Kay Hian downgraded its call on Singapore Airlines (SIA) from "hold" to "sell" due to the stock's "very lofty" valuation. Analyst Roy Chen noted that SIA's price-to-book ratio is 1.58 times, a 10-year high and 2.8 standard deviations above its historical mean. Despite the downgrade, Chen raised the target price to S$7.07, citing expected earnings growth and strong operational data. Chen forecasts SIA's Q1 2024 net profit to be between S$600 million and S$700 million.

images.alt_text: The counter saw 17.8 million shares change hands at the time. No married deals were recorded, according to data platform ShareInvestor.
OCBC cautions that much of SIA’s recovery has already been priced in its stock due to its first-mover advantage.
OCBC has up SIA's fair value to S$7.18 to factor in slower pace of passenger yields in FY2024.

site_title: BTS’ Suga’s D-Day arrives in Singapore with much fanfare
summary: BTS rapper and producer Suga's solo tour finally arrived in Singapore after over 120 days, with three sold-out shows at the Singapore Indoor Stadium. The concert marked his return to the city-state after more than four years, featuring songs from his solo albums and BTS' discography. Despite initially feeling lonely onstage without fellow members, Suga was met with a loud and enthusiastic crowd, showcasing his musicality and solidifying his connection with fans. The tour is the first solo outing for a BTS member and marks the final stop before encore shows in Seoul.

images.alt_text: (From left) Blackpink's Jisoo, Jennie, Lisa and Rose have played to sold-out stadiums and arenas during their Born Pink world tour.
Shares in Unusual have steadily risen since April, with a jump of over 10 per cent in May. The company cited the overwhelming response for Jacky Cheung’s concerts as a reason for the rise.

site_title: Spain snatch Nations League glory on penalties against Croatia
summary: Spain won the UEFA Nations League final against Croatia with a 5-4 penalty shootout victory after a 0-0 match in extra time. Real Madrid defender Dani Carvajal scored the winning Panenka penalty, while Spain goalkeeper Unai Simon denied two Croatian penalties. The win marks Spain's first major trophy since Euro 2012 and avenges their 2021 final defeat by France.

images.alt_text: Fans in the football-mad country receive bad news that Messi would not play.
Manchester United is widely seen as one of the most prized assets in all of sport.
Japan is the last major country where broadcasting rights remain unclaimed after Fifa reached an agreement on rights for five European countries on Wednesday (Jun 14).

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Samudera, Top Glove, Amara
summary: Singapore Airlines shares closed 1.8% down at S$7.77 on Friday, ending a 12-day winning streak, amid refuted claims of raising its stake in Air India. Samudera Shipping Line purchased two container vessels for US$59.9 million, with no expected impact on net tangible assets and earnings per share. Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weigh market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions.

site_title: Gold flat on dollar strength, traders assess hawkish US Fed remarks
summary: Gold prices remained flat at $1,956.93 per ounce as the dollar strengthened, making bullion less appealing for buyers holding other currencies. The US Federal Reserve's hawkish tone on interest rates weighed on gold prices, increasing the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion. Despite being considered a hedge against inflation, gold's value was largely unaffected by the recent interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The gold price peaked at US$2,039 on March 8 this year after the US announced an import ban on Russian oil followed by the escalation of Russia-Ukraine tension, but the uptrend did not lasted long after a series of interest rate hike by Fed.

site_title: Why my bearishness has been wrong so far
summary: The US economy's resilience, driven by pent-up demand and savings accumulated during the pandemic, has supported corporate earnings and the S&P 500 index, which is up 23.3% from its October 2022 low. However, unresolved inflationary pressures and the Federal Reserve's pause on rate hikes may complicate market navigation. FOMC meeting participants now project 1% US GDP growth for 2023, up from 0.4% in March, and expect two further 25-basis-point rate hikes this year to curb inflation. This economic resilience could lead to a soft landing for the US economy, but may require tighter monetary policy.

images.alt_text: If the Fed has done enough to address inflation, it could mean economic growth is about to slow and unemployment rise.
What the recent bank turmoil could mean for the direction of interest rates.
The Fed and other major central banks are intent on fighting inflation

site_title: Supply is ample, yet there is value in Singapore property
summary: Singapore's housing market remains strong despite concerns over limited land supply, thanks to the government's efforts to optimize land use. The country's ample supply of land and constant construction projects ensure that demand is met, albeit with a time lag. New homes will be built on previously undeveloped sites, such as the Old Police Academy and the former Keppel Club, with estimates suggesting 20,000 to 40,000 new homes could be developed from the 120-hectare site in Kranji. The government's proactive approach to land allocation and development helps maintain social cohesion and supports the country's strong "work, live and play" destination reputation.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Turf Club's current site in Kranji will be returned to the government by March 2027 to make way for housing and other developments in the area.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Monday; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.4% to 3,247.59. Losers outnumbered gainers 57 to 46 in the broader market, with key local banks opening lower. The US indices also closed lower, with the S&P 500 down 0.4%, Dow Jones down 0.3%, and Nasdaq Composite down 0.7%. The mixed global market trend was attributed to the interest-rate hike pause by the central bank.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines shares closed 1.8 per cent down at S$7.77, ending its 12-day winning streak.

site_title: Verstappen takes Red Bull’s 100th win in Formula One
summary: Max Verstappen won the Canadian Grand Prix from pole position, leading every lap and securing his 41st career win. This milestone victory marked Red Bull's 100th Formula One win, surpassing the team's record books alongside Ayrton Senna. Verstappen extended his championship lead, finishing 9.5 seconds ahead of second-place Fernando Alonso. Lewis Hamilton finished third for Mercedes, while Sergio Perez secured a sixth-place finish for Red Bull.

site_title: Billionaire Forrest ‘can’t wait forever’ for US$80 billion Congo hydro deal
summary: Australian billionaire Andrew Forrest warned that he cannot wait "forever" to seal a deal with the Democratic Republic of Congo for a US$80 billion hydropower and green hydrogen project. The proposed Grand Inga project would generate 40 gigawatts of power, equivalent to a quarter of Africa's total current capacity. Forrest said he needs a deal by 2023 or Fortescue could walk away, and any partners must agree to not ship in labor to build the project. The project aims to boost access to power in sub-Saharan Africa and produce green hydrogen for domestic use and export.

site_title: AstraZeneca planning China business spinoff: FT
summary: AstraZeneca is planning to spin off its China business, with listing a separate unit in Hong Kong considered an option, according to a Financial Times report. The move aims to protect the company from tensions between China and other global powers while retaining control. The idea has been discussed for years but was recently sidelined due to a global biotech downturn. AstraZeneca's China business accounts for 13% of the company's total sales, making it the biggest drugmaker in China.

site_title: Oil prices come off earlier gains as banks cut China growth forecasts
summary: Global oil prices fell on Monday, reversing gains from last week. Brent crude lost 68 cents to $75.93 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude lost 59 cents to $71.19. The decline was attributed to concerns over China's slowing economy, outweighing Opec+ output cuts and the drop in US oil rigs. Last week, Brent posted a 2.4% gain, and WTI rose 2.3%. The decrease in oil prices was seen as a response to the uncertainty surrounding China's economic growth.

images.alt_text: While MTQ does not expect a return to the heyday of huge orders and high growth, it will focus on keeping utilisation high and opportunities in the Middle East, says group CEO Kuah Boon Wee.
Money managers have cut their net long US crude futures and options positions by 13,191 contracts to 73,273 in the week to Jun 13.
Brent futures rose US$2.47, or 3.4 per cent, to settle at US$75.67 a barrel on Thursday.

site_title: Bangladesh finally floats currency to unlock more IMF funds
summary: Bangladesh's central bank has finally allowed the currency to float freely, giving the country access to more IMF funds. This move is aimed at boosting economic growth to 7.5% for the next fiscal year and eventually graduating from being a least developed country. The new market-driven exchange rate regime is expected to provide greater transparency and efficiency in foreign exchange transactions, benefiting businesses, individuals, and the economy.

images.alt_text: Bangladesh is constructing the first of two nuclear power plants in collaboration with Russia’s state-owned atomic company Rosatom in a US$12.65 billion project

site_title: Oilfield equipment specialist MTQ zeroes in on Middle East for ‘steady growth’
summary: MTQ Corporation, an oilfield equipment specialist, expects steady growth in the Middle East, focusing on traditional energy and renewable opportunities. Despite not expecting a return to high growth, the company aims to maintain high utilisation rates. Its Bahrain segment recorded the highest annual revenues in over a decade, marking a promising trend.

site_title: Barclays ramps up lending to hedge funds, rich investors in Asia
summary: Barclays has ramped up lending to hedge funds and wealthy investors in Asia, with its prime financing business' share of overall Asian market revenue nearly doubling from a year ago. The bank's expansion aims to reduce reliance on volatile trading revenue and meet its pledge of a 10% return on tangible equity. Barclays has also bolstered its offerings in corporate derivatives and macro products, and hired new talent in Asia to grow its special situations structured credit and private lending business. The bank's head of markets, Hossein Zaimi, attributes the growth to an increasing appetite from Asia quantitative and multi-strategy hedge funds for prime financing.

The Italian loans are one of the final remaining parts of its retail business in the country.

site_title: No Signboard controlling shareholder requisitions EGM to remove directors amid legal dispute
summary: No Signboard Holdings, a Singapore-based restaurant operator, received a notice from its controlling shareholder GuGong to hold an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to remove at least five directors and appoint new ones. The move comes amid a legal dispute over a share consolidation and transfer of controlling interest passed at the company's annual general meeting in 2022. GuGong, controlled by executive chairman and CEO Lim Yong Sim, seeks to annul earlier resolutions and appoint a new board related to Lim. The company faces "serious financial challenges" and is seeking legal advice regarding the notice of requisition.

site_title: UK manufacturers lift 2023 outlook, boosted by aircraft and electronics
summary: UK manufacturers have revised their 2023 outlook, lifting expectations due to strong demand for aircraft and electronics. Make UK now expects factory output to fall 0.3% this year, a 0.2% improvement from its previous forecast. The group still expects 0.8% growth in 2024. Despite this, supply-chain pressures remain a concern, particularly for medium-sized firms. Order growth and hiring plans are modest, while difficulties in sourcing materials continue to affect the industry. The improved outlook aligns with a broader economy expected to grow 0.4% this year and 1.3% in 2024.

site_title: Surging mortgage rates bring early summer slowdown for UK housing market: Rightmove
summary: UK housing market slows in June due to surge in mortgage rates, marking the first decline in asking prices in six years. Average asking prices rose 0.6% over the previous decade for this time of year, but dropped £82 in June, the first monthly decline. Experts attribute the slowdown to mortgage market turmoil and expected further Bank of England interest rate increases, which could prompt buyers to pause.

site_title: China’s big-city homeowners cash out as wealth dream fades
summary: China's big-city homeowners are losing confidence in property as asking prices in Shanghai and other major cities have slumped for three straight months, with inventory reaching a record high. Transactions in the city have tanked by one-third, and homeowners are cutting prices to sell due to economic concerns and financing needs. Policymakers are considering new support measures to keep the economy afloat, but analysts predict a deeper-than-desired slump and a structural shift in China's real estate market due to its ageing population and limited urbanization.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China cut a key interest rate and injected US$33 billion into financial markets on Thursday, as data showed the world’s second-largest economy was flagging.
The property slump has broad ramifications for the economy.
Retail sales – a key gauge of consumer confidence – rose 12.7 per cent, missing forecasts of 13.6 per cent growth and slowing from April’s 18.4 per cent.

site_title: China’s plan to boost rural EV sales meets with sceptical buyers
summary: China's government launched a "Green Cars Going Rural" sales campaign to boost electric vehicle (EV) sales in rural areas, where EVs are underutilized due to high prices, limited charging infrastructure, and a lack of practical models. Despite the challenges, experts say rural areas are a natural market for EVs, with more standalone houses and lower operating costs. However, prices remain a significant barrier, with the cheapest EVs costing around 38,800 yuan. The government aims to increase EV penetration in rural areas to 40% of new car sales by 2025, in line with its goal of reaching net zero emissions by 2060.

site_title: Headwinds could continue to rattle Singapore market in H2 despite attractive valuations
summary: Singapore's stock market is expected to face headwinds in the second half of 2023, despite attractive valuations, due to concerns over high interest rates and an expected external slowdown. The banking sector has underperformed in the first half, contributing to the muted STI performance. Analysts predict uneven performance across sectors, with macroeconomic concerns remaining in focus.

site_title: Ermotti suggests ‘massive downsizing’ might come to Credit Suisse’s investment bank
summary: UBS CEO Sergio Ermotti suggests Credit Suisse's investment bank may undergo "massive downsizing" to reduce costs following the takeover. Ermotti notes that UBS implemented similar restructuring in his previous tenure, citing the need for a "prudent corporate culture" to reduce risks for the combined bank. The fate of Credit Suisse's Swiss business remains uncertain, with options including sale or spinoff on the table. A decision is expected in the third quarter of this year.

summary: Experts weigh in on whether to invest in China or India, citing China's economic force and India's fast-growing potential. The IMF forecasts China's GDP to grow faster than India's over the next decade. However, other factors such as long-term drivers and investment returns should be considered before making a decision. The conversation highlights the need for a balanced approach when investing in these emerging economies.

site_title: Trump criticised by Republican opponents over classified documents case
summary: Several top Republicans, including White House hopefuls Mike Pence and Asa Hutchinson, criticized Donald Trump's handling of classified information, following his 37-count indictment. Trump is accused of mishandling sensitive secrets and scheming to prevent investigators from recovering them. The criticism comes as Trump prepares for a potential 2024 presidential bid, with rivals plotting their paths to the election. Former Trump defense secretary Mark Esper also voiced harsh criticism of Trump's actions.

site_title: SVB Financial to sell SVB Securities to management team
summary: SVB Financial Group agreed to sell its investment banking business, SVB Securities, to the management team led by CEO Jeff Leerink. The deal involves a combination of cash, note repayment, liability assumption, and a 5% equity stake. The securities branch will be rebranded as Leerink Partners, with backing from The Baupost Group. The sale excludes MoffettNathanson, which will remain part of SVB Financial Group. A hearing to seek court approval is set for June 29.

site_title: Gold at pivotal crossroads with ambiguous Fed stance
summary: Gold prices have experienced a technical pullback after a 25% rally from November 2022, driven by the Fed's ambiguous stance on interest rates and dollar appeal. Despite potential long-term recession and economic meltdown, gold faces short-term bearish bias and faces a critical support level at $1,940. The Fed's projection of "higher for longer" rates increases the metal's opportunity cost, reducing demand as a hedge against inflation. A forecast of gold hovering at $2,000 per ounce is possible, but the looming recession and heightened US dollar appeal pose significant challenges to gold prices.

images.alt_text: US gold futures lost 0.7 per cent to US$1,954.50.

site_title: ‘The Flash’ dashes to box office win but stumbles short of estimates
summary: "The Flash" film opened at the top of the North American box office with US$55.1 million, but fell short of estimates. The animated film "Elemental" took the No. 2 spot, earning US$29.5 million. "Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse" rounded out the top five, bringing its total to over US$280 million domestically. The live-action "The Flash" was expected to earn more, with analysts calling its earnings "far below estimates".

site_title: Saudi wealth fund launches new firm to attract pharma investors
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) has launched a new entity, Lifera, to attract pharmaceutical and biotech companies to invest in drug manufacturing. The company aims to partner with local and international firms to develop life-saving medicines, including insulins, vaccines, and cell therapies. The move is part of the kingdom's efforts to diversify its economy away from oil sales, with the goal of becoming one of the world's top 15 economies by 2030. Lifera will enable the private sector to scale up, securing the supply of life-saving medicines and creating jobs.

Lead investors play a crucial role in ensuring problems are surfaced in a timely manner, providing guidance, and monitoring progress.
