(Photo by Sajjad HUSSAIN / AFP)

site_title: New Google lawsuit aims to curb fake business reviews
summary: Google has filed a lawsuit against Ethan QiQi Hu, a Los Angeles man, for creating hundreds of fake business listings on its platforms and selling them to real businesses to lure in customers. Hu allegedly used props to verify fake listings, bought thousands of fake positive reviews, and sold profiles to real businesses. Google claims Hu created over 350 false profiles with 14,000 illegitimate reviews, violating Google's terms of service and engaging in false advertising and unlawful business practices. Google seeks unspecified damages and a court order to block Hu's alleged misconduct.

images.alt_text: The company said that if a Google account had not been used or signed into for at least two years, it might delete the account and content across Google Workspace, which includes Gmail, Docs, Drive, Meet and Calendar as well as YouTube and Google Photos.
Tinder-owner Match Group and Indian startups ask the watchdog to investigate Google's new User Choice billing (UCB) system, alleging that it is anti-competitive.

site_title: North Korea starts key party meeting to discuss defence strategy: KCNA
summary: North Korea's Central Committee held an enlarged plenary meeting to discuss its diplomatic and defence strategy amid a "changed international situation". The meeting, attended by leader Kim Jong Un, also plans to review the country's economic projects. This comes after North Korea fired two short-range missiles off its east coast, following military drills by South Korean and US troops. The meeting is expected to last multiple days and will likely shape the country's defence strategy.

site_title: Meta's social media apps back up after outage
summary: Meta's social media apps, including Facebook and Instagram, experienced an outage affecting nearly 20,000 users, with issues also reported with WhatsApp and the Ads Manager. The outage was resolved over two hours after it began, with outage-tracking website Downdetector reporting less than 500 issues remaining by 6:30 pm ET.

site_title: CDL raises more than S$160,000 for Assisi Hospice
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) has raised over S$160,000 for Assisi Hospice at the Assisi Fun Day 2023, a fundraising event that attracted 10,000 visitors and raised over S$500,000. The event, co-organised with CDL, featured a charity segment - The CDL Challenge Bubble Soccer, which contributed S$130,000. The funds will support patients and their families at Assisi Hospice, with the goal of raising S$1 million.

images.alt_text: Data from the Singapore Police Force shows that the number of scam cases rose to 6,492 in 2022, up 42.7 per cent from 2021.

site_title: Why ‘workations’ are no substitute for a proper holiday
summary: The US summer holiday season is expected to see a record number of passengers, but many travelers will be on "workations" rather than traditional vacations, blurring the line between paid and unpaid leave. This trend is driven by cultural attitudes towards holidays, with Americans viewing vacations as a sign of weakness, and a desire for life-work balance. The rise of workations also reflects the ongoing debate over flexible working arrangements and the "right to disconnect" from work. Experts argue that while flexibility is necessary, it should not come at the cost of a clear boundary between work and personal life.

images.alt_text: A "Wall Street" sign near the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US on Thursday, March 23, 2023. Stocks struggled for direction as banks remained lower even after Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said in prepared remarks to lawmakers that the US is ready to take further measures to protect deposits, if needed. Photographer: Angus Mordant/Bloomberg
A good way of looking at trust is to identify green flags that signal the trustworthiness of a coworker or manager.
People who get stuck in a cycle of self-sabotage possess the promise of a bright future but ultimately hinder their own ability to thrive.

site_title: Britain faces recession, flood of job losses if rates hit 6%
summary: The UK economy is at risk of recession and job losses if interest rates reach 6%, according to economists. The Bank of England's benchmark lending rate has risen to its highest level since 2008, with mortgage costs and business loans increasing significantly. A recession could trigger a collapse in consumer spending, housing prices, and unemployment, with experts warning that the corporate sector is near a tipping point. The UK's growth prospects are also expected to slow, with living standards potentially slipping behind those of other G7 nations, as the government struggles to balance inflation control with economic impact.

images.alt_text: The BOE’s quarterly inflation attitudes survey showed expectations for inflation in the coming 12 months fell to 3.5 per cent from 3.9 per cent in February.

site_title: King Charles III saddles up for birthday parade
summary: King Charles III is set to participate in the Trooping the Colour ceremony, a traditional military parade marking the British sovereign's official birthday. The event, which began in 1748, will feature 1,400 soldiers, 400 musicians, and 200 horses, led by a 10-year-old shire mare named Juno. Charles, 74, will ride at the event for the first time since his mother Queen Elizabeth II in 1986, marking the start of his 74-year reign. The ceremony will be televised and includes a fly-past of 70 military aircraft and a 41-gun salute.

images.alt_text: Royal fans pose with a Union Jack flag depicting Britain's King Charles III  along the procession route, on The Mall, near to Buckingham Palace in central London.

site_title: Fed see key services inflation elevated with few signs of easing
summary: The US Federal Reserve's latest monetary policy report indicates that key services inflation remains elevated, with no signs of easing. The report suggests that the Fed's efforts to slow inflation may depend on a rise in US joblessness to ease tight labor market conditions. Labor demand has eased but continues to exceed available workers, with job vacancies still elevated. The report also notes that bank lending has tightened and is likely to contract further, despite the banking system remaining sound and resilient. The Fed has left its benchmark policy rate unchanged, but projections indicate possible interest rate hikes by year's end.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell speaks during a news conference following the Federal Open Market Committee meeting in Washington on Jun 14, 2023.
Fed officials have touted the annual stress tests as a measure of the health and resilience of the country’s biggest banks.
Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, speaks during a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting in Washington, DC, on June 14, 2023.
The US Fed kept interest rates unchanged, but said borrowing costs will likely rise by another half of a percentage point by the end of this year.

Federal Reserve Board Chairman Jerome Powell speaks during a news conference following the Federal Open Market Committee meeting, at the Federal Reserve in Washington, DC, on June 14, 2023. The US Federal Reserve voted on Wednesday to pause its aggressive campaign of interest rate hikes despite "elevated" inflation.

site_title: Gloom descends on Sunak as Johnson saga and rate hikes persist
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's team seeks to move on from the Boris Johnson saga and rising interest rates, which have brought a sense of gloom to Downing Street. A damning report found Johnson misled parliament over the "Partygate" scandal, while rising interest rates are causing turmoil in the mortgage market. The UK economy has also shrunk for the second month, dealing a fresh blow to Labour leader Keir Starmer. Despite Sunak's optimistic outlook, the government is facing mounting pressure over its handling of the economic situation and the ongoing fallout from the Johnson scandal.

images.alt_text: Boris Johnson (left) and Donald Trump have championed a similar style of politics.

site_title: Oil gains for the week as supply cuts balance demand concerns
summary: Oil prices rose for the week, driven by higher Chinese demand and Opec+ supply cuts, despite expected economic weakness and interest rate hikes. Brent crude gained 94 cents to $76.61 a barrel, while US WTI crude rose $1.16 to $71.78. Supply cuts by Opec and Saudi Arabia, combined with growing Chinese demand, lifted prices. Money managers cut their net long US crude futures and options positions by 13,191 contracts to 73,273.

images.alt_text: The rise in freight rates come ahead of higher crude demand in Asia in third quarter as refineries complete maintenance and ramp up output to meet peak summer fuel demand.

site_title: How ‘Transformers: Rise of the Beasts’ throws a 90s hip-hop party
summary: The film "Transformers: Rise of the Beasts" incorporates 1990s hip-hop into its soundtrack, giving it a unique sonic identity. Director Steven Caple Jr. drew inspiration from 90s New York City hip-hop to create a nostalgic and inclusive spin on the franchise. The film features period-accurate fashions, classic cars, and diegetic hip-hop tracks, including LL Cool J's "Mama Said Knock You Out" and Nas' original song "On My Soul." The soundtrack's blend of throwback and contemporary elements complements the film's globe-trotting action sequences, showcasing a resurgence of 90s hip-hop culture.

images.alt_text: The delays are unwelcome news for theatre chains desperate for more films from studios to draw movie-goers back to their screens.

site_title: Blinken says his China trip aims to lower risk of conflict
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken is set to visit China, aiming to lower the risk of conflict between the two nations. The trip, delayed due to a Chinese spy balloon incident in February, aims to establish "open and empowered" communications and explore areas for cooperation on global issues such as economic stability and climate change. Despite expectations of a limited breakthrough, Blinken acknowledges that sustained diplomacy is necessary to prevent competition from veering into confrontation.

images.alt_text: Anthony Blinken’s upcoming visit to Beijing could possibly provide an opportunity to announce an agreement on cooperation over issues of common interest.

site_title: The Last Word on classic cocktails
summary: The Last Word, a quieter hideaway from Nutmeg & Clove, offers a minimalist take on classic cocktails. Located upstairs in a shophouse unit, the bar features elegant glassware and a relaxed vibe. The Sake Sakura Martini is the best-selling cocktail on the happy hour menu, drawing inspiration from the bar's name. General manager Shelley Tai aims to create a fun and casual atmosphere, contrasting with the more formal Nutmeg & Clove bar below.

images.alt_text: The Devil, one of the signature cocktails at tarot-themed bar 3 of Cups, is sweet but strong, with a fiery kick.

jabarfly20 - FiftyFive Coffee Bar's initial cocktail menu is themed after the seven seas. The Indian, for instance, features spices ranging from garam masala to sansho pepper.

copyright/source: FiftyFive Coffee Bar

site_title: Singapore, US to expand cooperation to new frontiers, says Vivian following meeting with Blinken
summary: Singapore and the US are expanding their bilateral cooperation in cybersecurity, climate change, and space, said Singapore's Minister for Foreign Affairs Vivian Balakrishnan after a meeting with US Secretary of State Antony Blinken. The US-Singapore Climate Partnership signed in 2021 will see intensified efforts in regional energy transitions, low and zero-emission technologies, and urban decarbonization. The two countries also agreed to strengthen their economic relationship, with Singapore investing in the US and US exports supporting over 250,000 jobs in America.

images.alt_text: “Intense competition requires sustained diplomacy to ensure that competition does not veer into confrontation or conflict,” says US Secretary of State Anthony Blinken (right) at a briefing alongside Singapore Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan.

site_title: US$100 for a bowl of pho? Michelin Guide’s Vietnam debut seeks to give local eateries a boost
summary: The Michelin Guide has debuted in Vietnam, recognizing 103 local eateries, including 17 devoted to pho, a traditional Vietnamese noodle soup. Four restaurants, including Anan Saigon in Ho Chi Minh City, received Michelin stars. The guide aims to boost Vietnam's tourism and F&B sectors, with authorities hoping the global spotlight will drive international visitors. The inclusion of Vietnam in the guide is expected to have a positive impact on the country's economy, with a recent study showing that food and drinks make up nearly 25% of an overnight tourist's total expenditure.

images.alt_text: The Wuling HongGuang MiniEV, touted as the best-selling mini EV model in the world with starting price expected to be at around 100 million Vietnamese dong (about S$5,667), will make an entrance into Vietnam in the second quarter of this year.

site_title: US: Stocks dip, ending strong week with whimper
summary: US stocks ended the week on a weak note, dipping after a strong week of gains. The S&P 500 fell 0.4% to 4,409.59, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.3% to 34,299.12. Despite improving economic data and expectations of the Federal Reserve nearing the end of interest rate hikes, the market experienced a "mean reversion" after a strong week. Notable declines were seen in Disney (-1.7%) and Humana (-3.9%), while Adobe shares rose 0.9% after reporting record quarterly revenues.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., May 16, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Twitch star signs US$100 million deal with rival platform
summary: Twitch star Felix Lengyel, known as xQc, has signed a two-year deal with rival platform Kick, worth around $70 million, with potential incentives that could push the total to $100 million. This move is a significant blow to Twitch and highlights the growing competition between streaming platforms. Lengyel's deal could shake up the online entertainment industry's economics.

images.alt_text: Though wholesaling of hard commodities is not entirely new to China’s streaming platforms, it appears to be on the rise.
People attend the Ubisoft Forward livestream event in Los Angeles, California, June 12, 2023. The event features a look at upcoming Ubisoft games.

site_title: Musk: Tesla’s value is based primarily on vehicle autonomy
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk stated that the company's market value is primarily based on vehicle autonomy. He believes that achieving full self-driving capability will be solved soon, despite missing targets in the past. Musk emphasized that even a low probability of autonomy is valuable, and the value of Tesla is driven by its autonomy features. This statement reflects the company's focus on autonomous technology, which has contributed to its high market value.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise on defensive boost, post best week in 2 months
summary: European shares rose to a three-week high, fueled by luxury and defensive stocks, following a week dominated by major central bank policy decisions. The European Stoxx 600 index gained 0.5% on Friday, its best performance in over two months, as China-focused luxury stocks and healthcare gained ground. The European Central Bank raised borrowing costs and signaled more policy tightening, but the Bank of Japan maintained ultra-easy monetary policy.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.1 per cent lower after falling as much as 0.8 per cent earlier in the day.

site_title: PGA Tour, LIV Golf, Public Investment Fund of Saudi Arabia file motion to dismiss lawsuits
summary: The PGA Tour, LIV Golf, and the Public Investment Fund of Saudi Arabia have agreed to end all pending antitrust litigation, filing a motion to dismiss with prejudice. The decision comes 10 days after a joint interview explaining the parties' plan for a new, for-profit entity controlling professional golf. US senators have expressed concerns over the potential merger, with one senator stating that the union will "fall apart entirely" if specific terms are not ironed out. The proposed entity would see Al-Rumayyan as chairman and Monahan as CEO, with the PGA Tour holding a majority voting interest.

images.alt_text: The PGA Tour, DP World Tour and rival Saudi-backed LIV circuit announce an agreement last week to merge and form one unified commercial entity.

site_title: Dutch fund manager says ESG ban on Singapore government-backed debt only applies to some funds
summary: Dutch fund manager Van Lanschot Kempen said its ESG (environmental, social, and governance) test, which previously listed Singapore government-backed debt as non-compliant, only applies to advanced mandates used by some pension fund clients. The test does not apply to other clients or non-state-backed debt instruments, contradicting earlier statements from Singapore government agencies. Kempen's ESG test is based on a proprietary methodology and is used to screen for environmental risks, with Singapore's climate action being described as "in reverse".

site_title: Meta to lower age for users of virtual reality headset to 10 from 13
summary: Meta, the owner of Facebook and Instagram, plans to lower the recommended age for using its Quest virtual reality headset to 10 from 13, sparking concerns over privacy and safety. The change aims to give families more ways to use the headset, with parental approval required for preteens and restricted content for the age group. Meta is discussing the plan with regulators, who have taken action against tech companies for violating children's privacy laws. The move is part of Meta's efforts to build a virtual reality-based metaverse, a crucial aspect of its future business.

images.alt_text: “We are consulting with health experts to understand which claims and categories of misinformation could continue to pose this risk,” Meta says.
Meta is a prolific publisher of open-sourced AI research via its in-house research lab.

site_title: Meta rolls back measures to tackle Covid misinformation
summary: Meta has rolled back its measures to combat COVID-19 misinformation on Facebook and Instagram, citing improvements in authentic sources of information and general awareness. The policy change will not affect countries with ongoing COVID-19 public health emergencies. Meta will still remove content violating its coronavirus misinformation policies and is consulting with health experts to identify remaining risks. This decision follows Twitter's earlier rollback of its COVID-19 misinformation policy in November.

images.alt_text: Meta introduced the “AI Sandbox” for advertisers to test early versions of features that use artificial intelligence technology.
FILE PHOTO: Meta Platforms Inc's logo is seen on a smartphone in this illustration picture taken October 28, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: US keeps China on FX watch list, without designating manipulators
summary: The US Treasury has placed seven major economies, including China, on its "monitoring list" for currency practices, but refrained from designating any trading partner as a foreign-exchange manipulator. The list includes China, South Korea, Germany, Malaysia, Singapore, Switzerland, and Taiwan. The Treasury is calling for greater transparency in China's exchange-rate policy, citing a lack of transparency around its exchange rate mechanism. The US will continue to monitor Switzerland's currency practices, which exceeded one of the three criteria for manipulation.

images.alt_text: Brics countries have to resolve a perennial problem – how to move from bilateral to multilateral clearing and to a common currency.

site_title: Michael Jordan finalising Hornets sale to Gabe Plotkin Group
summary: Michael Jordan is finalizing a sale of the Charlotte Hornets to a group led by Gabe Plotkin and Rick Schnall. As part of the agreement, Jordan will retain a minority share of the team, which he has owned for 13 years as the NBA's sole Black majority owner. The sale is valued at approximately $3 billion, pending NBA vetting and approval. Plotkin and Schnall's group also includes music artists J Cole and Aeric Church, as well as other local investors, with Jordan's stake expected to remain a minority share.

site_title: Hong Kong’s luxury rental market is starting to rebound
summary: Hong Kong's luxury rental market is showing signs of a rebound after a pandemic-induced decline. According to Knight Frank, prime residential rents rose 1.9% in the first quarter, with the consultancy expecting a 5% increase in 2023. The market's recovery is driven by expats returning to the city and a new talent visa attracting high-earners and foreign graduates. This contrasts with Singapore's luxury rental market, which surged 31.5% year-over-year due to increased foreign wealth and stricter regulations.

images.alt_text: The Business Times' Property Insights newsletter (June 13, 2023)

site_title: China’s cabinet pledges to roll out more measures to spur growth
summary: China's cabinet has pledged to introduce measures to spur economic growth, including expedited policies for venture capital funds, technology startups, and measures against illegal financing. The move comes as economic growth beats expectations in the first quarter but forecasts for the rest of the year are downgraded due to slowing factory output and weak external and domestic demand. The government has set a 5% GDP growth target for this year, and policymakers agreed to step up financing support for technology companies and draft rules for supervising private funds.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man visits a display of semiconductor devices at Semicon China, a trade fair for semiconductor technology, in Shanghai, China March 17, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Odey suspends withdrawals from four funds managing US$1 billion
summary: Odey Asset Management has suspended withdrawals from four funds managing approximately US$1 billion amid mounting redemption pressure following fresh sexual assault allegations against founder Crispin Odey. The funds, including Brook Developed Markets and Brook Absolute Return, were previously suspended, and the firm has removed its founder from the partnership and shuttered one fund. This move comes after a Financial Times investigation into Odey's treatment of women over 25 years, including multiple allegations of sexual harassment and assault. The suspension aims to facilitate orderly portfolio transactions.

site_title: US consumer year-ahead inflation expectations lowest since 2021
summary: US consumer year-ahead inflation expectations have fallen to a two-year low of 3.3% in June, the lowest since March 2021. The sentiment index rose to a four-month high of 63.9, driven by an agreement to resolve the debt-ceiling crisis. However, Americans are growing more concerned about their incomes, with a decline in labor market optimism. Longer-term inflation expectations eased slightly, and the current conditions gauge rose to 68, while expectations advanced to a four-month high of 61.3.

images.alt_text: A worker fits wheel hub badges on the Ford Focus automobile assembly line inside the Ford Motor Co. factory in Saarlouis, Germany, on Wednesday, Sept. 25, 2019. Ford recently announced it expects 'electrified' vehicles – which include mild hybrids, traditional hybrids, plug-in electric hybrids (PHEVs) and battery electric vehicles (BEVs) – to make up over 50% of its passenger vehicle sales by year-end 2022. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

Shoppers on Powell Street in San Francisco, California, US, on Tuesday, Nov, 29, 2022. US retailers eked out modest growth over Black Friday weekend with deep discounts that lured shoppers seeking a reprieve from stubborn inflation. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: Indonesia to launch carbon exchange in September
summary: Indonesia plans to launch its carbon exchange in September, with power generation companies set to be the first to trade. The exchange, operated by the Indonesia Stock Exchange, will be supervised by the Financial Services Authority and the Environment and Forestry Ministry. Initially, coal power plant owners can sell emission allowances to less efficient peers. The government aims to expand the exchange to other sectors, including forestry and energy-intensive industries, with a cap on emissions and carbon tax planned for implementation in the future.

site_title: Orchard Road business group aims for energy and water efficiency, less waste
summary: The Orchard Road Business Association aims to make the Singapore shopping precinct more sustainable by reducing waste, energy, and water consumption. The association, led by chairman Mark Shaw, plans to implement targets such as energy-efficient buildings and green infrastructure by 2028. Shaw emphasized the need to balance sustainability with the "bottom line," acknowledging that increased costs may be passed on to tenants. The pedestrianization of Orchard Road, starting in 2025, is also part of the sustainability plan, with a goal of creating a more walkable and experiential retail environment.

images.alt_text: On top of resuming travel and recovering flight and airport capacities, Singapore must redefine our destination, reconnect with our fans, and reinvent our industry to secure the future of tourism, says STB chief executive Keith Tan.
As part of Orchard Road’s rejuvenation plans, Tanglin’s identity as a neighbourhood with a strong artisanal flavour will be strengthened.
Some trends suggest that malls at Orchard Road, which is now lit up for Christmas, may see brighter prospects than suburban malls.

site_title: Prince Harry and Meghan to part ways with Spotify
summary: Prince Harry and Meghan, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, have ended their partnership with Spotify's Archewell Audio less than a year after launching their podcast "Archetypes." The companies released a joint statement saying they had "mutually agreed to part ways" and were "proud of the series" they created. The decision comes as Spotify tightens its belt, with plans to lay off 200 people and 6% of its workforce. The couple has other business ventures, including a multiyear deal with Netflix for documentaries and scripted shows.

images.alt_text: The company also posted a Q1 operating loss of 156 million euros, compared to an operating loss of 6 million euros a year earlier.

site_title: After Sincere saga, property tycoon Kwek Leng Beng visits China to talk green projects
summary: Hong Leong Group chairman Kwek Leng Beng visited China to discuss green projects with Shanghai mayor Gong Zheng. The meeting came after a failed joint-venture deal with Sincere Property Group, which led to significant losses for CDL, a Singapore-listed real estate group. Kwek remains confident in China's market potential and plans to expand Hong Leong's portfolio, with a focus on sustainable developments and collaboration with the Shanghai government. The meeting marked a fresh start for CDL, which has a pipeline of 64 projects in China.

images.alt_text: Banyan Tree Group founder and executive chairman Ho Kwon Ping, who turns 71 in August, takes the approach of “leaving nothing unresolved by the time you die”
While greening of buildings may feature high on the agenda of property groups, do not expect these groups to lead in building social inclusivity.

site_title: China takes next step in currency globalisation, with some HK stocks priced in yuan
summary: China's gradual internationalization of its currency takes a significant step as about 24 Chinese companies, including Alibaba and Tencent, begin trading in yuan on Hong Kong's stock market, starting Monday. The Dual Counter Model allows investors to trade stocks in both yuan and the Hong Kong dollar, reducing reliance on the US dollar and mitigating geopolitical risks. The move is expected to boost overseas asset pools denominated in yuan, with fund managers anticipating increased demand over time.

images.alt_text: One of the reasons overseas investors have been wary about investing in Chinese debt has been the weakening yuan.

site_title: Saudi Arabia plans 1.5 billion riyal expansion of Burning Man-born Habitas
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to invest 1.5 billion riyals (S$535 million) in expanding the Habitas hotel and events company, which aims to attract new international visitors to the kingdom. The company plans six new properties across the kingdom, including two existing ones, and will be part of the Saudi Tourism Development Fund's goal to double tourism to 100 million annually by 2030. Habitas CEO Oliver Ripley sees potential for the brand to attract liberal creative types to Saudi Arabia, despite criticism over human rights violations and gender inequality.

site_title: Global tax deal at risk as first pillar teeters
summary: The global tax deal, aimed at rewriting outdated international taxation rules, is at risk due to domestic US politics. The first pillar, which aims to reallocate taxing rights on $200 billion in profits from multinational companies, faces opposition and may not be implemented by the US. The second pillar, which aims to end a decades-long tax rate race to the bottom, also faces challenges. If the US does not ratify the treaty, other countries with digital taxes may impose their own, potentially fragmenting the global tax system.

images.alt_text: Hanoi wants to introduce a top-up tax, but it fears that without some sort of compensation, the higher levy could make it less attractive to large multinationals.

site_title: WWE must face wrestling rival’s antitrust lawsuit
summary: A US judge has rejected WWE's attempt to dismiss an antitrust lawsuit filed by MLW Media, a smaller rival in the professional wrestling industry. Judge Edward Davila found that MLW had presented "circumstantial" evidence that WWE uses its dominance to block rivals from accessing distributors and arenas, citing 92% of US media rights revenue and exclusive agreements with major networks. The lawsuit, filed in 2022, claims WWE's activities have "had a substantial effect" in foreclosing competitors from the market, and the judge allowed the case to proceed.

site_title: Electric-vehicle startups set to extend blistering rally
summary: Electric-vehicle startups, including Nikola, Lordstown Motors, and Workhorse Group, are set to extend a blistering rally in their shares, with gains adding over $500 million to their collective market value. The rally has come without apparent news or catalysts, leading analysts to suspect a potential squeeze in highly shorted stocks. Retail investors have also plowed into EV shares, with Nikola being the fifth most traded US stock by retail investors on Thursday. The stocks have drawn bullish options activity, with Nikola's stock rising 20% ahead of the bell on Friday, poised to stay above the Nasdaq minimum level.

images.alt_text: VinFast electric vehicles are parked before delivery to their first customers at a store in Los Angeles, California, U.S.,  March 1, 2023.

site_title: Lufthansa submits new offer to pilots ahead of strike deadline
summary: Lufthansa has submitted a new offer to its pilots ahead of a strike deadline on June 30, threatening to disrupt the summer season. The revised offer includes a 18.5% salary increase, paid over several years until 2025, following previously paid wage increases in September. However, the collective bargaining committee has stated that essential elements of the pilots' demands are still missing from the offer. The pilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit had requested a concrete offer at the beginning of June, amid ongoing wage negotiations.

site_title: Japan increases support for domestic EV battery output
summary: Japan has increased support for domestic EV battery output with a US$2.2 billion investment, providing nearly US$1 billion in new subsidies to Toyota and other manufacturers. The move aims to boost economic supply chain security and counter international competition. Toyota plans to ramp up battery production with an annual capacity of 45 gigawatt hours by 2026, with the goal of achieving 150 gigawatt hours by 2030. The subsidies are part of a broader push to secure Japan's storage battery supply chain and gain wider access to the US EV tax credit.

images.alt_text: In Toyota’s case the total amount of the project to be subsidised is seen reaching 330 billion yen.

site_title: Chinese delegation to meet with Germany's top corporate brass next week
summary: Chinese Premier Li Qiang will meet with top German corporate CEOs next week as part of a visit to Europe. The meetings aim to strengthen ties amid Germany's efforts to diversify away from China. German companies, which heavily depend on the Chinese market, are at odds with the government's goal. Key CEOs from Mercedes-Benz, SAP, Siemens Energy, Audi, and others will participate in the discussions, focusing on Mercedes' commitment to China and China's market opening. The meetings highlight the dilemma of balancing economic ties with China's dependence on critical raw materials.

images.alt_text: The West has increasingly moved to restrict the use of Huawei in particular in 5G due to what critics say are its close links to Beijing’s security services.

site_title: Hyflux independent director further charged under Securities and Futures Act
summary: Independent director of Hyflux, Lee Joo Hai, has been further charged under the Securities and Futures Act for allegedly making false or misleading statements. Lee is being investigated for potential lapses in disclosures by Hyflux on its Tuaspring Integrated Water and Power Project and possible accounting irregularities. He was previously charged with neglect as an independent director in March. Lee contests the latest charge and maintains his professional conduct, with IPC Corporation stating his character and integrity remain suitable for him to continue as a director.

images.alt_text: 凯发集团（Hyflux Building）办公楼外观。
The recent cases of independent directors being hauled to court for disclosure-related offences have sent shockwaves to many independent directors.
The three charges levelled against Olivia Lum on Friday pertain to Section 157(1) of the Companies Act,

site_title: Syngenta wins Shanghai Exchange approval for 65 billion yuan IPO
summary: Syngenta, a Swiss-headquartered seed giant, has won approval for its 65 billion yuan (US$9.1 billion) initial public offering (IPO) on the Shanghai stock exchange. The company, owned by Sinochem Holdings, has been working on the listing since 2019. The IPO will be used to fund high-end agricultural technology research, global acquisitions, and business expansion. The approval comes after a previous application was withdrawn and resubmitted, and follows China's reforms aimed at speeding up access to funding in the nation's US$10.3 trillion equity market.

images.alt_text: The Syngenta offering in China has been in the works since 2019.

site_title: Thailand seeking to re-engage Myanmar junta with Asean meeting: letter, sources
summary: Thailand's caretaker government has proposed to "fully re-engage" Myanmar's military rulers, inviting Asean foreign ministers to an informal meeting on June 18, in an effort to jump-start a stalled peace plan. The proposal comes after Asean barred Myanmar's ruling generals from high-level meetings due to their failure to honor the "5-point consensus" agreement, which included calls for an immediate end of hostilities and dialogue between all parties. The meeting is expected to take place despite Indonesia's decision not to attend, citing progress in behind-the-scenes efforts to engage multiple parties in the conflict.

images.alt_text: A chair for a Myanmar representative is left unoccupied during a retreat session of the 42nd Asean Summit in Labuan Bajo, East Nusa Tenggara, Indonesia, May 11, 2023. Asean has barred Myanmar junta leaders from attending its high-level meetings over its failure to implement the plan, which its top general agreed to in April 2021 in a meeting in Jakarta.

site_title: BOJ, ECB rate decisions send yen to fresh 15-year low against euro
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its ultra-low interest rates and forecast slower inflation, but the yen fell to a fresh 15-year low of 154.70 per euro due to market expectations of potential intervention. In contrast, the European Central Bank (ECB) raised interest rates to a 22-year high, and the euro surged to a one-month high against the US dollar. The yen's decline was also influenced by soft US economic data and traders' reduced bets on US interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Japanese yen banknotes of various denominations are arranged for a photograph in Soka City, Saitama Prefecture, Japan, on Wednesday, 29 August 2012. The dollar headed for a monthly advance versus the yen before U.S. data forecast to show consumer spending rose the most since February. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

site_title: Samudera buys two container vessels for US$59.9 million
summary: Samudera Shipping Line has agreed to buy two container vessels for US$59.9 million, with delivery expected in the second half of 2023. Each vessel has a capacity of 1,500 twenty-foot equivalent units. The purchase is not expected to significantly impact the company's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the financial year ended December 31, 2023.

site_title: Volkswagen: battery unit PowerCo will be ‘investor-ready’ early next year
summary: Volkswagen's battery unit PowerCo is expected to be "investor-ready" by early next year, according to the company's battery chief Thomas Schmall. This follows comments from CFO Arno Antlitz that a strategic investor may be sought in 2024. No further details were provided, but more information will be disclosed at Volkswagen's capital markets day next Wednesday. The move comes as interest in PowerCo is reportedly high, with the carmaker evaluating how long to keep the unit on its books.

images.alt_text: Member of the Board of Management Volkswagen AG Technology Thomas Schmall speaks during a press conference before the groundbreaking ceremony for German carmaker Volkswagen's first battery cell production plant 'SalzGiga' in Salzgitter, Germany, July 7, 2022. REUTERS/Fabrizio Bensch

site_title: UK clears Amazon's US$1.7 billion deal for Roomba-maker iRobot
summary: The UK's Competition and Markets Authority has cleared Amazon's $1.7 billion acquisition of iRobot Corp, maker of the Roomba vacuum cleaner, citing no competition concerns. The deal, announced last year, aims to expand Amazon's smart-home device portfolio. The EU will review the deal by July 6, while the US Federal Trade Commission is also examining it. iRobot's shares rose 12% in pre-market trade, while Amazon's stock was marginally down.

images.alt_text: iRobot Roomba i7+ robot vacuum cleaner.
AWS started selling Nvidia’s H100 chip in March but as part of systems of its own design.

site_title: Amara requests trading halt; shares up 24% since Jun 15
summary: Amara Holdings has requested a trading halt pending an announcement. The company's shares have surged 24% since June 15, closing at S$0.44 on Friday before the halt. The trading halt was called during the midday break, and the company's announcement is expected to be released soon.

site_title: Singapore Airlines denies media report on raising stake in Air India
summary: Singapore Airlines denied a media report stating it may raise its stake in Air India from 25.1% to around 40%. The airline reiterated its November 2022 announcement, stating there is no change in its position. The report, citing sources, claimed SIA had discussed a potential increase in stake with Tata Group in response to a request from a Singapore-based airline. Air India has not commented on the matter.

site_title: Pacific Star, Inch Kenneth Kajang Rubber to delist
summary: Pacific Star Development and Inch Kenneth Kajang Rubber are set to delist from the bourse on June 19 and June 21, respectively. Pacific Star's trading suspension ended after receiving additional financing from lenders, allowing it to resolve issues including unsold condominium units. The companies' delisting follows prolonged suspensions due to changes in control and macroeconomic challenges. Post-delisting, Pacific Star's independent directors will step down.

images.alt_text: Iskandar boleh

The board is of the view that it is not meaningful to submit a resumption of trading proposal until the group is able to complete the bulk sale of unsold units at Puteri Cove Residences and Quayside (pictured), and to determine the future growth prospects of the group.

site_title: Euro-area inflation calls for ECB tightening bias, IMF says
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged the European Central Bank (ECB) to tighten its monetary policy, citing inflation in the Euro region that remains above the 2% goal. Despite cooling from a peak of 10.6% in October, inflation remains more than three times the ECB's target, and the IMF suggests a sustained "tightening bias" is needed to anchor inflation expectations and return inflation to target. The IMF also praises the Euro-zone economy's resilience but warns of modest growth and a prolonged period of output below pre-war trend due to persistently higher energy prices.

images.alt_text: The European flag flutters in front of the building of the European Central Bank (ECB) on October 5, 2011 in Frankfurt/M., western Germany. The European Central Bank could cut its key interest rates later this week, analysts predicted, as Frenchman Jean-Claude Trichet prepares to step down after eight years as the bank's president.    AFP PHOTO    FRANK RUMPENHORST    GERMANY OUT

site_title: Japan's 10-year bond yield slips after BOJ decision
summary: Japan's 10-year government bond yield fell 2 basis points to 0.405% after the Bank of Japan maintained its ultra-loose monetary policy, aiming to support a fragile economic recovery. Despite investor expectations of a policy tweak, short positions were limited, and yields declined across the curve. The BOJ's decision was seen as a cautious move amid stronger-than-expected inflation and a looming policy shift in July.

images.alt_text: As widely expected, the Bank of Japan kept intact its short-term interest rate target at -0.1 per cent and that for the 10-year bond yield around 0 per cent at the two-day meeting that ended on Friday.

site_title: Issue 53: Keppel’s green transformation; Indonesia confronts coal phase-out’s complexities
summary: Keppel Corp, a Singapore conglomerate, is rapidly shifting its business towards green activities. The company has secured energy-efficient cooling contracts in Thailand and is investing in sustainable energy and environmental developments, with 60% of its new business announcements related to these sectors. Keppel's transformation is largely driven by the divestment of its oil and gas-related business, with infrastructure accounting for 35% of its 2022 net profit. However, the early retirement of coal assets in Indonesia, as part of the country's JETP program, is proving complex due to concerns over financing and regulatory frameworks.

images.alt_text: Keppel’s EaaS service allows businesses and building owners to enter a supply and service contract for energy usage and management.
Singapore’s small landmass has left it with limited options when it comes to building renewable energy infrastructure.
Coal barges to be pulled along Mahakam river in Samarinda, East Kalimantan province, Indonesia, in August 31, 2019.
The Hoa Binh hydroelectric power plant in Hoa Binh province, Vietnam; Vietnam plans to have hydropower account for 19.5 per cent of the energy mix by 2030, down from 29 per cent in 2022.
“I believe that Toyota today can manage its business with a sense of speed,” new CEO Koji Sato says.

site_title: Indonesian prosecutors name 3 palm oil groups as suspects in corruption case
summary: Indonesian prosecutors have named three palm oil companies - Wilmar Group, Musim Mas Group, and Permata Hijau Group - as suspects in a corruption investigation, alleging misconduct in obtaining export permits during a time of restricted shipments. The investigation follows the jailing of executives from the companies for manipulating documents to obtain permits. The move aims to recover state losses and holds the companies responsible for their actions, which contributed to soaring local cooking oil prices.

images.alt_text: At an industry conference on Monday, Malaysian producers Sime Darby Plantation and United Plantations said they will not have difficulty complying with the new law as they have not been planting on deforested land for years.

site_title: Indonesia’s illiquid stock market churning out 1,000% stock gains
summary: Indonesia's stock market has seen extreme gains in illiquid shares, with at least 83 companies experiencing a 1,000% swing in the past three years. Regulators have introduced a watchlist board to identify troubled companies, citing concerns about investor protection. The market's low liquidity and high valuations have raised questions about the stability of the nearly $640 billion stock market. Analysts and investors are calling for tighter regulation, with some pushing for further action to curb market manipulation. The issue is particularly concerning given Indonesia's economic growth challenges and its goal of attracting more investors.

images.alt_text: Yield-hungry investors have already been piling into Indonesian bonds after the central bank all but ended its tightening cycle earlier this year.
Indonesia property to stay soft until year-end, on rate hike, currency pressure: Maybank Kim Eng

site_title: BMW XM review: A bold statement, or just a bold face?
summary: The BMW XM, the most expensive and powerful BMW, has been reviewed in Dubai. With a 4.3-second 0-100kmh acceleration and 653 horsepower, the car is meant to be a bold statement. Despite its hybrid powertrain and massive 2.7-tonne weight, the XM is capable of tackling mountain roads with ease, thanks to its active suspension and powerful electric motor. The car's interior features a spacious, wraparound lounge chair-like design, and its exterior is characterized by a massive grille and intimidating styling. While its price point of S$1.01 million may be steep, the BMW XM is undeniably a unique and special car.

images.alt_text: At S$174,900, the Skoda Octavia is hands down the best all-rounder of the bunch, and easily one of the best ways to get the very most bang for your motoring buck.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined 14.7% in May, surpassing the 9.8% contraction in April. This drop was attributed to decreased shipments to Hong Kong, Malaysia, and Taiwan. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks closed higher on Friday, marking a second consecutive winning week, with the STI up 0.5%. The country's key exports also saw a larger-than-expected 14.7% drop in May, according to data from Enterprise Singapore.

site_title: Baidu wins commercial licence for driverless taxis in Shenzhen
summary: Baidu has obtained a commercial licence for its driverless taxi service, Apollo Go, to operate in 188 square kilometers of Shenzhen, China. This is the company's first fully driverless service in the city, following similar licences in Wuhan, Chongqing, and Beijing. Baidu plans to add 200 fully driverless robotaxis to the road this year, expanding its autonomous ride-hailing service.

site_title: UK public’s inflation expectations ease in May, Bank of England survey shows
summary: The UK public's inflation expectations decreased to 3.5% in May, down from 3.9% in February, according to a Bank of England survey. Expectations for inflation in five years' time remained steady at 3.0%. The public's net satisfaction with the central bank's inflation control fell to a record low of -13%, while consumer price inflation dropped to 8.7% in April. Despite cooling inflation expectations, the BOE is closely monitoring the situation and preparing for potential interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: A shopper pushes a shopping trolley at the Tesco Basildon Pitsea Extra supermarket, operated by Tesco Plc, in Basildon, U.K., on Tuesday, Dec. 1, 2015. Many European food retailers are coming to terms with persistently low inflation as well as consumers who remain frugal yet purchase food more frequently. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg
Britain has Western Europe’s highest rate of inflation for food, with prices up more than 19 per cent over the past year, the worst such run since the 1970s.

site_title: Two Thai firms to light up SE Asia’s IPO market with listings worth US$2.5 billion: sources
summary: Two Thai firms, Big C Super centre and CPF Global Food Solution, plan to raise up to $2.5 billion combined through initial public offerings (IPOs) on the Bangkok stock exchange. Big C could raise up to $1 billion and CPF Global Food up to $1.5 billion, solidifying Southeast Asia's status as a global IPO hot spot. This follows a year of $454 million in IPOs in Thailand, and comes as the market shows growth, with Refinitiv data showing a 6.9% rise to $2.66 billion as of mid-June.

site_title: Intel to invest US$4.6 billion in new chip plant in Poland
summary: Intel plans to invest up to $4.6 billion in a new semiconductor assembly and test facility in Poland, creating 2,000 jobs and thousands more during construction and supplier hiring. The facility is part of Intel's multi-billion-dollar investment drive in Europe to build chip capacity, following similar investments in Germany, Ireland, and France.

images.alt_text: SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son has said he hopes the Arm IPO can be the largest ever by a chip company.

site_title: Flush with cash – why do the super-rich need so many bathrooms?
summary: The wealthy's obsession with luxurious bathrooms is a growing trend, with many high-end homes featuring multiple en-suite bathrooms, including some with as many as 42. This "bathroom inflation" is seen as a symptom of spatial decadence, but also raises questions about functionality and waste of resources. The phenomenon began in the US in the 1980s and has since spread to mid-market and suburban homes, with some critics arguing that it's a gross waste of resources and leads to problems like steam and odors seeping into bedrooms.

images.alt_text:
Interior Decoration ideas - Italian-made
marble bathroom and gold  crimmings, built
for comfort and luxury.
Out of the 295 units, only three have been sold as of May 22.
The mansion's other amenities include a 15-car garage, indoor and outdoor pools, two domes, a 70,000-litre coral reef aquarium, a power substation and panic rooms.

site_title: US chip giant Micron to invest US$600 million in China plant
summary: Micron, a US chip giant, plans to invest over US$600 million in its packing and testing factory in Xi'an, China, over the next few years. The investment will acquire equipment and add a new factory at the facility. This move comes less than a month after China banned Micron's chips from critical infrastructure projects, following a national security review.

images.alt_text: The Indian investment would follow a Chinese ban on the use of Micron chips in what Beijing called critical infrastructure, a move that cast uncertainty over the status of US chipmakers in the world’s largest semiconductor market.

site_title: Singapore stocks end higher on Friday in line with region; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks ended higher on Friday, closing 0.5% up at 3,260.03, following a second consecutive winning week. The benchmark Straits Times Index rose 17.18 points, driven by 350 gainers outweighing 216 losers in trading of 2.7 billion securities worth S$2.6 billion. Despite weaker economic data, including a 14.7% year-on-year decline in non-oil domestic exports in May, the market performance was supported by gains in the broader region.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures of SGX
Iron ore continues to gain recognition as a “proxy for industrialising Asia”, says SGX.

site_title: Micron nears US$1 billion investment in India chip packaging plant
summary: Micron Technology is nearing a $1 billion investment in a semiconductor packaging plant in India, following a Chinese ban on the use of its chips in critical infrastructure. The deal, which could reach $2 billion, aims to diversify the company's footprint and strengthen supply chains outside of China. The move is seen as a win for India's "Make in India" plans and an opportunity for the US to counterbalance China's influence in the global semiconductor market.

images.alt_text: China’s cybersecurity watchdog on Sunday instructed operators of “critical information infrastructure” to stop buying from Micron, one of the world’s largest chip manufacturers.

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB raises Sheng Siong target to S$2.04 on attractive valuations
summary: RHB Research has maintained its "buy" call on Sheng Siong, raising its target price to S$2.04 from S$2, citing attractive valuations. The supermarket chain operator's fundamentals remain intact, with steady revenue in the first quarter and a diversified sourcing mix. RHB analyst Alfie Yeo expects stable gross and operating margins, driven by revenue growth and staff costs tied to performance. The new target price implies a 25.2% upside from the current share price.

images.alt_text: Sheng Siong’s board is currently made up of 10 directors, five of whom are non-executive and independent.
Sheng Siong will likely be able to raise prices to pass on costs while preserving margins, as it has done so in the past when prices rose, RHB noted.

site_title: Indonesia fans vexed after Messi pulls out of friendly
summary: Indonesian fans of Lionel Messi expressed disappointment and frustration after the soccer star pulled out of a friendly match in Jakarta due to false advertising. Messi's absence led to a sell-out crowd, with fans like Surya Wijaya Ang, who traveled 12 hours to attend, feeling let down. Organizers had promised Messi's appearance, but he confirmed he would not play, citing a separate match in Beijing. Fans took to social media to express their disappointment, with some even offering to sell their tickets. Despite the setback, Ang plans to attend the match anyway.

images.alt_text: There’s no official date for Messi’s debut – the multi-million US dollar deal to make him the star of Inter Miami has yet to be finalised.

site_title: ICP shareholder requisitions EGM to remove three directors
summary: ICP Ltd, a CATALIST-listed company, has received a requisition notice from shareholder Ang Kong Meng to convene an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to pass seven resolutions. The resolutions include removing three directors, Tan Kok Hiang, Koh Tien Gui, and Ong Kok Wah, and appointing Ang and Hor Siew Fu as new directors. Ang alleges that the company's proposed share placement aims to dilute shareholders' interest and that the funding will be used for strategic partnerships rather than acquisitions. The company's board disagrees with these allegations and will convene the EGM to discuss shareholders' concerns and provide clarity on the company's strategy.

images.alt_text: One of the hotels, 2nd by hotel androoms Nagoya, has 13 floors with 211 rooms. It was built in 2017.
ICP ditches purchase of 5% stake in Osaka hotel

site_title: Hot stock: Singapore Airlines breaks 12-day winning streak, falls 1.8% to S$7.77
summary: Singapore Airlines' 12-day winning streak came to an end as its shares fell 1.8% to S$7.77 on Friday, June 16. The airline refuted a media report suggesting it may raise its stake in Air India to create a bigger full-service national carrier. Despite this, the airline reported a 65.8% year-on-year increase in May passenger traffic, with 2.8 million passengers served together with its budget carrier Scoot. Analysts from Morgan Stanley downgraded the airline's fair value to S$7.30, citing that the gains may have been priced in.

images.alt_text: OCBC cautions that much of SIA’s recovery has already been priced in its stock due to its first-mover advantage.
Those who helmed the national carrier before current CEO Goh Choon Phong had all risen through the ranks and spent decades rotating across the various departments and subsidiaries.
Singapore Airlines says there is no change in SIA's position from the November 2022 announcement.

site_title: Tesco sees signs of UK inflation starting to ease as sales rise
summary: Tesco, the UK's largest grocer, reported a 9% sales gain in the first quarter, driven by higher prices. The company's CEO, Ken Murphy, said signs of easing grocery inflation are emerging, but retail profit is expected to remain flat at around $3.2 billion. Tesco has increased its price match with Aldi to over 700 products and is trying to keep prices low. Despite rising shares, the UK government's proposal to introduce voluntary price caps on groceries was met with opposition from supermarkets, with some calling it "harebrained."

images.alt_text: Britain has Western Europe’s highest rate of inflation for food, with prices up more than 19 per cent over the past year, the worst such run since the 1970s.

site_title: What’s a barranca? US Open golfers hope they don’t find out
summary: The US Open golf tournament at the Los Angeles Country Club features a unique feature known as a "barranca," a narrow, winding, steep-walled gully or river gorge. The barranca, which was restored to its original appearance in 2017, poses a challenge to golfers, particularly on the second and 17th holes, where errant shots can result in a one-stroke penalty. Renowned golfers Rickie Fowler and Xander Schauffele tied for the lead after the first round, with Fowler setting a US Open record-low round of 62. The barranca is not only a hazard but also an aesthetically pleasing feature of the course design.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Turf Club's closure comes amid shrinking audiences and prize purses.
The Zurich-based organisation is bolstering its presence ahead of the 2026 World Cup when Miami and 15 cities across the US, Mexico and Canada host games.
The PGA Tour, DP World Tour and rival Saudi-backed LIV circuit announce an agreement last week to merge and form one unified commercial entity.

site_title: Australian home rents higher than advertised prices, study finds
summary: Australia's home-rental inflation has accelerated, with prices paid by new tenants 24% higher than advertised rates since 2020. This surpasses the 22% gain in CoreLogic's index and reinforces a picture of strong housing demand and limited property listings. The Reserve Bank of Australia and Australian Bureau of Statistics joint study found rent inflation is broadly based across new and existing tenants, property types, and states. The data is a concern for the RBA, which has raised interest rates 12 times to control inflation, with further hikes possible.

site_title: When will air travel finally recover?
summary: Global commercial air travel demand reached 90% of pre-Covid levels in May, according to Bain & Company's Air Traffic Demand Forecast Model. The complete rebound is expected in the first half of 2024, primarily driven by the resumption of Chinese air travel. However, a potential recession and rising inflation may delay the full air-travel recovery, potentially dampening leisure travel in 2023-2025.

images.alt_text: Travelers inside a departure hall at Haneda Airport in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, April 27, 2023. Japan's Golden Week holidays start Saturday and will cover much of next week. Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg

site_title: Jardine C&C and Carro enter strategic partnership for used cars and aftersales
summary: Mainboard-listed Jardine C&C and used-car tech platform Carro have entered a strategic partnership worth over US$60 million. Under the deal, Carro will acquire a stake in Jardine's used-car subsidiary, Republic Auto, while Jardine C&C will acquire a stake of equal value in Carro. The partnership aims to combine the strengths of both companies, with Jardine leveraging its infrastructure and expertise and Carro using its technology-driven approach. The deal will enhance offerings such as a wider variety of used cars and an improved online-to-offline customer experience, and will also create a new joint venture for a multi-brand after-market workshop business.

images.alt_text: Cycle & Carriage authorised service centre at Ubi
BYD by 1826, a new restaurant in Boat Quay which is also a dealer for BYD electric cars.

site_title: China's Xi tells Bill Gates he hopes US-China friendship will continue
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping met with Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates in Beijing, marking Xi's first meeting with a foreign entrepreneur in years. Xi expressed hope for continued US-China friendship and described Gates as his first American friend this year. Gates, who stepped down from Microsoft's board in 2020, said he was honored to meet Xi and discussed topics such as global health, education, and climate change. The meeting comes ahead of a long-delayed visit by US Secretary of State Antony Blinken to China, and reflects Xi's efforts to engage with the global business community despite growing tensions with the US.

images.alt_text: While he is inspired by the potential of artificial intelligence, Bill Gates acknowledges that it “raises hard questions about the workforce, the legal system, privacy, bias, and more”.

site_title: Europe’s petrol prices show market fears plunging back into crisis
summary: Europe's petrol prices are flashing warning signs of a potential market crisis, despite low storage levels and muted Asian demand. Small outages in Norway and a planned shutdown in the Netherlands have caused huge price swings, raising concerns about the region's fragile supply. The market's volatility, at levels not seen since the crisis, may hinder the European Central Bank's efforts to curb inflation and could drive up energy prices, potentially leading to a repeat of last summer's prices.

images.alt_text: Global oil demand this year will rise by 2.35 million barrels per day (bpd), or 2.4 per cent, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) says in its monthly report.

site_title: Madrid house price gains spell trouble for PM Sanchez
summary: Madrid's housing market is experiencing significant gains, with home prices rising 4.9% year-over-year, contrasting with declines in five other major European cities. Rising interest rates and declining consumer spending power have led to a nationwide shortage, particularly in Madrid, where housing prices continue to rise despite government efforts to cap rent increases. The issue has become a political problem for Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez ahead of a snap election on July 23. Experts attribute the shortage to a combination of housing shortages, gentrification, and foreign investment, which has squeezed consumers already dealing with inflation and higher financing costs.

images.alt_text: Households are benefiting from a strong labour market, meaning fewer people are likely to stop paying back their mortgage due to unemployment, says the ECB.

site_title: Business families’ secret to succession is when boss/dad/mum learns to let go
summary: Family business leaders in Asia are struggling to pass on the reins to their children, with many patriarchs holding onto power due to ego, insecurity, and a fear of death. Experts say that a gradual transition, open communication, and fairness are key to building a lasting dynasty. Banyan Tree Group's Ho Kwon Ping and Family Succession Advisors' Ethan Chue offer advice on how to bridge the gap between parents and children, including honest conversations, creating a family constitution, and acknowledging different interests and skills. Successful families like EtonHouse's Ng Gim Choo and Ng Yi-Xian are finding ways to pass on the business while maintaining family harmony, with some even drafting a family constitution to guide future generations.

If you work for a listco your family controls, does pay incentivise you the way it would for an outsider?
Family-run listcos: A smart investment decision, or 'clusters of long-term insiders'?
Dual governance methods, more independent director involvement crucial for family businesses: panel
The financial world's favourite TV drama Succession is now in its 4th and final season.
Brian Cox stars in the hit TV series Succession.

Signage of Adani Group in Mumbai, India, on Friday, Jan. 27, 2023. Shares of Adani Group’s companies have lost more than $30 billion in market value in less than two sessions, as a selloff sparked by US short seller Hindenburg Research’s scathing report deepened on Friday. Photographer: Indranil Aditya/Bloomberg
Of the 500 listed in the study, 17 family firms are from South-east Asia, with two from Singapore.
A deep conversation with your financial adviser is a must before you decide on a trust for legacy planniing.
The year 2023 looks set to be a year of two halves, and investors will benefit from responding accordingly, says some of Asia's top private bankers.

site_title: Bank of Japan keeps ultra-low rates, forecast of inflation slowdown
summary: The Bank of Japan maintained its ultra-low interest rates, defying global peers that are hiking rates to combat inflation. The decision left the yen weak, sinking to around 140.75 yen per US dollar. The central bank cited temporary factors, such as the war in Ukraine, for the recent inflation slowdown, and will review its non-traditional policies to boost economic growth. The decision is expected to be reviewed in mid-2024, with the goal of achieving 2% inflation within the governor's five-year term.

images.alt_text: The Tokyo Stock Exchange closed the June 14 session with the Nikkei index at 33,502.42 points, the highest close in over 33 years.
In Toyota’s case the total amount of the project to be subsidised is seen reaching 330 billion yen.

FILE PHOTO: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida speaks about his parent policy at a press conference at his official residence in Tokyo on March 17, 2023. YOSHIKAZU TSUNO/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo

site_title: Sweden braces for fallout from property slump
summary: Sweden's government is preparing to intervene in the country's property market, which has been hit by a slump in prices, high debts, and rising interest rates. The economy, which is heavily reliant on property, accounts for 80% of household debt, and commercial property companies have been downgraded to junk by rating agencies. The government has a financial clout to prevent a wider crisis, but concerns about the property sector are weighing on the currency and investors are wondering if Sweden is the first domino to fall in Europe.

images.alt_text: The old town of Gamla Stan in Stockholm. Swedish public housing is carefully conceptualised to be spacious and have leisure spaces such as playgrounds.

site_title: Into the world of extended reality
summary: Extended reality (XR) technologies, including virtual reality (VR), augmented reality (AR), and mixed reality (MR), are becoming increasingly ubiquitous, raising concerns about data protection and privacy. XR devices collect vast amounts of personal data, including sensor data, location information, and usage patterns, which can be highly sensitive. Gaze tracking and motion analysis can even reveal subconscious thoughts and behavioral patterns. To mitigate these risks, companies can implement technical solutions such as on-off switches, local data processing, and end-to-end encryption. Policy-wise, clear policies on data collection and sharing, limiting third-party access, and creating feedback loops are essential. Governments must also play an active role in building well-informed regulations to ensure the development of trusted XR spaces.

images.alt_text: The rise of artificial intelligence has also renewed fears about people’s jobs being replaced.
Social media giant Meta has forecast the tech would eventually replace mobile as the main computing platform.
People attend the Ubisoft Forward livestream event in Los Angeles, California, June 12, 2023. The event features a look at upcoming Ubisoft games.
An Apple Vision Pro mixed reality (XR) headset is unveiled during the Apple Worldwide Developers Conference at Apple Park campus in Cupertino, California, US, June 5, 2023.

site_title: The seven companies driving the US stock market rally
summary: The US stock market is experiencing a surge, dominated by tech stocks, masking a humdrum performance from the majority of stocks. The S&P 500 index has climbed over 14% this year, with seven top-heavily weighted tech companies driving the rally, including Apple, Microsoft, Alphabet, Amazon, Nvidia, Tesla, and Meta. These companies have gained between 40% and 180% this year, with five of them representing nearly a quarter of the index's market capitalization. Analysts warn that this concentration could lead to a market correction or even a recession, but some predict a short-term catch-up and a strong finish to the year.

images.alt_text: Thanks to a stock surge, Nvidia's valuation touched US$1 trillion, joining the ranks of other Big Tech stocks such as Amazon and Microsoft.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.4 per cent higher at 34,212.12 on Tuesday.

site_title: US trade chief seeks supply chain redesign to boost resilience
summary: US Trade Representative Katherine Tai calls for a redesign of global supply chains to boost resilience and address fragile and unsustainable globalization. The redesign aims to prioritize workers, the environment, and small businesses, and improve supply chain efficiency. Tai believes current free trade agreements have reinforced existing fragile supply chains, making the US vulnerable to crises and disruptions. A fundamental shift in incentivizing production decisions is required to achieve this goal.

site_title: Vietnam central bank cuts interest rates again to spur growth
summary: Vietnam's central bank cut its key interest rates by 50 basis points, its fourth policy rate adjustment this year, to support slowing economic growth amid global uncertainties. The refinancing rate was cut to 4.5%, the discount rate to 3%, and the electronic interbank rate to 5%. The move aims to shore up the manufacturing-led economy, which has been affected by weak global demand and slower credit growth. Vietnam's economic growth slipped to 3.3% in the first quarter, with a 12.3% decline in exports in the first five months of the year.

site_title: Major banks cut China 2023 GDP forecasts as recovery falters
summary: Four major Western banks have lowered their 2023 GDP growth forecasts for China, citing a faltering post-pandemic recovery. UBS, Standard Chartered, Bank of America, and JPMorgan now expect China's GDP growth to be between 5.2% and 5.7%, down from an earlier range of 5.7% to 6.3%. This follows May data showing industrial output and retail sales growth missing forecasts, adding to expectations that Beijing will need to implement more measures to shore up the economy.

images.alt_text: Tokyo markets struggled on a stronger yen, even as the Bank of Japan on Friday stood pat on its ultra-loose monetary policy.

Real estate agents said low-cost apartments in smaller Chinese cities such as Huainan and Rushan in the east, and Gejiu in the south-west, are also being bought, largely by people living outside those locations.

In the EU’s review of the 5G “toolbox,” the commission will say that publicly excluding Huawei and ZTE from national networks is justified and will explicitly call out Huawei and ZTE as high-risk vendors by name for the first time.

site_title: Nissan confirms top executive Gupta leaving company
summary: Nissan confirms the departure of chief operating officer Ashwani Gupta, effective June 27, citing a desire to pursue other opportunities. The move revives concerns about the company's leadership stability following former CEO Carlos Ghosn's 2018 arrest. A new executive line-up will be announced on the same date, amid reports of a rivalry between Gupta and CEO Makoto Uchida, with some speculating Gupta's departure was due to his ambition to take the top job.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Nissan Motor's chief operating officer Ashwani Gupta speaks at a press conference to announce the construction of a gigafactory at Nissan's plant in Sunderland, north east England on July 1, 2021. Top Nissan executive Ashwani Gupta is leaving the company, the Japanese automaker confirmed June 16, 2023, a day after reports of a leadership clash inside the company. (Photo by Oli SCARFF / AFP)

site_title: SGX reprimands seven former Nutryfarm directors for breaching disclosure rules
summary: Seven former directors of Nutryfarm International have been reprimanded by the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) for failing to disclose material information about the company's potential restructuring of third-party loans into convertible bonds, leading to a 36.4% decline in shares in 2021. The reprimand was issued after the company failed to disclose the talks with its creditor, Corpbond IV, in a timely manner, resulting in unusual trading activity. The directors were accused of not making a reference to ongoing negotiations in their August 2021 announcement.

images.alt_text: Nutryfarm didn't give loan updates when SGX queried because it was 'premature', says board
Durian and health foods distributor Nutryfarm said on Friday (J
NutryFarm requests trading suspension pending review of ongoing concerns

site_title: BT Market Focus: Fed rate pause gave cheer to markets (Ep 47)
summary: The pause in the Federal Reserve's rate hike has provided a boost to markets, despite lingering fears of future rate hikes. Market uncertainties were also fueled by the ongoing US-China trade tensions, with Trump's comments on tariffs and the US dollar's decline. Despite this, investors are cautiously optimistic about the market's prospects. The pause in rate hikes has allowed investors to reassess their portfolios, and some analysts believe that the market is due for a rebound.

images.alt_text: What caused markets to be choppy this week?
A mixed week for markets amid inflation and US debt ceiling talks.

site_title: Night owls die earlier due to drinking and smoking: study
summary: A 37-year study found that night owls, who tend to stay up late, do not have a higher risk of death compared to early risers, as long as they don't use their later nights for excessive drinking and smoking. The study, which followed nearly 24,000 same-sex twins in Finland, found that definite night owls had a 9% higher risk of death from all causes, mainly due to smoking and alcohol consumption. Researchers conclude that night owls can reduce their risk of early death by being mindful of their habits.

Not even the rich in America were benefiting from the extremely high income and wealth inequality of the Gilded Age.
