site_title: Vast cyber espionage campaign linked to China: report
summary: A vast cyber espionage campaign linked to China has compromised computer defenses of hundreds of organizations, including government agencies and research institutions in at least 16 countries. The campaign, attributed to UNC4841, targeted victims in the Asia-Pacific region and Taiwan, with emails of prominent employees dealing with matters of interest to the Chinese government being stolen. The attack, similar to a 2021 hack of Microsoft Exchange, involved booby-trapped email messages and exploited a vulnerability in Barracuda software, and is believed to have started as early as October last year.

images.alt_text: In the EU’s review of the 5G “toolbox,” the commission will say that publicly excluding Huawei and ZTE from national networks is justified and will explicitly call out Huawei and ZTE as high-risk vendors by name for the first time.

The Chinese market for mystery boxes, whose contents are sold undisclosed and which are also known as blind boxes, has grown quickly, contributing to the fast expansion of domestic toymakers such as Pop Mart.
Prior to the recent developments, Singapore had earned a name for itself as one of the region’s top gambling spots, with two casinos – one at MBS and the other at  RWS.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Friday; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.3% to 3,252.18 points, following strong overnight gains on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers 85 to 35, with top-traded counters including Seatrium and Marco Polo Marine. Local banks also traded positively, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC rising 0.5%, 0.1%, and 0.2% respectively. The US market ended higher, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index advancing 1.2% each.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines and its budget carrier Scoot saw a 65.8% increase year on year in passengers served in May.

site_title: New fee benchmarks unlikely to hit private healthcare players; insurance premiums may rise: analysts
summary: New fee benchmarks for private healthcare services in Singapore are unlikely to significantly impact listed healthcare providers, as most have already priced their services within the recommended ranges. The updated benchmarks, released by the Ministry of Health, will help private healthcare providers work with insurers on pricing of premiums, potentially leading to increased insurance premiums. The revised benchmarks cover 1,900 surgical procedures and include recommended costs for room charges, surgical fees, and equipment. While the guidelines are not prescriptive, allowing doctors to charge higher prices, the increased fee benchmarks may lead to higher bill sizes and insurance premiums.

images.alt_text: Raffles Medical located at Raffles Holland V taken on 7 Feb 2018

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singapore Airlines, Sats
summary: Singapore Airlines and Scoot saw a 65.8% year-on-year increase in passengers served in May, with 2.8 million passengers. The national carrier's shares rose 4.1% following the announcement. Sats, the airport service company, also made news after putting three regional chief executives in charge of its gateway services business lines, including its air cargo handler Worldwide Flight Services.

site_title: Will democracies stand up to Big Brother?
summary: The world is rapidly expanding its use of AI-enhanced surveillance technology, threatening democratic values and individual rights. Policymakers must address the issue to prevent a dystopian future. Limiting patents on surveillance technologies and establishing international norms can help strike a balance between benefits and privacy. However, countries like China, which have systematically increased domestic surveillance, are unlikely to cooperate. The global choice is between robust standards governing surveillance or extensive repression by autocratic regimes. Democracies must consider the economic implications of buying goods from countries with questionable surveillance practices, potentially undermining their own democracies.

images.alt_text: The proliferation of AI in our lives and society is bringing up some tough questions about ownership.
Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak  has cast China as the world’s greatest challenge to security and prosperity.

site_title: It’s finally time to buy Japan
summary: Japan's stock market has seen a significant surge, with the Nikkei index reaching a 33-year high. The Tokyo Stock Exchange's efforts to encourage companies to increase their book value ratios have led to a shift in investor sentiment. Around 50% of Japan's companies trade on a price-to-book ratio of under one, and 25% are on a forward P/E of between 5 and 10. Activist funds and companies are pushing for change, and if successful, this could lead to a rise in the value of these cheap stocks.

images.alt_text: BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda aims to maintain the ultra-loose monetary policy of his predecessor, but the central bank is widely expected to adjust its YCC policy eventually.
The trading houses have been renewing record highs since Warren Buffett says in April that he’s raises his holdings in them and is looking to increase his exposure to stocks in Japan.
Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc

site_title: Of stories, songs, skills and shamans
summary: Four indigenous children survived 40 days in the Amazon jungle after their small plane crashed, killing three adults, including their mother. The children's survival can be attributed to their traditional knowledge and adaptive skills passed down through generations by indigenous people. They learned essential skills such as navigating the forest, identifying edible plants and animals, and building shelters. The children's faith in their grandparents and shamans also played a crucial role in their survival, with the community performing rituals to communicate with protective spirits. However, the loss of traditional knowledge and cultural practices is under threat due to land encroachment and state neglect.

images.alt_text: Colombia targets 30% reduction in deforestation
An open-air structure that will help to discover in advance what the future of the biome will be like due to climate change, in Manos, Brazil, 23 May 2023.

site_title: Oil futures up 3% on strong China refinery data, weaker US dollar
summary: Oil futures rose 3% to a one-week high on Thursday, driven by a weaker US dollar and a surge in refinery runs in China. Brent futures reached $75.67 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $70.62 a barrel. A jump in Chinese refinery throughput and expected strong demand in the second half of the year also contributed to the price increase. Analysts expect a supply deficit and higher oil prices in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Oil refineries and tankers at the Houston Ship Channel in La Porte, Texas, Feb 14, 2023. US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude closed US$1.15, or 1.7 per cent, lower at US$68.27.

site_title: Canada’s housing data shows recovery accelerating before rate hike
summary: Canada's housing market showed signs of recovery in May, with home sales rising 5.1% from April and 1.4% year-over-year, the first annual increase since June 2021. The Canadian Real Estate Association's Home Price Index edged up 2.1% monthly and 3.2% annually. A healthy job market and population growth contributed to the recovery, but the Bank of Canada's recent interest rate hike may slow construction activity and hinder government plans to reduce housing shortages.

site_title: Mercedes drivers can soon turn to ChatGPT for voice control
summary: Mercedes-Benz has announced a test program allowing US drivers to power some of their luxury vehicles with ChatGPT, a popular chatbot, starting June 16. Compatible with around 900,000 vehicles, ChatGPT will provide natural-sounding responses and allow drivers to ask for destination information or other queries. The test, lasting three months, will inform Mercedes' plans for adding artificial intelligence to other countries and languages. The partnership with Microsoft, the creator of ChatGPT, will also explore integrations for tasks like restaurant reservations and movie ticket bookings.

images.alt_text: Quants’ focus on advanced artificial intelligence to aid decision-making comes amid a tough investment environment.
The advent of ChatGPT-powered trading algorithms and similar programs could worsen the problem of too many traders on the same side of a deal.

site_title: US judge considers whether Terraform Labs’ cryptocurrencies were securities
summary: A US judge is considering whether Terraform Labs' cryptocurrencies, including TerraUSD and Luna, were securities, a key issue in the SEC's fraud case against the company and its founder Do Kwon. The judge questioned whether the offering of the Anchor protocol, which offered high returns, should be considered a security. Terraform Labs and Kwon argue the case should be dismissed, claiming the digital assets do not fit the definition of securities. The judge will rule on the motion to dismiss the case by July 14.

images.alt_text: Binance.US and Coinbase Global are the latest crypto exchanges to come under scrutiny after the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) sued the pair for allegedly breaching its rules, and industry executives expect more enforcement actions.
On Tuesday, Binance.US and the SEC agreed to work on a deal that avoids a total asset freeze at the cryptocurrency trading platform.

Sam Bankman-Fried, who faces 13 charges tied to the collapse of FTX, challenged five of the counts because he says they weren’t covered by an extradition agreement that paved the way for his return to the US last December to face prosecution for an alleged multibillion fraud.

site_title: Richard Branson’s Virgin Galactic sets June date for first commercial spaceflight
summary: Richard Branson's Virgin Galactic plans to fly its first commercial passenger space mission, Galactic 01, as soon as June 27, marking the beginning of commercial operations after numerous delays. The flight will include researchers and will be followed by a second commercial flight, Galactic 02, in early August. The company has already received deposits from 800 people from 66 countries, who are eagerly awaiting their chance to fly on the company's spaceplane VSS Unity out of Spaceport America in New Mexico.

images.alt_text: The troubled CST-100 Starliner program was finally meant to send humans on a test flight to the International Space Station on July 21.

Virgin Galactic hasn’t been into space since July 2021, when the company famously flew its billionaire founder and five other company employees to the edge of space using its passenger rocket plane, the VSS Unity (above).

site_title: Darker economic outlook after Singapore key exports’ surprise 14.7% drop in May: economists
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined 14.7% in May, exceeding economists' median forecast of a 7.7% drop. This marks the eighth consecutive month of decline, with electronics and non-electronics exports continuing to contract year-over-year. Economists predict a double-digit contraction for May's industrial production and a 1.4% year-on-year fall in Q2 GDP, with a heightened risk of a technical recession. Key exports to the EU and South Korea contracted in May, while shipments to China and the US grew.

images.alt_text: A pilot boat sails past container vessels at Pasir Panjang port terminal in Singapore on January 3, 2023 (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: Binance.US cuts jobs in anticipation of costly SEC fight
summary: Binance.US, the US affiliate of Binance Holdings, has laid off an unspecified number of employees ahead of a costly legal battle with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) over allegations of mishandling customer funds and securities rules. The company agreed to work with the SEC to avoid a total asset freeze, which would have put it out of business. Binance.US is preparing for a multi-year and costly litigation process, citing the need to "shrink the size of teams" across the company.

images.alt_text: The UK-based lenders and the Bank of China were questioned by the HKMA last month on why crypto exchanges were not being accepted as clients.
The SEC sought the asset freeze last week for Binance.US, a trading platform owned by Binance Holdings founder Changpeng Zhao.
The SEC last week widened its crackdown on the crypto industry through a one-two punch against the biggest firms, Binance Holdings and Coinbase.

The SEC launched lawsuits last week against market leaders Binance Holdings and Coinbase Global, and flagged a number of altcoins as unregistered securities, including SOL and ADA.

site_title: SGX RegCo appoints new chairman, members for disciplinary committee
summary: SGX Regulation (SGX RegCo) has appointed Lok Vi Ming as chairman of its disciplinary committee, replacing Cavinder Bull after six years. Lok, a lawyer with over 30 years of experience, will be joined by Vincent Leow, Eunice Chua, and Prof Eleanor Wong as new members. The committee will hear charges brought by SGX RegCo against persons who breach SGX rules and impose sanctions, including fines and public reprimands. Two new members, Chua and Prof Wong, have also been appointed to the Appeals Committee.

images.alt_text: Jadason Enterprises will have to meet requirements under Rule 1314(1) of the Listing Manual to be removed from the watch-list within 36 months from Jun 6.

site_title: Bankman-Fried prosecutors ask judge to set aside some charges
summary: US District Judge Lewis Kaplan granted a request from federal prosecutors to separate five charges against Sam Bankman-Fried, who faces 13 charges tied to the collapse of FTX, due to an unresolved dispute over his extradition from the Bahamas. Bankman-Fried challenged these charges, claiming they weren't covered by an extradition agreement that allowed him to return to the US last December. The separation avoids a potential legal fight that could have delayed his trial, set to begin in October.

images.alt_text: FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried and several company insiders have been indicted on fraud charges for their role in the company’s collapse.
3AC co-founder Zhu Su
US regulators including the SEC agree that Bitcoin, which is by far the largest digital asset, isn’t a security.
FCA research shows that estimated crypto ownership has more than doubled from 2021 to 2022, with 10 per cent of 2,000 people surveyed stating they own crypto assets.
In the longer term, Coinbase is facing a bigger hit should the SEC’s lawsuit prevail.
Coinbase CEO Brian Armstrong’s net worth has slumped by US$361 million to US$2.2 billion.
Bitcoin, the world’s largest cryptocurrency, was last at US$25,797, up 0.2 per cent in Asian trade on Tuesday, pinned near a more than two-month low.

site_title: Krayon timepieces turn maths into haute horology
summary: Swiss watchmaker Remi Maillot's company, Krayon, has created a highly complex timepiece called "Everywhere" that tells when the sun rises and sets anywhere in the world. Launched in 2017, the 42mm watch features a 595-part automatic movement and took a year to produce. Only eight pieces have been made and sold so far, with a price tag of around S$1 million. Krayon has since shifted its focus to a simpler version, "Anywhere," which can be set to tell sunrise and sunset times in any location, priced around S$200,000, and plans to produce 35 pieces this year.

images.alt_text: While launched as “new to the Black Bay line”, the Black Bay 54 is actually a downsized version of the Black Bay Fifty-Eight introduced in 2018.

site_title: Cheap ‘like cabbage’ apartments in some Chinese cities draw buyers, and caution
summary: Chinese residents are buying low-cost apartments in smaller cities, with prices plummeting by 27% in some areas. Buyers, mostly from outside the cities, are drawn to these affordable options, including speculators, young people seeking a "lie flat" lifestyle, and retirees. Despite the Chinese economy's struggles, these purchases indicate a small corner of the sector is showing signs of life. Experts caution, however, that these transactions reflect caution and a lack of confidence in the future income.

images.alt_text: A pedestrian crosses a road in front of residential buildings in Beijing, China, on Friday, Nov. 25, 2016. Home prices in first-tier and red-hot second-tier cities "apparently" stabilized in the second half of October after those regions announced fine-tuned curbs, the National Bureau of Statistics said. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
Retail sales – a key gauge of consumer confidence – rose 12.7 per cent, missing forecasts of 13.6 per cent growth and slowing from April’s 18.4 per cent.
The property slump has broad ramifications for the economy.
The People's Bank of China cut a key interest rate and injected US$33 billion into financial markets on Thursday, as data showed the world’s second-largest economy was flagging.
High youth joblessness has weighed on consumer confidence, as households have chosen to repay their debt early to reduce risks.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip after ECB rate hike
summary: European shares declined 0.1% on Thursday, following the European Central Bank's 25 basis point interest rate hike to 3.5%, its highest level in 22 years. The move aims to combat sticky inflation in the euro zone, which stands at 6.1%. Markets await further economic data and central bank updates to break out of a trading range.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.3 per cent to 34,408.06 on Thursday.

site_title: US: Stocks rally as market bets Federal Reserve could be done hiking
summary: US stocks rose 1.3% to 34,408.06 on Thursday, following a day after the Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged but signaled further hikes in 2023. Despite Fed forecasts, Treasury yields pulled back, indicating skepticism about future rate increases. Analysts attribute the market's optimism to the stock market's lack of faith in the Fed's ability to raise rates. Retail sales in May rose 0.3% to $686.6 billion, with petrol station sales falling but rising in other venues. The European Central Bank also raised interest rates for the eighth consecutive time.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., May 30, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: US factory output edges up, helped by motor vehicle production
summary: US factory output edged up 0.1% in May, driven by increases in motor vehicle, electronic equipment, and appliance production, but was still sluggish due to cautious manufacturers amid tepid global demand and equipment spending. Total industrial production, including mining and utilities, fell 0.2%. Consumer spending on merchandise rose 0.3% in May, despite challenges such as stricter lending standards and higher rates.

site_title: Restaurant chain Cava valued at US$4.7 billion as shares pop on debut
summary: Restaurant chain Cava Group debuted on the New York Stock Exchange, valuing the company at $4.7 billion. The company sold 14.4 million shares, raising $318 million, and its shares opened at $42, above the IPO price of $22. This marks a rebound in the IPO market after a lull in 2022, with the Renaissance IPO Index rising 30% this year. Cava was founded in 2006 and is owned by three friends with Greek roots.

site_title: Manchester United negotiating exclusivity with Qatar’s Sheikh Jassim in US$6 billion-plus sale talks: sources
summary: Manchester United is in talks with Qatar's Sheikh Jassim bin Hamad al-Thani to sell the club for over $6 billion, with a proposed exclusivity deal. The Glazer family, who own minority stakes, would cash out as part of the deal. The Qatari offer is seen as more favorable than a bid from British billionaire Jim Ratcliffe. Manchester United shares jumped nearly 15% on the news before paring some gains. The deal would be one of the largest sports transactions ever, surpassing the Washington Commanders sale earlier this year.

site_title: Vietnam automaker VinFast seeks breakthrough in South-east Asia’s EV market
summary: Vietnam's VinFast plans to expand its electric vehicle (EV) market presence in South-east Asia, targeting countries such as Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia. The company aims to sell up to 50,000 EVs globally in 2023, with a focus on regional growth. Despite past setbacks in the US market, VinFast expects to break even by 2024 and be profitable the year after. The company's regional expansion is seen as crucial to achieving its growth goals, with Vietnam expected to remain its main market. VinFast plans to introduce right-hand steering versions of its EV models to cater to regional buyers.

images.alt_text: VinFast’s SPAC deal is expected to close in the second half of 2023.

site_title: Stellantis Ventures spends first 100 million euros on green drive
summary: Stellantis Ventures, the carmaker's green drive investment arm, has spent around 100 million euros in its first round of investments, using roughly a third of its initial 300 million euros. The investments support 10 start-ups and one mobility venture fund, including companies like Nauto, Trails Offroad, and Lyten, which will integrate their products into Stellantis' ecosystem from 2024. The investments align with Stellantis' 2030 goals to reduce carbon transport.

site_title: Messi mania in Miami has US$2,600 soccer tickets rivalling Taylor Swift
summary: Lionel Messi's upcoming debut with Inter Miami has sparked a surge in ticket prices, rivaling those of Taylor Swift's concert tickets. Average resale prices for Messi's potential debut on July 21 are around $2,600, while tickets for Swift's Eras Tour cost $2,625. Limited supply, combined with high demand, is driving the price increase, with season ticket holders considering cashing in on their investments. The cheapest ticket for Messi's debut is over $950, and prices for the July 4 match against Columbus Crew start at $29.

images.alt_text: The Zurich-based organisation is bolstering its presence ahead of the 2026 World Cup when Miami and 15 cities across the US, Mexico and Canada host games.
Chinese fans have been desperate to get close to their hero Messi, with tickets for the game ranging from 580 to 4,800 yuan quickly selling out.
This is the Argentina captain’s seventh visit to China and his first since 2017.

A mural of Argentine football player Lionel Messi in Miami on June 7, 2023. Messi on Wednesday announced he will sign for Major League Soccer side Inter Miami, spurning talk of a Barcelona reunion or Saudi Arabian blockbuster deal.

site_title: Once Upon a Times House … Singapore’s veteran editors, journalists tell their stories
summary: Veteran Singaporean editors and journalists share their stories in the book "Once Upon a Times House," which showcases the history of Singapore's English- and Malay-language press. The book, launched on June 23, aims to inspire young journalists and highlight the transformative years of leading newspapers. Copies will be distributed for free to secondary schools and institutes of higher learning, with proceeds going towards the Business Times Budding Artists Fund, supporting financially disadvantaged youth in the arts.

images.alt_text: From left:  BT Editor Chen Huifen, Standard Chartered Bank, Tan Wei Zhi, Regional Head of Impact & Engagement, Singapore & Asia
Launched on Sunday (Jan 8), the AEAS Fun Club features arts and creative activities.

site_title: BOE issues fresh warning over risks in pension transfers
summary: The Bank of England's Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) has issued a warning to life insurers about the risks of "funded reinsurance," a practice where insurers pay upfront to transfer pensioner longevity risk to another firm. The PRA warns that if a major reinsurer fails, the original insurer may be left with sub-optimal portfolios and exposed to significant risks. The warning comes as £44.7 billion of pension risks were transferred to insurers last year, highlighting the need for improved risk management.

site_title: EU to ban Huawei, ZTE from internal commission networks
summary: The European Commission plans to ban equipment from Chinese vendors Huawei and ZTE from its internal telecommunications networks due to security concerns. This move comes ahead of an update to the EU's 5G guidance, which will encourage member states to phase out equipment from the companies considered high risk. The commission will explicitly call out Huawei and ZTE as high-risk vendors by name for the first time. This decision follows similar actions taken by countries blocking Chinese technology from their core networks due to spying concerns.

site_title: Euro hits 15-year peak against yen after ECB raises rates
summary: The euro reached a 15-year peak against the yen, hitting 153.39 yen, after the European Central Bank (ECB) raised interest rates by 25 basis points to 3.5%, its eighth consecutive increase, to combat eurozone inflation. The ECB also revised its inflation forecast for this year to 5.1%, higher than expected. The euro's appreciation against the US dollar was attributed to the ECB's hawkish stance, with short-term interest rates moving higher, and the market interpreting this as a sign of further tightening.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index – which measures the performance of the US currency against six others – dips 0.2 per cent to 103.14, after touching its lowest since May 22 overnight at 103.04.

site_title: US retail sales up in May; weekly jobless claims unchanged
summary: US retail sales rose 0.3% in May, driven by motor vehicle purchases and other goods, exceeding economists' expectations. Despite inflation and higher interest rates, spending has remained resilient due to strong wage gains and tight labor market. The Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, anticipating further rate increases this year. The unemployment rate rose to a seven-month high of 3.7% in May, but remains low by historical standards.

images.alt_text: NOVATO, CALIFORNIA - APRIL 07: A customer walks by a now hiring sign posted in front of a Ross Dress For Less store on April 07, 2023 in Novato, California. The U.S. labor market added 236,000 jobs in March bringing the national unemployment rate down to 3.5 percent. (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: ‘No impediment’ to CEO retaining role amid police probe: board of Singapore Kitchen Equipment
summary: Singapore Kitchen Equipment's board sees no impediment to CEO Sally Chua and senior manager Charlene Koh remaining in their roles amid a police probe by the Commercial Affairs Department. The investigation, into potential Penal Code offences, arose from a fact-finding review that found employees altered documents without instructions. Chua and Koh were released on bail, with their passports surrendered, and have been told no charges have been made against them. The board cited strengthened internal controls and lack of conclusive evidence as reasons to let them keep their positions, but may revise their assessment if further developments occur.

images.alt_text: Singapore Kitchen Equipment was founded by husband-and-wife duo Sally Chua and Alan Lee.
Singapore Kitchen Equipment was founded by husband-and-wife duo Sally Chua Chwee Choo and Alan Lee Chong Hoe.

site_title: Japan to give Toyota 120 billion yen support for domestic EV battery output: Nikkei
summary: Japan will provide Toyota with around 120 billion yen (S$1.1 billion) in support for its domestic production of lithium-ion batteries for electric vehicles. The government aims to secure supply chains away from China, a major player in EV batteries. The move is part of a broader effort to promote domestic battery production, with the government designating storage batteries as critical to economic security. Toyota's total project cost is estimated to reach 330 billion yen, with the government covering a third of capital expenditure and half of technological development.

site_title: Singapore says it takes climate action ‘seriously’, following ESG blacklist by asset manager
summary: Singapore's government has reiterated its commitment to climate action, despite being blacklisted by Dutch asset manager Van Lanschot Kempen over environmental concerns. The country aims to quadruple solar panel deployment and achieve a 3% solar energy share by 2030. Singapore has also pledged to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050 and implemented a broad-based carbon tax, covering 80% of its greenhouse gas emissions. The government disputes Kempen's assertion that the share of renewables in Singapore's energy mix fell between 2016 and 2021, citing an increase in solar energy during this period.

images.alt_text: Singapore’s small landmass has left it with limited options when it comes to building renewable energy infrastructure.

site_title: Philippines says China’s Yadea to invest US$1 billion in e-motorcycle plant
summary: China's Yadea Group Holdings plans to invest approximately $1 billion in an e-motorcycle factory in the Philippines, with an annual production capacity of 3-5 million units. The factory, located in Batangas, aims to cater to domestic demand and potentially export to other countries. The Philippines is trying to attract foreign direct investment, particularly from electric vehicle manufacturers, through tax perks and faster permit processing. This investment comes as the country targets a 10% increase in investment approvals this year.

site_title: Crypto investors step up risk management after last year’s meltdowns
summary: Crypto investors are becoming more cautious in their dealings after last year's market meltdowns, with institutional investors prioritizing exchanges with stronger asset protection and due diligence. Binance.US and Coinbase Global are under scrutiny after the US SEC sued them for allegedly breaching rules, and industry executives expect more enforcement actions. To mitigate risk, investors are executing trades in smaller chunks, removing assets from exchanges, and opting for off-exchange settlement solutions, with some companies even halting dollar deposits on Binance's US affiliate.

images.alt_text: Sam Bankman-Fried, who faces 13 charges tied to the collapse of FTX, challenged five of the counts because he says they weren’t covered by an extradition agreement that paved the way for his return to the US last December to face prosecution for an alleged multibillion fraud.
FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried and several company insiders have been indicted on fraud charges for their role in the company’s collapse.
3AC co-founder Zhu Su
US regulators including the SEC agree that Bitcoin, which is by far the largest digital asset, isn’t a security.

site_title: Sats’ gateway services to be helmed by three regional CEOs
summary: SATS is appointing three regional CEOs to lead its gateway services business lines, including Worldwide Flight Services (WFS). Bob Chi will oversee Hong Kong and Singapore WFS operations, while John Batten leads Europe, Africa, and other regions. Mike Simpson oversees US, Canada, and Brazil operations. The company also announced two key executive appointments, including Henry Low as chief operating officer and Tan Chee-Wei as chief human capital officer. These changes aim to facilitate a "global model" for operating and managing gateway services.

images.alt_text: Sats recorded a net profit of S$6 million in the second half of FY2023.
Sats' group management board will oversee the company's global business, which is spread over more than 20 countries.

site_title: PE firm ChrysCapital to invest US$100 million in India’s Lenskart
summary: Private equity firm ChrysCapital is set to invest $100 million in Indian eyewear brand Lenskart, bringing the company's total capital infusion to nearly $850 million in the past year. This investment follows previous investments from sovereign wealth fund Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, US private equity firm KKR, Japan's SoftBank Group, and Singapore state investor Temasek. The deal values Lenskart at $4.5 billion, expanding the company's presence in Asia and the US, with approximately 2,000 stores across 10 countries, addressing a global market of around $20 billion.

site_title: Over half of Singaporeans rely on social media to discover new restaurants: study
summary: Singaporeans heavily rely on social media and personal referrals when discovering new restaurants, with 71% using personal referrals and 52% using restaurant profiles on social media. The most prominent social media channels for restaurant discovery are Facebook, Instagram, and TikTok. Convenience, cuisine, and personal referrals are the top factors for Singaporeans when dining at a new restaurant. When making reservations, Singaporeans prefer booking directly with a restaurant through its website, phone call, or in person, citing factors such as seating location, dining experience, and complimentary drinks.

site_title: North Korea fires two short-range missiles after warning of response to allied drills
summary: North Korea fired two short-range missiles off its east coast, landing in waters within Japan's exclusive economic zone, following a warning of an "inevitable" response to military drills by South Korean and US troops. The latest action comes amid stalled diplomatic efforts to reduce tensions and persuade Pyongyang to abandon its nuclear arsenal. The missiles were launched as US President Joe Biden's national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, was in Tokyo for meetings with Japanese and South Korean counterparts.

images.alt_text: North Korea’s Kim Yo Jong, leader Kim Jong Un’s sister, said her country’s military spy satellite will soon enter into orbit and promised Pyongyang will increase military surveillance, state media KCNA reported on Thursday.

site_title: US import prices drop in May on energy, food
summary: US import prices dropped 0.6% in May, marking the sharpest annual decline since May 2020, with energy and food costs declining after increasing in April. This is the fourth consecutive month of annual import price declines, providing a boost to the Federal Reserve in its fight against inflation. Import prices excluding fuel and food edged up 0.1%, while export prices fell 1.9% and plummeted 10.1% year-over-year.

images.alt_text: The producer price index for final demand dropped 0.3 per cent last month on lower energy costs after rising by an unrevised 0.2 per cent in April, the Labor Department said on Wednesday.

site_title: Ringgit weakens to record RM3.45 against Singapore dollar, but could rebound soon
summary: The Malaysian ringgit hit a record low of RM3.45 against the Singapore dollar, weakening 8.5% from a year ago and 4.2% since the start of the year. Analysts attribute this to outflows of foreign funds due to weak local market sentiment and domestic issues, including slower-than-expected economic data and a declining trade surplus. Despite some forecasts predicting a rebound by the end of the year, the ringgit is expected to continue falling before improving, with some predicting a potential rebound towards RM4 by the end of 2023.

images.alt_text: The ringgit has declined nearly 4 per cent year-to-date, from RM3.29 on Jan 1, 2023.

site_title: The best books on fatherhood
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The article features 10 book recommendations for Father's Day, celebrating the art and joy of parenting. The books cover various aspects of fatherhood, including parenting styles, masculinity, and relationships. The list includes classics like "Letters to My Son" by Kent Nerburn and "The Book of Dads" edited by Ben George, as well as more contemporary titles like "The Daily Dad" by Ryan Holiday and "Sh*t My Dad Says" by Justin Halpern. The books offer wisdom, humor, and insights into the complexities of fatherhood, making them great reads for new and experienced dads alike.

images.alt_text: Banyan Tree Group founder and executive chairman Ho Kwon Ping, who turns 71 in August, takes the approach of “leaving nothing unresolved by the time you die”
HBO's Succession series, starring Brian Cox and Matthew Macfadyen, illustrates how wealthy families can lose it all - by doing what Cox' character Logan Roy has done.

site_title: ECB raises rates to 22-year high and signals more to come
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) raised interest rates to a 22-year high of 3.5% and signaled further policy tightening to combat high inflation. The 4 percentage point increase in borrowing costs in a year is the fastest pace on record. ECB President Christine Lagarde stated that conditions in the economy are uneven, with manufacturing weakening but services remaining resilient. The bank aims to achieve a timely return to inflation of 2% and will continue to increase rates in July and possibly September.

images.alt_text: The ECB’s most recent forecasts put it at 2.2 per cent in 2025.

site_title: Audi chief sets sights on China in electric car catch-up
summary: Audi CEO Markus Duesmann says the company needs to accelerate development of new electric vehicle models to meet growing demand, especially in China, where the brand has lagged behind rivals BMW and Mercedes-Benz. Audi aims to reduce development time to 30 months, down from 48 months, and introduce over 20 new models by 2025, with half powered by electric motors. The company also plans to strengthen its presence in North America, where it sees a strong market and generous subsidies.

site_title: Progressive Wage Model for waste management sector kicks in Jul 1
summary: The Progressive Wage Model (PWM) for the waste management sector in Singapore comes into effect on July 1, providing sustained wage increases for up to 3,000 workers over six years. As part of the model, workers must attend skills upgrading courses. Firms like Impetus Conceptus have already raised lower-wage workers' salaries, citing the need to retain staff due to high attrition rates. The PWM aims to support career progression and improve working conditions for lower-wage workers, with Senior Minister of State for Manpower Zaqy Mohamad noting that it is the last in a planned series of PWMs for the sector.

images.alt_text: Higher pay, career pathways for up to 3,000 workers with Progressive Wage Model for waste management sector

site_title: German economy to shrink in 2023: economic institutes
summary: Germany's economy is expected to contract by 0.2% in 2023 due to inflation and higher interest rates, according to two economic institutes. The Berlin-based DIW institute and IfW Kiel institute revised down their forecasts, citing a mild recession in 2022 and 2023. However, strong wage growth and slowing inflation are expected to drive a recovery in the later half of the year, with modest growth predicted for 2024, ranging from 1.5% to 1.8%. The path of inflation in the coming months will be crucial to offsetting the winter surprise.

images.alt_text: German inflation, harmonised to compare with other European Union countries, eased to its lowest level in more than a year in May.

(FILES) This file photo taken on April 29, 2020 shows a customer wearing a face mask doing her shopping in a supermarket in Duesseldorf, western Germany. - Inflation will keep rising in Germany in the year 2023 while the economy goes into recession, as the soaring price of energy weighs on households and businesses, the country's leading economic institutes said in a forecast published on September 29, 2022. (Photo by Ina FASSBENDER / AFP)
“Despite a weak economy, the labour market is steady overall,” said Daniel Terzenbach, head of the regions at the Labour Office.

site_title: Alibaba president says group will expand local business in Europe
summary: Alibaba Group, led by President J Michael Evans, plans to expand its local business in Europe by adapting its TMall platform to serve local brands and customers. The company has already started a pilot project in Spain and aims to expand across Europe. This move focuses on building local businesses, distinct from its existing operations in China, to cater to the growing demand for e-commerce services in the region.

site_title: Alliance Global looks to expand casinos beyond Manila
summary: Alliance Global Group, a Philippine investment company, plans to expand its casino resorts beyond Manila to capitalize on growing tourism areas. The company aims to increase premium mass-market gamblers to half of gross-gaming revenue and expand VIP junket operations. Travellers International Hotel, Alliance's gaming venture, returned to profitability in 2022 with a record gross-gaming revenue. The company's expansion plans come as the government considers selling state-owned casinos and China's crackdown on Macau affects the region's gaming sector.

images.alt_text: Macau’s tourism has started ramping up since China's reopening, returning to 66 per cent of the pre-Covid level in April as the mainland resumed international flights.
Casinos along the Cotai strip in Macau, China. Photographer: Eduardo Leal/Bloomberg
The latest casino revenues out of Macau are the highest since January 2020, when the Covid-19 pandemic had yet to fully grip China.

site_title: UK’s biggest fund manager expands assets blacklist due to climate concerns
summary: LGIM, the UK's largest fund manager with $1.5 trillion in assets, has expanded its exclusion list to funds with almost £158 billion due to climate concerns. The list now applies to nearly £158 billion in assets, affecting 99% of its holdings. The move is in response to the need to address unacceptable environmental damage and is in line with the urgent need to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius. LGIM has already divested from Air China and Cosco Shipping Holdings.

site_title: SIA, Scoot flew 2.8 million passengers in May, up 66% on year
summary: SIA and its budget carrier Scoot served 2.8 million passengers in May, a 65.8% year-on-year increase. Scoot flew over 1 million passengers, more than double from last year. Passenger traffic and load factors were robust across all route regions, with Scoot's PLF at 90.7% and SIA's at 87.2%. The companies' passenger networks expanded, covering 114 destinations in 36 countries and territories, with SIA serving 74 and Scoot serving 63.

images.alt_text: OCBC cautions that much of SIA’s recovery has already been priced in its stock due to its first-mover advantage.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower on concerns over hawkish Fed
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Dow Jones falling 33.35 points, or 0.10%, to 33,945.98, as investors reacted to the Federal Reserve's signal that interest rates may rise further this year. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also retreated from 14-month highs, with the S&P 500 opening 7.26 points lower, or 0.17%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 53.60 points, or 0.39%. The decline follows recent market highs and amid concerns over hawkish Fed policies.

site_title: Japan's Kishida says he won't dissolve Diet, ending snap election talk for now
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced he won't dissolve the Diet, ruling out a snap election for now. The decision comes amid speculation that Kishida might dissolve Parliament to solidify his power within the ruling party. Kishida cited the current session of the Diet, set to end on June 21, as a reason for his decision. The opposition had planned to submit a no-confidence vote, but Kishida instructed his party to vote against it, rendering the motion symbolic. An election for the lower house is not due until 2025.

images.alt_text: Japan’s consumer price index rose 4.3 per cent in January from a year earlier, the fastest gain in 41 years.

site_title: China unveils plan to modernise more farm facilities by 2030
summary: China has unveiled a plan to modernize 40% of its vegetable farms and 60% of its aquaculture facilities by 2030, aiming to boost food output and ensure safe and stable supplies. The plan, which runs from 2023 to 2030, targets the use of digital solutions and advanced equipment. Funding details are not provided, but the move follows significant investment in China's indoor farming sector, which was highlighted by the challenges during the Covid pandemic. The plan aims to improve food production and security, but the funding mechanism is unclear.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An employee picks out bad beans from a pile of soybeans at a supermarket in Wuhan, Hubei province April 14, 2014. REUTERS/Stringer

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's job market shows signs of easing with a fourth consecutive quarter of falling job vacancies, reaching 99,600 in March. The ratio of job vacancies to unemployed persons remains high at 2.28. Meanwhile, private home sales rose 17% in May compared to April, and Siemens plans to invest €200 million (S$290.6 million) in a new factory, creating over 400 jobs.

site_title: Health screenings meet exercise and wellness in Minmed’s offering at Jewel
summary: Minmed Group, a GP clinic chain, has launched a wellness initiative at Jewel Changi Airport, offering health screenings and fitness classes. The 1,500-square-foot health screening centre features seven plush suites and offers non-fasting tests for blood cholesterol and diabetes screenings, with results available the next working day. The centre also hosts fitness classes, including rhythmic cycling, yoga, barre, and Pilates, at iconic locations in Jewel. The goal is to provide comprehensive health screening services and connect people with activities and services that improve their health and well-being, aligning with Singapore's Healthier SG strategy.

site_title: India’s Go First Airlines hopes to resume daily flights by end of June
summary: Go First Airlines, which filed for bankruptcy protection in May, plans to resume daily flights by the end of June, aiming to restore 94% of its original 167 daily flights to 157. The airline is awaiting regulator approval and creditor funding to recover from engine issues that grounded its fleet. With 22 aircraft deployed and a reduced pilot force, Go First hopes to revive operations in the next two weeks, focusing on high-demand routes like Srinagar, Delhi, and Leh.

images.alt_text: The low-cost carrier, recently rebranded as Go First, was plunged into financial crisis this year, sparked by what it called “faulty” Pratt & Whitney engines that grounded about half its 54 Airbus A320neos.

site_title: Sri Lanka's economy shrinks 11.5% in Q1 as financial crisis continues
summary: Sri Lanka's economy shrank 11.5% in Q1 due to high inflation, high interest rates, and restrictions on imports. The country's central bank projects a 2% GDP contraction this year, while the IMF estimates a 3% contraction. The agriculture sector grew 0.8%, while industries contracted 23.4% and services dropped 5%. The central bank recently slashed interest rates to stimulate the economy, expecting growth to turn positive in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Visitors to the Asian nation have risen, with tourism receipts estimated to have gained 18 per cent to US$696 million in January to April from a year ago.

site_title: Singapore stocks gain on Thursday as Fed pauses rate hikes; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.8% on Thursday as the US Federal Reserve paused rate hikes, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,242.85 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 352 to 219, driven by shares of Singapore Airlines, Keppel Corp, and Mapletree Logistics Trust. The Fed signaled potential future rate hikes, citing improving growth data and decelerating inflation.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.4 per cent higher at 34,212.12 on Tuesday.

site_title: Siemens to invest 200 million euros in new Singapore plant, create over 400 jobs
summary: Siemens to invest 200 million euros in a new high-tech factory in Singapore, creating over 400 jobs. The plant will showcase digitalization possibilities and incorporate highly-automated manufacturing processes, serving growing demand from South-east Asia and beyond. The investment is part of a two billion euro expansion plan, focusing on manufacturing capacity and research and design in Asia.

images.alt_text: The results of Siemens, whose sensors, controllers and software are used in factories, transport systems and buildings, are seen as indicators for the health of the broader industrial economy.
Many OT systems are highly complex and consist of segregated technology.

There's been a carefully constructed narrative around technology, one of techno-optimism : invent as much as you can, and good things – higher wages, better health, and more opportunity – will follow. Not so.
While Google has previously introduced AI tools for advertisers, it is now using the technology to help brands achieve more specific goals for their ads.

site_title: India trade gap widens in May as weaker global demand drags
summary: India's trade deficit widened in May to $22.12 billion, the widest in five months, due to a 10.3% decline in exports to $34.98 billion, mainly due to sluggish demand from major buyers overseas. Imports fell 6.6% to $57.10 billion. The services sector is providing some reprieve, with information technology and business consulting work driving exports to $25.3 billion. The wider trade gap poses a risk for the nation's current account deficit and investor sentiment.

site_title: Odey funds, staff hunt for new home as crisis engulfs firm
summary: Odey Asset Management, a London-based investment firm, is in advanced discussions to transfer its funds and some staff to other asset managers due to the crisis triggered by sexual assault allegations against its founder, Crispin Odey. The firm's assets are managed by portfolio managers other than Odey, and several funds were renamed to remove his name. Odey Asset Management stated that any sale or rehousing would be subject to regulatory approval, following the termination of its banking relationships and investor redemption requests.

images.alt_text: Hedge fund founder Crispin Odey leaving Westminster Magistrates' Court, after being found not guilty of indecent assault, during a three-day-long trial in London on March 11, 2021.
The FT reports that 13 women allege hedge fund manager Crispin Odey has sexually assaulted or harassed them over a 25-year period.

site_title: Asia-Pacific office market to improve further, more resilient than global peers: reports
summary: Asia-Pacific office market occupancy levels average 80%, surpassing Europe's 65% and North America's 50%. Peaking interest rates in the second half of 2023 are expected to boost investor confidence, with office investment volumes holding steady. Markets such as Singapore and Seoul show strong fundamentals, with decreasing vacancy rates and record net absorption. Office-focused real estate investment trusts (Reits) in the region are expected to be more resilient than their global peers, with only three out of 15 rated Reits having negative rating outlooks.

images.alt_text: Tommy Leung, co-head of global family and institutional wealth Apac, UBS Global Wealth Management said investors like setting up family offices in Singapore as they feel comfortable in the country.
coins, banknotes, money

site_title: China’s property investment slump deepens; home demand weak
summary: China's property investment declined 7.2% in the first five months of 2023, worse than expected, and home prices gained only 0.1% in May. The property market remains in a "slow recovery," with developers focusing on existing projects and still needing policy support. China is considering stimulus measures to boost the sector, which is crucial for economic growth. The property slump has broader economic implications, affecting employment, supplier payments, and developer debt restructuring. Policymakers expect the sector to gradually stabilize with supportive policies and improved market expectations.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China cut a key interest rate and injected US$33 billion into financial markets on Thursday, as data showed the world’s second-largest economy was flagging.
New-home prices in 70 cities, excluding state-subsidised housing, increased 0.1 per cent last month from April.

site_title: Taiwan pauses rate hikes as focus shifts to flagging economy
summary: Taiwan's central bank maintained its benchmark rate at 1.875% for the first time since December 2021, pausing rate hikes to focus on the flagging economy. Officials downgraded their growth forecast to 1.72% due to weak exports and investment. The decision comes after the Federal Reserve held rates steady and lower-than-expected inflation data for May eased pressure for another rate hike. Taiwan's economy is in recession, shrinking 2.9% in the first quarter, and policymakers prioritize economic growth over inflation.

site_title: China bookings to return to pre-pandemic level by early 2024: Agoda
summary: China's overseas travel bookings are nearing pre-pandemic levels, with Agoda predicting they will return to 2019 numbers by the end of 2023 or early 2024. Following China's removal of pandemic restrictions, travel to destinations like Thailand, Hong Kong, and Phuket has seen a significant boost. Thailand's tourism industry, which accounted for 12% of the economy before the pandemic, is expected to receive 30 million foreign arrivals this year, with 5 million from China. Bookings have fully recovered for Thailand, but potential growth is seen with tourists from India and South Korea.

images.alt_text: Retail sales – a key gauge of consumer confidence – rose 12.7 per cent, missing forecasts of 13.6 per cent growth and slowing from April’s 18.4 per cent.
The People's Bank of China cut a key interest rate and injected US$33 billion into financial markets on Thursday, as data showed the world’s second-largest economy was flagging.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei surrenders gains to end lower after four-day rally
summary: Japan's Nikkei index ended 0.05% lower at 33,485.49 after a four-day rally, reversing gains of 6% since the start of the week. The broader Topic index fell 0.2% lower to 2,293.97. Investors locked in profits after the Nikkei's sharp gains, with drug makers and chip-related shares among the worst performers. Foreign investors remained net buyers of Japanese stocks for the 11th straight week, with 1.3 trillion yen (S$12.3 billion) in purchases.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People pass by an electronic screen showing Japan's Nikkei share price index inside a conference hall  in Tokyo, Japan June 14, 2022. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

site_title: ⚰️ RIP corporate ladder, hello non-linear career path
summary: The traditional corporate ladder is becoming obsolete as workers in Singapore increasingly opt for non-linear career paths, with 70% planning to pivot into a new role within 2-3 years. Employers are shifting towards skills-based hiring, valuing relevant skills over experience. To succeed, career pivots require planning, including setting clear goals, developing new skills, and building connections. While non-linear paths are gaining popularity, they're not suitable for everyone, and staying in the same role requires continuous skill development to remain relevant.

site_title: China issues rules on sales of mystery boxes
summary: China's market regulator has issued guidelines to regulate mystery box vendors, banning the sale of items to minors under 8 without guardian consent. The move comes as the fast-growing market, popularized by domestic toy makers like Pop Mart, expands. The guidelines are effective immediately, and Pop Mart's Hong Kong shares rose 1.49% following the announcement. The regulation aims to strengthen compliance management in the thinly regulated market.

site_title: Regional markets mixed as US Fed pauses rate hikes but further increases loom
summary: The US Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged but signaled another half-point increase by the end of this year, citing stronger-than-expected economic growth and slower inflation. Regional markets reacted mixedly, with the Hang Seng Index rising 2.2%, while the Nikkei 225 fell 0.1%. Analysts expect a 60% probability of a 25 basis point hike in July, with some favoring dividend-yielding stocks and others expecting economic slowdowns in the US and Asia.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell speaks during a news conference following the Federal Open Market Committee meeting in Washington on Jun 14, 2023.
Fed officials have touted the annual stress tests as a measure of the health and resilience of the country’s biggest banks.
Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, speaks during a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting in Washington, DC, on June 14, 2023.

site_title: South Korea's house price decline in May, softest in 10 months
summary: South Korea's house price index fell 0.22% in May, its softest decline in 10 months, according to the Korea Real Estate Board. This marks a significant slowdown from April's 0.47% loss. The decline is attributed to rising hopes for a market recovery, with some areas experiencing price increases. The central bank's decision to hold interest rates steady has also contributed to the easing of the decline. The government's policy measures, including tax cuts and special loans, aim to engineer a soft-landing of the real estate market.

site_title: Swiss government confirms growth outlook, trims inflation forecast
summary: The Swiss government has confirmed its economic growth outlook, trimming its inflation forecast. This year's growth is expected to slow to 1.1% from 2.0% in 2022, while next year's growth is forecast to be 1.5%. Despite a strong start to 2023, international inflationary pressures and economic risks remain, and the Swiss National Bank may update its economic forecasts soon.

images.alt_text: Speaking less than two weeks before the SNB sets rates at its quarterly meeting, the central banker highlights that “we still have an environment where inflation is too high, and there are relatively widespread price increases”.

site_title: China youth jobless rate hits record 20.8% in challenge for policymakers
summary: China's youth jobless rate reached a record 20.8% in May, four times the overall jobless rate, as the economy's recovery slowed. This has weighed on consumer confidence, prompting households to repay debt early. Policymakers have rolled out measures to promote hiring, including subsidies and financing for key industries. People's Bank of China governor Yi Gang pledged to promote full employment and stabilize the job market. The high youth unemployment rate is a challenge for policymakers, particularly during summer when tens of millions of graduates flood the market.

images.alt_text: People rest on stone barricades on a street, following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Shanghai, China, September 9, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song

site_title: Deutsche Bank poaches London dealmakers from Citigroup, BofA
summary: Deutsche Bank is hiring top dealmakers from Citigroup and Bank of America to rebuild its European mergers and acquisitions franchise. Robert Plowman, Citigroup's co-head of consumer products investment banking, and Siddharth Malik, Bank of America's global co-head of consumer and retail, will join Deutsche Bank in London. Additionally, Credit Suisse bankers William Mansfield and Rumesh Rajendram will also join the bank, with Mansfield becoming vice chairman of EMEA M&A. The hires are part of Deutsche Bank's efforts to strengthen its consumer and retail M&A team.

site_title: Savouring a California wine country far from Napa and the crowds
summary: In California's wine country, a lesser-known region south of Silicon Valley is gaining attention for its quiet, bucolic charm and high-quality wines. Wineries such as Windy Oaks, Sarah's Vineyard, Calerrain Wines, and Lightpost Winery are producing prizewinning chardonnay, pinot noir, and other estate vintages, often made with grapes sourced from nearby regions. Unlike Napa Valley, this region offers a more relaxed atmosphere, with local beekeepers, roadside honey sales, and picturesque vineyards. Visitors can enjoy wine tastings and picnics amidst the rolling hills and scenic views, with some wineries offering interactive experiences and knowledgeable staff.

images.alt_text: The Windy Oaks Estate Vineyard & Winery, in the foothills of the Santa Cruz mountains in Corralitos, Calif., May 30, 2023. A growing patchwork of small and bucolic wineries an hour’s drive south from Silicon Valley are making and serving prizewinning chardonnay, pinot noir and other estate vintages. (Drew Kelly/The New York Times)

Jim Schultze, founder of the Windy Oaks Estate Vineyard & Winery, in the foothills of the Santa Cruz mountains in Corralitos, Calif., May 30, 2023. A growing patchwork of small and bucolic wineries an hour’s drive south from Silicon Valley are making and serving prizewinning chardonnay, pinot noir and other estate vintages. (Drew Kelly/The New York Times)

site_title: New private home sales up 17% in May from April, on the back of a doubling in launches
summary: Singapore saw a 17% increase in private home sales in May, driven by a doubling in launches, with 1,038 units sold. This is the highest monthly number of private homes sold in a year. The Continuum and The Reserve Residences, two freehold projects, accounted for 72.1% of all sales. Foreign buyers declined 47.8% in May due to the ABSD hike, with only 36 units sold. Despite this, demand for new homes remains firm, with 3,181 new private home sales made in the year to date.

images.alt_text: The star attraction at  11 New Bridge Road is the Song Fa Bak Kut Teh outlet which occupies the ground floor.
Generic private properties around Orchard area.
The Business Times' Property Insights newsletter (June 13, 2023)

site_title: Too early to bet against Singapore amid wave of casino openings in Asia: analysts
summary: Singapore's integrated resorts face increased competition from new casino openings in Japan and Thailand, but analysts say it's too early to bet against the city-state. Japanese IRs are expected to target Japanese, Koreans, and northern Chinese, while Thai IRs may attract more Chinese visitors. The Asia-Pacific casino sector is forecast to grow at 3.2% annually from 2022 to 2027. Singapore's market share could be impacted, but analysts point to the country's established reputation, hotel supply, and growing mass market as factors to defend its market share.

images.alt_text: Macau’s tourism has started ramping up since China's reopening, returning to 66 per cent of the pre-Covid level in April as the mainland resumed international flights.
Casinos along the Cotai strip in Macau, China. Photographer: Eduardo Leal/Bloomberg
The latest casino revenues out of Macau are the highest since January 2020, when the Covid-19 pandemic had yet to fully grip China.

site_title: Akio Toyoda approved as Toyota chairman with lower vote
summary: Toyota Motor Chairman Akio Toyoda was reappointed with the lowest shareholder vote since 2010, garnering 84.57% of the vote. The dip in support may indicate frustration among a small minority due to Toyota's slow transition to battery-based electric vehicles. Despite this, Toyoda's "multi-pathway" approach has helped fuel a 15% rally in shares over the past six days, the largest jump since August 2020. Toyoda will continue to lead the company, which aims to sell 1.5 million battery EVs annually by 2026 and 3.5 million by 2030.

images.alt_text: “I believe that Toyota today can manage its business with a sense of speed,” new CEO Koji Sato says.

site_title: Supertanker freight rates jump as Mideast crude exports to Asia rise
summary: Supertanker freight rates have jumped to the highest since April, driven by rising demand for crude oil in Asia ahead of peak summer fuel demand. Chartering costs for Very Large Crude Carriers (VLCCs) from the Middle East to China, Japan, and Singapore have reached worldscale 80, the highest levels since April. This surge in freight rates is attributed to a flurry of bookings, tightened regional ship availability, and a surge in tanker rates from the US Gulf Coast. Rates are expected to continue rising in the coming weeks, driven by an estimated 27.9% increase in US crude arrivals in Asia in June.

site_title: From supersized to superior gratification: A new path for the food industry
summary: A new approach to the food industry, dubbed "epicurean marketing," suggests that focusing on the pleasure of food can encourage consumers to make healthier choices. By shifting from the "food as fuel" model to one that emphasizes pleasure, food companies can incentivize consumers to return to smaller portions. Tactics include changing portion shapes, segmenting portions, branding, and using multi-sensory marketing to evoke pleasure. This approach is seen as a more inclusive and effective way to promote healthier eating habits, as it doesn't rely on income or nutritional labels, but rather on the sensory experience of food.

images.alt_text: “We are very collectivist… that entire mindset fits the group buy mindset,” says Nanyang Business School professor Sharon Ng. “I think the idea that we come together as a community to buy something aligns very much with Asian values.”
How might an epicurean description of a course of beef, shallot marmalade, triple-cooked butter potatoes, sunchoke and creamed watercress, and red wine reduction sauce, influence a diner's appetite?

site_title: UK’s Johnson deliberately misled Parliament: committee report
summary: A UK parliamentary committee report has found that former Prime Minister Boris Johnson deliberately misled Parliament over rule-breaking parties at his office during Covid-19 lockdowns. The committee, which has stripped Johnson of automatic access to Parliament, also accused him of being "complicit in a campaign of abuse and attempted intimidation" towards it. Johnson denies deliberately misleading Parliament, calling the allegations a "lie".

images.alt_text: Political analysts suggested that Johnson might be quitting in his constituency to run for a safer Conservative seat, such as one vacated by Nadine Dorries, a loyalist of Johnson who announced Friday that she would not stand for reelection.

site_title: Battle lines harden over Big Oil’s role at climate talks in Dubai
summary: The 28th Conference of the Parties (COP28) of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) will take place in Dubai, hosted by the UAE. The event is expected to be contentious, with oil-rich countries and fossil fuel companies invited to participate, sparking criticism from activists who see this as a betrayal of climate goals. The UAE aims to deliver a collective pledge to triple renewable energy by 2030, but critics argue this is too little, too late, and that the presence of fossil fuel interests will undermine progress.

images.alt_text: EU and UAE will work to “ensure maximum support on global 2030 targets for the tripling of renewable energy and doubling of energy efficiency,” a statement says.
OP28 president-designate Sultan Al Jaber  is also the UAE's Minister of Industry and Advanced Technology
Al Jaber, 49, wants “transformational progress.”

site_title: Fashion retailers resilient despite consumer fears
summary: H&M and online fashion retailer ASOS reported strong starts to June, with H&M gaining 6% in shares after analysts forecast a stronger third quarter. This comes as a relief to investors concerned about weakening demand in the US and economic uncertainty driving shoppers to spend less on clothes in Europe, the US, and China. H&M has sought to increase its fashion appeal and develop its higher-priced brand Cos, targeting shoppers less vulnerable to a higher cost of living. The resilience in the fashion sector has alleviated concerns about economic uncertainty.

site_title: HSBC, StanChart face pressure from Hong Kong to take on crypto clients: FT
summary: HSBC and Standard Chartered are facing pressure from Hong Kong's banking regulator, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), to accept cryptocurrency exchanges as clients. The HKMA questioned the lenders in April, citing concerns that excluding crypto exchanges could create an "undue burden" on potential customers setting up in Hong Kong. This comes as countries like the US increase scrutiny on crypto exchanges, with the US affiliate of Binance halting dollar deposits amid SEC scrutiny.

site_title: TikTok to invest billions of dollars in South-east Asia: CEO
summary: TikTok CEO Chew Shou Zi announced plans to invest "billions of dollars" in South-east Asia over the next few years, focusing on e-commerce, education, and community. The funds will support over 120,000 small and medium-sized businesses, entrepreneurs, and youth, with a $12.2 million initial investment. This investment aims to drive growth and development in the region.

images.alt_text: TikTok denies any improper data use and says it has spent more than US$1.5 billion on data security measures.
Shopee accounted more almost half of South-east Asia's GMV for 2022, taking top spot among e-commerce players.

TikTok is the fastest growing social network in the report, used by 20 per cent of 18- to 24-year-olds for news, up five percentage points from last year. Fewer than half the survey respondents expressed much interest in news at all, down sharply from 6 out of 10 in 2017.
The letter, from Senators Richard Blumenthal (right) and Marsha Blackburn, focuses on how sensitive data about American users may be stored in China and how employees there may have access to it.

site_title: Indonesia May trade surplus shrinks to smallest in 3 years
summary: Indonesia's trade surplus in May narrowed to the smallest in three years, at US$440 million, due to easing commodity prices. Exports rose 0.96% to US$21.72 billion, beating expectations of an 8.7% annual drop. Imports increased 14.35% to US$21.28 billion, with a 60% annual increase in capital goods imports. Economists predict a shrinking trade surplus and economic growth slowdown due to risks from US and China's economic slowdown and Indonesia's bauxite export ban.

images.alt_text: The case, brought by several politicians including from the ruling Democratic Party of Struggle (PDI-P), seeks a return to the ‘closed’ ballot system.
An aerial view of a main road in Jakarta. Indonesia’s digital economy is the largest in South-east Asia, valued at US$70 billion in 2021 and estimated to reach US$146 billion in 2025.

site_title: Beijing to cover IVF, other fertility treatments to boost birth rate
summary: Beijing's government announced it will cover 16 types of assisted reproduction technology under the city's healthcare system starting July 1, in an effort to boost China's declining birth rate. The measures include in-vitro fertilization, embryo transplantation, and freezing and storing semen. This move comes as China grapples with its first population drop in six decades, with a record low of 6.77 newborns per 1,000 people in 2022. The decision aims to support fertility rates, particularly for single and unmarried women who face barriers in accessing fertility treatments.

images.alt_text: Concerns about China’s shrinking population have prompted more than 20 recommendations by members of the country’s top political advisory body to boost birth rates, with experts saying some measures could help slow its population decline.

site_title: Hong Kong pauses rate hike cycle following US Fed decision
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) held its base rate steady at 5.5% on June 15, following the US Federal Reserve's decision to pause interest rate hikes for the first time in 15 months. The pause is expected to give Hong Kong banks, including HSBC and Standard Chartered, more flexibility to maintain their lending rates. The decision is also seen as a response to the city's recovering economy, which is expected to grow at 4.6% for 2023.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s interbank rate is affected by the US interest rate trend due to the Hong Kong dollar’s peg to the greenback.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise as Fed holds rates, China cuts interest rate
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday after the Federal Reserve decided against hiking interest rates and China's central bank cut borrowing costs. The move is seen as a signal to kickstart the struggling Asian economies. Despite US inflation still double the bank's target rate, policymakers signalled more increases are likely later in the year. The decision eased worries of a recession and guided hopes for a soft landing.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers are closely matched with gainers at 62 to 61 as at 9.02 am.
The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.4 per cent higher on Wednesday.
Hong Kong, Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore and Taipei were all on the rise on Wednesday, though Seoul and Wellington struggled.

site_title: Japanese broadcasters ‘cutting it fine’ on Women’s World Cup rights
summary: Japanese broadcasters are at risk of missing out on televised coverage of the Women's World Cup due to unclaimed broadcasting rights. Despite FIFA reaching an agreement with five European countries, Japan remains the last major country without a deal. Broadcasting rights had been bundled with men's tournament rights but were sold separately this year. Japanese Football Association chief Kozo Tashima expressed concern, citing a "gulf between positions" and the need for terrestrial TV coverage to attract new fans. The Women's World Cup kicks off on July 20, with games currently only available online via the FIFA app.

site_title: Chinese miners try livestream sales to shift coal glut
summary: Chinese miners are using livestream sales to shift the country's coal glut by targeting wholesale industrial buyers. With record-high coal inventories, miners are advertising coal shipments on platforms like Douyin, often with energy content of 5,500 kcal per ton. Three active coal channels have held 164 online events this quarter, up from 120 last quarter. The shows can last over two hours and generate viewer comments, including some joking about the prices of coal shipments. The revenue generated by these events is unclear, but they appear to be a creative way for miners to sell excess coal.

images.alt_text: China has devoted significant resources to the construction of renewable energy capacity in recent years.

site_title: China’s economy slows in May, firming case for more support
summary: China's economy showed signs of slowing in May, with retail sales growing 12.7% but missing forecasts of 13.6% growth. Industrial output rose 3.5% from a year earlier, below expectations. This adds to concerns about the post-pandemic recovery and prompts expectations of further interest rate cuts to support the economy. The slowdown is a departure from earlier gains this year, raising pressure on policymakers to act.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China cut a key interest rate and injected US$33 billion into financial markets on Thursday, as data showed the world’s second-largest economy was flagging.
The People’s Bank of China is expected to cut a key policy interest rate on Thursday, which would allow banks to lower lending rates next week.

site_title: Apac deal activity falls 25% from January to May: GlobalData
summary: Asia-Pacific deal activity fell 25% year-on-year from January to May 2023, with 5,707 deals completed, down from 7,604 in the same period in 2022. This decline is in line with the global trend of economic uncertainties impacting deal activity, attributed to geopolitical tensions, inflation, and recession fears. Venture financing deals fell 32%, followed by M&A deals (16%) and private equity deals (15%). Countries such as Indonesia, New Zealand, and South Korea saw the largest decline in deal volume, with Indonesia falling 43%.

images.alt_text: The latest bull market arising from the ashes has some elements of the short and violent pandemic bull market, which began in March 2020.
Globally, Goldman is working on its third round of staff cuts in under a year.

site_title: ECB to raise rates further even as economy stutters
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to raise interest rates for the eighth consecutive time, by 25 basis points to 3.5%, in a bid to combat high inflation. The decision comes despite a stagnant economy and moderating inflation, as the eurozone inflation rate remains above the ECB's 2% target. The ECB's president, Christine Lagarde, is expected to keep a further hike in September, and the central bank will update its economic forecasts, which suggest inflation will exceed the target in 2024.

images.alt_text: While the ECB has hiked interest rates rapidly to make up ground in its fight against resurgent inflation, it is having a harder time reversing years of massive asset purchases.
The ECB’s most recent forecasts put it at 2.2 per cent in 2025.

Christine Lagarde, president of the European Central Bank, at ECB And Its Watchers conference in Frankfurt, Germany, on Wednesday, March 22, 2023. The European Central Bank will take a "robust" approach that allows it to respond to inflation risks as needed but also aid financial markets if threats emerge, according to Lagarde. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

site_title: Macron to meet Elon Musk in Paris to talk Tesla investment
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron is set to meet with Tesla CEO Elon Musk on Friday to discuss potential investment in a factory in France and tech regulation. This is the second meeting between the two in over a month, with Macron aiming to promote France as a hub for the electric vehicle industry. France has offered generous subsidies and a business-friendly environment to attract Tesla and other companies, including Chinese EV giant BYD. Musk previously chose Germany for Tesla's only European factory, but France is competing with other EU countries such as Spain.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Visitors check a Tesla Model 3 car next to a Model Y displayed at a showroom of the U.S. electric vehicle (EV) maker in Beijing, China February 4, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo/File Photo
Shares of Tesla were up 4 per cent at the close of regular trading in New York on Friday.
Elon Musk was the only Tesla director to challenge the investors’ claims in court after his colleagues on the board agreed to a US$60 million settlement.

site_title: Australian jobs surge boosts rate-hike bets as inflation lingers
summary: Australia's employment surged in May, with 75,900 new jobs added, exceeding forecasts and boosting bets on further interest rate hikes to combat inflation. The jobless rate declined to 3.6%, fueling pressure on the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) to tighten policy further. This intensifies concerns of a potential recession, with overnight-indexed swaps predicting at least two more RBA hikes to 4.6% this year. The data suggests wages growth will increase, prompting the RBA to hike rates to tame inflation.

images.alt_text: A pedestrian walks past the Reserve Bank of Australia headquarters in Sydney, Australia, on Tuesday, Oct. 23, 2012.
