Treasurer Wayne Swan on Monday reiterated that the Australian government would seek to return the budget to surplus in 2012-13 following four years of deficits which have pushed up the amount of Australian debt outstanding to about $260 billion. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg

site_title: Magnitude 6.2 earthquake strikes Philippines
summary: A magnitude 6.2 earthquake struck the Philippines on June 15, 2023, at a depth of 112 km off Calatagan town, about three hours from Manila. While there were no immediate reports of damage or casualties, disaster authorities deployed teams to assess the impact. The quake sent people rushing out of buildings, with temporary closures reported at Ninoy Aquino International Airport and the Manila metro system. Authorities warned of aftershocks but ruled out tsunami waves, with no major damage or casualties reported as of now.

images.alt_text: Footage from NHK showed buildings shaking near the Narita International Airport in Chiba. Airport authorities were checking for damage to its runways, NHK says.
The collapsed first floor of a house and a car crushed in Suzu, Ishikawa Prefecture, due to a strong earthquake on Friday.
Indonesia suffers frequent earthquakes because it straddles the so-called Pacific Ring of Fire, a seismically active zone where different plates of the earth’s crust meet.

site_title: Canada cuts ties with Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank on claims of Chinese interference
summary: Canada has halted its involvement with the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) amid claims of Chinese interference, following Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland's announcement. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's government will lead an immediate review of the allegations, citing concerns over the bank's "toxic culture" and alleged Communist Party dominance. The move comes as Trudeau's government faces criticism over alleged Chinese interference in Canadian election campaigns. The AIIB has denied the allegations, calling them "baseless and disappointing". Canada's decision marks a significant shift in its stance on the bank, which it had previously joined in 2018.

images.alt_text: This will be the first time AIIB enters the Asian venture capital market since its founding.

site_title: China’s central bank cuts key interest rate to boost economy
summary: China's central bank cut a key interest rate to boost the economy, lowering the medium-term lending facility (MLF) rate to 2.65% and injecting $33 billion into financial markets. The move aims to stimulate domestic consumption and ease financing burdens on small and medium-sized private businesses. However, the economy is still facing challenges, including a debt-laden property sector and a global slowdown, with youth unemployment reaching a record 20.8% in May. The rate cut is seen as a response to weak economic data, including factory activity contraction and sinking exports.

images.alt_text: High youth joblessness has weighed on consumer confidence, as households have chosen to repay their debt early to reduce risks.
Hong Kong, Shanghai, Tokyo, Sydney, Singapore and Taipei all rose on Thursday mid-morning but there were losses in Seoul, Manila and Jakarta.

site_title: Brokers’ take: OCBC raises SIA’s fair value to S$7.94 on robust travel demand
summary: OCBC Investment Research has raised its fair value estimate on Singapore Airlines (SIA) to S$7.94, citing robust travel demand in the near term. The move comes after the research team previously raised its fair value to S$7.18. Despite the positive outlook, OCBC cautions that much of SIA's recovery has already been priced in due to its first-mover advantage, and its share price has rallied 33% year-to-date. OCBC maintains its "hold" rating on the stock, considering its risk-reward profile as more balanced.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines (SIA) aeroplanes at Changi Airport on Dec 24, 2022.
Those who helmed the national carrier before current CEO Goh Choon Phong had all risen through the ranks and spent decades rotating across the various departments and subsidiaries.

site_title: Cromwell European Reit to divest Bari asset in Italy
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) plans to divest its Italian asset in Bari, valued at €73.3 million, as part of its strategy to sell non-core and non-strategic assets. The divestment comes a week after the Reit announced plans to sell its Milan office asset. No selling price has been disclosed, and a definitive agreement has not been reached. The decision is in line with Cromwell E-Reit's strategy to divest assets over the next two to three years.

images.alt_text: The Piazza Affari 2 in Milan, Italy. Cromwell European Reit had called it a trophy asset in the heart of Milan's central business district, being located opposite the Milan Stock Exchange.

site_title: China home-price growth weakens as housing recovery falters
summary: China's new-home prices in 70 cities, excluding state-subsidized housing, grew 0.1% in May, the slowest pace in four months. This follows a decline of 0.23% in the secondary market, snapping three months of gains. The residential property market is facing renewed weakness, with the sector accounting for 20% of China's gross domestic product. China is considering a stimulus package to boost the economy, which includes measures to support real estate and domestic demand. The market's decline weighs on the global economy, particularly commodities like iron ore and copper.

site_title: US Federal Reserve leaves rates steady, sees two small hikes by end of 2023
summary: The US Federal Reserve left interest rates steady, but signaled a possible half-point hike by the end of 2023, citing a stronger-than-expected economy and slower inflation. Chairman Jerome Powell noted that the Fed has covered a lot of ground and the full effects of tightening have yet to be felt. The median projection sees the benchmark interest rate rising to 5.50-5.75% by the end of the year, with nearly all officials expecting more rate rises this year.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.7 per cent to 33,979.33 on Wednesday.
The producer price index for final demand dropped 0.3 per cent last month on lower energy costs after rising by an unrevised 0.2 per cent in April, the Labor Department said on Wednesday.
The US dollar index – which measures the performance of the US currency against six others – dips 0.2 per cent to 103.14, after touching its lowest since May 22 overnight at 103.04.

site_title: China holds urgent meetings on economy with business leaders
summary: China is holding urgent meetings with business leaders and economists to discuss ways to stimulate the economy, restore confidence in the private sector, and revive the real estate industry. The meetings, attended by senior officials, have resulted in calls for more market-oriented policies and better-coordinated monetary and fiscal stimulus. China's economy is struggling with weak sentiment after Covid lockdowns and policy crackdowns, and officials are expected to cut a key policy interest rate on Thursday, which would allow banks to lower lending rates next week.

images.alt_text: E-commerce sellers such as China-founded, Singapore-based Shein and Temu, a rival owned by PDD Holdings that operates the Chinese e-commerce site Pinduoduo, are big beneficiaries of the exemption.
The flood of discounted feedstock prompted Chinese authorities to toughen scrutiny of crude oil quotas.

site_title: Japan’s May exports grow unexpectedly on solid car shipments
summary: Japan's exports rose 0.6% year-over-year in May, marking the 27th consecutive month of growth, driven by double-digit growth in car shipments. The rate of expansion slowed due to inflation and rising interest rates. Despite a decline in exports to China, US-bound exports grew 9.4% year-over-year. The trade balance came to a deficit of 1.3725 trillion yen, and the country's GDP expanded 2.7% in the January to March period, beating a preliminary estimate. The data will be scrutinized by the Bank of Japan during its policy-setting meeting.

images.alt_text: Japan's core machinery orders rose 5.5 per cent in April from the previous month, government data showed on Thursday.
“I believe that Toyota today can manage its business with a sense of speed,” new CEO Koji Sato says.
Children try to make a snowman in a park in Suginami Ward after a light dusting of snow fell across parts of the Tokyo metropolitan area on February 10, 2023. (Photo by JIJI Press / AFP) / Japan OUT

site_title: Indonesia court to rule on ballot system months from 2024 election
summary: Indonesia's Constitutional Court will rule on a possible change to the country's electoral system, which seeks to return to a 'closed' ballot system. Critics warn this change would undermine democracy and revert to authoritarian rule, where party leaders appoint lawmakers. Eight out of nine parties in parliament have denounced the case, and President Joko Widodo has denied seeking to extend his time in office. The ruling is expected to be issued on Thursday, just eight months before the 2024 general and presidential polls, fueling concerns about potential political interference.

images.alt_text: Analysts said the changing sentiment in local markets and recent developments surrounding domestic issues led to outflows of foreign funds, causing the ringgit to weaken further.
PalmCo has a total of 560.078 hectares of oil palm plantations in Indonesia, according to its website.
Coal barges to be pulled along Mahakam river in Samarinda, East Kalimantan province, Indonesia, in August 31, 2019.

site_title: Chinese ride-hailing giant Didi boasts US$14 billion value, one-year after NYSE delisting
summary: Chinese ride-hailing giant Didi Global boasts a market value of around $14 billion, one year after its NYSE delisting due to Beijing's tech crackdown. Despite the delisting, the company continues to attract some institutional investors, including Davis Selected Advisers and Carmignac, with a combined value of $11.1 billion. This marks a significant rebound for the company, making it one of the top 11% of NYSE-listed firms in terms of market value.

images.alt_text: A Didi robotaxi concept car Didi Neuron, with robotic arms that can help passengers pick up luggage.

site_title: Singapore Kitchen Equipment CEO, senior manager out on bail amid CAD probe
summary: Singapore Kitchen Equipment CEO Sally Chua and senior manager Charlene Koh have been released on bail after being interviewed by the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) amid a probe into a potential offence under the Penal Code 1871. The investigation was initiated after CAD ordered the company to produce documents a year ago. The company stated that business will continue as normal, despite the development.

images.alt_text: Singapore Kitchen Equipment was founded by husband-and-wife duo Sally Chua Chwee Choo and Alan Lee Chong Hoe.

site_title: Tourism, factory restarts temper Sri Lanka economic contraction
summary: Sri Lanka's economy likely contracted 8.9% in the first quarter of 2023, a slower pace than the 12.4% contraction in the previous quarter, according to economists. However, a rebound in tourism and remittances, along with some industrial activity, provided a boost. Tourism receipts rose 18% to US$696 million in January to April, and the Purchasing Managers' Indices showed an expansion in March. The IMF expects Sri Lanka's economy to return to growth next year as fresh funding is received and local authorities implement reforms.

images.alt_text: The CBSL has cut its standing deposit facility rate and standing lending facility rate to 13 per cent and 14 per cent respectively.
Soaring inflation has battered the economy for more than a year after a severe foreign exchange crisis set off Sri Lanka’s worst financial crisis in seven decades.

site_title: Goldman, Citi begin cutting about 35 dealmakers across Asia
summary: Goldman Sachs and Citigroup are cutting approximately 35 investment-banking jobs across Asia, amid a muted environment for dealmaking due to macro-economic concerns and tumultuous markets. Goldman is reducing about 15 dealmakers, including nine from equity capital markets, while Citigroup may eliminate more than 20 jobs, mostly at junior levels. These cuts follow a trend of job eliminations globally, particularly in China, where the economy is struggling.

images.alt_text: A Goldman Sachs Group Inc. logo hangs on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange in New York, U.S., on Wednesday, May 19, 2010. Goldman Sachs Group Inc. racked up trading profits for itself every day last quarter. Clients who followed the firmÕs investment advice fared far worse. Photographer: Daniel Acker/Bloomberg
Citigroup’s markets division brought in roughly US$5.29 billion in revenue in last year’s second quarter.

site_title: New Zealand slips into recession
summary: New Zealand's economy contracted in the first quarter, shrinking 0.1% due to interest rate hikes and bad weather. The country is now in a technical recession, with two quarters of negative growth. Annual growth slowed to 2.2%. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand's aggressive interest rate hikes are seen as a necessary step to slow down inflation. Economists expect the cash rate to have peaked, and the contraction may add to expectations of a recession ending soon.

images.alt_text: New Zealand has one of the highest house-price-to-income ratios in the world.

The revised airline charges will be effective from July 1, the airport operator said, ending a year-long fee freeze as it looks to fund NZ$3.9 billion (S$3.18 billion) of improvements over the next five to six years.

site_title: Stronger regulation, appropriate pricing model needed to ensure right balance of PHVs
summary: Singapore's private-hire vehicle (PHV) market is experiencing rapid growth, with an average of 653 PHVs added to the roads each month. However, this has led to concerns over wait times, high prices, and the potential for market distortions. Regulators are calling for stronger regulation and a more appropriate pricing model to ensure a balance between PHVs and public transport. The current COE bidding system has pricing inefficiencies, and tougher standards for shared-use vehicles should be explored to meet public needs. A clearer regulatory framework is necessary to ensure PHV services benefit commuters, not just operators.

images.alt_text: A free market may be able to determine the most efficient ratio of ride-hailing and shared-car services in the market, but there are other considerations to the pricing of private transportation.
A Grab delivery rider with Foodpanda thermal bag on his motorcycle in Singapore.

site_title: Mothership beats mainstream news platforms, becomes most used online source
summary: Mothership, a social media news platform, has become the most used online news source in Singapore, surpassing mainstream competitors Channel News Asia and The Straits Times. According to a Reuters Institute Digital News Report 2023, 48% of respondents in Singapore use Mothership weekly, while 46% use Channel News Asia and 42% use The Straits Times. However, Mothership lags behind in brand trust, with 52% of respondents expressing distrust. Mainstream outlets, such as Channel News Asia and The Straits Times, remain the most trusted news brands in Singapore.

images.alt_text: TikTok is the fastest growing social network in the report, used by 20 per cent of 18- to 24-year-olds for news, up five percentage points from last year. Fewer than half the survey respondents expressed much interest in news at all, down sharply from 6 out of 10 in 2017.
News sites like CNA, Mothership.sg and The Straits Times are courting Gen Z on TikTok.

site_title: US lawmakers seek new law to protect TikTok user information
summary: US lawmakers have introduced a bipartisan bill to protect Americans' data from foreign adversaries, particularly China. The legislation aims to prevent foreign-owned social media apps like TikTok from collecting and sharing user information. The bill would also allow nations with strong privacy protections to strengthen their relationships with the US. Senate Finance Committee Chairman Ron Wyden described the bill as a measure to "turn off the tap of data to unfriendly nations" and stop data from being sent to China.

images.alt_text: Shopee accounted more almost half of South-east Asia's GMV for 2022, taking top spot among e-commerce players.

TikTok is the fastest growing social network in the report, used by 20 per cent of 18- to 24-year-olds for news, up five percentage points from last year. Fewer than half the survey respondents expressed much interest in news at all, down sharply from 6 out of 10 in 2017.

site_title: Presidential hopeful George Goh aims to qualify under clause that gives elections committee discretion
summary: George Goh, a presidential hopeful, claims he can qualify under Article 19(4)(b) of the Singapore Constitution, which requires a candidate to have experience and ability comparable to someone fulfilling Article 19(4)(a). His media team says a team of professionals, including lawyers, has assessed his eligibility based on his companies' collective market capitalization value of S$3.15 billion. Goh has owned over 40 companies, including seven publicly listed ones, and co-founded Harvey Norman Ossia. He will not publicly disclose further details of his case, leaving it up to the Presidential Elections Committee to decide his eligibility.

images.alt_text: Speaking to media outside the Elections Department, potential presidential candidate George Goh said he wanted to give the people a choice.

George Goh says he decided to run for president after the eligibility requirements for private sector candidates were raised in 2017, as he was “concerned that the more stringent requirements would lead to another uncontested election”.

site_title: Japan’s April core machinery orders rise 5.5% month-on-month
summary: Japan's core machinery orders rose 5.5% in April from the previous month, the first monthly increase in three months, exceeding economists' median forecast of a 3.0% gain. On a year-on-year basis, core orders fell 5.9%, less than the forecasted decline of 8.0%. The data suggests a slight improvement in the country's economic outlook.

images.alt_text: Employees pack boxes of Fujitsu Ltd. computer servers at the Fujitsu Isotec Ltd. plant in Fukushima Prefecture, Japan, on Wednesday, Dec. 9, 2009. Orders for Japanese machinery fell in October, adding to signs the nation's rebound from its deepest postwar recession isn't strong enough to encourage companies to spend on plant and equipment. Photographer: Haruyoshi Yamaguchi/Bloomberg

site_title: Twitter sued by music firms over violating copyrights, at up to US$150,000 a work
summary: The National Music Publishers' Association (NMPA) sued Twitter, alleging the social media platform violates songwriters' copyrights by using their music without permission. The NMPA, representing 17 music publishers, including Sony Music and Universal Music Publishing Group, is seeking a court declaration that Twitter wilfully infringed approximately 1700 songs. The companies are seeking up to $150,000 for each infringed work and over $250 million in damages. Twitter has not commented on the lawsuit, which comes after the platform's acquisition by Elon Musk in 2022.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk announced in a tweet on Friday (Jun 9) that Twitter will start paying content creators for the advertisements displayed in their replies
FILE PHOTO: Twitter corporate headquarters building is seen in downtown San Francisco, California, U.S. November 18, 2022. REUTERS/Carlos Barria//File Photo

site_title: US Treasury unveils clean energy subsidy payments for non-taxpayers
summary: The US Treasury has unveiled rules allowing non-profits, tribes, and governments to receive direct payments from the Inflation Reduction Act's clean energy subsidies, expanding incentives beyond corporations. The Inflation Reduction Act offers billions in tax credits for decarbonization and enables project owners to sell credits to third parties. Non-taxpaying entities can receive 12 of the tax credits as cash payments, known as elective or direct pay, to encourage project development and speed the transition to a low-carbon economy.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 4.1 points or 0.1% to 3,222.24. The decision to pause the interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve contributed to the gain. Seatrium lost 1.6% and Matex Internationa gained 3.7%, while Singtel rose 1.2%. The US Federal Reserve maintained current interest rates but signaled borrowing costs might increase to resolve slower inflation.

images.alt_text: Keppel Corporation has obtained two contracts to provide "energy-as-a-service" in Bangkok's Sam Yan Smart City.

site_title: Federal Reserve’s ‘hawkish pause’ not enough to halt the bull market
summary: The US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision was met with a "hawkish pause" that initially sent the stock market into a selloff, but ultimately recovered as investors interpreted the move as a dovish signal. Despite the Fed leaving interest rates unchanged, the central bank hinted at two additional rate increases, citing expectations for economic growth and inflation. The decision was seen as a "double bluff" by bulls, who interpreted the Fed's comments as a potential pause in rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rebounded, with the tech sector gaining more than 1% in the wake of the Fed's press conference.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Board Chairman Jerome Powell speaks during a news conference following the Federal Open Market Committee meeting, at the Federal Reserve in Washington, DC, on June 14, 2023. The US Federal Reserve voted Wednesday to pause its aggressive campaign of interest rate hikes despite "elevated" inflation, while indicating a sharp increase could be needed before the end of the year. (Photo by Mandel NGAN / AFP)
The HKMA moves in lockstep with the Fed, given the local currency’s peg to the US dollar.
US gold futures lost 0.7 per cent to US$1,954.50.
Higher interest expenses also raise the bar for how much companies have to earn from projects to cover financing costs, potentially resulting in less investment.
Fed officials have touted the annual stress tests as a measure of the health and resilience of the country’s biggest banks.

site_title: Labour demand shows signs of easing in Q1 as job vacancies fall for 4th straight quarter
summary: Singapore's labour market remains tight, with job vacancies falling for the fourth straight quarter to 99,600 in March. The ratio of job vacancies to unemployed persons has declined from December but remains high at 2.28. Employment growth has also moderated from the previous quarter. Experts attribute the slowdown to the challenging external economic environment, including recent bank failures and hawkish central bank moves. Despite this, the domestic labour market has begun to soften slightly, with Labour Minister Tessa Oh stating that the labour market report shows signs of easing.

images.alt_text: Generic pix of office workers crossing a traffic junction along Cecil Street in the Central Business District (CBD) during lunchtime on May 09, 2023.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Singapore Paincare, OUE Commercial Reit
summary: Keppel secured two contracts for "energy-as-a-service" in Bangkok's Sam Yan Smart City. Singapore Paincare is investing in a Chinese community hospital operator, while OUE Commercial Reit obtained a sustainability-linked loan of S$430 million for refinancing and corporate purposes. Trading halted for Imperium Crown pending an announcement.

images.alt_text: A generic picture of the Keppel Corporation logo at the Central Business District, shot on December 23, 2022. Can be used for stories on offshore and marine, property, infrastructure and asset management businesses, money, banking, economy, recession, finance, investments, banks and Singapore.

site_title: Gold flat as investors assess US Fed’s signals on more hikes
summary: Gold prices remained flat on Thursday, following the Federal Reserve's expected pause on interest rate hikes. The Fed's new economic projections signaled a stronger-than-expected economy and slower inflation, leading to a possible rise in borrowing costs by another half-percentage point by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: While gold is seen as a hedge against inflation, higher rates to tame price pressures generally weigh on the non-yielding asset’s appeal.

site_title: Oil drops 1.5% as Fed projects more rate hikes this year
summary: US oil prices dropped 1.5% on Wednesday after the Federal Reserve projected more interest rate hikes this year, sparking concerns about demand. Oil refineries and tankers saw a 1.7% decline in US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude to $68.27 a barrel, while Brent crude futures fell 1.5% to $73.20 a barrel. The Fed's decision, despite keeping interest rates unchanged, signals a stronger economy and higher borrowing costs, which may reduce oil demand and boost the dollar, making US-denominated commodities more expensive.

images.alt_text: The flood of discounted feedstock prompted Chinese authorities to toughen scrutiny of crude oil quotas.
Oil traders have been closely watching while the government begins refilling the emergency stockpile, as its purchases are bound to tighten the market.
Brent crude futures settled up US$2.45, or 3.4 per cent, to US$74.29 a barrel on Tuesday.

site_title: US Fed to release banks’ stress test results on Jun 28
summary: The US Federal Reserve will release the results of its annual stress tests on June 28, which examine the ability of the 23 biggest US lenders to withstand crisis conditions. The tests were put in place after the 2008 financial crisis to ensure the US banking system's resilience. This year's test includes an "exploratory market shock" scenario, and Fed officials are considering changes to account for new forms of financial stress. The results will provide insight into the health and resilience of the country's biggest banks, following three US lenders' failures since March.

site_title: HSBC announces fresh terms for stalled France sale
summary: HSBC has agreed to revised terms for the sale of its French retail banking business, which was previously stalled due to regulatory concerns. The deal will see HSBC retain a portfolio of 7 billion euros in home loans and invest 407 million euros in the buyer, My Money Group. The new terms, announced Wednesday, reflect rising interest rates and increased attractiveness of the business. The deal, which was initially valued at one euro, is expected to result in a pre-tax loss of up to $2.7 billion for HSBC.

images.alt_text: HSBC says in an email that it will remove its current new business residential products from sale via brokers at 5 pm local time on Wednesday “in order to maintain service levels.”
HSBC is stepping up in the market when VC activity is slowing due to global market uncertainty in the wake of the Federal Reserve-led monetary tightening.

site_title: IMF blasts Pakistan budget as deadline for loan deal looms
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) criticized Pakistan's budget as insufficient to meet its aid program goals, raising concerns about a July 31 deadline to unlock $6.7 billion in loan payments. The IMF stated that the new tax policies "miss an opportunity to broaden the tax base in a more progressive way" and create an unfair tax system. Pakistan faces $23 billion in external repayments and needs financing assistance from countries like Saudi Arabia and the UAE to service its debts. A deal with the IMF is crucial to avoid default and maintain economic stability.

images.alt_text: Pakistan is racing to secure IMF loans to avoid a default.
The State Bank of Pakistan’s (SBP) key rate remains at a record high of 21 per cent.

site_title: LVMH joins with Epic Games to offer virtual experiences
summary: LVMH, a French luxury goods group, has partnered with Epic Games to offer virtual experiences. The collaboration will utilize Epic's 3D creation tools to create immersive products, fashion shows, and ad campaigns. LVMH will leverage Epic's Unreal Engine platform to create "digital twins" of physical products, allowing customers to visualize how products will look and behave before manufacturing. This move aims to engage younger generations with virtual experiences, aligning with Epic's metaverse vision.

site_title: Federal Reserve’s Powell appears to see plenty of room to run on balance sheet drawdown
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated that financial conditions are favorable for the central bank to continue reducing its balance sheet, despite concerns about potential reserve scarcity. The Fed can likely maintain a monthly drawdown of around $100 billion, possibly into 2024, due to high reserves in the banking system. Powell also indicated that the Fed will consider a cumulative half percentage point in further interest rate hikes this year, but refrained from another rate hike at its recent meeting.

images.alt_text: The yield on short-term government bonds, the most sensitive to interest rate moves, jumped this week to the highest since 2008.
The producer price index for final demand dropped 0.3 per cent last month on lower energy costs after rising by an unrevised 0.2 per cent in April, the Labor Department said on Wednesday.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.7 per cent to 33,979.33 on Wednesday.

Federal Reserve Board Chairman Jerome Powell speaks during a news conference following the Federal Open Market Committee meeting, at the Federal Reserve in Washington, DC, on June 14, 2023. The US Federal Reserve voted on Wednesday to pause its aggressive campaign of interest rate hikes despite "elevated" inflation.

site_title: US media split on Trump reflects divided nation
summary: A US federal judge ordered former President Donald Trump to stand trial on 37 criminal counts related to his mishandling of classified documents and obstruction of official attempts to recover them. The case has sparked a media divide, with some outlets, like Fox News, portraying Trump as a victim and a "wannabe dictator" and others, like CNN, labeling him "dangerous" and refusing to air his live statements. The case raises concerns about Trump's eligibility to run for president in 2024, as he is also his party's frontrunner, potentially facing a prison sentence.

images.alt_text: Former US President Donald Trump during a stop at the Versailles restaurant in the Little Havana neighborhood in Miami, June 13, 2023.  Trump on Tuesday pleaded not guilty in a Miami courtroom to federal charges he mishandled state secrets.
Boris Johnson (left) and Donald Trump have championed a similar style of politics.

The surprise announcement by Trump’s lawyers John Rowley and Jim Trusty could prompt further legal complications ahead of Trump’s scheduled appearance in federal court in Miami on Tuesday in the documents case.
Donald Trump said on social media that he had been summoned to appear at the federal courthouse in Miami on Tuesday.

site_title: Crypto altcoins lead slide after US Fed raises possibility of rate hikes
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised the possibility of resuming interest-rate hikes, sparking a sell-off in the cryptocurrency market. Bitcoin fell for a third day, testing the $25,000 price level, while Ether dropped 4.6% and altcoins like XRP and Litecoin declined 8% and 6%, respectively. Market analysts attribute the downturn to traders unwinding short-term trades in response to the hawkish Fed outlook, with some experiencing liquidations on decentralized exchanges.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Board Chairman Jerome Powell speaks during a news conference following the Federal Open Market Committee meeting, at the Federal Reserve in Washington, DC, on June 14, 2023. The US Federal Reserve voted on Wednesday to pause its aggressive campaign of interest rate hikes despite "elevated" inflation.
The SEC launched lawsuits last week against market leaders Binance Holdings and Coinbase Global, and flagged a number of altcoins as unregistered securities, including SOL and ADA.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise on Federal Reserve pause hopes
summary: European shares rose 0.4% on Wednesday, driven by banks and miners ahead of a US Federal Reserve pause in interest rate hikes. The Stoxx 600 index, led by gains in Italy and Spain's lender-heavy indexes, pushed past a 1% trading range. A drop in US producer prices and moderating consumer prices supported bets for a pause in tightening. The European Central Bank is set to hike rates by 25 basis points on Thursday, while markets await more economic data and updates from central banks to drive a definitive move.

images.alt_text: Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, speaks during a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting in Washington, DC, on June 14, 2023.

Federal Reserve Board Chairman Jerome Powell speaks during a news conference following the Federal Open Market Committee meeting, at the Federal Reserve in Washington, DC, on June 14, 2023. The US Federal Reserve voted on Wednesday to pause its aggressive campaign of interest rate hikes despite "elevated" inflation.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.7 per cent to 33,979.33 on Wednesday.

site_title: OUE C-Reit unit obtains S$430 million sustainability-linked loan
summary: OUE C-Reit's indirect subsidiary, OUB Centre, has secured a S$430 million sustainability-linked loan. The loan, obtained from multiple lenders, will be used for refinancing existing borrowings and general corporate purposes. This is OUE C-Reit's third SLL, with no further refinancing requirements until 2025. The loan's proceeds will also help reduce the Reit's total borrowings, which comprised 69.6% SLLs as of end-March.

images.alt_text: Mandarin GalleryThe merger of OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust and OUE Hospitality Trust will create one of the largest diversified Singapore real estate investment trusts. Its portfolio will comprise seven properties across the office, retail and hospitality sectors, including Mandarin Gallery.
OUE C-Reit independent director to remain in role amid unrelated legal dispute, manager says

site_title: US companies scramble to cuts costs, pay down debt as interest rates surge
summary: US companies are scrambling to cut costs and pay down debt as interest rates surge, with interest expenses rising 22% in the first quarter compared to a year earlier. Electronics giants like Apple and telecom providers like Verizon are among those feeling the pinch, with interest costs soaring to $1.21 billion for Verizon in the first quarter. Companies are taking steps such as delaying bonuses, scaling back hiring, and reviewing dividend payments to cope with the increased costs. Higher interest rates may lead to less investment and a focus on right-sizing debt and balance sheets.

images.alt_text: A former US president has never before been ordered to stand trial on federal charges. The fact Trump is also his party’s 2024 frontrunner raises the shocking possibility of a nominee seeking the White House under threat of a prison sentence.
Fed officials have touted the annual stress tests as a measure of the health and resilience of the country’s biggest banks.
Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, speaks during a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting in Washington, DC, on June 14, 2023.

site_title: TikTok Shop thriving in a crowded field of S-E Asia e-commerce players
summary: TikTok Shop, the e-commerce arm of TikTok, has seen significant growth in South-east Asia, with its gross merchandise value (GMV) increasing from $600 million in 2021 to $4.4 billion in 2022. The platform expanded to five new countries, including Thailand, Vietnam, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Singapore, but still trails leader Shopee. TikTok Shop's success highlights the growing e-commerce landscape in the region, with Shopee's parent company Sea's e-commerce arm accounting for almost half of the region's total GMV in 2022.

images.alt_text: Sea CEO Forrest Li
Li argues that Sea has a unique opportunity to bring e-commerce to emerging markets, the kinds of places where Amazon may be at a disadvantage.

site_title: Are Sino-American ties being reassessed?
summary: US Secretary of State Anthony Blinken's upcoming visit to Beijing may signal a shift in the debate over China in Washington, as signs of a re-evaluation of Sino-American ties emerge. Despite rising tensions, the US remains China's single largest trading partner, and China is one of the two largest foreign creditors to the US. The Biden administration is debating a more nuanced approach, with Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo introducing a more accommodative stance, suggesting that the Sino-American economic relationship can be managed through international cooperation.

images.alt_text: In a photo provided by the US Navy, sailors recover the downed Chinese surveillance balloon off the coast of South Carolina on Feb 5, 2023.
A US official said on condition of anonymity that US Secretary of State Anthony Blinken was expected to reschedule his visit to China in the coming weeks but stressed that no date had been set.

Asked about criticism of the bilateral relationship during an Arab-China business conference, Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman says: “I actually ignore it because ... as a business person .. now you will go where opportunity comes your way.”

site_title: Tesla’s US$240 billion rally set to collide with a bearish signal
summary: Tesla's stock, which added over $240 billion to its valuation in 13 days, appears to be on a collision course with a bearish signal. The company's shares dropped 1.3% on Wednesday, ending their longest-ever run of gains. The 14-day relative strength index shows shares are overbought, a technical signal suggesting a reversion is near. This comes amid a wider mania for artificial intelligence-related investments, receding fears of a hard recession, and positive news from Tesla, including electric-charging pacts with General Motors and Ford Motor.

images.alt_text: Shares of Tesla were up 4 per cent at the close of regular trading in New York on Friday.

site_title: Who will be SIA’s next captain?
summary: Singapore Airlines CEO Goh Choon Phong is set to step down as he turns 60, with speculation surrounding his successor. Analysts and investors are considering five top contenders: Lee Lik Hsin, Tan Kai Ping, JoAnn Tan, Chin Yau Seng, and Leslie Thng, all of whom have extensive experience within the airline group. Goh has emphasized the importance of promoting from within, with the airline's "strong bench" of talent. The board will ultimately decide on the next CEO, with the possibility of a female leader, JoAnn Tan, making history as the airline's first female CEO.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines (SIA) aeroplanes at Changi Airport on Dec 24, 2022.
OCBC has up SIA's fair value to S$7.18 to factor in slower pace of passenger yields in FY2024.
SIAEC's revenue has risen 40.6 per cent to S$796 million, but this is only about 80 per cent of pre-Covid figures.
Leslie Thng, CEO, Scoot
SIA notes that its current budget for in-flight meals is about 20 per cent higher than that for FY2019 and 2020, even though it expects that its capacity will be lower than that year.

SIA’s board has recommended a final dividend of S$0.28 per share. Including the interim dividend of S$0.10 per share, the total dividend payout for the fiscal year stands at S$0.38 per share.
The 2020 and 2021 MCBs were part of the S$15 billion rights issue approved by SIA shareholders in April 2020 to tide the airline group through the pandemic, which decimated travel for two years.

site_title: Cyber insurance premiums surge by 50% as ransomware attacks increase
summary: Cyber insurance premiums surged 50% in 2022, reaching US$7.2 billion, as ransomware attacks and online commerce increased demand for coverage. This marks a tripling of premiums in the past three years, according to a study by ratings firm AM Best. The surge in premiums is attributed to "systematic risk" and the risk appetite of insurers, with reinsurers also playing a role in determining coverage.

images.alt_text: To fully leverage AI for cybersecurity, machine learning, natural language processing and other AI tools have to be integrated into a defence strategy.

site_title: Building a sustainable digital economy in S-E Asia
summary: The article highlights the need for a sustainable digital economy in South-east Asia, driven by the growth of digital economy companies (DECs) in the region. To achieve this, governments must invest in digital and physical infrastructure, improve Internet penetration, and provide support for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The study found that market development, technological development, and institutional development are crucial for a sustainable digital economy. Policymakers must prioritize these three pillars to ensure an inclusive and secure digital economy, mitigating environmental impacts, addressing cybersecurity and data privacy concerns, and establishing a trusted regulatory landscape.

images.alt_text: The hacker house will run both online and offline and consists of developer quests, hackathons and meetups in cities around the world, including in Singapore.
Digitalising at breakneck speed, Asia stands to gain from the rapid development but also has more to lose than most from climate change.

site_title: Malaysia’s six upcoming state elections, and what’s at stake
summary: Malaysia is set to hold six state assembly elections simultaneously by July, seen as a crucial test for the ruling unity government. The elections will gauge the support level for Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's administration and determine the coalition's influence on policy implementation. The six states are led by the Malaysian Islamic Party (PAS) in Kelantan, Terengganu, and Kedah, while Anwar's Pakatan Harapan (PH) coalition controls the other three. The PH government has proposed infrastructure developments, including foreign investments, to address poverty and lack of infrastructure in the PAS-led states.

images.alt_text: The Pengerang Integrated Petroleum Complex in Johor, in part given its proximity to Singapore, is hoped will spur Malaysia's green energy transition, Malaysia's Minister of Economy Rafizi Ramli reportedly said.
Malaysia�s Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim leaves the lower house of parliament after receiving a vote of confidence, in Kuala Lumpur on December 19, 2022. (Photo by HASNOOR HUSSAIN / POOL / AFP)

site_title: People’s Park Centre eyes third collective sale bid; People’s Park Complex jumps on the bandwagon
summary: People's Park Centre and People's Park Complex, two Chinatown developments in Singapore, are exploring collective sale options. People's Park Centre, which attempted to sell in 2019 and 2022, is considering a reserve price of S$1.5 billion to S$1.7 billion. The owners of People's Park Complex, a 31-storey development, are also pursuing a collective sale, with the process underway. The en bloc attempts come as the collective sale environment faces challenges, with only a third of sales succeeding in the current cycle, attributed to a mismatch of expectations and rising costs.

images.alt_text: PropNex, the real estate agency appointed for the mortgagee sale, says the 48 cheques collected were all from Singaporean buyers.
Three cluster semi-detached houses were sold via tender at Eleven @ Holland on Jun 12.

“We are very collectivist… that entire mindset fits the group buy mindset,” says Nanyang Business School professor Sharon Ng. “I think the idea that we come together as a community to buy something aligns very much with Asian values.”

site_title: UK corporate debt costs soar above US peers
summary: The UK's corporate debt costs have surged above those of US peers, with the yield on short-term government bonds reaching its highest since 2008. The Bank of England's decision to raise interest rates is increasingly likely, with a one-in-three chance of a 6% rate by early next year. This divergence is driven by persistent UK inflation, faster-than-anticipated wage growth, and labour shortages. UK firms face higher borrowing costs, with yields rising 70 basis points this year, compared to a 6-fold increase in US firms.

images.alt_text: A video grab from footage broadcast by the UK Parliament's Parliamentary Recording Unit (PRU) shows Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt making his annual budget statement in the House of Commons in London on March 15, 2023. site_title: EU lawmakers approve legislation to make batteries greener
summary: The European Union Parliament approved new rules to make batteries more sustainable and greener, affecting the design, production, and waste management of all types of batteries sold in the EU. The regulations aim to reduce emissions, use recycled materials, and encourage recycling, with targets to collect 63% of portable batteries by 2027 and 70% by 2030. The rules will come into force once the European Council formally endorses the text, coinciding with the EU's goal of 30 million electric vehicles by 2030, driven by soaring battery demand.

site_title: Toyota shareholders reject climate resolution in win for automaker
summary: Toyota shareholders rejected a climate resolution urging greater disclosure of its climate lobbying, voting down the proposal by a significant margin. The resolution, submitted by Danish pension fund AkademikerPension and two other European asset managers, aimed to increase transparency on Toyota's lobbying activities related to climate change. The outcome was seen as a win for Toyota, which has been praised for its ambitious electric vehicle roadmap and multi-pathway approach to carbon neutrality. New CEO Koji Sato expressed confidence in the company's ability to manage its business with speed, and shares rose 6.3% following the announcement.

site_title: Volkswagen unveils plan to boost flagship brand
summary: Volkswagen unveiled a plan to boost its flagship brand by achieving a return of 6.5% by 2026 and increasing earnings by 10 billion euros. The plan involves changes across multiple areas, including reducing costs through synergies, focusing on top-selling models, and discontinuing less popular ones. The goal is to achieve this ambitious target, enabling the company to safeguard jobs, invest in new technologies, and modernize plants.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on March 14, 2023 the logo of German car giant Volkswagen (VW) is pictured on a Volkswagen ID Buzz van during the company's annual press conference to present the business reportin Berlin. - German auto giant Volkswagen reported on May 4, 2023 a sharp fall in first-quarter net profits to 4.7 billion euros ($5.2 billion) due to an accounting effect, while both sales and revenues increased. (Photo by John MACDOUGALL / AFP)

site_title: US: Dow falls, Nasdaq rises after mixed Federal Reserve rate decision
summary: US stocks ended mixed on Wednesday after the Federal Reserve maintained current interest rates but signaled plans for additional rate increases. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.7% to 33,979.33, while the S&P 500 added 0.1% to 4,372.59. The Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.4% to 13,626.48, defying expectations of a Fed pause. The Fed maintained its benchmark lending rate between 5.0% and 5.25%, with forecasts indicating strong support for two more hikes in 2023.

images.alt_text: Traders work the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) during the opening bell in New York on May 23, 2023. Stock markets slid on May 23 after fresh talks between President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarty on raising the US debt ceiling ended without an agreement as a crucial deadline approaches. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: No Signboard receives letter of demand from Orchard Gateway landlord
summary: No Signboard Holdings received a letter of demand from its Orchard Gateway landlord for an outstanding two months' security deposit of S$98,738.40. The landlord demanded payment by June 16 to maintain the security deposit and reopen the outlet. Failure to do so may result in damages of S$200 per day and potential re-entry or legal proceedings. No Signboard is seeking legal advice on the matter, following the termination of its franchise agreement with Little Sheep hotpot chain.

site_title: All about fatherhood
summary: Father's Day is celebrated on Sunday, honoring unsung parents who often receive less attention. To mark the occasion, a collection of books on fatherhood is highlighted, offering advice and inspirational stories on raising children. Meanwhile, a new wellness initiative at Jewel Changi Airport and a survey on dining habits in Singapore provide additional content. Fine dining options, such as Poise, are also recommended, offering elevated takes on humble ingredients.

site_title: Bill Gates in China to meet President Xi on Friday
summary: Bill Gates is set to meet Chinese President Xi Jinping on Friday during his visit to China, marking Xi's first meeting with a foreign private entrepreneur in recent years. This meeting, possibly a one-on-one encounter, may discuss global health and development challenges with the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation. Gates, Microsoft's co-founder, has not met with Xi since 2015 and has stepped down from Microsoft's board to focus on philanthropic works. The meeting comes after a long hiatus by Xi in meeting foreign private entrepreneurs, with several CEOs visiting China since its reopening.

images.alt_text: While he is inspired by the potential of artificial intelligence, Bill Gates acknowledges that it “raises hard questions about the workforce, the legal system, privacy, bias, and more”.

site_title: Keppel bags two deals to provide ‘energy-as-a-service’ in Bangkok
summary: Keppel Corp has secured two contracts in Bangkok to provide "energy-as-a-service" (EaaS) through its joint venture with Decarb Corp. The deals involve designing and retrofitting chilled-water systems in two buildings, Centara Watergate and Watergate Pavilion, to improve energy efficiency and reduce carbon emissions. The projects are expected to be completed by 2024, with a combined design capacity of 1,350 Refrigeration Tonnes, and are estimated to save over 23% of costs and reduce emissions by 18,000 tonnes over 20 years.

images.alt_text: The group's participation in the green hydrogen project consortium will give it access to a ready and reliable source of hydrogen as feedstock for the green production facility it plans to develop with Incitec Pivot and other potential partners.
The solutions, which support businesses’ decarbonisation goals, will be rolled out progressively in this coming year.

site_title: Private market exchange ADDX appoints SGX veteran Chew Sutat as chairman
summary: Private market exchange ADDX has appointed Chew Sutat, a former senior managing director at Singapore Exchange (SGX), as its chairman. Chew has been a board member of ADDX's holding company, ICHX Tech, since 2018 and will retain this role. He also chaired the platform's listing committee since 2019. ADDX provides access to alternative asset classes, including private equity, hedge funds, and private credit, and has listed over 70 deals on its platform, working with notable companies such as Singtel and Temasek-owned Fullerton Fund Management.

images.alt_text: In assets like private debt, illiquidity and poor visibility on credit risk are a challenge for individuals, particularly for those with a portfolio of less than US$10 million.
Yangzijiang Financial chief executive Vincent Toe said that the MOU will broaden the group's reach and boost its total assets under management.

site_title: Vietnam state coal miner to boost output to battle power shortage
summary: Vietnam's state coal miner, Vinacomin, plans to boost production by 15% this year to address electricity shortages amid high temperatures. The company aims to produce 39.7 million tonnes of coal, aiming to supply the power sector. This move comes as the country faces structural and bureaucratic issues, which have led to rolling blackouts at industrial parks and residential areas in recent weeks.

images.alt_text: epa10674738 A view of a Hanoi’s street as public lights are turned off to save electricity, Vietnam, 05 June 2023. Vietnam's capital city Hanoi has dimmed street lights, decorative lights, and lights from advertisement billboards to save electricity amid power shortage which Vietnam Electricity (EVN) power company said was due to rising consumption during heatwave.
