site_title: Hong Kong dollar interbank rates could meet or overshoot US rates, says HKMA
summary: Hong Kong's interbank rate could catch up or surpass US rates due to the city's seasonal demand for the local currency for dividend payments, according to Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) chief executive Eddie Yue. The peak season for dividend payments is in June to August, causing the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate to rise. This could lead to higher interest rates in Hong Kong, potentially surpassing those in the US. The HKD overnight interbank offered rate rose to 3.88% on Wednesday, the highest since May 30.

site_title: HSBC to raise UK mortgage prices for second time in a week
summary: HSBC will raise UK mortgage prices starting Thursday, its second increase in under a week, due to rising costs. The bank will remove its current new business residential products from sale via brokers at 5 pm local time on Wednesday to maintain service levels. Other lenders, including Banco Santander and NatWest Group, have also increased prices amid a fresh jump in mortgage rates. The average UK two-year fixed-rate mortgage rate has reached 5.9%, the highest since December.

images.alt_text: HSBC is stepping up in the market when VC activity is slowing due to global market uncertainty in the wake of the Federal Reserve-led monetary tightening.
HSBC said it decided to wind-down its wealth and personal banking business in New Zealand, the bank website showed on Tuesday.
UK households are cutting down other expenses to cover higher loan repayments, while many prospective buyers are avoiding the mortgage market altogether.

site_title: US: Wall St subdued at open as investors await Fed decision
summary: US stocks fell at the open on June 14, 2023, as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 167.42 points, or 0.49%, to 34,044.70. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 falling 2.72 points, or 0.06%, and the Nasdaq dropping 2.76 points, or 0.02%. The decline was partly due to shares of UnitedHealth, which warned of higher medical costs. Investors will closely monitor the Fed's decision later in the day.

site_title: US producer inflation subsides as energy, food prices fall
summary: US producer prices fell 0.3% in May, the smallest annual increase in nearly 2-1/2 years, due to declining energy and food costs. This signals that inflation pressures are abating and could provide relief to consumers. The Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates unchanged, with Fed officials citing reduced inflation concerns. Economists believe the decline in producer prices could lead to a period of consumer goods disinflation, but some remain skeptical about the potential for deflation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers select and pack items during Cyber Monday at the Amazon fulfilment centre in Robbinsville Township in New Jersey, U.S., November 28, 2022. REUTERS/Eduardo Munoz
Fed officials like to look at an even narrower category of core inflation, services excluding housing, to assess the trajectory of the stickiest price pressures.
Overall inflation in the US is decelerating, thanks to energy and food costs. Food commodity prices have dropped back to levels seen prior to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Mubadala forms 80 billion yen Japanese residential property venture
summary: Mubadala, an Abu Dhabi state investor, has formed a joint venture with Proprium Capital Partners and Manulife Investment Management to build an up to 80 billion yen (S$767 million) property portfolio in Japan. The venture will acquire existing rental multi-family properties and seek additional assets. Samurai Capital, a leading asset manager, will also partner the venture. The joint venture was seeded with existing properties in Japan, aiming to expand the portfolio through strategic acquisitions.

site_title: Singapore Paincare eyes China entry with investment in community hospital operator
summary: Singapore Paincare Holdings is investing 40 million yuan (S$7.6 million) in community hospital operator PuXiang Healthcare Holding in China, marking its first overseas market entry. The investment, made by its 51%-owned subsidiary Singapore Paincare Capital, gives the company a 2.26% stake in PuXiang, which operates 15 community hospitals in Beijing, Hebei, and Tianjin. The deal aims to establish a foothold in China's expanding healthcare market and explore joint medical services and pain management expertise.

images.alt_text: Dr Bernard Lee says the group's newly launched TCM brand aims to both integrate TCM with Western treatment interventions and capture a more pro-TCM patient profile.

site_title: Xi: China willing to help foster Palestinian peacemaking with Israel
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has expressed China's willingness to help the Palestinians achieve internal reconciliation and promote peace talks with Israel. Xi reiterated that the fundamental solution to the Palestinian issue lies in establishing an independent Palestinian state based on 1967 borders with East Jerusalem as its capital. China is also offering development assistance and humanitarian aid to the Palestinians, amid stalled peace talks and internal divisions within the Palestinian Authority. Xi and Palestinian President Mahmud Abbas have agreed to establish a strategic partnership and signed bilateral documents, including an economic and technological cooperation pact.

images.alt_text: China has always firmly supported the just cause of the Palestinian people to restore their legitimate rights,  Chinese Foreign Minister Qin Gang says.

site_title: Citigroup’s CFO warns 1,600 job cuts will boost expenses this quarter
summary: Citigroup's CFO, Mark Mason, warned that 1,600 job cuts will boost expenses by up to $400 million in the second quarter, primarily affecting its investment-banking and trading divisions. The bank has already set aside severance costs for 5,000 employees this year. Mason stated that the firm remains expense-disciplined, sometimes requiring cost-cutting measures like reducing headcount.

images.alt_text: Citigroup headquarters in New York.Photographer: Juan Cristobal Cobo/Bloomberg

Citi staff celebrating Citi Family Day with the announcement of Citi’s partnership with Touch Community Services. At the centre (in red) is guest of honour Eric Chua, Senior Parliamentary Secretary for MCCY and MSF.
The cuts are necessary for the bank to reduce its cost base because of adverse market conditions, according to a person within the bank, who isn’t authorised to speak publicly.

site_title: HK court approves withdrawal of wind-up case against Sunac China
summary: A Hong Kong court has approved the withdrawal of a winding-up case against Sunac China Holdings, removing a hurdle to the developer's $9 billion debt restructuring. The case was filed by a bondholder who claimed $22 million in principal and interest, but Sunac secured support from 87% of its offshore debt holders. This decision is a relief after three smaller peers were ordered to liquidate due to liquidity issues. Sunac's restructuring plan, featuring convertible bonds and debt swaps, now requires court approval to become binding on all creditors.

site_title: EU antitrust regulators charge Google with anti-competitive ad-tech practices
summary: EU antitrust regulators have charged Google with anti-competitive practices in its digital advertising business, alleging that the company favors its own ad exchange services over competitors. The European Commission stated that a behavioral remedy is unlikely to be effective and that Google may need to sell part of its business to address concerns. Google, the world's dominant digital-advertising platform, has 28% market share of global ad revenue, with $224.5 billion in advertising revenues in 2022. The EU competition watchdog believes that only mandatory divestment of part of its services can address competition concerns.

images.alt_text: While Google has previously introduced AI tools for advertisers, it is now using the technology to help brands achieve more specific goals for their ads.

site_title: US dollar backs down as traders price in a Fed skip
summary: The US dollar index dipped 0.2% to 103.14, its lowest since May 22, after unexpectedly soft US inflation data led to speculation that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates. The dollar index's drop comes as investors expect a hawkish hold by the Fed, but with a low probability, now below 5%. Meanwhile, the euro rose 0.1% to $1.0805, and sterling reached a one-month high of $1.265, while the Chinese yuan hit its weakest level in over six months against the US dollar.

site_title: Saudis look to China for business as US influence wanes
summary: Saudi Arabia has shifted its focus to strengthening ties with China, a move seen as a response to waning US influence in the region. Since President Xi Jinping's visit to the kingdom in December, Chinese executives have been actively seeking Gulf investment and a potential role in Saudi's Vision 2030 plan to transform the economy. Saudi officials have welcomed China as a "principal investment partner" in the region, with the goal of integrating China into the Arab world's development drive.

images.alt_text: Asked about criticism of the bilateral relationship during an Arab-China business conference, Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman says: “I actually ignore it because ... as a business person .. now you will go where opportunity comes your way.”

site_title: Qatar in talks with Egypt's wealth fund over hotel  investments
summary: Qatar's sovereign wealth fund is in talks with Egypt's wealth fund to potentially invest in seven historic hotels in Egypt, with the QIA considering a stake of up to 30%. The deal could be a landmark agreement between the two countries, which restored diplomatic ties in 2021 after a long-running dispute.

images.alt_text: In 2021, QIA set up a Singapore office to give it access to some of Asia’s largest companies and investors.

site_title: UBS amasses 1,200 private bankers in Asia as region spared cuts
summary: UBS has acquired 1,200 private bankers in Asia as part of its integration with Credit Suisse, surpassing rivals DBS and HSBC combined. The move is driven by global wealth chief Iqbal Khan's bet on Asia's lucrative client base. The acquisition cements UBS's dominance in the region, but marks a departure from its investment bank, which is expected to see widespread cutbacks. The integration has also scuppered Credit Suisse's plans to spin off parts of its wealth business, leaving dealmakers at a loose end.

images.alt_text: Jin Yee Young will join UBS on Jun 29, hopping over from Deutsche Bank where she had warmed the seat for under six months.

site_title: New GoTo CEO Walujo may not stay long, say sources
summary: GoTo Group's new CEO, Patrick Walujo, may not stay in the position for long, according to sources. Walujo plans to focus on improving profitability before potentially resigning, splitting his time between GoTo and his private equity firm, Northstar Group. His initial three-year term as CEO is subject to shareholder approval, and his tenure is likely to depend on trimming spending and improving profits.

images.alt_text: Gojek-Tokopedia merger: other startups eye fresh valuations
Northstar Group closes fifth fund with US$590m in capital
GoTo says CEO Andre Soelistyo, who has been in the company since 2015, has submitted his resignation and will take the post of commissioner as a deputy chairman.
Newly appointed CEO of GoTo Patrick Walujo is also the co-founder of private equity firm Northstar Group, one of the earliest investors of Gojek.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's inflation is projected to ease by 2024, with a forecasted 3.3% headline rate and 3% core rate. Economists downgraded the country's 2023 growth forecast to 1.4%, citing manufacturing contraction. The Singapore government has invested S$500 million in AI research and development over the past five years. The STI rose 0.9% on Wednesday ahead of the US Federal Reserve's decision, while private sector economists set new benchmarks for hospital fees and private equity bonds were redeemed.

site_title: World Bank chief to 'push' its balance sheet, vows to protect 'AAA' rating
summary: World Bank President Ajay Banga plans to expand the bank's balance sheet to fight climate change and other global challenges, but will not compromise its "AAA" credit rating. He aims to achieve tens of billions of dollars in additional annual lending, not hundreds of billions, through steps such as using hybrid capital and subordinated debt. Banga's efforts aim to channel private capital into developing countries to reduce carbon emissions and fund job-creating investments, a goal also emphasized by US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen.

images.alt_text: The Indian-born executive was nominated by the US for the job precisely because of his previous work in the private sector.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise on Wednesday ahead of Fed decision; STI up 0.9%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.9% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index closing at 3,218.14, driven by gains from Keppel Corporation, CapitaLand Investment, and Singapore Airlines. Investors await the US Federal Reserve's decision, with Saxo market strategist Charu Chanana noting the Fed may hold rates but still lean hawkish due to labor market strength and easing financial conditions.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.6 per cent higher on Tuesday, tracking the global market rally.

site_title: Shell to exit Pakistan unit with sale of shares
summary: Shell's Pakistan unit, Shell Pakistan (SPL), will exit the country after selling its 77.42% shareholding, including Downstream businesses and a 26% stake in Pak-Arab Pipeline Company Ltd. The move comes due to losses in 2022 caused by exchange rates, devaluation of the Pakistani rupee, and overdue receivables. Shell's parent company initiated the sales process to simplify its portfolio and support its high-grade strategy. The decision does not impact SPL's current business operations, which will continue unaffected.

images.alt_text: Shell CEO Wael Sawan attends the China Development Forum 2023 in Beijing, China, on March 25, 2023. REUTERS/Thomas Peter

site_title: Vodafone, Hutchison strike £15 billion deal to create UK mobile leader
summary: Vodafone and Hutchison have agreed to a £15 billion merger, creating a UK mobile leader with 27 million customers. Vodafone will own 51% and Hutchison 49%, with current Vodafone UK boss Ahmed Essam leading the combined group. The deal aims to drive competition and investment, with a £11 billion network investment plan over 10 years. Regulators will scrutinize the deal, which faces opposition from trade unions and concerns over national security. The combined operator will overtake BT's EE and VM O2, with improved network coverage expected within 12 months.

site_title: A Southern Italian wine dinner experience for The Business Times readers
summary: The Business Times is hosting a one-night wine dinner experience at Sofitel Singapore Sentosa Resort & Spa, featuring Southern Italian cuisine and wines from Produttori Di Manduria. The five-course dinner, curated by Chef De Cuisine Paolo Benedet, will take place on June 27 at The Cliff and will showcase the region's rich gastronomic heritage. Tickets are priced at S$138++ per diner, and two pairs of seats are being given away to subscribers.

images.alt_text: Black Périgord truffles vary in size from 3cm in diameter to the size of a large orange.

site_title: Australia's central bank owes underpaid workers more than US$770,000
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia, owes over US$770,000 to current and former employees after an internal review found it systematically underpaid leave entitlements. The review identified 1,173 staff members owed approximately US$777,975. Most of the owed amount came from leave entitlements that should have been paid out when staff left the bank. The bank has contacted the staff and begun making payments, with the Finance Sector Union welcoming the bank's apology.

images.alt_text: Some further tightening may still be required to bring inflation to heel but that would depend on how the Australian economy and inflation evolve, said Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe at the Morgan Stanley Australia Summit in Sydney.

site_title: Singapore shoppers blur lines between online and offline retail: report
summary: Singapore leads in omni-channel spending, accounting for 57% of retail spend in 2022, where consumers combine online and offline shopping. A study by GlobalData found that 48% of shoppers browse in physical stores before buying online, while 49% browse online before buying in a physical shop. This trend is driven by price-conscious consumers amid rising inflation.

images.alt_text: The future may lie in a hybrid and connected experience that effectively bridges online and offline advantages.
Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling launched the Retail Industry Transformation Map 2025 at the official opening of Castlery’s flagship store.

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB lowers ESR-Logos Reit’s target price to S$0.40, keeps ‘buy’ call
summary: RHB Research has maintained its 'buy' call for ESR-Logos Reit with a revised target price of S$0.40, down from S$0.45. The research team lowered distribution per unit estimates due to temporary earnings dilution from recent equity fundraising, but remains positive on the Reit's mid- to long-term strategy and redevelopment plans. ESR-Logos Reit is expected to use proceeds from divestments to acquire assets from its sponsor's pipeline, potentially in Singapore. The Reit's gearing is expected to fall below 35%, offering S$500 million in debt headroom.

images.alt_text: Ceva Logistics Singapore, the anchor tenant of the property located at 15 Greenwich Drive, occupies approximately 31,230 square metres or 74.2 per cent of the property by net lettable area.

Despite headwinds in Singapore such as rising inflation and interest rates, the manager expects the logistics segment to remain strong for storage space in ramp-up warehouses, along with an increasing demand for cargo lift assets for smaller occupiers.

site_title: Bringing durian snowskin mooncakes to China
summary: Singapore-based durian confectioner Golden Moments successfully launched its Mao Shan Wang durian snowskin mooncakes in China last August, ahead of the Mid-Autumn Festival. Despite the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic, the company was able to establish a presence on popular Chinese e-commerce platforms such as Tmall and WeChat. Golden Moments' products feature premium Mao Shan Wang durian and are packaged in elaborate gold-coloured packaging, suitable for corporate and personal gifts. The company plans to expand its offerings in China and explore offline channels, including pop-up stores in Shenzhen.

images.alt_text: Within Asean, Singapore ranks at the top of countries for businesses to venture into in their overseas expansion plans, while Thailand and Malaysia tie for second place.
Ling Goh (right) founded Ms Durian in 2019 and works closely with Jeslyn Tan (left), co-owner.

site_title: Amazon’s cloud unit is considering AMD’s new AI chips
summary: Amazon's cloud unit, AWS, is considering using AMD's new AI chips, despite not making a final decision. AMD's CEO Lisa Su outlined a strategy to win over major cloud customers by offering a customizable AI system. AWS Vice-President Dave Brown said the company is working with AMD on the design, which could plug into existing systems. This comes after AWS declined to work with Nvidia on a similar system, and prefers to design its own servers from the ground up.

images.alt_text: The company’s Instinct MI300 series will include an accelerator that can speed processing for generative AI – the technology used by ChatGPT and other chatbots.
AWS is the world’s largest seller of on-demand computing power and software services, which it delivers from a network of vast server farms.

site_title: ‘End of an era’ in Europe
summary: Former Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, known for his populist policies and ability to bounce back from scandals, has passed away. Berlusconi's tenure from 1994 to 2011 marked a significant shift in European politics, influencing figures like UK's Boris Johnson and former US President Donald Trump. His legacy highlights the evolution of populist politics in Europe over the past few decades. Berlusconi's remarkable ability to adapt and survive controversies has left a lasting impact on the continent's political landscape.

images.alt_text: Boris Johnson (left) and Donald Trump have championed a similar style of politics.
While Johnson’s immediate political career is over, he hinted that he may attempt to return at some point.
Silvio Berlusconi never publicly named an heir but people familiar with the matter told Reuters his eldest child, Marina, who already chairs Fininvest, is the most likely to take the reins.

FILE PHOTO: Forza Italia leader Silvio Berlusconi gestures during the closing electoral campaign rally of the centre-right's coalition in Piazza del Popolo, ahead of the September 25 general election, in Rome, Italy, September 22, 2022. REUTERS/Yara Nardi/File Photo

site_title: Swiss stock exchange is investigating worst outage in a decade
summary: The SIX Swiss Exchange is investigating its worst outage in over a decade, which occurred on June 13 when trading was interrupted for over 3 hours. The exchange has ruled out a hack and attributed the issue to a technical problem. A post-mortem analysis will be released in the coming days. The outage adds to a string of glitches in global stock markets, prompting regulators to focus on improving protocol for such incidents. The exchange has promised to implement measures to prevent similar outages in the future.

site_title: Brics common currency would be no threat to the US dollar
summary: Brics countries, including Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa, have discussed creating a common currency, with the New Development Bank tasked with finding ideas to achieve this. A common currency would likely exist in addition to the US dollar, not replacing it, and would be a regional initiative similar to the euro. China would need to shoulder the burden of establishing and funding the mechanism, providing credit in renminbi to countries with trade deficits, and removing obstacles to the fungibility of the renminbi.

images.alt_text: President Xi Jinping has taken steps to promote the country’s reputation abroad, even as he focuses on implementing reforms and bolstering growth at home.

(FILES) This file photo taken on March 26, 2023 shows cargo ships berthing at Suqian port in China's eastern Jiangsu province. - China's exports rose in March for the first time in six months, customs data showed on April 13, as the world's second-largest economy continued its recovery following the end of onerous coronavirus curbs late last year. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT
President Lula said the Brics bank has great potential “in that it frees emerging countries from submission to traditional financial institutions, which want to govern us.”

site_title: Airbus predicts Asia to lead air traffic boom in coming decades
summary: Airbus predicts the global air traffic boom will be driven by Asia, with the installed fleet expected to more than double to 46,560 aircraft by 2042. The majority of new deliveries (40,850) will be narrow-body planes, mainly in China and the rest of Asia, with the country expected to have 9,440 aircraft by 2042. Airbus expects to expand its lead in narrow-body jet manufacturing, while Boeing will maintain its dominance in widebody sales, with the Middle East maintaining the highest proportion of widebody fleets.

images.alt_text: Airbus and US rival Boeing are contending with supply chain and production headaches that have slowed efforts by both plane makers to ramp up deliveries.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank initiates coverage on Jollibee Foods with ‘buy’
summary: Maybank Securities initiated coverage on Jollibee Foods with a "buy" call, citing strong earnings growth driven by robust domestic spending and rising margins in the international segment. Analysts expect FY2023 earnings to rise 14% and FY2024 earnings to rise 18%, with revenue increasing 17% and 11% year-over-year. The brokerage set a discounted cash flow-based target price of 285 Philippine pesos, representing a 21.8% potential upside. Maybank believes JFC's premium valuation is warranted due to its dominant market position and above-average consumption growth in the Philippines.

images.alt_text: Philippine fried chicken king targets expansion after Covid
Jollibee eyes 450 new, mostly overseas stores as it sees rebound

site_title: Zurich Insurance eyes US$400 million stake in general insurance arm of India's Kotak
summary: Swiss insurer Zurich Insurance is in talks to buy a 51% stake in India's Kotak General Insurance, valued at around $800 million. The deal, which could be worth $400 million, would be Zurich's first major investment in the fast-growing South Asian insurance market. Kotak General Insurance is seeking an investor to turn around its business and grow faster, but prefers retaining control of the company after the stake sale. The deal comes as India relaxes foreign investment rules for the insurance sector, allowing companies to acquire majority stakes of up to 74%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Zurich Insurance is seen in Davos, Switzerland January 20, 2020.  Picture taken January 20, 2020. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Thai industrial mood at 8-month low on weak exports, political uncertainty
summary: Thailand's industrial sentiment index fell to 92.5 in May, its lowest level in eight months, due to weak exports and uncertainty over the new government. The Federation of Thai Industries (FTI) reported a second consecutive month of decline, down from 95.0 in the previous month. Slowing global growth and exchange rate volatility are affecting demand for shipments, with exporters also impacted. This marks the second consecutive month of decline in industrial sentiment, highlighting the challenges facing the Thai economy.

site_title: About S$500 million invested in AI innovation in last 5 years: Josephine Teo
summary: The Singapore government has invested approximately S$500 million in artificial intelligence (AI) research and development over the last five years. Minister Josephine Teo emphasized the need for private sector collaboration to harness AI for public good. The government is running initiatives to nurture tech talent, including the Company-Led Training program, which has trained over 2,600 individuals in AI and data analytics roles. Additionally, US-based philanthropic initiative Schmidt Futures will fund up to 110 post-doctoral fellows to focus on AI innovations in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics.

images.alt_text: The hacker house will run both online and offline and consists of developer quests, hackathons and meetups in cities around the world, including in Singapore.

AI Verify was launched as a minimum viable product for international pilot last year. It has attracted interest from over 50 local and multinational companies including IBM, Dell and Hitachi, IMDA says.
DPM Lawrence Wong at the Asia Tech x Singapore 2023 conference, held in Sentosa, on June 6, 2023.

site_title: MOH sets benchmarks for private hospital fees
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) has set new benchmarks for private hospital fees in Singapore, covering 2,100 procedures, including 21 common surgical procedures and eight common medical conditions. The benchmarks aim to reflect current costs and inflationary pressures, with recommended price ranges for hospital fees and surgeon fees. Existing benchmarks have been raised by 12.1% for surgeons and 9.9% for anaesthetists. The guidelines are not mandatory but aim to provide a reference for private healthcare providers and insurers, with the goal of controlling healthcare costs and ensuring transparency.

images.alt_text: Daxue Investments, Temasek Holdings’ indirect unit, and True Light P, held by Temasek-owned True Light Capital GP, will altogether hold 17.55 per cent stake in Viva Shanghai after the deal.
Analysts from UOB Kay Hian and the Singapore research team remain bullish about Delfi’s growth prospects in Indonesia.

site_title: OK Lim’s lawyer casts doubt on whether CAD followed protocol to question former tycoon
summary: OK Lim's lawyer questions the police's protocol in questioning the former oil tycoon, citing his severe depression and anxiety. The defense argues that Lim was unfit for questioning due to his mental state, poor concentration, and weak memory. However, the prosecution's witness, Sim Wan Lin, claims that she made an effort to minimize the time needed for the sessions and offered breaks to help Lim recollect his statements. The defense further questions Sim's intentions, suggesting that she prioritized finding evidence to implicate Lim over his mental well-being. The trial continues.

images.alt_text: The criminal trial on cheating and forgery charges against Hin Leong's founder Lim Oon Kuin, better known as OK Lim, continues in Singapore's State Court.
Singapore's fallen oil legend Lim Oon Kuin or OK Lim, as he is better known, arrives in the State Courts on Apr 11.
How it all went south for Hin Leong

site_title: Logitech says CEO stepping down, shares fall
summary: Logitech CEO Bracken Darrell is stepping down with immediate effect, leaving the company after a 10-year tenure. Darrell will remain with the company for a month to facilitate the transition. Interim CEO Guy Getch will take over. The company's shares fell 8.6% after the announcement, caught analysts off guard. Darrell cited a desire to hand over leadership, stating he will remain a customer, shareholder, and fan of the company.

images.alt_text: The maker of computer mice, keyboards and video conferencing equipment said its non-GAAP operating income slipped 47 per cent to US$82 million in the reported quarter.
The Swiss company’s move is in line with downsizing efforts across the tech industry.

site_title: German wholesale prices drop sharply in May
summary: German wholesale prices dropped 2.6% in May, the largest decline in nearly three years, indicating a decrease in inflation. This follows a 1.1% drop compared to the previous month. The decrease was mainly due to falling prices for mineral oil products. Consumer prices rose 6.3% in May, the lowest level in over a year, suggesting inflation is easing.

site_title: Narrow breadth of current bull market in US stocks warrants caution
summary: The US stock market has entered a bull run, with the S&P 500 rising over 20% since its October low, driven by a tech-driven rally. However, the narrow breadth of the market raises concerns that any correction could be sharp. Despite a pause in rate hikes and supportive inflation data, the prospect of recession remains a concern. Investors should be cautious, as tech stocks, which account for over 28% of the S&P 500, could be winners in an AI-infused future but also pose a risk of over-concentration.

images.alt_text: The latest bull market arising from the ashes has some elements of the short and violent pandemic bull market, which began in March 2020.

(FILES) In this file photo a sign for Bank of America is seen on 3rd Avenue in New York City, on May 11, 2018. - Bank of America announced plans to lift its minimum wage to $25 an hour and said on May 18, 2021 it is requiring US vendors to pay employees at least $15 an hour. The salary hike for employees will take place by 2025, the company said. In March 2020, the giant US bank lifted its minimum wage to $20 an hour from $17 an hour. (Photo by HECTOR RETAMAL / AFP)

site_title: Harry Potter park in Tokyo hopes to enchant Asian fans
summary: A new Harry Potter theme park, Warner Bros Studio Tour Tokyo, is set to open in Tokyo on June 16, offering fans a chance to immerse themselves in the boy wizard's world. The park recreates iconic film locations like Diagon Alley and the Ministry of Magic, and tickets have sold out until August for 6,300 yen (S$60.40) for adults. The location near the Japanese capital is ideal, capitalizing on the growing global tourism market after the Covid-19 pandemic, with the park aiming to put itself at the center of the regional market.

site_title: Shell boosts dividend, steadies oil output in new CEO plan
summary: Shell boosts dividend, aims to keep oil output steady as part of CEO Wael Sawan's efforts to regain investor confidence. The company will increase overall shareholder distribution to 30-40% of cash flow and ramp up share buybacks. Shell will maintain oil production at 1.5 million barrels per day through 2030, while growing its natural gas business to defend its position as the world's largest LNG player.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Shell sign at one of the oil company's petrol stations in South East London, Britain, February 2, 2023. REUTERS/May James/File Photo

site_title: Indian wholesale prices fall 3.48% in May
summary: Indian wholesale prices fell 3.48% in May, the second consecutive month, due to easing input costs from lower commodity prices. The wholesale price index (WPI) fell 0.92% in April. Food prices dropped 1.59% year-on-year, while fuel and power prices fell 9.17%. This easing of inflation pressure follows a recent decline in retail inflation to 4.25% in May, closer to the Reserve Bank of India's 4% target.

images.alt_text: “The cumulative impact of our monetary policy actions over the last one year is still unfolding and yet to materialise fully,” Reserve Bank of India (RBI) governor Shaktikanta Das says.

site_title: Ubisoft sets sights on VR, AI shakeups in future of gaming
summary: Ubisoft is investing in virtual reality (VR) and artificial intelligence (AI), expecting them to revolutionize the gaming industry. The company's CEO, Yves Guillemot, believes VR will become a major disruptor, driven by Apple's massive investment in the technology. Ubisoft also plans to develop games for Apple's Vision Pro headset and has announced a free-to-play version of Assassin's Creed and a VR version compatible with Meta's Quest gear. Additionally, Guillemot sees generative AI as a "fantastic opportunity" to make games more intelligent and immersive.

images.alt_text: Globally, Tencent’s appetite for content isn’t waning even at a time it’s divesting assets and spending more judiciously at home.
Global NFT sales were US$736 million in March.
The string of setbacks has led to a more than 55 per cent plunge in Ubisoft’s shares since August, which could make it a prime takeover target in the industry.

site_title: Thai central bank focused on domestic outlook, sees continued recovery
summary: The Bank of Thailand has reaffirmed its focus on domestic economic growth, stating that the policy rate is not yet at a "neutral level." The central bank will continue to normalize interest rates, aiming for positive real interest rates, as it seeks to balance economic expansion with inflation control. The bank expects continued economic growth, with some upside risks, and has maintained its forecasts for 3.6% growth this year and 3.8% next year.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Thailand (BOT) sees average headline inflation returning to within its target range of 1 per cent to 3 per cent in 2023.
The government expects at least 25 million foreign visitors in the whole of 2023.

site_title: Greenpeace activists climb Deutsche Bank building to protest against investment policies
summary: Greenpeace activists scaled Deutsche Bank's Frankfurt headquarters on June 14 to protest against the bank's and its asset management company DWS' climate investment policies. The banner "Force DWS, protect the climate" was unfurled, drawing a half dozen police vehicles but no arrests. The action comes ahead of DWS' annual shareholder meeting, where CEO Stefan Hoops plans to address allegations of "greenwashing." Greenpeace finance expert Mauricio Vargas will also speak, stating that DWS' scandal is Deutsche Bank's scandal. DWS disputes the allegations and claims to have recently adopted new policies on dealing with coal companies.

images.alt_text: Greenpeace activists hang a banner to protest Deutsche Bank and DWS investment policies on Deutsche Bank's headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany, June 14, 2023.  REUTERS/Tom Sims
Germany is aiming to have renewables make up 80 per cent of its energy mix by 2030, up from 46 per cent currently.

site_title: China increases oil import quotas 20% on year ago
summary: China has issued a third batch of 2023 crude oil import quotas, increasing the total volume in the first half of the year to 194.1 million tonnes, a 20% rise from the same period last year. The new quotas total 62.28 million tonnes, mainly allocated to independent refiners, and are part of a tougher scrutiny of crude oil imports following a flood of discounted feedstock.

images.alt_text: One of the reasons overseas investors have been wary about investing in Chinese debt has been the weakening yuan.
Oil traders have been closely watching while the government begins refilling the emergency stockpile, as its purchases are bound to tighten the market.

site_title: Acclaimed Malaysian horror film embraces ‘female monstrosity’
summary: Malaysian director Amanda Nell Eu's horror film "Tiger Stripes" celebrates "feminine monstrosity" as a symbol of female empowerment. The film follows three teenage girls navigating puberty, body changes, and social pressures, culminating in a transformation into tiger-like creatures. Eu aims to challenge the silence and fear surrounding puberty, offering a fresh take on female empowerment and liberation. "Tiger Stripes" has been hailed as a "body horror" and has won top prizes at the Cannes Film Festival, cementing Eu's position as a rising talent in the industry.

images.alt_text: In this picture taken on June 12, 2023, Malaysian director Amanda Nell Eu, winner of the grand prize at Cannes International Critics' Week 2023, poses for pictures during an interview with AFP in Kuala Lumpur. In "Tiger Stripes", the first Malaysian movie to win a top prize at Cannes, teen monsters don't just get acne, they start to morph and growl, sprouting whiskers and claws and escape into the jungle. (Photo by Mohd RASFAN / AFP)

site_title: Art Basel’s pre-fair jitters turn to relief as sales remain solid
summary: Art Basel's pre-fair jitters about a faltering art market dissipated as sales remained solid during the VIP opening. Collector Lonti Ebers expressed her willingness to buy art regardless of market conditions, while art experts like Loa Haagen Pictet and Thilo Wermke reported brisk sales. Established dealers like Hauser & Wirth and Pace also saw encouraging first-day responses from collectors, with several major sales including a Louise Bourgeois sculpture for $22.5 million and a Mark Bradford piece for $4.5 million.

Spectrosynthesis III at Tai Kwun is one of the best exhibitions in Hong Kong right now.

site_title: Google launches AI-powered advertiser features in push for automation
summary: Google has launched two AI-powered features for advertisers to help brands achieve specific goals. The new features, Demand Gen and Ad Placement, use AI to automatically find the best ad placements across Google's services, including Gmail and YouTube. Early testing shows a 40% increase in video views for brands using the new tool, allowing advertisers to focus on their marketing strategy and storytelling. The move aims to automate ad placement and provide more effective advertising for brands.

Google touts the News Showcase as a way to support a news industry that has seen its main source of revenue dwindle since advertisers left print media for search ads.

site_title: What’s this? A handbag for ants?
summary: MSCHF, a creative collective, unveiled its Microscopic Handbag, a tiny, fluorescent green bag measuring 657 by 222 by 700 micrometers, smaller than a grain of sea salt. The bag is a commentary on the impracticality of luxury handbags and strips away all utility, leaving only a brand signifier. It will be sold as a lot in an auction organized by Sarah Andelman and Pharrell Williams' auction house, with the proceeds to be donated to charity. The bag was created using a 3D printing process and will be displayed at Men's Fashion Week in Paris.

images.alt_text: Ling Fu decided to start her own luxury handbag label when she got frustrated with the buying process of coveted handbags.

site_title: A US$204 million mansion is Dubai’s most expensive house for sale
summary: A US$204 million mansion in Dubai's Emirates Hills neighbourhood is the most expensive house for sale, featuring 60,000 sq ft of indoor space, a 15-car garage, and a 70,000-litre coral reef aquarium. The property, nicknamed the "Marble Palace," took nearly 12 years to build and was decorated with 400 pieces of art. Only a few potential buyers, estimated to be around 5-10, have shown interest, with two viewing the property in the past three weeks. The sale price is justified by the value of the materials and time invested in building the luxurious property.

site_title: HSBC eyes leading role in banking for VCs, startups after hiring wave
summary: HSBC is expanding its services to venture capital firms and startups globally, hiring a large team of technology and healthcare bankers in the US, Hong Kong, and Israel. The bank is focusing on deposit gathering, transactional banking services, and lending, and is already doing venture-type lending in India and Singapore. This move comes as global VC investment slows due to market uncertainty, with HSBC CEO Michael Roberts saying it's a good time for the bank to establish this initiative as VC companies grow.

images.alt_text: HSBC said it decided to wind-down its wealth and personal banking business in New Zealand, the bank website showed on Tuesday.
Quinn says the bank was considering expanding its technology operation across France, Germany and other markets in continental Europe, as well as potentially growing in Asia.

site_title: Airbus to send Chinese-made A321 to Wizz in a first for Europe
summary: Airbus is set to deliver a Chinese-made A321 jet to Wizz Air Holdings, marking a first for Europe, as the company works to ramp up deliveries amid supply chain and production headaches. The A321neo took its first test flight on June 9, and Airbus's Tianjin plant has secured a production slot for the carrier. Most of the planes built in Tianjin have gone to Chinese airlines, but this marks a shift towards European customers as the plant expands its global reach.

Widebody aircraft are generally more complex to manufacture because they have more elaborate interiors, like fancier business-class seats and flexible layouts for elements like galleys.

site_title: Economists downgrade 2023 growth forecast to 1.4%, manufacturing set to shrink: survey
summary: Economists have downgraded Singapore's 2023 economic growth forecast to 1.4%, citing a contraction in the manufacturing sector and a deeper slump in non-oil domestic exports. Inflation is expected to ease by 2024, with headline inflation at 3.3% and core inflation at 3%. The construction and accommodation and food services sectors are the only sectors to show improvement, according to a quarterly survey of professional forecasters.

images.alt_text: Economists barely change 2023 forecasts for Singapore’s growth, inflation: survey

site_title: South Korea’s jobless rate falls to record low, factory sector still shaky
summary: South Korea's jobless rate has fallen to a record low of 2.5% in May, the lowest since 1999, according to Statistics Korea. The number of employed people rose by 351,000, with growth in the services sector and a softer decline in the manufacturing sector. However, conditions remain soft due to slowing economic growth and external challenges. Employment growth is expected to continue, driven by the face-to-face services sector, but a manufacturing sector recovery is delayed due to weak exports and facility investments.

images.alt_text: A view shows Samsung Electronics' chip production plant at Pyeongtaek, South Korea, in this handout picture obtained by Reuters on September 7, 2022.  Samsung Electronics/Handout via REUTERS    THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY
It was the 15th month in a row that the export-reliant economy suffered a trade deficit but the smallest amount since May 2022.

site_title: Retail and films drive modest growth in UK economy
summary: The UK economy grew 0.2% month-on-month in April, matching expectations, despite contractions in manufacturing and construction. Retail and the film industry drove growth, while the health sector was the biggest drag due to junior doctor strikes. The economy expanded 0.1% over the three months to April, indicating a "low growth trajectory." Finance minister Jeremy Hunt stated the government will stick to its plan to halve inflation this year, despite the data.

images.alt_text: Markets expect that even once the BOE is done tightening, the first quarter-point cut won’t take place until late in 2024.

site_title: China e-commerce shipments would lose US tariff exemption under proposed law
summary: A bipartisan US group of lawmakers plans to introduce a bill to eliminate the de minimis rule, exempting imports valued at $800 or less from tariffs if shipped to individual consumers. The rule, widely used by e-commerce sellers like Shein and Temu, would be banned for shipments from China immediately upon enactment. The move aims to curb the importation of low-value packages, including those made with forced labor, and has been criticized for exploiting the exemption. The bill's sponsors include Republican Senator Bill Cassidy and Democratic Senators Tammy Baldwin and JD Vance.

images.alt_text: The hiring comes as Shein, a Singapore-based, China-founded e-retailer, faces more scrutiny from US lawmakers who have worries about the company’s connections to China.
US lawmaker warnings about China e-commerce fashion retailers such as Shein could signal upcoming regulatory action.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.3% to 3,197.76, following global markets' gains on mild US inflation data and interest rate hike expectations. Gainers outnumbered losers 80 to 32, with Koh Brothers Eco Engineering rising 6.1% after securing a S$186 million contract. The three local banks were mixed, with DBS and OCBC gaining, while UOB lost 0.1%.

images.alt_text: Koh Brothers Eco and LBD Engineering have secured a S$186 million contract from HDB to construct the Kallang Integrated Development.

site_title: Gold holds steady as traders brace for US Fed decision
summary: Gold prices held steady at $1,945.29 per ounce, influenced by the easing of the US dollar and the upcoming US Federal Reserve decision. The annual increase in the consumer price index was the smallest in over two years, but underlying price pressures remain strong, potentially leading to a Fed rate hike. Expectations of an unchanged interest rate are currently at 94.2%. Global fund managers cut equity allocations to a five-month low, while cash levels dropped to 5.1% as investors await the Fed's decision.

images.alt_text: The US dollar eased 0.1 per cent, making greenback-priced bullion more appealing to overseas buyers.

site_title: Summer rate hikes threaten to push UK housing market to breaking point
summary: The UK housing market is facing significant challenges due to a worsening cost-of-living crisis, economic uncertainty, and soaring borrowing costs. Mortgage rates have jumped, and lenders are withdrawing products, setting up borrowers and homebuyers for a nerve-racking summer. Economists predict a 10% decline in home values, and two-year mortgage rates near 6%, a "tipping point" for the market, according to Zoopla's executive director.

images.alt_text: A view of residential properties with the skyline of London's financial district seen behind, seen from Alexandra Palace in London on January 15, 2023. (Photo by Justin TALLIS / AFP)

site_title: Rare icons evacuated from Ukraine go on show in Paris’ Louvre Museum
summary: The Louvre Museum in Paris has begun exhibiting five rare icons evacuated from Ukraine's Bohdan and Varvara Khanenko National Museum of Arts in Kyiv. The icons, including 16 fragile works, were secretly evacuated in May and transported to France via Poland and Germany. The exhibition, titled "The Origins of the Sacred Image," will run until November 6, featuring icons from the 6th to 14th centuries. The Ukrainian culture minister expressed gratitude for the gesture, stating it symbolizes support for Ukrainian culture amidst ongoing war and damage to cultural heritage sites.

site_title: From black gold to green goals
summary: Fortrec Group, a local petrochemical company, is helping refineries reduce their carbon footprint by converting "refinery bottoms" into industrial solvents. The company's proprietary process can calculate the carbon emission savings, increasing interest from refineries seeking to report reductions. With a target of US$300 million in revenue by 2026, Fortrec aims to triple its current revenue and reduce transportation costs by setting up local joint ventures with refineries and solvent manufacturers. This move will help eliminate carbon emissions from transportation and reduce costs.

site_title: Meta releases ‘human-like’ AI image creation model
summary: Meta has released a new "human-like" AI image creation model called I-JEPA, which can analyze and complete unfinished images more accurately than existing models. The model uses background knowledge to fill in missing pieces, rather than looking only at nearby pixels. This approach helps the technology avoid common errors, such as hands with extra fingers. Meta plans to make the model open-sourced to promote innovation and safety. The move follows Meta's efforts to incorporate generative AI features into its consumer products, including ad tools and Instagram photo modification.

site_title: China rate cut gives investors reason to buy yuan bonds again
summary: China's central bank cut its seven-day reverse repurchase rate to 1.9% on June 13, boosting speculation of a potential one-year loan rate cut and fueling a rally in government bonds. The move is seen as a sign of policymakers' efforts to shore up the economy, with HSBC Asset Management and BNY Mellon Investment Management predicting further fiscal stimulus and a significant rally in Chinese bonds. The People's Bank of China's decision is expected to give investors reason to return to the nation's bonds, particularly as the yuan continues to weaken.

site_title: Extreme weather killed 195,000 in Europe since 1980
summary: Extreme weather events in Europe have claimed nearly 195,000 lives and caused over 560 billion euros in economic losses since 1980. Heatwaves accounted for 81% of deaths and 15% of financial losses. The European Environment Agency (EEA) attributes these losses to climate change, which has increased the risk of drought five- or six-fold. Economic losses are projected to rise to 25 billion euros per year by the end of the century if global temperatures rise by 1.5°C.

site_title: The birth of the 2023 bull market
summary: The US stock market has entered a new bull market, following a 18-month-long bear market that began after the US Federal Reserve raised interest rates to combat inflation. The S&P 500 has risen 20% from its low, meeting the definition of a new bull market. Investors are focusing on consumer spending, inflation easing, and the potential of artificial intelligence (AI) technology, with AI-related stocks leading the way. The bull market is characterized by a shift from fear to greed, with the CBOE market volatility index at its lowest level since 2020.

site_title: Disney to turn updated ‘Little Mermaid’ into TV series
summary: Disney is developing a new animated children's series, "Disney Junior's Ariel," inspired by its 1989 film "The Little Mermaid," featuring a black Ariel. The series, aimed at toddlers, is currently in production and set for release next year. This comes after Disney faced backlash for casting Halle Bailey as Ariel in the live-action remake, a departure from the original's white actress. The new series aims to provide a more inclusive representation for young viewers.

site_title: US plans to buy 12 million barrels of oil for reserve this year
summary: The US plans to purchase approximately 12 million barrels of oil this year to refill its depleted Strategic Petroleum Reserve, now at a 40-year-low following a historic 180 million barrel drawdown last year. This includes 3 million barrels scheduled for August and an additional 3 million barrels from a recent solicitation. The Energy Department aims to continue seeking additional repurchases as market conditions allow.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Koh Brothers Eco Engineering, EC World Reit
summary: Koh Brothers Eco Engineering and LBD Engineering secured a S$186 million contract from the Housing and Development Board (HDB) to construct the Kallang Integrated Development. EC World Reit received a waiver from the Monetary Authority of Singapore to complete its proposed divestment of two Chinese logistics assets by the June 16 deadline, allowing it to avoid delays. The news may impact trading of these companies' securities.

site_title: AMD gives peek at upcoming line of AI processors in challenge to rival Nvidia
summary: AMD unveiled its upcoming Instinct MI300 series of AI processors, aiming to challenge Nvidia's dominance in the AI computing market. The MI300X accelerator can speed processing for generative AI, a technology used by chatbots like ChatGPT. The move is in response to booming demand for AI computing, with data centers struggling to handle the workload. AMD's goal is to help data centers handle the AI traffic, making it a key player in the burgeoning market.

site_title: Singapore’s first listed retail PE bonds redeemed, additional 0.5% bonus paid
summary: Singapore's first listed retail private equity (PE) bonds, Astrea IV, have been fully redeemed with a 0.5% bonus paid to bondholders who subscribed to the 2018 tranche. The bonds, worth S$242 million, had a fixed interest rate of 4.35% per annum. The redemption was made five years after their issue date, and the performance threshold was met at the time of redemption. This successful redemption is seen as a testament to the strong fundamentals of the Astrea transactions and quality of the Astrea portfolios, according to Azalea Asset Management's CEO.

site_title: Binance.US, SEC not far apart on deal avoiding full asset freeze
summary: US district judge Amy Berman Jackson has agreed that Binance.US and the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) are "not that far apart" on a deal that avoids a full asset freeze for the cryptocurrency trading platform. The SEC had sought an asset freeze for Binance.US, accusing it of operating illegally, but the two sides have agreed to work on a compromise that would protect billions of dollars in customer funds. The judge has referred them to a magistrate judge to work on a compromise agreement, and will hold off on deciding the SEC's request until the work is completed.

site_title: China, Singapore private wealth continues to support shophouse demand
summary: China and Singapore private wealth investors continue to drive demand for shophouses in Singapore, with recent deals including a S$30 million purchase of a three-storey shophouse at 37 Boat Quay, setting a record for a conservation shophouse in Districts 1 and 2. Another deal saw a S$23.8 million sale of a four-storey corner conservation shophouse at 11 New Bridge Road, with a China national linked to ACON Laboratories buying the property. The shophouse market remains active, with buyers typically requiring little or no financing, despite a slowdown in viewings due to the school vacation.

images.alt_text: 28 Stanley Street (white building) is being sold with vacant possession.
The six-storey shophouse at 52 Boat Quay is the tallest conservation shophouse along the Singapore River.

site_title: Bank of England started interest rate hikes first, but is set to finish last
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) was the first major central bank to raise interest rates in response to post-pandemic inflation surge, but is now expected to be the last to stop. Strong labour-market figures sparked a surge in bond markets, with two-year gilt yields jumping to the highest since 2008. Markets now price a more than one-in-three chance that the BOE will lift its benchmark rate to 6% by early next year, potentially exacerbating a housing slowdown.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England in the City of London, UK. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Asia: Markets extend rally as US inflation data fans rate pause hopes
summary: Asian markets extended their rally on Wednesday, driven by US inflation data that fueled hopes of a Federal Reserve interest rate pause. Hong Kong, Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, and Taipei rose, while Seoul and Wellington struggled. Speculation over China's economic support measures and Beijing's upcoming monetary policy decision also boosted traders. The sharp drop in US inflation, slightly more than forecast, suggested 15 months of central bank tightening was starting to take effect.

The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.6 per cent higher on Tuesday, tracking the global market rally.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.4 per cent higher at 34,212.12 on Tuesday.

site_title: Netflix brings food from screen to table at first pop-up restaurant
summary: Netflix is launching its first pop-up restaurant, "Netflix Bites," in Los Angeles, starting June 30. The restaurant, featuring chefs from popular shows like Iron Chef and Chef's Table, will offer an elevated dining experience with a special tasting menu and custom cocktails. The pop-up will be open 7 days a week from 5 pm to 10 pm. This marks Netflix's latest move into live experiences, following previous events like a "Queen's Ball" and a pop-up retail store.

site_title: AI startup Synthesia gains unicorn status after Nvidia-backed fundraise
summary: Synthesia, a UK-based AI startup, has raised $90 million at a valuation of $1 billion from Accel and Nvidia-owned NVentures. The company helps over 50,000 businesses, including Amazon, create custom AI avatars for instructional and corporate videos. Synthesia navigates concerns over deepfakes by only creating avatars of consenting individuals. The funding round makes Synthesia a unicorn, a startup valued at over $1 billion, and follows a trend of AI startups receiving significant investments amid a slowdown in funding.

site_title: Asia’s gamblers cheer wave of legalisation, pressuring Macau
summary: Macau, the world's largest gambling hub, faces increasing pressure from neighboring countries and the Middle East as they move towards building or allowing their first casinos. This shift in the Asian gaming landscape could lead to a decline in Macau's market share, as countries like Japan, Thailand, and the UAE target Chinese tourists. Macau's casino revenue has dropped by half since China's crackdown on high rollers, and the territory must now pivot to mass entertainment options to remain competitive. The establishment of new gaming centers could pose a significant challenge for Macau, which has pledged to invest billions in non-gaming industries.

images.alt_text: MGM has been expanding into digital products, with the market for land-based casinos already built out and new licences hard to win.

site_title: Fuelling Hong Kong’s innovation path: Lessons from Singapore
summary: Hong Kong can fuel its innovation path by learning from Singapore's success, according to a recent visit by Chinese President Xi Jinping to the Hong Kong Science and Technology Parks Corporation. Singapore has emerged as a frontrunner in Asia's innovation landscape, registering over 6,000 patents and earning $11.6 billion in IP revenue in 2021. Hong Kong, however, earned only $0.7 billion in IP revenue in 2020, highlighting the need to understand the factors contributing to the gap and draw valuable lessons. To catch up, Hong Kong must strategise and implement policies to retain and groom top talent, and adapt to the global dynamic to ensure sustainable innovation growth.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise as US inflation data soothes rate hike jitters
summary: European shares rose 0.6% on Tuesday, following mild US inflation data that suggested the Federal Reserve may skip raising interest rates this week. The Stoxx 600 index tracked the global market rally, with miners and tech stocks also gaining ground. China's rate cut boosted metal prices, and shares of luxury giant LVMH and industrial technology group Hexagon rose. However, German consumer prices rose 6.3% in May, and the Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates again to contain inflation.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.4 per cent higher at 34,212.12 on Tuesday.

site_title: Fewer people trust traditional media, more turn to TikTok for news: report
summary: A report by the Reuters Institute for the Study of Journalism found that trust in traditional media has declined, with fewer than half of respondents expressing interest in news. Instead, 20% of 18- to 24-year-olds rely on TikTok for news, up 5 percentage points from last year. The survey also found that people prefer algorithms to editors or journalists in selecting news, and that 56% worry about identifying real and fake news online.

site_title: Disney delays ‘Avatar’, ‘Star Wars’ films in major shakeup
summary: Disney has delayed several major films, including 'Avatar' and 'Star Wars', by up to three years. The third 'Avatar' film is now set to release in December 2025, while two other 'Avatar' sequels and two Marvel 'Avengers' films have been pushed back to 2029, 2031, and 2026, respectively. The decision not to release the next 'Star Wars' film until May 2026 is also notable, as it has been nearly four years since the last 'Star Wars' film was released. No Pixar or Disney animated films appear to be impacted by the delays.

site_title: Shell’s six decarbonisation proposals
summary: Shell releases a 2020 report, "All Hands on Deck 2.0", outlining six decarbonisation proposals for the shipping industry. The proposals, aimed at achieving net-zero emissions by 2050, include scaling up demand for low-carbon fuels, taking a segment-specific approach, and leveraging local regulations. The report's recommendations aim to create clearer signals of demand, prioritize and tailor solutions, and drive progress through near-term material impact on greenhouse gas emissions. Shell's president, Melissa Williams, emphasizes the need for collective action to decarbonize the shipping industry.

site_title: Amazon says it’s resolving outage that knocked websites offline
summary: Amazon's cloud-computing arm, AWS, is resolving an outage that disrupted a range of websites and services, including the New York transit agency's status updates. The issue, affecting the US-EAST-1 region, began on Tuesday and caused errors and latencies in one of its data centre clusters. Dozens of AWS services were impacted, including the Verge news site and the MTA's website and app. AWS reported a "recovery" of Lambda and other services on its status health page, with a company spokesperson saying the status page had the latest information.

site_title: Trump pleads not guilty, jets to greet supporters in New Jersey
summary: Former US President Donald Trump pleaded not guilty to 37 federal charges of mishandling state secrets, becoming the first former president to face federal criminal charges. The charges, brought by the Justice Department, allege Trump conspired to stymie officials' efforts to recover top-secret documents and refused to return them after leaving office in 2021. Trump's trial is set to move to the West Palm Beach division of the south Florida federal district court, with US District Judge Aileen Cannon assigned to preside. Trump maintains his innocence and claims the case is politically motivated.
