site_title: US inflation report signals Fed rate pause will become a full stop
summary: US inflation has cooled, with the consumer price index (CPI) rising 4% in May, the smallest advance since March 2021. Core services inflation, excluding housing, receded to its slowest pace in 15 months, giving the Federal Reserve room to consider pausing interest-rate hikes. Fed officials, including Chair Jerome Powell, have signaled a preference for skipping a rate hike, and economists predict the central bank will leave rates unchanged this week. However, the July CPI report will play a key role in determining the Fed's next move, and some economists still expect a rate hike in July.

images.alt_text: Overall inflation in the US is decelerating, thanks to energy and food costs. Food commodity prices have dropped back to levels seen prior to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
China’s yuan falls to a six-month low after the central bank lowers a short-term lending rate for the first time in 10 months.

site_title: Meta guru says ChatGPT-style AI is out-of-date
summary: Meta's chief scientist Yann LeCun says generative AI, like ChatGPT, is at a dead end, promising a new AI that resembles human rationality. Meta's latest AI project, JEPA, aims to move beyond regurgitating existing information and give machines the ability to conceptualize abstract ideas. LeCun believes generative models are overhyped and will be replaced in a few years, citing the need for AI that "more closely reflects how people understand the world." Meta's JEPA project is open-source, aiming to develop AI that perceives the world and makes predictions.

images.alt_text: As a large language model, ChatGPT lacks the concept of "truth".
Amid the focus on Google versus Bing, don't overlook social media’s strong potential in search.
CEO of ChatGPT creator OpenAI Sam Altman, and OpenAI’s member of technical staff Rachel Lim speaking at a panel discussion at Singapore Management University on June 13, 2023.
Open AI chief executive Sam Altman will meet with South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol and about 100 local startups on Friday.
Solar panels at the Nvidia headquarters in Santa Clara, California, US. As the AI frenzy boosts demand for processors that can accelerate computing, the company has made a huge killing this year.

site_title: EY CEO retires after UK audit firm’s split plan fails
summary: EY CEO Carmine Di Sibio will retire in 2024, a year earlier than planned, following the rejection of a plan to split the firm's audit and consulting units. The US branch rejected the split in April, and Di Sibio was set to oversee the break-up until 2025. The decision comes amid a failed attempt to restructure the UK firm, EY.

site_title: China’s property tycoons remain in charge even as empires fall
summary: China's property tycoons, despite facing empires in crisis, remain in charge of their companies. Billionaire Hui Ka Yan could retain 42% of shares in China Evergrande Group, while Zeng Jie might keep 45% of Fantasia Holdings Group's shares under a restructuring plan. This contrasts with US practices, where founders are ousted after missteps. Keeping property magnates in charge aligns with creditors' interests, ensuring the companies' survival and avoiding liquidation. However, the decision may be driven by personal responsibility and a passion for the business, with some founders facing government scrutiny after past failures.

images.alt_text: The star attraction at  11 New Bridge Road is the Song Fa Bak Kut Teh outlet which occupies the ground floor.
Hong Kong’s aspirations to become a thriving innovation and technology hub can be fuelled by learning from Singapore’s success in this field.
China’s real estate sector is still reeling from its worst-ever debt crisis that triggered a wave of defaults last year.
Ronshine said it will actively engage with its creditors and seek a solution to the latest debt.

site_title: Boeing delivers 50 jets in May as 737 MAX rebounds from defect
summary: Boeing delivered 50 jets in May, a 43% increase from the same month last year, with 35 of those being 737 MAX jets. The company has rebounded from a bracket installation defect issue in April, where it delivered only 17 MAXs. Boeing's monthly orders and deliveries are expected to increase to 40 per month in the second half of the year. Despite supply chain challenges, the company booked 69 orders in May, including 59 MAXs and 10 Dreamliners, but reported 11 cancellations.

images.alt_text: The earlier deal covered Boeing’s larger 787 Dreamliners to handle long-range flying for Riyadh Air and the existing flag carrier, Saudia.

site_title: US SEC to weigh new artificial-intelligence rules for brokerages
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) plans to introduce new rules for brokerages using artificial intelligence (AI) to interact with clients, aiming to address conflicts of interest. The proposal, set to be introduced as early as October, would apply to predictive data analytics and machine learning. SEC Chair Gary Gensler has expressed concerns over brokers' recommendations and the potential for inherent conflicts of interest with AI technologies. The move comes as the US government has not yet formulated a comprehensive approach to regulating AI in finance, with top consumer watchdog Rohit Chopra warning of potential fraud and discrimination.

images.alt_text: As Singapore-listed companies age, hungry management teams are needed to drive outperformance.
Upbeat sales targets by Nvidia has bouyed its stock. About 1,300 ESG-registered funds hold more than US$20 billion in Nvidia, according to Bloomberg.

site_title: EY CEO resigns after UK audit firm’s split plan fails
summary: EY CEO Carmine Di Sibio is retiring in 2024, a year earlier than planned, following the rejection of a plan to split the firm's audit and consulting units. The "Project Everest" plan aimed to accelerate growth and avoid conflicts of interest but required partner approval. Di Sibio, 60, will oversee the split until the end of his mandate in 2025. The decision comes after the US branch rejected the plan in April, and Di Sibio announced his retirement in a webcast to partners.

site_title: Germany overtakes China as second-most attractive country for renewables investment
summary: Germany has surpassed China as the second-most attractive country for renewable energy investment, according to a report by EY. The US remains the top spot, driven by the passage of the Inflation Reduction Act. Germany aims to have renewables make up 80% of its energy mix by 2030, up from 46% currently. This move follows Germany's efforts to speed up power market reform and move away from fossil fuels. The country has also closed its last three nuclear power stations.

images.alt_text: The European Union has struggled to reach a deal on renewable energy targets with members split on the issue of nuclear energy.

site_title: US: Stocks rally on cooling inflation figures
summary: US stocks rallied on Tuesday after data showed cooling US inflation, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average finishing 0.4% higher at 34,212.12. Consumer inflation eased for an 11th straight month, reaching its lowest level in around two years, and futures markets indicate traders expect the Federal Reserve to hold steady on interest rates. The S&P 500 advanced 0.7% and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 0.8%, with expectations of a Fed pause potentially priming the market for a broader equity rally.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., May 16, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: China offers ‘Chinese wisdom’ over Palestinian peace talks, to fund projects
summary: China has offered to support Palestinian peace talks and fund projects in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, as Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas visits Beijing for a three-day state visit. Foreign Minister Qin Gang said China will continue to support peace talks and contribute "Chinese wisdom" to help resolve the issue. The two countries have agreed in principle on four projects, including a solar power installation and road infrastructure development, which China will fund. China's support for the Palestinian cause is seen as a significant development in the region, following Abbas's failed meeting with American officials at the UN General Assembly last month.

site_title: Big countries should build capabilities that help workers rather than hold competitors down: Tharman
summary: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized that countries should prioritize building their own capabilities to benefit ordinary workers, rather than competing with others through protectionist means. He argued that absolute economic performance is crucial for workers' opportunities, jobs, and social mobility. Tharman suggested that governments should focus on progressive social policies, such as targeted spending and insurance, to support the poor and ensure economic competitiveness. He also emphasized the need for a balanced approach, investing 90% of efforts in people's capabilities and 10% in preventing others from abusing their position.

images.alt_text: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam and Jurong GRC MPs (from left) Shawn Huang, Rahayu Mahzam and Xie Yao Quan at the opening of ActiveSG Sport Village @ Jurong Town on Sunday; Tharman says: "Having a contest is important for me. I much rather win or lose with the contest. My whole approach is not to shy away from competition, it has always been that way. It’s how I prove myself."
Going by election results, Tharman is one of the most popular politicians around.

Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam will resign from the People's Action Party and step down from his Cabinet positions on Jul 7 to fulfil his official commitments in Singapore and internationally.

site_title: EU proposes regulating ESG ratings providers
summary: The European Union has proposed regulating ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) ratings providers to improve industry standards. Critics argue that current methodologies are complex, opaque, and favor companies with more information, rather than those effectively managing ESG risks. EU Commissioner Mairead McGuinness aims to make ratings "reliable and comparable." The move is part of a broader package to encourage ethical investment.

images.alt_text: Henry Fernandez, chief executive officer of index provider MSCI, said that climate risk is going to lead to the biggest repricing of assets and reallocation of capital in the history of the world.

site_title: Sembcorp wastes little time on goal to unlock more value
summary: Sembcorp Industries is exploring the potential divestment of its waste management business and energy-from-waste plant, with preliminary discussions with selected parties underway. The move follows a Reuters report suggesting US private equity group KKR & Co and Australia's Macquarie Asset Management are potential bidders for SembWaste. The disposal is expected to fetch around S$486 million to S$520 million, with Sembcorp aiming to expand its focus on clean energy. This is part of the company's asset-light strategy to monetize assets, deleverage balance sheets, and improve its return on equity proposition.

images.alt_text: CGS-CIMB analysts say Sembcorp Industries may be included in the MSCI Singapore Index by September or November 2023.
Reuters had reported in May that HSBC was hired to run the sale of the unit.
Maybank estimates Sembcorp's new contract in the Middle East to be S$400 million.

site_title: Tens of thousands evacuated as cyclone menaces India and Pakistan
summary: Tens of thousands of people have been evacuated across India and Pakistan as a cyclone, named Biparjoy, approaches their coast. Over 40,000 people have been evacuated, with 20,000 in Pakistan's Sindh province and 20,000 in India's Gujarat state. The cyclone is forecast to make landfall as a "very severe cyclonic storm" with winds of up to 150 km/h, and authorities have warned of heavy winds, rains, and potential damage. The storm is expected to hit near the Indian port of Jakhau on Thursday evening, affecting up to 1.6 million people.

images.alt_text: After three years of the La Nina climate pattern, which often lowers global temperatures slightly, the hotter El Nino is back in action, according to an advisory issued on Thursday (Jun 8) by the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s Climate Prediction Center.

site_title: Oil prices settle more than 3% higher after China rate cut
summary: Oil prices surged over 3% on Tuesday after China's central bank cut a short-term lending rate for the first time in 10 months, boosting crude prices. Brent crude futures rose $2.45, or 3.4%, to $74.29 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude gained $2.30, or 3.4%, to $69.42 a barrel. The rate cut aims to add momentum to China's post-pandemic recovery, the world's second-largest economy and biggest crude importer.

images.alt_text: Global oil demand this year will rise by 2.35 million barrels per day (bpd), or 2.4 per cent, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) says in its monthly report.
Brent crude futures fell US$2.95, or 3.9 per cent, to settle at US$71.84 a barrel, their lowest since Dec 2021.

site_title: Social media’s potential as the king of search
summary: Google's dominance in search is being threatened by new developments, including Microsoft's beta version of Bing powered by AI technology similar to OpenAI's ChatGPT, and Google's own plans around Bard, an AI-powered platform. This shift could lead to a new era in search, with social media potentially playing a significant role. As search engines continue to evolve, users may see a broader range of options and a more personalized experience.

images.alt_text: Google is racing to catch up with rival Microsoft, which has rushed to integrate ChatGPT-like powers in a wide array of its products, including the Bing search engine.
The updates to Bing are part of Microsoft’s effort to capture more of the estimated US$286 billion market for search advertising globally.

site_title: Addressing Asia’s digital conundrum is key to fulfilling net-zero ambitions
summary: Asia-Pacific's rapid digitalization poses a climate conundrum, as the region's growth is fueled by low-cost energy demands. Despite being the world's largest emitter of greenhouse gases, Asia stands to gain from climate action, with a potential $10.1 trillion revenue opportunity by 2030. However, the region's decarbonization rate is below the global average, and businesses face challenges in measuring and addressing their environmental impact. To achieve net-zero carbon emissions, Asia must prioritize digitalization, data-driven decision-making, and a concerted effort from governments and businesses to drive a just transition to a greener region.

images.alt_text: An installation of solar photovoltaic panels on Jurong Island under JTC's Solarland programme.
Carbon capture facilities, such as this one in China, are gaining in popularity and interest; but what are some of the pitfalls investors in such projects should be aware of? PHOTO: REUTERS

It will be challenging for companies to report comprehensive and high-quality data in alignment with the coming sustainability reporting standards if organisations do not invest in and implement the right monitoring and reporting systems, along with new models and methods for data sharing.

site_title: India’s inflation to cool gradually, central bank chief says
summary: India's inflation is expected to cool gradually, according to Reserve Bank of India (RBI) governor Shaktikanta Das. The central bank's monetary policy actions over the past year are still unfolding and are unlikely to meet its 4% inflation target in the short term, with the forecast of 5.1% for the current financial year being above its aim. The RBI will likely keep its benchmark repo rate unchanged for a second straight meeting to align inflation near the mid-point of its 2-6% range on a durable basis.

site_title: Flows into Japanese equities highest in 20 years; analysts say market still has room to run
summary: Investor interest in Japanese equities is at its highest in 20 years, driven by improving economic fundamentals and a rotation out of China into other Asian economies. Foreigners poured in a net $31.8 billion into Japanese equities in the year to June 2, with the Nikkei 225 reaching a 33-year high. Analysts expect Japanese equities to be re-rated upwards, citing a high single-digit earnings increase, rising dividends, and shareholder buybacks. Bank of Singapore and Morningstar's director of Asia equity research, Lorraine Tan, are bullish on the market, citing a combination of resilient economic fundamentals and positive corporate governance reforms.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Shibuya Crossing Japan streets
While the Spo

site_title: US consumer prices slow in May; core inflation sticky
summary: US consumer prices slowed in May, rising 0.1% as petrol prices fell, marking the smallest annual increase in inflation in over two years. Despite this, core inflation remained strong, increasing 0.4% for the third consecutive month, driven by high rents and used cars. The Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates unchanged, but may adopt a hawkish stance, as underlying price pressures remain above its 2% target.

images.alt_text: Travelers arrive at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago, Illinois, on November 22, 2022, ahead of the upcoming Thanksgiving holiday. - The Chicago Department of Aviation anticipates nearly 1.7 million passengers will travel through Chicago’s two airports for the Thanksgiving holiday travel period between Tuesday, November 22 and Monday November 28. (Photo by KAMIL KRZACZYNSKI / AFP)

site_title: India set for US$168 billion finance behemoth as HDFC merger nears
summary: India is set to create a US$168 billion finance behemoth with the merger of HDFC Bank and Housing Development Finance Corp (HDFC), expected to be completed by early July. The merger, which began in April 2022, will create the world's fifth-most valuable bank and impact over tens of millions of customers and shareholders. A cut-off date will be announced to determine HDFC shareholders eligible to receive HDFC Bank shares, and the merged entity is likely to trade under the HDFC Bank ticker before July 20.

site_title: EC World Reit receives waiver for deadline to divest Chinese logistics assets
summary: EC World Reit has received a waiver from the Monetary Authority of Singapore to complete its proposed divestment of two Chinese logistics assets by October 31, rather than the original deadline of June 16. The waiver is conditional on obtaining unitholders' approval for the extended timeline and conducting two independent valuations of the properties. The divestment, valued at 2.03 billion yuan (S$392.7 million), was originally approved by unitholders in December 2022, but its completion has been delayed due to purchasers' financing issues.

images.alt_text: Stage 1 Properties of Bei Gang Logistics, one of seven properties in EC World Reit’s portfolio. EC World Reit's net property income fell 12.3 per cent on the year to S$26.1 million in the first quarter, from S$29.7 million.

site_title: Toyota to face governance challenge at shareholder meeting
summary: Toyota faces a governance challenge at its shareholder meeting, with the two largest US public pension funds voting against Chairman Akio Toyoda due to concerns over board independence and climate lobbying. Toyota's board has been flagged as not independent by two prominent US proxy advisers, citing ties to groups such as the International Paralympic Committee and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group. Despite strong financial performance, Toyota's governance framework is being scrutinized, with some investors seeking greater disclosures on the company's climate lobbying and more independent oversight.

images.alt_text: In April, the automaker sold 8,584 EVs worldwide, including under its Lexus brand, accounting for more than 1 per cent of its global sales in a single month for the first time.
Toyota plans to roll out at least two new types of batteries within the next few years.

site_title: Americans pulling back from revenge spending, which could slow inflation
summary: Americans are pulling back from "revenge spending" after two years of heavy recreational spending following pandemic lockdowns. This could lead to a slowdown in inflation, as hotel prices and airfares are now cooling. Economists expect a decrease in services inflation, which the Federal Reserve has been monitoring. However, some analysts, like Goldman Sachs, predict hotel prices and recreation-related costs may increase in May, but then decrease in June and July, potentially offsetting the inflationary impact. This shift could contribute to a slowdown in overall inflation.

images.alt_text: “We’re probably in either a mild recession or moderate economy, we can see that. I think actually, in the US, we’re in a business recession, and the consumer is just fine, the consumer is strong.” United Airlines CEO Scott Kirby says.

site_title: Citi staff take up 1,300 volunteering spots
summary: Citi Singapore has partnered with Touch Community Services for a six-month initiative called Project V, aiming to benefit approximately 3,600 people in need. Over 1,300 volunteering spots will be taken up by Citi staff, engaging in activities such as delivering meals, mentoring children, and assisting individuals with special needs. The partnership is part of a national-level corporate volunteerism pilot, led by the Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth, and aims to establish sustainable volunteer partnerships between the private, public, and people sectors.

images.alt_text:
hytouch13 - Citi staff celebrate Citi Family Day with the unveiling of Citi's partnership with Touch Community Services, in which Citi staff with take on more than 1,300 volunteering opportunities over 6-months.



Credit : CITI

site_title: China is biggest loser of millionaires globally, report says
summary: China is expected to lose 13,500 high-net-worth individuals with investable wealth of over $1 million, the largest net outflow globally this year, according to Henley & Partners. This follows a slowdown in wealth growth in China, driven by President Xi Jinping's "common prosperity" drive and prolonged COVID restrictions. In contrast, Australia is expected to attract 5,200 millionaires this year, surpassing the UAE to become the top country for HNWI inflows. The UK's exodus of HNWIs is also expected to double, making it the third-biggest loser globally.

images.alt_text: The PBOC has cut its seven-day reverse repo rate by 10 bps to 1.90 per cent from 2.00 per cent.
Household loans including mortgages are up 367.2 billion yuan in May, versus a contraction of 241.1 billion yuan in April.

site_title: Accenture looks to power AI efforts with US$3 billion investment
summary: Accenture plans to invest $3 billion over three years in its data and AI practice, aiming to double the number of employees working on AI to 80,000. The investment will help companies across 19 industries, as the technology is expected to change the way many jobs are done. This move follows Accenture's layoffs in March and comes after other companies like Salesforce also investing in generative AI. Accenture's investment will also be used to launch a tool called the "AI Navigator for Enterprise" to guide businesses on using AI technology.

site_title: If horse-racing here has run its course, so be it
summary: The Singapore Turf Club is set to close in 2027, marking the end of horse-racing in the city-state. Despite its decline in popularity, the institution's closure is not mourned, as the 120-hectare land can be repurposed for housing, with potential for tens of thousands of new homes. While the closure will have an impact on the racing community, the redevelopment offers a broader benefit to the population. The closure may also accelerate the fates of the 700 racehorses, reducing the demand for breeding and potentially leading to fewer horses being bred for a racing career.

images.alt_text: With the handover due in 2027, the Turf Club will host its last race meeting on Oct 5, 2024, and close its facility by March 2027. Its last event will be the 100th Grand Singapore Gold Cup.
Horse racing: Yusoff Fadzli steering the Donna Logan-trained King Arthur (No. 2) to their last win together in a Kranji Stakes A (1,200m) race on Oct 10, 2022.
The Singapore Turf Club's current site in Kranji will be returned to the government by March 2027 to make way for housing and other developments in the area.

site_title: Japan's Kishida unveils new child care plan amid election rumours
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida unveiled a child care plan to reverse the country's dwindling birthrate, aiming to double child care spending by the early 2030s. The plan includes bigger payouts to families with children and providing homes for hundreds of thousands of households. The measures are seen as a bid to boost his party's support ahead of a potential snap election, which could be triggered by opposition lawmakers' threats to submit a no-confidence motion. Kishida hopes the plan will address the aging population's impact on the country's economy and society.

images.alt_text: Japan is among the world’s fastest ageing societies, with the annual number of newborns falling below 800,000 for the first time, having previously peaked at 2.09 million in 1973 during the second baby boom.

site_title: BBVA, Bank of Cyprus launch first AT1 euro bonds since Credit Suisse rescue
summary: BBVA and Bank of Cyprus issued the first euro-denominated Additional Tier 1 (AT1) bonds since Credit Suisse's rescue in March. BBVA aims to raise 750-1 billion euros, while Bank of Cyprus sold a 220 million euro AT1 bond attracting over 2.2 billion euros in orders. The move aims to restore confidence in AT1 bonds, which were frozen following US banking failures and the rescue.

images.alt_text: A sign on the exterior of the UBS Group AG headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland, on Tuesday, April 19, 2022. UBS increased pay for junior bankers in the U.S. for a second time in less than a year, bringing the Swiss lender in line with Wall Street rivals trying to stem defections amid a race for talent. Photographer: Pascal Mora/Bloomberg

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq hit fresh 1-yr highs after May inflation data
summary: The US stock market reached fresh one-year highs on June 13, driven by modest May inflation data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 44.75 points, or 0.13%, to 34,111.08, while the S&P 500 climbed 13.68 points, or 0.32%, to 4,352.61. The Nasdaq Composite opened higher by 104.60 points, or 0.78%, to 13,566.53. The data boosted hopes that the Federal Reserve may skip raising interest rates at its policy meeting on Wednesday.

site_title: China EV-maker BYD opens Boat Quay restaurant as part of hybrid showroom
summary: Chinese EV-maker BYD has opened a restaurant in Singapore's historic Boat Quay as part of a hybrid showroom, blending food and automotive experiences. The BYD by 1826 restaurant features dishes inspired by BYD models and technology, with an "experience centre" offering information on the company's technology and models. The restaurant aims to demonstrate the shift from internal combustion engine cars to electric vehicles as a change in lifestyle. This unconventional approach could shape BYD's strategy in the region. BYD recently dethroned Tesla as the top seller of passenger EVs in Singapore, with plans to launch its smallest and potentially cheapest EV later this year.

images.alt_text: Toyota plans to roll out at least two new types of batteries within the next few years.
Kim Hock Corporation has trialled wheel loaders for a month and received good responses from its operators.

site_title: US dollar sags before inflation data, yuan weakens on rate cut
summary: The US dollar fell slightly as investors awaited US inflation data, while the euro rose 0.37% to its highest since May 23. China's yuan fell to a six-month low after the central bank lowered a short-term lending rate for the first time in 10 months. The US dollar index declined 0.26% to 103.32, with traders expecting a possible pause in interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. The yuan's weakening reflects concerns about China's post-pandemic recovery.

site_title: Opec oil demand forecast holds steady as economic clouds gather
summary: OPEC forecasts global oil demand to rise by 2.35 million barrels per day (bpd) or 2.4% in 2023, unchanged from the previous month. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) warns that the world economy faces rising uncertainty and slower growth in the second half of the year due to high inflation, elevated interest rates, and tight labor markets.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures fell US$2.95, or 3.9 per cent, to settle at US$71.84 a barrel, their lowest since Dec 2021.
A view shows oil pump jacks outside Almetyevsk in the Republic of Tatarstan, Russia June 4, 2023. REUTERS/Alexander Manzyuk
Oil prices had risen early in the week, buoyed by Saudi Arabia’s pledge over the weekend to cut more output on top of the cuts agreed earlier with the Opec and its allies.

site_title: Society will need to ‘co-evolve’ with artificial intelligence, says OpenAI’s Sam Altman
summary: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman emphasized the need for society to "co-evolve" with artificial intelligence to mitigate its potential harm. The company has released ChatGPT to the public to improve it, despite initial controversy over its tendency to "hallucinate" with false answers. Altman expects progress on hallucinations and expects AI costs to decrease, making it more accessible. He urged regulators to understand AI's limits before setting policies, warning that "heavy regulation" could block progress.

images.alt_text: Open AI chief executive Sam Altman will meet with South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol and about 100 local startups on Friday.
“I don’t want to be sued by ... public market, Wall Street etc, so no, not that interested,” OpenAI CEO Sam Altman says.
In remarks at Israel’s Tel Aviv University, OpenAI founder Sam Altman on Monday stressed that his call for oversight was not aimed at “the systems of today”.

site_title: Malaysia to seek Interpol help to investigate controversial comedian
summary: Malaysia will seek Interpol's assistance to investigate Jocelyn Chia, a New York-based comedian who made insensitive jokes about Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 and sparked outrage in Malaysia and Singapore. Chia was widely criticized by Malaysia's home minister, with the national police chief announcing plans to investigate her comments under Malaysian laws. The move comes amid concerns of a crackdown on free speech in Malaysia, following the shutdown of a comedy club last year.

images.alt_text: Jennifer Aniston and Adam Sandler play a married couple in the 2019 Netflix film 'Murder Mystery' and its sequel, which begins streaming on Friday.

site_title: Koh Brothers Eco unit and partner bag S$186m HDB contract
summary: Koh Brothers Eco Engineering, a subsidiary of Koh Brothers Eco, secured a S$186 million contract from the Housing & Development Board to construct the Kallang Integrated Development, including public housing, a childcare centre, and road expansion works. The contract, worth 10% of the joint venture partner LBD Engineering, boosts Koh Brothers' order book to S$703.2 million. CEO Paul Shin attributed the healthy order book to the joint venture project and ongoing maintenance works at Tuas Water Reclamation Plant, set to be completed in 2025.

site_title: GM, SDI will build US$3 billion battery manufacturing plant in Indiana
summary: General Motors (GM) and Samsung SDI are building a US$3 billion battery manufacturing plant in Indiana, expected to start operations in 2026 and create 1,700 jobs. The plant will have an annual production capacity of 30 gigawatt hours and produce high-nickel prismatic and cylindrical battery cells. This investment is part of GM's plan to increase its electric vehicle production capacity in North America, with the goal of producing 1 million units annually by 2025.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Entrepreneur George Goh, a potential presidential candidate, claims to be "confident" he will meet the S$500 million shareholder equity criterion despite not strictly meeting the requirement. Meanwhile, the Singapore Exchange's securities turnover value rose 23% to S$23 billion in May, and three housing units at Eleven @ Holland were sold via a tender exercise. In other news, Cineleisure will set up cinema businesses Golden Village and The Projector, while mm2 Asia will exit the market. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) slipped 0.2% on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore biotech company INEX to acquire Taiwan genomics firm for S$5.4 million
summary: Singapore biotech company INEX has agreed to acquire Taiwan genomics firm Yourgene Health (Taiwan) for up to S$5.4 million. The acquisition is expected to boost INEX's capabilities in fetal health, oncology research, and bioinformatics, and contribute S$4.7-5.4 million in additional revenues in 2023. INEX plans to use the acquired laboratory to run and distribute its proprietary diagnostic technologies in cancer research. The deal is subject to Taiwan's investment commission approval and is expected to complete within 8-12 weeks.

images.alt_text: As the anchor tenant of Imperio Mall, Quantum Healthcare plans to establish a centralised outpatient centre, Quantum Specialist Centre.

site_title: Singapore stocks slip on Tuesday despite rally across Asia; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% to close at 3,189.40, despite a rally in regional markets. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC declined, while Sembcorp Industries rose 3.1%. IG market analyst Yeap Jun Rong attributed the decline to institutional investors' net outflows for the fourth straight month. The STI's value-focused composition may also be a reason for its trailing performance, as growth sectors attract investors' attention.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.6 per cent higher at 34,066.33 on Monday.

site_title: Singapore dollar seen to depreciate against yen
summary: The Singapore dollar is expected to depreciate against the Japanese yen, potentially reaching below 100 yen in the next 12 months, according to market experts. The prevailing spot rate is 103.5 yen, with some analysts predicting a brief appreciation before a gradual decline. This could make Japanese stocks more attractive to Singapore investors, but the exact timing and extent of the depreciation are uncertain.

images.alt_text: Bank of Singapore is bullish on Japan's domestic consumer discretionary segments.

site_title: Finding hungry management teams in the age of AI may be key to picking a winning stock portfolio
summary: A key to finding winning stocks in the age of AI may lie in identifying management teams with a "Day 1" mentality, characterized by curiosity, nimbleness, and a willingness to experiment and take calculated risks. As corporate Singapore ages, companies can avoid pitfalls of growing complexity and complacency by embracing a "Day 1" mentality. Investors can look for management teams that demonstrate hunger for success and a drive to innovate, as these traits can provide a competitive edge in a rapidly changing business landscape.

images.alt_text: In March, more than 1,100 industry leaders advocated for a six-month pause on training powerful AI models.

site_title: Europe’s ‘election of the year’ grinds into gear
summary: Spain is gearing up for a snap national election in late July, amid a complex situation with the EU presidency starting on July 1. The election comes after poor local election results in May, and the government of Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez, from the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party, is "on the ropes." The Socialist Party is hoping for a similar result to the 2019 election, but polls indicate a strong chance of a change in power with the right-of-centre People's Party, led by Alberto Nunez Feijoo. The election's outcome could have significant implications for Europe, particularly with the Ukraine war and EU policy issues at stake.

images.alt_text: Spain’s Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez gestures as he speaks during a joint press conference with his Swedish counterpart at La Moncloa palace in Madrid on June 5, 2023. (Photo by PIERRE-PHILIPPE MARCOU / AFP)

The scale of Sunday’s defeat, in which the conservative mainstream People’s Party (PP) took as many as eight regional governments from the Socialists, meant Sanchez felt compelled to “take personal responsibility for the results.”
Even if Macron (left) and Scholz don’t patch up their relationship, it is possible that future incumbents will see a compelling need to do so.

site_title: ‘Final Beatles record’ out this year aided by AI: McCartney
summary: Paul McCartney revealed that a "final Beatles record" will be released later this year, created with the help of artificial intelligence (AI). The song, likely a 1978 John Lennon composition called "Now And Then," was a demo that Lennon had recorded for McCartney before his death in 1980. McCartney worked with Peter Jackson and AI to separate Lennon's voice and a piano, allowing for a new version of the song to be completed. The project marks a new chapter in McCartney's use of AI in music, which he described as both "kind of scary" and "exciting."

site_title: Bunge, Viterra will merge to form US$34 billion agri-trading powerhouse
summary: US-based agri-trading companies Bunge and Viterra are merging to form a US$34 billion agricultural trading powerhouse. The deal values Bunge and Viterra at US$17 billion each, with Bunge shareholders owning approximately 70% of the combined company due to a significant cash payment. Viterra shareholders will receive about 65.6 million shares of Bunge stock and US$2 billion in cash. The deal brings the combined company closer in size to leading rivals Archer-Daniels-Midland and Cargill, drawing close regulatory scrutiny.

images.alt_text: Glencore's Viterra buys Gavilon grains unit to expand in US

site_title: Venezuela's 'daily bread', humble arepa conquers the world
summary: Venezuela's arepa, a humble cornmeal flatbread, is gaining popularity worldwide as Venezuelans emigrate due to the country's economic crisis. The arepa can be filled with various ingredients and is often eaten as a daily staple. It has become a gluten-free option in trendy eateries in New York, Paris, and Tokyo, with many Venezuelans starting their own businesses to share their culture and cuisine. The arepa is seen as a food that has no social class, and its popularity is spreading globally, representing a connection to Venezuela's heritage.

images.alt_text: Fhef ArChan Chan, the 37-year-old chef of Ho Lee Fook located in the glitzy Central district, is one of the city's most celebrated women chefs and among a handful of young innovators redefining Cantonese food.

site_title: Singapore Airlines’ stock tops global peers on record profits
summary: Singapore Airlines' shares have reached their highest level in five years, with a 32% rally in the past three months, following the carrier's record profit as travel resumed after COVID. The airline's highest-ever annual net income is driven by pent-up demand, with analysts predicting further positives due to seasonally higher summer travel and rising demand from China. SIA's outperformance may be attributed to its premium branding and proactive investment in flight capacity and staffing.

site_title: Meet Ben Paul and find out how to invest smarter at Mark to Market ‘Live’
summary: Ben Paul's Mark to Market "Live" returns on July 15 at The Capitol Kempinski Hotel, featuring a new format as a personal wealth forum. This event is the first to be held in front of a live audience. Ben Paul, award-winning senior correspondent, will discuss investment strategies and answer questions from attendees. The forum is an extension of Paul's popular weekly column and monthly podcast.

images.alt_text: Quarz offered a laundry list of improvements the new internal manager could pursue to boost Sabana Reit's performance.

site_title: Hong Kong to recruit 27,000 foreign workers amid shortage
summary: Hong Kong will recruit 27,000 foreign workers to address a severe manpower shortage in services and industries, following a surge in business after pandemic curbs were lifted. The government aims to attract workers in sectors such as construction and aviation, citing the labor force as crucial to the city's economic development. The move is seen as a response to the labor shortage, which has been exacerbated by the post-pandemic rebound in business.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s aspirations to become a thriving innovation and technology hub can be fuelled by learning from Singapore’s success in this field.

site_title: S$10,000 may be a new normal for motorcycle COEs
summary: The demand for cheaper, small-capacity motorcycles remains high due to food delivery services allowing riders to fund their purchases. The new bidding rules for motorcycle Certificates of Entitlement (COEs) have led to prices sticking closer to S$10,000, rather than the expected drop to S$5,000. This is partly due to the importance of motorcycles as a means of income generation. Prices plummeted 59% to S$5,002 in the first round of COE bidding in May, but are expected to stabilize around S$10,000.

images.alt_text: June’s first round of COE bidding marks the second COE round since the LTA brought forward the deregistrations of about 6,000 non-extendable five-year COEs from Category A and B.

site_title: Trump, Johnson and a trial for the rule of law
summary: US President Donald Trump and former UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson have championed a similar style of politics, characterized by a cult of personality, nostalgia nationalism, and a disregard for the rule of law. Both have claimed to be victims of a deep-state conspiracy, despite being held to account for their actions. This style of politics is concerning, as it threatens the integrity of democracies worldwide. The US and UK must demonstrate that their systems can hold leaders accountable, and that the rule of law is a reality, not a myth. The outcomes of Trump's and Johnson's current trials will send a vital message to the world.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump said on social media that he had been summoned to appear at the federal courthouse in Miami on Tuesday.

The surprise announcement by Trump’s lawyers John Rowley and Jim Trusty could prompt further legal complications ahead of Trump’s scheduled appearance in federal court in Miami on Tuesday in the documents case.

Political analysts suggested that Johnson might be quitting in his constituency to run for a safer Conservative seat, such as one vacated by Nadine Dorries, a loyalist of Johnson who announced Friday that she would not stand for reelection.

site_title: OK Lim told CAD officer: ‘We did not plan to cheat banks for financing’
summary: OK Lim, founder of Hin Leong Trading, testified in Singapore's State Court that he did not plan to cheat banks for financing, stating it's common for oil companies to submit verbal sales contracts to banks for financing to get faster cash flow. He claimed he asked employees to draft contracts after verbal discussions with Unipec and CAO, but prosecutors allege the transactions are "complete fabrications" and that Lim instructed employees to submit forged documents to HSBC, resulting in $112 million in bank funds. Lim's testimony continues in the ongoing trial.

images.alt_text: Lim Oon Kuin, better known as OK Lim, of the failed Hin Leong group faces cheating and forgery charges. The hearing continues at the State Court
Serene Seng, a former long-serving employee of Hin Leong, is Singapore prosecutors' third witness in the trial on cheating and forgery charges against OK Lim at the State Court
Lim Oon Kuin, better known as OK Lim, of the failed Hin Leong group faces cheating and forgery charges
Singapore's fallen oil legend Lim Oon Kuin or OK Lim, as he is better known, arrives in the State Courts on Apr 11.
OK Lim, founder of collapsed Hin Leong empire, appears in State Courts for the trial on cheating and forgery charges against him

site_title: UK loses nearly four million days to worst strikes since 1990
summary: The UK has lost nearly 4 million working days to strikes since the start of last year, the most since 1989-90, with industrial action showing no signs of abating. The Office for National Statistics reported 257,000 days lost in April, mainly due to junior doctors, nurses, and civil servants protesting against below-inflation pay offers. The total days lost since January last year have risen close to 3.9 million, with ongoing disputes over pay and the cost-of-living crisis exacerbating the situation.

images.alt_text: Striking teachers march during joint strike action by train drivers, teachers, university staff and civil servants, in Leeds, UK, on Wednesday, Feb. 1, 2023. The day of coordinated industrial action is expected to be Britain’s most severe day of strikes for over a decade, piling pressure on Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s Conservative administration to resolve disputes with public sector workers by making more generous offers on pay. Photographer: Dominic Lipinski/Bloomberg

site_title: Hong Kong restarts scheme for private firms to build subsidised housing
summary: Hong Kong has announced plans to allocate three parcels of land by the end of 2024 for private developers to build subsidized housing, aiming to accelerate the supply of affordable homes. The "Home Ownership Scheme" will provide 2,300 flats at 65% of market rate, with discounted reserve prices for the first two sites. Private developers can also participate by using their own land, but may face limited incentives, with no government buyback of unsold flats and no encouragement to sell unmodified flats. The move aims to address the city's widening wealth gap and affordable housing crisis.

images.alt_text: Transaction volume is also expected to continue to soften and fall to a four-month low in May after the spike in the beginning of 2023.

site_title: China’s May new loans miss expectations, more stimulus likely
summary: China's new bank loans rose to 1.36 trillion yuan in May, missing analyst estimates, but the central bank kept policy accommodative to support the economy. Household loans, including mortgages, increased 367.2 billion yuan, while corporate loans rose to 855.8 billion yuan. The recovery is losing momentum, with demand faltering and deflation risks rising, leading to expectations of more stimulus measures to spur growth. The People's Bank of China may cut the benchmark lending rate or loan prime rate in the near term to support the economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Chinese 100 yuan banknotes are seen on a counter of a branch of a commercial bank in Beijing, China, March 30, 2016. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon
The PBOC has cut its seven-day reverse repo rate by 10 bps to 1.90 per cent from 2.00 per cent.

site_title: Buffett’s Japan trading firm picks hit records on targets
summary: Warren Buffett's investment in Japanese trading companies has led to record highs. Shares of Mitsui & Co, Mitsubishi, Itochu, and Sumitomo rose as much as 2.8%, 2.9%, 2.2%, and 1.2%, respectively, after Jefferies Financial Group raised their price targets by over 40%. The companies have gained due to Buffett's increased exposure to stocks in Japan, as well as improved shareholder returns and ESG scores. Mitsubishi has seen a 51% gain this year, beating the Topix index's 20% advance.

site_title: Gold jewellery recycling in India seen matching record this year
summary: India is expected to sell a record amount of used gold jewellery this year, with recycled bullion sales projected to jump over 20% and match 2019's high of 119.5 tons. The surge in domestic gold prices, driven by a weakening rupee, is likely to lead to lower gold imports, potentially putting downward pressure on international prices near $1,960 an ounce. This trend is driven by India's large gold holdings and the practice of buying gold after a good harvest to sell later for other essentials.

site_title: Petition found in box that stopped Abe murder hearing: Japanese media
summary: A suspicious package containing a petition for leniency in the trial of Tetsuya Yamagami, accused of murdering former Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, was delivered to a court in Nara, Japan, prompting its cancellation. The package, which triggered a security alert, contained a printout of a Change.org petition signed by 13,000 people. No explosives or hazardous substances were found, and police have declined to confirm reports about the sender. Yamagami faces charges of murder and could face the death penalty if convicted.

images.alt_text: Japan’s consumer price index rose 4.3 per cent in January from a year earlier, the fastest gain in 41 years.
Bank of Singapore is bullish on Japan's domestic consumer discretionary segments.
It makes no sense to have one safety culture for workers being transported between their lodgings and workplaces and another for everyone else.
Almost two million visitors arrived from overseas in April, compared with less than 140,000 a year earlier.

site_title: A restaurant in Wales is crowned best in the UK again
summary: Ynyshir in Wales has been named the best dining spot in the UK for the second year in a row, according to the Estrella Damm National Restaurant Awards. The restaurant, led by Chef Gareth Ward, offers an internationally influenced menu with dishes such as lobster tail and claw, and costs £375-£520 per person. The awards, which rank 100 UK restaurants based on votes from industry experts, also saw London restaurants dominate the top 50 spots, with 33 out of 50 restaurants in the city making the list.

images.alt_text: The arepa can be whatever you want: filled with anything from cheese and meat to beans or seafood, even greens.

site_title: AI hype starting to ‘smell like dotcom era’, says ESG veteran
summary: A recent surge in artificial intelligence (AI) stocks has raised concerns about a potential bubble, with veteran ESG investor James Penny comparing the market to the dotcom era. Nvidia's upbeat sales targets have led to a 160% gain in its market value, with the Nasdaq adding a third of its value. Penny advises investors to be selective and focus on AI adopters rather than manufacturers, citing a "pick-and-shovel" strategy. He also warns of the risk of a recession, cautioning against overexposure to sectors reliant on low interest rates and a strong economy.

images.alt_text: Solar panels at the Nvidia headquarters in Santa Clara, California, US. As the AI frenzy boosts demand for processors that can accelerate computing, the company has made a huge killing this year.

site_title: UK labour market tightens unexpectedly with surge in wages
summary: Britain's labour market tightened unexpectedly in April, with unemployment dropping to 3.8% and average earnings rising to the highest ever outside the pandemic. The tight labour market, combined with a shortage of workers who dropped out during the pandemic, is fueling a wage-price spiral that is a concern to the Bank of England, potentially exacerbating inflationary pressures.

images.alt_text: The median pay settlement awarded by major British employers increased to 5.6 per cent in the three months to April, the highest in records dating back to 2005 and up from 5.0 per cent in the three months to the end of March, according to Incomes Data Research.

site_title: Japan attracts fresh interest – for good reason
summary: Japan's equity market is attracting fresh interest due to a combination of macro factors and corporate reforms. The Nikkei 225 Index reached 32,000 for the first time in 33 years this month, with global investor flows turning positive and exceeding $30 billion in 2023. BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda aims to maintain ultra-loose monetary policy, but the central bank is expected to adjust its policy eventually. This follows the "Abenomics" economic policy, which included monetary easing, fiscal stimulus, and structural reforms, designed to propel Japan's economy from stagnation.

images.alt_text: Bank of Singapore is bullish on Japan's domestic consumer discretionary segments.

site_title: When to buy stocks in a market crash
summary: Investors often debate whether to buy stocks during a market crash. Legendary investor Warren Buffett suggests keeping a "too hard" tray to remind himself that not all stock ideas are worth his time. A calm mind and simple plan are key to successful investing, regardless of market volatility. Fear can be a significant obstacle, but understanding what keeps you calm can help you make rational decisions. Keeping rules simple, having a level head, and avoiding unrealistic expectations can also help investors execute their plans effectively. Ultimately, it's essential to focus on what works for each individual investor.

images.alt_text: The Big Tech rally of this year is expected to have further to run.
The Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index of New York-listed mainland companies, consisting mainly of Internet giants such as Alibaba Group, lost 5.6 per cent this month.

site_title: Hong Kong to unveil plan to recruit foreign labour amid shortage
summary: Hong Kong is set to unveil a plan to recruit foreign labor amid a severe manpower shortage in services and industries. The city's economy has grown rapidly since pandemic curbs were lifted, but a shrinking local workforce and labor importation policies have contributed to the shortage. The government aims to bring in at least 10,000 construction workers and 8,000 laborers in transportation and logistics. The move is expected to ease entry rules for foreign workers and help mitigate risks to the city's economy and competitiveness. The plan's details are to be announced soon.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s inflation expectations were unchanged in the survey, at 2.4 per cent and 2.3 per cent for this year and next, respectively.

site_title: Golden Village and The Projector to set up shop in Cineleisure; mm2 Asia to exit
summary: Cineleisure will see a shift in its cinema tenants, with Golden Village and The Projector setting up shop by the end of 2023, while Cathay Cineplexes will cease operations on June 30. This move aims to rejuvenate the mall experience with a new tenant mix. Other new tenants include karaoke chain HaveFun Karaoke, Japanese restaurant Shujin Master Sushi Bar, and Taiwan Night Markets. mm2 Asia's departure marks the second cinema exit in the area in a year, with shares trading flat.

images.alt_text: Cathay Cineplexes will cease operation at the iconic The Cathay after 26 June

site_title: Asia-Pacific VC and PE growth overtakes North America: Preqin
summary: Asia-Pacific venture capital and private equity funds have overtaken North America and Europe in growth rate, with combined assets under management growing 2.5 times since 2018. Despite a cautious approach towards China, the region is expected to see improved long-term investment returns and increased investor interest, with 46% of VC investors targeting Asia-Pacific in the first quarter of 2023. South-east Asia, in particular, has seen significant growth, with over 80% of total private capital assets under management, driven by a growing middle-income population and substantial economic growth potential.

images.alt_text: Across their portfolios, limited partners (LPs) are recording record levels of returns, with two in five LPs reporting net annual returns of over 16 per cent across the lifetime of their private equity portfolios.
coins, banknotes, money

site_title: HSBC to close New Zealand wealth and personal banking business
summary: HSBC has announced plans to wind down its wealth and personal banking business in New Zealand, citing a strategic review and the need to focus on less profitable markets. The process will occur over several years, with customers and staff advised to switch to other service providers. The bank will continue to operate in New Zealand, primarily serving international clients through its wholesale banking business. This decision follows HSBC's global review to exit less profitable markets and expand in Asian markets, with similar moves already made in France, Greece, Russia, and Canada.

images.alt_text: UK households are cutting down other expenses to cover higher loan repayments, while many prospective buyers are avoiding the mortgage market altogether.

site_title: SGX securities turnover value rises 23% to S$23 billion in May
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) securities turnover value rose 23% to S$23 billion in May, driven by buoyant commodity and equities markets. Commodity derivatives volumes increased 13% to 3.8 million contracts, amid growing demand for risk management. This growth is attributed to iron ore, which is seen as a "proxy for industrialising Asia".

images.alt_text: SGX noted that trading activity in March was driven by the optimism of China’s recovery, as well as easing expectations for global interest rates to stay elevated.
Earnings per share has risen to S$0.266 in H1 2023 from S$0.204 in H1 2022.
SGX H1 net profit up 12.4% on higher revenue
SGX records 12th straight month of SDAV growth in January

site_title: Ikea bets on remote interior design as AI changes sales strategy
summary: Ikea is expanding its interior design services to the UK and US, training 8,500 call centre workers as interior design advisers, and leveraging an AI bot called Billie to handle customer queries. The company aims to grow its remote interior design sales to 10% of total revenue by 2028, driven by a push to appeal to Gen Z customers. This move follows a 2 billion euro expansion in the US and is comparable to rival Wayfair's launch of a digital design studio.

images.alt_text: Ingka plans to open eight new big Ikea stores and nine smaller stores in the US, as well as upgrading existing stores.
Sweden’s Ikea is seeking to win market share in the US as cash-strapped consumers look for more affordable products.

site_title: UK homebuilder Bellway flags demand woes as high rates weigh
summary: UK homebuilder Bellway flags renewed slowdown concerns due to high mortgage rates and cost-of-living pressures. The company's forward order book fell to £1.71 billion, down from £2.40 billion last year. Moody's warned British house prices are likely to fall 10% over the next two years. Bellway's CEO Jason Honeyman noted that customer interest is currently healthy but cost-of-living pressures and uncertain interest rate hikes could impact housing demand. The company's midcap peer Crest Nicholson also flagged a slowdown in the sector.

images.alt_text: A pedestrian passes a row of terraced houses in southeast London, U.K., on Thursday, July 21, 2016. London's seven-year housing boom may be about to end after the U.K. voted to leave the European Union. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Nikkei closes above 33,000 for the first time in 33 years
summary: Japan's benchmark Nikkei gauge surged, closing above 30,000 for the first time in 33 years, with a 1.8% gain to 33,018.65. The move was led by technology shares amid expectations of investment in chip-related companies. The broader Topix also rose 1.16% to 2,264.79, following global shares that climbed ahead of US inflation data and policy decisions from the Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians stand in front of an electronic share price board showing the numbers of the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Tokyo on June 14, 2022. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)

site_title: UBS plans Hong Kong investor event to carry on Credit Suisse legacy
summary: UBS plans to host a major conference in Hong Kong from May 27-29 next year, building on the tradition of Credit Suisse's annual event after acquiring its former Swiss rival. The conference, initially held as the Future Now Asia-Pacific conference, will be folded into the Asian Investment Conference. UBS CEO acknowledged the end of rivalry with Credit Suisse, with the event to be branded as UBS. The venue has not been announced yet, but HSBC previously announced it would hold a similar gathering in conjunction with the Rugby Sevens tournament in early April.

images.alt_text: Amy Lo will now serve as chair of global wealth management Asia, focusing on key clients, strategic growth opportunities and regulatory management in the region.

A sign on the exterior of the UBS Group AG headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland, on Tuesday, April 19, 2022. UBS increased pay for junior bankers in the U.S. for a second time in less than a year, bringing the Swiss lender in line with Wall Street rivals trying to stem defections amid a race for talent. Photographer: Pascal Mora/Bloomberg
“It’s true that around 10 per cent of the workforce have already left in the last few months before the takeover,”  says Sergio Ermotti, CEO of UBS.

site_title: ‘Outright lie’: India denies Dorsey’s claims it threatened to shut down Twitter
summary: India denies threatening to shut down Twitter, calling Jack Dorsey's claims an "outright lie." Dorsey stated that the country threatened to shut down Twitter unless it restricted critical accounts and also threatened to raid employees' homes if it didn't comply. Deputy Minister Rajeev Chandrasekhar disputed Dorsey's claims, saying no one was jailed or Twitter was shut down. The incident highlights the struggles faced by foreign tech giants operating under India's government, which has criticized Google, Facebook, and Twitter for not doing enough to tackle fake or "anti-India" content.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk announced in a tweet on Friday (Jun 9) that Twitter will start paying content creators for the advertisements displayed in their replies
FILE PHOTO: Twitter corporate headquarters building is seen in downtown San Francisco, California, U.S. November 18, 2022. REUTERS/Carlos Barria//File Photo

site_title: Three Eleven @ Holland housing units sold from S$1,050 to S$1,079 psf
summary: Three cluster semi-detached houses at Eleven @ Holland were sold via a tender exercise, with prices ranging from S$1,050 to S$1,079 per square foot. The properties, valued at S$3.91 million to S$4.02 million, exceeded the vendor's expectations. Located in District 10, Eleven @ Holland has 82 semi-detached homes, with the sold properties featuring three storeys, an attic, basement, five bedrooms, and five bathrooms. The sale highlights sustained demand for landed homes due to their scarcity and desire for spacious homes or multi-generational living.

images.alt_text: Located in District 10, Eleven@Holland comprises 82 semi-detached houses
PropNex, the real estate agency appointed for the mortgagee sale, says the 48 cheques collected were all from Singaporean buyers.

site_title: Stabilising home prices
summary: HDB resale flat prices rose 0.3% in May, marking the third consecutive month of marginal price increases. Analysts attribute the slowdown to sellers becoming more realistic and buyers being more rational. Meanwhile, the HDB has announced plans to set aside more temporary housing for families waiting for their new flats, doubling the number to 4,000 over two years. In the private home market, strong interest in a 48 semi-detached house development has drawn buyers, while a tycoon has purchased four bungalows on Nassim Road for a total of S$206.7 million.

site_title: Oil prices settle down 4% on jitters ahead of US Federal Reserve meeting
summary: Oil prices fell 3.9% to their lowest since December 2021 due to rising global supplies and concerns about demand growth ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting. Brent crude futures dropped to $71.84 a barrel and West Texas Intermediate crude fell to $67.12 a barrel. Goldman Sachs cut its oil price forecasts, citing higher-than-expected supplies, and the US Fed is expected to keep interest rates unchanged but may resume rate hikes next month, weighing on prices.

images.alt_text: At an industry conference on Monday, Malaysian producers Sime Darby Plantation and United Plantations said they will not have difficulty complying with the new law as they have not been planting on deforested land for years.
FILE PHOTO: A Shell sign at one of the oil company's petrol stations in South East London, Britain, February 2, 2023. REUTERS/May James/File Photo
A view shows oil pump jacks outside Almetyevsk in the Republic of Tatarstan, Russia June 4, 2023. REUTERS/Alexander Manzyuk

site_title: Toyota unveils plans for new battery tech, EV innovation
summary: Toyota Motor plans to introduce high-performance, solid-state batteries and other technologies to improve the range and performance of its electric vehicles (EVs). The company aims to launch next-generation batteries in 2026 and commercialize mass production of solid-state batteries in 2027-2028. This move seeks to win over consumers with vehicles offering longer driving ranges and quicker charging times, following its record-breaking EV sales in April, where 8,584 EVs were sold worldwide, accounting for over 1% of its global sales.

images.alt_text: Toyota plans to roll out at least two new types of batteries within the next few years.
FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: The Toyota logo is seen at its booth during a media day for the Auto Shanghai show in Shanghai, China, April 19, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Asia: Markets struggle to match Wall Street as inflation data loom
summary: Asian markets struggled to follow Wall Street's gains on Tuesday, with Tokyo, Seoul, Wellington, and Taipei rising but Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Manila, and Jakarta falling. Investors await the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, with expectations of a possible pause in rate hikes. The European Central Bank is set to increase rates on Thursday, while the Bank of Japan is expected to hold steady. China announced a rate cut to boost its economy, which has slowed down after the lifting of COVID-19 restrictions.

site_title: Entrepreneur George Goh ‘confident’ he will meet qualifying criteria for presidency
summary: George Goh, founder of Harvey Norman Ossia, is confident he will meet Singapore's qualifying criteria for the presidency despite not strictly meeting the S$500 million shareholder equity requirement. Goh has publicly listed five companies with a collective market capitalisation value of S$3.2 billion and has been assessed by his team as eligible. He emphasizes his independence and experience as a businessman, citing his ability to manage funds and investments, and notes that his supporters believe he has the necessary skills to lead the country.

images.alt_text: Prospective candidates must apply for a Certificate of Eligibility and submit their community declarations to stand in the election.

George Goh says he decided to run for president after the eligibility requirements for private sector candidates were raised in 2017, as he was “concerned that the more stringent requirements would lead to another uncontested election”.

site_title: Sygnum gets in-principle approval from MAS for major payment institution licence
summary: Sygnum, a fintech startup backed by Singtel, has received in-principle approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to operate as a major payment institution. This approval paves the way for Sygnum to expand its Singapore offering to include a regulated crypto brokerage service, featuring a fiat-digital asset gateway and trade execution for a range of cryptocurrencies. The licence will strengthen Sygnum's market position in Singapore and South-east Asia, with its CEO citing Singapore's progressive regulatory framework as a key factor.

images.alt_text: Seba Bank's headquarters in Zug, Switzerland
Accredited investors can now trade cryptocurrencies via DBS’ mobile banking app.
Sygnum's headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland.
Silvergate suffered a run on deposits last year in the wake of the bankruptcy of FTX, which was a key client.
Mainstream US banks have become warier of processing wire transfers and holding deposits for the crypto industry, following last year’s turmoil and amid growing regulatory scrutiny.

site_title: FTC files to block Microsoft from closing Activision deal
summary: The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has filed a lawsuit in federal court to block Microsoft's $69 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard, citing concerns over harm to competition in the US video game market. The FTC seeks a court order to block the transaction before its July 18 deadline. Microsoft is appealing the UK's Competition and Markets Authority decision, which also blocked the deal. The FTC's trial is set to begin on August 2, with a potential decision by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Malaysia caters to about 13 per cent of the world demand for chip testing and packaging, and what Trade Minister Zafrul Abdul Aziz estimated as a quarter of US chip-testing and assembly needs.
From 2015 to 2020, Microsoft retained the data that it collected from children during the Xbox account creation process, even when a parent failed to complete the process, according to the complaint.
Microsoft president Brad Smith will be in London, where he is giving a “scheduled talk about the potential of AI and the need for thoughtful regulation of it.”

site_title: Intel is in talks to be an anchor investor in chip designer Arm’s IPO
summary: British chip designer Arm is in talks with potential investors, including Intel, to anchor its planned IPO, which could be one of the largest chip company listings in history. Arm aims to raise up to $10 billion in its New York listing. Intel's involvement could demonstrate its commitment to Arm's technology and open up its factories to other firms, a key part of CEO Pat Gelsinger's plan to return the company to the semiconductor industry's top spot.

images.alt_text: The Japanese conglomerate, which has been hit by the slumping value of its tech portfolio, has seen its shares gain 17 per cent since last week’s close.

site_title: Gold steadies as traders await inflation data, US Fed decision
summary: Gold prices edged higher on Tuesday as the US dollar eased 0.1%, making greenback-priced bullion more appealing to overseas buyers. Spot gold rose 0.1% to $1,959.23 per ounce, while US gold futures rose 0.2% to $1,973.40. Traders await US inflation data and the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates, which are expected to keep rates unchanged. The European Central Bank and Bank of Japan will deliver their rate decisions on Thursday and Friday, respectively.

images.alt_text: Gold prices climbed 0.7 per cent for the week ended on Friday, helped by a more than 1 per cent jump on Thursday after a surge in US weekly jobless claims.

site_title: UBS Asia-Pacific wealth management co-head expands role
summary: UBS Asia-Pacific wealth management co-head Amy Lo has expanded her role to focus on key clients, strategic growth opportunities, and regulatory management in the region. She retains primary responsibility for Hong Kong, North Asia, and Greater China but will now serve as chair of global wealth management Asia. Jin Yee Young joins UBS from June 29 as Lo's co-head of the Asia-Pacific business, and Benjamin Cavalli will lead strategic clients starting July 3. August Hatecke, the former co-head, will lead UBS' global wealth management business in Switzerland.

images.alt_text: “It’s true that around 10 per cent of the workforce have already left in the last few months before the takeover,”  says Sergio Ermotti, CEO of UBS.
Jin Yee Young will join UBS on Jun 29, hopping over from Deutsche Bank where she had warmed the seat for under six months.

site_title: Barclays CEO says banker exodus followed a business refocus
summary: Barclays CEO CS Venkatakrishnan attributes the recent high turnover in the firm's investment bank to a business refocus, including shuffling top leaders and expanding into new areas such as sustainable companies and private equity firms. While the attrition is higher than usual, Venkatakrishnan says it's still only slightly higher than normal annual turnover. The firm has made new appointments to its investment banking division, aiming to take market share from rivals and grow its business in the US and Europe.

images.alt_text: The Italian loans are one of the final remaining parts of its retail business in the country.
Tom Road is newly appointed as deputy head for Barclays Private Bank, Singapore.

site_title: Pakistan holds rates to prevent growth from falling further
summary: Pakistan's central bank kept interest rates unchanged at a record 21% to prevent further economic growth and curb inflation, which reached a record 38% last month. The move aims to secure IMF loan repayments and avoid a default, as the country faces $22 billion in external debt payments in fiscal year 2024. Despite a government goal of 3.5% growth, domestic demand is expected to remain subdued, and the central bank sees inflation starting to fall from June onwards.

images.alt_text: Pakistan’s purchase gives Russia a new outlet, adding to Moscow’s growing sales to India and China, as it redirects oil from Western markets because of the Ukraine conflict.
Pakistan Finance Minister Ishaq Dar said the government will engage in negotiations on its bilateral debt, but doesn’t plan to ask creditors to take major reductions on principal.

site_title: US: Stocks extend upswing ahead of inflation data
summary: US stocks rose 0.6% on Monday, reaching 34,066.33, ahead of Tuesday's consumer price index report, which is expected to influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions. Analysts believe the Fed will skip an interest rate hike, supporting the bull market rally. The Dow Jones Industrial Average extended its upswing, with investors focusing on the potential shift in the central bank's stance.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange shortly after the opening bell as trading is halted in New York, U.S., March 16, 2020. REUTERS/Lucas Jackson//File Photo

site_title: Coinbase pushes for legislative remedy as it fights US SEC suit
summary: Coinbase is fighting a lawsuit by the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) alleging it operates an unregistered securities exchange. The company's chief legal officer, Paul Grewal, said Coinbase will push for legislative solutions on crypto rules. A draft bill addressing the issue may advance in the US House of Representatives by the end of the summer, potentially resolving the case. If the court disagrees, the case will proceed through discovery and a trial, with Coinbase operating business as usual in the meantime.

images.alt_text: The purportedly independent American affiliate of Binance says its banking partners are preparing to stop US dollar withdrawal channels as early as Jun 13.
Shares of the cryptocurrency exchange tumbled as much as 21 per cent at the opening of trading, driving the value of the put options to US$5.65 each.
“The SEC allowed us to become a public company ... so, its not great to have a regulator come back and say, actually, we changed our mind,” Coinbase CEO Brian Armstrong says.
Charging the crypto exchanges may be a move by the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to clarify the regulatory grey area in which cryptocurrencies have existed for years.

site_title: New York occupancy breaks 50% for first time since pandemic hit
summary: New York City's office occupancies have surpassed 50% for the first time since the COVID-19 pandemic, reaching 50.5% according to Kastle Systems data. This milestone comes amid increased return-to-office mandates from major employers, but may be a temporary blip as remote work's popularity continues to impact the city's economy, costing over $12 billion annually. Other major cities, such as Washington, DC, and San Francisco, have yet to reach this threshold.

site_title: China cuts short-term borrowing costs to support recovery
summary: China's central bank, the PBOC, cut its seven-day reverse repo rate by 10 basis points to 1.90% in a bid to restore market confidence and support the post-pandemic recovery. The move signals possible easing of longer-term rates and may lead to further stimulus measures, including interest rate cuts, to sustain growth. The yuan hit a six-month low, while yields on China's benchmark 10-year government bonds fell to a fresh 7.5-month low.

images.alt_text: The People’s Bank of China will enhance “counter-cyclical” policy adjustments to fully support the real economy.
People's Bank of China (PBOC) governor Yi Gang says he has confidence the official growth target of around 5 per cent can be achieved this year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Raffles Education, Hatten Land, Quantum Healthcare, Sheng Siong
summary: Raffles Education lodged bankruptcy applications against defendants in the Educomp case, failing to pay S$3.4 million. Hatten Land signed a tenancy agreement for 138,769 sq ft at its Imperio Mall@Hatten City in Melaka. Quantum Healthcare also signed a deal to occupy space at the mall. Sheng Siong defended its non-compliance with corporate governance code provisions, stating it's not necessary given the group's size and operations.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Tuesday; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.2% to 3,189.22. Gainers slightly outnumbered losers 59 to 54, with top traded stocks including 3Cnergy and Seatrium. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also traded lower. The global markets were largely positive, with US indices closing higher on Monday as investors expect the Federal Reserve to skip an interest rate increase.

images.alt_text: Raffles Education has lodged bankruptcy applications against the defendants in the Educomp case.

site_title: BT Explains: Vietnam’s severe electricity shortage and the risks it brings
summary: Vietnam is experiencing a severe electricity shortage due to an unusually long heatwave, which has reduced water volumes at hydropower dams and increased electricity demand. The heatwave has led to power blackouts and has prompted the government to issue a directive urging people to conserve electricity. Vietnam's power plan, PDP8, aims to double the country's power generation capacity to 150 GW by 2030, with a goal of reducing reliance on coal and increasing renewable energy sources. However, the plan relies heavily on foreign funding, and the country's renewable energy supply is still limited, exacerbating the power shortage situation.

images.alt_text: Da Nang is home to nearly 900 foreign-invested projects with a total investment capital of US$5.9 billion.
Coal barges to be pulled along Mahakam river in Samarinda, East Kalimantan province, Indonesia, in August 31, 2019.
Vietnam's large imports decline could indicate a further slowdown ahead in industrial production as businesses reduce purchases of raw materials and equipment.

People wearing long clothing to protect themselves from the heat while riding motorcycles along a street in Hanoi. Extreme weather conditions in Vietnam saw temperatures exceed 44 deg C in some regions recently.

site_title: HSBC’s new technology arm primed for expansion: CEO Quinn
