A mural of Argentine football player Lionel Messi in Miami on June 7, 2023. Messi on Wednesday announced he will sign for Major League Soccer side Inter Miami, spurning talk of a Barcelona reunion or Saudi Arabian blockbuster deal.

site_title: Touting cheaper labour and relaxed customs, India makes big push to be a global electronics repair hub
summary: India has launched a pilot project to establish itself as a global electronics repair hub, aiming to generate up to $20 billion in revenue and create 5 million jobs over the next five years. The project, launched by the Ministry of Information and Technology, will focus on electronics repair resourcing and will involve companies like Lenovo and Flex. This move is expected to capitalize on the $100 billion global electronics repair outsourcing sector, currently dominated by China and Malaysia.

images.alt_text: India’s hold on rates contrasts with recent central bank actions elsewhere.
The RBI’s move will make onshore and offshore pricing more aligned and also provide better liquidity, price discovery, transparency and access to market participants, HSBC says.
“With this revival package, BSNL will emerge as a stable telecom service provider focused on providing connectivity to remotest parts of India,” the cabinet says.
Any cooling – especially one driven by inequality – would pose a challenge for Prime Minister Narendra Modi as he seeks a third term in general elections next year.

site_title: Europe: German stocks lead gains, all eyes on central bank meetings
summary: European stocks rose on Monday, with the Stoxx 600 index closing 0.2% higher and the DAX up 0.9%. Adidas shares jumped 5.5% after an analyst upgrade, while luxury majors LVMH and Hermes also gained. Central bank meetings, including the US Federal Reserve, European Central Bank, and Bank of Japan, are expected to influence markets this week. The ECB is predicted to hike interest rates by a quarter percentage point to tame inflation, while the Fed is seen holding rates steady.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.6 per cent higher at 34,066.33 on Monday.

site_title: Yellen says IMF, World Bank are important counterweights to China
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen will testify before Congress, praising the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank as American-aligned counterweights to China's growing influence in the developing world. Yellen's plan to expand the World Bank's scope aims to address global challenges such as climate change and pandemics. Republicans, who control the House Financial Services Committee, are likely to scrutinize her remarks, citing concerns about the institutions' mandates and potential limitations on US investments in China.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen speaks during a news conference at the Treasury Department in Washington, U.S., April 11, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz/File Photo

US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen’s announcement allows a little more time for Democratic President Joe Biden and Republican House of Representatives Speaker Kevin McCarthy to reach an accord to raise the federal government’s self-imposed borrowing limit.

site_title: Binance plans to swap 750 million of token pairs to ensure liquidity
summary: Binance plans to swap 750 million tether-tron token pairs for tether-ether to maintain stablecoin liquidity amid regulatory scrutiny. The move follows recent regulatory actions, including a lawsuit by the US Securities and Exchange Commission. The swap, starting after 12 pm UTC on Monday, will be held directly with the tether team. This action aims to cushion some of the fallout from Binance's recent blows, including a lawsuit and halted dollar withdrawal channels.

images.alt_text: The SEC said in its lawsuit that Merit Peak, which described itself as trading with the “self-made wealth” of Zhao, operated on both the Binance.com and Binance.US platforms.

site_title: Seatrium’s inclusion in the STI in June changes previous assumption about index methodology
summary: Seatrium's inclusion in the Straits Times Index (STI) in June has changed the previous assumption about the index methodology. FTSE Russell, the index compiler, reviews the STI semi-annually in March and September, screening all SGX-listed securities based on eligibility criteria. Seatrium's large market capitalization following its acquisition of Keppel Offshore and Marine (KOM) made it a potential STI candidate. Its addition as an index constituent replaced Keppel DC Reit, surprising market watchers and challenging previous assumptions about the index review process.

images.alt_text: Keppel DC real estate investment trust has been booted from the Straits Times Index (STI) and will be replaced by Seatrium.
The STI tracks the performance of the 30 largest and most liquid companies listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX).

Sembcorp Marine's increased market cap of S$8.2 billion makes it the largest counter on the Straits Times Index (STI) reserve list, which means it has a chance of being added to the benchmark index – depending on how it and other index counters trade in the coming months.

site_title: Eurozone bond yields fall ahead ECB policy meeting
summary: Eurozone bond yields fell ahead of the European Central Bank's policy meeting, with investors scaling back bets on future interest rate hikes. The ECB is expected to raise rates by 25 basis points, but most analysts still forecast the depo rate to peak at 3.75% in July. Money markets price in an ECB depo rate of 3.77% by autumn, and US inflation data may provide fresh clues about the Federal Reserve's tightening path.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A symphony of light consisting of bars, lines and circles in blue and yellow, the colours of the European Union, illuminates the south facade of the European Central Bank (ECB) headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany, December 30, 2021. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay//File Photo

site_title: Berlusconi’s passing raises prospects of business empire’s shakeup
summary: Former Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi has died at 86, sparking a potential shakeup in his business empire. Shares in his family's broadcaster, MFE-MediaForEurope, rose 10.3% on news of his passing, as investors anticipate changes in the company's leadership. Berlusconi's eldest child, Marina, is seen as the most likely to take the reins, given her role as Fininvest chair and her close relationship with her father. The family's assets will be divided according to Italian law, with Marina and her brother Pier Silvio inheriting two-thirds of the wealth, while the remaining one-third can be assigned freely to determine the company's future leadership.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Forza Italia leader Silvio Berlusconi gestures during the closing electoral campaign rally of the centre-right's coalition in Piazza del Popolo, ahead of the September 25 general election, in Rome, Italy, September 22, 2022. REUTERS/Yara Nardi/File Photo

site_title: UBS CEO says about 10% of Credit Suisse staff have left
summary: UBS CEO Sergio Ermotti confirmed that around 10% of Credit Suisse staff, approximately 5,000 employees, have left before the takeover, amid heightened uncertainty and recruitment efforts from competitors. This departure rate is higher than previously reported. UBS has already announced plans to cut jobs to reduce costs and take advantage of synergies. The 10% figure translates to nearly 400 employees per week since Credit Suisse's rescue. Ermotti expressed sympathy for departing employees, stating they will find a better place to work at UBS.

images.alt_text: Jin Yee Young will join UBS on Jun 29, hopping over from Deutsche Bank where she had warmed the seat for under six months.
MAS notes that there will be no interruptions to the day-to-day proceedings of UBS and Credit Suisse’s Singapore operations as the banks will continue to operate here under separate licences.

A sign on the exterior of the UBS Group AG headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland, on Tuesday, April 19, 2022. UBS increased pay for junior bankers in the U.S. for a second time in less than a year, bringing the Swiss lender in line with Wall Street rivals trying to stem defections amid a race for talent. Photographer: Pascal Mora/Bloomberg
UBS has come up with a list of nearly two dozen “red lines” that prohibit Credit Suisse staff from a range of activities.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as investors eye inflation data, Fed verdict
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday as investors awaited inflation data and the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision this week. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 30.02 points, or 0.09%, to 33,906.80. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened near 2023 highs, driven by optimism about the market outlook.

site_title: Why secrets lost their sizzle
summary: The US government has released a trove of secret documents, known as the Discord Leaks, which detail its intelligence on the Russia-Ukraine war. The documents, allegedly leaked by a low-ranking Massachusetts Air National Guard member, reveal US intelligence assessments that Ukraine's counteroffensive may not achieve significant territorial gains, and that Russia's special forces are severely depleted. However, the public's reaction has been muted, with many outlets focusing on the individual behind the leak rather than the leaked secrets themselves. Experts attribute this to the war's minute-by-minute reporting and the lack of politically scandalous revelations.

images.alt_text: US National Guardsman Jack Teixeira, accused of leaking classified documents online, may still have access to classified materials, federal prosecutors said in court documents filed on Wednesday.
FBI agents arrest Jack Teixeira at his home in North Dighton, Massachusetts, US, April 13, 2023.. The US Air Force guardsman has been arraigned over a leak of classified military intelligence.

site_title: US food prices are still up 8.2% online even as inflation cools
summary: US food prices remain high, increasing 8.2% online despite cooling inflation. In contrast, online prices for essential items like food, pet products, and personal care continue to rise. Non-essential items like computers, appliances, and electronics saw significant declines, with online prices dropping 16.5%, 7.9%, and 12% respectively in May. The Adobe Digital Price Index tracks price changes across 1 trillion retail site visits and over 100 million items.

site_title: Taming of the crypto hydra has lessons for how to wrangle AI
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission's recent crackdown on crypto tokens has lessons for regulating artificial intelligence, which is rapidly evolving and generating new use cases daily. The SEC's actions against Coinbase and Binance serve as a cautionary tale for AI, as seen in the slow response to Bitcoin's initial launch. Experts, including Chamath Palihapitiya, argue for AI regulation due to the rapid compounding of technology, and various countries, including Singapore, China, and the UK, are taking steps to establish oversight. The US must join global efforts to establish meaningful governance and avoid a replay of the crypto space's issues with AI firms exploiting geographical borders.

images.alt_text: AI Verify was launched as a minimum viable product for international pilot last year. It has attracted interest from over 50 local and multinational companies including IBM, Dell and Hitachi, IMDA says.

UK prime minister Rishi Sunak, left, meets US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, June 7, 2023. Britain will host the world’s first summit on artificial intelligence later this year, Sunak announced.
US lawmakers are beginning to consider what new rules might be needed because of the rise of AI.

site_title: US dollar edges lower as Fed pause eyed in busy central bank week
summary: The US dollar slipped on Monday as traders awaited central bank decisions this week, including the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. The dollar index fell 0.5% last week, its worst weekly drop since mid-April. Markets expect the Fed to keep interest rates on hold, while the European Central Bank is expected to hike rates by 25 basis points. The euro rose 0.2% against the dollar, and the Japanese yen remained flat. The US dollar is seen vulnerable to a rate cut in the future, according to analysts.

site_title: Learn from US failings to maintain confidence in smaller banks
summary: US regulators should supervise all banks, not just large ones, to restore confidence in smaller banks. Small and mid-sized banks are perceived as riskier due to their concentrated portfolios and increased exposure to climate-related risks. Regulators should adopt a more comprehensive approach to risk management, including climate scenario analysis, and incorporate climate into bank rating systems. Joint inter-agency guidance could help reduce regulatory compliance costs and align with the New York State Department of Financial Services' guidance on managing climate risk.

images.alt_text: Gregory Becker, the former chief executive of Silicon Valley Bank, testifies before a Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee hearing to examine the failures of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank on Capitol Hill in Washington, May 16, 2023.
The FDIC says the US$472 billion in deposit outflows in the first quarter is primarily uninsured funds, as insured deposits actually rose US$255.1 billion, or 2.5 per cent
The remarks follow comments from Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen, who said she expects US regulators to be open to such deals as firms consolidate.

site_title: Harvey Norman Ossia founder George Goh announces presidential bid
summary: Harvey Norman Ossia founder George Goh, 63, has announced his candidacy for Singapore's next presidential election, citing concerns over stricter eligibility requirements for private sector candidates. Goh, an independent candidate, has no political party affiliations and has never worked in the public sector, citing his financial and technical skills and managerial expertise as qualifications. He questioned Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam's suitability for the role, citing his close alignment with the ruling party.

images.alt_text: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam and Jurong GRC MPs (from left) Shawn Huang, Rahayu Mahzam and Xie Yao Quan at the opening of ActiveSG Sport Village @ Jurong Town on Sunday; Tharman says: "Having a contest is important for me. I much rather win or lose with the contest. My whole approach is not to shy away from competition, it has always been that way. It’s how I prove myself."

Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam will resign from the People's Action Party and step down from his Cabinet positions on Jul 7 to fulfil his official commitments in Singapore and internationally.
Prospective candidates must apply for a Certificate of Eligibility and submit their community declarations to stand in the election.

site_title: Pakistan central bank leaves key rate unchanged, signals tightening pause
summary: Pakistan's central bank kept its key interest rate unchanged at a record high of 21% on June 12, signaling a pause in tightening measures amid concerns inflation may have peaked at 38% in May. The decision follows 1125 basis point rate hikes since April 2022 to curb inflation. The Monetary Policy Committee expects inflation to start falling from June, but acknowledges domestic uncertainty and external vulnerabilities. The central bank aims to anchor inflation expectations and bring inflation towards its medium-term target, pending any unexpected shocks.

images.alt_text: Pakistan Finance Minister Ishaq Dar said the government will engage in negotiations on its bilateral debt, but doesn’t plan to ask creditors to take major reductions on principal.
The economic crisis comes as the country is also facing political stress, with former premier Imran Khan and his supporters clashing with the powerful army, a traditional power base in Pakistan.

site_title: Vietnam’s factories boost operations as power shortages ease
summary: Vietnam's power shortages are easing, allowing factories to resume operations after nationwide outages began last month. Thousands of factories in northern Vietnam, including those owned by Samsung Electronics and Apple, can now operate from midnight to 5 pm daily. The measures will be implemented nationwide, with priority access to power for industrial parks during the day and saving electricity for citizens at night. Power supplies improved over the weekend after repairs to malfunctioning coal-fired generators and increased water levels in reservoirs due to light rain, with forecasts of more rain expected to ease strain on hydropower supplies.

images.alt_text: Some industrial parks in northern provinces of Vietnam, where top manufacturers like Samsung and Foxconn factories are located, have been facing blackouts.

site_title: Ex-Credit Suisse star banker Young Jin Yee joins UBS to take over from August Hatecke
summary: Young Jin Yee, a former Credit Suisse star banker, joins UBS on June 29, taking over as co-head of global wealth management for Asia-Pacific. She moves from Deutsche Bank, where she spent less than six months, and replaces August Hatecke, who is returning to Zurich to lead UBS's Switzerland business. Yee's new role includes responsibility for Singapore and South-east Asia, subject to regulatory approvals. This move comes as UBS expands its global wealth management team, with key roles being filled by individuals from both UBS and Credit Suisse.

images.alt_text: A sign on the exterior of the UBS Group AG headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland, on Tuesday, April 19, 2022. UBS increased pay for junior bankers in the U.S. for a second time in less than a year, bringing the Swiss lender in line with Wall Street rivals trying to stem defections amid a race for talent. Photographer: Pascal Mora/Bloomberg
MAS notes that there will be no interruptions to the day-to-day proceedings of UBS and Credit Suisse’s Singapore operations as the banks will continue to operate here under separate licences.

site_title: Nasdaq to buy financial software firm Adenza for US$10.5 billion
summary: Nasdaq to acquire financial software firm Adenza for $10.5 billion, its largest acquisition to date. The deal, valued at $5.75 billion in cash and 85.6 million shares, aims to enhance Nasdaq's tech offerings and boost growth. Adenza, expected to generate $590 million in annual revenue, will help Nasdaq expand its anti-financial crime software and ESG services, with recurring revenue from non-market units making up 75% of its total. The acquisition is part of Nasdaq's efforts to diversify under CEO Adena Friedman.

site_title: India's retail inflation eases to a more than 2-year low in May
summary: India's retail inflation eased to a 2-year low of 4.25% in May, below the Reserve Bank of India's target of 4% for the third straight month. Food inflation moderated to 2.91%, while core inflation remained below 6% for a third consecutive month. However, economists expect inflation to pick up again due to deficient monsoon rains and the El Nino weather phenomenon, which could add pressure on food prices in the coming months.

images.alt_text: The Maiden Pharmaceuticals plant in Sonipat was sealed in 2022 following the deaths of more than 70 Gambian children from acute kidney injury that were linked to the company's cough syrups.

site_title: Italy’s scandal-hit Berlusconi dies at 86
summary: Silvio Berlusconi, Italy's longest-serving premier, has died at 86 after a life marred by scandal. The billionaire media mogul and politician was diagnosed with leukaemia and a lung infection in April 2023, but remained active in politics until his death. Despite facing numerous court cases and convictions, Berlusconi never spent time behind bars. He dominated Italian public life for decades, serving as prime minister four times and founding the Forza Italia party. His death is likely to destabilize Italian politics, with his party part of Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni's right-wing coalition.

images.alt_text: The 86-year-old media mogul and senator, who has been in and out of the hospital in recent years, is in Milan’s San Raffaele Hospital.

site_title: JPMorgan reaches settlement with Epstein’s victims
summary: JPMorgan has reached a settlement with victims of Jeffrey Epstein, a financier who was convicted of soliciting prostitution from a teenage girl in 2008. The lawsuit, filed by an unidentified woman on behalf of Epstein's alleged victims, alleged JPMorgan ignored repeated warnings of Epstein's sex trafficking activities. The proposed deal, which has not disclosed a settlement amount, is in the best interests of the victims and aims to settle a lawsuit filed last November. The number of victims could potentially rise to over 100.

images.alt_text: Jamie Dimon, chairman and chief executive officer of JPMorgan Chase & Co., during a Bloomberg Television interview at the JPMorgan Global High Yield and Leveraged Finance Conference in Miami, Florida, US, on Monday, March 6, 2023. Dimon said last month that the US economy was still performing well, with strength in consumer spending and plentiful jobs. Photographer: Marco Bello/Bloomberg

site_title: MAS urges UBS, Credit Suisse to handle Singapore jobs ‘responsibly’ after takeover
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is monitoring the takeover of Credit Suisse by UBS, with no expected disruptions to the banks' Singapore operations. MAS urges the banks to handle the job implications "responsibly" and has established a governance structure to facilitate the integration. The banks will continue to operate under separate licences, with their primary activities remaining private banking and investment banking. MAS is in close contact with the Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority and the banks themselves on the integration.

site_title: Rio Tinto to invest US$1.1 billion to expand aluminium smelter in Canada
summary: Rio Tinto plans to invest US$1.1 billion to expand its low-carbon aluminium smelter in Quebec, Canada, boosting annual capacity by 160,000 metric tonnes. The investment, supported by the Quebec government, will power 400,000 electric cars and is the company's largest investment in its aluminium business in over a decade. Construction is expected to take two-and-a-half years, with the new smelter expected to be fully ramped up by the end of 2026.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sign adorns the building where mining company Rio Tinto has their office in Perth, Western Australia, November 19, 2015. REUTERS/David Gray/File Photo
Apart from higher wages due to a shortage of skilled labour, the Anglo-American miner had to pay more for fuel and raw materials.

site_title: Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan turn bullish on emerging market local bonds
summary: Morgan Stanley has upgraded its stance on emerging market local currency bonds to bullish, citing expected rate cuts ahead of the Federal Reserve's decision. Strategist James Lord stated that EM rate cuts are on the way, driven by the Fed's actions. This move follows similar bullish assessments by other Wall Street banks. Despite this, Lord expressed caution regarding developing economies' currencies due to the strong US dollar. The upgrade is seen as a positive sign for investors in emerging markets.

site_title: Success is less about means, more about meaning, says DPM Wong on renewing social compact
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized that success in Singapore's meritocracy is not solely about material achievements, but rather about personal meaning and fulfillment. The refreshed social compact should prioritize a continuous learning approach, social support for vulnerable groups, and a renewed sense of solidarity among Singaporeans. Wong also stressed the importance of inter-group interactions and mutual respect in building a stronger sense of community. The government will work to assure the needs of the middle and vulnerable groups, while encouraging everyone to look beyond their own communities and celebrate their shared identity as Singaporeans.

site_title: Singapore stocks climb on Monday amid mixed regional trading; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index closing at 3,196.07, driven by gains from Hongkong Land and DBS. The broader market saw 266 gainers versus 226 losers, with 1.3 billion securities worth S$829.7 million traded. Investors await decisions from global central banks meetings later this week, with the US Federal Reserve's meeting on Wednesday expected to be closely watched.

images.alt_text: China’s blue-chip CSI300 Index closed up 0.2 per cent, while the Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.1 per cent.

site_title: Nomura to scale back loss-making brokerage venture with Line
summary: Nomura Holdings plans to scale back its loss-making brokerage venture with Line Group, Japan's largest securities firm will take over client brokerage accounts, while Line Securities will focus on foreign-exchange margin trading services. The restructuring comes amid a gloomier outlook for the business, which had battled losses as it sought to attract younger clients. The companies agreed to the overhaul after considering resource allocation, with talks to prepare for the completion in 2024 and the launch of a new Line Securities.

site_title: Big palm oil players say EU deforestation law will not hurt exports
summary: Malaysia's two largest palm oil producers, Sime Darby Plantation and United Plantations, claim they will not face difficulties complying with the EU's new law banning imports linked to deforestation. The companies stated they have not planted on deforested land for years and have signed agreements to avoid deforestation and development on peatlands. However, they expressed concerns about small farmers, who may struggle to provide the required documentation under the new law.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers handle palm oil fruits at an oil palm plantation in Slim River, Malaysia August 12, 2021. Picture taken August 12, 2021. REUTERS/Lim Huey Teng/File Photo

site_title: Glencore, automakers to back US$1 billion nickel, copper SPAC deal in Brazil
summary: Glencore, Stellantis, and PowerCo have agreed to back a $1 billion deal to buy two Brazilian mines, Santa Rita nickel sulphide and Serrote copper, from private equity funds advised by Appian Capital. The deal is part of a mining M&A spree driven by investors betting on rising demand for metals needed for the global green energy transition. ACG Acquisition Company, a London-listed SPAC, will purchase the mines.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s IPO market has raised US$1.58 billion as of April this year, second only to China in the Asia-Pacific region excluding Japan.

site_title: Spotlight Singapore to connect startups in Singapore, Vietnam through arts and culture
summary: Singapore's Spotlight Singapore, a cultural diplomacy platform, will connect startups in Singapore and Vietnam through arts and culture from October 19-23. The eighth edition, Spotlight Singapore in Vietnam (SSVietnam), will mark 50 years of diplomatic relations and a decade of strategic partnerships between both countries. A delegation of 200 Singaporean youths, artists, and young entrepreneurs will participate in the event, exploring business opportunities and fostering collaborations with Vietnamese counterparts.

images.alt_text: Falling manufacturing activity on the back of declining global orders has taken a toll on jobs in Vietnam's export-reliant cities and provinces.
Since fundraising from established foreign funds faced rocky path amid global economic distress, local venture capital firms took the lead to provide growth capital for Vietnamese early-stage startup

site_title: Mak Swee Wah to retire as Singapore Airlines COO; CFO Tan Kai Ping to take over
summary: Singapore Airlines announced the retirement of Chief Operations Officer Mak Swee Wah, effective September 9, after 40 years with the group. Mak will be replaced by CFO Tan Kai Ping, who will assume the COO role and oversee cabin crew, customer service, and operations. Tan previously spearheaded the airline's fundraising efforts during the pandemic and managed the restructuring of its aircraft order book. Incoming CFO JoAnn Tan will take over the CFO role and lead efforts to restore network connectivity and capacity.

images.alt_text: SIA was asked by Sias how it manages the interests of its equity holders versus those of its MCB holders
Ng Chin Hwee will retire from his role as chief executive officer of SIA Engineering from October.

site_title: China, HK stocks close roughly flat as investors brace for fresh data
summary: China's blue-chip CSI300 Index closed up 0.2% on Monday, while the Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.1%. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index remained little changed. Investors are bracing for fresh data this week, which may add to concerns over China's economic health, as risk appetite has been curbed by signs of a slowing post-Covid recovery.

site_title: Indonesia’s PalmCo plans US$500 million IPO this year: sources
summary: Indonesian palm oil producer PalmCo plans a US$500 million initial public offering (IPO) in Jakarta's fourth quarter, targeting to raise funds for increasing company value through investments in technology, downstream business, and renewable energy. The IPO, facilitated by Mandiri Sekuritas, DBS, BNP Paribas, and CIMB, will solidify Indonesia's IPO market as one of the world's hottest this year, following successful first-time share sales in the region.

images.alt_text: At an industry conference on Monday, Malaysian producers Sime Darby Plantation and United Plantations said they will not have difficulty complying with the new law as they have not been planting on deforested land for years.

site_title: Smith pocket watch fetches record US$4.9 million after fake Omega
summary: A pocket watch created by renowned UK watchmaker Roger Smith sold for a record US$4.9 million at an auction in New York, surpassing the highest price ever paid at auction for a British watch and the fourth-highest for a pocket watch. The 'Pocket Watch Number Two' features perpetual calendar, tourbillon, and Moonphase complications, built over five years from handcrafted parts. The sale comes after Phillips auction house was involved in a scandal over a faked Omega Speedmaster sold for US$3.3 million in 2021.

images.alt_text: The Omega Speedmaster with ‘Broad Arrow’ hands from 1957 featured on the Phillips website.

site_title: Raffles Education files bankruptcy applications against defendants in India Educomp case
summary: Raffles Education has filed bankruptcy applications against Indian edtech businessman Shantanu Prakash and Singapore lawyer Dennis Lui, who failed to pay S$3.4 million awarded by the High Court. The group was awarded S$221,080 and S$2.65 million in damages for claims of misrepresentation. The court had also ordered them to pay costs and disbursements totaling S$507,720. The two defendants have filed appeals against the High Court's decisions, but no stay of enforcement has been granted pending the appeal.

images.alt_text: Raffles Education has said that is it in compliance with board diversity policies in a response to SGX Regco queries
The relationship between Raffles Education and Educomp had started around 2006.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's international visitor arrivals exceeded 1 million in May for the third straight month, but slipped from April's post-pandemic high. China was the fourth-largest source of tourist arrivals, with 95,613 visitors. Local business sentiment hit a two-year low for Q3 2023, amid a worsening outlook for the manufacturing and wholesale sectors. Harvey Norman Ossia founder George Goh announced a presidential bid, while a new thermal power station could be built on Jurong Island over the next few years. Singapore stocks climbed 0.3% on Monday amid mixed regional trading.

site_title: Thailand’s poll body to investigate PM frontrunner Pita
summary: Thailand's election commission will investigate Prime Ministerial frontrunner Pita Limjareonrat over whether he was qualified to run in the recent election due to his ownership of shares in a media firm, which is prohibited under election rules. Pita has downplayed the issue, but faces potential disqualification, up to 10 years in jail, and 20 years banned from politics if found in violation. The investigation is another setback for Pita as he battles to win backing for his premiership.

images.alt_text: epa10675351 Move Forward Party leader Pita Limjaroenrat (C) speaks to the media after a meeting with the working group of seven party allies to form a coalition government, at Pheu Thai Party headquarters in Bangkok, Thailand, 06 June 2023. An eight-party coalition, spearheaded by the Move Forward party, agreed to form a government with Limjaroenrat as prime minister, after winning the most seats in the 14 May general election.  EPA-EFE/NARONG SANGNAK

epa10646001 Move Forward Party's leader Pita Limjaroenrat speaks during the signing ceremony of a memorandum of understanding among pro-democracy parties to form a coalition government, in Bangkok, Thailand, 22 May 2023. An eight-party coalition, spearheaded by the Move Forward party, agreed to form a coalition government with Limjaroenrat as prime minister, after winning the most seats in the 14 May general election.  EPA-EFE/NARONG SANGNAK

site_title: Redefining retirement: 7 considerations
summary: The traditional framework of three life stages - education, work, and leisure - is losing relevance due to longevity and inflation. To redefine retirement, consider balancing health, time, and money, and start spending wealth earlier rather than later. Leaving a bequest may not be the best way to show love to children, and instead, consider helping them financially now. The question of how much is enough for a sustainable retirement depends on individual needs and goals. The "unretired" trend shows that some people continue to work after retirement for financial and psychological reasons. Prioritizing health is crucial for a fulfilling retirement.

images.alt_text: Longevity is your friend in retirement planning
A longevity road map for happier, more fulfilling lives
Generic pix of a customer being served at the CPF Bishan Service Centre, 16 February 2023.

site_title: Ex-Samsung Elec executive accused of stealing secrets for China chip factory
summary: A former Samsung Electronics executive has been indicted on suspicion of stealing company technology to build a rival chip factory in China, causing at least $233 million in losses. The accused, who worked 28 years at Samsung and SK Hynix, allegedly acquired data to build a factory just 1.5 km away from a Samsung facility. Prosecutors estimate the theft caused significant economic losses and jeopardized national security, amid intensifying competition between the US and China in the chip industry.

images.alt_text: A view shows Samsung Electronics' chip production plant at Pyeongtaek, South Korea, in this handout picture obtained by Reuters on September 7, 2022.  Samsung Electronics/Handout via REUTERS    THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY

site_title: New global development agenda should be inclusive and sustainable: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for a new global development agenda that is inclusive and sustainable. He proposed three areas for collaboration: upholding an open and rules-based framework for trade and investment, promoting financial flows to catalyze economic development and innovation, and working together to address global challenges like climate change and pandemics. Heng urged the US and China to take leadership roles in these efforts, believing that their combined influence can drive meaningful progress and reduce the risk of instability and conflict.

site_title: EY promotes more than 900 employees to partner worldwide
summary: EY has promoted 966 employees to partner worldwide, with women making up 34% of the new cohort, a 2% increase from last year. The largest number of promotions were in Europe, the Middle East, India, and Africa, followed by America. By department, assurance led with 304 new partners, followed by tax, consulting, and strategy and transactions. The new partners will begin their roles in early July.

images.alt_text: GlobalWafers CEO Doris Hsu was picked from nearly 5,000 programme participants that included the 49 winners across 45 countries and jurisdictions competing for the global title.

site_title: Can the ECB escape its own trap?
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is struggling to reverse years of massive asset purchases, despite rapid interest rate hikes to combat resurgent inflation. The bank's balance sheet has expanded significantly, creating a liquidity glut, making it difficult for policymakers to escape their trap. The ECB has raised interest rates by 375 basis points in less than a year, but reversing the policy of massive bond purchases is proving more challenging. This dilemma is a result of central banks' failure to anticipate the threat of inflation in 2021 and 2022, when they persisted with extremely low interest rates and asset purchases.

images.alt_text: Inflation is falling in most places but at different speeds, leaving policymakers a variety of challenges.
The ECB’s most recent forecasts put it at 2.2 per cent in 2025.

site_title: Ten highlights from the 2023 French Open
summary: The 2023 French Open concluded with Novak Djokovic and Iga Swiatek being crowned champions. The tournament featured geopolitics and controversies, including a backlash against Ukraine's Marta Kostyuk for refusing to shake hands with Belarus' Aryna Sabalenka. Djokovic sparked controversy with a message on his television lens, while Daniel Altmaier's marathon match against Jannik Sinner set a record. Iga Swiatek won her second consecutive French Open title, while Novak Djokovic claimed a record-breaking 23rd Grand Slam title. The tournament also saw notable performances from Taylor Fritz and Miyu Kato, who found redemption after being involved in a doubles controversy.

site_title: UBS completes Credit Suisse takeover to create bank titan
summary: UBS completed its acquisition of Credit Suisse Group, creating a global wealth-management titan. The deal, valued at $13.3 billion, marks the biggest merger in banking since the 2008 financial crisis and ends Credit Suisse's 167-year independent existence. UBS will integrate Credit Suisse's business, including clients and loan exposures, and plans to cut risk at the investment bank. The Swiss government has agreed to cover losses on a specific portfolio of Credit Suisse assets, with UBS also planning to impose its own risk tolerance and restrictions for clients. Thousands of job cuts are expected as the two companies undergo integration.

images.alt_text: UBS has come up with a list of nearly two dozen “red lines” that prohibit Credit Suisse staff from a range of activities.

site_title: Learning lessons from HBO’s Succession series in creating multi-generational wealth
summary: Wealthy families can learn from HBO's Succession series on creating sustainable multi-generational wealth by prioritizing trust, transparency, and positive family dynamics. Establishing a culture of trust and open communication can build a solid foundation for long-term prosperity. Families should also define their purpose of capital, aligning financial decisions with core values, and nurture positive family dynamics. Implementing an oversight board and introducing a governance policy can help safeguard wealth and reputation. By learning from the Roy family's successes and failures, today's inheritors can create a stronger, more sustainable legacy.

images.alt_text: Singapore's variable capital company framework has been hailed as a game-changer as it offers tax efficiency and flexibility in fund vehicles and investments. DBS's multi-family office service leverages on the VCC framework.

Robert Weeber, AlTi president (international wealth management); Anthonia Hui and Leonardo Drago, co-founders of AL Wealth Partners. The merger is expected to open up new opportunities for families in areas like impact capital.

site_title: No pause in sight as ECB eyes next rate hike
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to deliver another interest rate hike on June 15, with analysts predicting a 25 basis point increase to take the deposit rate to 3.50%. The move aims to combat inflation, which slowed to 6.1% year-on-year in May, but remains above the ECB's 2% target. The eurozone has technically entered a recession, with two consecutive quarters of contraction, and policymakers stress the need to continue tightening monetary policy to bring inflation under control.

images.alt_text: epa10410721 Commuters make their way to work in London, Britain, 17 January 2023. According to the Office for National Statistics (ONS), UK wages have grown at their fastest rate for twenty years. Real wages however have fallen by some 3.8 percent as pay failed to keep up with inflation.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN
Inflation is falling in most places but at different speeds, leaving policymakers a variety of challenges.

site_title: Georg Fischer offers to buy Uponor for 2.1 billion euros
summary: Swiss industrial company Georg Fischer has made an offer to acquire Finnish plumbing-equipment manufacturer Uponor for 2.1 billion euros, representing a 12% premium over a rejected offer by Belgium's Aliaxis. The offer, valued at 28.85 euros per share, has been recommended by Uponor's board of directors and secured financing through existing cash and bank facilities. The deal would give Georg Fischer control of more than 50% of Uponor's shares, which are currently held by 36.9% of shareholders.

site_title: Swiss federal administration under cyberattack: ministry
summary: Switzerland's federal administration was hit by a distributed denial of service (DDoS) cyberattack on Monday, blocking access to several government websites and state-linked companies. The attack, attributed to the "NoName" group, was similar to a recent attack on the Swiss parliament. The government said it was taking measures to restore accessibility and that no data was lost in the attack. The National Cyber Security Centre is analyzing the incident along with affected units.

images.alt_text: To fully leverage AI for cybersecurity, machine learning, natural language processing and other AI tools have to be integrated into a defence strategy.

site_title: Sim Leisure to refurbish Sentosa’s KidZania for S$3 million, expects reopening in Q1 2024
summary: Sim Leisure has secured a 5-year lease agreement with Sentosa Development Corporation to refurbish KidZania for S$3 million. The revamped attraction is expected to reopen in Q1 2024, featuring new design, theming, and role-play activities, as well as a toddler-exclusive area and adult events lounge. The refurbishment will be funded partly by third-party sponsors, with the company expecting a positive contribution to its operations.

images.alt_text: Monthly passenger volume at Marina Bay Cruise Centre Singapore has already recovered beyond pre-pandemic levels.
Sunway Theme Parks, which owns and operates Sunway Lagoon, is confident to achieve a 90 per cent recovery in revenue by the end of this year.

site_title: HDB to double interim rental flats for families to 4,000 units over next two years
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore plans to double the number of interim rental flats for families waiting for their new homes to 4,000 units over the next two years. Currently, there are 2,000 units available. Eligible applicants must have a monthly household income of S$7,000 or below and have an uncompleted flat from HDB's sales exercises. The move aims to alleviate pressure on the rental market and provide more subsidized housing options.

images.alt_text: Singapore property
Resale prices rise at a moderate pace of 0.3 per cent in May.
The Singapore Turf Club's current site in Kranji will be returned to the government by March 2027 to make way for housing and other developments in the area.

site_title: India needs to restore faith in the ‘world’s pharmacy’
summary: India's pharmaceutical sector, known as the "world's pharmacy," faces significant challenges in restoring trust in its products due to numerous cases of negligence and deliberate ignoring of warnings. Investigations have linked Indian-made medicines to multiple deaths globally, including children in Africa and Central Asia. The US FDA has sent out dozens of notices to Indian pharmaceutical companies, and the Pentagon is independently testing medicines meant for US soldiers. Consolidating regulators, making inspection records public, and implementing stricter testing for generics manufacturers are proposed solutions to address the issue and prevent further deaths and economic ripple effects.

images.alt_text: Indian doctors warn against cow dung as Covid cure
Temasek-backed PharmEasy's owner files for 62.5b rupee India IPO

site_title: Crypto stays shaky after US SEC crackdown led to weekend selloff
summary: Cryptocurrencies fell on Monday, staying above weekend lows, after the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) launched lawsuits against market leaders Binance Holdings and Coinbase Global, flagging altcoins like SOL and ADA as unregistered securities. Bitcoin dropped 1.2% to $25,811, while Solana's SOL slipped 4.6% and Binance Coin dropped 7%. Sentiment remains shaky due to regulatory uncertainty, with thin volumes and market makers pulling out funds.

images.alt_text: Mainstream US banks have become warier of processing wire transfers and holding deposits for the crypto industry, following last year’s turmoil and amid growing regulatory scrutiny.
The purportedly independent American affiliate of Binance says its banking partners are preparing to stop US dollar withdrawal channels as early as Jun 13.

site_title: Temasek-backed firms buy stake in Viva Biotech unit ahead of listing
summary: Temasek-backed firms, Daxue Investments and True Light P, have agreed to invest 1.06 billion yuan (S$199.4 million) in Viva Biotech Holdings' unit, Viva Shanghai, ahead of its planned listing. The deal will dilute Viva Biotech's stake to 75.79% from 100%. The funds will be used to redeem convertible bonds and settle outstanding liabilities. The restructuring plan also involves transferring assets and personnel to Viva Shanghai, with investors expecting the listing application to be filed by June 30, 2024.

images.alt_text: The hacker house will run both online and offline and consists of developer quests, hackathons and meetups in cities around the world, including in Singapore.

Former FTX chief executive Sam Bankman-Fried, who faces fraud charges over the collapse of the bankrupt cryptocurrency exchange, departs from his court hearing at Manhattan federal court in New York City, US, Jan 3, 2023. Temasek wrote down its US$275 million investment in FTX last year after the crypto company’s meltdown
One way Temasek manages risk is by diversification, with about half of its early-stage investments spread across 200 companies, including FTX.

site_title: Analysts positive on outlook of FBM KLCI heavyweights despite sluggish Q1 performance
summary: Analysts remain optimistic about the outlook of FBM KLCI heavyweights despite a sluggish Q1 performance, with earnings declining 35% quarter-on-quarter and 3% year-on-year to RM15.8 billion. Global headwinds, softening commodity prices, and political uncertainty are attributed to the underwhelming performance. However, analysts expect corporate earnings to improve after Malaysia concludes state elections by August, with some sectors like banks and utilities showing double-digit core earnings growth. Maybank and MIDF Research have adjusted their year-end KLCI targets, with Maybank reducing its target to 1,520 points and MIDF Research maintaining its target at 1,590 points.

images.alt_text: We expect Anwar Ibrahim's (centre) new government to be more people-oriented, pushing for more targeted subsidies to help low-income groups, while maintaining or revising some of the key initiatives proposed in the previous Budget 2023.

site_title: Novartis to buy Chinook for up to US$3.5 billion
summary: Novartis agreed to acquire Seattle-based biotech firm Chinook Therapeutics for up to $3.5 billion, bolstering its late-stage drug development line-up. Chinook shareholders will receive $3.2 billion in cash plus a contingent value right worth up to $300 million, depending on regulatory achievements. The deal aims to develop treatments for a rare severe kidney disease, with a clinical trial expected to read out in the fourth quarter of this year. The acquisition is expected to close in the second half of 2023.

site_title: Glencore makes offer for Teck's steelmaking coal business
summary: Glencore has offered to buy Teck Resources' steelmaking coal business as a standalone unit, following a second rejection of a proposed merger. The Swiss mining company had initially offered $22.5 billion, but the deal was twice rebuffed. Glencore, which mines and trades thermal coal, would demerge the coal units of both companies if the deal is successful. The offer is considered a "distant second" to Glencore's merger plans.

site_title: DBS launches multi-family office VCC for ultra-wealthy families
summary: DBS Private Bank has launched a multi-family office (MFO) service leveraging Singapore's variable capital company (VCC) framework. The DBS MFO, called DBS Multi Family Office Foundry VCC, offers tax efficiency, flexibility, and in-house fund administration and custody, providing stability and safety for ultra-wealthy families. The minimum wealth requirement is around S$15 million, and the bank has received positive feedback from clients. DBS already serves as banker to over a third of Singapore's single family offices and has seen its family office assets under management more than double in the last two years.

images.alt_text: Singapore sees jump in family offices as Asia's ultra-rich set up camp
Family offices are a booming business, but present challenges
The super rich are choosing Singapore as the world's safest haven

site_title: Buying a condo? Check if there are enough car park spaces
summary: In Singapore, buyers of uncompleted new homes may face challenges in securing car park spaces, as many developments sell off-plan with limited parking provisions. With rising costs and labor, some condominiums may consider charging for car park usage or selling individual spaces to generate revenue. This trend may be influenced by Singapore's car-lite initiative and increasing demand for more pedestrian-friendly areas. As a result, savvy buyers will need to carefully consider car park space provisions when purchasing a new home, potentially leading to a shift in how condominiums manage parking facilities.

images.alt_text: With high interest rates, developers may benefit from buyers choosing new homes sold off-plan because of the progressive payment scheme.

site_title: Gold ticks lower on firmer dollar, central bank meetings in focus
summary: Gold prices edged lower in early Asian trade on Monday, down 0.1% to $1,957.92 per ounce, amid a firmer dollar and investors' anticipation of central bank policy meetings this week, potentially marking a pause in US interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Higher interest rates dull the appeal for zero-yield bullion.

site_title: Cortina reminds customers affected by data breach to be alert to scams, phishing attacks
summary: Luxury watch retailer Cortina has reminded customers affected by a recent data breach to be cautious of scams and phishing attacks. The breach, which occurred on June 4, resulted in over 7 GB of data being uploaded to a file-sharing site, including customer information, sales tactics, and staff account credentials. Cortina declined to disclose the number of affected customers, but advised customers to obtain information from reliable sources. The company's website remains down, and shares ended the week flat.

images.alt_text: Cortina first disclosed the cybersecurity incident in a bourse filing late Tuesday (Jun 6).

site_title: Japan’s wholesale inflation eases, goods close to consumers continue to rise
summary: Japan's wholesale inflation eased for the fifth consecutive month in May due to declining fuel and commodity prices. The core consumer inflation rate remained at 3.4% in April, despite a slowdown in corporate goods price index to 5.1% in May. This suggests cost-push pressure on consumer inflation may be subsiding. The Bank of Japan is expected to maintain its ultra-loose policy, predicting a moderate economic recovery.

images.alt_text: Sushi with shrimp is served on a conveyor belt at sushi chain “Kura Sushi” in Tokyo, Japan, March 13, 2023. The Japanese conveyor belt sushi chain said on Monday that they started using an artificial intelligence camera system early this month to catch unhygienic pranks after a video of a man licking a soy sauce bottle filmed at one of their restaurants in central Japan went viral online. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon

The skylines of Tokyo and Ichikawa during the evening hour in Ichikawa city, Chiba prefecture, east of Tokyo on June 7, 2023. The country’s power market is predicted to be less tight this summer in most of the regions than last summer when the government asked for energy conservation across the nation, according to the industry ministry’s forecast in May.

site_title: Apac limited partners expect more down rounds in venture capital portfolios: report
summary: Limited partners in the Asia-Pacific region expect more down rounds in venture capital portfolios over the next 12 months, with 75% anticipating this trend. Despite this, 70% of LPs believe it will be a strong vintage year for private equity in their region. LPs are optimistic about investments in healthcare, IT, and renewable energy, with 87%, 75%, and 69% respectively viewing these sectors as attractive. Only 21% view the consumer sector as an opportunity for private equity investment, and LPs are concerned about the level of debt in buyout deals.

images.alt_text: Hedge funds, private equity lure billions from rich Asians
FILE PHOTO: Trading information for KKR & Co is displayed on a screen on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., August 23, 2018. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo
Notably, more than half of LPs saw more than 16 per cent in net returns from their Asia-Pacific venture investments.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank positive on Sembcorp’s  renewable acquisitions, raises target price to S$6
summary: Maybank Research has raised its target price on Sembcorp Industries to S$6.00 from S$4.35, citing optimism over the group's earnings prospects and recent renewable acquisitions in the Middle East, including a S$400 million contract. This represents a 10% discount to regional utilities companies trading at 13 times price-to-earnings ratio. The research house maintains a "buy" call on the stock.

images.alt_text: Construction of the centre is expected to commence in the second half of this year, and be fully operational by 2026.
Reuters had reported in May that HSBC was hired to run the sale of the unit.
Singapore's liquefied natural gas terminal at Jurong Island. Sembcorp Gas has agreed to import natural gas piped from the West Natuna gas fields in Indonesia at an estimated value of S$1.9 billion.

site_title: Andreessen Horowitz to open its first international office in London
summary: US venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz will open its first international office in London, following months of talks with British authorities. The London office, set to open later this year, will support blockchain technologies and startups, led by general partner Sriram Krishnan. The move comes as the US Securities and Exchange Commission cracks down on the cryptocurrency sector, with recent lawsuits against Coinbase and Binance. The office will work with UK universities, expanding Andreessen's presence in the UK.

site_title: Westpac to layoff 300 workers in business and retail unit, says trade union
summary: Westpac Banking is set to lay off approximately 300 workers in its consumer and business banking segments, representing 0.8% of its total workforce. The layoffs come as the bank experiences strong profit growth amid rising interest rates and inflation. The move has been criticized by the Finance Sector Union of Australia, which claims the cuts will exacerbate existing workload demands. Westpac has not commented on the layoffs, citing a public holiday.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An advertising sign for a new housing development area is seen with the Melbourne skyline in the distance May 5, 2009. REUTERS/Mick Tsikas/File Photo
Westpac disclosed plans to move away from an absolute expense target and to focus more on improving its expense-to-income ratio in comparison to its peers.

site_title: Asia: Traders tread cautiously ahead of US Fed rate decision
summary: Asian markets traded cautiously on Monday ahead of the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, with Tokyo, Singapore, and Taipei rising, while Hong Kong, Shanghai, Seoul, Jakarta, and Wellington fell. Positive job data and hopes of the Fed standing pat in June have fueled a strong month for global markets. Investors are waiting for the US inflation data and interest rate decision, which may impact the market's outlook.

images.alt_text: In early Asian trade on Friday, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Tokyo, Seoul, Sydney, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta were all in positive territory.

site_title: Saudi Aramco to supply full oil volumes to some Asian refiners in July: sources
summary: Saudi Aramco will supply full volumes of crude oil to some Asian refiners in July, despite plans to cut production to 9 million barrels per day. The move comes after the company raised its official selling prices for July-loading cargoes, potentially hurting refining profits. Saudi Aramco has pledged to maintain China's July crude intake around the same level as June, despite some Chinese state-owned refiners requesting lower supply. The decision aims to meet demand from other refiners who have asked for more supply due to a low base in June.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Saudi Aramco logo is pictured at the oil facility in Abqaiq, Saudi Arabia October 12, 2019. REUTERS/Maxim Shemetov/File Photo

site_title: UBS to impose restrictions on Credit Suisse bankers after takeover complete: FT
summary: UBS will impose restrictions on Credit Suisse bankers after the takeover is complete, including a ban on clients from high-risk countries and complex financial products. UBS has created a list of nearly 24 "red lines" that prohibit staff from certain activities. The Swiss government has also agreed to guarantee up to $13.39 billion of losses UBS may incur from selling Credit Suisse's assets. The restrictions aim to prevent money laundering and ensure compliance with regulatory requirements.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH upgrades Marco Polo Marine to ‘buy’ on improved financials
summary: UOB Kay Hian upgraded its call on Marco Polo Marine to "buy" with a target price of S$0.060, citing improved financials and higher charter rates. The research house raised its FY2023 to FY2025 revenue forecasts by 41 to 55% and increased net profit estimates by 2% and 15%, respectively. Analysts highlighted the company's strong cash position and expansion efforts in the offshore wind-farm sector.

images.alt_text: Marco Polo Marine's revenue for the half year more than doubled to S$55.9 million, from S$27.6 million the previous year.

site_title: EMA looking to build new power plant on Jurong Island
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) is planning to build a new thermal power station on Jurong Island, with two plots of land identified for the potential project. The power plant will utilize H-class combined-cycle gas turbines (CCGTs), the most efficient thermal generation units available, and must adhere to stricter emission intensity limits and be designed for future hydrogen fuel use. The project aims to meet growing electricity demand and maintain a secure power system, with peak power system demand expected to reach 10.1 GW by 2028.

images.alt_text: Jurong island
Singapore government to build power generation capacity if tenders draw insufficient interest

site_title: Applications for Singapore’s next presidential election open on Jun 13
summary: Applications for Singapore's next presidential election open on June 13, 2023, allowing prospective candidates to apply for a Certificate of Eligibility and submit community declarations. Candidates must meet public or private sector service requirements, including three years of public service or $500 million in shareholders' equity for private sector service. The election is open to candidates of all races, with the next election potentially held anytime from June 13, 2023. Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam and George Goh have announced their bids, following President Halimah Yacob's term expiration on September 13, 2023.

images.alt_text: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam and Jurong GRC MPs (from left) Shawn Huang, Rahayu Mahzam and Xie Yao Quan at the opening of ActiveSG Sport Village @ Jurong Town on Sunday; Tharman says: "Having a contest is important for me. I much rather win or lose with the contest. My whole approach is not to shy away from competition, it has always been that way. It’s how I prove myself."
Under the Constitution, the Singapore government can tap on past reserves only with the president’s approval.

Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam will resign from the People's Action Party and step down from his Cabinet positions on Jul 7 to fulfil his official commitments in Singapore and internationally.
Incumbent President Halimah Yacob has announced that she will not be seeking a second term at the next presidential election.。

site_title: China’s Nio cuts prices, ends free battery swapping as sales slide
summary: China's Nio cuts prices for all models by 30,000 yuan (S$5,646) starting June 12, amid mounting pressure on profitability due to lukewarm sales. The company will also end free battery swapping services to new buyers, after offering them for free four times a month to existing owners. Nio's investments in battery swapping stations have been questioned by investors, contributing to a net loss of 4.7 billion yuan in the first quarter. The move aims to boost sales and profitability amid a price war in China and weakening demand.

images.alt_text: People visit a Nio booth during the 20th Shanghai International Automobile Industry Exhibition in Shanghai on April 18, 2023.

Firms such as Nio and Li Auto managed to enter China's electric vehicle industry by partnering original equipment manufacturers or through mergers, but regulators may tighten rules to remove such possibilities.

site_title: Singapore tourist arrivals slip in May, but remain at over a million
summary: Singapore's international visitor arrivals exceeded 1 million in May for the third consecutive month, but slipped to 1.11 million from April's post-pandemic high of 1.13 million. Despite this, visitor arrivals remain more than 2.5 times higher than in May 2022. Indonesia remained the top source of visitors, followed by India, Malaysia, and China. Experts attribute the decline to seasonal effects and dissipated post-public holiday travel demand, but expect visitor arrivals to meet the Singapore Tourism Board's full-year prediction of 12-14 million.

images.alt_text: On the year, hotels' average room rate is up 32.8 per cent on the year.
Indonesia is the top source of tourists in April, with Malaysia, India, Australia and China rounding out the top five.
Olympic Esports Week will mark several firsts – not just for Singapore, but also for the esports world. The event bears similarities with the Olympic Games, but players will compete virtually.

site_title: MAS launches AI-focused fintech challenge, 20 finalists to receive S$20,000 each
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched a fintech challenge focusing on Artificial Intelligence (AI) solutions to transform the financial services industry. Interested participants can submit innovative solutions to address 16 problem statements, with up to 20 finalists receiving S$20,000 each. The challenge aims to discover reliable AI solutions that meet four key characteristics: interoperability, inclusivity, affordability, and fairness. The application deadline is July 18, with three winners receiving S$50,000 in prize money and the opportunity to apply for a further grant of up to S$500,000.

images.alt_text: “This is a true statue created by five different masters that would never have been able to collaborate in real life,” says Pauliina Lunde, a spokeswoman for Swedish machine engineering group Sandvik.
Closeup of woman holding color paper shopping bag at street. Summer sale and Black Friday shopping concept. Vintage tone film in cover size photo.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Cromwell European Reit, Nio, LHN, Cortina, CFM Holdings
summary: Cromwell European Reit's manager is in advanced talks to sell its Milan office asset for nearly US$144.7 million. Nio reported a net loss of US$700 million in Q1 2023, with vehicle sales falling 37.5% from Q4 2022. LHN Logistics may generate S$32 million in cash proceeds if an offer to buy its indirect 84.05% stake goes through. Cortina Watch's data breach has led to a threat to release customer information online. CFM Holdings has not quantified the impact of Panasonic's Malaysia operations cessation on its business.

site_title: Singapore business confidence hits two-year low for Q3 2023: SCCB
summary: Singapore's business confidence has hit a two-year low for Q3 2023, with the SCCB Business Optimism Index falling to +3.98 percentage points, down from +5.10 percentage points in Q3 2022. The downtrend is attributed to worsening outlooks in the manufacturing and wholesale sectors, amid global financial conditions, geopolitical developments, and sluggish demand from China.

images.alt_text: Selling prices is the only one of all six indicators to improve a quarter-on-quarter for Q2 2023.

site_title: Qatar’s top dealmakers get ready for a spending power boost
summary: Qatar's sovereign wealth fund, Qatar Investment Authority (QIA), is preparing to increase spending in new sectors such as technology and healthcare as the country's economy recovers from the World Cup expenses. QIA's CEO Mansoor Ebrahim Al-Mahmoud stated that the fund will focus on investments in Asia and the US, particularly in climate change, infrastructure, and digitization. With a budget of $450 billion, QIA aims to expand its reach beyond traditional European markets and capitalize on the growing demand for its natural resources.

images.alt_text: PIF will acquire a 75 per cent stake in Riyadh-based club Al-Hilal, which is reportedly interested in signing Argentina’s Lionel Messi for as much as US$400 million a year.

site_title: Several Chinese lenders cut yuan deposit rates from Monday
summary: Chinese commercial banks cut interest rates on yuan deposits, following state lenders, to ease pressure on profit margins and support the real economy. The cuts, implemented on Monday, include reductions of 5 basis points for demand deposits and 10-15 basis points for time deposits. Analysts expect further cuts by the central bank, potentially lowering the reserve requirement ratio, to expand credit and boost investment spending amid China's slowing economy. The People's Bank of China will enhance "counter-cyclical" policy adjustments to support the real economy.

images.alt_text: People's Bank of China (PBOC) governor Yi Gang says he has confidence the official growth target of around 5 per cent can be achieved this year.

China's producer price index for May fell for an eighth consecutive month, down 4.6 per cent, the National Bureau of Statistics said. That was the fastest decline since February 2016 and bigger than the 4.3 per cent fall in a Reuters poll.

site_title: Downturn in ESG funds may reverse in the next few quarters: MSCI CEO
summary: MSCI CEO Henry Fernandez predicts a potential reversal of the downturn in Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) funds in the next few quarters. This comes as technology companies, which are over-allocated in ESG funds, begin to outperform energy stocks. Despite this, macroeconomic uncertainty due to rising inflation and interest-rate hikes may continue to impact ESG funds. Fernandez expects climate risk to drive a significant repricing of assets and reallocation of capital, leading to increased demand for climate tools and ESG products.

images.alt_text: ESG funds, including both unit trust funds and exchange-traded funds, have grown into a US$400 billion market in the US alone.
The extent to which ESG investment strategies deliver better returns than their conventional equivalents remains a topic of debate.
Clients had voiced concerns about “an upward drift in ratings across the fund universe,” which is now being addressed, according to MSCI ESG Research.

site_title: ‘Incredible’ as history-making Djokovic wins record 23rd Grand Slam title
summary: Novak Djokovic won a record-breaking 23rd men's Grand Slam title, defeating Casper Ruud in the French Open final. Djokovic, 36, is now the first man to win all four majors at least three times and is halfway to the first calendar Grand Slam since Rod Laver in 1969. The win cements his case as the greatest player of all time, surpassing Margaret Court and Serena Williams' 23 titles. Djokovic plans to continue his historic run, targeting Wimbledon and a potential 24th Grand Slam title.

images.alt_text: Djokovic ended the contest with a sizzling service return on his first match point.

(FILES) France's Yannick Noah (L) shakes hands with Sweden's Mats Wilander (R) while stepping over the net, after victory in their men's singles final match of The Roland Garros 1983 French Open tennis tournament in Paris on June 5, 1983. It's been 40 years since a French player last won the men's singles title at Roland Garros and Yannick Noah's 1983 achievement is unlikely to be matched this year when the second major of the season starts on May 28, 2023. (Photo by DOMINIQUE FAGET / AFP)
“Lajovic played well. On the other hand, I played much worse than I wanted to,” Djokovic told reporters after the defeat in Banja Luka, Bosnia and Herzegovina.

site_title: Pakistan PM says first discounted Russian crude oil cargo arrives in Karachi
summary: Pakistan Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif announced that the first discounted Russian crude oil cargo has arrived in Karachi, marking a new relationship between Pakistan and Russia. The cargo, part of a deal struck in April, offers relief to Pakistan, which faces a payments crisis and is at risk of defaulting on its debt. This is Russia's first oil cargo to Pakistan, adding to Moscow's growing sales to India and China, as it redirects oil from Western markets due to the Ukraine conflict.

images.alt_text: Pakistan Finance Minister Ishaq Dar said the government will engage in negotiations on its bilateral debt, but doesn’t plan to ask creditors to take major reductions on principal.
The economic crisis comes as the country is also facing political stress, with former premier Imran Khan and his supporters clashing with the powerful army, a traditional power base in Pakistan.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Monday; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.3% to 3,197.42, as US equities ended the week higher on expectations of paused interest rate hikes. Gainers outnumbered losers 75 to 34 across the broader market, with Seatrium gaining 0.8% and DBS rising 0.9%. The top traded counter was Seatrium, with 12.8 million shares changing hands, while Thai Beverage's share price dropped 0.9%.

images.alt_text: Cromwell European Reit's manager revealed it is in advanced talks to sell its office asset in Milan, Italy.

site_title: Goldman expects ‘L-shaped’ recovery in China’s property market
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts a 'L-shaped' recovery in China's property market, which has avoided a collapse despite three years of Covid restrictions. The sector is expected to experience a multi-year slowdown due to falling demographic demand, policy shifts, and weaker housing affordability. Analysts led by Wang Lisheng expect credit easing and mortgage rate reductions, but not a government-led 'up-cycle'. The goal is to reduce the economy's reliance on the property sector and promote public housing and property taxes.

images.alt_text: The People’s Bank of China will enhance “counter-cyclical” policy adjustments to fully support the real economy.
Xtra's UHNW Chinese clients favour brands like Tom Dixon, whose Melt modern lights are pictured here.
Ronshine said it will actively engage with its creditors and seek a solution to the latest debt.

site_title: UK must seize opportunities of AI to remain a tech capital: PM Sunak
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is urging tech leaders to seize the opportunities of artificial intelligence (AI) to remain a tech capital. He emphasizes the need for balancing innovation with mitigating potential negative consequences. Sunak aims to make the UK a global leader in AI safety regulation, hosting a global summit later this year. The government will work with businesses to capitalize on AI opportunities while ensuring safe development.

images.alt_text: Many Britons reaching the end of their current fixed home loans are forced to accept higher rates with far bigger monthly repayments.

epa10410721 Commuters make their way to work in London, Britain, 17 January 2023. According to the Office for National Statistics (ONS), UK wages have grown at their fastest rate for twenty years. Real wages however have fallen by some 3.8 percent as pay failed to keep up with inflation.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: FTX customer names will not be revealed by bankruptcy court
summary: US bankruptcy judge John Dorsey has allowed FTX to permanently redact the names of its 9 million individual customers from its bankruptcy filings, citing concerns over potential scams and identity theft. The judge also authorized the removal of company and institutional investor names from customer lists on a temporary basis. Dorsey denied a request from Bahamian liquidators to begin litigation in Bahamas courts, citing the need for cooperation between US and Bahamian courts. The decision aims to protect FTX customers from potential risks.

images.alt_text: Former FTX chief executive Sam Bankman-Fried, who faces fraud charges over the collapse of the bankrupt cryptocurrency exchange, departs from his court hearing at Manhattan federal court in New York City, US, Jan 3, 2023. Temasek wrote down its US$275 million investment in FTX last year after the crypto company’s meltdown

Federal prosecutors in Manhattan said Sam Bankman-Fried stole billions of dollars in FTX customer funds to plug losses at Alameda, buy real estate, and make political contributions through an illegal straw-donor scheme. They have also charged him with bribing Chinese officials.

site_title: World Bank must drive private investment in climate transition: Banga
summary: World Bank President Ajay Banga emphasizes the need for "informed risk-taking" to encourage private investment in addressing climate change in developing countries. He aims to free up tens of billions of dollars to support a just energy transition, but notes that trillions of dollars are needed. Banga believes private sector capital is critical, as governments and multilateral development banks cannot suffice. He plans to work with other lenders and organizations to maximize the bank's impact, calling for collaboration to avoid silos in addressing the issue.

images.alt_text: FILE — Shipping containers stacked high on docks are sorted and unloaded onto trucks at the Port of Los Angeles in San Pedro, California, March 23, 2022.
