(Photo by Tony KARUMBA / AFP)

site_title: Malaysia woos Microsoft, Google to bolster data hub ambitions
summary: Malaysia is seeking to attract tech giants Microsoft and Google to bolster its data hub ambitions amid rising US-China tensions. The country has already attracted companies like Tesla and Amazon Web Services (AWS) with investments totaling RM25.5 billion. Malaysia aims to establish itself as a neutral supply chain base, positioning itself as an alternative to China. With 13% of global demand for chip testing and packaging, Malaysia is vying with other South-east Asian countries for investments to build new supply chains.

images.alt_text: Abdul Rasheed, a career central banker who joined BNM in 1988, was appointed for a five-year term effective July 1.
The Hari Raya celebration in April is one of the reasons that causes declining factory output of the month.

site_title: China’s installed non-fossil fuel electricity capacity exceeds 50% of total
summary: China has surpassed its 2021 target, with non-fossil fuel electricity capacity exceeding 50% of total installed capacity, according to the National Reform and Development Commission. By the end of 2022, China's installed power generation capacity was 2,564.05 GW, with wind and solar power accounting for 50.9% of the total. However, China's energy mix remains weighted towards fossil fuels, with coal accounting for 56.2% of total energy consumption. The country aims to peak carbon emissions before 2030, but inconsistent utilization of renewable resources remains a challenge.

site_title: British supermarket Waitrose cuts prices on 200 products
summary: British supermarket Waitrose reduced prices on over 200 products as part of a £100 million plan to combat high inflation. The price cuts, which include items like butter, tomato ketchup, and golden caster sugar, aim to attract customers struggling with high inflation. This move follows a February price cut on over 300 own-brand products, which helped attract new customers. Waitrose aims to pass on savings to customers once food inflation drops, but faces competition from rivals like Tesco and Sainsbury's.

images.alt_text: Many Britons reaching the end of their current fixed home loans are forced to accept higher rates with far bigger monthly repayments.

site_title: ‘Decade of emerging markets’ may be about to regain traction
summary: Emerging markets are poised to regain traction, with yield-hungry investors flocking to Indonesian bonds after the central bank ended its tightening cycle earlier this year. Despite China's highly-touted reopening rally fizzling, developing-nation assets are expected to take off in the second half, driven by global interest rate peaks, Chinese authorities' growth support, and structural reforms in India. Morgan Stanley Investment Management had earlier flagged this as the decade of emerging markets, with HSBC Asset Management's Xavier Baraton predicting faster rate cuts in inflation-free countries like India.

images.alt_text: Stocks in Japan, India and Korea have beaten China peers more often than not since 2020.

site_title: UK forecasters see stronger growth and less risk of recession
summary: UK forecasters have revised their economic growth predictions, expecting the country to avoid a recession and instead experience slight growth in the first half of 2023. The Bank of England's latest report notes a reversal of its previous forecast for the longest period of contraction in modern history. Business leaders, however, remain concerned about the growth outlook, citing a lack of staff to fill vacancies and limiting the UK's growth potential. The Confederation of British Industry now forecasts 0.4% GDP growth in 2023 and 1.8% in 2024.

images.alt_text: Governments around the world are now trying to find a balance whereby they can assess and rein in some of the potential negative consequences of AI without stifling innovation.
Many Britons reaching the end of their current fixed home loans are forced to accept higher rates with far bigger monthly repayments.

site_title: US Fed will keep rates high thanks to inflation fuelled by corporate greed, investors say
summary: US investors believe keeping interest rates high is the best way to combat inflation fueled by corporate greed. A Bloomberg survey found 90% of respondents attribute inflation to companies raising prices beyond their costs since the pandemic. Most (67%) point to the retail sector as the most opportunistic in pricing, while energy comes in second. The majority (53%) expect profit margins to return to pre-pandemic levels, but many believe tighter monetary policy won't lead to prolonged sticky inflation, with most expecting inflation to return to 2% within two years.

images.alt_text: The energy department said contracts for the new solicitation of sour crude oil would be awarded by Jun 30.

site_title: Hong Kong economy to grow faster, Singapore to slow: survey
summary: Hong Kong's economy is expected to grow 4.6% in 2023, up from a previous estimate of 3.4%, driven by consumer spending and tourism. In contrast, Singapore's GDP is projected to expand 1.4%, down from 2% previously, due to weakening global demand. Economists raised Hong Kong's second-quarter growth forecast by 1.7 percentage points to 3.3%, while Singapore may enter a technical recession in the first half of 2023. Inflation expectations for both cities remain unchanged, with Hong Kong at 2.4% and Singapore at 5% for the full year.

site_title: Editors Talk: Journalism is no longer just writing (Ep 3)
summary: In a recent podcast conversation, associate editor Chan Cheow Pong of The Business Times discusses the changing roles in the modern newsroom, shifting from traditional journalism to a more inclusive concept of "audience." This entails considering various factors beyond traditional journalism skills, such as training in generative AI, and building a diverse talent pipeline. Cheow Pong emphasizes the need for education providers to adapt to these changes, rather than waiting for them to evolve.

images.alt_text: To cultivate these talents, media and journalism programmes in schools will need to make a culture shift towards developing audience-centric, product thinking mindsets and digital product management capabilities in students.
How podcasts’ unrealised potential is limitless.

site_title:
EURUSD poised for further upside 
within rising wedge
summary: The EURUSD is poised for further upside due to a recent bounce off the lower band of a rising wedge formation. The pair has rebounded strongly from a bottom of 0.9536 to a top of 1.1095 in April 2023, and is now hovering around 1.078. A rising wedge can be identified by two upward-sloping support and resistance trend lines, and the EURUSD has shown healthy bullish momentum with a reading above 50 on its Relative Strength Index. Technical targets are set at 1.093 and 1.115, with a potential bearish bias after achieving R2.

images.alt_text: The outlook on the Euro Stoxx 50 Futures contract is expected to be bearish, given the increasingly gloomy macroeconomic backdrop. Germany, the eurozone’s largest economy and an industrial powerhouse, is in the midst of a technical recession.

site_title: Billionaire George Soros hands control of empire to son Alex
summary: Billionaire George Soros, 92, is handing control of his $25 billion empire to his 37-year-old son Alexander, also known as Alex. Soros previously expressed hesitation about his children taking over his philanthropic Open Society Foundations, but now considers Alex "earned it." Alex plans to broaden the foundation's priorities to include voting rights, abortion, and gender equity, and will continue donating to left-leaning US political candidates. The OSF board elected Alex as chairman in December, and he now directs political activity as president of Soros' political action committee.

images.alt_text: George Soros, 92, has a net worth estimated at US$8.5 billion.

site_title: Sustainability, consumption, digitalisation to drive Asean deals, fundraising in H2: bankers
summary: South-east Asian companies in sustainability, consumer goods, and digitalisation are expected to drive capital market activity in the second half of 2023. Energy transition, digitalisation, consumption, and financial inclusion are four key themes that will drive growth in the region. Market players expect a strong focus on sustainability, energy transition, and technology, with increased competition and interest in mergers and acquisitions. Fundraising deals are expected to be triggered by refinancing, sustainability-led initiatives, and event-driven acquisitions, with volumes from local currency loan and bond markets.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong at the launch of NUS Sustainable and Green Finance Institute on Thursday (April 20) with Hsieh Fu Hua, chairman of NUS board of trustees, Professor Tan Eng Chye, NUS President and Professor Sumit Agarwal, managing director of the institute.

site_title: FDI flows to Asean double in past decade on region’s growth potential, supply chain diversification trends
summary: Foreign investment flows into the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) region have doubled in the past decade, with Singapore being the leading destination. Asean's growth potential, supply chain diversification, and post-pandemic manufacturing rebound have driven this growth. FDI flows are expected to continue, with the Asian Development Bank forecasting Asean's GDP to expand by 4.7% in 2023. The finance, insurance, manufacturing, wholesale, and retail trade industries are the top recipients of FDI, with Singapore, Malaysia, and Vietnam being key beneficiaries. The region's single market potential, driven by its large population and rising incomes, also attracts investors.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians in Tokyo's Ginza district, April 2023. Japan’s economy is finally breaking out of its decades-long deflationary mindset.

site_title: Singapore won’t fully benefit from expected lowering of green hydrogen production costs: experts
summary: Singapore is unlikely to fully benefit from the expected lowering of green hydrogen production costs, despite a Deloitte report predicting price parity with fossil-based hydrogen by 2035. The report highlights the need for overcoming challenges in transport, storage, and handling to make imported renewable fuel competitive. As Singapore aims to achieve net zero emissions by 2050, it is exploring hydrogen imports, with North Africa and Australia expected to be major export hubs.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange's weekly tanker and dry bulk market report for June 9, 2023, reveals mixed trends across various segments. The capesize market gained momentum with increased enquiry, but rates corrected slightly as the week progressed. In contrast, the Panamax market was relatively quiet, with rates fluctuating between firm and retracting bids. The ultramax and supramax sectors experienced poor sentiment, with rates kept in check by excess prompt tonnage. Handysize rates softened due to a lack of enquiry. The LR2 market saw a decline in freight levels and rates, while MRs were recorrected down. VLCC rates improved slightly, and Suezmax rates fell across the board. Aframax rates increased in the US market, while LNG and LPG rates showed some movement.

images.alt_text: A roundup of the week’s tanker and dry bulk market (Jun 2, 2023).

site_title: BT Mark to Market: Is Manulife US Reit a bargain? (Ep 32)
summary: Manulife US Reit is trading at a historical yield of 28% and a 70% discount to its book value, sparking debate over whether it's a bargain for investors. Senior correspondent Ben Paul analyzes market trends and corporate issues, suggesting the Reit could be a value trap. He recommends Manulife should emulate CapitaLand and Mapletree's strategies to revitalize the business. For long-term investors, the Reit could be a potential bargain, but a sale or recapitalization may be necessary to benefit investors.

images.alt_text: BT Mark to Market: Mapletree sets new standard for REIT sponsors (Ep 18)
Manulife US Reit's office properties have declined in value, and its gearing is bumping up against the statutory ceiling of 50 per cent

site_title: BT Explains: How a greater pivot towards domestic investments will impact Malaysia’s EPF
summary: Malaysia's Employees Provident Fund (EPF), the country's largest pension fund, is considering a pivot towards domestic investments to boost the economy. Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has called for EPF to increase domestic direct investments to 70% by the end of 2023, from 64% in 2022. This move aims to support Malaysia's capital markets, strategic industries, and infrastructure investments in the long term, potentially driving economic growth.

images.alt_text: Economists said extending the retirement age may be an inevitable option for low income groups in Malaysia to rebuild their retirement savings.

site_title: Airfares may stay sky-high, say industry experts
summary: High airfares may persist despite recent oil price falls due to factors such as limited airline seats and rising labour costs. Industry experts attribute the increase to the gradual return of demand for travel after the Covid-19 pandemic, coupled with the challenges of meeting growing passenger demand and covering rising costs. Fuel prices have eased, but labour costs and supply chain issues continue to affect airline profitability, with experts predicting costs may remain high until commercially viable solutions become available.

site_title: First coal phase-out projects under Indonesia’s JETP could commence by end of 2023
summary: Indonesia is on track to unveil its first concrete early coal phase-out projects under the Indonesia Just Energy Transition Partnership (JETP) by the end of 2023, with plans to come up with a comprehensive investment and policy plan by August. The $20 billion program aims to bring forward the closure of coal power plants and peak emissions date to 2030, but faces challenges including concerns over greenwashing, inability to produce carbon credits, and lack of financial support. Despite these hurdles, international pressure is on the program to succeed as a role model for energy transition, with experts calling for a comprehensive approach involving clear policy frameworks, financial incentives, and stakeholder engagement.

site_title: Prescriptive regulatory approach would unduly constrain BNPL providers: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has established a code for buy now, pay later (BNPL) providers to safeguard consumers from excessive borrowing risks. The code, which is industry-led and consistent with MAS' expectations, sets explicit requirements for providers. MAS argues that a prescriptive regulatory approach would unduly constrain BNPL providers and limit consumer choices. The code will be monitored, and non-compliant providers will face accreditation loss and reputational damage. MAS will reassess regulation if necessary, but for now, the code aims to strike a balance between consumer protection and industry flexibility.

images.alt_text: The new laws will impact consumer credit firms from Zip to Afterpay, which compete with banks to provide interest-free credit that is typically repaid in instalments.
BNPL providers in Singapore like Atome are signatories in an industry code rather than coming under the purview of MAS.

site_title: Gearing up to be a business catalyst
summary: The Philippine Chamber of Commerce in Singapore (PhilCham Singapore) marks its first year, focusing on insights, connections, and advocacy for businesses with interests in the Philippines. Founded by a tight-knit group of Filipino business leaders in Singapore, the chamber aims to deepen trade, investment, and industry growth between Singapore and the Philippines. It has launched webinars on key topics and plans to facilitate trade missions and support startups. PhilCham Singapore envisions itself as a catalyst for economic growth, advocating for favorable business conditions and fostering mutually beneficial relationships between the two nations.

images.alt_text: Philippine Ambassador to Singapore, Medardo G Macaraig, believes more opportunities will arise for Singapore investors in sectors they are already familiar with.

site_title: Saudi Arabia seeks cooperation with China, 'ignores' Western worries
summary: Saudi Arabia's energy minister, Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman, stated that the kingdom wants to collaborate, not compete, with China, despite Western concerns. The bilateral relationship has deepened in hydrocarbon, security, and sensitive tech ties, with the US expressing concern. Prince Abdulaziz ignored Western criticisms, saying, "I actually ignore it because... as a business person, now you will go where opportunity comes your way." This move aims to strengthen ties with China, a major energy consumer, and potentially shift Saudi Arabia's focus away from Western allies.

images.alt_text: A view shows oil pump jacks outside Almetyevsk in the Republic of Tatarstan, Russia June 4, 2023. REUTERS/Alexander Manzyuk

site_title: Aligned economic priorities usher in fresh investment opportunities
summary: Singapore investors are seeing fresh opportunities to enter the Philippines in areas such as consumer goods, infrastructure, and startups, with the two countries aligning economic priorities. The Philippines is Singapore's top source of foreign direct investment, with $2.4 billion in approved investment commitments in 2022. The countries have also strengthened trade and investment flows, with the Philippines being Singapore's seventh-largest trading partner. New Clark City, a 9,540-hectare greenfield development, is expected to attract Singapore investors, and the Philippine government is liberalizing sectors such as telecommunications and renewable energy to attract more foreign investment.

site_title: Singapore, Mongolia sign MOU to collaborate on carbon credits
summary: Singapore and Mongolia signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to collaborate on carbon credits, aiming to enhance cooperation on climate ambitions. The agreement will identify potential carbon projects that can yield credits, supporting both countries' goals under the Paris Agreement. An interagency working group will be established to implement the MOU, which is expected to precede a legally-binding agreement on the international transfer of correspondingly adjusted mitigation outcomes. The partnership underscores Singapore's commitment to advancing global climate action and ensuring the integrity of carbon markets.

images.alt_text: Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu (right) and Mongolia’s Minister for Environment and Tourism Bat-Erdene Bat-Ulzii (left) signing the Memorandum of Understanding between Singapore and Mongolia to enhance cooperation in carbon credits.

site_title: Paws and popcorn: Thai cinema goes pet-friendly
summary: Thailand has opened its first pet-friendly cinema, catering to the country's large pet industry, which is the second-largest in Asia. Dozens of four-legged film-goers attended the opening, including dogs and cats in costumes, with owners adjusting the sound and lighting for their comfort. The concept is based on child-friendly theatres and aims to address separation anxiety in pets. However, not all pet owners are thrilled about the idea, with some expressing concerns about animal welfare and the unnatural nature of the concept.

site_title: Proposal to internalise Sabana Reit’s manager transfers value from ESR Group to unitholders
summary: Quarz Capital has requisitioned an EGM for Sabana Industrial Reit to internalize its manager, Sabana Real Estate Investment Management, which is owned by ESR Group. The move aims to transfer value from ESR Group to Sabana Reit's unitholders, with potential cost savings of 7.2% in distributions per unit. Quarz criticizes Sabana Reit's operational performance, citing lower occupancy rates at higher-rent buildings, and offers a laundry list of improvements to boost performance. The proposal could mitigate potential conflicts of interest between ESR Group and the Reit's manager, as ESR Group's interests may conflict with those of the manager.

images.alt_text: Sabana Industrial Reit's NTP+ at 151 Lorong Chuan.

site_title: Is MBS trolling Biden? Or just defending Saudi interests?
summary: Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman (MBS) has taken several moves that may be seen as undermining US President Joe Biden, but these actions are driven by legitimate economic and strategic interests. MBS aims to maintain high oil prices to boost the Saudi economy and prepare for a future without oil. This strategy puts him at odds with Biden's desire for low oil prices, which would benefit the American consumer and hurt Russia. MBS has instead formed a merger between LIV Golf and the PGA Tour, and has improved relations with Iran and China, while maintaining ties with Israel and the US.

images.alt_text: A passionate golfer, Yasir Al Rumayyan is one of the most powerful financial professionals in the world. I
The announcement of the merger includes an agreement to end all pending litigation between the participating parties.

site_title: ‘I certainly much prefer a contest’, says Tharman of upcoming presidential election
summary: Singaporean Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam has expressed his preference for a contest in the upcoming presidential election, stating he "much rather win or lose with the contest." He also emphasized his approach to politics is not to shy away from competition, aiming to prove himself. Tharman, who has been a member of the People's Action Party for 22 years, will step down as senior minister and MP for Jurong GRC to run in the election, set for September 13.

images.alt_text: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam will resign from the People's Action Party and step down from his Cabinet positions on Jul 7 to fulfil his official commitments in Singapore and internationally.
Going by election results, Tharman is one of the most popular politicians around.

site_title: Opec+ working against ‘uncertainities and sentiment’, says Saudi minister
summary: Saudi Arabia's Energy Minister Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman announced a voluntary one million barrel per day cut for July as part of the Opec+ agreement. The deal, reached at a meeting in Vienna, aims to achieve market stability despite "uncertainities and sentiment" in the market. The agreement also lowers collective production targets for 2024 and extends voluntary cuts to the end of the year. The move is expected to reward investors who increase production capacity, with higher production allocations for those who do so.

images.alt_text: The two leaders also discussed bilateral cooperation, including measures to further increase trade and economic ties and joint projects.

site_title: There’s more trouble coming for regional banks
summary: US regional banks face increasing pressure as commercial property debt of nearly $1.5 trillion is due for repayment by 2025, amid declining office values and rising interest rates. Many smaller and regional banks have become heavily exposed to commercial real estate, exceeding the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp's guidelines. Some banks, like PacWest Bancorp, are already selling off portfolios to shore up liquidity. Experts warn that a credit contraction is inevitable, which could make it difficult for property developers and landlords to access credit, leading to further market instability.

images.alt_text: The Piazza Affari 2 in Milan, Italy. Cromwell European Reit had called it a trophy asset in the heart of Milan's central business district, being located opposite the Milan Stock Exchange.

site_title: S-Reits in STI and its reserve list gain 4% this year
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.6% in total returns for the year to date, slightly underperforming the iEdge S-Reit Index. Following the June quarterly review, FTSE Russell announced changes to the STI constituents, adding Seatrium and removing Keppel DC Reit. The STI reserve list now consists of six S-Reits, including Keppel DC Reit, which reported the best performance with 18.2% total returns.

images.alt_text: Dasin Retail Trust's Ocean Metro Mall. The Reit is one of the top performers for the month of May, posting a total return of 11.6 per cent.

site_title: Nanofilm makes ex-CEO of Dutch manufacturer its group chief commercial officer
summary: Nanofilm Technologies has appointed Ian Howe, former CEO of Dutch manufacturer Additive Industries, as its new group chief commercial officer. Howe will oversee the company's overall commercial strategy, including its advanced materials business unit and global industrial surface coatings operations. Gian Yi Hsen, who was redesignated as chief strategy officer, will focus on corporate strategies and merger and acquisition activities. The appointment is a recommendation by the company's nominating committee.

site_title: How to recover from a big career setback
summary: A significant career setback can be overwhelming, but it's possible to rebuild one's professional and personal life. Researcher Shelley Winner, who turned her life around in prison after a history of drug abuse, exemplifies this. Her journey involves five key aspects: architecture (structural underpinnings), culture (understanding the rules and values), power and influence (networks), identity (embracing inner strength), and guiding principles (mission). By applying these elements, individuals can tap into their inner strength and determination to reframe themselves and their circumstances, ultimately navigating setbacks with resilience and transforming their lives.

site_title: Rare Chinese Buddha statue up for auction at Bonhams in Paris
summary: A rare 1m-high Chinese Buddha statue, a 12th-13th century wood figure of the Buddhist Bodhisattva Guanyin, is up for auction at Bonhams in Paris on June 13. The piece, part of a set thought to have been lost, is expected to fetch 1 million euros. Only a handful of such pieces are believed to remain in the world, mostly in museums. The statue was last sold in the 1930s and has been in a French family home, where it was found in a private home, with no knowledge of its value.

images.alt_text: The contemporary and modern art galleries that show in the Swiss convention centre are broadly understood to be the best in the world, and the art those galleries bring is supposed to be the finest they have to offer.

site_title: SNB’s fight to tame inflation not yet done, says Swiss central bank chief
summary: Switzerland's central bank chief, Thomas Jordan, says the fight to tame inflation is not yet over, with inflation still too high and widespread price increases. He expects the SNB to hike interest rates again on June 22, citing the need to bring inflation below 2% in the long term. Jordan defended the central bank's rate hikes, stating that they are necessary to prevent inflation from accelerating further. He also emphasized the need for Swiss banks to monitor mortgages and the property market, but does not see the need for SNB action in this area.

images.alt_text: The quarterly decision on Thursday (Mar 23) by policymakers led by Thomas Jordan matches that of the European Central Bank, which raised by the same amount last week, and follows Wednesday’s move by the Federal Reserve to hike by a quarter point.

site_title: Scottish ex-leader Nicola Sturgeon arrested in finance probe
summary: Nicola Sturgeon, Scotland's former First Minister, was arrested on June 11, 2023, as part of a police investigation into the Scottish National Party's funding. The investigation is looking into the use of £600,000 raised by independence campaigners in 2017. Sturgeon's husband, Peter Murrell, and party treasurer Colin Beattie have also been arrested in the probe. Sturgeon's arrest caps a period of turmoil for the SNP and raises questions about her successor, Humza Yousaf's, ability to unite the party ahead of the next general election.

images.alt_text: “I’ve always been of the belief that no one individual should be dominant in any system for too long.” Scotland’s First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said.

site_title: Sunak faces new electoral headache after Johnson resigns
summary: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak faces a new electoral headache after Boris Johnson's surprise resignation from Parliament, which has triggered at least three by-elections that could expose softening support for the Conservative Party. Johnson called the resignation a "political hit job" after being investigated for allegedly misleading lawmakers over Covid-19 rule breaches. Three by-elections are now set to take place, including Sunak's own seat and those held by key Johnson allies Nadine Dorries and Nigel Adams, who have also resigned.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on May 9, 2022 Britain's then prime minister Boris Johnson looks up as he delivers a speech in front of 10 Downing Street in central London for the launching of the street market Downing street Spring Showcase. Johnson announced his resignation as an MP on June 9, 2023, accusing a parliamentary probe into the "Partygate" scandal of driving him out. Johnson, 58, said he was stepping down with immediate effect "triggering an immediate by-election" in his marginal seat, which heaps political pressure on his successor Rishi Sunak. (Photo by Ben Stansall / AFP)

site_title: US dollar gains before Fed meeting, inflation data
summary: The US dollar gained against other currencies on Friday before the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision next week, as investors awaited inflation data and clarity on the central bank's future rate hikes. The Fed is expected to hold rates steady, but remain hawkish and indicate a possible hike in July, with inflation remaining above the 2% target. The greenback's movement is largely rangebound, reflecting uncertainty about the economy's trajectory.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which measures the currency against six major peers, is down 0.19 per cent to 103.84.

site_title: LinkedIn bets on employers focusing on skills over degrees as future labour market currency
summary: LinkedIn is betting on a future where employers focus on an applicant's skills rather than degrees, as the platform builds artificial intelligence to make job matches more efficient. Despite 80% of employers believing skills-based hiring is preferable, more than half still prioritize college degrees due to perceived risk. LinkedIn's skills-matching feature has shown positive early signs, with 45% of recruiters using skills data to find candidates. The platform aims to address the lack of shared language and standard classification systems for skills, potentially aided by Microsoft's AI progress, to expand economic opportunity and hire a more diverse range of candidates.

site_title: Credit Suisse CEO memo signals UBS deal to close Monday
summary: Credit Suisse CEO Ulrich Koerner has indicated that the emergency takeover by UBS will close on Monday, marking the next step in the process. The Swiss government has agreed to guarantee up to $13.4 billion in losses for Credit Suisse, with UBS covering losses beyond $5 billion. This comes after UBS chief executive Sergio Ermotti hinted at a Monday close. The takeover is the result of Credit Suisse's financial struggles, and the bank's employees are awaiting answers as the process unfolds.

site_title: Drink with Messi for 300,000 yuan – Chinese police warn over scams
summary: Chinese police warn against scams surrounding Lionel Messi's visit to Beijing, including a promise of a dinner with the soccer star for 300,000 yuan, and unauthorized ticket resales. Other dubious offers include VIP packages and a shopping livestream appearance for 50 million yuan. Despite anti-scalping measures, tickets have sold out, with fans desperate to catch a glimpse of Messi, who will play a friendly match against Australia on June 15.

images.alt_text: This is the Argentina captain’s seventh visit to China and his first since 2017.

site_title: EU to try again for renewable energy deal after nuclear row
summary: The European Union will attempt to pass a deal on new renewable energy targets next week, following a last-minute opposition from countries like France that claim the law sidelines nuclear energy. The EU has struggled to reach a deal due to disagreements over nuclear energy, which has put on hold the bloc's plans to tackle climate change. Diplomats will meet on June 14 to approve the law, which aims to set more ambitious renewable energy goals.

site_title: Germany refuses Intel’s additional demand for subsidies for chip plant
summary: Germany's Finance Minister Christian Lindner is refusing Intel's demand for higher subsidies for a 17 billion euro chip plant, citing a lack of available funds to consolidate the budget. Intel was initially due to receive 6.8 billion euros in government support but is now demanding 10 billion euros due to increased energy and construction costs. Lindner stated that the country cannot afford the increased subsidies, instead opting to focus on consolidating the budget.

site_title: US forward Macario joins Chelsea on three-year deal
summary: US forward Catarina Macario has signed a three-year deal with Chelsea after spending two seasons in France with Olympique Lyonnais. Macario, 23, joins the Women's Super League winners following a standout college career at Stanford University. She will miss this year's World Cup due to an ongoing knee injury and aims to bring home the trophy for Chelsea, citing her European experience and winning mentality as key assets. Chelsea manager Emma Hayes praised Macario as "one of the most intelligent, creative attacking players in the world."

Challenger Technologies saw a 17.94% increase in shareholder stake after Digileap Capital acquired shares, bringing the stake to 17.94%. ComfortDelGro bought back 207,000 shares, and a Challenger shareholder raised their stake to 20.68%. These moves come amid a 0.6% gain in the Straits Times Index over the period.

site_title: Here’s a loophole that is causing completely preventable worker deaths in Singapore
summary: Singapore's workplace death toll has risen to 46 in 2022, the highest in years, prompting the Ministry of Manpower to call on employers to instill a strong safety culture and implement good safety practices. A loophole in the law allows workers to be placed at the back of lorries, increasing the risk of accidents and fatalities. Critics argue that this rule prioritizes business interests over worker safety, raising questions about the government's commitment to prioritizing workplace safety.

site_title: Spac-squared is Wall Street’s latest wheeze
summary: Wejo Group, a British connected-vehicle data company, is merging with TKB Critical Technologies I, a blank-cheque firm, to secure up to $100 million in cash. This unusual deal is a "re-Spac" as Wejo is already a publicly traded company. The move comes as Wejo faces financial pressures, including a cash balance that will expire soon and a history of burning through funds. TKB shareholders will receive $11.25 in value for their initial investment, and the deal is expected to take several months to close.

site_title: Taiwan’s GlobalWafers CEO Doris Hsu wins EY’s World Entrepreneur of the Year award
summary: GlobalWafers CEO Doris Hsu was named the EY World Entrepreneur of the Year, becoming the third woman to hold the title in the award's 23-year history. She was chosen from nearly 5,000 program participants across 45 countries and jurisdictions for her vision, innovation, and commitment to sustainability. Hsu led GlobalWafers' meteoric rise, overseeing successful mergers and acquisitions that transformed the company into the world's third-largest wafer manufacturer. She accepted the award, highlighting the under-representation of female leaders in the high-tech industry and encouraging others to succeed.

site_title: Green Link Digital Bank donates S$150,000 to SPD
summary: Green Link Digital Bank (GLDB) donated S$150,000 to SPD, a local charity helping people with disabilities, to commemorate its first year in Singapore. The donation includes S$100,000 in cash and S$50,000 in medical equipment, such as oxygen concentrators and assistive technologies. The cash will be used to provide additional subsidies to clients in SPD's programs, while the equipment will help the charity replace its existing equipment. This donation aims to demonstrate that corporations can play a meaningful part in creating positive social impacts in the community.

site_title: US will buy 3 million more barrels of oil for emergency reserve
summary: The US Energy Department announced plans to purchase 3 million more barrels of crude oil for the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, marking an effort to replenish the emergency reserve after releasing 200 million barrels last year. The new oil purchases will be awarded by June 30, with contracts for sour crude oil expected to be awarded at an average price of about $73 per barrel. This move aims to curb high energy prices and stabilize the market.

site_title: India agency sends notices to Deutsche, HSBC, Citi in Xiaomi royalty case
summary: India's Enforcement Directorate (ED) has issued show cause notices to Xiaomi, Deutsche Bank, HSBC, and Citigroup over alleged illegal remittances of 55.51 billion rupees (S$904.8 million) made by the Chinese smartphone giant to foreign entities. Xiaomi's local unit is accused of making illegal remittances by passing them off as royalty payments. The agency has frozen Xiaomi's assets, which are spread across accounts at various banks, including Deutsche, Citi, and HSBC. The company has previously denied the allegations, stating that the payments were legitimate.

images.alt_text: India has promoted electronics manufacturing and attracted the likes of Apple and Xiaomi, but the country still lacks a repair outsourcing industry, currently dominated by China and Malaysia, estimated at US$100 billion globally.

site_title: Manchester City crowned Europe’s champion, a title years, and billions, in the making
summary: Manchester City has won the Champions League, completing a rare treble of trophies in one season by defeating Inter Milan 1-0. The victory marks the culmination of 15 years of investment and ambition by Abu Dhabi, which purchased the club in 2008. Manchester City's dominance in English football is well-established, with five of the last six Premier League titles and a FA Cup win this season. The team's success has raised questions about the use of wealth and resources to circumvent financial regulations, but City denies any wrongdoing.

site_title: Messi in Beijing for friendly before move to Miami
summary: Lionel Messi arrived in Beijing on June 10 for a friendly match before joining Inter Miami in Major League Soccer as a free agent. This is his seventh visit to China, his first since 2017, and comes ahead of Thursday's Argentina-Australia match at Beijing's Workers' Stadium. Messi confirmed his departure from Paris St. Germain earlier this week, solidifying his status as one of the game's all-time greats.

site_title: Port of Seattle’s cargo operations shut by work action
summary: The Port of Seattle shut its cargo operations on June 10 due to "coordinated and disruptive work actions" by the International Longshore and Warehouse Union (ILWU), which represents 22,000 dockworkers. The Pacific Maritime Association blamed the ILWU for refusing to dispatch longshore workers to container terminals during the first shift of the day. Operations at Los Angeles and Long Beach had previously returned to normal after a series of labour actions from June 2 to June 7, resulting in delays to container ships. The ILWU disputed the PMA's statement, saying it remained committed to reaching a "fair and equitable" contract.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip as central bank meetings loom, Croda falls on profit warning
summary: European shares slipped 0.2% on Friday, ending the week 0.5% lower, amid anticipation of the US Fed's meeting and the European Central Bank's (ECB) rate hike. Investors fear a hawkish stance from the Fed and expect the ECB to tighten monetary policy, with a 98% chance of a 25-basis-point rate hike next week. Croda International fell 12.5% after a profit warning, while the insurance sector and banks were also weighed down.

site_title: Why the crypto world flinches when the SEC calls coins securities
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) considers a range of widely traded digital assets to be securities, which could impose steep regulatory requirements on digital-asset exchanges. The SEC has signaled that it considers coins worth $120 billion to be unregistered securities, and has sued Coinbase Global and Binance Holdings over allegations that they listed unregistered securities. The agency's securities rules apply to crypto staking, and the SEC's legal test for determining if an asset is a security involves investors kicking in money with the intention of profiting from the efforts of the organization's leadership.

site_title: Pakistan in talks to restructure debt with bilateral creditors
summary: Pakistan is in talks with bilateral creditors to restructure its debt, aiming to service interest payments and delay principal payments. Finance Minister Ishaq Dar stated the government will engage in negotiations, but won't seek major reductions on principal. The move comes as Pakistan faces $22 billion in external debt payments for fiscal year 2024, a significant burden on its cash flow. The government aims to balance economic growth with IMF-imposed austerity measures to revive its bailout program.

site_title: Tesla set for US$3 billion boost from Ford, GM charger deals
summary: Tesla is set to receive a potential US$3 billion boost by 2030 from deals with Ford and General Motors to use its charging network for their electric vehicles. The agreements, which standardize Tesla's charging model, will pressure competitors to adopt the same standard, effectively establishing Tesla's 'North American Charging Standard'. This could add significant revenue for Tesla, with estimates suggesting upwards of US$3 billion in charging revenue by 2030 and US$5.4 billion by 2032.

site_title: Oil posts second weekly decline as demand concerns overshadow Saudi cut
summary: Oil prices fell for a second straight week, with Brent crude futures declining $1.17 to $74.79 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude falling $1.12 to $70.17 a barrel. The decline was driven by concerns over demand growth, despite Saudi Arabia's pledge to cut more output. Disappointing Chinese data and a report of a potential US-Iran nuclear deal also weighed on the markets. Analysts expect oil prices to remain below $80 and may rise if the US Federal Reserve pauses interest rate hikes.

site_title: Chinese property developer Ronshine misses payment on SGX-listed US$316 million bond
summary: Chinese property developer Ronshine China Holdings has missed a payment on its Singapore-listed US$316 million bond, which matured on June 9. The outstanding amount is US$328.8 million, including accrued and unpaid interest. This marks the latest debt default by China's property sector, following China Evergrande Group's defaults. Ronshine will engage with creditors and seek a solution, but may face accelerated repayment or enforcement actions if no consensual solution is reached in a timely manner.

site_title: Their crypto company collapsed. They went to Bali.
summary: Crypto company Three Arrows Capital collapsed last year, causing a market meltdown that devastated the industry. Founders Kyle Davies and Su Zhu, both 36, fled to Bali, where they spent their days painting, reading, and sightseeing. Despite the collapse, they claim to be thriving, with no remorse for their role in the disaster. They have since planned a comeback, unveiling Open Exchange, a marketplace for traders who lost money in last year's crypto implosions. The founders, who managed over $4 billion at their peak, declined to apologize for the collapse, citing death threats and no government agency action. They have saved enough to live comfortably and plan to invest in real estate and other ventures.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on Tesla boost, Fed meet in focus
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by Tesla's surge after a tie-up with General Motors. The S&P 500 rose 10.95 points, or 0.26%, to 4,304.88, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 73.87 points, or 0.56%. Investors remained cautious ahead of inflation data and the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy decision next week. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also rose 18.83 points, or 0.06%.

site_title: Twitter to start paying content creators for ads in replies, Musk says
summary: Elon Musk announced that Twitter will start paying content creators for ads displayed in their replies, with an initial payment pool of $5 million. Verified creators will receive payment for ads shown to verified users. The move comes as new CEO Linda Yaccarino takes the helm, following Musk's efforts to retain advertisers after laying off thousands of employees. Musk previously stated that Twitter earns around 5-6 cents per hour of user attention, which could increase with relevant and timely ads.

site_title: S&P 500’s tech-heavy top is a feature, not a bug
summary: The US stock market's concentration in tech giants, particularly Apple and Microsoft, has raised concerns about risk. However, a study finds that shifts in the S&P 500 index's concentration don't necessarily make it more or less risky. Instead, the index's weighting by market value helps stabilize risk over time, as larger, more profitable companies tend to be safer. The S&P 500's top five holdings account for 24% of the index, which is the highest concentration since at least 1990. Despite this, the index has consistently returned around 10% a year over the long term, making it a lucrative investment.

summary: The COE prices in Singapore have rebounded after a sharp fall in late May, prompting Volkswagen Group Singapore to offer affordable options. The Skoda Octavia is ranked as the best all-rounder at S$174,900, followed by other models that can be registered with a Category A certificate, which is cheaper. site_title: AI statue designed by Michelango on show in Sweden
summary: A Swedish museum is showcasing a 150cm stainless steel statue, "the Impossible Statue," designed by artificial intelligence trained by five renowned sculptors, including Michelangelo and Rodin. The AI-generated artwork, on display at Stockholm's National Museum of Science and Technology, blends styles from the five masters, sparking debate about the role of AI in art. Museum officials say the statue's unique style and features evoke a sense of authenticity, but its authorship remains a topic of discussion, with some questioning whether it can be considered "art."

site_title: Google launches News Showcase in US this summer
summary: Google has launched the News Showcase in the US, a platform that pays over 150 US publishers for their content, as part of a broader effort to support the struggling news industry. The platform will feature curated content from top publishers, including local outlets and major news organizations, but Google does not disclose payment details. This move comes amid criticism from publishers and proposals for laws requiring tech giants to pay for news, similar to a proposed California law and a European Union copyright fee.

images.alt_text: Google has made efforts to solidify its position in mass-market phones, launching affordable devices such as those through its partnership with billionaire Mukesh Ambani’s Reliance Jio.

site_title: They fled San Francisco. The AI boom pulled them back
summary: Tech entrepreneurs Doug Fulop and Jessie Fischer, who fled San Francisco for a quieter life in Bend, Oregon, are returning to the Bay Area due to the artificial intelligence (AI) boom. The AI boom has brought energy back to San Francisco's tech scene, which had been struggling during the pandemic. With US$10.7 billion in funding for generative AI startups and a sense of community among tech workers, many are moving back to the Bay Area to be part of the startup ecosystem. The AI boom is also luring back founders of other tech companies, with some opting to relocate to San Francisco to tap into the community and resources.

site_title: Boris Johnson resigns from Parliament
summary: Former UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has resigned from Parliament, citing a "witch hunt" against him. Johnson had been under investigation for allegedly lying to Parliament about lockdown-breaking parties at Downing Street during the Covid-19 pandemic. He preempted a potential by-election in his constituency by quitting, avoiding the risk of losing his seat. Johnson's departure means a by-election will now take place, potentially affecting the Conservative Party's morale ahead of a general election expected in the second half of 2025. Johnson's exit marks a significant end to his career, which has been marked by frequent surges and setbacks.

site_title: Singapore shares flat as key Asian bourses rally
summary: Singapore shares ended flat on Friday, rising 0.01% to 3,186.97 points, after a choppy session. The benchmark index gained 0.7% for the week, despite a rally in key Asian indexes, driven by revived hopes for a Federal Reserve rate pause. Thai Beverage was the top performer, rising 3.6% to S$0.575, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding declined 2.3% to S$1.27.

site_title: Trump lawyers quit in documents case; Trump aide indicted
summary: US President Donald Trump's lawyers, John Rowley and Jim Trusty, quit their case defending him in a federal documents case, amid Trump's scheduled appearance in Miami court on Tuesday. Trump has been indicted on seven federal charges, including obstruction and illegally retaining classified documents. Trump's former military valet, Walt Nauta, has also been charged alongside Trump. Trump's lawyers cited the honor of defending him, but the surprise announcement may prompt further legal complications.

site_title: A rocky net zero pathway calls for a new approach to portfolios
summary: Investors should consider the implications of a shift towards a net zero world, driven by new policies, technology, and changing consumer preferences. A "disorderly" transition to a greener economy could lead to bouts of inflation, lower productivity, and subdued economic growth. Central banks may use short-term interest rates to counteract inflationary swings and prevent debt levels from becoming explosive. Sectors linked to the green transition are likely to benefit from policymakers' support, which could be likened to "green" quantitative easing. A successful transition is uncertain, weighing on the baseline scenario for capital market assumptions.

site_title: Public debt: Four ways to deleverage
summary: Singapore's CFA Society has discussed four ways governments can deleverage public debt: redeeming assets, pruning inflation, pruning budget deficits, and amending debt structures. Governments can discharge debt by selling off infrastructure, requisitioning assets, or taxing citizens and corporations. Inflation can lower debt-to-GDP ratios, and budget deficit reduction can produce surpluses. Restructuring debt and extending repayment periods can also help manage sovereign debt. However, perpetual debt can ignore excessive leverage and have dire consequences. Ultimately, governments must address public debt burdens to avoid crowding out private initiatives and debt ceiling brinkmanship.

images.alt_text: US Representative Thomas Massie wears a pin displaying the amount of the US national debt during a House Committee on Rules hearing about whether to raise the United States' debt ceiling and avoid a catastrophic default, at the US Capitol in Washington, May 30, 2023.

site_title: The transatlantic carbon-pricing clash
summary: The US and EU are at odds over carbon pricing, with the EU's cap-and-trade system facing a potential challenge from the US's tax-based approach. The US Inflation Reduction Act includes a subsidy for carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology, which could boost the sector with a guaranteed 12-year payment of $85 per tonne of CO2 removed. However, the effectiveness of CCS technology remains uncertain, with only a few industrial facilities existing globally and removing only small amounts of CO2.

images.alt_text: The Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) will put an emissions tariff on imports of carbon intensive goods entering the European Union (EU).

site_title: Netflix sign-ups jump as US password sharing crackdown kicks off: data
summary: US Netflix sign-ups surged in the first few days after the streaming giant's password-sharing crackdown took effect on May 23, with nearly 100,000 daily sign-ups reported on May 26 and 27. The move, which charges an additional $8 per month for users to add a member outside their homes, has been successful, with shares rising 2.3% to $418.92. This marks the company's four largest days of US user acquisition in 4.5 years, exceeding levels seen during the initial US Covid-19 lockdowns in 2020.

site_title: Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour appointed Malaysia central bank governor
summary: Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour, a career central banker, has been appointed as Malaysia's central bank governor for a five-year term, effective July 1. He succeeds Nor Shamsiah Mohd Yunus, who led the bank since 2018. Ghaffour, who joined BNM in 1988, has held several senior positions, including Deputy Governor and member of the Monetary Policy Committee. He expressed confidence in his ability to lead the bank and continue promoting monetary and financial stability, conducive to sustainable economic growth.

site_title: LHN to get S$32 million cash infusion if LHN Logistics offer goes through
summary: LHN Logistics, a Singaporean logistics company, is set to receive a S$32 million cash infusion if a Shanghai-listed company's offer to buy its stake is successful. The deal, valued at S$0.2266 per share, would be equivalent to 23% of LHN's market capitalization. LHN Logistics' shares have seen low trading volumes since its 2022 IPO, and the proposed deal would allow the company to realize its entire investment, generating an estimated net gain of approximately S$21 million.

images.alt_text: LHN Logistics reported a net asset value of S$0.0783 per share as at Mar 31, 2023.

LHN Logistics owns a fleet of 74 prime movers and 356 trailers across Singapore and Malaysia. Its primary customers are international ISO tank operators, chemical traders, freight forwarders and chemical branches of oil majors. It carries out its transportation operations here at its own property at 7 Gul Avenue, as well as at a leased logistics parking yard at 18 Penjuru Road.

site_title: US: Stocks end a tad higher as Tesla rallies
summary: US stocks closed higher on Friday, with the S&P 500 gaining 4.93 points, or 0.1%, to 4,298.86, as Tesla rallied 4.1% after General Motors agreed to use its Supercharger network. The benchmark index has advanced 0.4% this week and extended its winning streak to four weeks. Despite concerns about a looming recession and sticky inflation, stocks have been supported by a megacap stocks rally and better-than-expected earnings season. The Federal Reserve's policy meeting and inflation data next week will influence market sentiment.

images.alt_text:
wwpb29 - A Credit Suisse logo hangs in the entrance to Credit Suisse Group AG's headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland, on Wednesday, April 24, 2019. Credit Suisse's main trading business swung to a profit after two quarters of losses, as Switzerland's second-largest lender emerged relatively unscathed from what rival UBS Group AG called one of the worst environments in recent history. Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

The latest auction saw total applications of S$11.5 billion for the S$5.2 billion on offer, giving it a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.2.

site_title: Acrobats show off Art Nouveau heritage of Brussels
summary: Brussels is showcasing its Art Nouveau heritage through an innovative project featuring acrobats and trapeze artists. To mark the 130th anniversary of architect Victor Horta's landmark masterpiece, Tassel House, the city has designated 2023 the year of Art Nouveau. The project aims to draw attention to the style's beauty and craftsmanship, with photo and video displays in protected buildings, including the Solvay House, now a museum. The initiative, led by the Brussels-based acrobatic company, "Arabesque," hopes to spread knowledge of the city's Art Nouveau wealth beyond Belgium.

site_title: EU antitrust regulators approve Vivendi, Lagardere deal
summary: EU antitrust regulators have approved Vivendi's acquisition of Lagardere, a French media conglomerate, with conditions. Vivendi agreed to sell its publishing unit Editis and celebrity magazine Gala to address regulatory concerns. EU Commissioner Margrethe Vestager stated that the remedies will preserve existing competition in book publishing and press markets, benefiting consumers. The deal gives Vivendi control of Lagardere's flagship weekly publications Journal du Dimanche and Paris Match.

images.alt_text: The proposed legislation by EU, due to be unveiled next week, means providers of ESG ratings that also offer other financial services will be forced to keep those businesses separate to avoid conflicts of interest.

The new law, once it is passed after talks with the EU parliament and the Commission, updates the minimum set of rules on the tracing, identification, freezing, confiscation and management of criminal property.

site_title: Brookfield to buy Network International for £2.2 billion
summary: Brookfield Asset Management has agreed to acquire London-listed Network International Holdings for approximately £2.2 billion, expanding its presence in credit card processing in the Middle East. The deal represents a 64% premium to Network International's closing price before the offer period. Brookfield emerged as the frontrunner after interest from a consortium including CVC Capital Partners and Francisco Partners cooled. The acquisition is expected to create a payments giant in the region where digital wallets are accelerating, and is another boost to the UK's buyout market.

images.alt_text: The office vacancy rate in downtown Los Angeles reaches a record 30 per cent in the first quarter, according to Savills, one of the highest of major US city centres.

site_title: Where are Chinese consumers willing to spend?
summary: Chinese consumers are resuming spending on travel and dining out, but are not buying necessities and other consumer goods as much as before the pandemic. Retail sales of consumer goods rose 5.8% year-on-year, driven by services, while retail sales of goods gained only 7.3% and fell short of the 2019 period. Household deposits reached 130.2 trillion yuan, indicating a reluctance to spend and favoring precautionary savings. Online retailers are responding with aggressive competition, with discount platforms benefiting from consumers' reluctance to shop. Physical stores are under pressure, with nine out of 14 publicly traded supermarket operators reporting net losses last year.

images.alt_text: The combined assets under management of China's private securities fund managers is 5.9 trillion yuan, according to data by the Asset Management Association of China.

Firms such as Nio and Li Auto managed to enter China's electric vehicle industry by partnering original equipment manufacturers or through mergers, but regulators may tighten rules to remove such possibilities.
The total market capitalisation of China’s 27 publicly offered infrastructure-focused REITs slumped to 90.6 billion yuan (S$17.3 billion) on Apr 27.
Shanghai's main shopping belt, March 2023

site_title: All-conquering Manchester City seek final piece of treble jigsaw in Istanbul
summary: Manchester City, seeking to complete the treble, face off against underdog Inter Milan in the Champions League final in Istanbul. City has already secured the Premier League title and FA Cup, while Inter has been on an impressive run of form under manager Simone Inzaghi. The match, set for Sunday, will be the final piece of the jigsaw for City and manager Pep Guardiola, who has been building towards this moment since the club's takeover in 2008. The winner will claim the Champions League trophy, with Inter considered massive underdogs.

images.alt_text:
Soccer Football - Champions League Final Previews - Istanbul, Turkey - June 8, 2023
A giant replica of the Champions League trophy is seen in Taksim Sqaure ahead of the final on Saturday between Manchester City and Inter Milan.

Financial experts estimate promotion to Premier League to be worth around £170 million for Luton that have been through turmoil since they last played in the top flight 31 years ago.

site_title: Citi to cut 50 London jobs in investment and corporate banking
summary: Citi is planning to cut 50 jobs in London, including 30 investment banking positions and 20 corporate banking roles, due to adverse market conditions. The layoffs are part of the bank's efforts to reduce its cost base. This move follows hundreds of job cuts earlier in the year, affecting various parts of the company. The cuts amount to less than 1% of Citi's 240,000-person workforce.

site_title: EU puts ESG rating firms on notice as major overhaul planned
summary: The European Union is set to unveil a major overhaul of its Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) rating market, which has grown rapidly in recent years but lacks meaningful regulatory oversight. The proposed legislation would require ESG rating providers to separate their businesses from other financial services to avoid conflicts of interest, and could lead to fines of up to 10% of total annual net revenue for non-compliance. The move aims to increase transparency and standardization of ESG ratings, and is expected to result in the standardization and comparability of ratings, as well as greater dialogue and engagement from financial market participants.

site_title: Cromwell European Reit in advanced talks to sell Milan ‘trophy asset’
summary: Cromwell European Reit is in advanced talks to sell its Milan office asset, Piazza Affari 2, valued at around 100 million euros (S$144.7 million). The property is considered a "trophy asset" in the heart of Milan's central business district. Negotiations are ongoing, but no definitive agreement has been reached, and there is no certainty of a sale. This sale is part of the Reit's strategy to divest non-core and non-strategic assets over the next two to three years.

images.alt_text: The Reit also reports gains in both gross revenue and net property income thanks to higher portfolio occupancy.
One of Cromwell E-Reit's light industrial properties in Tilburg, The Netherlands

site_title: Hacker leaks Cortina Watch’s data online, including customer details and sales tactics
summary: A hacker leaked Cortina Watch's data, including customer details and sales tactics, on the dark web. The data dump, which exceeds 7GB, contains usernames and passwords, as well as sensitive information such as contact details, home addresses, and dates of birth. The leak also includes data on company and staff accounts, with multiple administrator accounts sharing the same password. The incident highlights a security breach and potential misuse of customer data.

site_title: Canada sheds 17,300 jobs in first decline in nine months
summary: Canada's economy experienced its first job loss in nine months, with 17,300 jobs shed in May, mainly among youth and self-employed individuals. The unemployment rate rose 0.2 percentage points to 5.2%, missing expectations. Despite job losses, wages continued to rise, with a 5% yearly pace for the fourth consecutive month. The job market remains resilient, with a tight labour market and strong economic growth.

images.alt_text: The BOC says it will continue to assess economic indicators going forward to see if they “are consistent with achieving the inflation target”.

site_title: Julian Assange loses US extradition challenge, will renew appeal next week
summary: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has lost his US extradition challenge, with a judge ruling he has no legal grounds to challenge the decision. Assange, 51, faces 18 charges related to WikiLeaks' release of confidential US military records and diplomatic cables. Britain has given the go-ahead for his extradition, and he will renew his appeal next week.

images.alt_text: US wins appeal against block on Assange extradition

site_title: Ong Beng Seng’s HPL puts in development proposal for Forum mall, former Hilton, HPL House sites
summary: Ong Beng Seng's Hotel Properties Limited (HPL) has submitted a development proposal to the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) for the Forum mall, voco Orchard Singapore hotel, and HPL House on a prime Orchard Road corner. The proposal involves rezoning the voco site from hotel use to commercial use, allowing for potential redevelopment into a luxury commercial project. Market watchers suggest the project could combine hotel and retail components, with estimated gross floor area of over 700,000 sq ft. The proposed change of use is the first step in a long planning process, with the URA's Strategic Development Incentive Scheme potentially contributing to the redevelopment.

images.alt_text: HPL's Hilton Singapore along Orchard Road to be rebranded voco under IHG

site_title: Fed seen ending 15-month hiking campaign, says survey
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to pause interest-rate increases for the first time in 15 months, according to a Bloomberg survey of 46 economists. The median projection suggests keeping rates steady at 5% to 5.25% through December, with a possible quarter-point hike in July and a similar-sized cut in December. Economists expect the US economy to continue growing, with inflation expected to remain high throughout 2024, and nearly 40% anticipating dissent at the June meeting.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen speaks during a news conference at the Treasury Department in Washington, U.S., April 11, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz/File Photo

site_title: Rowdy tourists spark partial Airbnb ban on Penang Island
summary: Penang Island in Malaysia has implemented a partial ban on Airbnb and similar short-term rental services due to complaints of rowdy tourists. The ban, set to take effect on March 1, 2024, will initially only apply to the island, excluding the mainland Penang state. The ban aims to regulate and manage tourist behavior, giving property owners time to comply with new regulations.

images.alt_text: The wholesale price of Musang King plunged to RM30 and below, as at June 6, due to inconsistent quality and fewer demand.

site_title: EV maker Lordstown plans to sue Foxconn over stake dispute
summary: Lordstown Motors plans to sue Foxconn over a stake dispute, citing a letter from the Taiwanese contract manufacturer stating it's unlikely to complete a nearly 10% share purchase due to a reverse stock split. The split was announced in May to meet Nasdaq listing norms and appease Foxconn, which threatened to scrap a $170 million funding deal. Foxconn has yet to respond to the claim, and Lordstown is seeking to ensure the purchase is completed.

site_title: UBS, Swiss government finalise US$10 billion loss guarantee deal
summary: UBS Group has finalized a US$10 billion loss guarantee deal with the Swiss government to cover losses from the rescue of Credit Suisse Group. Under the agreement, UBS will assume the first 5 billion francs (S$7.45 billion) of losses, while the government will take on the next 9 billion francs. The deal clears a major hurdle for the historic takeover and is expected to be completed soon, with UBS potentially becoming a financial titan twice the size of the Swiss economy.

images.alt_text: The Helvetia statue is pictured in front of the Swiss Parliament Building, in Bern, Switzerland, March 19, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse

site_title: BOJ sees little need to tweak yield control for now
summary: Bank of Japan officials see little need to adjust its yield curve control programme, citing improved bond market functioning and a smooth yield curve. Despite inflation running stronger than expected, officials remain cautious and don't expect to achieve the 2% price target soon. The decision will be made after assessing economic data and market developments. The BOJ is expected to maintain its monetary stimulus, and any policy shift could send ripples across global financial markets.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda participates in a news conference at the Fairmont Washington D.C. Georgetown hotel in Washington, U.S., April 13, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz

site_title: Dutch asset manager blacklists Singapore state-backed assets on environmental concerns
summary: Singapore's state-backed assets, including sovereign bonds and government entities, have been blacklisted by Dutch asset manager Van Lanschot Kempen due to environmental concerns, specifically the country's reliance on fossil fuels and lack of renewable energy infrastructure. The decision marks a rare example of a developed economy falling out of favor with investors focused on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) scores. Singapore's small landmass and limited options for building renewable energy infrastructure have led to a high reliance on imports and a significant share of electricity coming from natural gas.

images.alt_text: Coal-fired power plants across Asia are amongst the youngest in the world. Accelerating their early retirement will be complex but essential towards achieving a low-carbon future.
Billionaire Mike Cannon-Brookes has revived the project to export solar energy from Australia to Singapore via a 4,200 km undersea cable.

site_title: SGX quizzes impact of Panasonic’s Malaysia exit on CFM Holdings
summary: Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) is investigating the impact of Panasonic's Malaysia exit on Catalist-listed company CFM Holdings. Panasonic announced it will cease operations in Malaysia, potentially affecting CFM Holdings, which supplies cleanroom equipment. CFM Holdings has not received a notice from Panasonic Manufacturing Malaysia regarding the impact on existing contracts. The company is unable to comment on the financial impact or plans moving forward due to the lack of notice. CFM Holdings has other key customers in Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Panasonic eyes region to expand consumer business
Panasonic retrenches 700 as it shuts Singapore manufacturing operations
A Jan 2023 photo showing employees at a car assembly line in a Beijing factory in Qingdao, in China's eastern Shandong province.
The book value and net tangible asset (NTA) value of the property as at Dec 31, 2021 was S$7.73 million, the company said, bringing the potential proceeds from the sale to over S$5.6 million.

site_title: Indonesia’s new golden visa can attract top foreign talent, but the devil is in the details
summary: Indonesia's new "golden visa" program aims to attract top foreign talent, particularly in the fields of digitalization, health, research, and technology, with a 10-year permit and perks such as streamlined immigration services and a fast-track route to citizenship. The program is seen as a "game changer" to boost foreign investment and address the country's massive talent shortfall. However, industry players question whether Indonesia's lifestyle and competition from Singapore and Dubai will be enough to attract top talent, and the program's success remains to be seen.

images.alt_text: Airlangga Hartarto, Indonesia's Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs, confirms exporters will not be asked to convert their foreign exchange into rupiah.
GoTo says CEO Andre Soelistyo, who has been in the company since 2015, has submitted his resignation and will take the post of commissioner as a deputy chairman.
