summary: Paris aims to make the Seine river swimmable by 2025 for the 2024 Olympics, with the city working to improve water quality and prevent pollution. A new 50,000 cubic meter underground basin will collect rainfall to prevent sewage overflow, and existing homes are being upgraded to reduce wastewater discharge into the river. The goal is to host swimming and triathlon events in the river, with plans to maintain clean water quality beyond the Olympics.

site_title: WHO to seek global certificate system, inspired by EU's Covid pass
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has partnered with the European Union (EU) to create a global health certification system, inspired by the EU's digital Covid pass. The system, aimed at protecting people from health threats and facilitating global mobility, will be based on open-source technologies and standards. WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus and EU health commissioner Stella Kyriakides signed a landmark agreement in Geneva, with the EU's Covid certificate to be transformed into a global public good. The network will also include digitized international routine vaccination cards.

images.alt_text: nil

site_title: Saudi Arabia revives sports clubs' privatisation plan
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to privatize several sports clubs, starting in the fourth quarter of 2023, as part of its Vision 2030 economic diversification plan. The plan, launched by Crown Prince Mohammed Salman, will allow major companies and development agencies to invest in sports clubs in exchange for ownership transfer. The focus is on soccer, with the goal of increasing revenue to 1.8 billion riyals by 2030 and the league's market value reaching 8 billion riyals. This move aims to reduce reliance on oil and build new industries.

images.alt_text: In the case of China’s Baosteel, the Saudi venture marks its first full-process production base overseas.

site_title: China says local debt under control, no systemic risk seen
summary: China's local government debt is manageable, authorities say, with no systemic risk seen. The Ministry of Finance stated that government finances are generally healthy and urged local authorities to tackle their debts. The distribution of local government debt is unbalanced, with some regions exposed to high risks and under pressure to make big principal and interest payments. Despite China's ballooning municipal borrowing being the top financial risk for investors in Asia, Beijing has urged local authorities to avoid risks from spreading. Authorities have sufficient financial resources to address debt concerns.

images.alt_text: The PBOC has refrained from cutting interest rates this year and Beijing has been reluctant to sharply increase fiscal spending, concerned by financial stability risks after local government debts soared.

site_title: Sias calls for Gear minority shareholders to ‘vote wisely’ at EGM; says IFA justifications subjective
summary: Golden Energy & Resources' (Gear) minority shareholders are urged to "vote wisely" at an upcoming EGM, with the Securities Investors Association (Singapore) opposing the proposed voluntary delisting. The EGM will vote on a distribution in specie of Gem shares and the delisting of Gear. Sias claims the IFA's justifications for the exit offer are "subjective" and questions the comparability between Gear and other companies. Minority shareholders are advised to review the EGM circular and make informed decisions, with Sias standing by its view that the IFA process can be improved.

images.alt_text: Golden energy and resources' independent financial advisor has defended its valuation methodology as taking a more complete picture of Golden Energy Mines.

site_title: Vietnam’s power blackouts hit multinationals’ manufacturing hubs
summary: Vietnam's power blackouts have affected industrial parks in northern provinces, where top manufacturers like Samsung and Foxconn have factories. The power cuts, caused by a heatwave and surge in consumption, have disrupted industrial activities and threatened efforts to avert an economic slowdown. EuroCham, representing European companies, has urged the industry and trade ministry to address the issue, warning that the power cuts could undermine Vietnam's reputation as a reliable global manufacturing hub.

images.alt_text: Samsung centre building is seen in Hanoi Vietnam May 29, 2023. REUTERS/Francesco Guarascio

site_title: Sadness, shock: Horse-racing fraternity overwhelmed by news of Kranji racecourse closure
summary: The Singapore Turf Club has announced the closure of the Kranji racecourse in October 2024, with the facility set to close by March 2027. The 182-year-old tradition will end, with the land to be redeveloped for housing and other uses. The decision comes after declining attendance and revenue, with average attendance per race day decreasing from 11,000 in 2010 to 2,600 in 2019. The closure has sparked sadness and shock among the horse-racing community, with some expressing concerns about the short notice and impact on the industry.

images.alt_text: What next for the Singapore Turf Club?
With the handover due in 2027, the Turf Club will host its last race meeting on Oct 5, 2024, and close its facility by March 2027. Its last event will be the 100th Grand Singapore Gold Cup.
Horse racing in 1980 in Singapore.

site_title: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit bags 10% shares in Parkway Parade Partnership for S$90.5 million
summary: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit (LReit) has acquired a 10% stake in Parkway Parade Partnership (PPP) for S$90.5 million, based on a S$1.38 billion agreed market value of 291 strata lots in Parkway Parade. PPP holds an indirect 100% interest in the lots, representing 77.09% of total share value. The acquisition benefits LReit's unit holders by granting flexibility to raise its stake and accretion of distribution per unit (DPU) on a pro forma basis, with estimated DPU rising to 4.89 Singapore cents.

images.alt_text: Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust’s VivoCity recorded positive rent reversion at 7.9 per cent.
As part of Orchard Road’s rejuvenation plans, Tanglin’s identity as a neighbourhood with a strong artisanal flavour will be strengthened.
Lendlease Global Reit reports 99.8% committed portfolio occupancy for Q3

site_title: New Zealand gives former PM Ardern title of dame
summary: New Zealand has honored former Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern with the title of dame, citing her leadership after the 2019 Christchurch mosque massacre and during the Covid-19 pandemic. Ardern, 42, stepped down as prime minister in January, citing a lack of energy. The King's Birthday and Coronation Honours List recognized her service to New Zealand during challenging times, with Prime Minister Chris Hipkins praising her commitment to the country. Ardern initially hesitated to accept the honor, citing the collective effort of all New Zealanders in her work.

images.alt_text: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern: "I know that I no longer have enough in the tank to do this job justice."

site_title: British Airways tells 35,000 staff their data was hacked
summary: British Airways has informed 35,000 staff that their personal data may have been compromised in a cyberattack on the airline's payroll provider, Zellis. The data breach, which occurred in June, exposed employees' names, surnames, dates of birth, and potentially banking details. This is the latest technology glitch to affect the airline, following a computer outage last month that forced hundreds of flight cancellations. British Airways' group CEO Luis Gallego stated that the tech issues are fixable, but it will take time to resolve.

images.alt_text: “While the vast majority of our flights continue to operate today, we have cancelled some of our short-haul flights from Heathrow due to the knock-on effect of a technical issue that we experienced yesterday,” British Airways says.

site_title: Singapore shares buoyed by Wall Street rally; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.7% to 3,189.01 points on Monday, driven by a Wall Street rally, with gains outweighing losses 294 to 233 in the broader market. The Straits Times Index (STI) lifted after a mixed US jobs report lifted hopes that the Federal Reserve will hold off hiking interest rates this month. However, concerns about an impending global recession remain, with the US Treasury yield curve inverted for nearly 42 years.

images.alt_text: Singapore’s April retail sales up 3.6%; most industries report yoy gains

The figures combined with news that Washington had finally passed a debt ceiling deal to avert a catastrophic default, while a report that China is looking at fresh support for its property sector also boosted sentiment.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 134 to 37 after after 133.3 million securities worth S$154.1 million change hands.
Keppel DC Reit will be replaced by Seatrium as an STI constituent from Jun 19.
Keppel DC Reit, which has the Guangdong Data Centre among its portfolio of data centres, announced a

site_title: US dollar edges up as markets weigh chances of Fed rate hike
summary: The US dollar index edged up against major currencies on Monday as markets priced in a 30% chance of the US Federal Reserve raising benchmark rates this month. The dollar index came off the boil last week after Fed officials expressed a preference for a pause in rate hikes and after US debt ceiling talks calmed market jitters. Despite robust jobs data, analysts believe the Fed may still pause rate rises due to easing wage pressures and rising unemployment.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's information and communications sector grew 8.6% in 2022, outpacing the overall economy's 3.6% growth. A new Digital Connectivity Blueprint aims to enable seamless 10 Gbps connectivity across different networks. Retail sales rose 3.6% in April, with the food and alcohol, and cosmetics industries posting the highest growth. The Singapore Turf Club will close in 2024, and 120 hectares of land will be redeveloped for housing. Sembcorp is exploring the sale of its waste management unit, and Digital Core Reit warned its distribution per unit could be halved if one of its tenants goes bust.

site_title: Singapore Turf Club to close in 2027, freeing land in Kranji for housing, other uses
summary: The Singapore Turf Club will close its facility by March 2027, marking the end of its 185-year history. The club's last event will be the 100th Grand Singapore Gold Cup in October 2024. The land will be handed over to the government for redevelopment, including housing, leisure, and recreation. The decision comes amid declining spectator numbers, with average attendance per race falling by about half since 2010. The government aims to repurpose the 120-hectare Kranji site to meet future needs, including redeveloping the Woodlands Checkpoint and rejuvenating Woodlands Town.

images.alt_text: Horse racing: Yusoff Fadzli steering the Donna Logan-trained King Arthur (No. 2) to their last win together in a Kranji Stakes A (1,200m) race on Oct 10, 2022.
Horse racing in 1980 in Singapore.
What next for the Singapore Turf Club?
Putting the debate on prize money to bed

site_title: Singapore super-prime residential sales rebound in Q1, face slower sales ahead: Knight Frank
summary: Singapore's super-prime residential property sales rebounded 60.9% in Q1 2023 to 37 deals, surpassing cities like London and Geneva by volume. However, the average sale price fell 12.4% to US$15.6 million, down from US$17.8 million in Q4 2022. The number of transactions remained the same as the previous year, while the average sale price was down 15.2% year-over-year. Knight Frank expects transactions for super-prime residential properties to total between US$25 billion and US$27 billion for 2023, with a recovery in growth expected in 2024.

images.alt_text: Singapore is one of the top 10 cities in the high-end activity index, with 18 ultra-prime property sales and 121 super-prime property sales, says Knight Frank.
Real estate consultancy Knight Frank noted that the scant inventory of landed and non-landed homes on the market will continue to shrink in 2023.
Private home prices grew by 3.2 per cent in Q1 2023, after inching up 0.4 per cent in the previous quarter.

site_title: Tesla’s China-made EV sales rise 2.4% in May from April: CPCA
summary: Tesla delivered 77,695 China-made electric vehicles in May, a 2.4% increase from April. On a yearly basis, sales rose 142% from 32,165 vehicles in May 2022. This represents the largest year-over-year growth for Tesla in China.

site_title: China bonds, at centre of crisis fears, post surprise gains
summary: China's local-government financing vehicles (LGFVs) have posted surprise gains this year, with key spreads narrowing and yields increasing, despite concerns over debt crisis. LGFVs' US dollar notes have returned 3.9% and local bond issuance has reached 2.53 trillion yuan. Authorities appear to be prioritizing economic growth, but signs of strain persist, including delayed bond payments and debtors' pleas for aid. Experts caution that LGFVs are struggling to stay afloat, with 74% of bond investors saying they have no plan to cut their exposure to the sector.

images.alt_text: The PBOC has refrained from cutting interest rates this year and Beijing has been reluctant to sharply increase fiscal spending, concerned by financial stability risks after local government debts soared.
FILE PHOTO: People walk past the logo of China Evergrande Group seen on the Evergrande Center in Shanghai, China September 22, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Global airlines more than double 2023 profit outlook
summary: Global airlines have more than doubled their 2023 profit forecast to $9.8 billion, citing strong travel demand and easing pressure from oil prices. Despite peaking inflation, revenue levels are nearing pre-pandemic levels, with $803 billion expected in 2023. Airlines attribute the surge in demand to high employment levels and consumer confidence, but ongoing challenges such as supply chain issues and rising airport charges are dragging down the industry's recovery. The industry's low profitability is unsustainable, with airlines achieving a profit of $2.25 per passenger.

images.alt_text: Airports say a divergence of fortunes is holding back investment, after staff shortages and other snafus caused backups that ruined many travellers’ vacations last summer.

site_title: Redox, shareholders seek up to US$280 million in Australia IPO
summary: Redox, an Australian chemical distribution firm, is seeking to raise up to US$280 million in its initial public offering (IPO). The IPO will consist of 60% new shares and 40% existing shares, with a price range of A$2.50 to A$2.70 per share. This would value the business at A$1.3 billion to A$1.4 billion. The IPO is being led by UBS Group and is being oversubscribed by priority institutional bidders.

site_title: Veteran Singaporean banker Kevin Lam to head Malaysia’s Hong Leong Bank
summary: Veteran Singaporean banker Kevin Lam Sai Yoke, 55, will become the managing director and CEO of Hong Leong Bank in Malaysia, succeeding Domenic Fuda. Lam has a 30-year banking track record, including a stint as head of UOB's digital banking unit. He aims to build a strong Asean franchise and expand the wealth management business, with Hong Leong Bank emerging from the pandemic strong. Lam's appointment takes effect on July 1.

site_title: Global M&A appetite expected to grow, most bullish on Asia: report
summary: Global merger and acquisition (M&A) activity is expected to rise in 2023, with Asia's M&A-related financing expected to grow the most, according to a report by Norton Rose Fulbright and Mergermarket. 60% of respondents believe securing deal financing will become "somewhat easier" in Asia, while the US and Canada are also expected to see increased M&A activity. Technology, life sciences, and healthcare are expected to be the top three sectors for growth in inbound cross-border M&A. However, challenges such as high financing costs and antitrust regulations remain.

images.alt_text: epa10662794 Visitors view different computer server motherboards during the Computex Taipei 2023, in Taipei, Taiwan, 30 May 2023. According to organizers, this year’s exhibition runs from 30 May till 02 June and features latest tech trends in high performance computing, artificial intelligence application, next-gen connectivity, hyperreality, innovations and startups and sustainability.  EPA-EFE/RITCHIE B. TONGO
The Digital Connectivity Blueprint has plans to enable seamless 10 Gbps connectivity across different network types indoors and outdoors.

site_title: Big US banks face 20% jump in capital requirements, WSJ says
summary: US banks may face a 20% average increase in capital requirements as early as June, according to a report by the Wall Street Journal. The increases will depend on lenders' activities, with institutions with large trading businesses and those heavily dependent on fee income expected to take the biggest hit. The move aims to bolster the industry's financial strength amid the collapse of several smaller lenders this year.

images.alt_text: The FDIC says the US$472 billion in deposit outflows in the first quarter is primarily uninsured funds, as insured deposits actually rose US$255.1 billion, or 2.5 per cent

site_title: Foxconn’s May sales drop 9.5% y/y on smartphone weakness
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics maker, reported May revenue of NT$450.7 billion, a 9.5% drop from the previous year due to weakness in smart consumer electronics, particularly smartphones, during the traditional low season. Revenue was in line with expectations, however, and up 5% from April. The decline was attributed to the company's main business driver, smart consumer electronics.

images.alt_text: Foxconn, which assembles around 70 per cent of iPhones, has been diversifying production away from China, whose strict Covid-19 restrictions disrupted its biggest iPhone plant last year.
The surprise impairment leads some analysts to downgrade their forecasts for Foxconn, the world's largest electronics contract manufacturer and a key Apple supplier.

site_title: Infocomm sector grows 8.6% in 2022; new digital connectivity blueprint to support further growth
summary: Singapore's information and communications sector grew 8.6% in 2022, outpacing the overall economy. A new Digital Connectivity Blueprint aims to support further growth, with plans to enable seamless 10 Gbps connectivity, improve traditional connectivity, and develop local data centers and cloud computing. The blueprint also includes initiatives for physical-digital infrastructure and soft infrastructure, such as quantum-safe networks and digital utility stacks. The government expects the blueprint to catalyze at least S$10 billion in submarine cable investments and achieve full 5G standalone coverage by mid-2025.

images.alt_text: Singapore is developing use cases for 5G technology as it expands coverage.
NetLink Trust currently designs, builds, owns and operates the NBN’s passive fibre network infrastructure.

site_title: Eurozone business growth slowed in May as factories struggled
summary: Eurozone business growth slowed in May, falling to a three-month low of 52.8, below a preliminary estimate of 53.3, according to a survey. The manufacturing sector declined, while the services sector, driven by strong labor markets and rising wages, helped offset the downturn. Overall price pressures decreased, but the services sector increased charges faster, contributing to the slowdown. Despite this, demand for services continued to rise and firms increased headcount at a slower pace.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker transports packaged pasta at De Cecco's factory in Fara San Martino, Italy, November 29, 2021. REUTERS/Remo Casilli/File Photo

site_title: Tree-mendous ride: Wooden Citroen 2CV sells for 210,000 euros
summary: A unique Citroen 2CV, crafted from walnut, pear, apple tree, and cherry wood, has sold for 210,000 euros at an auction in France, setting a new record for the iconic vehicle. The car, in full working order, was purchased by a Paris-based collector who owns a vintage fairground attraction museum. This is believed to be the only wood-made Citroen 2CV in existence, showcasing the car's craftsmanship and attention to detail.

images.alt_text: Ferrari Classiche cars in a garage at the Ferrari factory in Maranello, Italy; Ferraris are the most prized vintage autos, according to Adolfo Orsi, founder of the Classic Car Auction Yearbook, which has been tracking auction sales data since 1990, who described them as “absolutely the blue-chips of this sector”.
While fashion races to halve its greenhouse gas emissions by 2030, the next generation of eco-couturiers could well hail from Singapore.

site_title: JPMorgan turns to blockchain for US dollar trades in India hub
summary: JPMorgan Chase has partnered with six Indian banks to launch a blockchain-based platform for settling US dollar transactions in GIFT City, India's newest international financial hub. The pilot project aims to provide a real-time, 24/7 settlement system, reducing transaction processing time and increasing availability. This move aims to support GIFT City's position as an alternative trading center to Singapore and Dubai, and is part of JPMorgan's effort to analyze banks' experience with the technology. The pilot project will use JPMorgan's blockchain platform Onyx.

site_title: Digital Core Reit manager warns DPU could be halved as second-largest tenant goes bust
summary: Digital Core Reit, a real estate investment trust, warns that its distribution per unit (DPU) could be halved if its second-largest tenant, Cyxtera, a data centre operator, completely eliminates its annual revenue. The tenant filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, representing 22.4% of the Reit's annual rental revenue. The Reit's manager expects aggregate leverage to increase by 200 basis points and total asset value to be reduced by 6%, but believes it can minimize the impact due to below-market rents and favorable fundamentals.

images.alt_text: For H2 FY22, the Reit reported gross revenue of US$54.9 million, up 3.6 per cent from its forecast. However, property expenses were also higher than expected.
DIgital Core Reit's Q1 2023 net property income fell as property expenses went up for the quarter.
Chief executive of Digital Core Reit's manager John Stewart believes that there is still a potential for positive rental reversions as supply remains tight and demand grows for data centre capacity.

site_title: Indonesia plans US$2 billion injection to help troubled state builders
summary: Indonesia's state-owned enterprises ministry plans to inject $2.05 billion into two construction firms, Hutama Karya and Waskita Karya, by 2024 to ease financial troubles. The government aims to help Waskita Karya take over two toll road projects and strengthen Wijaya Karya's capital position. The moves come amid concerns over the balance sheets of Indonesian state construction firms, which have deteriorated due to extensive borrowing to fund infrastructure projects. The capital injections must be approved by parliament.

images.alt_text: At BI’s last policy meeting, it had expected headline inflation to ease to within its target in the third quarter.

site_title: IMDA launches Joint Innovation Centre with Amazon Web Services to spur corporate innovation
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority of Singapore (IMDA) and Amazon Web Services (AWS) have launched a Joint Innovation Centre (JIC) to match corporates with startups, fostering innovation and tech adoption. The centre utilizes the Open Innovation Platform to match issues with problem-solving skills from startups. Corporates can join innovation challenges with prize monies ranging from S$20,000 to S$50,000. AWS provides access to its technologies and networks for startups, and the partnership aims to address the demand and supply of innovation for two years.

images.alt_text: NetLink Trust currently designs, builds, owns and operates the NBN’s passive fibre network infrastructure.
The Digital Connectivity Blueprint has plans to enable seamless 10 Gbps connectivity across different network types indoors and outdoors.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust’s indirect stakeholder says winding-up petition is not a default event
summary: Sino-Ocean Capital Holding's affiliate New Harvest disputes Dasin Retail Trust's substantial shareholder Zhang Zhencheng's claim that a winding-up petition against Sino-Ocean Capital represents a default event. New Harvest states that the termination of the shareholders' agreement is "incorrect" and "invalid", and has notified Zhang to withdraw his termination notice. The hearing of the winding-up petition has been postponed to August 17, and Dasin Retail Trust's units fell 4.5% to S$0.13 after the latest update.

images.alt_text: Substantial unitholder Zhang Zhencheng is suing to remove lead independent director Tan Huay Lim from the manager's board, alleging breaches of fiduciary duties.
Sino-Ocean Capital, an indirect stakeholder in both Dasin Retail Trust and its trustee-manager, is facing a winding-up petition in Hong Kong.
The Carrefour lease in Ocean Metro Mall was originally for a term of 20 years, commencing from Dec 28, 2014, for a total leased area of 17,770 square metres (sq m).
Ocean Metro Mall, one of seven malls in Dasin Retail Trust's portfolio.

site_title: Property groups keen to champion going green, but building social inclusiveness? Maybe not
summary: Property groups in Singapore are prioritizing environmental sustainability, using biophilic design to enhance human well-being and promote biodiversity, but struggle to champion social inclusiveness. Companies like City Developments Limited (CDL) excel in ESG ratings but focus on serving affluent customers, leaving lower-income groups out. CDL's recent loss in the Dow Jones Sustainability World Index highlights the stakes for property groups to prioritize sustainability. Despite this, Singapore's Housing and Development Board (HDB) plays a key role in providing affordable housing, and property groups may need to adapt to meet the needs of a more socially inclusive society.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee

CDL is eager to “pick up the pieces” now that Covid-induced air travel and tourism hiatus is no longer putting M&C – which also happens to be the property group’s biggest subsidiary – on perpetual fire-fighting mode, An said.

The net-zero transition presents opportunities for investors to build confidence, resilience and competitiveness in the wider economy, through profitably financing activities that support sustainable solutions.

site_title: Japanese get trained in 'Hollywood' smiles as masks slowly come off
summary: In post-pandemic Japan, a smile instructor is seeing a surge in demand as customers seek more approachable salespeople and local governments aim to improve residents' well-being. Keiko Kawano's "Hollywood Style Smiling Technique" method, which costs 7,700 yen per hour, has seen a four-fold increase in demand. Many Japanese people, despite the government's mask removal recommendation, continue to wear them daily, with 55% saying they do so as often as before the pandemic. Kawano believes a smile can signify safety and is needed for communication with foreigners, driving a growing need for people to smile.

images.alt_text: Alameda Central park in Mexico City, on Mar 25, 2023; admiring jacarandas blossoms has become an annual event in Mexico City since Japanese immigrant Tatsugoro Matsumoto planted the trees in the capital’s main avenues in the 1920s.

site_title: Nikkei closes at 33-year high; firm Wall Street lifts appetite
summary: Japan's Nikkei index reached a 33-year high, closing at 32,217.43, driven by gains on Wall Street and investors' expectations of the Bank of Japan maintaining ultra-loose policies. The Nikkei jumped 2.2% and the Topix advanced 1.7%, as investors bet on domestic equities. The Bank of Japan's two-day policy meeting, starting June 15, is seen as a key factor in the market's optimism.

site_title: India’s services growth defies inflation pressures: PMI
summary: India's services sector growth slowed slightly to 61.2 in May, but remained at a firm pace despite high inflationary pressures. The S&P Global India services PMI index has held above the 50-mark for 22 months, driven by strong demand and hiring. Input costs rose at the fastest pace this year, but firms passed on the burden to customers at the quickest rate since November. Inflation has been within the target range for two months, leading economists to expect interest rates to stay on hold this year.

images.alt_text: A surge in savings and minimal income disruption to cash-rich home buyers during the pandemic led to a rise in demand that has made the market more resilient to interest rates than initially expected.
Solid growth in the manufacturing sector has been one of the primary drivers of India’s economy over the past few quarters.

site_title: Putting the K in hip-hop: South Korea's Jay Park
summary: Jay Park, a 36-year-old Korean-American entertainer, has overcome a scandalous start to his career to become one of South Korea's most recognizable figures. He debuted as the leader of a K-pop band but was blacklisted after making critical comments online. Park fled Seoul, worked at a used tire shop, and eventually posted a viral YouTube cover of a song, which led to his musical comeback. He has since founded two hip-hop labels and is now establishing a third, focusing on mentorship and "freestyling" over strict training and control. Park attributes his success to grit, determination, and a willingness to challenge the traditional industry model.

images.alt_text: Shares of South Korean entertainment company Hybe Corporation suffered from a US$1.7 billion rout last week after members of Korean pop sensation BTS – managed by Hybe – said they would halt group activities while they focused on individual projects for a while.

site_title: UBS expects to seal Credit Suisse takeover as soon as Jun 12
summary: UBS expects to complete its takeover of Credit Suisse as early as June 12, 2023, creating a giant Swiss bank with a balance sheet of $1.6 trillion. The deal was backed by 200 billion francs in liquidity support from the Swiss central bank and a government commitment to swallow up to 9 billion francs in losses. Credit Suisse shares and ADS will be delisted from the SIX Swiss Exchange and NYSE upon completion. The mega-bank will employ 120,000 worldwide and has announced job cuts to reduce costs.

images.alt_text: The Swiss lenders are in the final stages of completing a combination orchestrated by the government in March as Credit Suisse was teetering on the edge of collapse.
Christian Wolf, who has been based in UBS’ Singapore office since 2009, replaces Axel Granger, who in March was appointed co-head of UBS’ Asia tech investment banking team.

UBS is due to report its earnings on Jul 25, but complexities include unfinalised details of government support in its emergency takeover of Credit Suisse and different accounting systems of the two banks.

site_title: Philippines AirAsia looking to revive IPO plans
summary: Philippine AirAsia, the low-cost airline, is reviving its initial public offering (IPO) plans, aiming to raise up to $250 million next year. CEO Tony Fernandes stated that the airline needs to raise capital, considering market volatility and recession threats in developed nations. Despite this, AirAsia will continue to offer competitive fares and expand its routes.

site_title: Telcos to be called upon for 10Gbps fibre network upgrade in 2024
summary: The Ministry of Communications and Information and Infocomm Media Development Authority announced plans to upgrade Singapore's Nationwide Broadband Network (NBN) to support 10 Gbps broadband speeds by 2024. The upgrade will require cooperation with telcos, building on the existing 98% broadband access rate. The government also allocated 500MHz of extra radio frequency spectrum for Wi-Fi use, enabling speeds of up to 9.6 Gbps. The upgrade aims to improve user experience and pave the way for innovations in areas like logistics.

images.alt_text: Brokers’ take: Analysts see NetLink as a defensive play amid volatility, raise target prices

Revenue for H2 rose 7.5 per cent to S$203.9 million from S$189.7 million. This was due chiefly to higher revenue from ancillary projects, non-building address points (NBAP) and segment connections, residential connections, and colocation orders.
Singtel's operating revenue fell 4.2 per cent to S$7.4 billion, although net profit is up 6.1 per cent to S$1.1 billion.

site_title: Who owns the Benin Bronzes? The answer just got more complicated
summary: The Benin Bronzes, looted by British soldiers in 1897, are at the center of a complex restitution effort. The Nigerian government announced in March that it had transferred ownership of the bronzes to Ewuare II, the current oba of Benin, which has caused anxiety among museums. The Smithsonian Institution, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and the German government had planned to return the bronzes to Nigeria, but the transfer to the oba's private hands has raised questions about the rightful owner. The oba wants the bronzes displayed in museums in Nigeria and around the world, but the Nigerian government and Western institutions are uncertain about how to proceed, sparking a debate about the ownership and display of contested artifacts.

images.alt_text: A general view of the ruins of an ancient spa where around 20 Etruscan and Roman bronze statues were discovered in San Casciano dei Bagni, a hilltop village in southern Tuscany still home to popular thermal baths, Italy.

site_title: ‘Mother of all transitions’: GFanz launches consultation paper on early retirement of coal plants
summary: GFanz, the Asia-Pacific chapter of the Glasgow Financial Alliance for Net Zero, has launched a consultation paper on early retirement of coal plants. The proposed guidelines, open for public comment until August 4, aim to ensure that coal phase-out projects are "credible, financially viable, and inclusive." The three-step process involves assessing plans, optimizing outcomes, and providing transparency and accountability. The guidelines also outline three financing mechanisms to improve economic viability. Financial institutions have welcomed the guidance but highlighted the need for clarity on scaling managed phase-out transactions and compatibility with internal financing policies.

images.alt_text: The responsible financing frameworks of all three local banks do not mention how they will accommodate early coal phase-out projects.
Gillian Tan, MAS’ Chief Sustainability Officer and Assistant Managing Director (Development & International) at her first interview with the media on Tuesday (May 30, 2023) at the MAS Building.
An initial investment plan detailing how Indonesia will green its power supply and cut greenhouse emissions is due mid-August.
Each plant has to be screened for its suitability based on affordability, energy security, and the “people dimension”, said ADB's Ramesh Subramaniam.
Developing Asia – which relies on steady and cheap access to power, currently coal generated for the most part, for economic growth – cannot simply replace coal with renewable energy.
Transition finance has been slow to address the coal challenge, but there are good reasons to be cautious.

site_title: China’s targeted stimulus steps raise doubts about rate cuts
summary: China's targeted economic stimulus measures, including tax breaks for electric vehicles and high-end manufacturing, suggest the government will focus on specific sectors rather than broader stimulus measures like interest rate cuts. The measures aim to boost the economy, but economists believe targeted support is more likely than major policy changes. The government has set a conservative growth target of 5% for the year, and while some economists expect further easing measures, a rate cut is considered unlikely, with a possible reserve ratio reduction instead.

images.alt_text: Most residents and businesses in China pay electricity rates tied to government-set benchmarks, counter to the arguably more robust free market models that prevail in Europe and the US.
Factory activity in May shrank faster than expected on weakening demand, reinforcing the unbalanced feature in the economic recovery.

site_title: India central bank deputy urges banks to address gaps in governance framework
summary: India's Reserve Bank Deputy Governor M Rajeshwar Rao urged banks to strengthen governance frameworks, emphasizing the need for clear expectations, risk management practices, and transparency. He urged boards to set guidelines for management and require regular risk management reports. The RBI has been encouraging banks to avoid financial instability following US bank failures, aiming to build trust with stakeholders and investors. The central bank's governor and deputy governor also emphasized the importance of effective governance and compliance.

site_title: China’s services activity picks up in May on improved demand: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector activity increased in May, with the Caixin/S&P Global services PMI rising to 57.1 from 56.4 in April, driven by a rise in new orders and a boost from the first May Day holiday following China's Covid reopening. However, factory activity shrank faster than expected due to weakening demand, highlighting the unbalanced feature in the economic recovery. The services sector is expected to remain upbeat over the next 12 months, but optimism has eased to its lowest since December 2022.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on September 14, 2021 shows the construction site of an Evergrande housing complexin Zhumadian, central China’s Henan province. - Pummelled by a housing crisis that caused a record-breaking slump in 2022, some Chinese property developers are starting to see light at the end of the tunnel, but analysts warn the sector is still on course to slow down in the long term. (Photo by JADE GAO / AFP)

Firms such as Nio and Li Auto managed to enter China's electric vehicle industry by partnering original equipment manufacturers or through mergers, but regulators may tighten rules to remove such possibilities.

site_title: Singapore’s April retail sales up 3.6%; most industries report yoy gains
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 3.6% year-over-year in April, with food and alcohol, and cosmetics industries posting the highest growth. Excluding motor vehicles, retail sales grew 4.2% year-over-year and 1.5% month-over-month. The growth is attributed to the ongoing international travel recovery and robust local labour market. Retail sales have clocked their 14th consecutive month of on-year growth, with almost all categories seeing year-over-year gains.

images.alt_text: Almost all retail sales categories saw growth in March, according to the latest data from SingStat.

site_title: Australia’s rate outlook in the air as inflation still untamed
summary: About one-third of economists expect the Reserve Bank of Australia to raise its cash rate to 4.1% on Tuesday, amid lingering price pressures and recovering home prices. However, a majority, including Commonwealth Bank of Australia, anticipate a hold at 3.85%. Traders are pricing 50-50 odds, indicating uncertainty. The decision comes as the domestic economy shows signs of slowing, with the RBA's head of Australia economics attributing a 70% chance of a hold, while acknowledging a tightening risk.

images.alt_text: In the keynote address at the Shangri-La Dialogue defence summit in Singapore, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said the future of the Asia-Pacific region was yet to be decided, and it was harmful to assume that a regional war was “inevitable.”
The lowest-paid employees will receive A$22.61 (S$20.10) an hour from Jul 1, based on Reuters calculations.

site_title: Morgan Stanley sees shock 16% US profit drop killing stock rally
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts a 16% drop in US S&P 500 earnings per share this year, contrary to bullish forecasts from other strategists. The investment bank expects a sudden pullback in corporate earnings to halt the US equity rally. Instead, Morgan Stanley recommends an overweight position in Japanese, Taiwanese, and South Korean equities, developed-market government bonds, and the dollar. They also suggest defensive stocks and high-yield bonds for yield-hungry investors. This divergent view contradicts the benchmark bull market following a 19.7% rally since October.

site_title: Hong Kong’s office towers have never been so empty
summary: Hong Kong's office towers are experiencing a record high vacancy rate, with over 13 million square feet of empty space, surpassing 15% of the total grade A office space. Billionaires Li Ka-shing and Lee Shau Kee's projects are struggling, with Cheung Kong Center at 25% vacant and The Henderson building at 30% leased. Rents and sale prices are plummeting, and Western banks are cutting space due to slow dealmaking. Chinese firms are also not filling the void as expected, with a spate of new buildings adding to the glut, making a rebound unlikely.

images.alt_text: The Cheung Kong Center building, which houses the headquarters of CK Hutchison Holdings Ltd. and CK Infrastructure Holdings Ltd. (CKI),  stands in Hong Kong, China, on Monday, July 30, 2018. CK Hutchison is scheduled to release half-year earnings results on Aug. 2. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore stocks open stronger on Monday; STI up 1.5%
summary: Singapore stocks opened stronger on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 1.5% to 3,214.06. The deal to avert a US debt default pushed global markets higher. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB gained, while Seatrium rose 3.3% and Yangzijiang Financial increased 1.5%. US indices, including the Dow Jones, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite, also rose sharply following the signing of the debt agreement and a stronger-than-expected job market report.

images.alt_text: Keppel DC Reit will be replaced by Seatrium as an STI constituent from Jun 19.

site_title: Binance’s regulatory woes pave a path for CEO Zhao’s heir apparent
summary: Binance's CEO, Richard Teng, is emerging as the likely heir apparent following CEO Changpeng "CZ" Zhao's regulatory woes. Teng, a 52-year-old Singaporean, has been appointed head of all regional markets outside the US, a role that could help steer Binance through regulatory challenges. The company faces multiple investigations and lawsuits in the US, Canada, and Australia, including a CFTC lawsuit and a probe into its use by Russians to skirt US sanctions. Teng's appointment signals a shift towards working with regulators, with his resume highlighting a regulatory background and experience in government entities.

images.alt_text: Before joining Binance, Richard Teng held other senior positions in the traditional financial sector.
Binance's global business and a US platform are the subject of a web of probes.
Customers in Australia can still transact using credit or debit cards, Binance said.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend global rally after ‘Goldilocks’ US jobs data
summary: Asian markets extended a global rally after a mixed US jobs report, lifting hopes the Federal Reserve will hold off hiking interest rates this month. The report, dubbed "Goldilocks" due to its balanced tone, suggested the economy was not facing an immediate risk of recession. Asian stocks surged, with Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Sydney gaining, while China's property sector received fresh support. Oil prices also rose after Saudi Arabia announced a surprise output cut. Analysts say the improved sentiment suggests a healthy market with reduced volatility, but warns of potential liquidity issues following the US debt ceiling deal.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Wellington and Manila markets all rose on Thursday, though Seoul and Taipei struggled.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The global shipping market experienced a challenging week, with the capeside market facing disruptions due to holidays. The Atlantic and Pacific regions saw a surplus of tonnage, leading to downward pressure on prices. The capeside timecharter index fell 33% to $9,254, while the Panamax market also declined. In the handysize sector, activity was limited, and rates remained stable. The MR market saw a decline, with the MR Atlantic Triangulation Basket TCE dropping from $36,010 to $32,121. The LNG market saw increased rates across the board, with the BLNG3g rate rising $11,740 per day to $48,531.

images.alt_text: A roundup of the week’s tanker and dry bulk market (May 26, 2023).

site_title: Philippine finance chief rules out return as central bank head
summary: Philippine Finance Secretary Benjamin Diokno ruled out returning to his previous post as central bank head, indicating he will stay in his current role. Diokno stated the next BSP governor should be a professional economist with international stature, not a former banker. The President will announce the next BSP governor in a few days, and current Governor Felipe Medalla can be reappointed. Diokno expressed confidence in staying in his position but acknowledged the President's final say in the matter.

site_title: UBS moves to retain more than 100 Credit Suisse Asia dealmakers
summary: UBS is seeking to retain over 100 Credit Suisse investment bankers in Asia, including senior dealmakers in Korea, Thailand, Vietnam, and India, as part of a merger between the two Swiss lenders. The retention target excludes China, where UBS has held talks with Credit Suisse's country chief executive officer, Janice Hu. The offers will not be effective until after the merger completes, and UBS aims to shore up talent in markets where Credit Suisse has a stronger presence.

images.alt_text: Christian Wolf, who has been based in UBS’ Singapore office since 2009, replaces Axel Granger, who in March was appointed co-head of UBS’ Asia tech investment banking team.

UBS is due to report its earnings on Jul 25, but complexities include unfinalised details of government support in its emergency takeover of Credit Suisse and different accounting systems of the two banks.

site_title: Thai PM frontrunner attends Pride parade, promising same-sex marriage, gender identity rights
summary: Thailand's frontrunner to become prime minister, Pita Limjaroenrat, attended a Pride parade in Bangkok, promising to pass laws allowing same-sex marriage and gender identity rights if he becomes premier. The event, which drew over 50,000 participants, marked Pride month and promoted gender equality. Limjaroenrat's progressive party, Move Forward, is part of a coalition seeking to pass the Marriage Equality Act and other laws to ensure equal rights for all couples, regardless of gender. The move is seen as a significant step towards promoting LGBTQ+ rights in Thailand, a country with a visible but still discriminated-against LGBT community.

images.alt_text: Casinos along the Cotai strip in Macau, China. Photographer: Eduardo Leal/Bloomberg
Pita Limjaroenrat, leader of the Move Forward Party, during a meeting of coalition parties in Bangkok. His party won the most number of votes at the May 14 general election.

site_title: Sonic boom in DC caused by US craft pursuing Cessna that crashed
summary: A US fighter aircraft chasing an unresponsive Cessna jet that crashed in Virginia caused a sonic boom in the Washington area on Sunday. The Cessna 560 Citation V was unresponsive when hailed by authorities, prompting a response from the North American Aerospace Defense Command (Norad). The Norad aircraft, authorized to travel at supersonic speeds, may have produced a sonic boom that was heard by residents. The incident occurred in airspace that has been highly restricted since the 9/11 terrorist attacks.

images.alt_text: Singapore Minister of Defence Ng Eng Hen has encouraged the two superpowers to reopen the lines of communication, echoing calls being made by Asian leaders throughout the three-day forum.

site_title: Further help on the way to drive Singapore businesses to be more water-efficient
summary: Singapore's national water agency PUB will increase funding for water-efficient projects under its Water Efficiency Fund (WEF) to support businesses in water conservation efforts. The funding cap will be raised to S$5 million, and co-funding ratios for water-efficiency assessments and pilot studies will increase to 70%. The moves aim to encourage businesses, especially small and medium enterprises, to undertake bigger water conservation projects, resulting in water savings of about 16 million gallons or 70 million litres a day.

images.alt_text: The Kranji NEWater Factory (above) and the Kranji Water Reclamation Plant will be redeveloped to meet the project increase in used water from upcoming major residential and industrial developments in the north of Singapore, such as Tengah New Town and Sungei Kadut Eco-District.
Water scarcity is acute in Asia
Coastal-protection measures to be carried out in phases

site_title: Bitcoin coders feud over whether to crush US$1 billion frenzy for memecoins
summary: Bitcoin coders are divided over whether to block meme tokens, which have flooded the network and caused record transactions and high processing fees. Some, like Ali Sherief, advocate for deploying software to block the transactions, citing the potential for abuse and disruption to Bitcoin's use for payments and value storage. Others, like Casey Rodarmor, defend the innovation, Ordinals, which allows Bitcoin's blockchain to host large numbers of memecoins and NFTs, arguing it can have wider applications. The controversy highlights the need to scale up Bitcoin's transaction capacity to avoid future traffic jams.

images.alt_text: Jurisdictions like Hong Kong and Dubai are seeking to attract companies, while Singapore plans curbs on retail-investor participation.
Binance's global business and a US platform are the subject of a web of probes.

site_title: Japan’s rapid return of tourists helping fuel inflation for BOJ
summary: Japan's economy is experiencing a boost from a surge in foreign tourists, with nearly two million visitors arriving in April, compared to less than 140,000 a year earlier. This influx of spending is fueling inflation and upward pressure on hospitality-sector pay and prices. The return of foreign tourists is supporting the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) growth plans, with tourism spending accounting for 1.1 percentage points of the annualized growth in the first three months of the year. The BOJ governor aims to see wage and price growth before considering policy changes, and the surge in tourism spending is helping to achieve this goal.

images.alt_text: The final au Jibun Bank Japan Services purchasing managers’ index (PMI) rose in February to a seasonally adjusted 54.0 from January’s 52.3.

site_title: India home prices set to stay above inflation: poll
summary: India's home prices are expected to stay above inflation, with a median forecast of 6.0% for national home prices this year, up from 5.5% in a previous survey. The Reserve Bank of India's 250 basis point repo rate hike is seen as modest compared to other major central banks, and interest rates are expected to stay at 6.50% for the rest of 2023. Despite concerns over affordability, analysts are bullish on the housing market outlook, citing increased demand in luxury and high-end segments.

images.alt_text: Solid growth in the manufacturing sector has been one of the primary drivers of India’s economy over the past few quarters.
India's full-year growth estimate has been revised to 7.2 per cent, above an earlier estimate of 7 per cent.

site_title: Gold eases as firmer dollar counters bets of US Fed pause
summary: Gold prices dropped over 1% on Friday after the US jobs report showed a 339,000 job increase, causing the dollar to strengthen and making gold less affordable for overseas buyers. The dollar index rose 0.2%, offsetting support from prospects of the Federal Reserve pausing rate hikes this month. As of Monday, spot gold was down 0.1% at $1,945.66 per ounce, while US gold futures fell 0.3% to $1,963.10.

images.alt_text: The dollar slipped, making bullion cheaper for holders of other currencies, while 10-year Treasury yields hit a two-week low.

site_title: DFI puts Jelita Shopping Centre on the market with S$85 million guide price
summary: DFI Retail Group is selling the 4-decade-old Jelita Shopping Centre in Singapore for a guide price of S$85 million, equivalent to S$2,528 psf on the existing NLA of 33,621 sq ft. The mall is anchored by DFI's Cold Storage supermarket brand and has a secondary listing on the Singapore Exchange. The group is seeking a buyer to enter into a long-term leaseback agreement, with options to lease back the ground floor or entire building. The site has significant redevelopment potential, with a rare 999-year tenure and a 2.2 plot ratio under the Master Plan.

images.alt_text: Mercatus said sale and purchase agreements were entered into on Wednesday with various subsidiaries of Link Reit to divest the group’s entire interest in Jurong Point and Swing By @ Thomson Plaza.

krmercatus16 - AMK Hub



Source: Mercatus Co-operative Limited
Frasers Centrepoint and sponsor Frasers Property has acquired a 50 per cent stake in NEX for S$652.5 million
DFI's Q1 grocery retail sales in South-east Asia were impacted by cautious customer shopping behaviour due to rising cost of living pressures.

site_title: Japan’s service activity expands at record pace in May: PMI
summary: Japan's service sector activity expanded at a record pace in May, with the au Jibun Bank Japan Services purchasing managers' index (PMI) rising to 55.9, its highest level since September 2007. This marks the ninth consecutive month of expansion, driven by a recovery in overseas demand and a surge in foreign tourists as pandemic restrictions eased further. Service sector companies also hired more workers for the fourth month in a row, with the rate of job creation the second fastest since 2007.

images.alt_text: Children held by their parents start their "Baby-cry Sumo" match, resumed for the first time in four years due to the Covid-19 coronavirus pandemic, at the Sensoji temple in Tokyo on April 22, 2023. (Photo by Philip FONG / AFP)

site_title: Barclays makes 2 senior appointments for Singapore office
summary: Barclays Private Bank has made two senior appointments in its Singapore office. Tom Road, who has 13 years of experience in London, will become deputy head of Barclays Private Bank, Singapore, focusing on ultra-high-net-worth and global family offices. Loh Wengmun, with over 30 years of industry experience, will join as head of dealing and derivatives, building the bank's capital markets and trading capabilities. The appointments aim to strengthen Barclays' presence in Singapore and meet the needs of family offices and UHNW clients in the region.

images.alt_text: The personnel change is also part of the bank’s effort to enhance female leadership across its global markets business in Asia-Pacific.
Venkatakrishnan told Barclays staff earlier this month that he is in remission after getting treatment for non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

site_title: China sets out proposals to underpin its massive renewables push
summary: China is proposing measures to prevent power bottlenecks and support its massive renewable energy push. The National Development and Reform Commission has announced plans to bolster grid operator finances, create flexible pricing, and encourage demand response. These steps aim to make China's power system more efficient and absorb a bigger share of clean energy. The government is also working to improve energy storage, with a fixed fee on 56 gigawatts of pumped hydropower energy storage projects. China aims to build an integrated power trading market by 2025, allowing supply and demand to play a bigger role in setting prices.

images.alt_text: Factory activity in May shrank faster than expected on weakening demand, reinforcing the unbalanced feature in the economic recovery.
China's shoppers account for about a fifth of the US$325 billion global luxury market, PwC estimates, and it’s weighing all the more now as the US heads for a possible second-half recession.

site_title: Saudi Arabia goes alone at Opec+ with million-barrel output cut
summary: Saudi Arabia has announced a 1 million barrel-a-day oil supply cut in July, taking its production to its lowest level in several years. The move, made by the kingdom alone, aims to bolster the price of its most important export and is seen as a test of wills between Saudi Arabia and bearish oil speculators. The decision comes after previous cuts failed to deliver a sustained price rally, and the rest of the 23-nation Opec+ coalition pledged to maintain existing cuts until the end of 2024.

images.alt_text: Opec+ pumps around 40 per cent of the world’s crude, meaning its policy decisions can have a major impact on oil prices.
The International Energy Agency expects global oil demand to rise further in the second half of 2023, potentially boosting oil prices.
The market’s focus has also shifted to a Jun 4 meeting of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and allies including Russia, collectively called Opec+.

site_title: Blackstone, Goldman lead EQT’s £1.25 billion direct loan deal
summary: Blackstone and Goldman Sachs Asset Management are leading a £1.25 billion direct lending deal to support EQT's purchase of Dechra Pharmaceuticals. Blackstone and Goldman are committing £400 million each, with other private credit lenders including CVC Capital Partners, KKR & Co, and PSP Investments, also participating. This deal highlights private credit lenders' increasing presence in traditional debt markets, and EQT's acquisition reinforces the role of private credit in European capital markets, according to Blackstone's head of UK origination.

images.alt_text: EQT will pay £38.75 (S$65.3) per Dechra share in cash, the companies said on Friday (Jun 2), lower than the £40.70 it proposed in April.

site_title: UK widens lead as Europe’s top draw for financial investors
summary: The UK has solidified its position as Europe's top destination for financial investors, securing 76 financial service projects in 2022, a 17% increase from the previous year. The UK accounts for 26% of all European financial services FDI projects, despite economic and political challenges. American investment, particularly from US-backed projects, contributed to the growth. The UK remains the most attractive European financial services market, according to EY, with 69% of investors planning to establish or extend financial services operations in the UK over the next year.

images.alt_text: UK government officials have been assessing the impact and potential duration of the current high levels of inflation, and believe the economy should recover sufficiently for Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt to announce a tax cut in April.

Striking teachers march during joint strike action by train drivers, teachers, university staff and civil servants, in Leeds, UK, on Wednesday, Feb. 1, 2023. The day of coordinated industrial action is expected to be Britain’s most severe day of strikes for over a decade, piling pressure on Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s Conservative administration to resolve disputes with public sector workers by making more generous offers on pay. Photographer: Dominic Lipinski/Bloomberg

site_title: Sembcorp exploring sale of waste management unit; early talks started with selected parties
summary: Sembcorp Industries is exploring the sale of its waste management unit, SembWaste, as part of its strategic initiatives to maximize shareholder value. Preliminary discussions with selected parties have begun, with HSBC acting as the financial adviser. The company emphasizes that the discussions are still preliminary and no definitive deal has been reached. This follows a previous statement that there was no definitive deal to sell SembWaste, which led to a 2.9% increase in the company's shares to an eight-year high of S$4.73.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Industries' statement comes in response to a Reuters article about the potential sale of the group's waste and recycling management unit, SembWaste.

site_title: Verstappen wins in Spain to continue Red Bull sweep
summary: Max Verstappen won the Spanish Grand Prix from pole position, securing his fifth win of the season and third in a row. The victory stretched his Formula One lead to 53 points, as Red Bull continued its sweep of the season with its seventh success in as many races. Lewis Hamilton finished second for Mercedes, while George Russell completed the podium. Verstappen's teammate Sergio Perez finished fourth, and he secured the bonus point for fastest lap.

images.alt_text: CEO Toshihiro Mibe said the 2026 regulations and Formula One’s push for sustainability were in line with Honda’s carbon neutrality goals.

site_title:
Companies wary of public perception
as they seek optimal path to net zero
summary: Companies are navigating the path to net zero while being cautious of public perception. A roundtable panel discussion highlighted the importance of transparency, stakeholder engagement, and aligning brand values with sustainable goals. Panelists from the banking, tourism, and energy sectors emphasized the need for clear payback on investment and the role of consumer education in driving sustainability. Companies are also exploring new financing models and partnerships to support the energy transition, with trillions of dollars needed to drive decarbonization. Ultimately, successful net-zero journeys require a strategic intent and adaptable targets.

images.alt_text: Schneider Electric and BT event: Navigating to Net Zero in a fast changing world
A survey conducted by Schneider Electric found that linking executive remuneration to decarbonisation progress could drive companies’ green plans.

site_title: Why resigning after collecting a bonus may not be the smartest thing for an employee to do
summary: A former employee in Singapore was ordered to return a discretionary bonus after resigning shortly after receiving it, despite the company having declared the bonus and paying it out. The court ruled that the company's employment contract included a clause allowing it to claw back the bonus if the employee resigned before a certain period, which the employee had failed to note. The case highlights the importance of carefully reviewing employment contracts and company policies, and the potential consequences of not doing so.

images.alt_text: As deals dry up, bonuses for investment bankers are forecast to shrink 10 per cent to 20 per cent.

A Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp cargo ship arriving in Busan, South Korea.  The company did so well that it is awarding its workers up to 30 months salary on their next payday as a bonus. Shareholders approved the move.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Seatrium, Keppel DC Reit, DFI, LHN Logistics
summary: Keppel DC Reit will be replaced by Seatrium as a Straits Times Index (STI) constituent starting June 19, following a quarterly review by FTSE Russell. DFI Retail Group is seeking a buyer for its Jelita Shopping Centre at a guide price of S$85 million. LHN Logistics will be the target of a voluntary general offer by Milkyway Chemical at S$0.2266 per share. Trading halts were called for by Matex International, GRP, BlackGold Natural Resources, and Digital Core Reit on Monday morning.

site_title: This headline has 13 words. How much did you expect it to say?
summary: Journalists struggle to balance the need for brevity and completeness in headlines, as readers often only click on attention-grabbing titles. Despite guidelines on concise headline writing, some headlines still prioritize sensationalism over accuracy. Studies show that clickbait headlines can hurt source credibility, but also lead to increased engagement. Newsrooms are torn between meeting reader expectations and maintaining journalistic integrity, with some opting for headlines that prioritize clicks over substance.

images.alt_text: To cultivate these talents, media and journalism programmes in schools will need to make a culture shift towards developing audience-centric, product thinking mindsets and digital product management capabilities in students.
News sites like CNA, Mothership.sg and The Straits Times are courting Gen Z on TikTok.
SPH assistant general manager Cheah Cheng Poh at a briefing to launch BT Online in June 1995.

site_title: ‘Across the Spider-Verse’ spins box office with US$120.5 million debut
summary: "Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse" debuted with a US$120.5 million opening weekend in the US, surpassing estimates and becoming the second-biggest opening weekend of the year. The film's worldwide total is US$208.6 million, with a 95% critic score and 96% audience score on Rotten Tomatoes. Producer Amy Pascal announced plans for more Spider-Verse projects, including live-action films.

images.alt_text: Disney’s budget for Little Mermaid was around US$250 million.

site_title: Investing CPF savings: Low-cost portfolios are now within easy reach
summary: The Lifetime Retirement Investment Scheme (LRIS) for Central Provident Fund (CPF) savings is now largely available, offering low-cost, lifecycle portfolios. Digital advisers like Endowus and MoneyOwl have lowered investment costs, making it possible for individuals to invest at significant cost savings. Endowus has onboarded institutional share classes of funds with lower annual management fees, while MoneyOwl features retrocession-free funds. The inclusion of passive index funds, such as Amundi index funds, has expanded investment options. However, the CPFIS remains saddled with legacy issues, including a large number of funds and limited globally diversified exchange-traded funds.

images.alt_text: Savvy investors have been applying to invest their CPF savings – particularly OA funds with lower yields – with many opting for Singapore Treasury bills.

site_title: Airbus predicts supply crunch with widebodies as travel rebounds
summary: Airbus predicts a supply crunch for widebody aircraft as travel rebounds, citing complex manufacturing processes and supply chain disruptions. The company is already sold out of its A321neo until 2029 and is focusing on delivering its more expensive widebody models to existing partnerships. To ease constraints, Airbus plans to increase A350 production to nine a month by 2025 and lift A330neo production to four a month by 2024. This follows a slower-than-expected delivery pace last year due to supply bottlenecks, with Airbus aiming to deliver 720 jets in 2023.

images.alt_text: Airports say a divergence of fortunes is holding back investment, after staff shortages and other snafus caused backups that ruined many travellers’ vacations last summer.

FILE PHOTO: Planes of German air carrier Lufthansa are parked as Lufthansa pilots start a strike over a wage dispute, at the airport in Frankfurt, Germany September 2, 2022.  REUTERS/Kai Pfaffenbach/File Photo

site_title: After month of pain, euro bulls look to Fed pause for relief
summary: Investors are increasingly optimistic about the euro, viewing recent weakness as a buying opportunity due to diverging interest-rate trajectories between the US and Europe. Despite a shaky economic outlook, the euro could push above 1.10 in the second half of the year as markets anticipate US rate cuts. Traders are betting on an 80% chance of a 25-basis-point rate cut by the Fed by December, while the European Central Bank is expected to lower rates later next year.

images.alt_text: The dollar climbed 0.8 per cent against the yen during the week, on track for its largest weekly percentage rise since mid-May.

site_title: Top priority for countries in coming decade is to prevent conflict in Asia: Ng Eng Hen
summary: Singaporean Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen emphasized the importance of preventing physical conflict in Asia in the coming decade. He cited the need for open communication channels between the US and China to de-escalate and avoid conflict, particularly in the South China Sea and Taiwan Strait. The minister noted that the US-China relationship is central to the stability of Asia and the Indo-Pacific region, and that the lack of regular communication between the two powers is detrimental to the region's security. By 2030, Japan's military budget is expected to reach over $60 billion, and Ng urged Japan to reassure its neighbors, including China, about its defense policy to maintain stability in South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: Singapore Minister of Defence Ng Eng Hen has encouraged the two superpowers to reopen the lines of communication, echoing calls being made by Asian leaders throughout the three-day forum.

site_title: European equities’ outperformance seen as unsustainable
summary: European equities' outperformance is seen as unsustainable due to a gloomy macroeconomic backdrop, including a technical recession in Germany, the eurozone's largest economy. The Euro Stoxx 50 Futures contract has fallen by 1.25% last week but is still up 12.76% year-to-date. Analysts believe that the year's outperformance is fueled by fading positive catalysts, such as China's reopening, and that inflation persistence will lead to a higher-for-longer interest-rate regime in the Eurozone. A bearish outlook is maintained, predicting continued downward pressure on the contract and a potential decline to test dynamic support levels.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 1.1 per cent lower on Wednesday, after hitting its lowest level since March 30.

site_title: US dollar jumps after surprise May payrolls boost
summary: The US dollar surged 0.8% against the yen, its largest weekly percentage rise since mid-May, following a surprise 339,000 increase in May's non-farm payrolls. The dollar index also rose, with a 0.435% gain, as traders weigh the possibility of the US Federal Reserve skipping a rate hike in June. Despite strong hiring, the jobless rate rose to 3.7%, and the dollar index slid 0.62% on Thursday due to Fed officials' signals and a bill suspending the debt ceiling.

images.alt_text: Japanese yen and U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration picture taken June 16, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration
The US dollar index, which measures the greenback against six major peers, climb to 104.63, its highest since Mar 16.

site_title: ARA H-Trust poised to ride growing wave of ‘bleisure’ travellers
summary: ARA H-Trust, a US-focused hospitality trust, is poised to benefit from the growing demand for "bleisure" travelers who combine work and leisure trips. Despite being undervalued, the trust has shown continuous improvement in revenue and net property income, with a 29.3% increase in revenue and 66.4% increase in net property income in 2022. CEO Lee Jin Yong attributes the recovery to the shift in consumer behavior, with people now viewing travel as a basic right. ARA H-Trust anticipates more upside as business and group travel segments return, and the trust's hotels are popular with both guests and investors.

images.alt_text: While the stress on the office sector may not be new, the shift to working from home has exacerbated the problem.
Accelerated global travel recovery saw most of CDLHT’s portfolio markets experience robust performance growth in FY22.
ARA H-Trust expects the outlook for the US lodging market to remain optimistic, outweighing economic uncertainty and geopolitical risks.

site_title: The hefty (BTO) price of being a romantic
summary: A delay in purchasing a HDB BTO flat can result in a significant opportunity cost. The author, who has been asked when they plan to buy a BTO flat, is hesitant due to concerns about the speed of the process. Their colleague views this as being overly cautious, likening it to being a "romantic." However, the author believes that rushing into a purchase can lead to regret and financial losses.

images.alt_text: Maybe more help can be extended on the homeownership front to local couples who bust the income ceiling to buy BTO flats.

Parc Meadow @ Tengah will have 15 residential blocks, ranging from 12 to 13 storeys.

For first-timers and especially young households, BTO flats may make the most financial sense. 
First-timers should choose homes they can best afford, and BTO flats are considered the most affordable housing in today’s market.
The number of households and grant amount given out have increased each year since, in line with more flats being sold.

site_title: Sunak mulls 2 pence tax cut before UK election
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is considering a 2p tax cut, either National Insurance or income tax, before the general election in April to boost the economy. The move aims to encourage people to return to work, following high inflation levels. Sunak made a 20% tax cut pledge last year, but prioritized income tax in the leadership race. The potential tax cut is seen as a response to the economy's current state, with Chancellor Jeremy Hunt set to announce a tax cut in April.

site_title: Housing affordability or a premium for good housing?
summary: Singapore's housing market is experiencing high prices, with private homes boasting a median price of US$1.2 million, surpassing Hong Kong. The affordability ratio stands at 13.7, placing private homes in the "unaffordable" range. However, public housing is considered "most attainable" in the 2023 Asia Pacific Home Attainability Index, indicating a contrast between affordable public housing and unaffordable private housing.

images.alt_text: The opportunity cost of delaying attempts to purchase a HDB BTO flat can be huge.
About 70 per cent of the poll’s respondents expect residential property in the CCR to bear the brunt of the new measures.
Rental prices and volumes rise across the condominium and HDB markets in APril.
ULI notes that the median price of Singapore’s private-sector homes now stands at US$1.20 million, compared with Hong Kong at US$1.16 million.
The highest transacted price in April stands at S$18 million for a resale unit at Sculptura Ardmore.

site_title: Singapore banks caught in grey area as regional financial sector moves to OK coal phase-out
summary: Singapore's three major banks - DBS, OCBC, and UOB - face uncertainty in financing early coal phase-out projects due to unclear policies. Despite the Association of Southeast Asian Nations' (Asean) Taxonomy's inclusion of coal phase-out in its sustainable financing framework, the banks' responsible financing frameworks lack guidance on accommodating such projects. This creates uncertainty, potentially delaying their participation in the emerging market of transition finance. Industry sources suggest the banks may review their coal policies before taking on coal phase-out projects, which could impact their decarbonization goals and reputations.

images.alt_text: Gillian Tan, MAS’ Chief Sustainability Officer and Assistant Managing Director (Development & International) at her first interview with the media on Tuesday (May 30, 2023) at the MAS Building.
Each plant has to be screened for its suitability based on affordability, energy security, and the “people dimension”, said ADB's Ramesh Subramaniam.
Transition finance has been slow to address the coal challenge, but there are good reasons to be cautious.
Developing Asia – which relies on steady and cheap access to power, currently coal generated for the most part, for economic growth – cannot simply replace coal with renewable energy.

Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong at the launch of NUS Sustainable and Green Finance Institute on Thursday (April 20) with Hsieh Fu Hua, chairman of NUS board of trustees, Professor Tan Eng Chye, NUS President and Professor Sumit Agarwal, managing director of the institute.
