site_title: Singapore, Australia to invest A$20 million in new green co-innovation programme for SMEs
summary: Singapore and Australia announced a new A$20 million (S$17.8 million) green co-innovation programme, the Go-Green Co-Innovation Programme (GGCIP), to drive co-innovation between small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in green products and services. The programme will support SMEs from both countries over the next four years, focusing on sectors like renewable energy, sustainable agriculture, and waste management. This is part of the landmark Singapore-Australia Green Economy Agreement, signed in October 2022, and aims to deepen cooperation in the green economy and other areas.

images.alt_text: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese at the joint press conference for the 7th Annual Leaders' Meeting in Canberra on Oct 18.
Singapore’s Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong (left) and Australia’s Minister for Trade and Tourism Don Farrell signed the GEA in the presence of both prime ministers.

site_title: In distorted Buenos Aires rental market, it's dollar versus peso
summary: Argentina's rental market has become distorted due to high inflation and a weakening currency, favoring dollar-wielding foreigners over locals. Property owners are reluctant to accept pesos, leading to a shortage of affordable rentals, with many opting to leave properties empty or rent informally. The country's 2020 rent regulation law, intended to protect tenants, has inadvertently worsened the situation. The Buenos Aires municipality estimates 130,000 empty properties, while 70,000 registered rentals cannot meet the demand of 500,000 households.

images.alt_text: Argentina’s fragile economic situation has been aggravated by a historic drought since last year.

site_title: US: Stocks rise as Nasdaq soars to 13-month high
summary: US stocks rose sharply on Friday, closing the week on a high, driven by a bumper jobs report and a deal in Congress to avert a US debt default. The Nasdaq Composite Index soared 1.1% to a 13-month high, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also rose. The deal eased market fears of a potentially catastrophic debt default, with the "fear gauge" sinking to its lowest level since before the Covid-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - JANUARY 09: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during afternoon trading on January 09, 2023 in New York City. The stock market closed with mixed results after opening on a high note with the Dow Jones and S & P 500 both closing on losses and Nasdaq closing with a second day of gains.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., May 30, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Evergrande unit faces 1,426 lawsuits involving US$49 billion
summary: Evergrande Group faces over 1,400 lawsuits worth approximately US$49 billion related to its mainland property unit Hengda Real Estate Group, with debts totaling around 272.5 billion yuan. The cases involve unpaid debts and disputes, underscoring the challenges for the embattled property developer in restructuring its borrowings. Evergrande has yet to win enough creditor support for its overseas debt restructuring plan, and the company's financial troubles have raised concerns about China's property sector, which remains a major financial risk to the country's economy.

images.alt_text: Evergrande says the enforcement notice requires it to pay compensation of about 770 million yuan (S$148.1 million) to the claimant, among other required payments.

site_title: Ride-hailing, COE prices and Singapore’s car-lite goal
summary: Singapore's car-lite goal aims to reduce private car ownership, but a free market may not determine the most efficient ratio of ride-hailing and shared-car services. The country's car prices surged in the past decade due to falling supply and robust demand. In contrast, a similar Toyota Corolla hybrid can be purchased for as low as US$27,000 in New York, while in Singapore, the price is around S$209,888, highlighting the country's high private car prices.

images.alt_text: The COE as a one-size-fits-all traffic management tool is too blunt, given the technology we have today.
Government studying COE market, ready to refine it if needed: Iswaran

site_title: Village garbage man helps unearth ancient bronze statues in Tuscany
summary: A retired Italian garbage man, Stefano Petrini, helped discover a collection of ancient bronze statues in Tuscany, considered one of Italy's most significant archaeological finds in decades. The 20 Etruscan and Roman statues, dating from the 3rd century BC to the 1st century AD, were found in the ruins of an ancient spa in San Casciano dei Bagni. Petrini's intuition led archaeologists to the site, where they uncovered statues, coins, and other artifacts, including a 2,000-year-old lock of curly hair. The statues are set to go on display in Rome's Quirinale Palace from June 22 after months of restoration.

images.alt_text: Egypt has carried out extensive digging operations in Saqqara and other ancient locations in recent years, which resulted in a number of high-profile discoveries.

site_title: Global inflows help Indian stocks become Asia’s top gainers
summary: Overseas investors purchased a net $5 billion of Indian shares in May, the highest since August, propelling the nation's equities to the top of emerging Asia's leaderboard this quarter. The Nifty 50 Index rallied over 6% due to India's resilient domestic economy. Global funds are optimistic about India's growth prospects, with GQG's chief investment officer predicting it will yield double-digit corporate earnings for the next five years. This buying spree is driven by concerns over China's recovery and a potential US downturn.

site_title: Australia raises minimum wage by 5.75% as living costs surge
summary: Australia's Fair Work Commission has raised the minimum wage by 5.75% from July 1, affecting over two million workers. The new wage is A$22.61 per hour, up from A$21.38. The decision aims to help low-paid employees meet basic financial needs amid soaring living costs. Some economists worry the increase may set a benchmark for other wage expectations and complicate inflation control. The move follows a decade-high 3.7% aggregate wage growth.

site_title: Gold climbs as rate hike bets ebb after weaker US data
summary: Gold prices rose to a one-week peak, reaching $1,976.81 per ounce, after weaker US economic data and expectations of the Federal Reserve skipping an interest rate hike. The dollar slipped, making gold cheaper for holders of other currencies, while 10-year Treasury yields hit a two-week low. The US manufacturing sector contracted for the seventh straight month, and new jobless claims increased modestly. The Fed's decision on rates is seen as uncertain, with 75% chance of rates remaining unchanged in June.

images.alt_text: In the physical market, India slashed the base import prices of gold and silver as prices on the world market corrected.
Most precious metals have fallen in price, except for gold. Silver and copper are down 4.7 per cent and 3.9 per cent, respectively, this year. Gold, meanwhile, is up 7.2 per cent.
The dollar index held firm, making bullion less attractive for holders of other currencies.

site_title: Building healthy workspace and cutting carbon footprint can go hand in hand
summary: Landlords are incorporating design features to create healthy workspaces, minimizing the risk of COVID-19 transmission. High-performance air filters and ultraviolet germicidal irradiation systems are being used in state-of-the-art designs, such as Guoco Tower. As hybrid working becomes the new norm, protecting employee health and wellness is crucial. Many firms are reconfiguring workspaces to support flexible practices, like hot-desking arrangements. This shift prioritizes employee health, acknowledging the importance of minimizing human contact in reducing virus transmission.

images.alt_text: Under the newly introduced Mandatory Energy Improvement regime, "energy-intensive" buildings will have to undergo audits on their energy use.
The overall Marina Bay District cooling network will operate at a total capacity of up to 90,000 RT, said SP Group.
The modern design inconspicuously incorporates water- and energy-conservation features.

site_title: Lululemon outlook lift thrills Wall Street as yogawear stays in vogue
summary: Lululemon's annual sales and profit forecasts were raised due to strong demand for its activewear, despite inflation and wider retail spending concerns. The company's shares surged 13% after hours, driven by a strong rebound in China, easing air freight costs, and tighter inventory control. Lululemon expects full-year 2023 revenue between $9.44 billion and $9.51 billion and annual profit between $11.74 and $11.94 per share. The company's sales increased 24% and net revenue rose 24% to $2 billion in the first quarter, beating estimates.

images.alt_text: US retailers shun indoor malls, shift to open-air centres
E-commerce battles sales fatigue and hiccups in quest for consumers' wallets
Tesla, Lululemon, Mastercard among top future-ready companies on aggressiveness, digitisation: IMD
Lululemon forecasts strong 2022, plans selective price hikes
FILE PHOTO: A shopper walks out of the Lululemon Athletica store in New York, December 16, 2013.  REUTERS/Shannon Stapleton  (UNITED STATES - Tags: BUSINESS FASHION TEXTILE)/File Photo

site_title: Rich Latin Americans transform laid-back Madrid into a new Miami
summary: Mexican investors have transformed Madrid into a luxury destination, with over 700 million euros spent on Spanish real estate and construction since 2020. The influx of wealthy Latin Americans has driven up property prices, creating a sizzling hot high-end dining scene in the city's Salamanca district. The trend is changing the face of Madrid, with luxury properties and restaurants sprouting up at a rapid pace. Many Mexicans are also looking for business opportunities, with some owning stakes in Spanish real estate firms. The city's low crime rate and affordable luxury properties are attracting the wealthy, making Madrid a new Miami.

images.alt_text: Households are benefiting from a strong labour market, meaning fewer people are likely to stop paying back their mortgage due to unemployment, says the ECB.

site_title: Fed emergency lending to banks ticks down in latest week
summary: US Federal Reserve's emergency lending to banks decreased to $188.1 billion in the latest week, down from $192.6 billion the previous week, according to Fed data. This decline was driven by a decrease in "other credit" and government wind-downs of failed banks. Discount window loans also fell to $4 billion, down from $4.2 billion on May 24. The Bank Term Funding Program loans rose to $93.6 billion, from $91.9 billion the previous week. The decline suggests easing bank sector stress.

site_title: Exxon CEO says technology advances could double its shale output
summary: ExxonMobil CEO Darren Woods aims to double the company's US shale oil output over a five-year period using new technologies. Currently, Exxon recovers about 10% of shale resources, and Woods believes that new technologies will significantly improve recovery volumes. The goal is to reach 900,000-1 million barrels per day in the Permian Basin by 2027, with the potential to unlock more oil from existing fields. Developing technology in-house will also allow Exxon to better identify acquisition targets and create a larger deal space.

images.alt_text: ExxonMobil is the only one of the five Western oil majors with no 2030 target for reducing customers’ carbon emissions from its products.
The Exxon case was set for a jury trial in Washington starting May 24.
FILE PHOTO: The Exxon Mobil Corp building is pictured in Georgetown, Guyana February 18, 2022. REUTERS/Sabrina Valle/File Photo

site_title: Design competencies needed for a complex and digital future
summary: Singapore's design industry is expected to grow by 25% by 2030, with two-thirds of its designers working in non-design sectors. Design competencies, such as problem-solving, creativity, and critical thinking, are essential for the new digital world. The Design Education Advisory Committee (DEAC) has proposed a 30-year plan to nurture design sensibilities among the population and provide recommendations for design education. The plan includes infusing design as a life skill, championing transdisciplinary learning, and promoting people and planet-driven design. Singapore aims to equip its workforce with design sensibilities to navigate complex challenges, including technological advancements and climate change.

images.alt_text: Building Singapore's next generation of creative problem solvers

In line with the new Jobs Transformation Map (JTM) for food services, trade associations and chambers in the sector have committed to work with over 800 member companies, employing around 80,000 workers, to transform their jobs.

site_title: Senate passes debt limit bill, staving off a calamitous default
summary: The US Senate passed a bipartisan debt limit bill, suspending the debt ceiling until January 2025 and avoiding a potential default. The bill, which increases Pentagon spending to $886 billion, also includes new spending levels and policy changes on energy project permitting and work requirements on social benefits. The measure was approved on a 63-36 vote, sending it to President Joe Biden for signature. The agreement is seen as a big win for the economy and the American people, but some Republicans expressed concerns about the level of spending and the need for additional funding.

images.alt_text: U.S. Capitol police stand outside the Capitol building as the Senate votes on debt ceiling legislation to avoid a historic default at the U.S. Capitol in Washington, U.S., June 1, 2023. REUTERS/Evelyn Hockstein

The Republican-controlled House voted 314-117 to send the legislation to the Senate, which must enact the measure and get it to President Joe Biden’s desk before a Monday deadline, when the federal government is expected to run out of money to pay its bills.
McCarthy, a California Republican, has repeatedly said that he would secure the support of a majority of his conference for the bill itself.

US Representative Thomas Massie wears a pin displaying the amount of the US national debt during a House Committee on Rules hearing about whether to raise the United States' debt ceiling and avoid a catastrophic default, at the US Capitol in Washington, May 30, 2023.
Both Democratic President Joe Biden and the top Republican in Congress, House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, have predicted they will get enough votes to pass it into law before Monday.
The deal still faces a difficult path to pass through Congress before the government runs out of money to pay its debts in early June.
Unemployment is at its lowest in more than a half-century, at 3.4 per cent, thanks to historically high demand for workers.

As Democratic and Republican negotiators iron out the final details of an agreement to suspend the federal government’s US$31.4 trillion debt ceiling in coming days, House Speaker Kevin McCarthy may be forced to do some behind-the-scenes wrangling.

site_title: The Gap beats shareholder lawsuit over commitment to diversity
summary: The 9th US Circuit Court of Appeals ruled in favor of The Gap Inc, stating that a corporate bylaw requiring shareholder derivative litigation to be filed in Delaware Chancery Court is enforceable. The ruling, which came in a 6-5 decision, cements a split among federal appeals courts on how forum selection provisions apply to derivative suits alleging violations of the federal Securities and Exchange Act. The court rejected claims that enforcing the clause would allow the company to avoid litigation and waive federal securities law obligations.

images.alt_text: Gap has yet to hire a new CEO since Sonia Syngal was ousted last July.

site_title: Manchester United aim to rewrite history with FA Cup glory at noisy neighbours’ expense
summary: Manchester United manager Erik ten Hag is aiming to rewrite history by winning the FA Cup, potentially ending Manchester City's treble bid. The match, on Saturday, comes 12 years after City defeated United in the FA Cup semi-final at Wembley. A United win would also give them a chance to join the 1999 United team as the only English club to win the EPL, Champions League, and FA Cup in the same campaign. United's resurgent performance has made City's treble bid under threat, with the Citizens needing just two victories to complete their historic feat.

images.alt_text: PSG's French forward Kylian Mbappe gives a thumbs up after receiving the Best Ligue 1 Player award during the 31th edition of the UNFP (French National Professional Football players Union) trophy ceremony in Paris, May 28, 2023.
Financial experts estimate promotion to Premier League to be worth around £170 million for Luton that have been through turmoil since they last played in the top flight 31 years ago.

(FILES) France's Yannick Noah (L) shakes hands with Sweden's Mats Wilander (R) while stepping over the net, after victory in their men's singles final match of The Roland Garros 1983 French Open tennis tournament in Paris on June 5, 1983. It's been 40 years since a French player last won the men's singles title at Roland Garros and Yannick Noah's 1983 achievement is unlikely to be matched this year when the second major of the season starts on May 28, 2023. (Photo by DOMINIQUE FAGET / AFP)
Saudi Arabia aims to bring Argentinian maestro Lionel Messi to the kingdom, where Portuguese football icon Cristiano Ronaldo plays for Al-Nassr.

site_title: SoftBank shares swept up in AI chip frenzy ahead of Arm IPO
summary: SoftBank shares surged 5% in early trading on June 2, 2023, reaching a 17% gain since last week's close, driven by a frenzy for semiconductor and AI-related stocks ahead of Arm's IPO. Despite a 6.4% year-to-date gain, SoftBank's shares still trail behind chipmakers like Nvidia and semiconductor indexes. Analysts, including Jefferies, upgraded their recommendations on SoftBank, citing the expected Arm IPO and enthusiasm for AI-related stocks.

images.alt_text: SoftBank’s founder Masayoshi Son says he hopes the ARM IPO can be the largest ever by a chip company.
FILE PHOTO: People pass by an electronic screen showing Japan's Nikkei share price index inside a conference hall  in Tokyo, Japan June 14, 2022. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo
S&P has lowered SoftBank’s rating to “BB” from “BB+”, citing its exposure to unlisted companies that are susceptible to changes in the external environment.
Chipmaker Arm, owned by SoftBank Group, last month filed confidentially for a US stock market listing, setting the stage for one of the biggest tech IPOs in the US this year.

site_title: Meta tells office workers to come in 3 days per week this fall
summary: Meta is asking employees assigned to an office to come in three times a week starting in September, as part of the company's push to work more efficiently. This move joins a trend of companies clamping down on remote work in the tech industry. Employees already working remotely can remain distributed, and Meta is committed to refining its model to foster collaboration and culture. Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg previously suggested that engineers perform better when working in-person with teammates three days a week.

images.alt_text: The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) says it is minded to accept the commitments, which include advertisers being able to opt out of allowing their data to be used to improve the Facebook Marketplace classified ads platform.
Overall the cuts hit non-engineering roles most heavily, reinforcing the primacy of those who write the code at Meta.

The European Commission had sought the information related to its investigation into Facebook’s data and online marketplace, prompting the company to compare the competition enforcer to a fishing super-trawler hoovering up data.
Britain’s competition regulator last year orders Meta to sell Giphy over fears that it could deny or limit competitors such as Snapchat and Twitter access to the target’s content.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on January 12, 2023 in Toulouse, southwestern France, shows a tablet displaying the logo of the company Meta. Facebook owner Meta has been fined a record 1.2 billion euros ($1.3 billion) for transferring EU user data to the United States in breach of a previous court ruling, Ireland's regulator announced May 23, 2023. The Irish Data Protection Commission, which acts on behalf of the European Union, said the European Data Protection Board had ordered it to collect "an administrative fine in the amount of 1.2 billion euros". Meta said it would appeal the decision. (Photo by Lionel BONAVENTURE / AFP)
AI’s rapid rise in recent months has raised alarm bells about the technology’s risks, including how it could upend the job market if it is not properly deployed.

site_title: South-east Asian tech giant Sea disbands investment arm: sources
summary: Sea Ltd, a South-east Asian tech giant, is disbanding its investment arm, Sea Capital, amid a cooling global investment environment. The two-year-old arm stopped new equity investing in 2022 and its entire team was disbanded in May. This decision comes as technology investors hold back on investing due to higher interest rates and market uncertainty. Sea Capital made at least three investments, including in FTX, which filed for bankruptcy protection in November. The move is part of Sea's broader overhaul, which includes reducing its workforce and exiting certain markets.

images.alt_text: Sea CEO Forrest Li
Li argues that Sea has a unique opportunity to bring e-commerce to emerging markets, the kinds of places where Amazon may be at a disadvantage.
Despite their recent doubling, the rally in Sea’s shares still looks like just a tiny blip on a longer-term price chart.
The salary hike marked a milestone for the Singapore-based e-commerce and gaming company, which had previously announced several rounds of layoffs and salary freezes.

site_title: Younger CEOs may be an answer to business uncertainty
summary: A 28-year-old, Agathe Monpays, has been appointed CEO of Leroy Merlin France, a leading DIY chain in Europe, sparking debate about the role of youth in business leadership. This appointment, along with rising numbers of first-time CEOs and board seats going to directors under 50, suggests a shift towards a more diverse and youthful leadership in Europe's boardrooms. Experts believe that the traditional CEO candidate with decades of experience may be outdated, and that a younger generation's fresh perspectives and skills are better equipped to navigate the challenges of a rapidly changing world.

images.alt_text: Do you think you can lead?

site_title: EU looks to 100 unicorns to boost green, digital goals
summary: The European Commission launched the "Scale Up 100" initiative to support 100 European deep-tech companies valued at $1 billion or more, aiming to boost the bloc's green and digital objectives. The selected startups will receive funding and mentorship from the EIC Scaling Club, a group of 100 investors, companies, and independent mentors. The initiative aims to increase the startups' annual growth by 40% in valuation, new investments, partnerships, and jobs, and by 50% for the top 20 performers in two years, with a focus on sustainability, digital, and health sectors.

site_title: JetBlue to spin-off Spirit Airlines' holdings at NY airport
summary: JetBlue will sell Spirit Airlines' holdings at New York's LaGuardia Airport to Frontier Group Holdings as part of their planned merger. The deal includes six gates and 22 takeoff and landing slots. The move aims to maintain low-cost carrier service at the airport. The divestitures are part of JetBlue's commitments in the merger agreement, which is expected to close in the first half of 2024. This follows the US Transportation Department's denial of an exemption request to operate under common ownership, citing antitrust concerns.

site_title: Boeing's first crewed space launch delayed, again
summary: Boeing has delayed its first crewed flight of the CST-100 Starliner space capsule due to new technical issues, including a faulty parachute system and flammable wire harness tape. The test flight was originally set for July 21 but has been postponed indefinitely. Boeing engineers identified the problems during testing and will report them to the US space agency, which has contracted Boeing to provide a taxi service to the ISS. No new date for the flight has been proposed, and the company had hoped to make its first manned flight in 2022.

images.alt_text: The earlier deal covered Boeing’s larger 787 Dreamliners to handle long-range flying for Riyadh Air and the existing flag carrier, Saudia.
The plane maker is keeping its 2023 free cash flow forecast of US$3 billion to US$5 billion, said its chief financial officer Brian West.
FILE PHOTO: Boeing Co's logo is seen above the front doors of its largest jetliner factory in Everett, Washington, U.S. January 13, 2017. REUTERS/Alwyn Scott/File Photo
Boeing announced plans in February to double its SAF purchases in 2023, buying 5.6 million gallons of fuel from Neste.
Ryanair is Boeing’s biggest customer in Europe, having built is entire fleet of short-haul aircraft around the workhorse model.

site_title: Indonesia pushes tourism to boost mangrove restoration
summary: Indonesia is promoting ecotourism to boost mangrove restoration, with the goal of replanting or conserving 4.1 million hectares of carbon-rich coastal areas that have been degraded by human activity. The country has lost 700,000 hectares of mangroves in the past year, and ecotourism is seen as a way to raise awareness about the importance of mangroves as biodiversity hotspots and carbon stores. Private institutions and NGOs are needed to support government efforts to restore mangroves, with tourism operators like The Mangrove Paddling Centre playing a key role in promoting conservation.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - In this aerial picture taken on February 23, 2023, mangrove trees are seen planted by the community in an attempt to slow erosion caused by rising sea levels are seen on Pari island in the Thousand Islands cluster. - Environmentalists have said most of the 42-hectare (103-acre) island could sink by 2050 because of rising sea levels. (Photo by Bay ISMOYO / AFP) / TO GO WITH "Indonesia-climate-court-Switzerland", FOCUS by Dessy SAGITA
The two countries are the world’s biggest palm oil producers and account for about 85 per cent of global palm oil exports.
Indonesia produces a wide range of nickel products, most of which are of a lower purity grade from the underlying product for the global benchmark nickel contract on the LME.

site_title: Construction companies see uneven recovery as they clear pandemic backlog
summary: Construction companies in Singapore are seeing an uneven recovery as they clear pandemic-era backlogs. Despite improved revenues, companies face pressure from rising costs, including material and manpower prices. Pre-pandemic contracts remain a challenge, with companies potentially unable to pass on increased costs. The industry is expected to recover, driven by a strong pipeline of projects and a smaller pool of contractors. Construction material prices are expected to stabilize as companies diversify their sourcing, and labor shortages may lead to more efficient construction methods.

images.alt_text: Parc Meadow @ Tengah will have 15 residential blocks, ranging from 12 to 13 storeys.
Most precious metals have fallen in price, except for gold. Silver and copper are down 4.7 per cent and 3.9 per cent, respectively, this year. Gold, meanwhile, is up 7.2 per cent.
Demonstration of a window water tightness test, one of the checks under Conquas. BCA has introduced a new banding system for developers, builders and private residential projects.

site_title: Taiwan shipping firms handing out mega bonuses to staff again
summary: Taiwanese shipping firms, Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp and Evergreen Marine Corp, are handing out massive mid-year bonuses to staff despite a slump in global cargo. Yang Ming is awarding up to 30 months of salary as a bonus, while Evergreen is providing 12 months of pay. The bonuses come after record profits last year, but the industry is expected to see significant declines in profit this year due to economic uncertainty and a decline in demand.

images.alt_text: A Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp. cargo ship arrives at the Port of Busan in South Korea, on Sunday, Feb. 15, 2009. South Korea's exports tumbled by a record 32.8 percent in January, foreshadowing a deepening slump in Asia's export-driven economies. Photographer: Seokyong Lee/Bloomberg News
News of Evergreen Marine's generous payouts has been widely shared on social media.
Hyundai Oilbankhas handed out its employees 10 times their base salaries as bonuses in 2022, more than the six times in 2021.

site_title: A reappraisal of the rupiah is overdue
summary: Indonesia's currency, the rupiah, has gained over 4% against the US dollar this year, making it Asia's best-performing major currency in 2023. The rupiah's resilience can be attributed to Indonesia's improved economic fundamentals, including a current account surplus and increased investment inflows. The country's young and dynamic population, rich commodity resources, and ample access to future-facing commodities also contribute to its strength. As the US interest rates rise, the rupiah has suffered less than most emerging-market peers, and foreign ownership of rupiah government bonds has held steady.

images.alt_text: Indonesian rupiah banknotes and coins are arranged for a photograph in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Thursday, Sept. 3, 2009. Indonesia's rupiah rose, snapping a three-day loss, after the government raised its 2010 economic growth target and the central bank said strength in the currency will help ease inflation. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg
As we look deeper into the dynamics of Indonesia’s electric two-wheeler market, it’s impossible to overlook the vital role that regulators play in shaping its trajectory.
Indonesia’s tax take rose dramatically in 2022 amid high global commodity prices, and this year’s revenues have remained strong.
Indonesia's Central Bank governor Perry Warjiyo says the central bank would continue strengthening measures to support the rupiah currency to mitigate against imported inflation.

site_title: CAG reverses losses to achieve net profit of S$33 million for FY2023
summary: Changi Airport Group (CAG) posted a net profit of S$33 million for FY2023, reversing its S$838 million loss in the previous financial year. Revenue doubled to S$1.9 billion, driven by a recovering aviation industry after borders reopened. The airport saw 82% of pre-Covid passenger levels in March 2023.

images.alt_text: The full reopening of T2 comes amid anticipation of a full travel recovery in 2024, or earlier.
The top five traffic markets for the quarter comprised Australia, India, Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand.

site_title: Hiring at US companies tops all forecasts, ADP data show
summary: US companies exceeded all forecasts with a 278,000 increase in private payrolls in May, according to ADP data. The gain was led by leisure and hospitality, mining, construction, and trade and transportation sectors. This marks a durable labour market that supports the economy. The median estimate of economists had predicted a 170,000 increase. The gains were concentrated in companies with fewer than 500 employees, while the South was the only region shedding jobs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage for a job fair is seen on 5th Avenue after the release of the jobs report in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., September 3, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Citigroup hires former UBS banker for energy dealmaking: memo
summary: Citigroup has hired Dan Ford, a former UBS banker, as vice chairman of its natural resources and clean energy transition group. Ford, who worked as an external senior advisor for the past year, has a 25-year career in banking, mainly focusing on the power and utilities sector. He previously led research coverage of such companies at UBS. Ford's hiring is seen as a strategic move to deepen client relationships, particularly in the energy sector, where Citi has advised on notable deals such as Vistra's US$3.43 billion acquisition of Energy Harbor.

site_title: Airbnb sues New York City over short-term rental restrictions
summary: Airbnb has filed a lawsuit against New York City over a new law restricting short-term rentals, which the company claims will effectively ban the practice. The law, set to take effect in July, requires hosts to register and comply with complex regulations. Airbnb argues that the law will limit the number of hosts and make it difficult for them to do business. The company is requesting that the court block the enforcement of the law, citing concerns about safety, community livability, and the hospitality sector's recovery.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: The Airbnb logo is seen on a little mini pyramid under the glass Pyramid of the Louvre museum in Paris, France, March 12, 2019. REUTERS/Charles Platiau/File Photo/File Photo
Airbnb’s results follow robust results and optimistic commentary from its online travel peers.
Airbnb currently partners with 250 buildings that allow renters to lease their apartments part-time on the home-sharing platform.
Airbnb has been one of the few tech firms to avoid mass layoffs, while many peers have cut their growth expectations amid higher interest rates and a sector-wide slowdown.
Airbnb said it expects to maintain last year’s margin of 35 per cent, the highest since it went public in 2020, despite recession fears that have sparked concerns about consumer spending.

site_title: Credit Suisse’s Robert Huray to join Deutsche Bank as South-east Asia vice chair
summary: Credit Suisse's Robert Huray is joining Deutsche Bank AG as vice chairman for South-east Asia in September. He will focus on large clients across Malaysia, Indonesia, and Singapore. Huray previously held the position at Credit Suisse and had a brief stint at Kuok Group, where he oversaw investments in the region.

site_title: Russia says US hacked thousands of Apple phones in spy plot
summary: Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) claims the US hacked thousands of Apple iPhones as part of a spy plot, compromising diplomats from Israel, Syria, China, and NATO members. The FSB alleges close cooperation between Apple and the National Security Agency (NSA) but denies Apple's involvement. Apple denies the allegations, stating it has never worked with any government to insert a backdoor into any Apple product. Kaspersky Lab, which was targeted, described the operation as a "complex, professionally targeted cyberattack" that began in 2019.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin says the United States and its allies are fighting an expanding proxy war against Russia after the Kremlin chief sent troops into Ukraine 15 months ago.

Apple will tap Broadcom for what are known as film bulk acoustic resonator (FBAR) chips, which are part of a radio-frequency system that helps iPhones and other Apple devices connected to mobile data networks.

A man walks past the Samsung logo displayed on a glass door at the company's Seocho building in Seoul on April 7, 2023. - Samsung Electronics said on April 7 it expected first-quarter operating profits to plunge over 95 percent on-year to a 14-year low, as memory chip sales were hammered by a global downturn. (Photo by Jung Yeon-je / AFP)

site_title: Goldman says more job cuts coming in ‘tougher environment’
summary: Goldman Sachs plans to cut more jobs, its third round in under a year, due to a "pretty risk-off tone" from clients and a potentially contractionary economic environment. The move is expected to affect less than 250 people, primarily senior employees. The bank is also on track to achieve its US$1 billion expense reduction goal. Analysts forecast Goldman's revenue this year to be roughly in line with last year's US$48 billion, still lower than 2021's record. The bank is preparing for a "tougher environment" amid cautious corporate CEOs and a risk-off market.

images.alt_text: The average fund is 15 percentage points underweight Apple, Microsoft, Alphabet, Amazon.com, Nvidia, Tesla and Meta Platforms, according to Goldman.

site_title: Nvidia is not the only firm cashing in on the AI gold rush
summary: Nvidia is not the only company profiting from the AI gold rush, with a trillion-dollar industry emerging for selling specialist chips and infrastructure. Companies like AMD, TSMC, and chip-design startups are benefiting from the surge in demand for computing power, with Nvidia's annual data centre revenue expected to double. Manufacturers like TSMC and Dell'Oro Group are also poised to benefit from the growth of AI servers, with server manufacturers like Wistron and Inventec seeing increased demand. The AI boom is also creating opportunities for software companies, with over 80 startups created to support AI infrastructure. However, concerns about energy consumption and the potential for regulators to clamp down on the technology may slow its deployment.

images.alt_text: In March, more than 1,100 industry leaders advocated for a six-month pause on training powerful AI models.
Will AI one day produce entirely new goods and services that will outcompete the human desire to please and interact with other people?
Generative AI – which not only classifies or predicts, but creates its own content with a human-like command of language – won’t just enhance work but transform it fundamentally.

site_title: KKR raises US$400 million for global retail private equity fund
summary: KKR has raised US$400 million for its international private equity fund targeting high net-worth clients. The firm plans to launch a US retail-focused private equity fund and infrastructure fund in the current quarter, aiming to capture the potential US$9-10 trillion of retail dollars migrating into the alternatives industry. Co-CEO Joe Bae sees this as a "long-term opportunity" for the industry and KKR, currently with only 1% of the US$180 trillion in individual wealth invested in alternatives.

site_title: Germany, Denmark sign offshore wind-power cooperation deal
summary: Germany and Denmark have signed an agreement to connect 3.2 gigawatts of wind energy generation capacity on the Danish island of Bornholm to the mainland by the 2030s. The project aims to create a green electricity supply, making it cheaper, safer, and more independent of fossil fuels. The transmission system operators will bear half the infrastructure costs, with 2 gigawatts transmitted to Germany and 1.2 gigawatts to mainland Denmark. This cooperation is part of the EU's efforts to expand wind farms and develop renewable energy projects in the region.

site_title: Dell's Q1 results fall less than feared on cost cuts
summary: Dell Technologies reported better-than-expected Q1 results, beating estimates for profit and revenue. The company's cost controls and supply chain performance helped drive the positive outcome. Despite a 20% decline in revenue to $20.9 billion, Dell's client solutions unit saw a 23% fall in sales and its infrastructure solutions unit saw an 18% decline. The company's stock surged 5% following the announcement. Dell's co-CEO attributed the results to "maintaining pricing discipline, reducing operating expenses, and supply chain normalizing ahead of competitors."

images.alt_text: The reductions amount to about 5 per cent of Dell’s global workforce, according to a company spokesperson.
Dell is grappling with cratering demand for personal computers since the pandemic boom days.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound on easing inflation data, US debt deal optimism
summary: European stocks rebounded 0.8% on Thursday as easing inflation data sparked debate on interest rate hikes and optimism over the US debt deal. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed at a two-month high, with basic resources, media, and energy sectors leading gains. Analysts expect interest rates to peak in September, rather than December, and some Fed officials hinted at a potential "skip" in June interest rate hikes. Meanwhile, the US House of Representatives passed a bill to suspend the $31.4 trillion debt ceiling, boosting investor sentiment.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 1.1 per cent lower on Wednesday, after hitting its lowest level since March 30.
Euro dollars, US dollars, currency, notes, money

The European Commission (above, its headquarters in Brussels) aims for its EIC "Scale Up 100" initiative 
to identify and support the growth of 100 promising European deep-tech companies with the potential to become businesses valued at US$1 billion or more.

site_title: Entertainment industry struggles with 215 billion piracy site visits
summary: The entertainment industry has seen a significant increase in piracy site visits, with 215 billion visits recorded in 2022, a 18% rise from 2021. Despite efforts by anti-piracy authorities to crack down on illegal streaming, data suggests that piracy remains a booming industry. The Alliance for Creativity and Entertainment (ACE) claims to have shut down operators in several countries, but free entertainment remains easily accessible, with 1.2 million members on a Reddit discussion board justifying piracy. Industry leaders recognize that eliminating piracy is unrealistic, and instead focus on making it a marginalized activity.

images.alt_text: Marilyn Monroe, dead for 59 years, is a counterfeiter's best friend
“The future is long-form streaming. To me, it’s breathtaking. These works will be the cathedrals of the 21st century. These will be the masterworks of art.” Screenwriting guru Robert McKee said.

site_title: JPMorgan to close 21 First Republic Bank branches
summary: JPMorgan will close 21 branches of First Republic Bank by the end of the year, integrating the failed lender into its operations. The closures, affecting about 100 employees, will be offered six-month transition assignments, allowing them to apply for other roles at JPMorgan, which has 13,000 vacancies. The branches account for about a quarter of First Republic's 84 branches across eight states, with relatively low transaction volumes and proximity to other First Republic offices.

site_title: ChatGPT-powered Wall Street
summary: ChatGPT-powered trading algorithms could worsen the problem of too many traders on the same side of a deal, potentially exacerbating market volatility. High-frequency trading, which uses computer programs to analyze market data and execute trades at high speeds, may be amplified by AI-powered tools. This could lead to increased market instability and decreased efficiency. Researchers warn that the growing use of AI in financial markets offers both benefits and perils, highlighting the need for careful consideration and regulation.

images.alt_text: ChatGPT logo and AI Artificial Intelligence words are seen in this illustration taken, May 4, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

A trader walks out of the New York Stock Exchange on Wall Street in New York. Some Wall Street firms are revising their profit projections for multiple S&P 500 industry groups, based on the adoption of AI.

site_title: Hong Kong’s April retail sales up 15% in fifth month of growth
summary: Hong Kong's April retail sales rose 15% year-over-year, marking the fifth consecutive month of growth, with sales reaching HK$34.7 billion. Consumer sentiment and tourist arrivals continued to improve, driven by the reopening of border checkpoints and the lifting of COVID-19 restrictions. Retail sales of jewellery, watches, and valuable gifts surged 75.2% from a year earlier, while tourist arrivals in April reached 2.89 million, a 4,692 visitor increase from April 2022. The government attributed the growth to the revival of inbound tourism and local consumption demand.

images.alt_text: “The recovery of inbound tourism and private consumption should continue to benefit the retail sector,” a government spokesperson says.

Glitzy Hong Kong shopping streets once packed with luxury stores that attracted 56 million visitors in pre-pandemic 2019 now have about half of their shop units sitting vacant, according to property management companies.

site_title: Oil rises 3% on US debt ceiling progress, traders on alert for Opec+ meeting
summary: Oil prices rose 3% on Thursday, the largest daily gain in two weeks, ahead of the Opec+ meeting on June 4. The US debt ceiling bill, passed by the House, helped offset rising US inventories, with US West Texas Intermediate crude rising to $70.10 a barrel and Brent crude futures reaching $74.65 a barrel. However, analysts warn that the overall demand outlook remains uncertain, and the Opec+ meeting may lead to caution around low price levels.

images.alt_text: Opec+ is meeting as prices slide below US$70 a barrel in New York, giving up the gains made since Saudi Arabia and other members made a surprise cut in early April.
Brent crude futures for August delivery settled US$1.11 lower to US$72.60 a barrel on Wednesday.
Most precious metals have fallen in price, except for gold. Silver and copper are down 4.7 per cent and 3.9 per cent, respectively, this year. Gold, meanwhile, is up 7.2 per cent.

site_title: US: Stocks rally on debt limit deal, hopes of rate hike pause
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, driven by hopes of a pause in interest rate hikes and a deal to suspend the nation's debt limit. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.5%, the S&P 500 rose 1%, and the Nasdaq Composite surged 1.3%. The House of Representatives approved the bill, which suspends the debt ceiling through 2024 and cuts government spending. Economic data suggested the Federal Reserve may hold back on further rate hikes, bolstering the market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange shortly after the opening bell as trading is halted in New York, U.S., March 16, 2020. REUTERS/Lucas Jackson//File Photo

Governor Philip Jefferson, a centrist who has been nominated to be vice-chair and who often echoes chairman Jerome Powell’s views, said Wednesday that skipping an increase would give policymakers time to assess data, but not preclude future tightening.
Stocks in Japan, India and Korea have beaten China peers more often than not since 2020.

site_title: Netflix shareholders withhold support for executive pay package
summary: Netflix shareholders have withheld support for the company's executive pay package, with a non-binding "say on pay" vote showing only 27% of shareholders in favor last year. The Writers Guild of America West urged investors to vote against the compensation, citing the company's ability to afford higher wages for writers during the ongoing strike. Despite changes made after last year's vote, including a salary cap and performance-based bonus plan, shareholders have maintained their disapproval of the executive pay structure.

images.alt_text: The streaming video pioneer has been looking for new ways to make money as it faces signs of market saturation.
Netflix launchs a significant increase in Japanese content in 2021, including anime, live action and animated feature films.
Netflix launched a US$7-per-month ad-supported tier in November in 12 markets.
Netflix in June also laid off 300 employees, or about 4 per cent of its workforce, in the second round of job cuts aimed at lowering costs.
That path to success is hard to find in today’s Hollywood, the writers say.

(FILES) The Netflix logo is seen on top of their office building in Hollywood, California, March 2, 2022. - April 19, 2023, after shipping out more than five billion DVDs in trademark red envelopes, Netflix has finally called time on the movie mail-out subscription business that launched today's Hollywood streaming colossus.
The announcement, made in a letter to shareholders before this week's earnings call, was greeted with bafflement by some broadband binge-watchers who did not know Netflix's DVD business was still running -- or that it existed in the first place. (Photo by Chris DELMAS / AFP)
Despite 27 per cent of the US population identifying as disabled, only 1.1 per cent of all characters in Netflix films and series have a disability, the study released on Thursday found.

site_title: Credit Suisse has paid back government-backed liquidity: Swiss minister
summary: Credit Suisse has repaid the government-backed liquidity it received from the Swiss National Bank, according to Finance Minister Karin Keller-Sutter. The bank initially borrowed 70 billion Swiss francs under the 100 billion franc scheme, with 60 billion francs repaid in the first quarter. Credit Suisse had previously struggled with cash outflows and applied for emergency liquidity assistance in March. The repayment brings the bank's net borrowings from the SNB to 108 billion francs. The move follows a state-orchestrated rescue and takeover by rival bank UBS.

images.alt_text: Created after the 2008 financial crisis, AT1s are the lowest rung of bank debt, producing juicy returns in good times but taking the first hit when a bank runs into trouble.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Credit Suisse bank is seen outside its office building in Hong Kong, China March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo
Credit Suisse has also been handing out retention bonuses to staff whom UBS sees as critical for the future of the combined bank.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims rise modestly; layoffs up in May
summary: US weekly jobless claims rose 2,000 to 232,000 for the week ended May 27, a modest increase. Despite fears of a recession, demand for labor remains strong, with 10.1 million job openings at the end of April. Layoffs have increased, with 80,089 job cuts announced by US-based employers in May, a 20% surge from the same period last year. Economists expect the unemployment rate to tick up to 3.5% from a 53-year low of 3.4% in April.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage for a job fair is seen on 5th Avenue after the release of the jobs report in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., September 3, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo/File Photo
Though claims for unemployment benefits rose moderately, they remain at levels consistent with a still-tight labour market.

site_title: US manufacturing slumps further in May; employment picks up: ISM
summary: US manufacturing contracted for a seventh straight month in May, with the Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing PMI falling to 46.9, the lowest since the Great Recession. New orders continued to plummet amid higher interest rates, but factories boosted employment to a nine-month-high. The persistent weak readings in the PMI support analysts' expectations that the economy will slip into recession this year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage for a job fair is seen on 5th Avenue after the release of the jobs report in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., September 3, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: High UK rentals suggest residential sector remains attractive investment despite various headwinds
summary: UK residential rents have reached an all-time record average of £1,199 ($2,002) per month, up 9.7% from the previous year. The surge is attributed to a shortage of rental properties and strong demand from foreign investors, particularly from Hong Kong, Singapore, and the US. London rents have skyrocketed, with Westminster seeing a 49% increase in the past five years. Despite regulatory risks, the improving rents are expected to support demand among foreign investors, who face challenges due to a weaker pound and soaring maintenance costs.

images.alt_text: The two-year British swap rate, which underpins many lenders’ own financing costs and mortgage pricing for two-year deals, has shot up around 50 basis points so far this week.
The UK housing market is facing disruption as a double whammy of high interest rates and a cost-of-living crisis threatens to weigh on property prices.
UK unitied kingdom house housing rent Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

site_title: RWS’ deputy CEO resigns
summary: Lam Yi Young, Resorts World Sentosa's deputy CEO, has resigned less than six months after taking the role, citing family care leave and a desire to pursue other interests. He had previously served as CEO of the Singapore Business Federation. Genting Singapore's shares fell 1% following the news. Lam's departure occurred during a tumultuous period for the company, with Lam taking over the deputy CEO role on January 1, 2023.

site_title: Macy’s earnings fall after cutting outlook as demand trends weaken
summary: Macy's Inc reported weaker-than-expected earnings due to declining sales and reduced demand trends. The company lowered sales guidance and took measures to address excess spring merchandise, citing macroeconomic impacts on consumer spending. Same-store sales for the Macy's brand fell 8.7%, while Bloomingdale's dropped 3.9% and Bluemercury rose 4.3%. The decline in sales was most prominent among customers earning less than $75,000 per year. Adjusted earnings per share were 56 cents, beating analyst estimates, and gross margin met forecasts.

images.alt_text: The company the fashion retailer blames the lower forecast on a deeper-than-expected lull in shopping between the major holidays of the season.
Macy's needs another Miracle on 34th Street
For the 2023 fiscal year, Levi sees net revenue of US$6.3 billion to US$6.4 billion, reflecting growth of 1.5 per cent to 3 per cent from the prior year.
Shoppers are shifting purchases to cheaper options such as Walmart, a trend that often coincides with a recession.

site_title: Luce, Gyu San and Wakuda launch new offerings in June
summary: Luce, Gyu San, and Wakuda have launched new offerings in June. Luce, a four-hands collaboration between Davide Giacomelli and Francesco Gasbarro, features a six-course menu showcasing their unique culinary styles. Gyu San has introduced a unique charcoal bar concept, offering Japanese wagyu katsu sandos. Meanwhile, Wakuda has launched an 18-course sushi omakase experience featuring seasonal ingredients.

images.alt_text: Foliage's understated interiors.

site_title: Working out a solution: Pros and cons of an out-of-court workout
summary: An out-of-court workout offers businesses facing financial distress a flexible, confidential, and minimally disruptive restructuring option. It allows debtors and creditors to reach a private agreement, reducing debt burden and allowing the business to continue operating. Workouts have several advantages, including flexibility, confidentiality, and minimal business disruption. However, they are not failproof and require a viable underlying business, unanimous creditor support, and careful communication to maximize success. Early identification and transparent communication by the debtor and creditor support are crucial to overcoming challenges such as the "hold-out creditor" problem.

images.alt_text: Unprecedented monetary stimulus in the aftermath of the global financial crisis and during the pandemic should provide fertile ground for distress investing. Excess capital is often misallocated and leads to wasteful and ill-advised investments.

epa10589067 A man rides a motorbike past the State Bank of Vietnam building in Hanoi, Vietnam, 24 April 2023. Vietnam's central bank plans to restructure loans for struggling businesses amid global slowdown. Vietnam’s gross domestic product (GDP) growth in the first quarter of 2023 slowed to 3.32 percent, according to the General Statistics Office  EPA-EFE/LUONG THAI LINH

Vietnam’s fifth-largest developer by market value has been badly hit with the real estate sector wracked by a government crackdown on corruption and stricter rules on corporate bond issuance and refinancing.

site_title: Sterling strengthens against dollar as chances of Fed skipping rate rise
summary: Sterling strengthened against the dollar, reaching its strongest in six months, after the Federal Reserve indicated it may skip a rate hike this month. The pound edged up 0.2% against the dollar and 2% against the euro, despite data showing a gloomy UK economy, with mortgage approvals and house prices falling. Analysts warn that the apparent strength is a mirage, given the UK's slow growth and high inflation, and the Bank of England is likely to raise interest rates again this month.

images.alt_text: Sterling is one of the best-performing Group-of-10 currencies this year, extending a recovery from a record low near parity against the US dollar in September to around US$1.23.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit manager appoints new CEO; outgoing chief moves to FLCAM
summary: Keppel DC Reit's manager has appointed 46-year-old Loh Hwee Long as its new CEO, effective July 28. He will replace outgoing CEO Anthea Lee, who will take over as CEO of Frasers Logistics and Commercial Asset Management (FLCAM) on August 14. Lee has 16 years of experience in Reit management under Keppel Group. The transition is expected to be smooth, with the outgoing and incoming CEOs working closely with the boards to ensure continuity.

images.alt_text: Keppel DC real estate investment trust has been booted from the Straits Times Index (STI) and will be replaced by Seatrium.
Keppel DC Reit's gross revenue rose 6.5 per cent in the quarter, from the acquisitions of Guangdong Data Centre 2 and the building shell of Guangdong Data Centre 3.

site_title: Eurozone’s factory downturn deepens in May despite price cuts
summary: The eurozone's manufacturing sector experienced a deepening downturn in May, with a final manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) of 44.8, down from April's 45.8. The decline in demand, despite factories cutting prices for the first time since September 2020, signals that the weakness in output is likely to persist for several more months. The output prices index fell to 49.0, a six-month low, while the index measuring output dropped to 46.4, its lowest level since February 2023.

images.alt_text: Largely healed supply chains and lower energy prices has led to input costs for factories falling at the fastest pace in over seven years.

site_title: Growing excitement over fusion energy, but still early days for venture capitalists
summary: Nuclear fusion, a clean energy gamechanger, has seen significant progress in the last five years, with the world making more progress in developing reliable ideas for fusion than in the past 25-35 years. Despite breakthroughs, mainstream venture capitalists remain cautious due to risks and uncertainties, but funding is on the rise, with at least $5 billion invested globally in the last two years. While fusion technology is still decades away from commercialization, it has the potential to provide limitless, zero-carbon energy and could be a key player in solving climate change, with Singapore potentially considering nuclear energy as a long-term option to achieve its net-zero target by 2050.

images.alt_text: Nio invests 995 million yuan for a 19.9 per cent stake of Neo Fusion, while Nio Capital invests 505 million yuan for a 10.1 per cent share.

site_title: ECB’s Lagarde sees no clear evidence core inflation has peaked
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde stated that there's no clear evidence core inflation has peaked in the eurozone, indicating further interest rate hikes are needed to reach the 2% inflation target. Despite data showing a slowdown in eurozone inflation, core price pressures still need to be addressed, suggesting at least one more rate hike is likely. Lagarde also noted that monetary policy is being transmitted "forcefully" to credit, with considerable tightening still in the pipeline.

images.alt_text: ECB president Christine Lagarde says: “We are not done yet, we are not pausing based on the information I have today,” she said, adding that the “inflation outlook is too high and for too long”.

site_title: US agency steps up safety probe into air-bag ruptures
summary: The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has stepped up its investigation into potentially defective air-bag inflators, demanding a recall of 67 million inflators from auto supplier ARC Automotive Inc. The inflators, installed in vehicles from General Motors, Stellantis, BMW, Hyundai, and Kia, can project metal fragments into vehicle occupants, causing injuries. ARC has rejected the request, prompting the NHTSA to further probe the issue.

images.alt_text: The recall covers 994,763 Buick Enclave, Chevrolet Traverse, and GMC Acadia vehicles from the 2014 through 2017 model years with modules produced by ARC Automotive.

site_title: Singapore, China ink pact to set up bilateral defence hotline
summary: Singapore and China have signed an agreement to set up a bilateral defence hotline, aimed at strengthening high-level communication between defence leaders from both sides. The hotline, known as a "secure defence telephone link," will enable regular communication on global and regional security issues. The move follows a meeting between Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen and Chinese Defence Minister Li Shangfu, marking the first official meeting between the two ministers. The hotline is part of a broader agreement to strengthen defence cooperation and academic exchanges between the two countries.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - A Ukrainian tank fires at Russian positions near Kreminna, Lugansk region, on January 12, 2023, amid the Russian invasion of Ukraine. (Photo by Anatolii Stepanov / AFP)
Shangri-La Dialogue to resume this year: Ng Eng Hen

site_title: Australian PM Albanese in Singapore for 8th Leaders’ Meeting
summary: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is visiting Singapore from June 1-3 for the 8th Singapore-Australia Annual Leaders’ Meeting, his first official visit since taking office last May. The three-day trip will focus on strengthening bilateral cooperation, implementing the landmark Green Economy Agreement, and discussing mutual food and energy security, defence, and trade ties. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong will host Albanese for a welcome ceremony, an official lunch, and the keynote address at the Shangri-La Dialogue. This visit marks the 8th leaders’ meeting under the Comprehensive Strategic Partnership between the two nations.

images.alt_text: Singapore’s Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong (left) and Australia’s Minister for Trade and Tourism Don Farrell signed the GEA in the presence of both prime ministers.
Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese at the joint press conference for the 7th Annual Leaders' Meeting in Canberra on Oct 18.

site_title: PAP town councils to raise service and conservancy charges from July 1
summary: PAP town councils in Singapore will raise service and conservancy charges (S&CC) from July 1, 2023, due to increased costs. The first increase will see monthly fees rise by S$0.70 to S$7.90 for HDB flats, while commercial property owners and tenants will see an increase of S$0.01 to S$0.40 per sq m. The next hike in 2024 will see fees rise by S$1 to S$9.10 for HDB residents, and S$0.02 to S$0.41 per sq m for commercial property owners and tenants. The town councils are receiving government funding to cushion the impact of rising maintenance costs.

site_title: Macau’s May casino revenue soars 366% on visitor influx
summary: Macau's casino revenue surged 366% in May to 15.6 billion patacas ($2.62 billion), the highest figure since January 2020, driven by a five-day national holiday with 500,000 Chinese visitors. The influx of visitors came as China lifted Covid-19 restrictions, allowing citizens to gamble in Macau for the first time in over three years. Authorities aim to diversify income sources, as the territory grapples with a labour shortage, and casino operators face new regulations.

images.alt_text: The Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission had earlier confirmed it suspected Low was in gambling haven and Chinese special administrative region Macau.
MGM has been expanding into digital products, with the market for land-based casinos already built out and new licences hard to win.
Macau is the top destination for Chinese travellers within Asia from Apr 17 to May 7, according to travel data firm ForwardKeys.

site_title: Istanbul, city of great art despite restrictions
summary: Istanbul, a city of great art despite restrictions, continues to thrive under iron-fisted President Erdogan's rule. The city's cultural institutions, such as the Istanbul Modern museum, nurture a new generation of Turkish artists, despite economic and political struggles. Contemporary art institutions like Arter, SALT Galata, and Pera Museum showcase works by international stars and Turkish modernists. Meanwhile, writers like Orhan Pamuk and Elif Shafak have gained global recognition for their works, which often tackle taboo topics. Despite a repressive climate, art finds a way to flourish in Istanbul, providing a refuge for those seeking solace.

images.alt_text: Jane Lee's continues her exploration into the nature of painting with several stunning works. at SAM.

site_title: Crypto.com gets MAS licence to offer digital payment token services to Singapore customers
summary: Crypto.com has received a major payment institution licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), allowing it to offer digital payment token services to Singapore customers. This comes after an in-principle approval nearly a year ago. The move follows Hong Kong's recent decision to allow retail traders to trade cryptocurrency assets, with only two exchanges having been granted licences so far. Regulators emphasize the need for regulation, citing risks associated with cryptocurrency trading, while acknowledging the potential benefits of stablecoins.

images.alt_text: “Despite the potential risks involved, (virtual assets) also carries with it fundamental value,” says Christopher Hui, Hong Kong’s secretary for financial services and the treasury.
Venture capital firms Accel, GIC and Andreessen Horowitz are among those to have backed the company.
Jurisdictions like Hong Kong and Dubai are seeking to attract companies, while Singapore plans curbs on retail-investor participation.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on debt deal cheer
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Thursday, June 1, 2023, due to optimism over the passage of a bill suspending the US debt ceiling, despite dismal earnings from Salesforce. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 21.58 points, or 0.07%, to 32,929.85, while the S&P 500 gained 3.20 points, or 0.08%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 9.18 points, or 0.07%.

site_title: China’s mixed factory surveys show recovery still uncertain
summary: China's mixed factory surveys indicate a slow recovery, with a slight expansion in factory activity in May according to the Caixin PMI, but a deeper contraction in the official PMI. A faltering property market and concerns over youth unemployment add to economic uncertainty. Business and consumer confidence have not rebounded to pre-pandemic levels, and policymakers may need to provide more stimulus to boost domestic demand. Economists predict a possible interest rate cut in June to support the economy.

images.alt_text: While factories in Asia’s north bore the brunt of the economic pain, those in the south presented a mixed picture.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Hong Kong allows retail traders to trade cryptocurrency assets, marking a new development in the city's cryptocurrency market. Meanwhile, Crypto.com has secured a major payment institution licence in Singapore to offer digital payment token services. Breakthroughs in nuclear fusion have renewed excitement for sustainable energy, but venture capitalists are still hesitant to invest. Singapore hotels' average room rate recovers from March's dip, with the sector expected to benefit from the Jobs Transformation Map's digital upskilling initiatives.
