SIA chief executive Goh Choon Phong, who assumed the position in 2011, said he is grooming next-generation leaders for the group but the decision on his successor lies with the board.

site_title: Sifa 2023: The art of navel-gazing
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts (Sifa) continues into its second week with a series of introspective works. "The School," a participatory theatre production, invites audience members to re-examine how schools shape thoughts and behaviors. Meanwhile, "Me, You, Then, Now" by Muna Tseng reflects on her 40-year career as a dancer, while "Lolling & Rolling" and "Cuckoo" by Jaha Koo critique Western imperialism and the Asian financial crisis. The festival also features "BLKDOG," a dark and powerful hip-hop dance piece exploring violence and trauma experienced by children. Sifa 2023 runs until June 4.

images.alt_text: Abyss by 99 Art Company explores Korea’s deep-seated melancholy.
Sarkis’ solo show at Arter museum looks back at his long practice, with highlights of his best large-scale installations.

site_title: Euro steadies near two-month low as inflation eases in eurozone
summary: The euro steadied near a two-month low at US$1.0690 after eurozone inflation eased to 6.1% in May, below expectations. This easing inflation supports the argument that the European Central Bank (ECB) may not need to extend its monetary tightening much further. The ECB has raised base rates by 375 basis points over the past year, but with inflation subsiding, the market is now pricing in a 37% chance of a 25-bp rate hike by the ECB on June 15.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which measures the greenback against six major peers, climb to 104.63, its highest since Mar 16.

site_title: Swedish central bank says commercial real estate a worry
summary: Sweden's central bank, the Riksbank, has expressed concerns over the commercial real estate sector, citing higher interest rates and falling property values as major worries. The sector's exposure to banks has increased, and regulators warn that companies must strengthen their balance sheets. Moody's has taken negative rating action on 50% of Swedish real estate firms, and the crown currency is trading at its weakest level against the euro in over a decade, reflecting market concerns.

images.alt_text: Against a backdrop of sharply rising market rates, Sweden’s property firms must refinance more than US$40 billion of maturing bond debt over the next five years.

site_title: Easing inflation has allowed Vietnam central bank to cut rates earlier this year
summary: Vietnam's central bank cut its refinance rate by 50 basis points to 5% in June, its third rate cut this year, as inflation eased. The move aims to maintain macroeconomic stability and prevent a slowdown in growth. The country's GDP growth slowed to 3.3% in the first quarter of 2023, and average consumer prices rose 3.55% in the first five months of the year. The central bank will prioritize the safety of the banking system and closely monitor the real-time situation to adjust measures as needed.

site_title: European bond prices cling to this week's inflation-inspired gains
summary: European bond prices held onto gains from lower-than-expected inflation data, with Germany's 10-year yield rising 3 basis points on the day but falling 24 basis points on the week. The European benchmark saw its biggest weekly fall in yield in two months, but events such as eurozone regional inflation data and US payrolls data later this week may impact prices. Analysts attribute the relief in prices to central-bank policy showing an effect, with the European Central Bank's interest rate plans expected to be influenced by core inflation data.

images.alt_text: The German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, March 23, 2023.    REUTERS/Staff

site_title: Local shares end trading week higher, STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.2% or 7.5 points to close at 3,166.30 on Thursday, driven by investor opportunities following the US House vote to raise the debt ceiling. Top advancers included Jardine Matheson Holdings and DBS, while UOB and OCBC declined. Venture Corporation and iFast Corporation were among the notable decliners. The benchmark index narrowly edged past decliners, with 1.4 billion securities worth S$1.3 billion changing hands.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which measures the greenback against six major peers, climb to 104.63, its highest since Mar 16.
Share prices of leading Chinese makers of semiconductor equipment have jumped since end-March.
The average fund is 15 percentage points underweight Apple, Microsoft, Alphabet, Amazon.com, Nvidia, Tesla and Meta Platforms, according to Goldman.

site_title: MAS issues prohibition order to six former Great Eastern agents for fraud, dishonest conduct
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued a prohibition order to six former Great Eastern Financial Advisers agents for fraud and dishonest conduct. The six individuals, Chan Jun Yi, Chanel Quah Hui Wen, Lim Zhan Yi, Sherlin Chia Hee Ping, Tang Hong Kong Jackie, and Yvonne Quah, will be prohibited from participating in business activities for five years, starting from June 1. They were convicted of tax evasion and sentenced to imprisonment and penalties ranging from four days to eight weeks. The MAS deemed their convictions as evidence of their inability to perform financial advisory services honestly.

images.alt_text: MAS issues 10-year prohibition order to former DBS wealth manager for fraud
James Yeo Siew Liang was convicted of 18 counts of corruption in April 2021.

site_title: Asia:  US debt vote passage Asian markets, Federal Reserve now in view
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday after the US House passed a bill to avoid a debt default, bringing a brief respite to global markets. The bipartisan agreement lifts the debt ceiling, allowing the US government to borrow more cash. The move comes ahead of the Federal Reserve's next policy meeting and amid concerns over China's struggling economy. Investors will focus on US jobs data on Friday, which could influence the Fed's decision on interest rates.

images.alt_text: Across the broader marker, losers outnumber gainers by 57 to 44 after 55.4 million securities worth S$137.3 million are traded.
Hong Kong led losses, dropping more than two per cent on Wednesday.

site_title: Hot watches hit the shops early
summary: Major watch brands are now making newly launched timepieces available in stores, reducing the wait time for buyers. The Tudor Black Bay 54, IWC Schaffhausen Ingenieur Automatic 40, and Longines Spirit Flyback are among the early releases. The Black Bay 54 is a downsized version of the Black Bay Fifty-Eight, while the Ingenieur Automatic 40 features a 40mm stainless steel case and integrated steel bracelet. The Longines Spirit Flyback is the brand's first flyback chronograph model in over 50 years, priced below S$10,000. Replenishments for sold-out models are expected to arrive soon.

images.alt_text: Franck Muller’s CEO Nicholas Rudaz calls the novelties "very colourful, very complicated and very sporty."
Jean-Claude Biver (right) and his son Pierre (left) visited Singapore recently to show the first watch from their newly launched brand.
The TAG Heuer Carrera Plasma Diamant d'Avant-Garde Chronograph Tourbillon 44 mm.
Spirit of Big Bang Sang Bleu by Hublot.

site_title: Swiss face rent hikes with first mortgage gauge jump in 15 years
summary: Switzerland's national benchmark for mortgage costs rose to 1.5% from 1.25%, allowing landlords to raise rents by 3% under Swiss law. This is the first increase in 15 years, driven by the Swiss National Bank's efforts to combat inflation. Economists warn that subsequent rent hikes may fuel consumer-price growth, while the real estate market shows signs of weakening. The benchmark is expected to rise again on Sept 1 and Dec 1.

site_title: US-China tensions expected to dominate Asia security meeting
summary: US-China tensions are expected to dominate the Asia security meeting in Singapore, where over 600 delegates from 49 countries will attend. China's new Defence Minister Li Shangfu declined a bilateral meeting with US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin, citing US "artificial obstacles" as the reason. The Shangri-La Dialogue will focus on issues including Russia's war in Ukraine, tensions between China and Taiwan, and North Korea's weapons programmes, with no Russian or North Korean government delegates in attendance. Analysts say the lack of a bilateral meeting is a significant blow to US-China relations.

images.alt_text: The US had proposed in May that Secretary of Defence Lloyd Austin meet his counterpart Li Shangfu in Singapore during the Shangri-La Dialogue, a marquee Asia-Pacific security gathering.

site_title: Seatrium to replace Keppel DC Reit in STI
summary: SEATRIUM will replace Keppel DC Reit in the Straits Times Index (STI) starting June 19, 2023, following a quarterly review by FTSE Russell. Keppel DC Reit will be placed on the reserve list, alongside other non-constituents CapitaLand Ascott Trust, Frasers Centrepoint Trust, Olam Group, and Suntec Reit, in alphabetical order.

images.alt_text: The STI tracks the performance of the 30 largest and most liquid companies listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX).
CPIB announced on Wednesday that it had commenced investigations against Seatrium for alleged corruption offences.

0503 Darwis 吉宝企业提供照片 Suggested caption: Mr Loh Chin Hua, CEO of Keppel Corporation briefing media and analysts on Keppel’s major reorganisation to fast-track its transformation into a global alternative real asset manager and operator

site_title: Asia-Pacific family offices cut Greater China holdings in 2022: UBS survey
summary: Asia-Pacific family offices reduced their asset allocations to Greater China in 2022, citing policy uncertainties and rising geopolitical concerns. A UBS survey of 45 single family offices found allocations fell to 23% in 2022 from 40% in 2021. Only 15% plan to increase investments in Greater China over the next five years, indicating a decline in confidence in the region's economy. Policy uncertainties in China's property, education, and tech sectors were key factors in this shift, according to L H Koh, co-head of global family and institutional wealth Asia-Pacific at UBS Global Wealth Management.

images.alt_text: Tommy Leung, co-head of global family and institutional wealth Apac, UBS Global Wealth Management said investors like setting up family offices in Singapore as they feel comfortable in the country.
Hong Kong is trying to convince more family offices to open shop in the city.

site_title: Hong Kong’s crypto ambitions get a guarded reception from digital-asset companies
summary: Hong Kong has introduced a new crypto regulatory regime, allowing crypto exchanges to offer trading services to individuals and institutions if they secure and comply with licences. The framework aims to nurture a digital-asset hub, despite the industry's cautious response due to the 2022 market crash. Only a handful of major crypto firms, including Huobi and OKX, have expressed interest in applying for licences, with concerns over the added costs and regulatory requirements.

images.alt_text: “Despite the potential risks involved, (virtual assets) also carries with it fundamental value,” says Christopher Hui, Hong Kong’s secretary for financial services and the treasury.
China’s ban on crypto trading in 2021 dulled Hong Kong’s allure as a conduit for mainland cash.
The city has had a voluntary licencing system for crypto trading platforms since 2019.
Hong Kong will roll out a licencing regime for virtual-asset platforms on Jun 1, part of an effort to restore its status as a cutting-edge financial centre.

site_title: China new home prices, sales fall on soft demand in May
summary: China's new home prices fell 0.01% month-on-month in May, marking the first decline in four months, according to a private survey. Home sales by value also plummeted 18.8% from the previous month, adding pressure to the struggling property market. Demand remains bleak, particularly in small cities, as consumers remain cautious about big-ticket spending due to concerns over incomes and jobs. Experts warn of further market weakness, citing a lack of policy easing and stimulus measures.

images.alt_text: Out of the 295 units, only three have been sold as of May 22.

site_title: Fed signal for rate pause takes pressure off hot jobs report
summary: Federal Reserve officials signaled a pause in interest rate hikes, citing a need to assess data before making a decision. Governor Philip Jefferson, a centrist nominee, stated that skipping an increase would give policymakers time to review data, but not rule out future tightening. This move reduces market expectations of a rate hike in June, following a key employment report on Friday. Investor bets for a hike have fallen to 35% from nearly 60% earlier, as the importance of the jobs report is downplayed.

images.alt_text: A shopper caries a Zara clothing retailer bag  past GAP and Coach in Regent Street in London, U.K., on Tuesday, April 17, 2018. Photographer: Luke MacGregor/Bloomberg
Government data on Friday (May 26) are projected to show payrolls in the US increased by less than 200,000 in May.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Citi downgrades Suntec Reit to ‘sell’ ahead of expected office market downcycle
summary: Citi Research has downgraded Suntec Reit to "sell" from "neutral" and slashed its target price to S$1.13 from S$1.41 due to a potential downcycle in the office property market. The downgrade comes after the research house lowered its distribution per unit estimates for the Reit to account for higher debt costs, lower office rents, and weaker contribution from Singapore assets. Citi expects an industry downturn to impact Suntec Reit negatively, with a rental downcycle and subdued demand due to weak economic growth.

images.alt_text: Suntec Reit’s manager expects financing costs to remain high for the year.
Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust’s VivoCity recorded positive rent reversion at 7.9 per cent.
CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) has proposed to acquire an 80 per cent interest in phases one and two of the Singapore-Hangzhou Science and Technology Park (pictured).
Higher interest expense for the period results in a 27.8 per cent rise in finance costs for the Reit.

site_title: Asti says newly appointed valuer will help to facilitate, expedite potential exit offer
summary: Asti Holdings, a Singapore-listed semiconductor company, has appointed a new valuer to facilitate and expedite a potential exit offer. The company, which has been directed to delist by the Singapore Exchange, has received a non-binding letter of intent for an exit offer from a consortium. Asti's new valuer is working closely with its auditors to determine the valuation of its associate EoCell, which will help complete the company's FY2022 audit by September 30. The appointment is seen as a positive step towards a potential exit, with the company stating that an exit offer is the best available option for shareholders.

images.alt_text: Sias founder and chief executive David Gerald is asking Asti's board to answer a number of questions on behalf of the company's "concerned shareholders".
Semiconductor company ASTI has updated that the potential offeror has submitted applications to the Securities Industry Council in relation to the offer.
Boardroom battles where shareholders seek to propose resolutions to remove an existing director are always going to be acrimonious encounters.
Seminconductor company Asti said on Sunday it received an unsolicited, non-binding letter of intent for the acquisition of all the company's shares.
SGX has directed ASTI to hold its FY2021 and FY2022 AGM by 30 July 2023.
The company also urged shareholders not to attend the EGM and that even if any resolutions were to be passed through at the EGM, they would also be deemed invalid.
Michael Loh Soon Gnee (pictured) and Capital Engineering Network Public Company entered into a share purchase agreement on Feb 8.

site_title: Shein plans to bolster compliance and logistics executives ahead of US marketplace
summary: Shein, a Singapore-based e-retailer, is bolstering senior leaders and logistics executives to expand its US marketplace and meet regulatory compliance amid growing scrutiny from US lawmakers over its connections to China. The company is hiring a US head of logistics and anti-money laundering and compliance executives, and is also expanding its US marketplace personnel. The hiring comes as Shein faces criticism over its use of customs exemptions that allow low-cost packages to enter the US duty-free, raising concerns about forced labor.

images.alt_text: Now headquartered in Singapore, Shein competes with PDD Holdings’ Temu, which sells low-priced items ranging from clothing to electronics from China in the US.
Online, Shein plans to create a digital marketplace that will allow shoppers to buy other products from other brands through its platform.

site_title: Dubai ruler announces plan for mothballed second palm-shaped island
summary: Dubai's ruler, Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum, announced a plan to revive the mothballed Palm Jebel Ali, a palm-shaped island that has been dormant since 2009. The island, double the size of the functioning Palm Jumeirah, will feature over 80 hotels and resorts, catering to tourists. The move aims to capitalize on Dubai's booming property market, particularly among Russians fleeing the conflict in Ukraine.

site_title: South Korea exports fall for 8th month but pace eases for chip, China shipments
summary: South Korea's exports fell 15.2% year-on-year to $52.24 billion in May, marking the 8th consecutive month of decline, but at a slower pace than expected. The decline was largely due to weak demand for semiconductors, with China shipments easing 20.8% and exports to the US and EU also declining. However, trade minister Lee Chang-Yang expects a significant improvement in June's trade balance. New data shows a possible recovery in overseas demand, with the smallest fall in new export orders in 15 months.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Korea has already halted interest-rate increases, with analysts predicting a cut later this year as the country narrowly skirted a recession in the first quarter.
The vast majority of South Korean semiconductor exports are memory chips.
The weak economic activity in April follows the country’s slim growth in the first quarter of this year.

site_title: Asia’s super rich plan to invest more in Greater China: UBS
summary: Asia's ultra-rich families are planning to increase their investments in China by 30% in the next five years, according to UBS research. This follows a dip in 2022 due to Covid Zero restrictions and Beijing's tightening grip on the private sector. Meanwhile, family offices in Asia are diversifying their investments, with a 13% increase in allocations to the rest of the region and a focus on fixed income and equities in developed markets. Geopolitics remains a top concern, but Asia-Pacific family offices expect hedge funds to meet performance targets in the next 12 months.

images.alt_text: While factories in Asia’s north bore the brunt of the economic pain, those in the south presented a mixed picture.
Stocks in Japan, India and Korea have beaten China peers more often than not since 2020.

site_title: Swiss watch exports to top market US down for first time in over 2 years
summary: Swiss watch exports to the US declined for the first time in over 2 years, falling 4.9% in April, according to the Federation of the Swiss Watch Industry. Despite this, overall Swiss watch exports rose 6.8% in April and 10.5% in the first 4 months of the year. Exports to China surged 107% in April, while sales to Hong Kong and the UK increased by 16% and 10% respectively. The decline in US demand signals a slowdown in luxury Swiss watch sales, but global demand remains strong.

images.alt_text: While launched as “new to the Black Bay line”, the Black Bay 54 is actually a downsized version of the Black Bay Fifty-Eight introduced in 2018.
The Swiss-based firm blasted the move in an earlier statement after officials from Malaysia’s home affairs ministry confiscated more than a hundred watches from its Pride Collection.
Franck Muller’s CEO Nicholas Rudaz calls the novelties "very colourful, very complicated and very sporty."

site_title: An en bloc success, higher taxes and a new home launch
summary: A successful en bloc sale of Bagnall Court condominium for S$115.3 million below its guide price, and a private treaty negotiation period for Golden Mile Tower's en bloc sale. Meanwhile, a GuocoLand-led group is developing Guoco Midtown, a mixed-use development in the Beach Road area, and a consortium is redeveloping Golden Mile Complex. Despite sound fundamentals supporting Singapore property growth, near-term demand for space may be affected by the technology sector's reduced needs, and interest rates may remain high in 2023.

site_title: Asia’s factories signal more pain as China recovery falters
summary: Asia's factories saw mixed results in May, with Taiwan's PMI dropping to 44.3 and Vietnam's to a 15-year low, while South Korea's gauge ticked up marginally. Japan's factory activity reversed a decline for the first time since October 2022. New orders and output fell across most Asian markets, with China's manufacturing activity slipping deeper into contraction territory. The data suggests a disappointing second-quarter performance for the region, with weak Chinese growth weighing on regional trading partners.

images.alt_text: Stocks in Japan, India and Korea have beaten China peers more often than not since 2020.
Interest in AI has risen exponentially since the launch of ChatGPT late last year, prompting technology companies to rush out competing tools and chips to power them.

site_title: 12 people charged after company bank accounts used to launder US$36 million in scam proceeds
summary: Twelve people linked to 35 Singapore-registered companies have been charged with laundering US$36 million in scam proceeds through compromised bank accounts. The scams originated from business e-mail compromise, investment, and love scams. The companies failed to use reasonable diligence in their duties as directors, allowing foreign agents to operate the accounts. Those charged could face imprisonment terms of up to 12 months or fines of up to S$50,000. The case highlights the importance of directors' diligence and the consequences of breaching their duties.

images.alt_text: The agritech investments promised returns of up to 20 per cent per annum and more than S$3 million were collected from the investors, said the police.

site_title: India’s May factory activity grows at fastest pace since 2020
summary: India's factory activity expanded at its fastest pace since October 2020, growing at a 6.1% annual pace in the last quarter, according to a private survey. The manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) rose to a 2.5-year high of 58.7 in May, driven by strong demand and optimism, leading to the hiring of workers at the fastest rate in six months. This growth contrasts with regional peers such as China, Japan, and South Korea, and has strengthened the foundations of India's economy.

images.alt_text: China’s Lenovo and Singapore-based Flex, electronic manufacturers like CTDI, R-Logic, and Aforeserve have volunteered for the three-month-long Electronics Repair Services Outsourcing (ERSO) programme.
India's full-year growth estimate has been revised to 7.2 per cent, above an earlier estimate of 7 per cent.

site_title: Oil settles higher but posts fourth straight quarterly decline
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday, settling higher but posting a fourth consecutive quarterly decline, as investors worried about sluggish global economic activity and rising interest rates. Benchmark Brent crude futures rose 56 cents to $74.90 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 78 cents to $70.64 a barrel. Despite OPEC+ production cuts, prices remain under pressure due to macroeconomic concerns, with a Reuters survey predicting oil prices will struggle this year.

images.alt_text: Investors were concerned about rising interest rates and economic growth after Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell reiterated that he expects the moderate pace of interest rate decisions to continue in the coming months.

site_title: Jobs Transformation Map to boost retail sector with digital upskilling
summary: Singapore's Jobs Transformation Map (JTM) for Retail aims to boost the sector with digital upskilling, addressing challenges such as shifting consumer demands, labor shortages, and automation. The map identifies four key trends and nine emerging job roles that require new skill sets. Retailers can seek help from the Jobs-Skills Integrator for the sector, which will advise on job redesign and reskilling, and facilitate funding support. The initiative is expected to help retailers transform jobs, such as sales associates, to manage both online and offline channels, and address manpower shortages.

images.alt_text: Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling launched the Retail Industry Transformation Map 2025 at the official opening of Castlery’s flagship store.
Compared to last year, retail brands have expanded their range of products and stocked up on inventory in preparation for the holiday shopping season.

In line with the new Jobs Transformation Map (JTM) for food services, trade associations and chambers in the sector have committed to work with over 800 member companies, employing around 80,000 workers, to transform their jobs.

site_title: Lawsuit filed against Clearbridge Health chief in Jakarta court
summary: Clearbridge Health's executive director and CEO Jeremy Yee has been named as a defendant in a civil suit filed by shareholder Kreasi Putra Nusantara (KPN) in a Jakarta court. KPN claims Yee is liable for damages of 30 billion rupiah ($2.7 million) for allegedly conducting an unlawful extraordinary general meeting (EGM) of IGM, a former subsidiary of Clearbridge Health, in December 2022. Clearbridge Health's nominating committee and board have stated that Yee remains suitable to continue in his roles.

images.alt_text: Lawsuit against two Clearbridge units dismissed over jurisdiction issue

site_title: Divining demand, a mega mall deal, and commercial concerns
summary: Singapore's housing market is expected to slow down this year, with private residential prices forecasted to grow around 5% compared to 2022's 8.6% increase. The government is keeping a close eye on housing prices and borrowing, and affordability remains a concern. The rental market is also expected to be influenced by China's reopening and increased mobility. Meanwhile, the retail sector is showing signs of recovery, with Frasers' acquisition of Nex mall and retail Reits posting strong results. The office market, however, is facing uncertainty due to mass layoffs and economic uncertainties.

site_title: UK economic growth unrevised at 0.1% in Q1 2023
summary: The UK economy grew 0.1% in Q1 2023, unrevised from the initial estimate, but its GDP was 0.5% smaller than before the Covid-19 pandemic. The economy narrowly avoided a recession at the start of 2023, but economists expect it to tip into one in the second half of the year due to ongoing interest rate pressures. Households face increased costs and pressure from inflation, with real disposable income 0.8% smaller than the previous quarter. The current account deficit widened to £10.8 billion, or 1.7% of GDP.

images.alt_text: Inflation in the UK has defied the BOE’s efforts to rein in prices, prompting the central bank to unexpectedly raise interest rates by half a percentage point last week.

site_title: UK house prices resume decline with warning of headwinds
summary: UK house prices declined 0.1% in May, according to Nationwide's measure, reversing a 0.4% gain in April. The decline marks the fifth consecutive fall in prices, with the annual pace accelerating to 3.4%. Mortgage costs are expected to remain high due to inflation, with interest rates projected to remain higher for longer, potentially exerting upward pressure on mortgage rates. Despite the decline, demand in London remains high, and estate agents expect confidence to return to the market as the year progresses.

images.alt_text: Terraced residential housing in Sheffield, UK, on Friday, May 19, 2023. The Office for National Statistics are due to release the latest UK CPI Inflation data on Wednesday. Photographer: Dominic Lipinski/Bloomberg

site_title: HSBC explores deals in ESG debt market that Credit Suisse built
summary: HSBC is exploring debt-for-nature swaps, a growing market dominated by Credit Suisse, to free up capital for environmental commitments in countries with limited access to bond or loan markets. HSBC's managing director, Farnam Bidgoli, says the bank is cautious about the market's efficiency and is considering alternative structures, such as green or sustainability-linked bonds. The market, valued at potentially $2 trillion, faces challenges including high transaction fees and limited liquidity.

images.alt_text: OK Lim, founder of collapsed Hin Leong empire, appears in State Courts for the third day of hearing on cheating and forgery charges levelled against him by Singapore prosecutors
The British government and the Bank of England facilitated a private sale of SVB UK to HSBC in March.

“It’s overwhelmingly clear what the majority of our shareholders bar one expect from us, and therefore all our focus now is on delivering for the business and for our customers,” Georges Elhedery, HSBC's CFO, says.

site_title: Singapore hotels’ overall room revenue at year-to-date high in May
summary: Singapore hotels achieved a year-to-date high in room revenue in May, reaching S$398 million, a 9.1% increase from April and 72.7% higher than May 2022. Average room rates (ARR) edged down 0.4% to S$270.75, but were up 21.7% year-on-year. RevPAR and average occupancy rate also showed sequential growth, with RevPAR up 2.5% and average occupancy at 79.9%. The recovery in tourism is expected to continue, with hotel RevPAR projected to grow with better occupancy rates.

images.alt_text: On the year, hotels' average room rate is up 32.8 per cent on the year.
China is the fourth-largest source of tourist arrivals to Singapore in May, with 95,613 visitors.
Mark Shaw, chairman of the Orchard Road Business Association (ORBA).

site_title: CapitaLand Investment raises renewable energy target as part of refreshed 2030 sustainability master plan
summary: CapitaLand Investment (CLI) has updated its 2030 sustainability master plan, aiming to increase its use of renewable energy to 45% by 2030 from 35%, and to reduce waste intensity by 20%. The company also targets at least 40% female representation in senior management. CLI aims to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050 and reduce Scope 1 and 2 carbon emissions by 46% by 2030, leveraging sustainable finance and integrating sustainability into the real estate lifecycle.

images.alt_text: Meanwhile, revenue from CLI's real estate investment business rose 11 per cent to S$447 million in Q1 2023, from S$403 million in the previous year.

site_title: Sri Lanka surprises with interest-rate cut, signals rebound from crisis
summary: Sri Lanka's Central Bank (CBSL) surprised markets by cutting interest rates for the first time in three years, signaling a potential rebound in the economy. The CBSL reduced its standing deposit facility rate and standing lending facility rate to 13% and 14% respectively, from 15.5% and 16.5%. The decision comes after a US$2.9 billion bailout from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) helped ease inflation and pressure on the country's balance of payments. The government aims to restructure its debt by September to unlock more IMF funds, and analysts expect the economy to grow from the third quarter, with inflation forecast to reach single-digit levels by September.

images.alt_text: Soaring inflation has battered the economy for more than a year after a severe foreign exchange crisis set off Sri Lanka’s worst financial crisis in seven decades.

Krishna Srinivasan, Director of the Asia and Pacific Department at the IMF says the governance exercise will identify key weaknesses and corruption vulnerabilities across six key areas including central bank governance, financial sector oversight, market regulations among others.

site_title: No halt on Malaysia, Indonesia EU trade talks over palm oil, says Malaysian minister
summary: Malaysia's Commodities Minister Fadillah Yusof stated that negotiations with the EU on a free trade agreement (FTA) will resume if the EU treats Malaysia fairly and as a partner. The talks have been on hold since 2012 due to a dispute over a deforestation law affecting small palm oil producers. Indonesia, the world's largest palm oil producer, is also negotiating with the EU, but has been "very patient" waiting for a resolution. The EU's law banning the import of products from land cleared of forests has been criticized by both countries as punitive and unfair.

images.alt_text: Most precious metals have fallen in price, except for gold. Silver and copper are down 4.7 per cent and 3.9 per cent, respectively, this year. Gold, meanwhile, is up 7.2 per cent.
Indonesia and Malaysia accounts for about 85 per cent of global palm oil exports and the EU is their third-largest market.
The expansion will be done in phases based on the readiness of biodiesel blending facilities across Malaysia, Commodities Minister Fadillah Yusof says.

site_title: Singapore hotels’ average room rate recovers from March slip, gains 3.3% in April
summary: Singapore hotels' average room rate (ARR) rose 3.3% in April to S$273.18, driven by a 32.8% year-on-year increase. RevPAR edged up 0.6% to S$212.69, while overall room revenue slipped 0.6% to S$368 million. Despite a slight decrease in average occupancy rate to 77.9%, ARR generally improved across hotel categories, with luxury and upscale hotels experiencing sequential increases. The recovery is attributed to 'revenge travel' and increased demand from business travelers and tourists willing to spend on better accommodations.

images.alt_text: Indonesia is the top source of tourists in April, with Malaysia, India, Australia and China rounding out the top five.
The Jobs Transformation Map identifies how job roles and skills in the hotel industry will be affected by technology, as well as global and local trends, over the next three years.

On top of resuming travel and recovering flight and airport capacities, Singapore must redefine our destination, reconnect with our fans, and reinvent our industry to secure the future of tourism, says STB chief executive Keith Tan.

site_title: IMF urges Bank of Japan to keep ultra-low rates, but be ready to shift course
summary: The International Monetary Fund's chief economist Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas urged the Bank of Japan to maintain ultra-low interest rates, as it will take time to re-anchor inflation expectations to its 2% target. However, the central bank must be prepared to tighten policy if inflation remains above its target for too long. Gourinchas cited the experience of other central banks, such as the US and European central banks, which struggled to tame high inflation, and warned that Japan could face similar dynamics. The BOJ must be vigilant and communicate its readiness to address inflation risks if they arise.

images.alt_text: While factories in Asia’s north bore the brunt of the economic pain, those in the south presented a mixed picture.

Japanese yen banknotes of various denominations are arranged for a photograph in Soka City, Saitama Prefecture, Japan, on Wednesday, Aug. 29, 2012. The dollar headed for a monthly advance versus the yen before U.S. data forecast to show consumer spending rose the most since February. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

Children held by their parents start their "Baby-cry Sumo" match, resumed for the first time in four years due to the Covid-19 coronavirus pandemic, at the Sensoji temple in Tokyo on April 22, 2023. (Photo by Philip FONG / AFP)
The BOJ has kept ultra-low interest rates on the view the recent rise in inflation above its 2 per cent target is driven mostly by cost-push factors.

site_title: Aims Apac Reit’s private placement closes at S$1.214 apiece
summary: AIMS Apac Reit's private placement of new units closed at S$1.214 per unit, at the low end of the estimated price range. The placement aims to raise S$70 million, with around 57.7 million units issued. The manager also plans to declare an advanced distribution of between S$0.017 and S$0.019 per unit, and will use funds to enhance assets, reduce debt, and pay fees. The new units are expected to be issued on or around June 12.

images.alt_text: Aims Apac Reit to launch equity funding exercise to raise around S$100 million

site_title: What’s the point of prizes?
summary: The existence of prizes implies the existence of "bright excellence" in a world torn apart by conflict, suggesting humanity is meant for better than destruction. Prizes bring great entertainment but don't change anything, with award ceremonies ranging from demure literary events to extravagant TV shows. The value of prizes is debated, with some viewing them as a measure of worth, while others see them as empty gestures.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Ke Huy Quan and team from "Everything Everywhere All at Once" arrives at the Vanity Fair Oscar party after the 95th Academy Awards, known as the Oscars,  in Beverly Hills, California, U.S., March 12, 2023. REUTERS/Danny Moloshok/File Photo
Andrea Riseborough, Best Actress Oscar nominee for To Leslie..

site_title: Apac family offices bullish on equities, fixed-income instruments in developed markets: UBS
summary: Asia-Pacific family offices are optimistic about equities and fixed-income instruments in developed markets, with 40% planning to increase stakes in the next five years. The UBS Global Family Office Report 2023 found that Apac family offices allocated 28% of their investments to equity-related investments in developed markets, up from 18% in 2021. This shift reflects investors' confidence in the region's growth and diversification into dollar-denominated assets.

images.alt_text: Robust demand and a strong currency can draw foreigners to Singapore property despite high taxes and low yields.

Robert Weeber, AlTi president (international wealth management); Anthonia Hui and Leonardo Drago, co-founders of AL Wealth Partners. The merger is expected to open up new opportunities for families in areas like impact capital.

site_title: Australia first-quarter business investment hits 7-year high, outlook solid
summary: Australia's business investment surged to a 7-year high in the first quarter, reaching A$36.1 billion, driven by a 1.7% rise in the mining sector. This marks the highest level since 2015. Firms also boosted their spending plans for the year to A$137.6 billion, up 6.4%. Despite forecasts of a gloomy GDP print, business investment may be a "bright spot" in the economy, according to analysts.

images.alt_text: China is Australia’s largest trading partner but the relationship became strained and trade sanctions were placed on a range of Australian exports in 2020.
Prices in bellwether Sydney jumped 1.8 per cent, the city’s biggest increase since September 2021.

site_title: PM Lee tests positive for Covid-19 again; doctors cite ‘rebound’ which occurs in 5 to 10% of cases
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has tested positive for Covid-19 again, approximately 5-10 days after his initial recovery. He feels fine and has been advised by doctors to self-isolate until he tests ART negative. The "rebound" case is a rare occurrence, affecting 5-10% of cases, and PM Lee's risk of transmission is considered low. He will miss a scheduled ceremony but prioritizes the safety of others, expressing apologies to the organizers.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong had tested positive for Covid-19 on May 22, following a recent string of work trips.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said he tested positive for Covid-19 after recent work trips.

site_title: Temasek-backed Tessa Therapeutics to cease operations after failure to raise funding
summary: Tessa Therapeutics, a Singapore-based biotech company backed by Temasek, will cease operations after failing to secure funding. The company, which had raised $397.8 million in equity funding, cited market conditions and reduced investor risk appetite as reasons for the decision. Despite announcing promising results for a cancer treatment cell therapy platform, the company was unable to attract investors, leading to its liquidation. The closure raises implications for Singapore's emerging biotech ecosystem.

images.alt_text: Wanted: experts to sit on startups’ scientific advisory boards
Tessa is a player in the niche field of CAR-T therapy.
Tessa is a player in the niche field of CAR-T therapy.

site_title: Global money is fast chasing alternatives in Asian equities as China anxiety grows
summary: Global investors are shifting their focus away from China's equity market as anxiety over the country's economy grows. Since 2020, stocks in Japan, India, and Korea have outperformed China's peers more often than not. Despite concerns that a slowdown in China will drag on other Asian markets, these countries' strong growth prospects, including chipmakers in Korea and Taiwan, and a growing retail investor base in India, are attracting investors. Overseas inflows into Japan and Korea have increased, while global fund allocations for China have dropped to October levels, with China's stock gauge experiencing losses of up to 20%.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Korea has already halted interest-rate increases, with analysts predicting a cut later this year as the country narrowly skirted a recession in the first quarter.
Youth unemployment in China hit a record 20.4 per cent in April, and a new high of 11.58 million university students are due to graduate this summer.

site_title: Gold trades in tight range as market awaits debt ceiling vote
summary: Gold prices edged up 0.2% to $1,965.61 per ounce, but remained in a tight range as traders await the US debt ceiling vote. The bill to suspend the US debt ceiling cleared a key hurdle in the House of Representatives, setting the stage for a vote. Investors view a US default as a potential catastrophic event for global markets, despite a softer dollar making bullion less expensive for overseas buyers. Meanwhile, US job openings unexpectedly rose in April, pointing to persistent labor market strength that could prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates again.

images.alt_text: Higher interest rates dull the appeal for zero-yield bullion.

site_title: IReit Global to acquire portfolio of retail properties in France for 76.8 million euros
summary: IReit Global, a Europe-focused real estate investment trust (Reit), is acquiring a portfolio of 17 retail properties in France for approximately 76.8 million euros (S$112.2 million). The portfolio is fully leased to B&M Group, a leading discount retailer in Europe, and will increase IReit Global's portfolio to 54 assets. The acquisition is expected to generate an initial net property income yield of 7.9% and will be 2% accretive to the Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) on an adjusted basis. The deal is part of IReit Global's strategy to strengthen its exposure to index-linked assets in established European markets.

images.alt_text: IReit Global to acquire Decathlon properties in France for 110.5m euros
IREIT Global says that the European office market is likely to remain muted in 2023.
IReit Global's new tenant will be occupying about 25 per cent of Darmstadt Campus in the 15-year lease.

site_title: London's Heathrow appoints Danish airport boss Thomas Woldbye as CEO
summary: Heathrow Airport has appointed Thomas Woldbye, the current CEO of Copenhagen Airport, as its new CEO, replacing John Holland-Kaye. Woldbye will step down from Copenhagen Airport by September 30 after 12 years in the role. Heathrow Chairman Paul Deighton praised Woldbye's track record in running a major airport and securing consensus among stakeholders. Woldbye's appointment is seen as a significant move to address the airport's upgrade plans, which include higher fees to finance a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: China woos Dimon, Musk amid pressure on Xi to boost economy
summary: China is courting global business leaders, including Jamie Dimon and Elon Musk, amid concerns over the country's economy and anti-foreigner sentiment. The move comes as China faces a sluggish post-pandemic recovery, weak manufacturing and export data, and a property slump. Foreign direct investment into China has plummeted, with investors pulling $30 billion in the first quarter. Chinese officials, including President Xi Jinping, have emphasized protecting industrial security and welcoming foreign investment to bolster the economy. The resumption of global business leaders engaging in person with Chinese officials suggests a shift towards a more positive tone, with officials assuring foreign businesses that China will protect their interests and rights.

images.alt_text: Chinese State Councillor and Foreign Minister Qin Gang meeting Tesla chief executive officer Elon Musk in Beijing on Tuesday (May 30).
Tesla sold 267,171 Model Ys in the first quarter of this year, of which 94,469 were sold in China, higher than 83,664 in the United States and 71,114 in Europe.

Elon Musk said he was “willing to continue to expand its business in China”, according to a foreign ministry readout in which he also reportedly stressed Tesla’s opposition to economic “decoupling” with the United States.
JPMorgan Chase & Co CEO Jamie Dimon stressed the bank’s plans regarding his tenure were unchanged, although did not give specifics.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Broad markets consolidate; transportation stocks on the move (Ep 49)
summary: Broad markets in Singapore consolidated this shorter trading week, with transportation stocks on the move. SGX's wrap for the week highlighted the sector's performance. Insights from The Business Times' newsdesk and corporate news for investors provided additional analysis. The podcast concluded with notable news and commentary from the newsdesk. Transportation stocks' performance was attributed to market consolidation, with SGX Securities offering market insights.

images.alt_text: Did the skittish week for markets extend to Singapore?
How will the pause in the Fed's rate hike affect markets?

site_title: Salesforce gives forecast for slowing sales growth in push for profit
summary: Salesforce reported a lackluster outlook for future sales, with shares slipping 7.1% in extended trading. Despite beating analyst estimates in its fiscal first-quarter revenue and earnings, the company maintained its annual revenue forecast and shifted its focus to generating higher profits. This move has raised concerns among investors, following a tumultuous six months marked by job cuts, executive departures, and public pressure from activist investors.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on December 1, 2020, The Salesforce logo at Salesforce Tower in San Francisco, California. - Cloud computing giant Salesforce on January 4, 2023, said it was shedding about 10 percent of its employees, or just under 8,000 jobs, and closing several offices. With the plan, Salesforce joins other US tech giants including Facebook-owner Meta, Twitter and Amazon that have also imposed job cuts as the world economy heads into a downturn. (Photo by Stephen Lam / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / AFP)

site_title: Australia pushes trade diversification despite warmer China ties
summary: Australia is pushing for trade diversification despite warming economic ties with China, its largest trading partner. The government aims to reduce reliance on China through agreements with the European Union and India. Trade Minister Don Farrell emphasized the importance of diversifying trade, citing lessons learned from strained relationships with key trading partners, including China. The Australian government is also hopeful for an end to barley tariffs and eased restrictions on wine exports to China. The country is on the brink of finalizing a free-trade agreement with the EU and negotiating a broader trade deal with India.

images.alt_text: Prices in bellwether Sydney jumped 1.8 per cent, the city’s biggest increase since September 2021.

Appearing before lawmakers, Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe said inflation expectations were well anchored for now, but that cannot be taken for granted and entrenched inflation would lead to higher interest rates and unemployment.

site_title: Exxon, Chevron shareholders soundly reject climate-related petitions
summary: ExxonMobil and Chevron shareholders overwhelmingly rejected climate-related proposals at their annual meetings, dismissing over a dozen calls for stronger measures to mitigate climate change. Exxon, the only Western oil major without a 2030 target for reducing customers' carbon emissions, received less than half of the support for its emission reduction proposal. The results support the two companies in resisting pressure from investor groups to follow European rivals in accepting tougher emissions reductions goals.

images.alt_text: The Corruption Practices Investigation Bureau has commenced investigations on Seatrium for alleged corruption offences, said the agency in a Wednesday press release.
Opec+ is meeting as prices slide below US$70 a barrel in New York, giving up the gains made since Saudi Arabia and other members made a surprise cut in early April.
Brent crude futures for August delivery settled US$1.11 lower to US$72.60 a barrel on Wednesday.

site_title: US House passes debt ceiling deal as default threat looms
summary: The US House of Representatives passed a debt ceiling deal with a 314-117 vote, sending the legislation to the Senate before a Monday deadline when the federal government is expected to run out of money. The bill, a compromise between President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, suspends the debt ceiling through January 1, 2025, and includes spending cuts and reforms. The measure was supported by 165 Democrats and drew opposition from 71 hardline Republicans, who had sought deeper spending cuts and more stringent reforms. A deal in the Senate is expected before the weekend, with potential delays over amendment votes.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.4 per cent lower at 34,908.27 on Wednesday.
A shopper caries a Zara clothing retailer bag  past GAP and Coach in Regent Street in London, U.K., on Tuesday, April 17, 2018. Photographer: Luke MacGregor/Bloomberg
McCarthy, a California Republican, has repeatedly said that he would secure the support of a majority of his conference for the bill itself.
The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage increases 22 basis points to 6.91 per cent, according to Mortgage Bankers Association (MBA) data out on Wednesday (May 31).

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.2% to 3,165.33. Losers outnumbered gainers 57 to 44, despite global markets being down due to concerns over a China slowdown and US debt ceiling voting. DBS rose 0.8%, UOB gained 0.9%, while OCBC fell 0.2%. The STI was also boosted by gains in CapitaLand Ascott Trust, which rose 0.9%.

images.alt_text: Concor Park in Munich, Germany is part of IReit Global's portfolio.

site_title: Seatrium says CPIB’s investigations relate to Sembcorp Marine’s activities before 2015
summary: Seatrium, a Singapore-based company, is under investigation by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) for alleged corruption offences. The investigation, which began after a notice from the Office of the Comptroller General of Brazil, relates to events prior to 2015 and involves Sembcorp Marine, with which Seatrium merged in February 2023. Seatrium is cooperating with CPIB and has stated it will make announcements if material developments occur. No formal charges have been laid against key executives, and their identities have not been disclosed.

images.alt_text: The Corruption Practices Investigation Bureau has commenced investigations on Seatrium for alleged corruption offences, said the agency in a Wednesday press release.
The STI tracks the performance of the 30 largest and most liquid companies listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX).

site_title: Stocks to watch: IReit Global, Clearbridge Health
summary: IReit Global is acquiring a portfolio of 17 French retail properties for 76.8 million euros, partially funded by a preferential offering of new units. Clearbridge Health's CEO Jeremy Yee is a defendant in a civil suit filed by a shareholder in a Jakarta court. Aspen (Group) and Seatrium have requested trading halts pending announcements, with Seatrium facing an investigation for alleged corruption offences. Sysma has also requested a trading halt, while NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times.

site_title: China slowdown fear is starting to show up in South Korean markets
summary: South Korea's markets are showing signs of concern over a China slowdown, despite the Bank of Korea halting interest-rate increases. Foreigners bought $11 billion of Korean debt in May, the most since 2021, as they wager on the central bank turning dovish. Analysts predict a cut later this year due to the country's narrow recession in the first quarter. The deteriorating economic outlook for China's largest trading partner is contributing to concerns of slowing growth in Asia's biggest economy.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Korea starts raising interest rates in August 2021 to tame inflation.

site_title: Squeezed UK households tap into savings at record pace
summary: British households withdrew £3.8 billion from savings in May at a record pace, driven by withdrawals from bank accounts and offset by inflows into government savings products. Mortgage approvals fell to 50,524 in May, down from 66,000 in the same period last year, as higher interest rates weigh on the housing market. This marks the first back-to-back falls in net mortgage lending since 1997.

images.alt_text: IMF official Alfred Kammer says the BOE's surprise move last week to ramp up its pace of tightening was "important".
The CBI says retail sales volumes are average for the time of year at +1 per cent in June compared with -18 per cent in May.
Inflation has proven particularly sticky in the UK with the consumer prices index rising the same amount in May as the previous month.

site_title: After Yin’s Major breakthrough, hopes rekindle for China to produce more top golfers
summary: Chinese golfer Yin Ruoning won the KPMG Women's PGA Championship, becoming the second golfer from China to win a Major, following Feng Shanshan's 2012 victory. This breakthrough has reignited hopes for China to produce more top golfers, with several Chinese golfers performing well on the American Korn Ferry Tour and European Tour. Liang Wen Chong's 2010 PGA Championship finish and Zhang Lianwei's 2004 Masters appearance had raised expectations, but China's golfing success was hindered by the Covid-19 pandemic. Yin's win has sparked renewed optimism for China's golfing future.

images.alt_text: The 20-year-old Yin, who collected her maiden LPGA Tour title at the DIO Implant LA Open earlier this year, is only the second Chinese woman to win a golf major.
Rickie Fowler waits to putt on the sixth green during the first round of the US Open Championship at The Los Angeles Country Club on June 15, 2023.
The Singapore Turf Club's closure comes amid shrinking audiences and prize purses.

site_title: Japan, South Korea to discuss FX swap deal in first finance talks for 7 years
summary: Japan and South Korea will hold their first bilateral finance dialogue in 7 years on June 29, aiming to mend strained ties and discuss common geo-strategic risks. The talks will focus on restoring a lapsed currency swap arrangement, global economic developments, and multilateral financial cooperation. The deal's restoration would symbolize improved relations, analysts say, as both countries face challenges from China and North Korea. Japanese Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki and South Korean counterpart Choo Kyungho will lead the discussions.

site_title: Showcasing South-east Asian heritage at Restaurant Fiz
summary: Restaurant Fiz, a new eatery in Tanjong Pagar, Singapore, showcases South-east Asian heritage through its modern Malay cuisine. Chef Hafizzul Hashim's menu is inspired by his childhood and grandmother's cooking traditions, featuring dishes such as deep-fried oysters, ayam percik, and crabmeat in yellow curry. The restaurant's interior is quietly opulent, with a monastic vibe and energetic flamenco guitar music. The chef's Michelin-starred background and knowledge of regional ingredients and techniques come together to create a unique dining experience. A seven-course menu, including desserts, is available for $288, with a focus on authentic South-east Asian flavors and ingredients.

images.alt_text: Barrio's interiors are cheaply done in a cheerfully unkempt way.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as upbeat US data plays against rates outlook
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Wednesday as upbeat US data on consumer confidence and new home sales offset concerns about inflation and interest rates. The US economy remained resilient despite rate hikes, lifting hopes of a "soft landing" for the Fed. However, a report that Washington may block AI chip exports to China weighed on sentiment. The Bank of Japan stood by its ultra-loose monetary policy, despite a weakening yen, and investors await a meeting of top central bankers later in the day.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong climbed more than one per cent after five days of losses, while Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Manila and Jakarta also rose. Tokyo, Seoul, Wellington and Taipei retreated.

site_title: Indian government meets Foxconn, Samsung, Reliance to improve PLI scheme
summary: The Indian government met with major global firms like Foxconn, Samsung, and Reliance Industries to improve the production-linked incentive (PLI) scheme, which aims to boost manufacturing in the country. The meeting, led by Trade Minister Piyush Goyal, focused on simplifying procedures, improving local manufacturing costs, and grievance redressal. The PLI scheme has attracted 625 billion Indian rupees in investments since its introduction in 2020, with estimated further investments of 2.74 trillion rupees. The government aims to increase payouts to 29 billion rupees across eight industries by fiscal 2023.

images.alt_text: Air India passenger aircraft are seen on the tarmac at Chhatrapati Shivaji International airport in Mumbai, India, February 14, 2023. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas
The partnership involves Infosys working with Danske to accelerate the bank’s technological transformation.

site_title: How seniors are spending it
summary: Seniors in Singapore are spending their higher disposable income on bespoke holidays and rejuvenating treatments, shifting away from traditional leisure activities. As the country becomes a "super-aged" society by 2030, with one in four citizens 65 and above, affluent seniors are seeking to live life to the fullest. They are opting for unique experiences, such as stem cell treatments and fine dining, and businesses are catering to this demographic, offering tailored services and luxury products.

site_title: Oil prices inch higher after political turmoil in Russia
summary: Oil prices rose slightly, with Brent crude futures increasing 33 US cents to $74.18 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate futures rising 21 US cents to $69.37 a barrel, amid concerns about global demand growth and potential supply disruptions due to Russian political instability. However, analysts say the geopolitical impact on the market is minimal, with economics dominating the market. The Russian turmoil may worsen supply shortages in the months ahead, with analysts warning of potential disruptions to oil supply.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures rose 1.3 per cent to US$74.78 a barrel and US crude was up by the same margin to US$70, recouping a little of losses made last week.

site_title: Are the good times over for Singapore’s listed watch retailers?
summary: Singapore's listed luxury watch retailers, The Hour Glass and Cortina Holdings, have seen their shares correct over the past year following a post-pandemic boom. Despite reporting higher profits and revenue in the FY2023, both companies have reported lower revenue growth and year-on-year declines in net profit in the second half of FY2023. Economic indicators suggest a slowdown in demand, with Bloomberg reporting a 15% drop in pre-owned watch prices and a potential technical recession in Singapore. However, the global economic environment is weakening, and stock markets have held up well, potentially driving consumer confidence and spending on luxury items.

images.alt_text: Shipments surge by 14 per cent in May to 2.3 billion Swiss francs (S$3.4 billion) in value, the Federation of the Swiss Watch Industry says on Tuesday (Jun 20).

site_title: Fresh, higher-quality deal opportunities sprout during funding drought
summary: Funding in South-east Asia declined 48% in the second half of 2022, and the trend continues into the first half of 2023, with venture capital firms seizing opportunities in a "funding winter." Startups are dropping valuations to attract investors, and founders are being forced to be more committed to their ventures. In response, venture capital firms are focusing on early-stage startups, quality deal flow, and lean, capital-efficient business models. The current environment is expected to test both founders and business models, with later-stage startups likely to be separated into those that can adjust their course and those that cannot.

images.alt_text: Fintech funding has been growing to new heights in 2022, but as the funding winter sets in, the next 12 months may not see money flowing as freely to fintechs as before.
A valuations soften, some startups are raising money to make acquisitions.

site_title: India flags antitrust concerns with Air India, Vistara merger
summary: India's Competition Commission has issued a "show cause" notice to Air India, asking it to explain why the planned merger with Vistara should not be investigated further over competition concerns. The merged entity could have a monopoly on certain routes and categories, such as business class travel. Air India has 30 days to respond, and if concerns persist, the CCI could order a "Phase II" review that could delay the merger. The move raises concerns about a duopoly in India's aviation market, with a merged Air India-Vistara and IndiGo controlling over 80% of the domestic market.

images.alt_text: With a total of almost 1,000 jet orders between them, IndiGo and Air India are betting an economic boom and growing middle class will spur demand for domestic air travel, and new jets will help them grab a bigger share of international traffic.

site_title: Lifestyles of affluent seniors: how they are living it up
summary: Singapore's affluent seniors are redefining retirement, moving beyond traditional stereotypes. Unlike the image of uncles gathering over beers, affluent seniors are prioritizing lifestyle and travel, with 61% of high net worth individuals aged 60 and above engaging in leisure activities. The country's ageing population is driving a shift towards palliative care, with the government acknowledging the need for evolving healthcare services. As the population ages, seniors are focusing on maintaining their health, fitness, and legacy, with many seeking to stay active and engaged in their golden years.

site_title: Indian central bank members diverge on further rate hikes as growth risks emerge
summary: India's Reserve Bank of India (RBI) monetary policy committee members diverged on future rate hikes, with some arguing that further tightening could harm the economic recovery. The RBI kept interest rates steady for the second meeting in a row, citing inflation concerns. External members expressed caution, while internal members emphasized the need for vigilance against inflation risks. The RBI reiterated its inflation target of 4% and emphasized the need for forward-looking assessment of the economy.

images.alt_text: “The cumulative impact of our monetary policy actions over the last one year is still unfolding and yet to materialise fully,” Reserve Bank of India (RBI) governor Shaktikanta Das says.

site_title: Seven years on, Brexit puzzle grows
summary: Seven years after the UK's EU exit referendum, a growing number of Brexiteers, including former Leave campaign leader Nigel Farage, now believe Brexit has failed. A YouGov poll found 22% of Leave voters from 2016 think Brexit is a mistake, with 56% of those who consider Brexit a failure believing it was doomed from the start. The UK is now widely perceived as not "making Brexit work," with a focus shifting to making the most of the freedoms Brexit offers, rather than re-joining the EU.

images.alt_text: One UK official says they have told Prime Minister Rishi Sunak that strong trading relations with Europe will be essential for the economic challenges of the future in areas such as emerging technologies, and to deal with threats like global supply shocks and China.
Another aim of the treaty is to cut remaining tariffs on UK exports such as red meat, chocolate and baked goods.
Boris Johnson knows that causing by-elections by resigning his seat in parliament will expose the weakness of his party and of Prime Minister Rishi Sunak.

site_title: ECB officials gather amid strain over hiking journey’s last mile
summary: European Central Bank officials are set to discuss the timing of interest rate hikes at their annual retreat, amid uncertainty over how much more tightening is needed to control inflation. Despite a survey suggesting the ECB will deliver the right dose of tightening, economists expect the final stages of the cycle to be the toughest. The ECB is considering whether to pause or continue hiking rates, with recent economic weakness in the eurozone and signs of stubborn underlying price gains weighing on their minds. A hike in July is likely, but the question remains whether a pause is warranted or more action is needed.

images.alt_text: The ECB has already raised borrowing costs by 400 basis points since last July, with another move next month all but certain.

Protestors during a demonstration against pension reform on Boulevard Voltaire in central Paris, France, on Tuesday, March 28, 2023. French unions are holding a new day of nationwide strikes Tuesday to try to force President Emmanuel Macron to reverse his decision to push through unpopular pension reforms. Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg

site_title: 'Crazy' good: star chef Ana Ros puts Slovenia on food map
summary: Slovenian chef Ana Ros, owner of two-Michelin-starred restaurant Hisa Franko, is helping put her small Alpine homeland on the European culinary map. With a self-taught approach and a "crazy" personality, Ros has gained international recognition for her innovative flavor combinations. Her restaurant, currently ranked 32nd in the World's 50 Best Restaurants list, showcases the country's unique cuisine, which blends Latin, Slavic, and Germanic influences. Ros's success is credited to her commitment to using local, seasonal ingredients and honoring traditional Slovenian cooking methods.

images.alt_text: Gravy-glossed, egg-topped loco moco is a beloved Hawaiian dish. The local cuisine is a distinctive reflection of the various groups who settled on the islands – the authenticity lies in the merging of cultures, not the siloing of them.

site_title: Asia Grand prevails in legal dispute against interior designer for its Bras Basah restaurant
summary: The High Court has ruled in favor of Asia Grand, a restaurant operator, in a dispute with boutique interior designer AI Associates over the remodelling of its restaurant in Fairmont Singapore. AI Associates was awarded a contract to carry out work on July 13, 2022, and claimed S$133,529.08 from Asia Grand for the project. The court has allowed a February 15 adjudication determination against Asia Grand to be set aside, effectively overturning the claim. The outcome is a victory for Asia Grand, which had disputed the payment claim made by AI Associates.

images.alt_text: Asia Grand's new interiors at Fairmont Singapore.
Corner House closed its doors on June 17.
Zeniya Kanazawa in located in a traditional wooden house in the samurai town.
No Signboard's now-closed Esplanade outlet. The group is liquidating its various loss-making and non-core subsidiaries.

site_title: Helping SMEs tackle issues of liquidity, business development and efficiency
summary: Singapore's small and medium enterprises (SMEs) face challenges in growth and sustainability due to liquidity, business development, and operational efficiency issues. To overcome these, governments and institutions like banks can provide support from start-up to growth and expansion. SMEs should prioritize liquidity, develop business strategies, and adopt digital capabilities to overcome challenges. The Singapore government and financial institutions are committed to supporting SMEs through various schemes and initiatives, including the SME Co-Investment Fund and mentorship programs.

images.alt_text: Under a cost-sharing agreement, companies share the costs and risks of qualifying R&D activities, while claiming tax deductions on the proportionate amount spent.
SMEs' top concern for the year ahead is the rising global interest rates, according to a DBS survey released on Mar 20.

site_title: Where have all the fine diners gone?
summary: Fine dining restaurants in Singapore are experiencing a shift after a strong post-Covid rebound. Despite a softening economy, inflation, and outbound travel, many Michelin-starred restaurants now have shorter waiting lists and are able to accommodate bookings for lunch and dinner within a few days. Diners have become more selective about spending their money, leading to a change in dining sentiments. This change is expected to impact the fine dining scene in Singapore, a gourmet hub in Asia.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones falling 92.46 points, or 0.27%, to 34,206.66, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The drop was attributed to hawkish commentary from Federal Reserve officials. However, PayPal rose after agreeing to sell part of its European buy-now, pay-later loans.

site_title: Bitcoin jumps to US$28,000 on boost from BlackRock ETF filing
summary: Bitcoin surged to a two-week high of $28,142 after BlackRock filed for a spot Bitcoin ETF with the Securities and Exchange Commission, boosting the largest digital asset by 5.3% and adding 9% to its value since the filing. The move is seen as a significant development in the sector, with traditional incumbents such as Citadel Securities and Fidelity Digital Assets launching new crypto exchanges and Deutsche Bank applying for regulatory permission to operate a custody service.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The BlackRock logo is pictured outside their headquarters in the Manhattan borough of New York City, New York, U.S., May 25, 2021.  REUTERS/Carlo Allegri/File Photo

site_title: Premium car COE prices hit record high of S$121,000, other categories remain largely stable
summary: COE prices for June's second round of bidding showed mixed results across categories, with Category B hitting a record high of S$121,000. Category A prices fell 1.8% to S$96,206, while Category C prices rose 1.6% to S$83,140. Category D prices decreased 2.7% to S$10,709, and Category E increased 1.8% to S$123,000. Industry experts attributed the surge in Category B prices to continued demand for luxury cars, with some speculating that a relatively high Prevailing Quota Premium could be a contributing factor.

images.alt_text: A Grab delivery rider with Foodpanda thermal bag on his motorcycle in Singapore.

site_title: Saudi Arabia’s PIF leads bidding for US$2.5 billion Vale base metals stake
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) is leading the bidding for a $2.5 billion stake in Vale's base metals unit, with a potential 10% holding. The deal is part of PIF's efforts to diversify Saudi Arabia's economy and secure access to strategic minerals. PIF is in advanced discussions with Vale and may complete the deal through a joint venture with Saudi Arabian state miner Maaden, beating out rival bidders including Mitsui and the Qatar Investment Authority. A formal agreement could take several weeks to finalize.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - A picture taken on April 19, 2023, shows an aerial view of the Sossego copper mine, explored by Brazilian mining company VALE, in Canaa dos Carajas, Para state, Brazil. - Canaa dos Carajas is a small city at the edge of the Brazilian Amazon that has become a boom town in recent years thanks to mining. Canaa is a place of extremes: At one end of the spectrum sits mining giant Vale, which runs one of the world's biggest open-air mines here and has made the city the richest in Brazil in 2020 in GDP per capita. At the other end are an estimated 100 illegal mines where "garimpeiros," illegal miners, make a living digging holes in the earth, living on constant alert in case of a raid. (Photo by Nelson ALMEIDA / AFP)

site_title: Malaysia-born designer slaying it in fashion world with royal and celebrity fans
summary: Malaysian-born designer Han Chong's London-based label Self-Portrait has achieved significant success, with royal and celebrity fans such as Kate Middleton, Meghan Markle, and Beyonce. Chong's designs are characterized by ultra-feminine and flattering styles, and he attributes his success to his ability to balance style and business sense. He has expanded his brand globally, opening stores in Asia and Europe, and has seen year-on-year sales double annually since 2020. Chong has also diversified his brand, introducing children's lines and handbags, and has successfully funded himself after just six months of business.

site_title: Luxury F&B faces fallout as rich diners stay away
summary: Luxury fine dining in Singapore is experiencing a downturn as wealthy diners become more selective about spending due to rising inflation, a softening economy, and travel restrictions. Despite Michelin-starred restaurants and popularity, many establishments are struggling to fill seats, with some closing down, such as Basque Kitchen by Aitor and Corner House. Japanese restaurants, which were once popular, are also feeling the strain from intense competition. Weaker restaurants are seeing a 30% drop in business, particularly in the high-end segment, as customers allocate more disposable income to traveling overseas.

images.alt_text: Getting a second Michelin star helped to boost business at Cloudstreet.

site_title: MAS fines DBS, OCBC, Citi, Swiss Life for money-laundering rule breaches uncovered in Wirecard probe
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) fined four financial institutions - DBS, OCBC, Citi, and Swiss Life - a total of S$3.8 million for breaching anti-money laundering and countering the financing of terrorism (AML/CFT) requirements. The breaches were identified during MAS's examinations following news of irregularities in Wirecard's financial statements. DBS was fined the largest amount, S$2.6 million, for failing to maintain due diligence information and update risk ratings. The institutions have accepted the penalties and taken remedial actions to address the deficiencies identified.

images.alt_text: This is the first Wirecard-related conviction in Singapore and globally.
In the wake of the accounting scandal around German payments company Wirecard, auditors have turned cautious and become much more selective, scrutinising potential clients much more closely.
CoAssets in the crosshairs of MAS, CAD on 'suspected misconduct'
German prosecutor looking into regulator's handling of Wirecard

site_title: Neighbourhood Spanish cooking at Barrio
summary: Barrio, a casual Spanish eatery in Hillcrest, Singapore, has received mixed reviews. The restaurant's interiors are cheaply done, with a cheerfully unkempt atmosphere. Food-wise, dishes such as jamon iberico croquetas, pork belly pintxos, and seafood paella are basic and priced lower than their counterparts at the parent restaurant, Kulto. The service is impersonal, with a prickly host and inconsistent server quality. Despite this, the restaurant has attracted a loyal neighbourhood crowd who appreciate the affordable prices and lively atmosphere. Rating: 5.5.

images.alt_text: Poise's quietly luxurious interiors.

site_title: Getting drunk on Drops of God
summary: A French-Japanese TV drama "Drops of God" is based on the popular manga of the same name, which has had a significant impact on the wine industry in Asia. The manga caused wine sales to soar among young Asians, with some vineyards experiencing a 130% rise in sales in Japan and a similar boom in South Korea, China, and Taiwan. The TV adaptation, now available on Apple TV+, follows a French woman as she competes in a high-stakes wine-tasting test to inherit her late father's wine collection. The show features a transnational storyline, showcasing the art of wine appreciation and highlighting lesser-known vineyards.

images.alt_text:
